HEADLINE: Bank Yields Off Slightly

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit moved lower for the week ended today, according to the Bank Rate Monitor. But analysts at the publication said the shallow decline this week could indicate that the banks did not share the expectation of other financial sectors that the Federal Reserve would move to lower rates again.
"The numbers over the last six months show that the Fed has the latitude to change," said Robert K. Heady, the publisher of The Monitor, which focuses on interest rates. 
 At Monday's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, which many analysts regard as a good barometer of what many banks might pay depositors in the weeks ahead, the average discount rates fell smartly this week.
The average rate on a three-month bill was 3.59 percent, down 8 basis points from the previous auction, while the six-month bill was down 11 basis points, to 3.66 percent.
New York area banks overall were again off slightly, with a money market account down 2 basis points, to 3.34 percent, and three-month certificates of deposit and six-month certificates unchanged at 3.49 percent and 3.64 percent, repectively.
Commercial banks lowered the average money market account by 5 basis points, to 3.09 percent, and the average yield of a three-month C.D. down a basis point, to 3.33 percent, and a six-month certificate 2 basis points, to 3.41 percent.
The higher-paying savings banks for the most part did not cut their money market accounts, now at 3.59 percent, moving up the yield on three- month C.D.'s by 2 basis points, to 3.66 percent, while leaving their six-month C.D. unchanged at 3.86 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Olympia & York, the troubled Canadian developer, is expected to disclose today that the value of its real estate assets fell by as much as $4 billion in Canadian currency in 1991. [Page D1.]
The publishing world was stunned by the news that Tina Brown, editor of Vanity Fair magazine, would replace Robert A. Gottlieb as editor of The New Yorker. [A1.] 
 Ross Perot asserted that Citibank, the nation's largest bank, was insolvent, a charge quickly rejected by regulators. [D1.]
Hughes Aircraft will lay off 9,000 employees largely because of the rapid decline in Pentagon spending. [D1.]
Equifax agreed to major changes in its procedure for maintaining credit reports on millions of individuals. [D3.]
Alcoa is eliminating 2,100 jobs to increase efficiency and will take a $40.6 million second-quarter charge. [D3.] In a new twist to the provisions of the Clean Air Act, Alcoa will sell air-pollution rights to a utility. [D3.]
Fiat said 1991 profits fell 39 percent, to the lowest level in four years, and that more difficult times were ahead. [D3.]
Wetterau agreed to accept a lower takeover offer of $644 million from a rival supermarket company, Super Valu. [D3.]
Amoco promoted several executives in what was seen as the creation of a team of successors for the top job. [D5.]
The chairman of Aerospatiale, the French member of Airbus, will quit because he has reached retirement age. [D5.]
Subaru and its advertising agency Wieden & Kennedy made a mid-course correction in their advertising campaign. [D6.]
 
The Economy
Businesses and consumers appear to be emerging from the recession. But most are unconvinced that their woes are over. [D1.]
The leading indicators climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in May, but the sense that the recovery was slowing was not dispelled. [D2.]
Consumer confidence in the economy stopped growing in June after a three-month surge, the Conference Board reported. [D2.]
 
Iternational
American steelmakers filed trade complaints against Japan, Germany, Mexico, Canada and 17 other countries seeking steep customs fees on imports. [D2.]
The single floating exchange rate for the ruble that goes into effect today will mean still higher prices for Russians. [A7.]
 
Business and Technology
Researchers are scrambling to develop composite materials that are light and strong and can withstand high temperatures for the nation's space plane program. [D7.]
A new generation of surgical materials and techniques can help athletes heal from injuries faster. [D7.]
 
Markets
Stocks ended narrowly mixed as momentum from Monday's sharp rally waned. The Dow eased 1.34 points, to 3,318.52. [D8.]
Prices of most Treasury securities moved lower in slow trading as dealers awaited June employment data. [D15.]
Soybeans, grains and energy futures tumbled after separate reports on supplies were issued. [D16.]
The dollar rose overseas but fell at home on a lukewarm report on consumer confidence. Gold fell in New York. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Madison Avenue was divided in its assessment of the shift in editors at The New Yorker. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
Equitable Life faces a tough sell in raising $500 million through an initial public stock offering. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: The Candidate Who Would Be an Analyst

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
It was almost a throwaway line.
But at a time when the banking industry is showing signs of regaining its financial balance, Ross Perot chose to resurrect old charges that the nation's largest bank -- Citibank -- is insolvent.
Appearing Monday night on a live broadcast on ABC News, he answered a question about Japanese ownership of the Seattle Mariners baseball team by calling it an example of how the United States is "losing in international competition." Then veering into banking as an example, he noted that the largest American bank is only the 21st largest in the world, and contended that "if you ever take the third world loans that'll never be paid out, it's insolvent." While he did not identify the bank by name, only Citibank fits the bill.
 
Rejected by Regulators
 
 It was not a comment normally heard from a public official concerned with the health of the banking system and mindful of the dangers of creating undue worry among depositors. In fact, his charge of insolvency was quickly rejected by regulators. Leonora Cross, a spokeswoman for the Comptroller of the Currency, the Washington-based regulator for most of the nation's largest banks, said yesterday that "Citibank is not insolvent."
But Mr. Perot is not a public official, he is a businessman. And as an investor, he has bet over the last six months that Citicorp, the bank's parent, problems would cause its stock to fall. According to his filings with the Federal Election Commission in mid-May, Mr. Perot did not own any Citicorp stock, but did borrow more than $1 million of the banking company's stock late last year, and again on March 25, so he could sell it.
That practice, known as short selling, would produce a profit for Mr. Perot if the price of Citicorp stock declined and he was able to buy shares at a lower price than the shares he sold, but did not own. Loans of Citicorp stock to Mr. Perot were reported to the Federal Election Commission on May 18, and reported in Grant's Interest Rate Observer on June 5.
James D. Squires, a spokesman for Mr. Perot, said in a telephone interview yesterday that "as a matter of principle we are not answering any questions about the financial disclosures." He added that later in the campaign "I am sure you will hear Mr. Perot talking about the declining competitive position of American banks."
While Mr. Perot's thinking about the problems of the banking system and the measures that might improve its health remain unclear, the available information strongly suggests that as an investor, he badly misjudged the prospects of Citicorp. Since the times Mr. Perot in effect placed bets that Citicorp stock would fall, its price has risen steadily.
Citicorp closed at $21.25 yesterday, up from $10.375 on Dec. 30, 1991, when he borrowed more than $1 million worth of stock from Goldman, Sachs & Company, and $17 on March 25, when he borrowed more than $1 million of stock from Jefferies & Company.
In recent months, Wall Street has judged Citicorp far healthier than Mr. Perot did. Several banking analysts have issued positive reports about the company and the stock has risen sharply this year. The sharp rebound in its stock price has come as the company's profit outlook has improved amid cost cutting and a slowdown in the souring of loans.
Mr. Perot's comments appeared to have no impact on Citicorp or other banking company stocks yesterday.
The problem for Citicorp the last few years has not been, as Mr. Perot said, its losses on loans to less-developed countries. Those losses were recognized, and subtracted from profits in 1987 when the company added $3 billion to its reserve for losses and in 1989, when it added an additional $1 billion.
Instead, the problem has recently been losses on commercial real estate, where 25 percent of Citicorp's $12.3 billion of loans were delinquent or not expected to be repaid in full and it held an additional $2.3 billion of real estate from foreclosed loans.
Assertions that Citibank and other large banks were insolvent were made occasionally in 1990 and 1991 as the industry's losses on commercial real estate loans led to comparisons with the savings and loan industry. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, echoed those contentions last July.
While the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has suffered heavy losses from bank failures in recent years, the banking system as a whole has fared far better than savings and loans because it had far more capital to absorb losses. Regulators forced banks beginning in 1989 to tighten lending standards that were too lax earlier in the decade.
The insolvency assertions are based primarily on contentions that bank accounting rules conceal the true deterioration of a bank's financial condition. While it is true that loans to businesses and consumers are not carried on a bank's books at the price they might be sold in the open market, regulators and many accountants say that fire-sale prices are not a fair way to evaluate loans that are delinquent or in trouble. Instead, they say that the losses a bank will incur on bad loans are reflected in the sums that banks subtract from their profits and add to their reserve for loan losses, or in the amounts by which banks write off as a loss all or part of a bad loan.
Even assuming that Citicorp has underestimated its losses on loans, analysts say, the company is far from insolvent. James Rosenberg, a banking analyst at Shearson, Lehman Brothers, said in a recent study that even if Citicorp suffered losses on risky loans much greater than the company has already admitted, it would still be solvent, with shareholders capital of $4.2 billion plus $2.3 billion more of preferred stock. That is not a thick cushion for a $216.9 billion company, but it is a cushion analysts expect will increase as Citicorp sells more nonessential businesses, cuts expenses and earns profits. After losing $457 million last year, Citicorp earned a profit of $183 million in the first quarter.
Banking specialists said that ranking banks by size understates the role American banks play in global financial markets. In the United States, 12,000 banks share the market while in other countries, like Japan, the market is far more concentrated and is dominated by just a few dozen banks.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chairman Retires at France's Aerospatiale

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 30

 BODY:
The chairman of Aerospatiale of France, one of the two main participants in the European aerospace consortium Airbus Industrie, stepped down today, the company announced.
Henri Martre led state-owned Aerospatiale to a prominent position in the world aerospace industry and fiercely defended Airbus against American criticism. He will be 65 years old next year, the retirement age for executives in state companies. 
 A spokeswoman for Aerospatiale said Mr. Martre would be replaced by Louis Gallois, the 48-year-old chairman of Snecma, a state-owned jet-engine maker.
Analysts said there was no reason to believe that factors other than age had played a part in Mr. Martre's replacement. They said his direction of the company had been highly successful.
The change comes as the protracted dispute between the United States and Airbus appears to have reached a tentative resolution. Aerospatiale and Deutsche Airbus of Germany, a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., each own about 38 percent of Airbus; the remainder is owned by British Aerospace P.L.C., which holds about 20 percent, and CASA of Spain, which owns 4 percent.
In April, officials said the dispute, centering on American accusations that Airbus had an unfair competitive advantage because it receives government subsidies, was settled. The agreement, however, has not been ratified, but an American economic official in Paris said: "Things are still going in the right direction."
Throughout the dispute, Mr. Martre, who has headed Aerospatiale for a decade, argued vigorously that American aerospace companies like Boeing were indirectly subsidized by orders from the Pentagon and the space program and were engaged in a thinly veiled attempt to thwart a European upstart in an industry they had long dominated.
Analysts said Mr. Gallois, who held senior posts in the Defense and Industry ministries before joining Snecma, was unlikely to change substantially the policy or direction of Aerospatiale.
He will, however, face a consolidation in the European aerospace industry and crucial decisions on Aerospatiale's future alliances. The Dutch aerospace manufacturer Fokker N.V. is among the companies in which Aerospatiale has recently shown an interest.

HEADLINE: Hughes to Cut 9,000 Workers And Write Off $789.4 Million

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 30

 BODY:
The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it would lay off 9,000 employees, or about 15 percent of its work force, largely because of the rapid decline in Pentagon spending.
The layoffs will come primarily in Southern California, where Hughes is the largest industrial employer, and will be spread over the next 18 months, company officials said. 
 Many of the job cuts will come at the managerial and supervisory levels, company executives said, including half the staff of 1,050 at corporate headquarters here.
The cuts are another jolt to California's economy, which is suffering its worst recession since the 1930's, in part because of widespread job losses in the military-contracting industry. In the Los Angeles area alone, employment in the aerospace industry has declined by nearly a third in the last six years, to about 200,000.
Hughes is the Pentagon's leading supplier of military electronics, and the job cutbacks stand in sharp contrast to the common wisdom that electronics companies would weather the cutbacks in weapons programs far better than manufacturers of airplanes, tanks and ships.
Hughes said it would also close buildings or entire plants at 92 sites in California and other states.
"This is the result of an industry that went into precipitous decline because of the breakup of the Soviet Union," said C. Michael Armstrong, the former I.B.M. executive who became chairman and chief executive of Hughes three months ago.
"Today the budget has been dramatically slashed," he said. "Programs have been canceled and others significantly delayed. The effect on this industry has been to force it to adjust."
Hughes has been reducing employment for five years, largely through an early-retirement program and attrition, but has never before undertaken such large-scale layoffs. It expects its work force to be about 50,000 people at the end of next year, from a current level of 60,000. The company's employment peaked six years ago at 82,100.
 
Taking $789.4 Million in Charges
 To pay for the layoffs and the plant consolidations, Hughes said it would take an after-tax charge against earnings of $749.4 million for the second quarter, which ended today. Hughes said it would also take a separate after-tax charge of $40 million in the quarter to reflect a change in the way it accounts for sales in some of its commercial businesses.
Hughes is a unit of the G.M. Hughes Electronics Corporation, which is controlled by General Motors. In last year's second quarter, G.M. Hughes earned $83.4 million, or 29 cents a share.
Most major military contractors have been slashing employment for years. But Hughes's action today, which it said was based on the assumption that Pentagon procurement budgets would decline 5 percent a year through much of the decade, suggested that the industrywide contraction would continue.
 
Further Review of Operations
 Mr. Armstrong said Hughes would continue to review its operations and possibly sell or close those that it no longer considered good investments. He said, for example, that the company has put its electrical connectors business up for sale and that several companies have expressed interest in buying it.
The layoffs, the consolidation of the plants and the sale or closure of noncore businesses, Mr. Armstrong said, would allow Hughes to invest in those areas where it believes its business can grow.
The plan should ultimately save Hughes $700 million a year in operating costs, executives said.
"We believe we will have established, among those markets we have selected to serve, a much more competitive Hughes," Mr. Armstrong said at a news conference.
Shares in G.M. Hughes, which trades as G.M. Class H stock, have risen sharply in recent weeks, apparently in anticipation of the cost-cutting moves. The stock closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $25.875, up 50 cents.
To cope with the decline in its military business, Hughes has been pushing into commercial technologies, including telecommunications networks and satellites and a host of smaller ventures. About 65 percent of the company's sales now come from the Government, down from 85 percent several years ago.
The hiring of Mr. Armstrong from the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this year clearly reflected the company's strategy of trying to become a more broadly based technology company.
But Mr. Armstrong reiterated today that Hughes had no intention of abandoning the military business, saying he believed the company could increase its market share and profits in selected types of programs.
Hughes, in fact, is in the process of acquiring the General Dynamics Corporation's missile business and its 9,000 employees.

HEADLINE: For Japanese, 'Shared Values' in U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 30

 BODY:
In the six months since President Bush's ill-fated trade mission to Japan, Washington and Tokyo have made little progress on the major economic issues that turned the visit into one of the bitterest encounters between the two countries in years.
Yet when Kiichi Miyazawa arrives on Wednesday afternoon for his first official White House visit as Prime Minister, no one expects the discussion to dwell on Japan's swelling trade surpluses, its automotive imports or the depth of either country's commitment to fundamental economic reform. 
 With both leaders facing difficult election campaigns, American and Japanese officials say they hope to move the focus to "shared values" and "mutual dependence," much as they originally planned for the President's trip in January before everything -- including Mr. Bush's stomach -- went awry.
"We don't want to repeat what happened in January," one of Mr. Miyazawa's closest foreign policy advisers said on Monday. "I can't imagine the White House does either."
Mr. Miyazawa will be arriving with a plan for the Japanese Government to spend $47 billion to $55 billion on a package to stimulate the country's lagging economy and, in theory at least, to increase its imports.
 
Aid to Russia Indicated
 Japanese officials also hint that Mr. Miyazawa will arrive in Washington, and next Monday in Munich at the summit meeting of seven large industrial nations, with a significantly greater willingness to aid Russia than Japan has shown anytime in the past.
Last month Helmut Kohl, Germany's Chancellor, charged that Japan's refusal to provide large-scale aid to Russia was threatening President Boris N. Yeltsin's efforts to transform the country into a market economy.
Japanese officials still insist, as they have at past summit meetings, that any major, direct economic support must be linked to the return of four northern islands seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.
But they have also begun to say that support for Mr. Yeltsin's initiatives are a major Japanese goal, signaling a willingness to funnel new money through international lending agencies.
"We feel that the Russians are now serious about negotiating a conclusion to a peace treaty" which hinges on resolving the territorial dispute, Koichiro Matsuura, the Deputy Foreign Minister, said on Monday. "We hope that there will be some breakthrough when Yeltsin comes in September," on his first official trip to Tokyo.
For Mr. Miyazawa, the most politically problematic issue in Washington and Munich is one he is least likely to be able to control: the ballooning of Japan's trade surplus.
By some estimates, the surplus with all of Japan's trading partners will climb to roughly $125 billion this year, nearly a 25 percent increase from 1991. In recent months, its surplus with the United States has also begun to rise rapidly.
"The figures are worrisome because they showed a 50 percent increase year over year in the bilateral deficit," Michael H. Armacost, the American Ambassador to Japan, said last week. "That risks injecting this issue into election-year politics, and that would not be desirable."
But no amount of Government prompting seems likely to induce Japanese consumers to purchase more imported goods in the middle of a continuing economic downturn.
In a series of appearances in Washington over the next two days, Mr. Miyazawa is expected to argue that over the last six months Japan has made great strides in taking a larger political role in world affairs.
During the visit both sides are expected to refer again to the "Tokyo Declaration," a reaffirmation of the political and security ties between the two countries that was overshadowed by the conflicts over American automobile imports and market access during the last trip.
"We're going to try it again," one of Mr. Miyazawa's advisers said recently, hoping to demonstrate to the Japanese public that the passage of the peacekeeping bill was contributing to improved relations with the United States -- only three weeks before an election for the upper house of Parliament that many expect will be a referendum on the peacekeeping question.
Mr. Bush may also not be eager to bring up the economic problems he raised in January because progress has been slim.
During the January visit, Japanese auto makers agreed to a target of selling 20,000 more American cars in Japan annually, a figure the Detroit executives who accompanied Mr. Bush described as inadequate. It has not been raised.
In the meantime, the United States appears to have switched emphasis: The latest American trade delegation to come through Tokyo said that the major trade issue of the year is no longer cars, but computer chips.
Equally uncomfortable to discuss is the progress of the "Structural Impediments Initiative," which Mr. Bush has hailed as a landmark effort to change the fundamental problems in the American and Japanese economic systems, the ones that hurt trade and competitiveness.
One big difficulty, as many American officials concede, is that Japan has enacted several of its commitments -- such as reforming its laws to make it easier to open large stores here and to cut working hours -- much faster than the United States has come through on its commitments.
Those included cutting the budget deficit and inducing Americans to increase their rates of savings. Both are far more difficult to achieve than the Japanese actions. But America's slowness to respond, some complain, will undercut future efforts to get Japan to make hard changes of its own.

HEADLINE: PLAN TO TIGHTEN EMBARGO ON IRAQ SUGGESTED BY U.S.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Seeking to slow an increase in illicit trade with Iraq, the Bush Administration failed to win greater cooperation from King Hussein of Jordan last week to enforce the United Nations trade embargo.
Washington is now considering a broader plan to stop illegal shipments after they arrive in Iraq, Administration officials said today. 
 The intensified planning represents at attempt by the White House to increase pressure on President Saddam Hussein, during an election season in which the Iraqi's survival since the Persian Gulf war continues to be politically embarrassing to Mr. Bush. Democratic criticism of Mr. Bush's handling of Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait has already tarnished the allies' victory in the war as a campaign asset for the President.
 
The Leaky Embargo
 In recent weeks, United States intelligence estimates have concluded that Mr. Hussein is strengthening his position in Baghdad with the help of an ever higher volume of critical supplies and other goods entering Iraq from Jordan, in violation of the 22-month-old trade embargo.
A recent National Intelligence Estimate said that up to 30 percent of the cargo crossing into Iraq from Jordan violates the trade embargo.
As a result, the White House last week dispatched the Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, to Jordan to press for King Hussein's cooperation in placing United Nations inspectors at the Red Sea port of Aqaba to turn back Iraq-bound cargo, Administration officials said.
 
Jordan Changes Direction
 A senior Administration official said Jordanian officials were presented with "evidence about sanctions violations that originated in Jordan and their significance for Iraq's economy."
"We essentially made the case for a strengthened United Nations regime," the official continued. "At the end of the day it was no sale -- the Jordanians felt they couldn't go along."
Jordan's position contrasted with its cooperation in the fall of 1990, when United States embassy personnel in Jordan were allowed to take up positions on the border crossing with Iraq, where they lifted the tarpaulins covering Iraq-bound trucks to affirm Jordan's compliance with the embargo.
Mr. Gates' trip was not announced in advance, but news of his presence in Amman leaked out. C.I.A. officials would not discuss the trip today.
The senior Administration official, acknowledging the failure of the diplomatic mission, said: "In the wake of that, we are in the process of thinking what our options are in this particular hole in the sanctions net. No decisions have been made."
 
Would Search Trucks
 But other Administration officials said the White House was preparing a plan under which United Nations policemen inside Iraq would search the hundreds of trucks that enter from Jordan every week. Food and medicine would be passed; items banned by the embargo -- virtually all other goods -- would be turned back.
Administration officials said the plan would draw on the authority of existing United Nations resolutions and would not require Jordan's cooperation. The inspectors could be drawn from the United Nations personnel in Iraq to search for weapons of mass destruction and monitor Iraq's compliance with other aspects of the cease-fire resolution that ended the gulf war 16 months ago.
The plan is to be reviewed Wednesday at the White House by senior deputies from major Government agencies. Officials also said three key allies, Britain, Turkey and Saudi Arabia, were briefed today on a proposed notification to Baghdad stating that United Nations personnel in Iraq could begin enforcing the embargo.
Administration officials acknowledged that there was an element of brinkmanship, since the plan would involve interference with vehicles on Iraqi soil and could prove both embarrassing and provocative to Iraq.
 
U.N. Tenacity
 As an added element of urgency, the United Nations today press Baghdad to renew a "memorandum of understanding" covering the presence of 1,100 United Nations personnel in Iraq, including 500 armed guards in northern Iraq. The current agreement on protection of the United Nations personnel and their access to all parts of Iraq expires midnight tonight.
United States officials indicated that there was support among members of the Security Council to maintain the United Nations presence in Iraq, regardless whether Baghdad renewed the agreement.
Up to now, a multinational naval force in the Red Sea has been intercepting ships bound for Aqaba, Jordan, to stop illicit shipments to Iraq. But these forces have been powerless to stop cargo labeled as bound for Jordan, but which is later trucked to Iraq.
In his meetings with Mr. Gates, King Hussein was said to have objected to any public cooperation with the effort to choke off supplies to Baghdad, but he pledged a willingness to cooperate in other unspecified covert actions aimed at destabilizing the Iraqi leader.
 
Two-Track Attack
 Testifying today before the Europe and Middle East Subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Edward P. Djerejian, Assistant Secretary of State for Middle Eastern Affairs, referred to the talks in Jordan.
"They said they could not implement certain arrangements which would involve outside observers," he said.
Asked what steps the Administration was considering to "ratchet up the pressure" on Iraq, Mr. Djerejian replied, "I can't discuss that in open session."
The United States has been engaged in a two-track policy against Iraq.
One emphasizes the trade embargo and inspections to force Iraq to destroy weapons of mass destruction and war-making industries.
The second track, authorized by a series of secret Presidential findings by Mr. Bush, emphasizes covert steps by the C.I.A. and Pentagon to build an Iraqi opposition capable of fomenting a coup that could topple Mr. Hussein and perhaps receive the backing of allied military forces.
 
The Oil Issue
 King Hussein's stance appears to be driven by domestic politics, as well as by economic fears that Iraq would cut off oil supplies. Iraq sends more than 60,000 barrels of crude oil a day to Jordan in truck tankers that traverse the same desert highway that supplies Baghdad. This oil meets most of the needs of Jordan's severely stressed economy, and has been overlooked by the United Nations commission enforcing the embargo.

HEADLINE: Amendments Stall Gun-Control Measure in Hartford Senate

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 30

 BODY:
A special session of the General Assembly that was expected to act swiftly on a package of gun-control laws has instead turned into a complicated political minuet.
On Monday, after almost 10 hours of debate, the House of Representatives passed a pair of bills that had been vastly transformed from the original proposals. 
 The package moved to the Senate late today, where the bills passed, but the fate of one of them became uncertain after a key amendment, banning the sale of cheap hanguns known as Saturday night specials, was defeated.
At the same time, the Senate approved an amendment that would make it easier to apply the death penalty, a combination that one of the bill's sponsors, Senator George Jepsen, a Democrat from Stamford, said would prove deadly because Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. opposed the death penalty and was likely to veto the measure.
"If the death penalty stays on it, without the handgun ban, it's in big trouble," Mr. Jepsen said before the vote. That bill, which makes it a felony to sell or otherwise provide firearms to juveniles, now goes back to the House, which returns to Hartford on Monday.
"It's very disappointing," Mr. Jepsen said. "One problem when you're dealing with a special session is that time is very limited." He said he would try to bring back the measure in the regular session.
Governor Weicker, who called the special session to consider gun control only, had proposed two modest measures intended to inhibit the flow of guns into the hands of juveniles. Those bills would have made it a felony to sell a gun to anyone under 18, and would have penalized people who carried guns within 1,500 feet of a school, with exceptions made for permit-holders, police officers and a few others.
 
Sense of Frustration
 Enthusiasts of stricter curbs added amendments to outlaw Saturday night specials and assault weapons. The former squeaked through the House by a handful of votes Monday night; the latter was defeated. But opponents of gun control won an amendment in the House that would make it easier to impose the death penalty, setting the stage for a likely veto.
In response to reporters' questions this morning, Mr. Weicker said he was still hopeful that gun-control measures of some kind would become law.
"I'll have to see what develops in terms of the final package," he said. "But I've got great optimism that everybody is doing the Lord's work here in terms of trying to get something that will be meaningful in stopping the violence."
The mood in both houses of the General Assembly seemed to be one of frustration as the battle's focus shifted from public safety to political gamesmanship.
 
Debate Reflects Division
 With Connecticut reeling from the recession, some legislators said they were concerned that certain measures, like the ban on Saturday night specials, might harm the state's gun manufacturers. "This is a terrible amendment," said Representative Angelo M. Fusco, a Republican from Plantsville, during debate on the issue. "It doesn't really doesn't do anything except harass Connecticut businesses that make some of the higher-priced weapons that fall into the Saturday night special category."
Others disagreed, saying that the amendment was aimed at cheap versions of those weapons that are churned out by factories owned by companies in other states.
The debate over gun control reflected the divisions in the Legislature between representatives from the state's beleaguered cities, like Bridgeport, New Haven and Hartford, and those from quiet suburbs like Farmington and Bethlehem.
"This is like banning Model T's," said Representative William R. Dyson, a veteran Democrat from New Haven. "You're hearing from people who may not care, because they're not being shot at in their towns."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Tongues Wag Over Shift at New Yorker

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE Talk of the Town, and all the other features of The New Yorker, were the talk of the avenue -- Madison Avenue, that is -- in the wake of the unexpected changes in editors that S. I. Newhouse Jr. made yesterday at that venerable weekly magazine and at his glitzy monthly, Vanity Fair.
Mr. Newhouse, chairman of the magazines' parent companies, named Tina Brown, the Vanity Fair editor in chief since 1984, to replace Robert Gottlieb as editor in chief of The New Yorker, a post he had held for five years. Graydon Carter, editor of The New York Observer, will succeed Ms. Brown at Vanity Fair. 
 Rarely has such a significant shift taken advertising and publishing executives so much by surprise. And rarely has opinion been so divided on what the moves might mean for the economic health of the magazines involved.
Some are thrilled; some are aghast; some are skeptical, concerned that The New Yorker could lose its distinctive cachet in seeking to woo reluctant advertisers.
"She is going to revitalize the magazine," Claude Fromm, executive vice president and media director at TBWA Advertising in New York, said of Ms. Brown.
Roberta Garfinkle, senior vice president and director of print media at McCann-Erickson New York, said: "From the advertiser point of view, the thinking has been that The New Yorker represents 'stodgy.' If her mission is to spruce it up, to bring it into the 90's without radically changing it, I can't wait." But, she added, she would be disappointed if Ms. Brown made "a more drastic change."
Steve Klein, media director at Kirshenbaum & Bond in New York, called The New Yorker under Mr. Gottlieb "a tremendous editorial product," and worried that the weekly might not "continue to be what it is."
"As a reader, I'm upset," he added of Ms. Brown's arrival, due in the fall. "As an advertiser, I don't know what to think."
Even blunter was John R. (Rick) MacArthur, president and publisher of Harper's Magazine in New York.
"It's the triumph of sleaze and salesmanship over quality," he said. "The idea of the editor of Vanity Fair being made editor of The New Yorker is like moving Trump Tower to the middle of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden."
He added that Ms. Brown's status as "the hottest editor on Madison Avenue," referring to Vanity Fair's strong gains in advertising pages since her arrival, was the sole reason Mr. Newhouse tapped her for The New Yorker.
"Now he's got an editor who can sell," Mr. MacArthur continued. "This is evidence of the ultimate sort of pandering. It's very depressing."
Ms. Brown, like her namesake Helen Gurley Brown, editor in chief of Hearst Magazines' Cosmopolitan, is known for her involvement in publishing-side matters. For example, the designer Calvin Klein was about to run his 116-page jeans ad supplement in Rolling Stone last fall, publishing executives say, when Ms. Brown persuaded him to switch to Vanity Fair.
She is also outspoken. She said she would have rejected a controversial Benetton ad that Vanity Fair ran this year, showing an AIDS patient at the moment he died.
Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive of The New Yorker, said that Ms. Brown, whom he praised as "the right person for the job," would be involved in functions like luncheons for advertisers.
But, he added, an incident like the courting of Calvin Klein "won't happen here, because this is a different place with different customs."
"I hate to sound precious," he added, "but this is a class act. She will never compromise the product. She will only enrich it."
Mr. Florio, who has seen The New Yorker through tough and flush times in the seven years since Mr. Newhouse purchased it for $168 million, is eager for Ms. Brown to arrive.
"She doesn't know this," he said, "but a salesperson came in to me and said, 'I've been working on the Banana Republic for three years and they called to say they heard, it's great news, and "We're in." ' "
The New Yorker's ad pages, which topped 4,300 as recently as 1981, according to the Publishers Information Bureau in New York, fell fairly steadily through the rest of the decade, then rose in 1989 and 1990 only to plunge 18.5 percent last year, to 2,001.
Contributing to the declines were intense competition for its affluent, well-educated readers from publications as diverse as Interview, Connoisseur and Vanity Fair, as well as the recession and, most recently, the Persian Gulf war, which crippled its mainstay category, travel advertising.
So far this year, though, results have improved; ad pages through May totaled 673.4, up 5.1 percent from a year earlier. Mr. Klein of Kirschenbaum noted that The New Yorker continues to enjoy one of the highest subcriber renewal rates in the industry. The median age of The New Yorker's readers, according to the 1991 Simmons Market Research Bureau study, is 43.6, compared with 33.6 for Vanity Fair, while the median household income stood at $56,061, compared with $44,560.
At Vanity Fair, ad pages soared as Ms. Brown transformed a moribund literary magazine that Mr. Newhouse had come close to closing into a sprightly potpourri of celebrity covers, star- and society-focused articles and occasional investigative journalism.
Since 1989, ad pages have remained steady in the high 1,400's, a performance that Ron Galotti, the publisher, said "has been unbelievable in this economy" and compared favorably with steep declines at rival monthlies. Through May, ad pages resumed their climb, rising 10.3 percent from the first five months of 1991.
Mr. Galotti added that Mr. Carter faced a "fantastic" challenge at Vanity Fair, but that he would benefit from the monthly's "position of strength" in the market.

HEADLINE: Economic Indicators Rise But Recovery Still Sputters

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The Commerce Department index designed to forecast the economy climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in May, its fifth straight advance and the largest since February.
But the moderate rise in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators was seen by most analysts as exaggerating the economy's prospects and doing nothing to dispel the growing sense that an already weak recovery is losing momentum. Recent reports have shown declines for home sales and orders for durable manufactured goods amid higher first-time claims for jobless benefits. 
 "I'm not too optimistic about where this economy is going," commented Richard D. C. Trainer, chief economist for the Bank of Tokyo in New York. "The recovery now is extremely fragile."
Analysts also noted that the index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current activity, was unchanged in May. It has now failed to rise for three straight months and is at the same level as December.
 
Other Reports Also Weak
 Meanwhile, the Conference Board reported today that its consumer confidence index stopped improving in June following three sharp increases. And purchasing managers in Chicago showed a slight improvement but ordering fell in Milwaukee.
This batch of figures came as the policy makers at the Federal Reserve began a two-day meeting to plot a course for the next seven weeks. Most analysts seem to believe the Fed, its credibility on the line because of Adminstration pleas to cut rates again, will decide against doing so unless Thursday's Labor Department report on the June job market is particularly weak.
One reason for negative interpretation of the widely anticipated six-tenths of 1 percent rise in the leading index was that six components fell while only five rose, observed Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist for A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
And some that rose were disparaged because they were seen as reflecting weakness -- a longer workweek, for example, being preferred to hiring new employees -- or have been subsequently reversed, as in the case of the stock market.
 
Breakdown of Components
 The biggest contributor to the rise was higher prices for materials that are especially sensitive to the business cycle, a volatile series that some analysts thought might be mere random fluctuation. The others were a rising proportion of companies experiencing slower deliveries from suppliers, higher stock prices and higher consumer expectations.
The components that fell, all of them just marginally, reflected lower new factory orders for consumer goods and materials, declining M-2 money supply, fewer contracts and orders for plant and equipment, a decline in unfilled orders for durable goods, lower building permits and rising first-time unemployment claims.
"Ouch!" exclaimed William C. Dunkelberg, chief economist for the National Federation of Independent Business. He added that his group's own predictive indicator moved sideways in May after four monthly gains but he nevertheless contended that the economy shows more substance now than a year ago, when a spring surge turned into a second-half swoon.
The department's index of lagging indicators, those that tend to turn only after the economy at large, dropped in May for the 16th month in a row. The 1.2 percent fall was the biggest since January.
Among private-sector forecasting indexes, the one compiled by Safian Investment Research of White Plains gained two-tenths of 1 percent in May, with 14 of 24 components moving up.
But Herzog, Heine, Geduld reported that its index slipped to a reading of plus 142 from plus 145, the first decline in seven months.
David B. Bostian Jr. called this result a possible cautionary sign that may reflect deferral of business decisions because of uncertainty about this fall's elections.

HEADLINE: U.S. Steelmakers Seek Steep Fees on Imports

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
American steel producers filed 84 trade complaints today against Japan, Canada, Mexico, Germany and 17 other countries, seeking steep customs fees on imports.
The filing of the complaints, which coincided with the arrival in Washington of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan, is new poison for the nation's already-difficult trade relations with important allies abroad. European, Canadian and Japanese officials warned that the cases would heighten tensions already raised by disputes over trade in soybeans, lumber and mini-vans. 
 "It's going to put further strain on an already strained relationship," a senior Canadian official told reporters on Monday.
Ella Krucoff, a spokeswoman for the European Community's Washington office, criticized the trade cases as "uncalled-for economic harassment and deeply disturbing to the steel trade."
The rising number of trade conflicts, coupled with European Community disarray over whether to create a single currency and central bank, has paralyzed 108-nation negotiations in Geneva to reduce international trade barriers. The disputes have also eroded support, especially in Canada, for a free-trade agreement in North America.
Japanese companies, which have spent $3.5 billion on large shareholdings and joint ventures with all six big steel companies in the United States, campaigned for their shipments to be excluded from today's cases. Senior Japanese steel executives held a series of secret meetings with their American counterparts in the unsuccessful effort, people involved in the steel cases said.
The Japanese steel industry responded indignantly to their inclusion in today's cases. "Having shown cooperation and support in both trade and investment, we are astonished that these efforts are being totally ignored by U.S. industry," said Yoshitaka Fujitani, the president of NKK America Inc., a subsidiary of the Tokyo-based NKK Corporation.
Yet in an extraordinary sign of both the extent and the limits of foreign investors' influence in the United States, four of the nation's six leading steel companies did not join the complaints against Japan, but filed against other countries. They are LTV, Inland Steel, Armco and National Steel.
But these companies did agree not to oppose the complaint outright, which would have considerably weakened the American steelmakers' case. Bethlehem Steel, USX and six small steel companies did file the petitions against Japan. The small steel companies joined the case in the last week, a person involved in the case said.
The complaints ask the Commerce Department to impose up to $1 billion in duties on flat-rolled steel imports that totaled $2.5 billion last year.
To win their cases, the big American steelmakers must convince the Commerce Department that foreign producers are either exporting steel below cost or are receiving government subsidies. They must also prove to the International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency, that they are in commercial trouble and that unfair imports are at least partly responsible.
Robert W. Crandall, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said the International Trade Commission could be hard to convince. He added that domestic competition from companies that recycle scrap metal into steel might prevent the big steel companies from raising prices even with import duties.
Some foreign steelmakers vowed today to retaliate. Donald K. Belch, the director of government relations at Stelco Inc., in Hamilton, Ontario, said that Canadian steel producers would file similar trade complaints against imports from the United States "almost immediately -- they are already prepared."

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Slips, Reversing 3-Month Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Consumer confidence in the economy stopped growing in June after a three-month surge, the Conference Board reported yesterday, in a widely followed survey that reflected the fragility of the recovery.
Economists expressed concern about the finding by the business research group because it suggested that consumers are turning more cautious about spending and borrowing money. Consumers account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and are the driving force behind recovery and expansion. 
 "The growth rate of the economy in this recovery is still quite feeble as compared to most other recession-recovery episodes," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.
The group's consumer confidence index, which chronicles consumer levels of financial security on a monthly basis, registered 71.7 in June, barely changed from the revised 71.9 reading in May.
The index, calculated on a 1985 base of 100, is derived from answers to questionnaires sent to 5,000 households nationwide, covering topics like personal spending plans, the job outlook and business conditions for the next six months.
The June reading followed a rise of more than 24 points in the index from February to May, which had been considered an important sign that consumers were growing more confident about their finances.
The news came as the Commerce Department reported its main economic barometer rose for the fifth straight month in May. But the advance was modest and economists saw no inconsistency in the numbers.
Release of the consumer confidence survey also coincided with a meeting of the Federal Reserve Board committee that charts monetary policy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fiat Reports 39% Decline In Earnings

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TURIN, Italy, June 30

 BODY:
Fiat S.p.A., the Italian automobile and industrial giant, said today that 1991 profits fell 39 percent, to the lowest level in four years.
The 90-year-old company forecast a continued squeeze as it pursues a $40 billion program to modernize production and update aging car designs. 
 Profits last year of 871 billion lire, about $720 million, were down from a 1990 profit of 1.417 trillion lire. Sales were 56.488 trillion lire, or about $48 billion, compared with sales of 57.209 trillion lire in 1990.
Company executives attributed the drop in part to high production costs in Italy and to the global economic slowdown. They also cited losses from Fiat's 1990 takeover of Ford New Holland, a Ford Motor Company unit that made agricultural machinery and tractors, which is now merged with Fiat's Geotech.
Fiat executives said the new company, called N. H. Geotech, lost $300 million last year and $120 million in the first six months of this year. Moreover, Fiat plans to spend up to $500 million more to recapitalize the new company this year.
But Fiat's chief executive, Cesare Romiti, said at a news conference today that Fiat also planned to close plants and cut jobs at the new company. It was not clear whether this would affect operations in the United States.
Fiat's acquisition of the tractor concern reflected a policy to consolidate strategic divisions to seek market dominance while shedding nonstrategic units to help finance the company's plans through 1996.
Under that policy, Fiat last year acquired both Ford New Holland and Spain's biggest truck producer, Enasa Pegaso. It has also shed its controlling interest in the past two years in the Telettra Telecommunications Company, which it sold to Alcatel Alsthom of France.
Umberto Quadrino, Fiat's planning director, said the sale this year of Fiat's remaining 25 percent stake in Telettra had yielded the equivalent of $700 million with a further $200 million to be paid in installments over four years.
That money, he told reporters, with expected income from the group's many divisions, would produce a profit for 1992, although on a smaller scale than last year.
The company's 1991 results also showed that Fiat took on debt last year for the first time in almost a decade -- the equivalent of roughly $225 million. Executives said borrowing was needed because of the capital investment plan at a time of depressed markets.
Fiat's concern about its future in the European car market reflects worries that other European producers, notably Ford and Volkswagen, are encroaching on its Italian stronghold. Fiat's share of the Italian market still stands at 46 percent, but in the late 1980's it commanded 60 percent.

HEADLINE: Consumers Hesitant in the Heartland

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CENTRALIA, Ill., June 25

 BODY:
After several years of profound economic malaise, businesses and consumers in much of the country appear to be emerging, at last, from the recession. But while they say they are more hopeful than they were a few months ago, most people are by no means convinced that their woes are past.
The recovery has yet to take hold in the Northeast or in California. But in interviews in and around Salt Lake City, Omaha and here in Centralia in the last week, dozens of people provided evidence that the economic recovery remained spotty and that even in areas of relative strength, faith in the recovery was thin. Consumers and businesses hold dampened expectations and neither group is likely to shed the caution adopted over the last several years.
 
'Depends on Who You Are'
 
 "Is the recession over?" said Neenah Sabir, a social worker, as she sat having a snack at the Crossroads Mall in Omaha. "Depends on who you are. I make a fairly decent salary, but even with that there are a lot of things you have to tighten your belt for."
Yet along with such wariness are clear signs that the economy is coming fitfully back to life.
In Omaha, Wayne Atchley, a Ford dealer, said he had 15 percent more visitors to his showroom so far this year than by this point last year, and sales have returned nearly to the levels of the late 1980's.
In Salt Lake City, Todd B. Kjar, a lawyer, and his wife, Jennifer, felt confident enough about their prospects to sell their house -- they found a buyer in a single day this month -- and trade up to a more expensive home. Before they move they will buy a refrigerator, just the kind of big-ticket purchase that economists look for as signs of consumer optimism.
Here in Centralia, a rural town of 14,000 that is 60 miles east of St. Louis, a Rockwell International Corporation auto-parts plant has hired 90 employees this year. Orders from car and truck makers are picking up, several new products are selling well and the plant expects to hire 50 people in the next few months for manufacturing jobs paying $10 an hour, adding them to the factory's work force of 900.
"There are some pretty strong indicators, and we're forecasting that things will continue on that path next year," said Larry W. Garretson, the factory's director of manufacturing.
The sporadic nature of the recovery has been reflected in recent economic statistics. The Commerce Department has reported, for example, that orders for durable goods fell 2.4 percent in May after gains in the previous two months.
After the economy showed a relatively healthy gain of 2.7 percent in the first three months of the year, more recent indicators illustrate "the now familiar pattern of ragged recovery," said David Hensley, an economist with the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles. "We expect this patchwork pattern of growth to continue through the remainder of this year."
Still, many business owners and managers, and many consumers, seem to have turned a psychological corner.
 
The Garage Door Indicator
 When the economy perks up, so does Kenneth D. Martin's garage-door manufacturing business, and in the last several months Mr. Martin has seen positive signs.
With interest rates low and home sales in some parts of the country rebounding, orders for Martin Door Manufacturing's garage doors should be up 10 percent this year, compared with 5 percent last year, Mr. Martin said in an interview at the company's factory in Salt Lake City.
The recovery looks uneven, because Mr. Martin's biggest market, California, remains mired in its worst slump since the 1930's. And after several years of slashing costs, he said he did not plan to add much to the family-owned company's work force of 80 people. But Mr. Martin says he is confident that after a false start last year, the economy is moving ahead again, albeit slowly.
 
Orders Up at Rockwell Plant
 At the Rockwell plant in Centralia, sales in the second half of the company's fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, are running 10 to 15 percent ahead of the first half. Mr. Garretson said sales next year should be up another 15 to 17 percent, to about $100 million.
A little more than half the increase is being generated by new plastic auto-body parts manufactured by the plant, and the rest reflects the improved economy and stronger orders from auto makers, Mr. Garretson said.
"We went for the last year or two with our customers shutting down their production lines for a week or a week and a half every month," Mr. Garretson said. "In the last few months there haven't been any shutdown weeks."
 
'We're Real Optimistic'
 A survey done last month for the credit card company Mastercard found that small-business owners believed, by a margin of 3 to 1, that the economy was improving. And most owners said they planned to hire some additional workers this year.
At a new shopping center in the Sugar House section of Salt Lake City, the parking lot was filling with shoppers' cars the other day and employees at a bookstore were unpacking crates of books and stocking the shelves.
"We're real optimistic," said Kathleen Pelzer, one of the 30 employees recently hired by the store, Bookstar, which is owned by Barnes & Noble Bookstores. "I think this is going to be a great success."
If the store does do well, it may be because of its steeply discounted prices. Most traffic at the shopping center seemed to head for discount stores -- a Toys "R" Us; a Nordstrom Rack, a low-price closeout store run by the department store chain, and specialty stores like Payless Shoes.
"Customer purchases are very value oriented," said Jack Baker, the president of Baker's Supermarkets, a chain of 10 stores around Omaha. Nadean Hall and her husband, Jay, own Botanic Design, a florist in Salt Lake City. To keep the business afloat for the last few years, they have each put in six days a week, often bringing their three young children to the store.
"Shopping at Nordstrom," Mrs. Hall said wistfully. "I haven't done that in years. We try to use our credit cards only in emergencies. And when we shop, it's on an as-needed basis." But Mrs. Hall said she was more optimistic now than a year ago.
So is Chris Bruce, a systems analyst in Omaha. She said her husband had just received a higher-paying job that would require them to move to Kansas. She expects them to be able to sell their house, which they just put on the market, for $125,500, a small profit over what they paid for it at the beginning of the year.
Still, Ms. Bruce said, they have hesitated about buying the Chevrolet Blazer they want.
"We're still a little cautious," she said. "We're very careful about what we get ourselves into."
The Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group in New York, has seen sharp increases in its consumer confidence index in each of the last three months. After plummeting throughout the second half of last year, the index has rebounded nearly to its level of a year ago.
Perhaps more important, the survey showed increased confidence among consumers that the economy would continue to improve in the next six months.
 
'Nothing's Stable Enough'HE>
Yet for many people, the recovery seems to be something enjoyed by other regions, or by their neighbors.
Economists say Utah's economy is one of the fastest growing in the region, but Alex Hansen, a 22-year-old resident of Salt Lake City, said, "Utah's economy is horrible." In February, she lost her job as an administrator for a chain of video stores and was unemployed for two months. She is now working part time at a supermarket.
To make ends meet, Ms. Hansen and her boyfriend, Dan Ponder, have sublet a spare bedroom in the home they rent. Mr. Ponder, who works with developmentally disabled students in a program financed by the local government, said neither he nor Ms. Hansen was banking on things getting better.
"Nothing's stable enough to get a good feeling," Mr. Ponder said.
Even some people who are feeling the benefits of the recovery, however, say they remain worried that the economy could turn down again.
In Centralia, Joel Spenner, a production worker at the Rockwell plant, said: "Do I feel secure in my job now? Yes and no. I remember what it was like a year ago."
Mr. Spenner said he and his wife together make $60,000 a year, but that with four children, it had been impossible to save money.
"I don't have much confidence, even with what's going on here," he said, pointing to the bustle of activity around the plant. "I know people who've worked their whole lives, but now they're just sitting around getting drunk. This plant can't hire everybody."

With him was Mark Neumayer, fish market manager. HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mixed Results Are Posted For Dollar and Gold Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed on world currency markets yesterday, rising overseas but mostly declining in domestic trading after the release of a lukewarm report on consumer confidence.
Gold prices also fell in domestic trading after rising in foreign markets. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $343.10 an ounce, off 60 cents from Monday. Republic National Bank said gold lost 45 cents an ounce, to a late bid of $343. 
 The dollar rose in foreign markets and began domestic trading with a rally. "Traders were thinking that maybe today's numbers would be a little more favorable to the dollar," said Mike Faust, an analyst with MMS International.
But Mr. Faust said selling hit the market around midmorning after the release of a Conference Board report that showed consumers' confidence stagnated during June.
The report underscored the modest pace of the economic recovery and put the market on alert for an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, Mr. Faust said. Such a move would be bearish for the dollar because it diminishes the value of dollar-denominated securities. The central bank is unlikely to take any action before tomorrow's release of June unemployment data, however.
Traders were unimpressed by another report showing the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May for the fifth straight increase.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.55 yen, up 0.05 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 125.85 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 125.60 yen, down from 125.80 yen on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5215 German marks, unchanged; 1.3710 Swiss francs, down from 1.3730; 5.1180 French francs, up from 5.1170; 1,150.50 Italian lire, down from 1,151.00, and 1.1985 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1958.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $343.45 an ounce from $342.35 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $343.25 from $342.50. In Hong Kong, gold was up 86 cents to close at $343.68.

HEADLINE: Congress and White House Are Nearing Agreement on Urban Aid

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
After more than five weeks of intense bargaining, Congressional and White House negotiators said tonight that they were nearing an agreement on a $5 billion urban aid package.
The emerging agreement would provide $500 million a year for five years for the nation's cities, including money for new social programs, as well as $2.5 billion for businesses in waivers on capital gains taxes to spur investment in impoverished neighborhoods. 
A senior White House official said the Administration was pleased with the arrangement, while Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, consulted with other senior Democrats to work out a few remaining details.
 
Joint Effort
 "We both gave in order to reach an agreement," said the White House official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Negotiators hoped the tentative compromise would reach the House floor on Wednesday, although there was still the possibility of a hitch. Congressional and White House aides said that Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, wanted to have a hand in setting up the urban enterprise zones.
The compromise represents a victory for moderates in the Administration as well as the Congressional leadership, who said that it was important to show that the two parties could respond quickly and ably to the rioting in Los Angeles.
At times during the negotiations, Democrats and Republicans told one another that if they did not compromise, Ross Perot, who has all but declared that he is an independent candidate for the Presidency, would benefit from the perception that they were indulging in political posturing.
 
More Money This Time
 The proposed package falls far short of the $35 billion program requested by the nation's mayors, but it went far beyond the $1.3 billion aid bill the White House and Congressional negotiators worked out two weeks ago. That assistance came mostly in the form of loans and grants to businesses and homes damaged in the Los Angeles disturbances.
A successful negotiation would allow Mr. Bush and Congressional Democrats the chance to declare a political victory. After three years, Mr. Bush was able to persuade Democrats to enact his plan for urban enterprise zones, with a major capital gains tax break.
In 50 such zones, half of which are in inner cities and the rest in distressed rural areas, businesses will be granted a five-year moratorium on capital gains, with a 50 percent reduction on capital gains taxes paid after the five years. Democrats had already agreed to a bill that would create enterprise zones with various tax breaks for investors, but they only now agreed to a significant break on capital gains taxes, which are at the heart of the Administration concept.
In exchange for compromising on the capital gains tax, the Democrats received the President's acquiescence for the $2.5 billion in spending for job training, education and health care programs to be coordinated with law enforcement activities. Known as Weed and Seed, specially trained detectives and SWAT teams would be assigned to clear neighborhoods of gangs and drug dealers before the social programs would be instituted.
Aides close to the negotiators said Richard G. Darman, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and staff members of the House Ways and Means Committee still needed to work out the accounting methods to be used to figure out the financing of the measure. A senior Gephardt aide said Mr. Rostenkowski was not in full agreement with the capital gains provision, adding, "This could still blow up in our faces."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Buoyed Clinton Goes on the Offensive

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Buoyed by new polls indicating that his Presidential campaign seems to be picking up some speed, Gov. Bill Clinton tried today to take advantage of the renewed concern about the abortion restrictions narrowly approved Monday by the Supreme Court.
In a long day of television appearances, speeches, meetings and news conferences, here and in New York, Mr. Clinton repeated that he favored the right to choose an abortion and said that he would select a running mate who held that view. He also said that if elected President he would appoint only Supreme Court Justices who support the Roe v. Wade decision legalizing abortion. 
 Before his 16-hour day was finished, Mr. Clinton, the presumed Democratic Presidential nominee, touched bases with almost all the major elements of the Democratic Party in an effort to widen his base and justify speculation that, suddenly, there is a genuine new leader of the Presidential pack.
"This has been a good day," he said enthusiastically at one point, his spirits obviously lifted by the new polls that show him in a dead heat with the other Presidential contenders.
Mr. Clinton promised the Congressional Black Caucus that he would work to heal racial divisions in the nation. "My whole career, my whole campaign, is about unity, not division," he told the lawmakers in a visit to Capitol Hill.
The caucus leader, Representative Edolphus Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, replied: "We smell victory in the air. There is no doubt about it."
 
Laying Out Middle East Policy
 In another speech, Mr. Clinton told leaders of the Service Employees International Union that his recently announced national economic plan would put people back to work and get the American economy moving. The labor leaders cheered in return.
Addressing a group of Jewish supporters, Mr. Clinton delivered one of his sharpest attacks yet on the foreign policies of the Bush Administration, accusing the President of forging appeasing relationships with "dangerous, despotic" Middle Eastern governments like that in Iraq.
Mr. Clinton said he opposed creation of an independent Palestinian state, said Jerusalem should be considered Israel's capital and promised help to Israel in its effort to assimilate Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union.
"The Bush Administration has pushed Israel relentlessly to make one-sided concessions," Mr. Clinton said. "You should not forget the Bush Administration's cold shoulder and the back of the hand."
The crowds that greeted Mr. Clinton at each appearance were noticeably larger than in the recent past, and his repeated precipitous plunges into sidewalk crowds had the confident earmark of a candidate who figured that he suddenly was the anointed leader of the pack.
 
'Pro-choice! Pro-Clinton!'
 Perhaps the Governor's most successful campaign stop of the day was before a cheering crowd of women gathered here on Pennsylvania Avenue to open an office to push an abortion-rights law through Congress.
"As President, I won't make you worry," Mr. Clinton told the women as they chanted, "Pro-choice! Pro-Clinton! Pro-choice! Pro-Clinton!"
The Governor called for a "political uprising" by American women, saying they were not being heard in discussions about major issues, especially the right to choose to have an abortion.
The Governor warned that the High Court's 5-to-4 vote on Monday served notice that the next President, if a Republican, would probably be in position to appoint more conservative Justices. Only one more such Justice, he said, would almost certainly tip the balance against the 1973 Roe decision.
"We don't need to go back to those days," Mr. Clinton said. "It's not good for America. It's not good for the women of America -- the uneven treatment, the disasters in dark alleys, the uncertainty, the fear, the hiding, the uneven application of the law."
