HEADLINE: Twisted Tale of a Kidnapping And of Dreams Gone Wrong

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
It was, in its way, a distinctly American tragedy, one built, perhaps, on greed and carried out with a casualness and ineptitude that shocked even the most seasoned of law-enforcement officials. It was, said Gary L. Penrith, the special agent in charge of the Newark Office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, an "unbelievably despicable" crime.
The largest kidnapping investigation in recent history began on April 29 with a car standing empty at the end of a secluded suburban driveway, its motor idling, its driver gone. 
 It ended yesterday with a guilty plea by Irene J. Seale, a 45-year-old mother of two described by friends as well-dressed and talkative, and who, for all appearances, seemed to come from "the average family." Yet last Saturday she led investigators through a tangle of underbrush to a grave in the desolate sand-swept New Jersey Pine Barrens and the decomposing corpse of Sidney J. Reso, the missing president of the Exxon Company International.
It also ended with an obvious betrayal, as the woman's husband, Arthur D. Seale, pleaded not guilty to charges that included kidnapping, extortion, conspiracy and improper use of the United States mails for the delivery of ransom letters. Mrs. Seale has agreed to testify against her husband. [Page B4.]
Over the past four days, interviews with family members, neighbors, former employers, law enforcement officials and others close to the case have yielded these findings about the abduction, the investigation and the people involved:
*Irene and Arthur Seale, despite their public expressions of love shortly after their arrest, had a troubled family history that several times called for police intervention in family arguments and in the recovery of a runaway child.
*Mr. Seale, a former police officer who as an Exxon employee was in charge of supervising guards supplied to the company by a contractor, is likely to have known Mr. Reso by sight while he worked at the Exxon offices at 200 Park Avenue in Florham Park, N.J., but he is not believed to have harbored any personal animosity toward the executive.
*Federal agents, in a ruse designed to lull the kidnappers into a false sense of security, purposefully misled reporters, describing the kidnapping in a rather lackluster way as a "missing persons" matter rather than a major kidnapping case. In fact, as the 59-day investigation wore on, it would become the largest nationwide manhunt since the high-profile kidnapping of Patricia Hearst in California 1974, said Federal investigators.
*Exxon officials, on the instructions of Federal agents, prepared $18.5 million in cash as a payoff to the kidnappers, though that money never left company coffers.
*Irene Seale was deeply disturbed by Mr. Reso's death and turned against her husband shortly after the couple's apprehension by Federal agents to "provide Mr. Reso with a decent burial," in the words of her lawyer.
While particulars of the investigation remain unclear, a picture has begun to emerge of the kidnappers as part of a deeply troubled family battling a private history of physical and emotional abuse and yet drawn, publicly, to a world of wealth and status typified by the star-studded resort towns of Vail, Colo., and Hilton Head, S.C., where they lived for a time.
It was, perhaps, their inability to sustain that expensive life style that led them to turn to a rash scheme launched late this spring at a time both were unemployed and living at the home of Mr. Seale's parents in Hackettstown, N.J.
 
The Abduction
Morning Commute Ends in Driveway
 April 29 was a Wednesday and Sidney J. Reso, the 57-year-old head of a subsidiary of one of the largest corporations in America, started his day by eating breakfast with his wife of 37 years at their home off Jonathan Smith Road, a cul-de-sac studded with elegant houses strung over four-acre plots in Morris Township. As Mr. Reso prepared for the day, Mrs. Seale, a trim, attractive blonde, jogged past the family's driveway and then returned to the van, where her husband was waiting nearby.
Sometime before 7:30 A.M., Mr. Reso stepped into his car and started on his daily 10 minute commute to his office in Florham Park.
He never made it past the end of his long driveway. There, according to law enforcement officials, a van rented by Irene Seale blocked his way after he stepped from his car to pick up the morning paper. Mr. Seale grappled with the Exxon executive in the driveway, law enforcement officials said, and then pushed him into the van, which was driven by his wife.
 
Shot in the Arm
 Inside the van, Mr. Reso and Mr. Seale scuffled, Mrs. Seale told the United States District Court at her hearing yesterday. As the two men struggled, Mrs. Seale confirmed, Mr. Reso was shot in the arm. Still bleeding from that wound, Mr. Reso was next taken to a rental storage locker the size of a small room not far from where the Seales were living. There, the Exxon executive was handcuffed, gagged with a strip of duct tape and bound hand and foot.
While Mr. Reso remained locked within the sometimes sweltering locker, the Seales began their attempts to extract millions in ransom from the oil company, the authorities said. The day after Mr. Reso's disappearance, Exxon officials received a call directing them to the Livingston Mall. At the mall, which is near Exxon's Florham Park offices, law enforcement officials said there was a note that instructed company officials to await further instructions.
At that moment, it was unclear whether Mr. Reso was alive, or even if the purported kidnappers were holding him.
A second note, found in a park in Morristown about five miles from the Reso's home on May 1, did little to clarify Mr. Reso's condition or whereabouts. Yet together, the notes raised a disturbing possibility. Signed "Rainbow Warriors," the notes raised the possibility that the abductors were extremists somehow linked to the environmental group "Greenpeace," since the group sometimes uses a ship known as "the Rainbow Warrior" to press for tougher environmental standards in the oil and nuclear industries.
Greenpeace officials denied any involvement, and Mrs. Reso told reporters that her husband's concerns about the environment would have made him an unlikely target for extremists from that group.
Before the news of the "Rainbow Warrior" letters leaked to the media, Mr. Reso was already dead. Mrs. Seale told the court yesterday that the couple tried to treat his arm wound, but she confirmed that the Exxon executive was found dead in the concrete-floored locker on May 3, just four days after his abduction.
No autopsy report has been released yet, and the precise cause of Mr. Reso's death remains unclear, though early statements by Mrs. Seale that Mr. Reso died of "natural causes" have been rejected by officials linked to the case. Officials have tried to determine whether Mr. Reso was even given food or water in captivity or if he was simply dumped in the locker and left alone without any significant care beyond superficial treatment of his arm wound.
Even if he was given something to eat and drink, the 57-year-old executive's chances were never very good. Law enforcement officials believe that the temperature in the metal locker would have become nearly unbearable during daytime, and that even a younger, heartier man might not have survived. Mr. Reso's health, in fact, was far from perfect. He suffered a heart attack three years ago and was still on medication at the time of his abduction.
By May 7, Federal officials may have already suspected that Mr. Reso had not survived the abduction. In response to an article in the New York Post suggesting the involvement of Greenpeace, W. Michael Murphy, the Morris County prosecutor, subsequently made an appeal for a photograph or voice recording of the missing executive.
None was forthcoming.
 
The Investigation
Staking Out Pay Phones
 As day after day passed with no proof from the kidnappers that Mr. Reso was alive, the investigation quickly grew. By May 12, a ransom letter was received at Exxon's corporate headquarters in Irving, Tex., calling for a payment and signed "members of the conspiracy," according to a Federal indictment filed on June 25 against the Seales.
On May 15, Jeremiah Doyle, the F.B.I.'s second in command in New Jersey, reiterated the bureau's demand for proof that the kidnappers were holding Mr. Reso and that the executive was alive and well.
That same day, a one-page note was found taped to a light pole in the Rockaway Townsquare Mall, about 12 miles from Hackettstown, after a security guard was alerted by an anonymous call. The note instructed Mr. Reso's wife, Patricia, to make a statement to the media. She appeared on television that evening, saying that she believed her husband was still alive and pleading for him to come home.
Weeks passed, and still there was no proof from the kidnappers. Finally, on June 1, the "members of the conspiracy" mailed a letter from Florham Park to Exxon's international division in Florham Park, calling for the payment of the ransom money.
Two days later, Arthur Seale applied for a passport, telling immigration officials that he had to make an "emergency" trip to the Bahamas. He received the passport the same day.
 
'No Response'
 The next call came June 8, from a pay telephone in Poole, Ga., to a cellular telephone number set up by the F.B.I. exclusively to monitor ransom communications from the kidnappers. In that call, a man's voice asked "why there had been no response to a previous message," according to the United States criminal complaint filed against the Seales on June 19.
Earlier in the week, the Seales had arrived in Hilton Head to visit their son, Justin. There, they dined with friends, appeared relaxed and seemed to be preparing to purchase a marina, said several people who met with the family during the week. One woman who met the Seales for dinner at a Japanese restaurant remembered Mr. Seale as "very relaxed and very open."
Several of Mr. Seale's acquaintances said he arrived in Hilton Head from Florida, where he had often traveled by sailboat in better times.
By this time, the investigative team had swelled to more than 300 people, law enforcement officials said. Mrs. Reso appeared before the media on June 16 and made a plea for her husband's safe return by Father's Day, June 21. "In my heart, I believe Sid is alive," she said. "He's very strong and he's got great faith."
That same day, F.B.I. agents found a peculiar note. Stuffed in a mailbox on Route 24 in Morris Township, it instructed Exxon officials to bundle the $18.5 million ransom in packets of $100 bills inside old Eddie Bauer laundry bags. The authorities were tipped to the letter's location by a prerecorded message left on the cellular phone.
The case was drawing to a close. On Thursday, June 18, Mrs. Seale rented an Oldsmobile from Bette's Rental Agency of Hackettstown. Two final calls were made to confirm arrangements for the ransom payment and teams of F.B.I. agents were dispatched across the county to watch pay phones.
 
A Flurry of Calls
 That surveillance net would soon prove effective. After a flurry of calls and a series of complicated directions throughout June 18, a surveillance team at the Chester Mall in Chester watched from a distance as a blond man placed a call wearing gloves. He then returned to the Oldsmobile rented by Mrs. Seale. A second person was observed in the passenger seat of that car, but could not be identified. The couple left the mall just after 10:40 P.M.
By 11:16 P.M. a woman fitting the description of Irene Seale was spotted at a pay telephone at the Somerset Hills Elks Club in Gladstone, walking toward a white Mercedes Benz. Three calls had been made to the special F.B.I. cellular phone earlier from that number.
At 12:40 A.M., the Oldsmobile pulled up at the rental facility in Hackettstown. No ransom money was ever dropped, and no further instructions had been received.
At the rental lot, Mr. Seale told waiting law enforcement officials that he was simply returning a rented car and waiting for his wife. Shortly afterward, Mrs. Seale arrived in the white Mercedes, and both were arrested. Inside Mrs. Seale's car, agents found two pairs of rubber kitchen gloves, four Eddie Bauer laundry bags, a briefcase with a 1985 Exxon directory marking the home addresses of the company's top executives and three .38-caliber slugs.
 
The Suspects
Domestic Troubles Hidden From View
 Over the next few days, the arrest of the Seles would be followed by a series of revelations about their probable intentions. Law enforcement authorities disclosed his emergency passport application. They also followed a trail of clues that, pieced together, seemed to paint a picture of Mr. Seale's plans for his life as a millionaire.
Michael Chertoff, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said a search of the couple's home in rural Lebanon Township had turned up, among other things, lists of banks in Switzerland, Pakistan and India, Mr. Seale's newly approved passport, a book about money laundering and a dozen handguns and other weapons.
But a backward glance at the Seale's life is equally revealing. Mrs. Seale's court-appointed attorney, Sallyanne Floria, yesterday told reporters that her client was abused and manipulated by her husband over the course of their 25 year marriage. "By the time of sentencing," said Ms. Floria, the jury would understand that Mrs. Seale would never have been involved in the crime had it not been for Mr. Seale's control.
It was by far the most dramatic time that the family's problems had become public. But it was not the first. Joe Venneman, a former police investigator in Eagle County, Colo., said the Seale's domestic troubles brought them to the attention of the police when their daughter, Courtney, 13 at the time, ran away from the family's home in Vail.
"I got the feeling that I wasn't getting the whole story from them," Mr. Venneman said, referring to his visit to the family's house. "They were a couple with a secret, and I was the third man out." Mr. Venneman dismissed the couple as "social wannabes" who were trying "to pull off a life style they couldn't afford."
Sgt. Rick Anardado of the Vail Police also came to know the family. "We received three runaway reports regarding their daughter," he said. On another occasion, the police were called in for a domestic disturbance involving the family's son.
Susan Brody, owner of Convention Designs in Vail, remembers Mrs. Seale without rancor. She said Mrs. Seale worked for her company as a secretary for less than a year, a time during which Mr. Seale was working as a stock broker at Paine Webber in Denver.
Acquaintances of the family in South Carolina were equally split on the subject of the family's background. Several friends, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said they were shocked at reports of the couple's involvement in the kidnapping and described the family as pleasant and ambitious.
"He doesn't even look like the guy I knew," said Porter Thompson, an advertising agent who worked with the Seales while they owned an interior design and furniture business on Hilton Head. Though Mr. Thompson was left with $30,000 in unpaid bills by the couple, he remembered them without bitterness. "Art was always fun," he said. "A happy guy. Cheerful. He was always pleasant. I am just praying they weren't involved in this."

HEADLINE: Tina Brown to Take Over at The New Yorker

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
In an announcement that stunned the publishing industry, The New Yorker yesterday named Tina Brown, the 38-year-old British editor in chief of Vanity Fair, to be its editor in chief. She will replace Robert A. Gottlieb, whose resignation was also announced yesterday.
Graydon Carter, a co-founder and editor of Spy magazine who last year became editor of The New York Observer, is to replace Ms. Brown at Vanity Fair. 
 The news, which spread like wildfire throughout the publishing industry, was as juicy as it was unexpected. It involves two of New York City's landmark publications. The New Yorker established a brilliant genre of witty and sophisticated journalism when it was founded in 1925. Vanity Fair, the sassy parvenu, became the hot magazine of the 1980's and 90's under Ms. Brown.
S. I. Newhouse Jr. chairman of both Advance Publications and The Conde Nast Publications, the parents of The New Yorker and of Vanity Fair, respectively, said in an interview that he and Mr. Gottlieb, who was president of Alfred A. Knopf before his appointment to The New Yorker five years ago, had held talks about the magazine's direction and "continuous evolution" for six to eight months.
"At a certain point, Bob, who is quite conservative and quite classical, was unable or willing to see the need for further evolvement," Mr. Newhouse said. "In a quiet way, he decided that this wasn't a good situation, and he resigned."
News of Mr. Gottlieb's resignation and Ms. Brown's accession met with none of the overt hostility that greeted Mr. Gottlieb when he took over. Many of the writers and editors had almost devotional regard for William Shawn, Mr. Gottlieb's predecessor, who had edited the magazine since 1951. The thought of an outsider's coming in to edit their beloved magazine was almost more than many of them could consider. But yesterday the news about Ms. Brown, who is not just an outsider but a Briton, was received more calmly.
"Everyone I have spoken to so far has been very open-minded and very charitable in an understandably circumspect and professional way," said Daniel Menaker, a New Yorker senior editor, who was on vacation in Massachusetts and fielding calls from colleagues in New York. "I have heard none of the weeping and gnashing of teeth."
Other editors reacted far more negatively when Mr. Newhouse broke the news to the staff at a morning meeting. One said the general feeling was that Mr. Gottlieb, whom many had come to respect, felt an obligation to save something of the magazine, whereas they said they feared Ms. Brown would not.
The news of the changes had been scheduled for release after Mr. Gottlieb's return in mid-July from a trip to Japan. But fears at Conde Nast that the news was leaking out prompted its release yesterday.
 
An Amicable Parting
 Mr. Gottlieb said in a middle-of-the-night interview from his hotel in Tokyo that he had made it clear when he was hired that he was not the person to carry out a real overhaul of The New Yorker because "I would not do it very well."
Conversations over the last several months between Mr. Newhouse and Mr. Gottlieb began to focus again on the need for change, both men said. And, increasingly, it became evident that Mr. Gottlieb was not the one to make these changes.
"The changes I did make -- the changes in Goings On About Town -- those seemed absolutely natural," Mr. Gottlieb said. "I did not see further larger changes that seemed to me appropriate to the magazine or that I was the one to carry out."
Mr. Newhouse, who is known for not prescribing to editors but rather giving them their heads, declined to specify what kind of changes he had in mind or the directions in which he wants to take the magazine.
Both he and Mr. Gottlieb described the conversations as pleasant and the parting as amicable.
"I don't want anyone to think that I have been treated badly," Mr. Gottlieb said. "Si has been extraordinarily generous to me."
While Mr. Newhouse said that the changes "in no way arose because of business or in an attempt to solve a business problem," people in the industry questioned whether financial considerations had not been part of the change.
Conde Nast is a privately held company, so figures on its profits and losses are not available, and its officials always decline to comment on them. But reports have been circulating through the industry that The New Yorker lost $10 million last year.
When asked if this was true, Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive of The New Yorker, replied: "Oh, God, no! If that were true, it would not be a new editor we'd be looking for. It would be a new publisher."
For many years, The New Yorker's advertising pages have declined, first in the face of competition for its affluent, well-educated readers, and more recently because of the recession. So far this year, however, results have improved. Ad pages through May totaled 673.4, up 5.1 percent from the same period a year ago.
The New Yorker's circulation for the last six months of 1991 was 627,263, down 2.2 percent from the last six months of 1990. Single-copy sales, a good test of a magazine's health, were down 8.3 percent.
 
No Imitation of Vanity Fair
 Both Mr. Newhouse and Ms. Brown said emphatically that she would not bring to The New Yorker the kind of glitz she used so successfully in Vanity Fair. Her most famous cover was a nude picture of the actress Demi Moore, who was seven months pregnant at the time.
"I do not know what she is going to do, but I know what she is not going to do," Mr. Newhouse said. "She is not going to go monthly. She is not going to drop the cartoons. She is not going to have some version of Vanity Fair at The New Yorker."
Reports have been circulating that Ms. Brown was becoming restless at Vanity Fair and considering job offers from Hollywood. She has told friends about offers from at least two major film studios and has been approached about jobs in television.
In an interview yesterday, she said she had thought hard about her preferences and decided that her real passion was print.
"Sitting with a writer, talking about how the story is going to be, that's when I come home happy; that's when my husband says I come home with a light in my eye," said Ms. Brown, who is married to Harold Evans, president and publisher of Random House, owned by Advance Publications.
An immediate question is whether Ms. Brown will bring to The New Yorker the group of writers she has developed at Vanity Fair. In answer, Ms. Brown praised the staff writers of The New Yorker and said that while she would search for new writing talent, "I have no idea of decimating the Vanity Fair stable."
She was effusive in her praise of her eight years at Vanity Fair, calling them "the most wonderful roller coaster" and "a journalistic Camelot" and describing Mr. Newhouse as "the white knight."
At 11 A.M. yesterday, Ronald A. Galotti, the publisher of Vanity Fair, escorted Ms. Brown into the magazine's conference room to announce her departure to the staff. The room was overflowing with apprehensive writers and editors who had heard the rumors.
Ms. Brown took one look and started to cry. She turned around, regained her composure and started to say she had news that was going to be very sad, but then she choked up again. At the end of the meeting, everyone stood up and cheered her.
Ms. Brown said Vanity Fair's circulation had just reached one million. The magazine, which is to celebrate its 10th anniversary in March, has enjoyed robust ad-page growth recently, although the recession has taken its toll. Ad pages last year totaled 1,440, down 2.2 percent from 1991. So far this year, growth has resumed. Ad pages through May totaled 544.6, up 10.3 percent.
Yesterday was a day of meetings. Ms. Brown met with some editors at The New Yorker and assured them that "she would not be adding photos or changing the magazine in the ways we had feared," said one person who attended the meeting. Mr. Carter also met with Vanity Fair staff members yesterday and assured them he had no intention of making drastic changes.
Mr. Carter, who is 42 years old and was born in Canada, said he would not turn Vanity Fair into another Spy. He was one of that magazine's three founders in 1986 and went on to be a co-editor. Under his stewardship, Spy published profiles of celebrities that many considered to be unnecessarily mean and often inaccurate. What might have been intended as humor struck many readers as nastiness. Asked if this kind of journalism would characterize his tenure at Vanity Fair, Mr. Carter said "No, absolutely not."
"Spy required certain things and a different set of talents," he said. "I hope that my nine months at The New York Observer shows that I have another set of talents. The Observer was very objective and very fair."
Mr. Carter assumes his new position immediately; The Observer has not named his successor. Ms. Brown is to start at The New Yorker in September, working with Mr. Gottlieb to learn the ropes.
There is one tradition Ms. Brown will not have to learn. In 1925, when Harold Ross founded the magazine, he made it clear that it would not be edited for "the old lady from Dubuque." There seems little fear that Ms. Brown will fail to honor that directive.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Taking Heat at Every Turn, Bush Shows a Boiling Point

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
President Bush's temper seemed to get the better of him in Detroit on Monday night.
Speaking to a group of Republican contributors, he said he was tired of hearing that the economy is not getting better when he is sure that it is, and he thinks Americans have just not gotten the word. Waving his arms in the air and nearly shouting, he said he is sick of not getting credit for the Persian Gulf war, the fall of communism and arms-control breakthroughs. 
 "I have worked my heart out as President of the United States," Mr. Bush said. "I'm getting a little sick of being on the receiving line -- receiving end -- of criticism day in and day out."
Mr. Bush summoned up a similar bout of anger in the 1988 New Hampshire primary to show that he was not down for the count. And he may have been putting on a calculated show of annoyance on Monday to send that same message to party faithful who have been agitating for him to get into the fight.
But frustration on his part would be understandable.
Last week, the Presidential campaign went through one of those periods in which the alignment of the battle clearly shifts. And the President got little out of it. A new round of polls, combined with the behavior of the candidates themselves, indicate three major developments.
 
Perot on Defensive
 One, the all-out attack by the President's surrogates succeeded in flattening the soaring trajectory of Ross Perot by assaulting his integrity, his mental balance and his respect for the Constitution.
But the second major point is that Mr. Bush did not get any boost at all from that effort, or from the sweeping arms-control agreement he signed less than two weeks ago with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. The White House campaign still looks to be dead in the water.
Third, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the presumptive Democratic nominee, gained strength with a calm, dogged campaign on issues. Mr. Clinton finds himself in the happy position of handing over his defensive position to Mr. Perot. Now it is Mr. Perot's psyche, rather than Mr. Clinton's personal history, that is the hot subject.
A new poll published today by The Washington Post and ABC News showed Mr. Clinton with a slight lead of 33 percent to 31 percent for Mr. Perot. Mr. Bush was preferred by 28 percent of those who were asked whom they would vote for if the election were held that day. .
 
'Net Neutral' on Bush
 The poll, conducted on June 24-28 among 785 registered voters, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points, meaning that it recorded a practical dead heat. But there was no denying that its rankings also seemed to provide an accurate snapshot of the moment.
Roger Ailes, an occasional political adviser to Mr. Bush, tried to play down the polling results in an appearance on the NBC News program "Today" this morning. But the best he could say was that the events of the last week or so were "a net neutral on the President."
Mr. Clinton and his aides could hardly contain their delight at the polling results, which were published two weeks before the start of the Democratic National Convention. "It's a natural roll into the convention," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director.
 
'Full-Scale Assault'
 Edward J. Rollins, Mr. Perot's campaign co-chairman, appeared with Mr. Ailes on the "Today" show and declared that Mr. Perot's campaign was moving along just fine. He discounted the polling results but acknowledged that the Republicans had damaged Mr. Perot with what Mr. Rollins called "a full-scale assault."
The figures published by The Post and ABC did not represent a statistically significant shift from previous polls that had Mr. Perot leading, Mr. Bush in the middle and Mr. Clinton trailing.
But polls have a psychological impact on a campaign that is so close, and this one served to underscore what was evident: that Mr. Clinton was recovering from his own slide, while Mr. Bush's position may actually have worsened.
"The Bush slide doesn't look like it's stopped," said Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee. "It looks like it's continued to bleed out even more."
Mr. Tully was quick to point out what Democratic and Republican strategists noted in the new poll: that the shift was caused in large measure by Democrats switching their allegiance away from Mr. Perot, possibly because the White House surrogates had succeeded in their mission of making Mr. Perot look scary. "They freed up some voters, but they freed up some Democrats and some Democratic leaners as well," Mr. Tully said of the Republican attacks.
The new poll made Mr. Bush's problem clear: He must shift from defense to offense. The Supreme Court decision on the Pennsylvania abortion case, for example, was at most a reprieve for Mr. Bush from a political problem, a defensive success that did not provide his campaign with the offensive momentum for which the President's advisers have been hunting for months.
After watching his opponents score public relations points on what he described on Monday as "weird talk shows," Mr. Bush has embarked on his own campaign of television appearances, including a scheduled hour-long stint on Wednesday on the CBS program "This Morning."
 
Bush and Reality Gap
 But Mr. Bush has mostly stuck to the counsel of political aides who told him to avoid any direct attack on his opponents until after the Republican National Convention, which will be held in Houston in August, and to focus on giving the impression of a chief executive hard at work on the nation's problems.
To Mr. Bush's obvious annoyance, it has not worked. "We had Yeltsin standing here in the Rose Garden, and we entered into a deal to eliminate the biggest and the most threatening intercontinental ballistic missiles -- the SS-18's of the Soviet Union -- and it was almost, 'Ho-hum, what have you done for me recently?' " Mr. Bush told a gathering of agricultural journalists here today.
Declaring that the economy was doing better than is generally recognized, Mr. Bush said, "There is a gap between reality and perception, and part of my job when I do get into a campaign mode is to try to close that gap and be sure that we are judged on reality, not on these erroneous perceptions that are being portrayed by the, in the, political process. Get it?"
In fact, Mr. Bush has long been in what he calls a "campaign mode," but only half-heartedly. He defends himself and promotes his programs at every opportunity and has refused only to engage directly with his opposition -- a decision that Republican strategists are starting to question.
 
'Nonpolitical Mode'
 Not only is Mr. Bush sounding increasingly defensive, but he has been forced of late to explain himself to his own party. "When I am unleashed and when we get out of this mode, this nonpolitical mode we're in, I'll tell you, I'll be ready for the fray," he said on Monday night.
But some Republicans say he is waiting too long. "In Bush's mind, he has a clock that starts in Houston and he sees all of this as rehearsal," Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican Whip, said in a recent interview.
"Bush simply has to be able to create no later than the convention a clear and compelling explanation of what changes he favors, why they fit the values of the American people and how they will improve the lives of the American people," Mr. Gingrich said. "If he doesn't do that, frankly, the Presidency is up to pure luck."

LENGTH: 1770 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Midwest: Fertile Region For Politics of Disgust

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, June 26

 BODY:
At truck stops and picnics, in downtown high rises and farm-town cafes, the American heartland is talking politics.
"I've voted Republican all my life, but I'm disgusted," 40-year-old Jim Allmon said in ball park bleachers as he watched his son play Little League in Springfield, Ill. "I'm leaning toward Perot and hope he doesn't come up with something off the wall." 
 But in the middle of Iowa, in Kellogg, another 40-year-old, Bonnie Crook, who voted last time for Michael S. Dukakis, said she was uncomfortable with Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire. "I don't want Bush. I don't like Clinton. But I'm afraid of Perot," she said, gazing from the window of her grocery at the one-block main street. "He's a Trojan horse. We don't know what's really inside him. Four years down the line, will he hurt us? Will we be sorry? I'm afraid so."
In a weeklong thousand-mile drive and in chats with some 200 people around the Midwest -- from Kansas City, Mo., north to Iowa, then across Illinois and Indiana -- Mr. Perot was very much the topic of conversation. But it was not always favorable: none of the wide-eyed fervor here that came out in similar conversations in California just four weeks ago, no blizzard of bumper stickers. For every Perot supporter, there was a Perot opponent.
 
Where Else to Go?
 The same was true of President Bush. He still has a base of support, especially in farm country. But even many people sticking with him said they were doing so not because he is so strong, but because Mr. Perot and Gov. Bill Clinton, the presumed Democratic nominee, are so inexperienced, so phony.
"I don't know what else to do," said Arthur Kane, a 45-year-old lawyer in St. Joseph, Mo. "Don't make me out to be leading the Bush bandwagon. I'm not. But I don't see where else to go. Clinton and Perot are just playing at it. They're not experienced leaders."
Polls show Mr. Clinton gaining support nationwide. But there was little evidence of that during this journey. People seemed accustomed to thinking in terms of a two-candidate race. And in this part of the country, where the sentiment is often Republican, it was Mr. Clinton, not Mr. Perot, who was perceived as the third-party candidate, eclipsed by an incumbent President and a "give 'em hell" billionaire even in some urban areas and among some people who voted Democratic four years ago.
"It's time for a change, but I don't think Mr. Clinton has the experience to go in there," said Tim Bredberg, a 38-year-old race horse trainer in central Illinois who voted last time for Mr. Dukakis. "I'm leaning toward Perot. He'll shake it up. If he doesn't come up with some concrete specifics, I'll go to Bush."
 
Lemonade, Not Vitriol
 From town to town and state to state, the country flashed by in a series of nonstop portraits -- white farmhouses engulfed in a sea of green corn, contented town squares with the flag flying high, farmers rushing out the door to greet a visitor not out of fear but to offer a glass of lemonade.
For the most part, people were well informed about the campaign, quoting newspaper articles and radio and television interviews. But being well informed does not necessarily mean they will vote. Mr. Perot is not so much a phenomenon here as just another candidate, and therefore not a reason for many nonvoters to change their ways.
"I haven't registered to vote, and I don't intend to," said Kevin Madlem, a 26-year-old farmer in Charleston, Ill., who was more concerned about the lack of rain than the Presidential campaign. "Bush, Clinton, they're all the same, all talk."
Asked about Mr. Perot, he said: "Everybody can talk. Everybody can say, 'Heck. I'll go out and do all them things.' He's no different than the rest of them. Talk. I don't care for any of them."
In some cases, not only is the race failing to rally nonvoters to vote, it is chasing away a few longtime voters.
"I'm about as disenchanted as I can get," John Chibnall, 30, said as held 8-month-old John Jr. outside Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield. "You couldn't get three bigger dunderheads. I voted for Dukakis. This time, I'm not going to vote. A Republican's out of the question. Clinton's just mediocre. There's no reason to vote for him. He's the consumate politician. Perot? He's a skillful liar, very shrewd."
In Iowa, in the Winga Cafe in Washington, politics is as much a part of life as the corn, and not voting is unthinkable. Visitors are welcomed to town by being elected president of the coffee club, which meets promptly at 10 A.M., just as it has for 60 years, a mix of business leaders, farmers and retired people, all white men.
On a recent morning, the conversation was the Bushites vs. the Perotists, with most of the older men supporting Mr. Bush and the younger ones Mr. Perot.
"I don't think Perot is the paragon of virtue some people think he is," said Rolly Crandall. "I voted for Dukakis, and I might vote for Clinton."
Then a shout rang out: "You voted for Dukakis!"
Mr. Crandall hunched down in the booth. "I'm not sure who I'll support. I don't put much stock in the marital infidelity stuff with Clinton," he said. "But I'm just not sure he's up to the job."
 
'All Right' or Not?
 The 36 members of the breakfast club then interrupted politics to honor one of the members: "Happy Birthday, Dear Louis, Happy Birthday, to you."
"No Perot," Rick Hofer, 44, said the second the singing stopped. "He'll be a dictator. There's a big difference between government and business. It wouldn't work."
John Winga Jr., the owner of Winga's, called Mr. Perot "probably all right," then added: "I think experience is what's most important. I'd prefer to go with Bush."
The breakfast club then broke the bad news to its visitor. The club's president gets stuck with he tab for coffee: $8.32. But who's counting?
Eight younger members, all of whom voted for Mr. Bush in the last election, stopped on the way out to press the Perot case. "Let's face it," said Mike Moore, 45, who administers a health-care center, Mr. Bush is "not ahead on the issues. Health care is a disaster, the environment. Let's give Perot a shot."
Jim Logan, a 44-year-old jeweler, took the breakfast club's president aside -- the visitor from New York who had just paid the check ($8.32, but who's counting?) -- to inquire about Mario M. Cuomo. "Why didn't he run?" he asked. "He would have won it."
The New York Governor was brought up from to time by others in the Midwest, with sentiments decidedly mixed. At a Rotary Club dinner in Mount Pleasant, Iowa, William Layne said: "Once Clinton said Cuomo was a potential Supreme Court nominee, that wrote Clinton off for me. Cuomo doesn't think in a straight line."
 
On to Indianapolis
 From downtown Indianapolis, with its skyscrapers and black faces, rural Iowa seemed part of another world. But it was just as easy to get a political debate going among office workers and bus riders. Mr. Bush was detested here. But there was some support for Mr. Perot and some for Mr. Clinton, though it was not enthusiastic.
"I'd like to see Clinton campaign a little more in black neighborhoods; I'd like to see him sweat," said Jackie Bryant, 32, a service representative for Indiana Bell, who is black. "I think he overreacted on Sister Souljah. He doesn't understand from the heart. He didn't come from a family with eight kids like I did. It's all too easy for him. He's never had to put forth any effort. I want him to sweat."
Sadie Ellis, 62, standing nearby, agreed that she'd like to see Mr. Clinton kept dangling for a while. But she hinted that she would probably have to come around to him. "Perot is too smooth a talker," she said. "Clinton? There isn't much there. I'm not too sure. I can't say I won't vote for him, but----"
While many blacks said they had no real sympathy for the rap performer Sister Souljah, whom the Arkansas Governor criticized for making what he called racially-divisive remarks, they also said that they thought Mr. Clinton had overreacted, that he should not take their votes for granted, which they seemed to think he was doing.
"Clinton is better than Bush, but Perot is better than Clinton," said Keith Thomas, 20, who is unemployed. "Perot's a businessman. Maybe he can help us get the economy going. I'm a little bit frustrated about Sister Souljah. She's been around for a long time and she's frustrated. She's angry at what she's seen. Clinton should understand that. I'm not saying anybody should kill whites. But Clinton needs to understand the frustration. I follow his line, but only to a point."
 
Playing at Twilight
 In Fairview Park in Springfield, Ill., as the Little League teams played on into the summer twilight, parents sat on lawn chairs and bleachers, talking politics and watching their sons, their uniforms two sizes too big, hit and run. About a third of the parents, who were mostly white, supported Mr. Clinton. The rest were split between Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot.
"We voted for Bush last time, but I'm afraid with Bush we're not going to see any real change," said Brian Piersma, 44. "There's nothing coming out of the Democratic Party. The country's foundering economically, and Perot seems to have some fresh ideas."
At that point, Mary Ann Mulvey, 41, who voted last time for Mr. Dukakis, interrupted. "Perot? No way!" she said. "I haven't heard him say specifically what he'll do. He has no plan. Bush is out of the question. Just look at the state of the country. I favor Clinton. He's got some ideas, he just doesn't seam to be getting a hearing for them."
Said Matthew Clarke, 32: "Did she say Clinton? Clinton! How can anybody say that. There's nothing there. He wants to be President merely for the sake of being President. He has no purpose, no vision. If you don't like Bush, then go for Perot."
 
Would Lincoln Be Sad?
 Elsewhere in town, at Lincoln's tomb, the weekly summer flag-lowering ceremony had just ended. People, clearly moved by the ceremony and by a moment or two inside the burial chamber, seemed saddened by the state of American politics.
"You think about Lincoln and what a great man he was," Clyde Aymes, 43, a stockbroker, said in the twilight. "It's sad, really, where we are. None of them comes close. I think Perot is a fraud. It'll be Bush or Clinton. It's too bad. I'm not sure I'll vote."
He walked away, only to run back a few seconds later. "I'll vote, I'll vote," he said, as if his conscience had got to him. "You have to vote. Why are our choices always so limited? I can't believe there isn't someone better out there. Someone who's real."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate;
Perot Turns to Professionals As Campaign Turns Rough

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 30

 BODY:
Amid tentative signs that the heady momentum of the last two months is beginning to flag, the undeclared candidacy of Ross Perot is moving into a new, more sophisticated phase, a top campaign official said today.
The official, James Squires, press secretary for the Perot Petition Committee, said in an interview that in the coming month the Texas billionaire would make greater use of professional political advisers to help his campaign, possibly put some campaign commercials on television and become more specific about his views. Such a shift would be a marked but expected departure from the campaign's almost exclusive reliance on enthusiastic but untutored volunteers, whose primary focus has been to gather enough signatures to try to qualify Mr. Perot for the ballot in the 50 states. 
 "We have to start doing something other than petition drives" Mr. Squires said.
 
Morning for Perot?
 In recent weeks, Edward J. Rollins, the co-manager of the Perot committee who is in charge of its day-to-day operations, has employed a number of professional political consultants to tackle chores like building crowds for rallies, conducting voter-registration drives and handling the hordes of reporters and camera crews covering Mr. Perot's public appearances. In addition, the Perot Committee has hired Hal Riney, a San Francisco advertising specialist who created the "Morning in America" theme for Ronald Reagan's 1984 campaign.
Mr. Rollins has said that Mr. Perot would declare his candidacy in July, but Mr. Squires and Thomas W. Luce 3d, the committee's chairman, said today that no date had been set for such an announcement.
The change in complexion of Mr. Perot's effort comes at a time when a spate of public-opinion polls show a slowing of his meteoric rise and some embryonic doubts about the plausibility of a Perot Presidency. A Washington Post-ABC News nationwide poll conducted June 24 through June 28 placed Mr. Perot in a virtual dead heat with President Bush and Bill Clinton. In a similar poll conducted by the Post and ABC from May 31 to June, Mr. Perot led Mr. Bush by 6 points and Mr. Clinton by 10.
Other polls have shown a similar erosion of Mr. Perot's standing. In a telephone survey of 810 adults in 12 Southern states conducted June 21 through June 24 by The Atlanta Constitution, Mr. Perot tied for second place with Mr. Clinton, 10 points behind the President. In Massachusetts, a statewide poll of 400 registered voters conducted June 24 through June 26 indicated that the Dallas independent also trailed Mr. Clinton by a margin of 28 percent to 26 percent, with Mr. Bush third with 23 percent. Earlier this month, the same poll had Mr. Perot leading both his possible rivals by 13 points.
"It's like the bloom is off the rose," said Gerry Cherzinsky, president of KRC Communications Research, which conducted the Massachusetts poll for The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV.
These polls suggest that Mr. Perot has been scarred in recent days by the bitter charges being flung back and forth between himself and surrogates for President Bush, and by a reluctance to provide clear answers to some pressing voter concerns.
"I think Bush's attacks have had an impact," Mr. Cherzinsky said. "My belief has always been that the more people know about Perot, the less people will like him. That's only normal for any politician."
Aides to Mr. Perot say they are not concerned about these polls, noting that the electorate has been extremely volatile all year and there are months to go before the election. "What we are seeing is not unexpected," Mr. Squires said. "When you go up in the polls as fast as he did, you're going to bump off the ceiling sometime."
Some political analysts say that Mr. Perot has perhaps also been hurt by his unwillingness to be specific on issues. That reluctance was on display Monday night. During an appearance on a 90-minute program on ABC-TV, Mr. Perot did not directly answer the question of whether he would allow homosexuals in the armed forces. And when asked whether he would sign the Freedom of Choice Act, which would provide a Federal statutory guarantee of abortion rights, he would say only that abortion was a woman's decision.
Mr. Perot also declined to specify how he would make good on his oft-stated view that the way to stop violence in the United States was to "get guns out of the hands of violent people".
Still, toward the end of the show, which featured questions from studio audiences in 10 cities, Mr. Perot virtually endorsed the economic proposals that had been put forward by Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator who dropped out of the race for the Democratic nomination this year.
"What is the most impressive platform I've seen so far? Senator Tsongas's platform, 'An Economic Call to Arms,' " Mr. Perot said, brandishing the small booklet that Mr. Tsongas and his aides passed out at virtually every campaign stop. Mr. Perot added, "There's a lot of good ideas here."
Mr. Perot has been in accord with Mr. Tsongas on a number of economic issues, including a cut in the capital gains tax to spur investment and opposition to a middle-class tax cut. But as he left the ABC studios, Mr. Perot declined to answer a reporter's question of whether he favored a five-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, another of Mr. Tsongas' economic tenets.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Journal;
Quake Spares Buildings but Undermines Denials

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 30

 BODY:
When Joan Welles, an actress, tells people she is moving to Boston, she finds it necessary to add, "We're not leaving because of the earthquakes or the riots." And with that explanation she defines the difficult new reality of this balmy city by the sea.
"It's tough here, it's really tough," she said today, realizing the implications of her words. "When you have a child, you find yourself thinking twice: Do I really want to continue here with the smog and with the earthquakes and with the crime?" 
She said the strong earthquake last weekend and its aftershocks have shaken her calm, and that she now tells herself, "I guess we're getting out at the right time."
It may be because she is about to leave that Ms. Welles has been able to set aside the denial that is a way of life here in Los Angeles. But a number of other people said they had found the current round of earthquakes unusually disturbing.
"I tell you, practically every conversation I've had in the last two days started out with, 'How did you feel about these earthquakes?' " said Linda Wong, director of the Achievement Council, a nonprofit social agency.
Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, who is a political analyst by profession, found broad implications in the latest earthquake and the fears it has aroused in a city still shaken by civil unrest.
"The earthquake is a metaphor for the shifting political, cultural, societal and economic ground," she said, referring to the recent rioting and the three-way Presidential race.
"There are not predictable patterns left, and I think this plays into things," she said.
Examining her own reactions as if she were analyzing an exit poll, she said: "It surprises me how on edge I am. My awareness has never been so heightened as it is now. I have mentally gone through my quake kit. I went out last night and filled up my gas tank. I now have a pair of shoes under my bed.
"I just came home from an appointment in Hollywood, and as I was driving in my own neighborhood, I unconsciously looked up to see whether there were any live wires around, just in case," said Ms. Jeffe, a political scientist. "Yesterday out driving, I was careful to urge my husband not to slow down as we went under underpasses. Sunday, I canceled a dinner in Malibu; I had nightmares of tootling along Pacific Coast Highway and being caught in a rock slide."
She paused to oberve herself with wonder. "You are talking to a Ph.D here, having her schedule and her life to some degree influenced, as it never has been, by apprehension."
But if the earth stops shaking over the next few days, Ms. Jeffe said, she will "shift again into blissful denial.
Donald C. Claussen, for example, a 38-year-old construction worker, said he views the world like this: "I know it's coming, but I haven't done much about it. I figure, if it kills me, it kills me. I mean, if a building falls on you, what can you do?"
Cindy L. Galvan, 18, put it this way: "I don't think they really know if the Big One is coming or not. You can't just be afraid all the time."
The alternative is to live in fear of electrical wires and highway overpasses, as Ms. Jeffe has been doing for the past few days, or like the man Ms. Welles said she knew who couldn't get earthquakes out of his mind.
"He was an older man," she said. "He got to the point where he was walking down one side of the street rather than the other to avoid falling telephone poles. It was very hard for him to stay here. He finally moved."
Though she said she had never been one to worry much about impending disaster, Ms. Welles said she now realized that she had been living with a symbol of terror that is particular to cities like Los Angeles: her child's earthquake kit.
Like thousands of other parents here, she had prepared for her daughter's preschool a packet with food, clothing, the names and addresses of relatives and photographs of herself and her husband to comfort her if the Big One hits.
"I'm going to pick up that kit when we leave," she said, "and that will be a great sense of relief."

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1834 words

HEADLINE: A State-Financed Boarding School Made Just for the Science-Deprived

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DURHAM, N. C.

 BODY:
Todd Rose was something of a misfit. A sturdily built teen-ager from a family swarming with farmers, he did not want to farm. He wanted to study science.
In his small town of Nashville, in tobacco and soybean country in eastern North Carolina, the local high school could offer him shop classes in plowing and welding but nothing in advanced science. 
 But Todd was a good-enough student to be accepted into the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics here, a public boarding school for bright students from around the state. He could pick from a banquet of academic delights -- genetics, anatomy, organic chemistry and fractal mathematics -- and even spend six hours a week at local hospitals, trailing cardiologists into operating rooms.
"That just blew my mind, that I was sitting here, at 17, looking at a person on a table while a doctor is explaining to me everything that's going on," Todd said. "It made me think this is something I want to do."
 
Example for Other States
 As it has done with Todd, the North Carolina School has cultivated hundreds of aspiring scientists after discovering them in the state's backwaters as well as its cities. Its success with those students since it opened in 1980 has inspired imitators in Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, South Carolina and Texas.
Together, say leading scientists and educators like Dr. Leon Lederman, these state-financed dormitory schools are one of the most potent antidotes to the country's deteriorating performance in science.
Dr. Lederman, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist who founded the Illinois school, said that youngsters ardent about science often felt isolated at conventional schools and would withdraw into themselves, grow bored or even become discipline problems. By contrast, he said, those who go to specialized schools find that suddenly "everyone is like them, they don't have to hide, and they start to flower."
 
In the State's Self-Interest
 But the motivation for these pioneering states is far from altruism. They want to leapfrog their agrarian and blue-collar economies into the more scientific and technological world of the future.
Many of these largely rural states faced a policy maker's Catch 22. Without a scientifically literate population, they could not lure advanced industries like those dealing with computers and pharmaceuticals. Yet with their old-fashioned industries, they lacked the tax base to give every school the laboratories and trained teachers could produce a scientifically literate population.
"You can get a ninth-grade education and work in a cigarette factory for the rest of your life," said Dr. William W. Youngblood, an administrator at the North Carolina School. "You can't get a ninth-grade education and work in a pharmaceutical company. You're frozen out of the 21st century."
North Carolina, which had long ranked near the bottom on almost every educational measure, decided to concentrate its resources on a single state school. Wealthy people had long sent their children to private boarding schools, but would the population of a largely rural state be willing to finance a public one?
In 1980 North Carolina opened the nation's first government-financed residential high school, but it had been a hard sell. The state's expense for the first four years was $19 million.
Because of smaller class sizes, sophisticated science equipment and, most of all, room and board, a single student's education at the school costs $12,000 a year, four times the amount spent on a conventional student. And there there were complaints from school boards that the school would skim off their best students for its enrollment of 550.
The school's proponents had to promise to train teachers from around the state and generate curriculums and textbooks that other schools could use. Also, arguing that the school's graduates would provide skilled employees for the many research-driven companies in the college-saturated area around Durham, they attracted $7 million from those companies in the school's first four years, for building renovation and new laboratories.
The payoff came in 1989, when a student, Celeste Posey of Cary, submitted her DNA research project to the prestigious Westinghouse Science Talent Search and finished fifth in the nation. Two years later, another student, Ashley Reiter of Charlotte, took first place for her project in fractals, winning $40,000.
Less glorious but perhaps more prized by the school is the roster of graduates who go on to become scientists and engineers. A survey showed that of the 1,349 students who graduated from 1982 to 1989, 80 percent went on to major in science and engineering.
Despite this record, however, funding the school remains an issue of perennial debate in the Legislature.
Situated in a Spanish-style 16-building campus that had been a decaying county hospital, the school has its own observatory and greenhouse and a laboratory outfitted with gel boxes and transilluminators for cutting-edge research on DNA.
The staff of 58 is as exceptional as the school's courses and equipment. Half the teachers come from colleges or private industry, and 37 percent hold doctorates.
To attract such people, the school's founders had to persuade the state to exempt it from normal teacher certification requirements; this was accomplished through a gimmick: the school was designated a branch of the state university system.
The teachers earn $23,000 to $43,000 a year, about the same as colleagues with similar education levels in the rest of the state. Many said they were drawn by the chance of working with exceptionally bright youngsters in the high school's intimate ambience.
Though many of the teachers have never before taught in high school, they often bring a firsthand grasp of their fields. Stephen J. Warshaw, for example, came after a career as a government water-quality expert.
On a muggy late-spring day, he took his ecology class to the Eno River, a shimmering stream in the piney woods nearby. Slogging into the shallow water, they used rigidly framed nets to jog aquatic insects from under rocks, and then identified the creatures using microscopes and charts arranged by body traits.
Trekking back to school, 17-year-old Julie Bass confided why she could not have had such a satisfying scientific experience back home in Asheville.
"First of all, we wouldn't have ecology," she said. "Second of all, we wouldn't have a field trip. In that school, everything is from a textbook."
 
Days of Cerebral Fun
 In Kevin G. Bartkovich's class, where the air is thick with terms like bifurcation trees and iterations, students are not just learning mathematics, they are also practically inventing it. Dr. Bartkovich teaches a class in fractals, one of only a handful in the country. Fractals, a word that did not exist 20 years ago, is a mathematical tool for imposing order on the seemingly chaotic geometry of mountain ranges, clouds, even lung tissue -- and is also a fertile field for just plain cerebral fun.
"It's not as though there's this well-defined theory we can learn," Mr. Bartkovich said outside his class. "People are still figuring out what this is all about."
The North Carolina School admits only juniors and seniors, because the founders believed that sophomores were too young to flourish on their own, away from home. It tries to balance race, sex and state geography, using a 24-member admissions committee that is itself diverse, and judging students on interviews as well as grades.
In 1992, 47 percent of the students were female. In proportions that roughly mirror the state's ethnic breakdown, 23 percent of the study body was black, 10 percent Asian, 2 percent Indian and 1 percent Hispanic. Ninety-four of the state's 100 counties were represented.
 
Changes From a Tiny Town
 The school has provided a haven for young people who might have felt out-of-place in their hometown schools. Julie Woosley, an effervescent 1986 alumna who is now a chemist at the Research Triangle Institute here, recalled that back home in Cullowhee, population 1,200, the physics teacher was about one month ahead of the class.
"We did not have chalk or paper, but the football team had a VCR and a wide-screen TV so they could see tapes of how they played," she said. "When I got to Science and Math, the thing that impressed me the most was that there were people who were curious about current events, religion, you name it."
For those singleminded about science, the most compelling classes are in research. After a crash course in deciphering scientific treatises, using the Duke University library, the biology research students learn how to distinguish varieties of bacteria, inject pathogens into plants and separate strands of DNA.
Once they are ready to tackle a professional-scale project, the school offers them two commodities they could not get in most public high schools -- space and time. It has laboratories restricted to research students, where they can be sure their agar plates and fish tanks will not be disturbed by the general stream of students.
Elizabeth Smith, 17, of Ayden, has been investigating the impact of nitrogen deficiency on plants she grows in the greenhouse. "At home we don't have the chemicals I need, we don't have a greenhouse, we don't have the money for vermiculite or pebbles," she said. "Before I came here, I was thinking about being an architect. Now I'm thinking about botany."
North Carolina Science and Math also has a less demanding program than research to give students a feel for careers in science. Like Todd Rose, who now wants to be a neurosurgeon, students are paired with researchers and doctors at nearby universities or at technological companies in Research Triangle Park.
Most students seem to thrive in the residential atmosphere. The dorm rooms are as unkempt as their college prototypes, except that the objects scattered about are closer to childhood -- a stuffed Winnie-the-Pooh or a Happy Birthday balloon. In one boy's room, a picture of Einstein is next to one of Arnold Schwarzenegger as the Terminator.
Students wander into each other's rooms to work through baffling math questions or to gossip or just get relief from the homesickness that many feel from being away about nine months a year. Each year, about 10 percent of the starting juniors return home to their local schools.
"Many of these kids have made nothing but 98 and 99," said Mr. Warshaw, who becomes principal next year. "Then they come here and get a C on their first test, they realize they're not at the top of the heap anymore and that's a big adjustment."
Yet most students eventually get A's and B's and go to respected colleges. Two-thirds attend college within the state, a fact that has vindicated the chauvinistic founders.
"We tell students they are here as the seedcorn of North Carolina's future," said Dr. John J. Friedrick, the school's executive director.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Shutout for Sanderson As Yanks Have a Blast

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Scott Sanderson throws pitches that should be hit. They float to the plate with incredible ease and look delicious to batters. Until they tap the ball 90 feet, miss it totally or pop it up harmlessly. Just like the Royals did last night.
Sanderson was dominant without looking menacing, and his assortment of change-ups, sliders, forkballs, fastballs and curveballs mesmerized a Kansas City club that had accumulated 33 hits and 16 runs in its preceding two games. 
 With Sanderson limiting the Royals to four hits, Don Mattingly smacking two singles, a double and a homer, and Mel Hall, Pat Kelly and Matt Nokes also smashing homers, the Yankees whisked to a 6-0 victory at Yankee Stadium.
That Sanderson painted corners and never exceeded 89 miles an hour on the radar pitching gun is nothing new. But his stellar performance was opportune because it prevented the Yankees from sliding four games below .500 for the first time this year.
 
Putting Things Together
 By tossing his first shutout of the season, Sanderson lowered his e.r.a. to 4.49, after it had been above 4.90 since mid-April. He threw an economical 86 pitches, 60 of which were strikes, did not walk a batter and retired 27 of 31 hitters.
"Scott put it all together tonight," said the pitching coach, Mark Connor. "That's as pretty as you can do it."
While Sanderson was completing his first shutout in nearly a year, Mattingly gave a glimpse of his old self with his first four-hit game since Sept. 12, 1989, a span of 431 games. Mattingly extended his hitting streak to 13 games with a single in the first, then he doubled in the fourth, hit his ninth homer of the season in the sixth and added an r.b.i. single in the seventh.
Since he was switched to fourth in the batting order June 12, Mattingly is hitting .372 to raise his average to .272.
But Mattingly still declines to talk much about his hitting, even now that it has become more robust. He has said since the spring that he wants to let his hitting do the talking for him. Last night, it was a gorgeous speech as Mattingly sprayed hits to all parts of the field.
 
Silence, Everyone
 "I want to go out there, put up the numbers and just play ball," said Mattingly. "All I want to do is let the game come to me. Hopefully, I can silence some people and show them I can still play."
One magazine has called the 31-year-old Mattingly over the hill. It upset him, and he has not forgotten it.
"That was an insult," Mattingly said. "I don't feel that in my heart, but if someone feels that way, it's an insult."
No one was insulting Sanderson after he allowed no runner to reach third base and only two to make it to second.
"There is satisfaction," said Sanderson, after notching the club's first complete-game victory. "I don't know if it is any more special."
Pat Kelly made only his third start in 17 games and gave the Yankees a 1-0 lead in the third by belting his third homer, off Mark Gubicza. Hall rocked his team-high 11th homer in the seventh to boost the lead to 4-0. Each homer was slammed on the first pitch. Nokes continued the trend and tied Hall for the team lead by hitting a first-pitch homer off Neal Heaton to start the eighth.
 
Some Joy Returns
 With another game less than 15 hours away, players rushed home after the victory. Sanderson had to pick up his nephew at the airport in Newark, and Mattingly dressed quickly after speaking to reporters. But first he conceded that the joy had gone out of baseball at times last season. It was back last night in a big way.
"The one thing I've always enjoyed is the baseball," Mattingly said. "I want to play the game the way it was supposed to be played and then go home."
Then he left.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Yankees are expected to try remedying their starting pitching woes by recalling BOB WICKMAN from Class AAA Columbus soon, club officials said. The right-hander is 9-2 with a 2.09 e.r.a. and has held hitters to a .194 batting average. Wickman might start Monday, and JEFF JOHNSON (2-3, 6.25 e.r.a.) will probably be dropped from the rotation. "It's not good enough right now," said General Manager GENE MICHAEL. "We just haven't finalized plans. We'll be discussing things to get it better." . . . Outfielder JESSE BARFIELD underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair damaged tissue in his left wrist Tuesday and will miss four to eight weeks. . . . BRIAN McRAE robbed MATT NOKES of a three-run homer by leaping above the center-field fence in the fourth.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
KYOEI STEEL OF JAPAN AGREES TO BUY FLORIDA STEEL CORP.

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Kyoei Steel Ltd. has agreed to buy the Florida Steel Corporation, the nation's largest maker of concrete-reinforcing steel bars. Kyoei, one of Japan's largest makers of steel bars, said it would pay an estimated $350 million for FLS Holdings Inc., the parent of the Tampa-based company. Kyoei agreed to buy many of the company's outstanding bonds and pay some of its bank debt. 
 The purchase ends about two years of financial struggles for Florida Steel, which has been hurting from the recession and the debt it took on in a 1988 leveraged buyout. Kyoei Steel, based in Hirakata, Japan, said it did not plan to alter the company's name, staff or managers. Florida Steel, which has annual sales of more than $463 million, was negotiating with lenders to ease the debt from its $306 million buyout. As of April, it defaulted on more than $5 million in payments to banks.

The Economy
U.S. steel producers, by filing trade complaints against foreign steelmakers, have created a $100 million export: legal and lobbying services that must be purchased by the foreign producers to defend themselves. [Page D1.]
Manufacturing growth slowed in June, according to the purchasing managers survey, indicating a lengthy rebound. [D1.]

 Companies
A winemaking process constitutes a trade secret belonging to a winery and may not be devulged by a wine maker to subsequent employers, a court ruled. [A1.]
General Motors bought Hughes Aircraft six years ago as a source of military business. But the end of the cold war has turned the acquisition into a money-loser. [D1.]

 International

 Markets

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Banking: Bright Spot Stands Out In Quarter

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
You can bank on it.
In fact, if that was your investment strategy in 1992, you have probably done quite well. Otherwise, it hasn't been much of a year so far.
In the second quarter of 1992, an unlamented period that saw more stocks go down than up in price, while Wall Street kept looking for signs of economic recovery, the bank stocks starred. 
 The Nasdaq bank index, a collection of mostly regional banks, zipped up 11.8 percent in the quarter, and has risen 26.3 percent this year. Of the 18 best-performing stocks on Nasdaq in the second quarter, 16 of them, including all of the top 7, are banks. And big banks also moved up. Bank of Boston gained 36 percent in the quarter, while Citicorp added 29 percent.
The reasons for that good performance include takeovers and, in some cases, relief that a bank whose survival had seemed shaky now looks as if it will make it. But the Federal Reserve has played the largest role. The Fed's efforts may or may not prove sufficient to produce a decent recovery, but the strategy of pushing down short-term interest rates has raised profit margins and saved a lot of money for banks.
 
Wall Street's Beliefs
 In addition, there is a belief on Wall Street that bank mergers will drive down costs and push up profits for years to come. Chemical Banking, which is digesting its acquisition of Manufacturers Hanover, rose 13.4 percent and by the end of the quarter was being hailed by Thomas Hanley, First Boston's bank analyst, as a growth stock.
Unfortunately, there is more to the stock market than bank shares, and the rest of the list was something less than scintillating. Areas like health care and pharmaceuticals did poorly, and there were disturbing signs that consumers are not especially eager to spend their money.
The Standard & Poor's 500 edged up 1.1 percent in the quarter, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.6 percent, but the Nasdaq composite fell 6.7 percent, despite the big gains by banks and smaller ones by other types of financial stocks.
 
Sensitive to Economy
 Among the Dow stocks, economically sensitive stocks continued to do well, as investors showed they were willing to bet that the recovery will endure, come what may. General Motors was the best performer of the Dow 30 for the second consecutive quarter, rising 20.1 percent after adding 26.8 percent in the first three months of 1992. Double-digit gains were also shown by I.B.M., at 17.2 percent; McDonald's, at 15.4 percent, and Exxon, at 13 percent.
The worst performers of the Dow 30 had one thing in common: a dependence on consumers. Woolworth sagged 12.1 percent, Sears, Roebuck slipped 11.4 percent and Procter & Gamble dropped 10 percent.
Carriage Inc., the Big Board's best performer (among common stocks that began the quarter at $5 or more), reported rising profits from its carpet operations, but a part of its 93 percent rise came on the news that Carriage's chief executive and principal shareholder, Clarence E. Harris, was suffering from prostate cancer. The company has a large insurance policy on his life, most of whose proceeds will be used to repurchase his stock.
The three worst performers on the Big Board for the quarter were all dependent on the clothing business, and found it tough. Financially troubled Gitano, the maker of women's clothing, fell 61 percent, while Aileen, a maker and retailer of clothes, dropped 59 percent and Fabri-Centers, a retailer of fabrics and patterns, fell 55 percent.
In 1991, some of the best stocks to own were small growth stocks. There were exceptions, but in many cases they were among the worst this year. The Nasdaq industrial average, which is dominated by technology companies, fell 11 percent.
Lately, it appears that many on Wall Street are giving up on such companies. Mutual fund investors, who poured money in earlier in the year, started to take cash out of some funds specializing in such stocks last month, but the funds still have large amounts of cash available for investment, largely because the fund managers have hesitated to buy stocks. And the short-sellers who bet against stocks have piled up big positions.

HEADLINE: Purchasers See Signs of Slow Growth

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Economic growth among manufacturers slowed somewhat in June, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers. Economists contend that the survey indicates that the rebound from recession will be gradual and drawn out.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said that its index of economic activity had fallen to 52.8 percent in June, from 56.3 percent in May. The decline was largely a result of slower growth in production and new orders. A reading below 50 percent indicates that the economy is contracting, the group says, while a reading above 50 is a sign of expansion. 
 "Since the index and its major components were at or above 50 percent, it seems that the economy is still expanding, although slowly," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former Federal Reserve governor and president of the Washington economic consulting firm Brimmer & Company. "It appears that the slowdown in economic growth has been broadly based. Since the trend has been upward over the last few months, I expect that the expansion will continue, although at a moderate rate."
 
Wide Range of Companies
 The monthly index is compiled from a survey of more than 300 purchasing managers at a wide range of industrial companies. It is considered important because it is the first significant indicator of economic activity in the previous month.
Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the puchasing managers survey committee and director of corporate purchasing for Pitney Bowes Inc., said the data continued to indicate economic growth. "However, the torrid pace of growth in May has clearly cooled in June," Mr. Bretz said. "Nevertheless, the sustained high level of growth in new orders strongly suggests that the economy will continue to grow in the third quarter."
The association's index of new orders slipped to 58.3 percent, from 61 percent in May. The new-orders index is considered the most important of the indexes because it directly affects the level of production in the months that follow.
New orders for exports followed a similar path. The index of orders for exports slid to 51.9 percent, from 56.9 percent in May. Imports fell in June after growing in the previous three months. The index of imports fell to 49.5 percent, from 53 percent in May.
The association's production index dropped to 56.4 percent, from 62.9 percent in May. Economists said the drop in the index reflected a decline in new orders in April.
