HEADLINE: Hughes Fails to Fulfill Hopes Of G.M. for Counterbalance

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 1

 BODY:
It was for times like these, when auto sales are slow, that the General Motors Corporation bought the Hughes Aircraft Company six years ago. Pentagon orders for military goods, it was reasoned, could be counted on regardless of lean economic times.
What was not foreseen, however, was the full impact of the end of the cold war. 
 Now, after Tuesday's announcement that G.M. would take a $749.4 million write-off and cut 9,000 workers from Hughes, analysts say Hughes will cause a second-quarter loss for the troubled auto maker. What is more, many analysts, though declining to speak for the record, rate the Hughes acquisition a waste of capital, noting that G.M. would be in far better financial shape today if it could spend the $5.2 billion it spent on Hughes on retrenching of North American automotive operations, which lost nearly $8 billion last year.
"We had been predicting a G.M. net profit in the second quarter of about $500 million, but now we're looking toward a net loss of about $250 million," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York.
G.M. earned a slim $179 million in the first quarter, after posting a $4.55 billion loss for last year. G.M. will announce its earnings for its second quarter, which ended Tuesday, later this month.
G.M. bought Hughes six years ago for $5.2 billion in cash and stock, winning an auction against the Ford Motor Company, the Boeing Company and others.
William Winters, a G.M. spokesman, reiterated the auto maker's stance that it has no intention of selling Hughes, although it is divesting other nonautomotive businesses to concentrate effort and capital on cars and trucks.
Hughes said the cutbacks will save about $700 million a year in cost and position the company for stronger financial results in the future. C. Michael Armstrong, Hughes's chairman, said he hoped to broaden commercial applications of the company's high-technology abilities.
Bruce McCristal, a spokesman for G.M. Hughes Electronics, said the subsidiary had earned a cumulative $4.31 billion since the acquisition. But with meager overall profits last year, G.M. has pursued alternative financing, selling $2 billion worth of common stock two months ago to raise cash.
G.M.'s common stock lost $1 a share today, closing at $43 on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares in G.M. Hughes, known as G.M. class H stock, lost $3.25 each, closing at $22.625 on the Big Board.
G.M. bought Hughes to take advantage of its expertise in high-technology systems integration, optics and other fields that might be useful in automotive research and development.
But the acquisition, a pet project of Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman at the time, was born in controversy. Ross Perot, then a G.M. director, opposed the acquisition because he said the price was too high, particularly in light of Soviet overtures for mutual arms reduction. Mr. Perot, who left G.M. in 1986, was the lone G.M. director to vote against it.
Since then, Hughes engineers have helped G.M. automotive engineers on a number of projects, including development of the Impact battery-powered car prototype. Mr. McCristal said Hughes engineers had completed installing half of a satellite network to 9,700 G.M. dealers. It will be complete in two years.
Still, Hughes Aircraft has failed to produce solid earnings for as long as G.M. has owned it. Analysts cannot calculate precisely how much Hughes has earned on its own because its results are lumped together with those of several Delco Electronics subsidiaries, which G.M. already owned.
Delco and Hughes were joined as part of the acquisition financing package, which paid the Howard Hughes Medical Institute $2.7 billion in cash and $2.5 billion worth of a new class of G.M. stock, G.M. class H.
Soon thereafter, the acquisition dissolved into a squabble between G.M. and the medical institute, which contended that class H stock did not pay adequate dividends -- dividends depended on earnings -- and there was an inadequate public market in which to sell the stock. The squabble was settled in early 1989 when G.M. paid the institute almost $1 billion and agreed to buy back much, if not most, of the class H stock.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Too High? Export a Few Lawyers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
In a perverse confirmation of American competitiveness in at least one sector of the economy, the nation's capital in one day created an export that could reduce the trade deficit by $100 million or more during the next 12 months.
It consists of legal and lobbying services to be contracted by the 21 foreign countries and 47 foreign steel companies who must defend themselves against the trade complaints filed here on Tuesday by struggling United States steel producers. To avoid punitive customs duties of up to 165 percent on shipments to the United States, each company and each country has hired or plans to hire at least one Washington law firm. 
 The firms charge $500,000 to $3 million for such jobs, with the average bill paid by a company or a government likely to run around $1 million, lawyers involved on both sides of the cases said.
Add this to the $20 million war chest that the nation's six major steel companies have assembled to file and fight the cases, and the new trade war over steel imports, at roughly $120 million, is almost certain to be the most expensive ever fought.
These cases "dwarf anything that has come before," said Alan W. Wolff, the partner at Dewey Ballantine who filed the American steel cases together with Robert E. Lighthizer, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Even $120 million may be a low estimate.
"I'd be surprised if it weren't over $100 million on the other side," Mr. Wolff said.
Dewey Ballantine and Skadden, Arps together buried the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission's dockets with two million pages of documents in 650 boxes on Tuesday.
The work available for trade lawyers and lobbyists in fighting and filing trade complaints surged last year and again this year, after a low of just 44 complaints were filed in 1990. American trade law makes it easier during a recession to convince the International Trade Commission that an industry is in trouble and needs protection from imports.
The bonanza has spawned a feeding frenzy among Washington law firms, as lawyers idled by the slump in corporate mergers and acquisitions now gallop after foreign steel clients. "This is a fat pig, and they all want a slice of it," Mr. Lighthizer said. "Every single person in town will be working on this, every single one."
When a dozen senators and representatives joined the nation's top steel executives for a news conference in the Capitol building on Tuesday to announce the 84 trade complaints against imported steel, they found themselves addressing a room filled with uninvited trade lawyers.
Eager for a list of the foreign steel companies being sued, the lawyers, who bill at rates of $100 or more an hour, had already grabbed many of the 150 press kits prepared by the steel companies' public relations firm, the Sawyer Miller Group. Well trained from long years of waiting outside Congressional hearing rooms for seats, other lawyers and their aides stood two or three abreast in a line down the marble corridor and around the corner.
Defending against a trade complaint is lucrative because it requires thousands of hours of legal and economic analysis, as each company tries to prove that it does not receive illegal government subsidies and is not exporting steel at unfairly low prices. Many foreign companies do not follow American accounting practices, and even American trade law does not always follow generally accepted accounting practices, so, much of the work involves translating companies' costs and prices into the unusual language of American trade complaints.
 
Strategies to Get Work
 Washington lawyers still without steel clients are busily devising strategies to woo them. Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon, which is already representing steel pipe producers in Argentina in a trade case filed earlier this year, retained a public relations firm in an effort to have its lawyers quoted as experts.
David P. Houlihan, a partner at the firm, said that was easier than calling complete strangers and asking them for work. "I just couldn't do that, the cold call," he said.
Other law firms are more brash. Sandra Wright, an international trade analyst at Donovan Leisure, Rogovin, Huge & Schiller, called a reporter two hours before the news conference on Tuesday in search of an early list of foreign steel companies to call.
While Donovan Leisure has traditionally concentrated on corporate law, it hopes to expand into trade, she explained.
Powell, Goldstein, Frazer & Murphy is likely to represent the biggest Dutch and German steel producers, while Willkie Farr & Gallagher will probably represent Brazilian steel producers and at least one Japanese company.
 
The Two Favorites
 But among the biggest beneficiaries from the steel cases are likely to be Dewey Ballantine and Skadden, Arps. Dewey Ballantine was successful when it represented American lumber producers seeking to impose punitive duties on lumber shipments from Canada, and the firm will be pulling lawyers away from general litigation to fight the steel case, Mr. Wolff said.
Skadden, Arps is drafting lawyers from its tax and environmental sections for the case, Mr. Lighthizer said. Neither firm would say how many lawyers they are putting on the case and for how long.
The risks of not paying generously to contest a trade suit were recently illustrated by Russia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and three other former Soviet republics. When accused of selling uranium in the United States below production costs, officials in the six republics tried to fill out the thousands of pages of necessary paperwork with little outside help.
In a tentative ruling on May 29, the Commerce Department said the republics had failed to return some forms and had botched others. So the department assumed that production costs in the republics were roughly comparable to costs in Canada, Britain and Namibia, and assessed a customs duty of 116 percent.
 
Diplomats Unhappy
 The decision appalled the State Department because it could wipe out shipments of a product that accounted for an eighth of the entire Soviet Union's exports to the United States last year. The Commerce Department issued its verdict days after Kazakhstan had agreed to renounce strategic nuclear weapons, and at a time of rising concern that the republics' nearly bankrupt nuclear industry might be driven by financial desperation into doing business with Iran and other potentially dangerous third world nations.
But the ruling was quietly welcomed by Washington trade lawyers as yet another reminder to the rest of the world that their skills are very much needed.

HEADLINE: Council Held Likely to Bar Waste Project

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration's plan to build a $550 million incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- one of the most bitterly contested public works projects in New York's history -- will almost certainly be rejected by the City Council before it adjourns next week.
The Council action would send the city's carefully crafted solid-waste management plan into chaos and probably force Mayor David N. Dinkins to negotiate a new agreement by the end of the month, when it must be presented to state officials. 
 The plan is the city's blueprint for disposing of garbage over the next 20 years through a complicated mix of recycling, efforts to reduce waste and the addition of at least one major incinerator, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
The plan's many vocal opponents object mostly to the new incinerator. But the administration and its supporters say that solutions that do not include incinerators are unrealistic. In the next two weeks, the Dinkins administration, if it cannot find the votes to defeat a veto, will have to find a compromise, possibly by delaying construction at the Navy Yard or by adding funds to hasten the recycling program.
 
Assessing the Votes
 Council members who oppose the plan said at a City Hall news conference yesterday that they were certain of at least 30 votes, enough to defeat the incinerator project and only 5 fewer than are necessary to override any mayoral attempt to reinstate it.
"There is no support for this program, which is really just an expensive incineration plan," said a Council member from Brooklyn, Steven DiBrienza. "What the city needs is much more recycling. We cannot have a plan that puts the emphasis on burning trash."
The final bill will depend largely on whether Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, takes an active position. So far, he has not spoken forcefully on the issue.
Mr. Dinkins, who supports the incinerator plan but has never forcefully campaigned for it, said it was still too soon to gauge the eventual outcome. But if the plan is spurned by the Council, which has sought to greatly expand the city's faltering recycling program, it will be a critical defeat for Mr. Dinkins and his newly appointed Sanitation Commissioner, Emily Lloyd. It will also present the most vivid example yet of how politically treacherous it has become to attempt to construct incinerators in New York, or most other American cities.
Some environmentalists say the plan, the city's first comprehensive solid-waste program in 20 years, places far too much emphasis on burning New York's enormous daily load of garbage and not enough on recycling it.
 
Remarkable Amounts
 There have been two types of opponents to the incinerator in the past: those advocates who believe that incinerators should be banned always no matter what the alternatives are, and those environmentalists who say that if the city cannot afford to invest heavily in both recycling and incineration, it should rely on the first. Increasingly over the last year, the two groups have merged to oppose the Navy Yard.
But others, including Ms. Lloyd and the State Environmental Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, warn that the city generates such remarkable amounts of waste -- nearly 28,000 tons a day -- that nearly every way of disposing it -- recycling, incineration and burying it in landfills -- will be necessary.
"The Council wants us to be able to tell them we are on the verge of a real crisis," Ms. Lloyd said. "And the crisis is not going to be here tomorrow. But it's as if they need rats frolicking on garbage bags before they can appreciate the critical issues we must face."
The city will close two major sections of its Fresh Kills landfill by the end of next year. Congress is considering legislation that would sharply curtail the amount of garbage New York can ship to landfills in other states. And tipping fees -- the charges for sending garbage to the landfills -- have risen rapidly and are expected to continue to climb.
All that, and the certainty that within 5 to 20 years the Fresh Kills lanfill will close completely, has forced New York to plan for the future. If the city fails to produce an acceptable program, the State Environmental Conservation Department can suspend permits for current landfills and decline to issue new permits, including those for any future recycling centers. While such action is unlikely, its practical effect would be to prevent all development in the city.
 
Quality of Life
 "If the leaders of New York City continue to believe that there is some magic solution to its waste problems, they risk causing a very substantial decline in the quality of life there," Mr. Jorling said.
Mr. Jorling has not taken a position on the specific Navy Yard incinerator because, he said, it would be improper since he must rule on permits. But he has made clear that he believes the city will need to explore all options for disposing of waste. And he added that if the incinerator was rejected this month, it might be necessary to begin the lengthy approval process all over should the city wish to try again to build it.
But opponents of the incinerator say the city has never made a real commitment to recycling and they contend that unless it is stripped of other alternatives, it never will.
The recycling advocates insist that if after aggressive recycling the city still need to find other solutions, they will reconsider their opposition to incinerators.
"The city wants to do everything at the same time," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "We are convinced for poltical and economic reasons that the city has failed and will continue to fail at trying to do both. It's time to recycle first."

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 35.58 On Hopes of Fed Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Speculation that the Federal Reserve might ease its monetary policy helped propel stock prices broadly higher yesterday, reviving a rally that began at the start of the week.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 35.58 points, to 3,354.10, bringing its net gain since the end of last week to 71.69 points. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by 1,217 to 548 on the New York Stock Exchange. The Standard and Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.74 points, to 412.88.
Volume on the Big Board totaled 214.3 million shares, against 201 million on Tuesday.
The rally extended to secondary stocks as well. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues gained 5.39 points, to 568.99, while the American Stock Exchange's market- value index rose 3.73, to 383.01.
 
Waiting for Employment Data
 The Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee met this week, and analysts have been debating the chances for new moves to ease credit conditions.
Many analysts believe the Fed's decision will be influenced by the latest data on unemployment, scheduled to be released this morning.
If the figures point to continued sluggishness in the economic recovery, the central bank would presumably have a new incentive to nudge short-term interest rates lower.
"Nonfarm payroll employment should show its fifth consecutive monthly gain in June," said Peter Greenbaum at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "However, this increase, like the May preliminary data, should be quite modest."
Those expectations were reinforced yesterday with a monthly report from corporate purchasing executives showing a drop in the pace of the manufacturing sector's growth last month.
On the Big Board, gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up 2 1/2, at 76; Merck, up 7/8, at 49 5/8; I.B.M., up 3/8, at 98 1/4; Boeing, up 1 1/4, at 41 1/8, and A.T.& T., up 3/4, at 43 3/4.
I.B.M. was one of the stocks chosen by Shearson Lehman Brothers for its midyear list of "10 uncommon values in common stocks."
Among other issues, BankAmerica rose 3/8, to 44 3/4; Chemical Banking 3/4, to 37 7/8; Autozone 1 3/8, to 29 3/8; Forest Laboratories 1, to 33, and Royal Dutch Petroleum 1, to 88 5/8.
Bradlees ranked among the volume leaders, trading at 12 1/2 after an initial public offering of 11 million shares of the stock by the Stop and Shop Companies.
Quarterdeck Office Systems lost more than half its value, plunging 6 3/4, to 5 5/8, as the most-active issue in Nasdaq over-the-counter trading. The computer software company estimated its earnings dropped sharply in the quarter that ended Tuesday.
Among other over-the-counter technology stocks, Novell gained 2, to 55 1/4; Intel 1, to 58; Microsoft 2 1/8, to 72 1/8, and Oracle Systems 2 1/8, to 17 3/8. Late Tuesday, Oracle reported sharply higher profits.
Securities-industry issues advanced as the bull market for both stocks and bonds showed signs of reviving. Morgan Stanley rose 1 1/8, to 51 1/4; Merrill Lynch 7/8, to 51 3/8; Paine Webber 1/2 to 22 1/8; Bear Stearns 1/2, to 17, and Charles Schwab 7/8, to 24 3/8.
Louisiana-Pacific, up 1/4 at 46 1/2, touched a new high. The company said it expected its 1992 earnings to live up to analysts' expectations.

HEADLINE: Millionaire Adding Unpredictability to a Campaign

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1

 BODY:
Here in this state of shuttered factories, collapsed banks and wilted real-estate investments, the campaign for the United States Senate seat held by Christopher J. Dodd has taken an unexpected turn with the entry of a Republican candidate some consider a Connecticut strain of Ross Perot.
His name is Charles Senter Johnson Jr., but he prefers to be known as Brook, a childhood nickname. A millionaire several times over, he runs a towel and bedding company called C. S. Brooks, lives in an exclusive enclave of this well-to-do Fairfield County suburb, where his neighbors are people like Ivan Lendl, and swings a polo mallet for recreation.
 
'A Dose of Success'
 And to counter the fact that a month ago the mention of his name drew blank stares from nearly everyone considered important in state politics, he has already spent $160,000 on television ads that depict him as an earnest, smiling executive in shirt-sleeves and describe him as "a dose of success Washington needs." 
 Mr. Johnson, 45 years old, has no political experience, local or national, and readily admits it. But he insists that his career in the textile business, which he says began at age 16 on the factory floor at the American Thread Company in Willimantic, has given him the skills he needs for the Senate.
"What is politics but business?" he said in a recent interview at his company headquarters-turned-command center here. "It's just the business of government."
Many here believe that Mr. Johnson has turned the Senate race into a contest that will be determined by who can spend the most to reach voters. He has refused to say exactly how much of his own money he plans to spend, but has said he expects his campaign to cost $4 million, considerably more than the $2.5 million to $3 million that statewide candidates usually spend here.
Mr. Dodd, 48, a Democrat, is seeking a third term. A poll of 500 state residents done for The Hartford Courant and the Institute for Social Inquiry at the University of Connecticut in May found that 42 percent of those polled viewed Senator Dodd favorably. The poll had a margin of sampling error of 5 percentage points.
The same poll found that few people knew anything about his Republican challengers, State Representative Christopher B. Burnham, a Stamford Republican whose campaign video makes much of his service in the Marine Corps during the Persian Gulf war, and the former Connecticut House minority leader, Robert G. Jaekle of Stratford. (Mr. Johnson did not declare his candidacy until the last week of May.) A fourth contender, a schoolteacher from New Fairfield, William G. Hare, is running as a citizen candidate for the Republican nomination.
Citing money problems, Mr. Jaekle dropped out of the race on June 16 and threw his support to Mr. Johnson, saying he thought Mr. Johnson had a better chance against Mr. Dodd.
 
Given Pause by War Chest
 While rejecting the idea that money will determine who represents Connecticut in the Senate, the other candidates are clearly given pause by Mr. Johnson's wealth.
"Anybody who's going to spend $4 million, you'd better take seriously," Senator Dodd said in a telephone interview. He added: "The idea that the Senate seat has a 'for sale' sign on it is, I think, offensive to people. In Connecticut, you win Senate seats the old-fashioned way. You earn them."
Mr. Burnham, an investment banker who has promised to walk across Connecticut to make himself known to voters, has similar feelings. "Johnson has the ability to write himself a check," he said, "but I have a million dollars in sweat-equity. Much more than money, what matters is your vision, your volunteers."
As for Mr. Jaekle's decision to support Mr. Johnson instead of him, Mr. Burnham, who has a war chest of about $300,000, compared with more than $1.5 million for Mr. Dodd, seems unconcerned. "I think Bob was impressed with the money," he said.
Mr. Johnson insists that he is not a bottomless pit, financially speaking. "It's a stretch," he said. "It's a sacrifice. I have some friends who could write some big checks, but the law won't let them."
His reasons for entering the race are straightforward, he said: "I decided that like a lot of people, you spend a lot of time complaining about the problems in Washington. But very few people want to sacrifice their life style to try and change the system."
Others take a different view.
"When all is said and done, Brook Johnson will ride off on his polo pony into the sunset," said Edward L. Marcus, the state Democratic chairman. "No one begrudges him having made a lot of money. I think it's wonderful. But I don't think it says much to the guy worried about job security or making the mortgage payment on his house. This indicates somebody who has an enormous ego and wants to buy his way into the election."
 
Consensus on Abortion Rights
 For the most part, the major candidates line up similarly on several major issues. Mr. Dodd, Mr. Burnham and Mr. Johnson all favor abortion rights, and all three say creating jobs in the state is a priority.
Mr. Dodd has become a target for Republicans over his work on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, especially his opposition to aiding the contras in Nicaragua. He responds by saying that he worked on many bills involving child care, higher education and other domestic issues, and says he will strive to help the state's military industry shift to other kinds of manufacturing that will preserve jobs.
Mr. Burnham seems especially interested in eliminating Government bureaucracy. Mr. Johnson says he would like to reduce spending, and recruit companies to Connecticut by being "a great ambassador to the world and the other states." His own factories are all in Tennessee and Canada, he said.

HEADLINE: 2 Environmental Bills Fail in Albany

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 1

 BODY:
The two most significant environmental bills facing the State Legislature this year were declared all but dead today, in large measure because two Republican Senators insisted on having the authority to block state land purchases in the Adirondacks and the New York City watershed in the Catskills.
As state lawmakers headed toward their annual end-of-session marathon, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Assemblyman Maurice D. Hinchey, a Saugerties Democrat who is chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee, both conceded that their environmental agenda had been thwarted in the Senate. 
 One bill would have established an environmental trust fund, financed by existing taxes on beer and soda containers, to be used for land preservation, solid-waste management and other environmental purposes. The other bill was intended to protect wilderness areas in the 100-year-old Adirondack Park through zoning restrictions and other regulations.
The Republican-majority Senate, responding to pressure from the beverage industry and from local residents in the Adirondacks and the Catskills, has killed both pieces of legislation for this session, Mr. Cuomo said.
 
Land Plan as 'Swiss Cheese'
 "It was as though you were declaring war on ecology, but that is their choice," the Governor said.
Environmental advocates said the trust fund was blocked because of the insistence by two Senators, Ronald B. Stafford of Plattsburgh and Charles D. Cook of Delhi, that it be amended to exempt nearly all of the land purchases in the Adirondacks and the Catskills proposed in the state's open space plan, which was released last week.
"They've made Swiss cheese out of the state open space plan," said Neil F. Woodworth, a lawyer for the Adirondack Mountain Club. "This is two people holding hostage the needs of the entire state."
Mr. Cook said: "We have a real problem in our area. The state owns too much of our land already."
 
'Some Kind of Political Fix'
 Mr. Cuomo, the legislative leaders and their staffs were still struggling to break the political logjam blocking other significant bills, including an economic development bond act and a fiscal bailout for Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
The Governor faulted Nassau and Suffolk leaders today for providing insufficient information to his office about their respective budget crises. "They apparently thought there was some kind of political fix here," Mr. Cuomo said, suggesting that Nassau and Suffolk officials believed their cause could be shepherded through the Legislature by Mr. Marino and other Senate Republicans from Long Island.
Nassau County is seeking state approval to float more than $70 million in bonds and to impose a 1 percent mortgage recording tax. Suffolk County needs state permission to borrow more than $90 million and to increase the county's 8 percent sales tax by half of 1 percent. Both counties need the financial help to close operating deficits in their budgets.
Mr. Cuomo said he has yet to be convinced that the borrowing and tax increases are necessary. And if he becomes convinced, he and Mr. Weprin are insisting that the bailout be accompanied by the creation of some form of oversight panel, like New York City's Financial Control Board. That step is opposed by the Senate Republicans.
 
Curbing Teen-Age Smoking
 "Nobody is more respectful of the local governments than I am," Mr. Cuomo said. "But I'm not going to abdicate my responsibility either and give them a blank check, especially not in counties that are regularly accusing the state of making their life more difficult by raising taxes, which we haven't done."
Mr. Cuomo has argued that if the Senate Republicans want to help Nassau and Suffolk Counties, they should approve his plan for the state to assume the share of Medicaid costs paid by local governments. But the Republicans continued to argue today that the plan would subject the state to large and open-ended costs, and there seemed little chance that the plan could be resuscitated this year.
There were signs of new life, however, for a bill that would give New Yorkers an opportunity to vote on the Governor's proposed $800 million economic development bond act. Among the issues being discussed by negotiators today was how the infrastructure projects that would be financed by the bond act would be spread around the state.
And negotiators for Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature announced a last-minute agreement on a bill aimed at aiding the prevention and detection of lead poisoning. The bill would require doctors and other health-care providers to offer lead-screening blood tests to children and pregnant women when they first treat them. It also would require the State Health Department to develop regulations for a comprehensive prevention and screening program.
Other health-related bills were still being discussed in closed-door meetings. One is aimed at curbing adolescent tobacco use by a variety of methods, including restricting the placement of vending machines. Another would prohibit doctors from referring patients to laboratories where the doctors have a financial interest.

HEADLINE: Senate Democrats Forge An Economic Strategy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Eleven Senate Democrats today brought out a $22 billion package of bills that they said would revive the nation's competitiveness in international markets.
Competitiveness and trade policy have faded as issues in the Presidential campaign, as have unsuccessful candidates in both parties who focused on them. And the senators, led by George Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, conceded that many of the 30 proposals in their package were not new. But they contended that the presentation of their ideas as a package would dramatize the Bush Administration's reluctance to pursue an industrial policy. 
 They called the plan a comprehensive strategy to maintain American technological leadership, rebuild manufacturing, create high-wage jobs and tighten trade laws. At its core is a trade bill with two central provisions.
 
Reviewing Foreign Trading
 One would allow industries to force the Administration to review foreign compliance with trade bills. The other would revive Super 301, a section of American trade law, much criticized by foreign governments, that would force the United States trade representative to challenge foreign trade barriers on a faster and more rigid schedule. The bill would not include restrictions on car imports from Japan.
The plan also includes bills to expand Federal support for research and development, increase vocational training and commercialize products from Government laboratories.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the presumed Democratic candidate, has called for some of the same programs, notably to expand vocational training and spend more Federal money on civilian research. He publicly endorsed today's Senate plan.
Two hours after the Senators announced their plan, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said as expected that he would try to amend this year's House trade bill with legislation on automobile imports.
But the measure Mr. Gephardt proposed today would restrict auto imports much less than previous plans backed by him and other House Democrats who have taken a tough stand on trade issues, suggesting that House and Senate leaders are moving toward each other on trade policy.
 
Curbs on Japanese Car Imports
 Rather than limit the sales of cars made by Japanese-owned factories in the United States, the bill would require the Administration to ask the Japanese Government for long-term restrictions on Japanese car imports. It would also require the Administration to monitor whether Japanese companies complied with their Government's informal offer to President Bush in January to more than double Japanese purchases of American auto parts by 1994. It would force the Administration to impose penalties on imports from Japan if the purchases fell short.
The offer was made during President Bush's visit to Tokyo. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan, stopping in the United States on his way to next week's economic summit meeting in Munich, met with Mr. Bush at Camp David today.
In the House, Democrats have avoided setting forth a comprehensive set of trade proposals out of concern that they would look weak if few of their bills were enacted. The 11 Senate Democrats set aside such concerns today in presenting their package of initiatives.
The plan reflects an alliance of two large factions among Democratic senators. The high-technology faction, which includes Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, strongly favors a greater Federal role in paying for civilian research and better educating American workers.
Another faction, represented today by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, is more interested in enacting trade legislation that would open foreign markets while possibly restricting foreign access to the American market. Senator Riegle has also been seeking legislation to amend Congressional rules to allow amendments to the free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that the Bush Administration is negotiating.
Conspicuously absent from the senators' news conference was Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, which writes trade laws. He said in an interview this evening that he had been too busy to attend and had not yet made up his mind on whether to proceed with a trade bill this year.

HEADLINE: Hector I. Vasquez Is Dead at 63; First Puerto Rican on School Panel

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Hector I. Vazquez, who in 1968 became the first Puerto Rican member of the New York City Board of Education, died on Monday at his home in Briarwood, Queens. He was 63 years old.
He died of prostate cancer, said a son, Jaime. 
 Mr. Vazquez was named to the Board of Education by Mayor John V. Lindsay in 1968 and served until late 1969. In 1968, Puerto Ricans made up 22.1 percent of the New York City school system's enrollment, and Puerto Rican groups had long protested that they lacked representation on the board.
The problems of Puerto Rican students were of particular concern to Mr. Vazquez. "High unemployment among Puerto Ricans," he once said, "is a chronic situation" because of the large number of high school dropouts and "the language problem."
From 1967 until 1974 he was executive director of the Puerto Rican Forum, a nonprofit organization promoting educational and job opportunities. It is now called the National Puerto Rican Forum and is an employment and training agency serving Puerto Ricans and other members of minority groups.
Mr. Vazquez was born in Cayey, P.R., and lived there until he was a teen-ager, when he moved to New York, where his family lived in the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan. He earned a bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of Miami in Florida in 1952 and a master's degree in economics from American University in Washington in 1956. He did further graduate work at Pace University.
From 1957 to 1966 he worked in the Puerto Rican Economic Development office in New York and as an executive of a manpower training program operated by the forum, the Urban League and Cornell University.
After leaving the forum he held posts in the New York State Department of Commerce, in the New York City Office of Business Development and elsewhere. From 1987 until his death he was president of Hector Vazquez Associates, which does business-development consulting.
Besides his son Jaime, of Queens, he is survived by his wife, the former Carmen Inoa; three sisters, Aurora Vazquez of Manhattan, Amelia Vazquez of San Juan, P.R., and Carmen Morgan of Vero Beach, Fla., and another son, Miguel, also of Queens.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Rise Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Additional signs of economic weakness helped push prices of Treasury securities up again yesterday and heightened anticipation among credit market participants about the release of June employment data today.
Prices fell early in the session after the Market News Service reported that representatives of the American Bankers Association's economic advisory committee met with a group from the Federal Reserve Board last week and found Fed governors reluctant to ease monetary policy. The group included the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan. 
 But traders and analysts noted that data released since that meeting had been uniformly weak. The sense of slowdown was reinforced yesterday by data from the nation's purchasing managers, who reported in their latest monthly survey that manufacturing activity in June had slowed from May levels.
The decline in the purchasing managers index, to 52.6 from 56.3, was led by declines in orders, production and employment.
"We are being overwhelmed by negative news," one government bond trader said.
 
'Desperate for Yield'
 To capture an acceptable yield, investors are moving into longer-dated securities.
"Rates in the short end are turning negative, once you take inflation into account," the trader said. "That is forcing people out the curve a little bit, and it could continue if rates were to go lower. People are desperate for yield."
So far, the desire to lock in higher yields does not encompass long-term Treasury securities. Bond yields moved a bit lower yesterday, but remain mired around the 7.75 percent level that has proven a stern resistance point.
"It is very odd to me that customers will extend out to buy product in other markets with some credit risk attached to it, but they will not move out on the Treasury curve," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
"I'm not sure I understand the reasoning, but that is what they are doing," Mr. Slifer said. "And it makes long-dated Treasuries the cheapest thing around."
 
Market May Be Vulnerable
 Some analysts and traders said that with prices at current levels, the market will be vulnerable if the employment data released today turn out to be stronger than expected.
Most economists are expecting the report to show that nonfarm payroll employment probably rose by 75,000 to 100,000 last month. An increase of more than 125,000 would almost certainly delay a move by the Fed to ease monetary policy.
But analysts said that a gain of less than 75,000 in nonfarm employment would probably pursuade the central bank to make another move.
 
Long Bond Yield: 7.74%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10230/32 , up 3/8 of a point, to yield 7.74 percent, down from 7.77 percent on Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10231/32 , up 10/32 , to yield 7.07 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, up 1/32 , to yield 4.80 percent.
 
Sale Set for 7-Year Notes
 Late yesterday the Treasury announced it would sell $9.75 billion of new seven-year notes on July 8, next Wednesday.
After the announcement the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.71 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.53 percent late yesterday, down two basis points, or 2 one-hundredths of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late rate of 3.61 percent.
 
Offering by Waste Management
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Waste Management Inc. offered $250 million of noncallable five-year notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 6 3/8 percent notes were priced at $98.85 to yield 6.651 percent, 38 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Italian Bank's Notes
 Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager on a $200 million offering of 15-year subordinated notes for Banca Commerciale Italiana, Italy's third-largest commercial bank. The noncallable 8 1/4 percent notes were priced at $99.914 to yield 8.26 percent, 1.16 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The debt sale is the Italian bank's first in the American capital market. Bankers familiar with the transaction said that demand for the notes was hampered somewhat by the 15-year maturity, as well as by Italy's uncertain economic future.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 of a point, in light trading.

HEADLINE: Revised Urban Aid Plan Is $5 Billion Compromise

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Eager to display an ability to govern amid rising disenchantment with partisan bickering, the White House and Congressional Democrats agreed tonight on a $5 billion aid package for the nation's cities. It includes tax incentives for businesses willing to invest in inner-city neighborhoods and $2.5 billion for a variety of social programs.
While the program falls far short of a sweeping effort to uproot urban poverty, it represents a victory for Republicans and Democrats alike who were able to weave their differing policy approaches into one package. While final enactment is still in doubt, President Bush appears on the way to achieving the core of his urban program: the establishment of urban enterprise zones meant to flood neighborhoods like Harlem and Watts with new capital investment. 
 At the same time, Democrats were able to get an Administration endorsement for five years of fresh spending for a $2.5 billion bundle of their favorite projects: Head Start education for preschool children, job training for the hard-core unemployed, inoculation for children and remedial education services for the disabled and others in danger of falling behind in the public schools.
 
Majority Leader Optimistic
 "This is not the millennium in urban policy," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader who was the lead Congressional negotiator. "But it's a step in the right direction. We obviously have lots of problems and they manifested themselves in Los Angeles and every night in our nation's cities."
Mr. Gephardt said that he thought "we ought to be able to pass this" in the House on Thursday.
A senior White House official said, "The President is pleased with the progress we have made." But he added that final passage was not certain, noting, "Bills like this are always volatile."
The volatility is rooted in a package that offers a target for conservatives and liberals alike. Many Republicans have resisted funneling $500 million a year more into programs they believe have created few benefits while contributing to the budget deficit. And many Democrats warn that the enterprise zones will create few new jobs and do little more than grant incentives for businesses to move from one neighborhood to another.
 
5 Weeks of Wrestling
 Coming nearly two months after the Los Angeles riots, the compromise package culminates more than five weeks of horse trading and political posturing that put the result in doubt until only hours before the deal was struck. At times when deadlocks loomed, members of the Administration and Congress told one another that their failure would only fuel the campaign of Ross Perot, the undeclared independent candidate who has exploited public exasperation with the fractious partisanship that has characterized relations between the White House and Capitol Hill.
In recent days, there have been intensive two-track negotiations to reach a compromise. On one, Mr. Gephardt worked out the compromise on the capital-gains tax provisions with Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp and Nicholas E. Calio, assistant to the President for legislative affairs. Mr. Kemp held to the Administration's position of exempting all capital gains until the bitter end, but Mr. Calio and the Democrats persuaded him to accept the deal.
On the other track, Mr. Gephardt and Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, worked out the accounting methods by which the spending provisions would be paid for without raising taxes. Details of their compromise were not immediately available.
The agreement arose from a smaller $1.3 billion aid package enacted two weeks ago, providing loans and grants for businesses and houses destroyed in the Los Angeles riots, and 360,000 summer jobs for urban teen-agers.
 
Urban and Rural Zones
 Under the new package, 50 enterprise zones would be established, 25 in the cities and 25 more in impoverished rural areas with high unemployment. Companies willing to invest in the zones would be able to exclude 50 percent of their capital gains as long as their interests were not sold for five years after the initial investments were made. Businesses in the zones would also be exempted from paying an alternative minimum tax, and they could roll over gains.
Democrats had already agreed to create enterprise zones as part of a $14 billion tax bill passed by the House Ways and Means Committee last week. But the Democrats, who had previously characterized capital gains cuts as a Republican plan to enrich the privileged, have now decided to go along with the Administration. Other tax measures, including repeal of the luxury tax on expensive cars, private airplanes and boats, as well as an extension of tax breaks for research and development and low-income housing and restoration of tax preferences on real estate losses, are also included in the measure.
 
Based on 'Weed and Seed'
 The House tax bill, which will now be amended under the White House-Congressional compromise, calculated that 50 enterprise zones would cost the Treasury $2.5 billion over five years. The amended tax bill should reach the House floor for a vote on Thursday.
The $2.5 billion in social spending would combine Republican aspirations for better law enforcement with Democratic hopes for improving the opportunities of urban poor. Adopting the principle of Mr. Bush's proposed "Weed and Seed" program, the new spending would be combined with intensive police activities. SWAT teams and special detectives would be used to sweep gangs and drug dealers out of neighborhoods before the social programs were initiated.
Mr. Gephardt said the Weed and Seed program would focus on the urban enterprise zones, so that job training could be offered to prepare neighborhood residents for the new businesses expected to locate near their homes.

HEADLINE: Russia's Rust Belt -- A Special report.;
On the Path to an Open Economy, A Decrepit Steel Plant in the Urals

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAGNITOGORSK, Russia

 BODY:
The 64,000 steelworkers at the Magnitogorsk Metallurgical Complex, the world's largest steelworks, are beginning to get nervous. The company is 90 days behind in paying wages and is offering instead 50-pound sacks of sugar and pieces of steel that the workers can try to resell.
As production falls, 5,000 of the workers do not have a full day's work and some have been sent home on forced vacations. 
 "The steelworkers do not yet grasp what is happening to them," said Valery Kucher, former editor in chief of the Magnitogorsk Worker, the city's daily newspaper. "They still believe that they are the pillars of the country."
 
Surviving on Subsidies
 Like dinosaur steelworks in the United States that were forced to close a decade ago, the Magnitogorsk plant is threatened with bankruptcy and extinction. But it is so far managing to squeeze out enough profit to stay alive.
It survives because some major costs are subsidized by the Government and profits are used not to enrich investors, but to build workers' apartments and rest homes, subsidize the city's trolley system and construct new rolling mills deemed essential for modernization and survival.
The steelworks are one of many giant state enterprises in company towns across Russia that have emerged as a powerful political force because they keep workers housed and fed.
But their clout runs counter to the pressure from industrial nations on President Boris N. Yeltsin to move quickly toward a market economy, even if this leads to layoffs and labor unrest. The state enterprises are a key to the balancing act as Mr. Yeltsin seeks billions of dollars in foreign aid while yielding on occasion to domestic pressures.
 
Magnitogorsk, or Else
 "If we close the plant, there are no other jobs," said Anatoly Starikov, the 51-year-old general manager of the steelworks. "People would have to look for work elsewhere, and in Russia that is unrealistic. If we halt part of the production, then half the city will be hurt. That is also inadmissible."
"And while we are not expanding social services, we do not cut them back," he continued. "We have to take care of people."
Once a proud symbol of the forced industrialization in the 1930's that made Russia a world power, today the Magnitogorsk steelworks have deteriorated into a vast complex of blackened buildings and ancient furnaces along the Ural River. From a skyline of smokestacks comes a constant flow of orange and white smoke that makes the steelworks one of the world's worst air polluters, adding to the pressure to close them.
Its managers acknowledge that to avoid the fate of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation mill in Lackawanna, N.Y., and United States Steel's Homestead Works in Homestead, Pa., which closed in the 1980's, Magnitogorsk needs $10 billion or more for a sweeping modernization that would make high-quality products at a lower cost. Such an investment is far off.
"The Soviet Government, before it collapsed, was on the verge of a decision to rebuild the steel works, financing the $5 billion project with subsidies," said Mr. Starikov. "Now the state has no money and cannot invest and, as a result, the steelworks and the city find themselves in a difficult position. We are facing the same crisis that Pittsburgh and the American steel industry faced 20 years ago."
 
Protecting Workers, Not Stockholders
 While the executives who closed Lackawanna and Homestead responded to pressure from stockholders, Mr. Starikov will not have shareholders until the steel works are privatized, which is not expected for at least a year and could take much longer. His constituents remain the townspeople he would have to lay off. They and their families make up half the population in this company town of 450,000 people.
"The workers have the power, and the managers try to satisfy them so that they can hold on to their own positions, and keep alive their hopes of some day becoming owners," said Aleksei Titkov, a Russian economist and sociologist. "These managers are operating in a middle ground between the old socialist state and the markets."
Mr. Starikov, who moved up to general manager last year from chief engineer at the steelworks, where he has spent his working life, is not alone in presiding over a difficult company.
While the Government remains the nominal owner of these giant enterprises, Mr. Starikov and his peers exercise most of the authority. They set production and wage levels, bank their revenues instead of turning them over to the state, buy their raw materials and make their own investment decisions. The Government, in fact, has become more adversary than ally.
Under pressure from the West to balance its budget and put the nation's finances in order to qualify for foreign loans, the Government in turn is trying to raise money by taxing the steelworks and other enterprises.
It is also trying to maintain high interest rates to discourage the steelworks and similar giants from borrowing money to stay afloat.
 
Caught in the Maze Of Market Reform
 The industrial nations are backing Mr. Yeltsin and his economic team, even at the cost of layoffs and bankruptcies. But the unrest that might result from widespread unemployment has become a bargaining weapon for the managers and their representatives in Parliament, among them Vladim Kluvgant, the 34-year-old Mayor of Magnitogorsk.
"I understand the position of Mr. Gaidar to stabilize the ruble," Mayor Kluvgant said, referring to the acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar. "But don't forget: You can bend a stick up to the point that it breaks. Otherwise you will have social explosion."
While Parliament manages to slow the transition to a market economy, Mr. Starikov, a stocky, quiet man with imposing black eyebrows, finds ways to sell enough steel to keep his expensive operation going.
One method has been to chip away at labor costs. Twice this year, Anatoly Kusov, a 47-year-old machine operator, has been ordered -- like the 150 others on his shift -- to take a leave, the most recent one covering most of June. Over dinner at his apartment, Mr. Kusov attributed his forced vacation to a company effort to revise work schedules. "I am not laid off," he said.
But Mr. Starikov made it clear that eventually many jobs at the steelworks might have to disappear. Production has fallen to an estimated 13.5 million tons this year, from a peak of 16 million in 1988, partly because the huge ore deposit that prompted Stalin to locate the steelworks here is now exhausted and other materials have become harder to obtain.
 
It's Steel, Yes, But Not Great Steel
 The complex still produces more steel than any other plant in the world, and 26 percent of Russia's tonnage.
The problem is that the steel coming out of this giant museum piece is below world standards. Within the Commonwealth of Independent States, Mr. Starikov can sell the steel at only 9,000 rubles a ton, or $90, less than half the world price.
The main customers are 8,000 domestic companies that cannot afford better quality imported steel and are themselves struggling to survive as Russia moves toward competition with more efficient foreign companies.
As a result of their own problems, these customers owe the steelworks 12 billion rubles, or 12 percent of the complex's expected revenue this year. Mr. Starikov and his managers offset the losses by simply running up a 12 billion ruble debt of their own with their suppliers and workers -- a practice that has complicated the effort by market-oriented economists to analyze the profits and losses of enterprises.
"If these customers go under, then the steelworks are doomed," said Mr. Kucher, the newspaper editor. "The steel is good for making tanks but not for making computers and modern cars. The world does not need Magnitogorsk's steel."
The world, in fact, treats Magnitogorsk steel not as a finished product, but as raw material. The company has exported more than 200,000 tons so far this year, but as slabs, sold mainly in Thailand and Western Europe. There they are turned into thin steel sheets and other finished products at rolling mills a generation younger than Magnitogorsk's newest machines.
The steel company estimates total revenue this year at 100 billion rubles, or $1 billion at current exchange rates -- alarmingly little for a major steel company. But in Russia, 100 billion rubles gets a company by when two major costs -- rail transportation and energy -- are still subsidized.
The company estimates its total 1992 outlay at 87 billion rubles, which leaves 13 billion, or $130 million, for investment in new equipment. That is not nearly enough.
The strategy to lure foreign investments, as described by Mr. Starikov and Valentin F. Sarychev, the 41-year-old deputy chief engineer, is to use the money to build much-needed rolling mills and new oxygen furnaces. The return on the investment would be paid in exports of finished steel. The Government recently authorized such an arrangement, but so far no investors have come forward.
If new facilities ever replace the old equipment, the work force would have to shrink to 40,000, from 64,000 now. "But we are not going to lay people off," Mr. Sarychev said. "We are creating new products and new jobs."
He listed a plan to diversify the plant's operations and the town's industries, expanding such current operations as a furniture subsidiary, a tin-can division and a unit that makes enamel-coated steel pots. In the future, car parts and steel ladles are to be made. But these operations will probably not be enough to re-employ all the steelworkers.
 
The City's Mask Of Prosperity
 However bleak the future might seem, the city of Magnitogorsk appears to be very much a going concern, even booming.
A new hotel is going up on the west bank of the Ural River, with a view of the steelworks across the river. A red-brick brewery is nearing completion. Construction cranes poke out from the roofs of a dozen nearly finished concrete-slab apartment buildings, built by the Kombinat. And nearby, a fourth river bridge is under construction.
Only gradually does the town's incipient decline become apparent. The trolley system, owned by the steel works, has not yet been extended into the newer neighborhoods. Many roads are unpaved and it still takes 10 years to get an apartment. Indeed, many people are on the waiting list to migrate from the east bank of the Ural to the relatively less polluted west bank.
Responding to the public outcry over pollution, Mr. Starikov last year named Anatoly Kostyukov, a metallurgical engineer, as the company's chief ecologist. But Mr. Kostyukov does not offer much relief. Given the high cost of pollution control and the old facilities, he says, reducing pollution to acceptable levels will take until at least 2000.
Offsetting this hardship, the steelworkers' pay averages more than 5,000 rubles a month and the most skilled earn 8,000 to 15,000 rubles in a nation where the average monthly wage is less than 3,000 rubles. The 8,000 to 15,000 rubles converts into only $80 to $150, but represents substantial purchasing power in a city where a four-course meal is only 100 rubles.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Magnitogorsk Metallurgical Complex in Russia, the world's largest steelworks, is threatened with bankruptcy and extinction, like dinosaur American steelworks that were forced to close a decade ago. (Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA FORCED TO TURN TO I.O.U.'S

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 1

 BODY:
Its economy racked by recession and its political leadership paralyzed by stalemate, the State of California ran out of cash today and began to pay its bills with I.O.U.'s for the first time since the Great Depression.
State Controller Gray Davis sent out the first 12,000 of the I.O.U.'s after the Democratic-controlled Assembly failed to reach agreement with the Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, on how to erase a $10.7 billion shortfall in the new state budget before the fiscal year began at 12:01 this morning. 
 Major banks said that for now they would honor the notes as they would regular checks, but they did not say for how long. Sooner or later, if no agreement is reached, the largest state will close schools, parks and libraries and curtail vital state services.
 
Much Finger-Pointing
 "This morning, California is running on empty," Governor Wilson said. He and the Democratic leadership of the Assembly are blaming each other, each party hoping the other will pay a political price this election year.
"We are prepared to wait through the Fourth of July, through the Democratic National Convention, all summer long," said the Governor's chief spokesman, Dan Schnur. "The more headlines in hometown newspapers talk about the mess in Sacramento, the more Democrats with election challenges are going to come to their senses."
The Governor said Democrats were at fault for rebuffing his demand that the state "recapture" about $1 billion that he said it overpaid local school districts last year. The main point of contention was the Governor's proposal to cut public-school support by reducing the number of children entering kindergarten and by other means.
The state's I.O.U.'s were the most dramatic symbol yet of the reversal of fortune for this once-booming state, which has been hit hard by the recession, widespread layoffs by military contractors and the riots in Los Angeles, as well as by earthquakes, fires, floods and drought.
Revenues to pay for the $58 billion spending plan are expected to be $10.7 billion short, including a $2.5 billion shortfall from last year. California's budget gap is about equal to the entire gross national product of Tunisia or Ecuador for 1991.
Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Florida also began the new fiscal year Wednesday without budgets. But none of their problems compare in size to that of California.
Even liberal Democrats are resigned to reducing welfare grants by 4.5 percent, cutting salaries by 4.7 percent in the state's university system, sharply raising student fees and repealing subsidies to local governments for police and fire departments and other services. The Governor wants still deeper cuts, including 15.3 percent from health and welfare spending.
No speedy resolution appeared likely in the standoff between Governor Wilson and the powerful Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco.
The I.O.U.'s mailed out today look like real checks but are printed with a statement saying they cannot be paid "for want of funds" and will not be until the State Treasurer advertises that the cash is in hand. They will pay 5 percent interest. Jay Ziegler, spokesman for Controller Davis, said the warrants are being used first to pay 12,000 state income-tax refunds totaling $4 million and 1,000 contractors due $30 million.
Last year, facing a $14.3 billion gap, Governor Wilson angered his own party and voters by joining Democrats to raise taxes by $7 billion. This year he vowed to veto tax increases.
The Democrats proposed to solve the budget crisis by cutting spending, extending a temporary sales-tax hike passed last year, raising state income taxes by suspending indexing for inflation, and passing a two-year budget in the hope that the economy would improve in the second year.
Mr. Wilson said this amounted to deficit financing, forbidden by the state Constitution. He asked the Legislature to approve a recovery of $1.1 billion given to local school districts under Proposition 98, a voter measure passed in 1988 that guarantees that 40 percent of the state's general-fund spending will go to elementary and secondary schools and community colleges.
On Tuesday, the Democrats agreed to give up on the new taxes and the two-year budget. The state Senate, agreeing to education cuts as preferable to other cuts, passed a budget measure largely acceptable to the Governor. But the whole package bogged down in the more fractious Assembly. The Assembly Democrats agreed to forgo the two-year budget and the tax increases but could not get the 33 Republicans in the 80-member House to go along, and thus could not get the two-thirds vote needed to pass a budget. Then they rejected the school cuts.
"We went two-thirds of the way," said James Lewis, spokesman for Speaker Brown. "We told the Governor all along our bottom line was to protect education. It's time for him to show us he is willing to seek some sort of compromise."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Florida Avoids Crisis
MIAMI, July 1, (Special to The New York Times) -- Florida began the new budget year without a spending plan at 12:01 A.M. yesterday, but by the afternoon a fiscal crisis had been averted when Gov. Lawton Chiles and the state Legislature agreed to a compromise calling for $532.5 million in new taxes and fees.
Governor Chiles, who has been battling lawmakers to increase revenues, had said he was considering shutting down some government operations in order to maintain essential services until an accord was reached.
After twice sending Mr. Chiles budgets without new taxes that he promptly vetoed, legislators reluctantly agreed to a package with $135 million in taxes on stocks and bonds, $109 million in extensions of the state's 6 percent sales tax and a 15 percent tuition increase at state colleges and universities. These, however, fell far short of the $1.35 billion in new taxes that Mr. Chiles had initially sought.
Even before the budget deadline expired today, Mr. Chiles had taken steps to ease the impact of a possible government shutdown. On Tuesday, he signed executive orders promising that essential state employees in law enforcement and health that they would be paid regardless of what happened, and giving his word to other workers they would be paid once a budget was adopted.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis
Focus Is Elusive for Bush
President Is Aimiable in Breakfast-TV Debut But Some Visitors Leave Hungry for Ideas

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
President Bush made his reluctant first foray into breakfast television politics today, an event that gave a taste of the potency of Presidential imagery but at the same time underscored the narrowness of the domestic policy agenda on which he is running.
For nearly 90 minutes on the program "CBS This Morning," Mr. Bush sat among the flower beds and crab apple trees of the majestic Rose Garden, the colonnaded veranda outside the Oval Office framing the shot, and took questions from 125 slightly bewildered tourists who had been plucked by CBS producers from the White House tour line on Tuesday. 
 They questioned him politely but persistently about education, the budget deficit, crime, drugs and family values and seemed hungry, in an amiable, supportive way, for the President to offer new ideas about leading the country.
 
'Hung Up in the Capitol'
 Mr. Bush, who remarked more than once with evident relief that the audience's questions were less "controversial" than reporters' queries, responded by promising action in each area. But instead of offering sweeping initiatives aimed at pressing national problems, Mr. Bush harkened back to legislation that he has long talked about and complained that it was being blocked by Congress.
"How are you going to educate your children? We've got a wonderful program on that," he said, adding that he also had "a great anti-crime, anti-drug program hung up in the Capitol."
In the end, the President was forced to retreat to his argument that he should get another four years because he has worked hard and shown he can handle international crises.
Mr. Bush, who has ridiculed Gov. Bill Clinton for playing his saxophone on late-night television and complained about Ross Perot's appearances on call-in programs, rounded up the children in the audience afterward and gave them a tour of the Oval Office while their parents gaped in astonishment.
White House strategists had designed the event to turn the video politics of 1992 to Mr. Bush's benefit, to show him at ease and in command. Members of the audience, who gave Mr. Bush a standing ovation, said they had been impressed by merely being at the White House and in the presence of the President, who they said seemed personable and eager to answer their questions.
But their enthusiasm and broad questions only seemed to underscore how much trouble the Bush team has had in making the power of Mr. Bush's incumbency work for him, and in developing a public relations strategy that will depict the President as engaged in offering big solutions to big problems.
Torie Clarke, Mr. Bush's campaign press secretary, said the President "talked about the accomplishments of the last three and a half years.
"He talked about low inflation and low interest rates, about historic arms-control agreements," she said, "and he said there are more things we need to do."
But Gary Bauer, head of the Family Research Council, a conservative political organization, said the television appearance seemed to crystalize what is wrong with the Bush campaign.
"This is a year when the trappings of the Presidency are not enough to cause the President to win re-election," Mr. Bauer said. "He's got to come up with a more sharply defined program to offer broadly to the American people, and it just didn't strike me that the vision was there today."
 
Guarding Office's Dignity
 While the Arkansas Governor and Mr. Perot have been getting vast amounts of television time, the President has found it hard to get a flattering sound bite on the evening news. He agreed only reluctantly to the sort of television appearance he made today because he had considered such programs beneath the dignity of his office.
Mr. Bush was clearly reaching for a sense of connection with his audience. "I think people are worried about their future," he said. "People that have a job wonder whether they're going to have it tomorrow."
But Mr. Bush continued to blame Congress for his problems. "I think we've got good programs to correct that," he said. "I will admit to having great difficulty getting them through the Congress."
 
Scoring Some Points
 And in his evident desire to demonstrate sympathy, the President made what may have been a political misstep. Asked at the end of the program about interest rates, Mr. Bush said, "I think every American would like to see them lower -- that includes the President -- because that will stimulate economic growth."
His comments did not take into account the tens of millions of retired people as well as other Americans who live at least partly on investments, such as certificates of deposit, on which income has been cut sharply as banks lowered interest rates to stimulate other sectors of the economy.
The participants' comments -- "warm," "nice" and "trustworthy" were frequently used -- suggested that Mr. Bush managed to project at least part of the image he was seeking.
But his reliance on blaming Congress for what some voters perceive as his own failings seemed to strike a sour note with some members of his audience. Interviewed afterward by the hosts of the program, William Lark, a police officer from Philadelphia, said Mr. Bush was "just passing the buck."
Pat Cardel, a computer programmer from Franklin, Tenn., said she was impressed by Mr. Bush's willingness to answer a variety of questions, but she added that she had heard little she had not heard before.
 
'An Energizer Bunny'
 Lonnie Thomas, 11, told The Associated Press after the Oval Office tour that Mr. Bush was "cool" but long-winded. "He kept going and going and going, just like an Energizer bunny," he said.
Asked bluntly by one member of the audience for a reason to vote for him, Mr. Bush responded with a rambling discourse on his election strategy.
"I think in the final analysis, people are going to say, 'Who has the experience, who has the temperament to take on these big problems day in and day out?' " he said.
"Sometimes at night, the phone rings over there, and I'm going to try to make that case to the American people. Not that I'm perfect, but that I've got a proven record of being tested by fire, and I, I think that's a good qualification. I think that's a good -- good reason to ask for some more time as President."
Michael McCurry, a Democratic political consultant, suggested that this approach may be inadequate at a time when the other candidates are working to sharpen their own ideas.
"Clinton seems to be working on getting some type of message together," he said. "Perot has a lot of message but not a lot of substance. Clinton will continue to work at it, and if Perot comes forward and says, 'I've been working on this hard for the last two months, and this is what I'm going to do,' what is Bush going to say? They have no mechanism in that campaign right now to break through the gridlock that traps them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush during his televised session in the Rose Garden. (CBS via Associated Press)
