HEADLINE: U.S.-French Relations Turn Icy After Cold War

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 1

 BODY:
As a meeting in Washington on May 11 between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, went from bad to worse, an exasperated Mr. Baker asked bluntly, "Are you for us or against us?"
The remark, contained in an official French transcript of the meeting, underscores the mutual suspicion, even outright anger, which has come to characterize relations between France and the United States in recent months. While tensions between the two countries have long existed, it appears that the end of the cold war has brought a new level of mistrust. 
 "There is extreme irritation on both sides," a senior French official, who read extracts from a transcript of the Baker-Dumas meeting, said on condition of anonymity. "We cannot accept that world diplomacy should be a one-man show, while Washington seems convinced that our reflections on the future of Europe are necessarily anti-American."
Relations have become so troublesome that senior French officials said they tried for several weeks to persuade President Bush to come to Paris and hold talks with President Francois Mitterrand on his way to the annual summit meeting of the Group of Seven leading industrial democracies, next week in Munich, Germany. But United States officials said the President's agenda was too crowded.
 
Bush-Mitterrand Meeting
 A private dinner between the two leaders is now planned in Munich in an effort to resolve what one American official called "a whole lot of difficulties in recent months."
Among the many sources of friction are the new French-German army corps, which France sees as as the embryo of a potential European army; a festering quarrel in the world trade talks over French agricultural subsidies; differences on environmental policy; American demands for more trans-Atlantic air routes, and French insistence that Europe play a more independent role in issues ranging from the Balkan fighting to the Middle East peace talks.
The barbed state of relations was illustrated this week when France's European Affairs Minister, Elisabeth Guigou, compared Mr. Mitterrand's decision to visit besieged Sarajevo, disparagingly with what she called Washington's rhetoric on the Balkan war. "We in France prefer to remain sober and act," she said.
According to several officials, difficulties have been compounded by the fact that Mr. Baker and Mr. Dumas have trouble concealing their personal dislike for each other. Mr. Baker's blunt Texas style grates on Mr. Dumas, who is a study in the use of nuance.
 
New Tensions
 The two Presidents get along much better, and President Bush called President Mitterrand on Tuesday to praise him for his courage in going to Sarajevo. But the closeness they established during the Persian Gulf war has been undermined by the recent tensions, the officials said.
Strains between the two countries have long existed. But while differences were mostly contained during the cold war within the broad sense that the countries saw eye to eye on the key issues, that certainty now seems to have fallen away in a Europe that the French hope may become as powerful as the United States.
France has been a main force in pushing for greater European unity, and Mr. Mitterrand announced today that the French referendum on a treaty leading to the monetary and political union of the European Community will be held on Sept. 20.
Mr. Mitterrand decided to put the European unity issue directly to the French voters after Danish voters rejected the treaty. Since the Danish referendum, Irish voters have endorsed the treaty.
While the United Staes has formally supported the push for European union, some aspects of the drive are worrying to Washington.
"The two countries have a rather different vision of the future," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. "The U.S. sees continuing having substantial influence in Europe. The French want some U.S. presence, but in a Europe that can carry far more weight. I don't think the views are irreconcilable, but they are far less convergent than during the cold war."
Nowhere has this lack of convergence been more apparent than in military matters.
At the heart of the heated exchange on May 11 between Mr. Baker and Mr. Dumas lay NATO, and particularly the question of how threatening the 35,000-man joint French-German army corps could be to the future of the Atlantic alliance.
France contends that the force, which it sees as the potential core of an army for a united Europe, is an essential response to a changed world in which the United States military presence in Europe is being cut and Europe will have to take more responsibility for its own defense. The number of United States forces in Europe has already been reduced from 320,000 in 1990 to about 200,000 now.
French Government officials do not conceal their desire that what they call the "Eurocorps" grow to embrace other countries. "Maybe soon it will be a four-country corps," Defense Minister Pierre Joxe said this week. "The idea is to enlarge."
But the United States and other European countries, including Britain and the Netherlands, are deeply concerned that the French-German force will undermine NATO, and they question exactly what its future mission is to be.
"How do NATO command-and-control mechanisms fit in with this Eurocorps?" asked one American official. "Which hat do the German soldiers wear? Whom do they report to? Are they under NATO? Over NATO? We need answers."
The Germans, ever cautious over postwar perceptions of rearmament and treading a fine line between their American and French allies, answer that the corps does not weaken NATO, which remains the cornerstone of European security, and that if anything it brings French soldiers closer to NATO.
 
Americans Leaving Anyway
 "It's not the Eurocorps that's encouraging American soldiers to leave Europe," said one official close to President Mitterrand. "They're leaving anyway. We need some of them to remain, of course, just as the U.S. needs a strong Europe with France and Germany at the center of it."
Jean Daniel, editor of the weekly magazine Le Nouvel Observateur and a man who has the ear of President Mitterrand, compared the American anger at the French talk of a European army to "a father who has told his son to emancipate himself and then starts telling him that he is ungrateful."
But Mr. Baker articulated a different vision in the meeting with Mr. Dumas, telling the French Foreign Minister: "I am sure you want U.S. troops to remain in Europe, but you doubt our capacity to stay there."
The delicate question now apparently facing President Bush and President Mitterrand is how to manage the post-cold-war transition in a way that maintains the fundamental identity of interest between the two countries that has in the past outweighed their differences. Most American and French officials believe the balancing act is possible, but concede that a new phase in relations has opened.
"The danger," said Mr. Hormats of Goldman Sachs, "is that if the notion persists that Europe and particularly France want to go its own way militarily, a lot of people here may want to cut troops a lot more than Europe actually wants."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Accord With Mazda Is Completed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 1

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company has completed the purchase of a half interest in the Mazda Motor Corporation's $760 million auto assembly plant in Flat Rock, Mich., the auto makers announced today.
The plant 25 miles south of Detroit assembles 240,000 cars a year including the Ford Probe and the Mazda 626 and MX-6. Opened in 1987, Flat Rock has 3,500 employees. 
 The deal apparently grew out of recession-pinched Mazda's need for cash and Ford's desire for more control over production of the Probe, said Chris Cedergren, an analyst at Autopacific Group Inc. in Thousand Oaks, Calif.
 
Avoiding Leftovers
 Under Mazda's full ownership of Flat Rock, Ford was committed to buy a fixed number of Probes a year regardless of demand, Mr. Cedergren said.
"Last year, they couldn't sell that stated level, and they ended up with a big inventory of leftover Probes," he said.
The slowed Japanese economy has cut into car sales and sent auto makers there looking for money, Mr. Cedergren said.
"All Japanese manufacturers have been hit pretty hard by the recession," he said. "Mazda could use an infusion of capital right now."
Ford bought a 25 percent stake in Mazda in 1979. Since then, the companies have collaborated on a number of joint projects. Last month, Ford increased its stake in a Ford-Mazda company that sells Fords in Japan.
Mazda also makes Ford Laser and Telstar models in Japan, while Ford makes the Mazda Navajo at its Louisville, Ky., plant. And next spring, Ford will begin supplying Mazda with 80,000 to 100,000 pickup trucks a year based on the Ranger model.
The companies announced tentative plans for the Flat Rock plant deal in April. They said they completed the transaction Tuesday after receiving approval from the United States Justice Department.
Ford and Mazda created a joint subsidiary, Auto Alliance International Inc., to run the plant in place of the Mazda subsidiary, Mazda Motor Manufacturing U.S.A. Corporation.
The companies named W. Wayne Booker, Ford vice president for Asia-Pacific auto operations, as chairman of Auto Alliance. Mamoru Takebayashi, who had been executive vice president of Mazda U.S.A., was named the subsidiary's president.
In related moves, Masahiro Uchida, the former Mazda U.S.A. president, was named senior director of Mazda in Japan, where he will oversee the auto maker's overseas operations, and Konen Suzuki, Ford of Japan president, was named president of Autorama Inc., the Ford-Mazda company that sells Ford models in Japan.
Ford shares fell 50 cents, to $45.375 today, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Separately, Ford said it was cutting the price of its 1993 model Mercury Tracer station wagon by $234 as part of a plan to expand a "one-price" strategy that is used to sell Ford Escort small cars.
Effective immediately, Ford will sell well-equipped versions of both its Tracer sedans and wagons for $11,665, excluding a $200 rebate in effect until Sept. 23.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As a senior director of Mazda in Japan, Masahiro Uchida will oversee the company's overseas operations. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: JAPANESE PLEDGES PUSH FOR GROWTH

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
In their first meeting since President Bush's ill-fated trip to Tokyo in January, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa promised Mr. Bush today that he would use "every possible means" to expand his country's domestic growth to stimulate more markets for American exports.
Mr. Miyazawa stopped over in Washington for consultations with Mr. Bush in advance of the meeting next week in Munich of the leaders of seven major industrial democracies. It was also an effort to put an end to the bout of name-calling and mutual accusations of unfair trade practices. 
 The January meeting was widely viewed as a disaster after Mr. Bush collapsed and vomited at a state dinner, an attack attributed to the flu. Relations were aggravated when the Japanese rebuffed pressure from the President, and from the heads of the Big Three auto makers whom he brought along, to buy American cars.
Today, both sides were determined not to have a repetition of that, and they left any airing of differences to private meetings, In public, they emphasized only the positives, and were all smiles.
 
Miyazawa Speaks in English
 Mr. Miyazawa set the tone, taking the unusual step for a visiting foreign dignitary of delivering his statement after their meeting in English, which he speaks fluently.
He began: "This is my first official visit to the United States as Prime Minister. I am delighted to have this opportunity to speak directly to the American people, for whom I have profound respect. Today, I am also very pleased that as an ally and a friend I have had very frank and productive talks with President Bush."
Japanese officials said Mr. Miyazawa outlined to President Bush a readiness to introduce a supplementary budget later this year that the Japanese press says would provide $47 billion to $55 billion to stimulate the nation's ailing economy. Details of that plan, though, remain sketchy, because the Prime Minister and his Liberal Democratic Party must still agree on the exact size and timing.
While the Prime Minister's promise was hailed by Mr. Bush, many economists pointed out that such Japanese economic stimulants would primarily focus on major public works, like bridges and roads, and that those are areas where it will not be easy for American companies to take part.
Mr. Miyazawa said Mr. Bush "on his part, expressed his determination to reduce the budget deficit and to raise the competitiveness of the U.S. industries."
The President did not spell out how he would fulfill such commitments, but he pronounced himself satisfied with the Japanese growth proposals. This has been a recurring pattern in American-Japanese relations, where Tokyo makes specific promises while Washington makes general ones, like reducing the deficit and increasing spending on research and development.
The Japanese commitment comes at a time when American officials are concerned over the rising trade deficit, despite a series of market-opening agreements with Japan. Last year's deficit was $43 billion, and this year's is running a little ahead of that, reaching $15 billion in the first four months. This is deeply troubling to White House officials in an election year.
"I'm encouraged by what the Prime Minister told me about Japan's plans to stimulate economic growth," Mr. Bush said in their joint appearance in the White House Rose Garden. "I had a chance to fill him in on ours. Both of us confirmed our desire for a strong and lasting recovery."
After their closing statements, Mr. Bush took Mr. Miyazawa by helicopter to Camp David, Md., for informal talks.
 
U.S. Aides Defend January Trip
 American officials argue that while the trip in January was awkward, it has had some positive results. They point out that the Ford Motor Company just bought 50 percent of Mazda's plant in the United States in order to produce a right-hand-drive Ford Probe intended almost entirely for Japanese export.
The officials said Toyota will soon be opening a supplier support center in Lexington, Ky., which will keep American auto-parts producers up to date on developments in Toyota technology, so that they will be better positioned to bid on contracts.
Two areas where Japan has not opened its market as much as American officials expected have been in computer semiconductors and glass. The Japanese promised to give American companies 20 percent of their semiconductor market, and the level today is around 14 percent. American glass companies have only about 1 percent of the Japanese market.
The two sides also discussed the dispute between Japan and Russia over four northern islands that the Soviet Union seized from the Japanese at the end of World War II.
The Americans have in principle supported Tokyo's insistence that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia acknowledge that the islands belong to Japan before it provides large-scale aid. Still, American officials would welcome Tokyo's adopting a more flexible position, since it is a major industrial democracy with enough cash to bolster the Yeltsin Government.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher After Reversing Early Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher against other currencies yesterday, erasing an early fall as traders bought the currency to cover short positions -- sales of borrowed holdings made in expectation of being able to pay them back at a lower price.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $344.30, up $1.20 an ounce from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $1 to a late bid of $344. 
 The dollar fell in overseas trading, and after domestic markets opened it was depressed further by a report that showed slower-than-expected economic growth.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index of business activity fell sharply to 52.8 percent last month from 56.3 percent in May. Sluggish economic activity usually hurts the dollar's value against other currencies.
But the dollar recovered in the afternoon as traders covered short positions to prepare for today's release of employment figures for June, said John McCarthy, chief dealer with Algemene Bank Nederland in New York.
The jobs report normally is released on the first Friday of the month but was pushed ahead by the July 4 holiday, which is being celebrated a day early in the financial markets.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.43 yen, down 0.12 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.90 yen. In New York, one dollar bought 125.40 yen, down from 125.60 yen late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9111 from $1.9030 late Tuesday. But in New York, one pound cost $1.9055, cheaper than $1.9060 the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5230 German marks, up from 1.5215; 1.3700 Swiss francs, down from 1.3710; 5.1245 French francs, up from 5.1180; 1,152.50 Italian lire, up from 1,150.50; and 1.20245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1985.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Need Zionism Equal Socialism?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ISRAEL'S Labor Party surprised the experts by trouncing the ruling Likud coalition in last week's elections. Could the torch bearers of the Zionist welfare state surprise them once again by transforming Israel into a modern free-market economy?
The prospect seems bizarre: foxes generally can't be expected to spruce up the chicken coop. But these foxes have learned pragmatism -- and they are certainly aware that Israel's security and capacity to absorb Jewish immigrants turn as much on its economic productivity as its military prowess. "This is the best chance in years to reform the economy," concludes Howard Rosen of the Institute for International Economics. 
 Israeli Socialism has never much resembled the house that Marx and Lenin built. Price controls did not generate chronic shortages; neither private ownership nor the accumulation of wealth was actively discouraged. But the inclination to find a bureaucratic solution for every economic problem left Israel almost as unprepared as the East bloc for the global economic free-for-all of the 1970's and 1980's. The skills needed to design a computer chip faster than NEC or build a jet fighter for less money than General Dynamics apparently aren't the same as those needed to make the desert bloom.
Economic stagnation explains in part why Israeli voters turned to the conservative Likud Party in the late 1970's. In contrast to the intellectual mandarins of Labor, Likud's tough nationalists owed nothing to organized labor or to Socialist ideology.
But those who expected a new Singapore to rise from the ashes were disappointed, for the business of governing Israel's fragmented parliamentary democracy is the business of perpetual coalition-building. And while Likud partisans can point to some victories in lowering tariffs and deregulating markets, the temptation to win new friends by protecting old sinecures proved irresistible.
Privatization of some $5 billion worth of state enterprises, for example, was put on indefinite hold because both jobs and bureaucratic turf were threatened. And just last month, Jerusalem forgave the debts of some hopelessly inefficient farm cooperatives. Over all, argues Stanley Fischer, an M.I.T. professor and former chief economist at the World Bank, the Likud years represented a "wasted opportunity by a Government that should have known better."
Why is the new old gang likely to make a difference? For one thing, Prime Minister-designate Yitzhak Rabin has pledged to slow Jewish settlements in the disputed territories. That could free as much as $600 million to $800 million that was being invested annually in housing, roads and basic services for the West Bank settlers -- no small change for an economy only one-hundredth the size of America's. For another, the Bush Administration is likely to reward Mr. Rabin with at least a part of the $10 billion in requested loan guarantees on top of the current $3 billion annual aid package.
The guarantees are no longer desperately needed to cover the costs of large-scale immigration, because the immigrants are no longer coming; just a trickle of Russia's highly educated Jews, it seems, are willing to fight for decent jobs in an economy with 12 percent unemployment. But Michael Bruno, the former head of the Bank of Israel, argues that the formal blessing by Washington would still give Israeli investors a psychological lift and reduce the cost of borrowing.
The make-it-or-break-it question, though, is whether Labor will be able to sweep aside the rubble of state control and allow free markets to flourish. Mr. Rabin will be in no position to build a wall between economic policy and interest-group politics.
Like the last Government, notes Mr. Rosen, "Labor will have to buy the coalition." And the piece of the coalition that could prove most expensive is the union movement -- more accurately, the money-hemhorraging social insurance systems operated by the unions.
But Mr. Bruno believes that high unemployment has eroded union power. And last year's effective privatization of the unions' bankrupt business empire, Koor Industries, suggests that organized labor no longer always gets what it wants.
In the end, the Labor Party's greatest asset may prove to be its pragmatism. Unlike the last Government, this one will not obsessed with the vision of a Greater Israel and will thus not be inclined to pay a heavy economic price for ideological support from fringe parties. Nor is it likely to operate under the illusion that it can stay in power long if it does not deliver what Likud never managed: a living standard approaching Northern Europe's.
"This is the 90's, not the 60's," concludes Mr. Bruno. The old rules no longer apply.
Mr. Fischer agrees: If big government in Poland, Argentina and Mexico can embrace free markets, he asks, why not Israel?

HEADLINE: Discrepancies In N.F.L. Revenue

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, July 1

 BODY:
Roger Noll, a Stanford University economics professor, testified today in the National Football League antitrust trial that the league's reported $1.3 billion in revenue for 1990 was "substantially understated" because of the way the owners do their books.
He said his research found that the N.F.L. reported 1990 total operating expenses of $411 million. Operating profits were reported as $163 million, but Noll said the profits were shielded from costs such as the $600,000 per team contributed to the World League of American Football and two antitrust lawsuits that are "the costs of defending and maintaining a monopoly." 
 Noll said his analysis of the N.F.L.'s financial statement showed that Norman Braman, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, paid himself a salary of $7.5 million for 1990. That salary was recorded as general expenses, when it could have been counted as profit for Braman, Noll told the jury.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
House Votes to Eliminate Money for Regulatory Council Headed by Quayle

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
In a pointed rebuke to the Bush Administration's environmental and labor policies, the House voted today to cut all financing for the Council on Competitiveness, the regulatory review board headed by Vice President Dan Quayle.
The action came as a response to the Administration's growing aggressiveness in narrowing environmental regulations that it says prevent businesses from expanding. The council, which seeks to reduce or eliminate rules that it believes decrease trade competitiveness, only last week dismayed many lawmakers on Capitol Hill by recommending that companies be allowed to increase emissions of air pollutants. 
 The vote was one of a handful of real votes today as Congress negotiated and postured over a wide range of issues. There was almost an end-of-session pace to the activity, as the Senate planned to take off two weeks after Thursday's session. The House only planned a long weekend for the Fourth of July, but had worked late Tuesday and was in a cranky mood as it approached another long night today.
The House, on a 236-to-183 vote, defeated a Republican amendment that would have provided financing for the council. The amendment was intended to reverse an earlier Appropriations Committee decision. The Senate still must vote on the issue.
Attacking the council during a partisan floor debate, Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon, said: "It has watered down restrictions on worker exposure to cancer-causing chemicals. It has delayed requirements for employers to report work-related deaths and injuries."
Representative Andy Ireland, Republican of Florida, defended the council, saying that cutting back on financing for the council "would be devastating to small business and our economy."
The House vote to end financing of the council came as part of a $22.8 billion appropriations bill for financing operations of the Treasury Department, the Postal Service and the President's executive offices. The bill was approved, 237 to 166. While the measure is $275.7 million less than the President requested, it still represents an increase of $2.9 billion over last year's budget.
The President had requested an appropriation of about $85,000 for the council and some other executive office expenses.
Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, the Democratic chairman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee that will deal with the bill, said he would not move to strike financing for the council, even though "Quayle and Bush have used it politically." Should the Senate follow Mr. DeConcini's lead, differing Senate and House bills would have to be reconciled in conference.
Mr. Quayle himself lobbied on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to retain financing for the council. He said, "This is simply a political ploy by partisan Democrats who want to give power to the unelected Federal bureaucracy instead of to the elected leaders of the executive branch."

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's X Percent Solution

 BODY:
President Bush bristles at the criticism that voters can't find his domestic agenda. He reminds audiences that he's sent scores of bills to Capitol Hill -- on crime, education, welfare reform, tax cuts. But people don't pay attention, he says, because this is "a weird political year."
On CBS's "This Morning" yesterday, he called attention to his program, one that "controls the growth of mandatory spending. . . . And we have a program. It's there. It's definitive." In an interview last week with The Times, he challenged the idea that only Bill Clinton has offered a coherent economic plan. His Administration has "32 pages of alternatives and options up there right now before the Senate." 
 In principle, the President has a point. The problem is that he has not pursued it in practice.
What is his "definitive" program? In the 1,000-page Federal budget for 1993, Budget Director Richard Darman devotes 2 1/2 pages to the idea of limiting mandatory spending -- spending for programs that automatically continue from year to year -- by a formula accounting for inflation and population growth.
It's a conscientious idea, but nowhere do Mr. Darman or his President suggest how they would cut spending to fit the formula. Would Mr. Bush charge retirees higher Medicare premiums? Would he cut back food stamps? He never says.
The 32-page plan Mr. Bush cited in the Times interview turns out to be a booklet advocating the balanced budget amendment. It consists mainly of charts; only three pages describe policies, largely a laundry list. Some proposals, like the one for health care reform, are innovative but lack tough measures needed to work. Others, like education and urban aid, involve so little money they can't possibly achieve their lofty goals.
This document describes Mr. Bush's proposal for a cap on mandatory spending in a few lines, none detailed. Indeed, the cap is described only as growth of "X%" after accounting for the impact of inflation and population growth. It's not hard to see why voters fail to understand where the President stands, not when he flaunts "definitive" solutions of X percent.
Though sketchy, Candidate Bush's proposal to cap mandatory spending is a responsible idea for controlling the deficit. Too bad that, in 42 months, President Bush has done so little to achieve it.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Hamilton Era?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Barring surprises like being elected Vice President, Lee Hamilton will become chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee next year. His career and character suggest he could spark far-reaching changes in how U.S. foreign policy is made and in the policy sausage that oozes from this new grinder.
Look for an end to the traditionally cozy connection between the White House and the chairman of the House panel. Look for stunning proposals to reorganize Washington's foreign policy machinery, including perhaps eliminating the enfeebled Agency for International Development. Look for a drive to recast priorities, much more economic emphasis and much less military-mindedness. 
 The Indiana Democrat does not want his approaches confused with isolationism. "I want the United States to be a world leader," he told me. "I don't agree with those who think we should play a reduced role in foreign affairs."
His goals could readily vaporize in the hands of a less determined and knowledgeable politician. But Mr. Hamilton, though gentlemanly and soft-spoken, also seems to have the steel and skill to be a powerhouse.
What, then, could derail a Hamilton era in the House, one that might rival and even exceed William Fulbright's mastery of Senate debate during the Vietnam War?
Bill Clinton could choose Mr. Hamilton as his running mate. But joining the ticket would not force the Congressman to abandon his safe seat. Indiana law, unusually, permits running for both offices. So even if a Clinton-Hamilton ticket loses, Mr. Hamilton almost certainly would be back in Congress.
Committee Republicans could fight Hamilton reforms. That is not likely either. Benjamin Gillman of upstate New York will replace the retiring William Broomfield as the ranking Republican, and Mr. Gillman is a genial man with no strong policy agenda. That leaves fellow Midwesterners Jim Leach and Jeff Bereuter as two key G.O.P. players, and both lean toward Mr. Hamilton's ideas. Only Henry Hyde, a partisan infighter, promises to be a problem.
Mr. Hamilton's strongest opposition could come from the institutional inertia of the committee itself. Congressional committees tend to develop their own styles. The House Armed Services Committee, for example, has been an independent and highly centralized operation since the days of Southern barons Carl Vinson and Mendel Rivers. This perfectly suits Les Aspin, the current chairman of that panel.
But the House Foreign Affairs Committee has traditionally been a far more decentralized operation -- dating back decades from the leadership of "Doc" Morgan and Clement Zablocki to its present leader, Dante Fascell, who will retire in December. Under their loose reign, subcommittee chairmen tended to go their separate ways.
Mr. Hamilton, however, has the necessary sway among Democrats to gather power in the committee as a whole. Stephen Solarz, who will be the number two Democrat on the panel if re-elected, is unlikely to challenge him. Besides, at least 7 of the top 11 Democrats on the committee will not be back next year.
Nonetheless, Mr. Hamilton cannot ignore the even deeper Morgan-Zablocki-Fascell tradition of helping out the White House. Since World War II, Presidents of both parties often got grief from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, but could count on its House counterpart. The House committee help proved decisive on crunch issues like Vietnam.
More recently, Mr. Fascell rounded up crucial Democratic votes for aid to the contras in Nicaragua and President Bush's decision to use force against Iraq. Mr. Hamilton opposed contra aid and favored giving economic sanctions more time before attacking Saddam Hussein.
Lee Hamilton is far less likely than his predecessors to salute a desperate call from the White House. He will listen, politely and seriously as always, then make up his own mind.
Besides his independence, Mr. Hamilton's greatest strength is also his weakness. He is an educator, a persuader. He believes in exposing the facts and issues, then engaging in reasoned debate. That gift was sufficient for Senator Fulbright gradually to shift public attitudes toward the Vietnam War. But it was not enough to win legislative battles.
To fulfill his promise, Mr. Hamilton will have to go beyond teaching -- and put his legislative mark on machinery and policy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Essay;
Latest From Olympus

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Let me set down my muckrake for a moment to don Olympian robes and deliver a thumbsucker: Whither the Presidential campaign of 1992?
Clear the palate: What is the campaign not mainly about? Contrary to what you have been told, it is not primarily about vague themes like "character" or "leadership" or "change," nor ideological differences, nor health plans or abortion rights or deficit reduction, nor fears of endless recession. 
 This campaign is, first, about your assessment of George Bush's Presidency -- whether you trust his old-shoe experience to keep the nation out of major trouble.
Second, it is about your willingness to risk the alternatives. (Political scientists use the Henny Youngman formulation: "How's your wife?" "Compared to what?") This is a personal choice, in which personalities count heavily, but your central decision is whether to accept or reject George Bush.
Ignore all polls, which at this stage are only misleading. Scorn all other pundits who see this as a close three-way race, titillating each other with visions of an Electoral College dropout into the House; it's fun as a civics lesson but it won't happen.
What will happen to the three campaigns is this:
President Bush will not really bottom out until he returns from Europe and the Democratic Convention ends in mid-July. He faces further downward pressure from the coming call for an Iraqgate special prosecutor and from sluggish economic growth, but like Rommel in retreat, he gathers strength for a counterattack. The story around Labor Day will be the new signs of life in an underdog President and confidence about his steadiness in debate.
As the novelty wears off, as summer wears on, and as more troubling facts emerge about Ross Perot's manipulations, Perotmania will ebb. The outrage groupies from the Buchanan and Brown camps will continue to lionize their latest protest vehicle, but his expensive midnight-in-America ad campaign will fizzle, and the large "I'm-only-looking" element of his support will remain only tentatively committed.
Bill Clinton's convention in New York will be adjudged a success, compared with the 1988 debacle; his acceptance speech will also shine by comparison with his speech then. Blacks will be on board, with or without Jesse Jackson, but women and ethnics and flags will predominate; viewers will not feel threatened, and Democrats will no longer think of their candidate as a young stranger.
Come the fall, polls, debates and the competition-loving media may preserve the illusion of a three-way race. But let us keep our eye on the central dynamic of the campaign -- yes or no to Bush -- which will ultimately force anti-Bush voters to dump the weaker anti-Bush candidate.
Added urgency will be given them to switch to the strongest by the Bush comeback in the finally significant polls. By picking up a good portion of the undecided-about-Bush vote, the President will draw ahead of the second and third candidates, who at first split the undecideds-about-Bush.
Conservative women who feel strongly about abortion rights will also have to decide "most likely to beat Bush" and will choose pro-choice Clinton over pro-choice-but Perot; they will far outnumber Democratic or independent women who are anti-abortion enough to switch to Bush.
Toward the end, with Bush leading, the third man's vote will "break," much as George Wallace's 24 percent in the polls broke to 14 percent on Election Day in 1968; in that case, the majority of Wallaceite union members went home to the Democrats, enabling Hubert Humphrey almost to catch Nixon at the finish line.
The way the Perot protest support breaks will decide the election. This means that the early peace between Clinton and Perot, as both pound Bush, will turn into a furious don't-waste-your-vote altercation at the end, as Bush's opponents pound each other. That's why the Perot vote will ultimately shrink to one-half the Clinton vote, despite equal advertising.
Will this give Clinton enough to catch Bush and win? We here on Olympus know the answer, of course, but that would require revealing the stunning, unexpected event that will take place in the run-up to Halloween, which I am not at liberty to vouchsafe to readers at this time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: First Airlifted Food Supplies Reach a Needy Sarajevo

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 1

 BODY:
The first food supplies to reach Sarajevo's 400,000 hungry residents by the tenuous air bridge opened earlier in the week were distributed today, but major problems continued to hinder plans to broaden the effort into a full-scale airlift.
The problems include the continuing fighting in areas near the airport and the fact that Sarajevo continues to be bombarded by Serbian guns on the hills surrounding the city, despite pledges of a cease-fire from Serbian leaders. 
 Among senior officials of the Bosnian Government, which is resisting Serbian attempts to carve out wide areas of the republic for an "ethnically pure" Serbian republic, there is still a widespread conviction that sustaining the airlift, and saving Sarajevo, will ultimately require some form of direct Western military intervention.
Disappointment at the failure of Western nations to intervene has been such that few people in Sarajevo took much notice of the Bush Administration's announcement on Tuesday that it is prepared to use United States air and naval units in support of an international military effort if fighting interferes with the airlift.
With five people killed in Sarajevo on Tuesday by Serbian snipers, and other casualties from the continuing bombardments by heavier guns, there is still widespread dismay that Western nations are not yet ready to do anything concrete to halt the relentless Serbian attacks on civilians.
 
Smiles on Refugees' Faces
 In the Skenderija sports hall, where medal ceremonies were held for the 1984 Winter Olympic Games, officials of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees worked with local relief agencies to distribute French military ration packs to about 1,500 Muslim refugees.
Trucks also delivered eight tons of long-life milk and medical supplies to the Kosevo hospital complex, where many of the sick and wounded from the three-month siege are being treated.
The smiles on the faces of the refugees were a testament to the relief felt around the city at the breakthrough achieved by the United Nations officials in taking control of Sarajevo airport from Serbian nationalist forces.
But after the four French military aircraft that flew in on Monday and Tuesday, there were no new relief flights today and only a trickle of flights, at best, was expected before security arrangements at the airport are improved, possibly this weekend.
The United Nations military force at the Butmir airfield on the southwest outskirts of Sarajevo needs to be built up to the point where a credible defense can be mounted against possible attempts to disrupt the airlift.
Today, the skeleton crew of about 30 officers and technical personnel who took over the airport on Monday were strengthened by the arrival of nearly 170 French marines, 120 of them on four French military planes and nearly 50 others in the United Nations weekly overland convoy from Belgrade, the Serbian capital.
Full control of the airport and its perimeter will only be possible when an 850-member Canadian armored battalion arrives from Croatia, where the battalion was involved in a separate United Nations peacekeeping exercise related to last year's Croatian war.
 
200-Mile Journey
 But the Canadians' 200-mile journey, in a convoy of 300 vehicles that include 80 tracked personnel carriers, has been repeatedly interrupted by local warlords in northern Bosnia, and the Canadian convoy was still five hours away from Sarajevo when it halted tonight.
Maj. Gen. Lewis W. MacKenzie of Canada, the United Nations commander in Sarajevo, said arrangements had been worked out with the Bosnian Government for the Canadian soldiers to take a route across backroads that will take them around some of the barricades put up by rival Serbian and Croatian militia groups.
The fact that the operation has gone as far as it has, with four flights carrying 38 tons having made it into the airport since Monday, is due largely to the personal initiative of President Francois Mitterrand of France and his Health Minister, Bernard Kouchner, who visited here on Sunday.
But to some, including senior officials of the Bush Administration and of several other European governments, the French initiatives have had an air of scene-stealing. For months before Mr. Mitterrand's visit here, France had resisted sanctions against Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia for its role in the killing here. More recently Paris vacillated, along with other European nations, in assessing what to do.
One senior United Nations official put it succinctly as the French food packs were distributed today. "What's been broken here is not just hunger, but the siege psychology," he said. "These people finally have the feeling that somebody out there cares."
The United Nations has much to worry about as it prepares for the full-scale airlift, which is expected to involve American, British and German military aircraft, as well as some planes chartered by relief agencies.
As matters stand, the entire operation could be interrupted or destroyed by any of a number of factors, each related to the fact that there is no cease-fire around Sarajevo, much less any prospect of a broader peace in the war across Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Lord Carrington, chairman of the European Community's conference on Yugoslavia, is expected here on Friday. He will try to persuade the Serbian nationalist leaders and the Bosnian Government to resume negotiations under Portuguese mediation for a peace settlement.
The negotiations broke down in May when President Alija Izetbegovic, his capital being progressively destroyed by Serbian attacks, walked out of talks in Lisbon.
The war, and the widespread atrocities committed by the Serbian forces, has hardened opinion among Muslims and Croats, and the Bosnian Government issued a new political charter over the weekend in which it rejected any future division of the republic among ethnic lines.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Agrees to Contribute Planes
WASHINGTON, July 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United States agreed today to contribute two military cargo planes to the United Nations effort to deliver relief supplies to Sarajevo.
But both President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d repeated the Administration's opposition to committing ground combat troops.
"It's right for the United States not to go ramming in as the sole perpetrator of force," Mr. Bush said in an interview on the "CBS This Morning" program. "Yes, we have two task forces right now in the Mediterranean. I have no plans at this juncture to use those forces."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
American Takes Yugoslav Post
 The Bush Administration cleared the way yesterday for an American business executive of Serbian origin to become the Prime Minister of the truncated Yugoslavia.
Milan Panic, chairman of ICN Pharmaceuticals, a conglomerate based in Costa Mesa, Calif., said he received word that the Treasury Department had exempted him from American sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia by executive order last month.
The sanctions, economic and political, are intended to bring pressure on the Serbian leadership of President Slobodan Milosevic to cease attacks against Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Mr. Panic was asked to accept the Prime Minister's post two weeks ago by Dobrica Cosic, the new Yugoslav President, who is a novelist. Mr. Cosic's candidacy was pushed by Mr. Milosevic.
The new Yugoslav Government retains authority only in the republics of Serbia and Montenegro.
Asked how he intended to deal with the Milosevic leadership, Mr. Panic said: "I think that will be resolved in the form that power will be transferred to us -- Defense, the Interior Ministry, Foreign Affairs."
Initially Mr. Panic, who is 62 years old, expressed strong reservations about the job, saying he would do it only if he received support from broad sections of Serbian society, including opposition political parties.
Aides to Mr. Panic said President Bush and Mr. Baker had approved the exemption without specifically endorsing the businessman's candidacy.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 3, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about tensions between the United States and France referred incorrectly to Sarajevo in some editions. It is in Bosnia and Herzegovina, not Yugoslavia.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: Feeling Pressure, Cheney Agrees To Allow Work on Novel Aircraft

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Yielding to political pressure from powerful members of Congress, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today reversed his decision to kill one of the Pentagon's most expensive new weapon systems.
The decision to devote $1.5 billion to development of the V-22 Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off like a helicopter and flies like a plane, is both a substantive and symbolic retreat by Mr. Cheney from Pentagon budget-trimming plans that have been strenuously resisted by Congress. 
 Congress has been of two minds on military spending. While wanting to pare the Pentagon budget so that money could be diverted to domestic programs, many lawmakers have been reluctant to make deep cuts in military spending during an election year, worried that it would hurt Pentagon contractors and increase unemployment in their districts.
The Osprey has already figured in the Presidential campaign, and Mr. Cheney's decision could well help Mr. Bush's re-election prospects, particularly in the states where the plane is being developed, Texas and Pennsylvania, each of which has a large number of electoral votes. The Osprey, is being developed by Bell Helicopter Textron in Fort Worth and Boeing Helicopters in Delaware County, Pennsylvania, just outside Philadelphia.
The companies developing the Osprey had cut back manufacturing plans during the stalemate between the Pentagon and the Congress over the V-22 program, according to press reports.
Several hundred workers were reported to be now assigned to the program, but a decision to go into production would create thousands of jobs and encourage the development of the plane for commercial transport purposes, creating still more employment.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the probable Democratic Presidential nominee, had endorsed the development of the Osprey, saying it might have important commercial applications.
Mr. Cheney, who made the Osprey a symbol of the Defense Department's ability to cancel costly weapons programs that have powerful constituencies on Capitol Hill and in the military, has repeatedly criticized the program as too costly. He has complained that the prototype aircraft was 3,000 pounds over its weight limit.
But today, the Defense Secretary backed down, proposing a compromise in a letter to Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader. Under the proposed compromise, about $1.5 billion would be spent in the fiscal years 1992 and 1993 to develop the V-22 and to begin a program to develop a alternative helicopter. A final decision whether to go for the Osprey or for the new helicopter would be decided in the future, Mr. Cheney wrote.
The effect of Mr. Cheney's decision is to maintain some momentum behind the program to develop the V-22 plane, while withholding final judgment on buying the aircraft for the armed forces.
The compromise echoes a similar agreement that was reached on May 21 to keep the Seawolf submarine program alive and keep shipbuilding jobs in Connecticut. President Bush had wanted to terminate a contract to build two submarines, but Congress voted to build only one. Mr. Bush then accepted the scaled-down project.
If the Pentagon and Congress ultimately decide to buy the plane on the basis of the program's merits or as a result of political pressures, tens of billions of dollars would probably be spent on the plane. The original plan, which Mr. Cheney deemed to be unwise and too costly, was to buy more than 500 of the V-22's. Mr. Cheney said today that the estimated cost of the program had soared to about $30 billion.
The Pentagon's insistence that the program be canceled as a waste of taxpayers' money has long been unpopular with lawmakers concerned with creating jobs at a time of high unemployment.
The Marine Corps and the Special Operations Forces have also long favored the development of the plane, despite Mr. Cheney's opposition.
Pete Williams, Mr. Cheney's spokesman, portrayed Mr. Cheney's decision as an effort to break a logjam with the Congress and denied suggestions by some lawmakers that the Defense Secretary had been told by the White House to drop his adamant opposition to the politically popular V-22 program.
In his letter to Senator Mitchell, Mr. Cheney made clear that he was still opposed to the Osprey program.
"If the V-22 was unaffordable in 1989, it is even more unaffordable now," Mr. Cheney said in the letter. "I remain convinced that we can find lower cost alternatives to satisfy the needs of the armed forces for a medium-lift aircraft."
Mr. Cheney said he was proposing a compromise because the Congress had adopted legislation blocking the Pentagon from examining a helicopter alternative to the Osprey and because he wanted to resolve a legal tangle with Congress over accusations that the Pentagon had illegally impounded funds by refusing to spend money that Congress had approved for the project.
The Pentagon has refused to spend $790 million authorized by Congress for the development and manufacture of three V-22 planes, asserting that engineering problems made it impossible to build three prototypes, as required by Congress, with the allotted money. But the Comptroller General later asserted that an illegal impoundment has occurred, setting the stage for a possible battle in the courts.
 
Partial Retreat, Official Says
 Gordon Adams, the director of the Defense Budget Project, a research organization that favors reductions in the Pentagon budget, described Mr. Cheney's move as a partial retreat and not a complete capitulation to the Congressional proponents of the V-22. The compromise allows development of the program to proceed, but it does not commit the Pentagon to equip the military with the planes. Political pressure had made the V-22 a "hot potato," Mr. Adams added. "This allows you to avoid the hot potato, if nothing else."
Representative Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania, a Republican member of the House Armed Services Committee, who has strongly supported the development of the plane, described Mr. Cheney's decision as an important victory for the the Osprey's proponents. As a result of the decision, "there will be that much more expertise and that much more momentum" in the V-22 program. Mr. Weldon said that there was no Republican support on the committee for Mr. Cheney's opposition to the plane.
Although Congress is expected to lift its prohibition of developmental work on a medium-lift helicopter, in light of Mr. Cheney's compromise, some experts say it would take so long to develop that it would not be a serious alternative to the V-22.
Mr. Cheney suggested in his letter that the decision whether to procure the V-22 or a new helicopter might not be made for years, saying it was a matter for "a future Congress and a future Administration."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, departing from his program of military budget trimming, reversed his decision to scrap one of Pentagon's costly new weapons systems. Continuation of the program to build the V-22 Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft offering vertical take-off with conventional plane flight, will keep jobs in Texas and Pennsylvania, where the aircraft is being developed. (pg. A15)

 NEW YORK CITY
 
 GLUT OF OFFICE SPACE HAS SIDE EFFECT
A glut of Manhattan office space has produced an unexpected side effect: Declining rents have slowed the pace of business relocations elsewhere. The glut has become so severe that for the first time the city's midtown business district was surpassed this year by Washington as the nation's most costly place to rent office space. A1.
 
 CUNY LAW SCHOOL NEARS ACCREDITATION
A pivotal committee of the American Bar Association has recommended that the Law School of the City University of New York -- an innovative institution with a mission to bring minority students into the profession -- be granted full accreditation. B4.
 
 HAWKING ILLEGAL FIREWORKS DOWNTOWN
From Broadway to the Bowery, Catherine Street to Broome Street, hundreds of peddlers and hawkers crowd Chinatown and Little Italy selling fireworks for the Fourth of July weekend. B3.
 
 TWO POLICE OFFICERS INDICTED
Two New York City police officers were indicted -- one in Brooklyn for murder, the other in Manhattan for assault -- in the shootings of civilians. The officer indicted for murder, Robert Cabeza, was accused of shooting a Brooklyn liquor store owner during an attempted robbery in 1991. In the Manhattan case, Officer Sean Gelfand was accused of shooting an unarmed taxicab driver, who the police said was innocently caught up in a robbery in April. B3.
 
 AN OFFICER'S ANGRY REACTION
When Officer Michael Dowd, a policeman who is charged with leading a ring of cocaine-dealing police officers, was served with departmental charges at his home early last month, he yelled at the New York City police investigators who confronted him, and his wife ordered them off the family's property, according to investigators. B3.
 
 JURY REJECTS DEATH PENALTY FOR MOBSTER
A jury rejected the death penalty for Thomas Pitera, a 37-year-old convicted mobster, in a case that attracted attention in legal circles because it was the first one prosecuted in New York under a Federal law that permits death sentences for murders in major drug operations. B4.
 
 REGION
 
 SOCIOLOGICAL CHANGES ON THE SHORE
When superhighways placed resort towns within an easy car ride of urban centers, the demography of the Jersey Shore uneasily changed. Nowhere was that change so evident as in Belmar, an oceanfront community of 6,000 that can swell to 25,000 on an average summer weekend. B5.
 
 A JOB THAT CHANGES HANDS OFTEN
Ever since New Jersey's most famous political boss, Frank Hague, stepped down as Mayor of Jersey City in 1947 after 30 years in office and turned the job over to his nephew, no one has held the position for two consecutive terms. Lately the term of office has been measured in months, not years. B5.
 
 Unemployment picture in New York region is bleaker than in other areas of the nation. A12.
 
 Newark man convicted of murder wins new trial because of videotaped testimony. B5.
 
 Our Towns by Andrew H. Malcolm B4

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Fed Takes Action
The unemployment rate rose sharply in June, and the Fed quickly responded to the news by cutting two key interest rates in an attempt to stimulate the economy. Analysts said the data were so grim the Fed had little choice, despite concerns that it would appear to be bowing to political pressure. [Page A1.] The news underscores a split on the President's staff over whether he should appear optimistic or sober on the economy. News Analysis. [A1.]
The Labor Department said the nation's jobless rate spurted another three-tenths of a point in June, to 7.8 percent, while payroll jobs slumped 117,000. The figures were stunningly gloomy and challenged assumptions of continued economic recovery. Analysts found little comfort in data that included a shorter work week, lengthening spells of unemployment, more layoffs and a swelling in the ranks of the jobless by 470,000 to a total of just under 10 million. [A12.] In an employment picture nationwide that is unremittingly bleak, the scene in the New York region appears blacker than most. [A12.] 
 Congress passed a major change in unemployment laws, making it easier for workers to collect extended benefits. [A13.]
Why can't the economy get moving? The Reagan boom left government with too much debt, consumers with too little savings, and many businesses bloated. News Analysis. [A12.]
The Fed's action gave a lift to the bond market and drove the dollar lower. But stocks ended the day much lower. [D1.]
Fed officials agreed in May to shift away from further rate cuts. A subsequent slump led them to lower rates anyway. [A12.]

Defense Secretary Cheney reversed his decision to kill an expensive new tilt-rotor aircraft, the V-22 Osprey. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Pact in Albany Limits Profits Of Criminals

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Friday, July 3

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached agreement this morning on a bill that would force criminals who profit from books or films about their crimes to share the profits with their victims. The measure is intended to replace the celebrated "Son of Sam" law that was struck down by the United States Supreme Court last year.
The accord was one of few to emerge from horse-trading in the round-the-clock drive to end the legislative session this morning. Many other bills were essentially being held hostage to one another, and officials were reluctant to declare final agreements on any measure until they had agreed on all. 
 Lawmakers said they were set to revive an $800 million bond act for economic development, with a bill negotiated by Governor Cuomo and the legislative leaders. It was delivered to Senate Republicans for consideration just after midnight. Lawmakers also said they had agreed on a $40 million deal to help balance the budget by selling part of the Aqueduct Race Track in Queens to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
 
Revision of 1977 Law
 Details of what will likely be dubbed the "Son of Son of Sam Law" were sketchy, but the premise was to require criminals who sell their stories to share at least part of the proceeds with the victims who can prevail in civil court claims against them.
The original 1977 law was named for the serial killer David Berkowitz, who called himself "Son of Sam." The law restricted criminals from profiting by selling their stories, but the Supreme Court ruled last December that the statute violated the First Amendment.
Under the new measure, sponsored by Senator Emanuel R. Gold and Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, both Queens Democrats, no limits would be placed on the criminal's ability to sell his story, but it would be easier for crime victims to share in the proceeds by making claims against them. Among other things, the measure would increase the statute of limitations for collections to seven years, from the present limit of one year.
Mr. Hevesi said the new measure met the suggested provisions that the Supreme Court had spelled out in its decision. "Speech is protected here," he said, "profiting is not protected."
A vote on the measure was not expected until close to dawn.
Several other bills that appeared on the verge of passage Thursday died as legislative exhaustion set in.
A tentative accord on stringent new measures to deter teen-agers from smoking collapsed. And a fiscal bailout desperately sought by county governments on Long Island also appeared in trouble, in large part because Governor Cuomo insisted that he would not approve of tax increases in the bill until county leaders demonstrated to him that they were necessary.
 
Chiding From Cuomo
 There was a clear sense in Capitol hallways that the end of the legislative year was imminent, a feeling that was compounded by word on Thursday that monthslong redistricting battles had been settled in the courts and in the United States Justice Department. Many lawmakers had feared they would have to return to Albany next week to haggle over that issue some more.
Governor Cuomo derided the lawmakers for failing to act on some of his major initiatives, including a fund for environmental protection, laws to strengthen protections of the Adirondack wilderness, and a state assumption of all responsibilities for Medicaid. But he, too, seemed prepared to bid the lawmakers farewell.
"They want to go home," Mr. Cuomo told reporters. "Some of them are out of socks. They've been here for 11 days now."
The unraveling of a bill on youth smoking appeared to be the most serious casualty of the rush to adjourn, and several watchdog groups blamed the tobacco industry for mounting a last-minute blitz to beat back the bill.
"Senator Marino has chosen to put the financial health of the tobacco industry ahead of the health of New York's children," said Blair Horner, legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawmakers and lobbyists gathered outside of the State Senate yesterday for last-minute discussions as the legislative year neared an end. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: American Flies to Belgrade To Take Top Yugoslav Post

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
After receiving permission from the Bush Administration, Milan Panic, an American pharmaceutical manufacturer, left today to become Prime Minister of federal Yugoslavia and carry out what he called a "peace mission" to help end the year-long conflict in the Balkans.
Mr. Panic had to receive United States permission in order to travel to a country that is under an international embargo and whose relations with the United States remain frozen, and to serve there as one of its top leaders while retaining his United States citizenship. 
 The Administration permission was required because the American sanctions against Yugoslavia prohibit United States citizens from carrying out any project, whatever its nature, that might help the country.
According to an aide of Mr. Panic (pronounced PAHN-itch), the exemption to United States sanctions, which was announced Wednesday evening, was approved by President Bush.
 
Hope for Changing Behavior
 Senior Administration officials said the waiver was issued in the hope that Mr. Panic might contribute to changing the behavior of the Serbian leadership, which is regarded as a principal instigator of the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the siege of the Bosnia capital, Sarajevo. Other officials were more skeptical about the Panic mission.
Mr. Panic was selected for the federal Yugoslav position by politicians who said they viewed him as a credible leader at a time when the Serbian leaders in Belgrade are facing mounting opposition in their own capital, and in the hope that he would help improve relations with Washington.
"This is a peace mission," Mr. Panic said in an interview today. "I know I am going on a pirate ship. But if I become captain, the pirate ship will be turned into a ship of peace."
He said he believed that his premiership of federal Yugoslavia would marginalize Slobodan Milosevic, President of the Serbian republic, because under the new Yugoslav constitution, authority over Ministries of Defense, Interior and Foreign Affairs would be held by the new Prime Minister.
 
Leaves for Budapest
 Mr. Panic departed Thursday evening for Budapest and is expected to drive on Friday to his native Belgrade, where he is scheduled to be formally elected Prime Minister by the federal Yugoslav Parliament on Monday. Permission for Mr. Panic to become the Yugoslav Prime Minister was granted by the Administration after more than a week of deliberations. The country he will govern has been reduced to less half its size by secessions of four republics of the old Yugoslavia -- Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Macedonia. Yugoslavia now consists of Serbia and Montenegro.
Mr. Panic, the 62-year-old chairman of I.C.N. Pharmaceuticals, a conglomerate based in Costa Mesa, Calif., has taken leave of absence from his executive positions in his $460 million international drug company. Over the last 22 years, Mr. Panic and his companies have been investigated by two federal regulatory agencies and assessed penalties, while stockholders have also contested some of his actions.
A national bicycle racing champion before he legt Yugoslavia in 1956, Mr. Panic became a successful entrepreneur in California by fostering biotechnology research. In the past, his zealous promotion of I.C.N. products drew censure and penalties from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Food and Drug Administration.
Recently, I.C.N.'s most profitable undertaking has been the Galenika pharamaceuticals company, a Belgrade concern whose American vice chairman is John D. Scanlan , formerly United States Ambasador to Yugoslavia. Mr. Scanlan had been advising Mr. Panic during his consideration of the position.
In the interview, Mr. Panic said he expected to serve as Prime Minister for a maximum of two years and then return to the United States. "I intend to stay American," he said.
He was offered the post of Prime Minister two weeks ago by President Dobrica Cosic (pronounced DOE-bree-tsah CHOE-sitch), a Serbian novelist who became head of state in Belgrade last month.
Mr. Panic finally accepted on the condition that he receive a guarantee from the Bush Administration that he would not face penalties under United States political and economic sanctions imposed by President Bush on federal Yugoslavia on June 5.
Those restrictions, part of a larger United Nations package of sanctions, were directed principally against the Serbian leadership of President Milosevic as pressure to stop aggression by Serbs against Bosnia and Herzegovina.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
100,000 in Belgrade Protest
 BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 3 (Reuters) -- More than 100,000 Serbs marched through the center of Belgrade today to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic. There were no indications that opponents of the President were mollified by the nomination of Mr. Panic as new Yugoslav Prime Minister.
Mr. Milosevic has come under increasing pressure from the opposition in the past week to step down as residents of the capital feel the effects of United Nations sanctions imposed because of his policy in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The opposition organized the biggest anti-Government demonstrations since World War II on Sunday, and they have continued for five days and nights.
The number of people joining the nightly demonstrations steadily rose and today's protest drew the most crowds, according to independent estimates.

HEADLINE: Congress Passes Jobless Aid And Bush Says He Will Sign

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Congress passed a major change in unemployment laws today to make it easier for workers out of a job more than six months to collect extended benefits in future recessions, and President Bush said he would sign the bill.
The permanent changes would take effect after the expiration next March of the third emergency benefits extension of the current recession. That extension is also included in this bill. It is expected to aid between 2 million and 2.5 million workers who will exhaust their basic 26 weeks of benefits through March. They will be eligible for up to 26 more weeks of benefits. 
 After the Government announced this morning that the June unemployment rate had soared to an eight-year high of 7.8 percent, the bill sailed through both Houses. The vote in the House was 396 to 23; in the Senate it was 92 to 3. The details of the measure were proposed last night by House conferees and agreed to by Senators this morning.
 
Bush Turns Around
 President Bush had opposed making permanent changes but had sought another emergency extension. This morning he said he might veto it, but tonight he said before leaving for Camp David, "I will sign this bill as soon as it reaches my desk."
He praised it for preserving fiscal discipline and avoiding new taxes, and said that the possible 52 weeks of regular and extended benefits combined were "an important safeguard for workers who still can't find jobs as the economy continues to grow."
As insisted on by both the White House and the Senate, the $5.5 billion measure will not increase the budget deficit. It will be financed through changes in the tax law that will require higher corporate estimated tax payments, increased taxes on lump-sum pension distributions and a one-year elimination of the personal exemption for high-income taxpayers.
Under the existing law, passed in 1982, a Federal-state extended benefits program paid long-term unemployed workers benefits only under extreme conditions. Despite the current 7.8 rate, only workers in Alaska and Puerto Rico would now be eligible under the existing law.
Because few workers were covered, Congress started passing emergency extensions of benefits last summer. President Bush killed two such bills but agreed to measures passed in November and February.
Under continuous pressure from Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, leaders in Congress came to support a permanent change in the law to end the frequent partisan battles over extensions.
In the brief House debate, Mr. Downey said: "The President is going to sign this bill for two reasons. Unemployment is up, and his popularity is down."
The bill passed today would make unemployed workers in a state eligible for an additional 13 weeks of benefits if the state's total unemployment rate for the last three months was at least 6.5 percent and was at least 10 percent higher than it was in the same period in either of the preceding two years. Up to 20 weeks of extended benefits could be paid in a state where the total unemployment rate was at least 8 percent and was 10 percent higher than in either of the previous two years.
If they preferred, states could still use the old, more restrictive standard, though in serious recessions they would face intense pressure to adopt the new, more generous and consequently more expensive formula.
The old requirement for eligibility for extended benefits was based on the Insured Unemployment Rate, which includes only workers covered by unemployment insurance. Workers joining or rejoining the work force were usually not covered, now were workers who had exhausted their unemployment insurance benefits. That rate is much lower than the total unemployment rate, which reflects everyone out of work and looking for a job.
Under the old law, workers have been eligible for up to 13 weeks of extended benefits if the Insured Unemployment Rate in their state was 5 percent, and if it was 20 percent higher than it was in the same 13 weeks of the two previous years. They could also be eligible for 13 weeks if the Insured Unemployment Rate reached 6 percent.
The old system did not extend benefits in West Virginia, even though that state's total unemployment rate today is 11.6 percent. Nor did it cover workers in California, though the rate is 9.5 percent, or in New York or New Jersey, both at 9.2 percent.
Unemployment benefits, about half a worker's previous salary, average $170 a week nationally.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes $981 Million in Aid for Ex-Soviet Bloc

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The Senate approved today a long-delayed aid package to the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe that authorizes nearly $1 billion in new spending and billions of dollars in credits and loans, all conditioned on continued movement toward democracy and a free market.
By a 76-to-20 vote, the Senate passed a bill that supporters said established a new framework for friendly relations between Washington and its former cold-war foes. The House is expected to take up a similar package later this month. 
 President Bush has made the aid program a top foreign-policy priority and, anticipating the Senate vote, he said today that he would brief President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia on the legislation when they met after a gathering of the Group of Seven industrial democracies in Munich next week.
The Senate acted after a two-day debate in which lawmakers struggled to overcome suspicions left over from decades of confrontation with the Soviet Union. In response, the bill included a provision to cut off aid after 12 months if Russia had not shown progress in withdrawing former Soviet troops from Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.
The package, along with measures already enacted, is to provide $2.5 billion in direct and indirect assistance, much of it in loans and loan guarantees, to Russia and 11 other republics in 1992 and 1993. The package for the former republics of the Soviet Union will account for about 5 percent of all United States foreign aid, according to Sen. Richard J. Lugar of Indiana, the second-ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee.
 
Who Gets What
 The legislation creates a total of $981 million in new budget authority for 1993, according to a Congressional Budget Office estimate.
Russia and 11 other republics of the former Soviet Union would receive $470 million in bilateral assistance, while $450 million would go to nine Baltic and Eastern European states, including republics that were part of Yugoslavia. Another $61 million would be spent to set up new diplomatic posts and centers to promote trade and investment by United States companies.
The bill also sets out Washington's contribution to multilateral aid efforts.
It increases financial backing for the International Monetary Fund by $12.2 billion and authorizes a $3 billion contribution to currency-stabilization programs, first for the Russian ruble and later for the currencies of the other former Soviet republics. The programs would be administered by the I.M.F.
Supporters of these multilateral efforts said they would not require any immediate outlay of taxpayer money. The ruble fund, for example, would be used only if the ruble fluctuates wildly.
 
The Non-Money Items
 The package also expands agricultural credits, student exchanges and other contacts, while eliminating numerous barriers to trade and investment by United States businesses.
The bill sets strict requirements for recipients.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said, "We have conditioned aid to any republic on good-faith conduct by each of these new states in several important areas -- human rights, economic reforms, non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and technology, and avoiding the use of military force against other states."
Conservative Republicans introduced several amendments to make these conditions stricter, but most were overwhelmingly defeated after the bill's proponents argued that Congress might actually set back Mr. Yeltsin's democratization plans by demanding too much of him.
The Senate also turned back efforts by liberal Democrats requiring that aid to the Soviet Union be matched by similar amounts of spending on domestic programs like the Job Corps and vaccinations for children.
President Bush first proposed the new aid in a speech on April 1, and two days later sent a letter to Congress appealing for bipartisan support. The letter said the package was "an issue that transcends any election."
Since then the aid request has been much debated and long delayed.
