HEADLINE: E.P.A. Told to Publish New Air Pollution Rules Before Compliance Deadline

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency cannot wait until next January to publish new air pollution rules that the states are supposed to put into effect this November, a Federal District Court judge has ruled.
The E.P.A. had planned to wait until Jan. 28, 1993, to publish its regulations for a car-inspection program that the Clean Air Act says must be in place by Nov. 15, 1992. 
 The agency's acting general counsel, Raymond B. Ludwiszewski, acknowledged that expecting the states to comply with rules before they are written "might appear to be an anomaly."
Late Wednesday, Judge Denis R. Hurley ruled that it was also illegal.
Judge Hurley gave the E.P.A. until Nov. 6, leaving the states nine days to comply with the regulations, which are expected to run several hundred pages.
 
Tests Are Inadequate
 At issue are automobile inspections in 75 metropolitan areas that fail to meet Federal smog standards in 22 states. By some estimates, 5 percent of cars emit 50 percent of smog-forming ozone. Many states already conduct annual inspections, but experts say they miss dirty cars, in part because nearly all states test emissions while cars are idling. Newer cars with computer-controlled fuel injection behave differently at different speeds, so idling tests are ineffective.
When Congress amended the Clean Air Act in 1990, it required "enhanced inspection and maintenance" procedures, to be put in effect by Nov. 15, 1992, and gave the E.P.A. until Nov. 15, 1991 to issue the regulations.
That is what the E.P.A. has yet to do.
"If you look at the Clean Air Act, there are literally hundreds of deadlines in the first year and a half," said Mr. Ludwiszewski. "You try as hard as you can to make as much progress as you can. You try to push the most important regulations up, but sometimes you have slippage."
Not everyone was understanding.
"It's almost like they're saying, 'The dog ate my homework'," said S. William Becker, the executive director of the Association of State and Local Air Pollution Control Officials, which is based in Washington.
 
States Risk Lawsuits
 The E.P.A. cannot be lenient, even if it wants to, because the Clean Air Act gives citizens the right to sue states that are not in compliance. A judge who found a state to be in violation could hold up Federal highway funds or ban new construction, public and private, on the grounds that it would add to pollution.
The suit was originally brought against the E.P.A. by the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based environmental group. A lawyer there, James F. Simon, said that while implementing the law would cost the states money, violating it would cost more. He said that the rule was opposed by some service stations that now do inspections and would be forced out of the business if more elaborate equipment is needed.
"One hundred million people live in areas with unhealthy air," he said. "For the E.P.A. to hold up this rule because of the economic interests of some small gas station owners seems unjustifiable to me."
In many cases, car owners will probably have to take their vehicles to central points, to be tested on treadmills. The regulations that the states are waiting for include questions like whether the repair work can be done at the same site or must be performed elsewhere, and how often cars will have to be tested.
 
Deadline's Meaning Debated
 A spokeswoman for the E.P.A., Martha Casey, said that her agency had finished writing the rule in February, only three months past deadline, but that the Office of Management and Budget had been very slow in its review, and is only now returning it for further work.
The E.P.A. and the states disagree on precisely what must be done by Nov. 15. The E.P.A. believes that the law requires the states to present detailed plans for implementing an enhanced inspection and maintenance program. Given its own tardiness, the E.P.A. had said that, in lieu of detailed plans to comply with nonexistent regulations, it would accept a promise by states to comply when the regulations were issued.
But Mr. Becker, of the association of states, said that the states were supposed to have actual inspection programs in place by the deadline, which is now clearly impossible.
The states do have some clues, Mr. Ludwiszewski said, because his agency has met with them and circulated draft regulations. If they are really concerned about huge penalties, he said, "then you take your best guess and go with it," instituting a program before the Federal requirements are spelled out. But, Mr. Becker said, that could mean state air pollution commissioners asking their legislatures to enact new, unpopular rules that might never be required by the E.P.A. If, for example, the state officials ask legislatures to require that repair shops be separate from inspection stations, and the E.P.A. regulations do not include that requirement, the officials will be accused of "crying wolf once too often."

HEADLINE: A Murky Recovery;
How Many Lean Years Must Follow The Long String of Very Fat Years?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Fifteen months after the recession supposedly ended, the economic recovery remains wobbly, slow and, to many Americans, barely perceptible.
Why can't this economy get moving? The answer is that the economy still has a hangover from the eight-year Reagan boom. The longest peacetime expansion in postwar history has left the Government with too much debt, consumers with too little savings and many businesses, especially in the sprawling service economy, too bloated. 
 Coping with these ill effects is as much a matter of time as it is of cheaper money.
"The economy needs a prolonged period of recuperation from the excesses of the 1980's," said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch.
The Federal Reserve Board, after all, has hardly been sitting on its hands. The central bank has cut interest rates 23 times since mid-1989 and the Federal funds rate, what banks pay each other for overnight loans, is now at 3.25 percent, its lowest level in decades. A more aggressive approach, much as it might have been desired by the White House, might very likely have backfired by fanning inflation fears and spooking investors.
So while forecasters expect the Federal Reserve's action to do some good, they warn that the pattern of sluggish and uneven recovery will probably persist for at least several quarters.
Three obstacles to growth make this likely: long-term interest rates remain high; consumers want to pay off debts, and, most important, businesses are determined to keep their costs under control.
 
'Symptom of Our Nervousness'
 Long-term rates -- which affect what home buyers pay for mortgages, municipalities for a new public works projects or businesses to modernize -- have come down far less than short-term rates, one reason the housing recovery has been so muted and construction employment so weak. Yields on 30-year bonds are above 7.6 percent -- 3 or 4 percentage points above the inflation rate most economists expect for a few years.
"It's basically a symptom of our nervousness," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist of the Shawmut National Corporation.
By all accounts, investors are edgy because of the $390 billion Federal deficit this year. Bondholders are evidently not convinced that the deficit will shrink by the time that private credit demands -- currently weak because of the sluggish world economy -- start to swell up again. If their fears were allayed and the difference between long- and short-term rates turned more normal, home buyers might be shopping for 6 percent, instead of 8 percent, mortgages.
It is that very deficit that makes it all but impossible for the Government to spend its way out of recession. At the same time, the deficit makes a significant tax cut unlikely.
"Why is fiscal policy dead?" Mr. Perna asked. "The budget deficit has prevented us from acting."
Consumers are still struggling with too much debt and too little savings. They are paying down installment debt and restraining spending on big-ticket items like housing and cars. With inflation tame and house prices unlikely to rise much, consumers also have less incentive to go into debt to put a deed in their pockets.
The trouble is that incomes are stagnating so that the ratio of debt to income has barely declined from its peak. "It's a prolonged process," said Mr. Steinberg at Merrill Lynch. "Eventually there's a way out, but only when the real constraining force -- debt -- begins to fade away."
But the biggest drag on the economy is the streamlining and cost-cutting that is evident in dozens of industries, and in state and local governments. With the end of the cold war, military suppliers are shedding thousands of jobs. The shakeout in the computer and car industries continues. And after years of open-handed hiring, service companies are focusing on increasing efficiency.
"Job growth is more important than ever before for income growth," said Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs. Pay increases are not keeping up with inflation, interest income is shrinking and no tax relief is in sight.
Some of the cost-consciousness reflects the executives' views that the recovery will be unusually anemic. Given those views, many executives believe that price increases will be tough, if not impossible, to get. Thus, they see squeezing labor costs -- by cutting their work forces, holding down pay increases, hiring conservatively and getting more out of the hands that are already on board -- as the only way to raise profit margins.
"Most companies are telling us that there is no price flexibility out there," said Mr. McKelvey at Goldman, Sachs.
Take Compass Transportation in Youngstown, Ohio. The company, which ships cars and steel all over the Midwest and East, says business is brisk and it is trying to hire more drivers. But though it is having trouble finding qualified applicants, the company is not raising its starting salary.
"We can't raise wages to attract more drivers," said one of the company's partners, Joseph Fleming. "Customers just aren't willing to pay more."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate;
AIDS Demonstrators Disrupt Perot Rally

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLYMPIA, Wash., July 2

 BODY:
With 200 American flags held aloft by volunteers standing on the steps of the Capitol under a crystal blue sky, it was the kind of camera-pleasing visual feast that organizers of Ross Perot's rallies strive for. But in their eyes this snapshot of Americana was marred for a time today by the presence of another image of late 20th century America: protesters.
A handful of members of Act Up, an advocacy group for people with AIDS, briefly took over the stage at Mr. Perot's rally here today, vowing not to leave until the Texas billionaire addressed issues of AIDS and gay rights. They wanted him to explain comments he has made saying he would not appoint homosexuals to his cabinet and would not lift the military's ban on homosexual soldiers. 
 "We want to know what Ross Perot stands for here in Olympia in Washington State," Stephen Michael, a member of Act Up from Seattle, shouted through a hand-held public address system. "We want answers. What does Ross Perot believe? Nobody has any idea, because Ross Perot won't say."
To head off further disruption, Mr. Perot met for 20 minutes with Mr. Michael and several other Act Up representatives, delaying the start of his rally. Mr. Michael said that Mr. Perot promised he would address gay rights issues. But in his brief remarks to the crowd of about 4,000 people, Mr. Perot did not refer to the demonstration or to gay issues.
Instead, Mr. Perot kept to his standard speech, urging the crowd to remain involved in the political process.
"Does everybody here understand that you cannot elect someone and send that person to Washington and have that person do it for you?" Mr. Perot asked the crowd. "You are going to have to stay deeply involved at the local, county, state and national level, as an owner, for these revolutionary changes to occur. But if you, the taxpayers want it, you can get it."
Mr. Perot urged the audience to register voters, whether or not they intend to vote for him, and he praised Washington's voter registration law, which allows individuals to register when they renew their drivers licenses.
His comment came the same day President Bush vetoed legislation passed by Congress that would have allowed voters nationwide to register when they renew drivers licenses, at unemployment offices or when they apply for welfare. Mr. Bush said the measure would encourage voter fraud.
 
Lifestyle Questions Arising
 While gay rights demonstrators have appeared at a number of Mr. Perot's rallies in recent weeks, today was the first time they succeeded in disrupting the proceedings. The presence of the protesters indicates that while Mr. Perot strives to focus his embryonic campaign on the issue of economic growth, questions concerning his tolerance of diverse lifestyles may continue to haunt him.
The demonstration came a day after the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith released a letter from Morton H. Meyerson, former president of Electronic Data Systems, and a top aide to Mr. Perot, defending the company's dismissal in 1983 of an employee in Seattle who grew a beard in violation of company policy. The employee, Reginald Dallaire, claimed to be an Orthodox Jew and refused to shave for religious reasons.
A Federal judge ruled that Mr. Dallaire had been discriminated against because of his religion and ordered his reinstatement. Mr. Dallaire later quit the company and moved to Alaska.
A two-page memorandum that accompanied Mr. Meyerson's letter questioned Mr. Dallaire's sincerity and raised questions about his motives and his character, issues that E.D.S. had not raised during the court hearing on the case, according to Mr. Dallaire's lawyer. The memorandum also indicated that after the suit had been settled and Mr. Dallaire had moved, his supervisors questioned his former neighbors about him.
According to the memorandum, Mr. Dallaire's neighbors told his supervisor, "that they had been somewhat afraid of him. It seems that he had the habit of mowing his lawn while wearing visible firearms. He also told some neighbors that he been (sic) a sharpshooter in Vietnam and stalked people through the wooded areas in Washington with his rifle to prove that he still had his sniping abilities."
The memo did not say why neighbors were questioned after Mr. Dallaire had already left the company.
"That's an incredible set of allegations, none of which were raised at the time," said Michael Reiss, a lawyer with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission who handled Mr. Dallaire's complaint against E.D.S. "Either it's a fabrication or a case where they're going out to try and get dirt on somebody after he's left the company."
In a telephone interview today, Mr. Meyerson said he "did not have the foggiest idea" why Mr. Dallaire's supervisor questioned his neighbors.
Today's disruption also highlighted the mistakes that can be made by a his grass-roots campaign organization that relies on enthusiastic but often inexperienced volunteers. In organizing the rally at which they turned in petitions containing more than 55,000 signatures, Mr. Perot's volunteers failed to get a permit to hold the event on the steps of the State Capitol. As a result, they did not have exclusive use of the steps, and could not force the ACT UP demonstrators to leave.

HEADLINE: House Approves Tax Bill With $14.5 Billion in Breaks

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Riding a wave of support for encouraging investment in depressed neighborhoods, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a broad package of tax legislation that includes an estimated $14.5 billion in tax breaks for businesses and individuals over six years.
But the legislation also raises additional taxes to avoid causing an overall increase in the Federal budget deficit. 
 The bill centered on provisions to create urban enterprise zones, in response to the Los Angeles riots in late April. It won wide support for many reasons, among them the Administration's endorsement, even though many members objected to one or another of its diverse provisions.
The bill's highlights include the extension of several tax benefits that had expired on June 30; the repeal of the luxury tax on jewelry, furs and expensive pleasure boats; the reinstatement of passive-loss deductions, which allow investors who incur losses in real estate to shield other income from taxation, and a provision that would let businesses depreciate their intangible assets -- but it would not allow this technique, which has been hotly debated, to be used retroactively.
The vote in the House was a significant step toward resolving dozens of questions about taxation that have been lingering since President Bush in March vetoed a previous tax bill that was much bigger and included a Democrat-backed tax break for the middle class at the expense of wealthier people. That provision was not in the bill that passed today.
Republicans backed the measure with the Administration's blessing, even though it included nothing along the lines of the President's longstanding central tax proposal, a reduction in the capital gains tax, which he was once again promoting in a talk to Republican representatives before the bill was approved.
Despite the House vote, considerable horse-trading remains to be done before a final agreement is reached with the Senate, which is developing several tax laws that in their current drafts conflict with the measure that the House approved today. The Senate will not consider its version of the legislation until later in the month.
 
Fourth of July Rush
 For its part, the House, after several days in which its leaders argued over both substance and procedure, voted its approval in a rush before leaving for an extended Fourth of July holiday, an important time for members to go home and campaign.
The House suspended its normal rules so that the bill could not be amended on the floor, an approach that required a two-thirds vote of approval. The vote to approve the bill was 356 to 55.
Some members shunned the compromise. "I oppose the bill," said Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio. "The bill is half good, half bad -- and where I come from that is mediocre."
But more common was the approach of Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, who in the brief time allocated for debate rose to praise one particular provision or another. She singled out for approval the permanent extension of tax breaks for small issues of industrial development bonds, which she called "the only measure targeted to the industrial backbone of our economy."
 
Three Other Measures
 That was one of four measures made permanent by the House bill after having previously been extended temporarily again and again, only to expire once more at the end of last month. Like the other three -- a low-income rental housing credit, a credit for employing economically disadvantaged young people up to age 24, and mortgage-revenue bonds -- this one was considered a useful spur for the economies of inner cities and thus a counterpart to the tax provisions included in the urban enterprise zone bill.
It is, at least on paper, more costly to extend this kind of tax break permanently than to eke out the breaks for a year or so at a time the way the Senate Finance Committee has tended to do. This difference is an example of how the negotiating must continue, often less because of differences over policy than because of the arcane accounting rules that the two chambers of Congress use to calculate whether tax provisions increase the budget deficit.
The House also temporarily extended several other tax breaks, including a tax credit for business research and development, the tax-free treatment for employer-provided educational assistance and the 25 percent deduction for medical insurance premiums paid by self-employed individuals.
Another provision extended for 18 months was special tax treatment for the charitable donation of property that has appreciated in value. To encourage such gifts, the bill would exempt the donors from the alternative-minimum-tax provisions of the tax law.
 
Moving Deductions Cut
 But to avoid throwing the budget further out of balance, there had to be some provisions that clearly raise revenues. One provision in the House measure cuts back on the kinds of moving expenses that can be deducted when people change jobs, including a $5,000 limit on allowable deductions. This provision alone, if it takes effect at the end of the year, is expected to raise an estimated $3.5 billion over next six years.
One of the hardest fights of the emerging tax law is over the ability of businesses depreciate intangible assets, like newspapers' subscriber lists, independent insurance agents' customer lists and the core deposits held by banks.
With many millions of dollars at stake, businesses are entangled in innumerable negotiations with the Internal Revenue Service over whether they can write off such assets over the years after they have been acquired, on the principle that a list of customers can lose value just as an automobile or a building can.
Proponents say that simplifying the law in this regard would be fairer to companies, would avoid litigation and, depending on how it is done, might even raise money for the Government. Opponents say that it would unduly reward participants in leveraged buyouts, especially if such depreciation was allowed retroactively, and that in the end it would cost the Government money.
 
Split on Retroactivity
 The House has now agreed to allow this kind of depreciation in the future but not retroactively. The Senate has not yet voted, but its Finance Committee favors allowing the retroactive use of these deductions for past tax years under certain limits.
This is just the kind of issue that will keep what one lawyer today laughingly called "the tax wonks" busy for a few more weeks before a tax law eventually emerges.
The provision allowing passive-loss deductions in real estate is an example of Congress's voting to undo one of the features of its last major tax overhaul, in 1986, when tax shelters were attacked across a broad front.
The unintended result of killing passive-loss deductions was to remove a tax break from people who actually spend most of their time in real estate, a decision that whipsawed many builders just as the real estate market turned sour on them. Part of the appeal at this time for restoring this tax break was the argument that it would add to the broader push for investment in urban areas.

HEADLINE: As Jobless Ranks Grow, Hope Falls in California

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 2

 BODY:
As the recession has deepened here in Southern California, the unemployment line on Venice Boulevard has grown longer, quieter and more angry.
Shuffling slowly forward, the podiatrist, the financial planner, the insurance saleswoman and others spoke with dignity about the humiliations of joblessness and about their sinking hopes for the future. 
 But on this day when new unemployment figures showed their numbers to be higher than in any other big industrial state, they also spoke bitterly about what they called the betrayal of an American ideal of success through hard work, and even of the fulfillment of a biblical prophecy of doom.
"Is this what America is built upon?" said Alex Spriggs, a 42-year-old podiatrist who has been out of work for nine months. "You get an education, you get a job, you try to live right and go by all the rules, and then you're out on the street. What can our kids look forward to? What about the ones that are coming out of college right now?"
Ron Ferraro, 51, an auto-body appraiser who has not worked since last year, was here to ask for an extension of his unemployment benefits, and also to pick up job-training forms for his 18-year-old son, who is out of work and homeless.
"I was on the telephone with him last night, and he was almost sobbing about the fact that he was scared," Mr. Ferraro said. "He's scared. I'm scared. It's almost as if the biblical prophecy of violence, pestilence and lawlessness was coming true."
Nationally, the unemployment rate for June was 7.8 percent, higher than it has been for eight years. The figure for California was still higher at 9.5 percent, the highest among the 11 major industrial states.
California's growing unemployment rate, up from 8.7 percent in May, is the latest evidence of the state's worst economic troubles since the Great Depression. Recovery here is not expected until at least next year, well behind the rest of the nation.
On Wednesday, with the Legislature and Gov. Pete Wilson unable to agree on a deficit-reducing budget package, the state began paying its bills with I.O.U.'s. Any reductions in state spending will almost certainly involve cuts in employment by state and local governments, pushing the unemployment figures still higher.
In the unemployment office on Venice Boulevard, the manager, Bob Fisher, said an internal report last month showed that claims had risen locally by 31 percent over the previous year.
"The more people we get here in our lobby, the more calm it seems to get," he said, almost as if people are becoming aware that their individual problems are only a small part of a large-scale disaster.
He said his office had yet to feel the effects of a layoff announced this week of 9,000 employees at the Hughes Aircraft Company, the state's largest industrial employer. Over the last six years, the gradual decline in military spending has cost the Los Angeles region alone about 100,000 relatively high-paying jobs.
In addition, the state's multibillion-dollar tourism industry has been shaken by the twin jolts of the riots and a series of earthquakes to the east of Los Angeles.
 
'There's No Recovery'
 "The Southern California economy is dead in the water," said Jack Kyser, the chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles, a privately financed research group. "Out here, there's no recovery, and the unemployment statistics just indicate that we have a lot of work ahead of us, and that it will be 1993 before there is any recovery."
Though the economic problems affect the entire state, they are felt most deeply in Southern California, which accounts for more than half of the state's economic activity.
Nevertheless, E. W. Kelly Jr., who represents veterans' affairs for the State Employment Development Department, said that what he called the "Golden State syndrome" still seemed to be alive, and that he still saw people coming here from other states in search of opportunity.
Standing in the sunshine outside the unemployment office, Mr. Kelly said, "I still run into those individuals walking up and down the streets looking for those Golden Streets of opportunity."
Waiting her turn on a plastic seat inside sat one of these seekers, Florestine Johnson, a 35-year-old insurance saleswoman who had come here a few weeks ago looking for work after losing her job in Washington State.
"With all my skills and qualifications and background, I would hope I would be successful," she said.
And indeed, success seemed to be smiling on her today. On the plastic seat beside her, Doug Knoblauch, an out-of-work financial planner, opened his notebook to suggest job contacts for her in the fields of insurance and banking.
Mr. Knoblauch, 31, said he had been having trouble collecting unemployment benefits because he continued to offer financial planning services on a private basis whenever he could.
But he said, "Brokers make money when money moves, and money isn't moving now." Though he spent $800 last year in professional insurance and licensing fees, he said he earned less than $3,000.
Surveying the slow-moving line from behind an information window, Howard Patton, an employment office official, said he was sure that even today's high figures understate the problem.
"They don't consider all those people who are frustrated and have given up," he said, "those that have resigned themselves to the fact that there is nothing out there and don't even come in here to see us."
Among those who had given up were Riffey Trawick, 28, and his friend James D. Carter, 30, who were going through the bins today outside a Salvation Army office looking for shoes.
Both men moved here from out of state in search of work, and managed fairly well for a while in construction and warehousing work. But as the economy contracted, both men fell off the bottom of the social ladder.
"I just feel like there's nothing else I can do," said Mr. Carter, who had shaved and had recently had a haircut. "I've looked for work and there isn't any. And if there was any, I don't think they'd hire me, not having a place to live and all."
Mr. Trawick said he was ineligible for unemployment benefits because he had always worked off the books for various employers. And now, he said, he believed he and Mr. Carter no longer had any place at all in society.
"I think they'd like to get rid of us, forget about us," he said. "We're an embarrassment."

HEADLINE: Russian Minister Warns of Coup Threat by the Army

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 2

 BODY:
The Russian Foreign Minister has caused a stir in Moscow by his warning this week that Communist and nationalist forces are manipulating the military in an effort to destabilize or overthrow the democratic Government here.
The minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, speaking to Izvestia, warned that pressure for the Russian Army to intervene in support of Russian-speakers living outside Russia's borders, in hotspots like Moldova and South Ossetia, was being orchestrated by politicians opposed to President Boris N. Yeltsin. 
 "The party of war, the party of neo-Bolsheviks, are raising their heads," he said, using their supporters in the military to fan the ethnic flames in Moldova and South Ossetia and then appealing to Russian patriotism to attract support for their undemocratic aims.
"I think the threat of an antidemocratic coup exists," Mr. Kozyrev said, "either through another congress of the Soviet Communist Party or by a reversal on the part of the apparat," the still-powerful state bureaucracy.
 
Turn to the West Criticized
 The essence of Mr. Kozyrev's concerns have been a common topic of conversation here, as Russia's much-ballyhooed economic reforms have slowed while living conditions for the great mass of people have worsened. The conservative opposition to Mr. Yeltsin in Parliament, elected in March 1990 when the Communist Party still held sway, has been searching for sticks with which to beat the President and his chief economic adviser, Acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar.
Having failed to elicit much active popular discontent on purely economic grounds, they have been criticizing Mr. Yeltsin's turn to the West, in particular his willingness in Washington to scrap Russia's main nuclear deterrent, the multiple-warhead, land-based SS-18, and his alleged failure to provide support for Russian-speakers and soldiers in Moldova and South Ossetia. The last is a criticism widely voiced by Mr. Yeltsin's own Vice President, Aleksandr V. Rutskoi.
Mr. Kozyrev's warnings have been expressed by other politicians, according to Oleg T. Bogomolov, director of the Institute of World Economic and Political Research and a member of Mr. Yeltsin's Presidential Consultative Council. "But when such an official speaks about such a danger, it seems more important," he said in an interview.
It also was a reminder of former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's warning of a coming right-wing coup when he resigned in December 1990, eight months before last August's effort to overthrow the former Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Mr. Kozyrev is uncomfortable with that comparison, Mr. Bogomolov said in an interview. But the Foreign Minister repeated his concerns today, in a seminar Mr. Bogomolov attended, saying, "The pro-Communist and nationalist forces are trying to challenge the President's efforts to transform Russia into a democratic state and enable it to join the community of civilized nations on the basis of equality."
 
Right-Wing Reaction Grows
 There is a growing right-wing reaction, Mr. Bogomolov said, which largely and unsurprisingly stems from national humiliation and economic distress. "Many people, including many democrats, think Mr. Gaidar's economic policy has failed and only aggravated conditions in the country," he said.
With a difficult economic situation and the violent conflicts on Russia's periphery, "of course many people demand some action."
Mr. Bogomolov said he did not think the conservative forces were powerful enough to accomplish their aims, "but when the conservatives promise order and a strict fight against corruption they gain some support."
He said that a new military coup was much less likely than a continuing effort to place more conservative politicians within the existing government structure. "The new people would determine the policy, which would become quite different," he said.
 
Where the Danger Lies
 Mr. Kozyrev is not alone in his fear of "these red-brown forces," Russian shorthand for the alliance of convenience between former Communists, the reds, and Russian ultranationalists, who are regarded by democrats here as fascist, and hence brown, as in Hitler's Brownshirts.
Sergei Shakrai, until recently a Yeltsin adviser, himself warned today that there would be a move to oust Mr. Yeltsin by Communists and the leaders of the powerful state military-industrial complex, which is threatened by economic restructuring and reform.
Speaking to the newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta a few days before the Constitutional Court hears a case challenging the legality of Mr. Yeltsin's ban on the Communist Party, Mr. Shakrai said there could be an effort to impeach Mr. Yeltsin on some pseudo-constitutional pretext. The Communists are discredited and cannot regain power on their own, he said, but democrats have failed to consolidate authority. The real danger this year, he said, comes from industrial leaders in combination with forces in the military.
Some of these responses simply reflect the Russian love of conspiracy, rampant in a country where real power never operated in the open and democracy has tenuous historical roots.
But there has also been concern over Mr. Yeltsin's efforts to co-opt hard-liners in the military when the defense budget is being cut, Russian soldiers are being withdrawn from the territory of old conquests, and ethnic struggles are threatening to envelop soldiers still stationed where they were when the Soviet empire died.
Some democrats fear that Mr. Yeltsin is repeating the mistake of Mr. Gorbachev before last August's coup: relying too much on alliances with conservative forces whose aim is not to support him but to replace him.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
President Vetoes the 'Motor-Voter' Measure

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
As expected, President Bush today vetoed the "motor-voter" bill, which would have required all the states to allow voter registration when citizens apply for driver's licenses or government benefits.
The President's veto message said the bill would have imposed needless, costly and constitutionally questionable Federal regulation on the states and would also have exposed "the election process to an unacceptable risk of fraud and corruption without any reason to believe that it would increase electoral participation to any significant degree." 
 The bill, which both the Senate and the House had passed by majorities that were less than veto-proof, would almost certainly have helped Democrats by adding to the voter rolls large numbers of welfare clients, the working poor and the disabled.
Beginning in 1994, it would have required all the states to allow citizens to register to vote when they apply for, renew or change the address on their driver's licenses. Some states already allow voters to register that way. It would also have allowed voters to register by mail and would have required that registration forms be available at welfare, unemployment and other social service offices.
Senator Wendell H. Ford, the Kentucky Democrat who was the measure's primary author, said he would lead an effort to override the veto.

HEADLINE: Guilty Plea Arranged In Israel Kickback Case

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
A New Jersey businessman has agreed to plead guilty to two Federal fraud charges in a complex case that Congressional investigators say links the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation to a kickback scandal involving the sale of jet engines to Israel.
Pratt & Whitney is the second big military contractor to become entangled in the case. The General Electric Company was briefly suspended by the Pentagon last month from receiving new jet-engine contracts because of its involvement. G.E. is now negotiating a settlement of civil and possible criminal charges with the Justice Department. 
 Congressional investigators previously said they were studying whether Pratt & Whitney had agreed to pay kickbacks in return for contracts from the Israeli Air Force, but no charges have been filed against the company. Calls to Pratt & Whitney and to United Technologies in Hartford went unanswered last night.
 
2 Companies Detailed
 In documents filed in United States District Court in New York, Federal prosecutors said they could prove that the businessman, Benjamin Sonnenschein, operated two companies under the direction of an Israeli citizen, Yoram Ingbir. The documents said the companies received contracts for computer software work from Pratt & Whitney.
Staff members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on investigations said they had evidence that Pratt & Whitney was directed to award the contracts to Mr. Sonnenschein's companies by Gen. Rami Dotan of the Israeli Air Force. General Dotan, the central figure in the case, pleaded guilty last year in Israel to extorting money from military contractors in the United States, and is serving a 13-year prison sentence.
In a civil case against General Electric that is being prosecuted by the Justice Department, Mr. Ingbir is identified as a conduit for kickbacks directed by G.E. to the control of General Dotan.
The documents filed in Mr. Sonnenschein's case said that he funneled to Mr. Ingbir more than $500,000 of proceeds from the Pratt & Whitney contracts from 1988 through 1990, largely through small deposits to bank accounts in the United States and in at least one case through a deposit to a Swiss bank.
The documents do not say what Mr. Ingbir did with the money. Mr. Ingbir has not been charged with any wrongdoing in the United States or in Israel.
The investigators for the House subcommittee said Mr. Sonnen schein's companies had received at least $5.3 million in contracts from Pratt & Whitney at General Dotan's direction. The actual value of the work done by the companies was far less, the investigators said, and involved expenses of only about $500,000.
Mr. Sonnenschein was described in the court documents as a relative of Mr. Ingbir who had been unemployed at the time Mr. Ingbir asked him to manage the two companies, the Yrret Company and Air Tech Inc., both of Fair Lawn, N.J.
Mr. Sonnenschein agreed to plead guilty to one count of transporting $50,000 in cash to Switzerland without reporting it to the Federal Government, as required by law, and to one count of failing to disclose to the Internal Revenue Service $261,000 under his control in a Swiss bank.
Mr. Sonnenschein agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, the plea agreement said. Prosecutors agreed to recommend a sentence of probation, plus a $50,000 fine and forfeiture of $2.8 million under Mr. Sonnen schein's control.

HEADLINE: Interest-Rate Payoff on California I.O.U.'s

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The inability of California to pay all its bills in cash is a black mark against its reputation in financial markets, but there is a silver lining for people and businesses who are issued i.o.u.'s instead of cash.
If the recipients of the i.o.u.'s hold the check-like pieces of paper, the state has promised to pay a 5 percent interest rate, which is much higher than the annual rate they could earn on a short-term bank deposit. If the i.o.u.'s are deposited or cashed at a bank, the bank will receive the 5 percent rate. 
 The 5 percent rate is well above average rates for money market accounts of 3.40 percent for large banks in Los Angeles and 3.30 percent in San Francisco. According to Bank Rate Monitor of North Palm Beach, Fla., investors would have to tie up their money in a bank certificate of deposit with a term of more than two years if they wanted to match the 5 percent rate being offered by the state.
Robert Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, notes that the interest rate offered by the state is likely to become even more attractive in coming days as banks reduce rates on deposits in response to the Federal Reserve's move yesterday to ease monetary policy and cut short- term interest rates.
The 5 percent interest rate was set by California officials in the Pooled Money Investment Board, which handles investments of excess cash by state agencies. After talking with local bankers, the state agreed to pay the maximum 5 percent rate allowed by law.
"We asked for the maximum interest rate to compensate for the expenses of handling the paper and customer inquiries," said Gregory Wilhelm, director of government relations for the California Bankers Association. So far, the state has issued only about 20,000 of the i.o.u.'s, although it expects to issue about 800,000 if its cash shortage continues through July.
Gray Davis, the State Controller, said interest paid to banks and corporations would be subject to state tax. For individuals, he said, the state had not yet determined if the interest was subject to tax or was tax-exempt, like the interest on bonds issued by the state.
Not all the state's bills are being paid with i.o.u.'s. Payments to local school districts and bond investors, which are required by the state Constitution, are still being made in cash.

HEADLINE: A Summer of Discontent

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Today's bad economic news underscores a serious split on President Bush's staff over whether he should appear optimistic or more sober about the state of the economy at this critical point in election year politics.
Some important advisers like Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff; Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady argue that as a rule the President should talk favorably about economic prospects to build public confidence as the election approaches. 
 But others, particularly Vice President Dan Quayle and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, maintain that the President should not seem optimistic lest voters see him as unsympathetic and out of touch with their economic troubles.
The dispute, which had been building for weeks and reflects a fundamental difference in expectations for the economy, first surfaced on June 22 at a senior staff meeting, according to people who were there. Mr. Boskin noted that on a political swing to California the previous weekend Mr. Bush had referred at almost every stop to the poor economic conditions in the state. Mr. Boskin reportedly said he was pleased by what he saw as a new tone of realism from the President.
 
'Wait a Minute!'
 A staff assistant at the meeting described what followed: "Skinner jumped in and said something like: 'Wait a minute! Everyone here knows the economy is doing well.' Then Boskin blew his cork and said that was nonsense and economically crazy and politically dangerous. It was all over in a minute or two, but I'm sure that's not the last we'll hear of it."
The President was not at the meeting.
The shouting match between Mr. Boskin and Mr. Skinner was described by people on Mr. Boskin's side, and their goal may have been to win Mr. Bush's support on a matter of substance as well as tone.
Since last year, Mr. Boskin, Mr. Quayle and their supporters have advocated pressing Congress hard for what President Bush calls his "growth package" -- primarily tax breaks to increase investment and stimulate construction and real estate.
But Mr. Skinner, Mr. Brady and others believe the President would lose such a fight with the Democratic Congress and should not risk a confrontation.
The dispute also reflected a fundamental disagreement on the actual state of the economy. Mr. Boskin is said to believe that new economic data, including the grim employment statistics released today, are so bleak that the President will look remote and uninformed if he is upbeat in his public statements.
Mr. Skinner and Mr. Brady seem to feel that economic conditions are more favorable. In a statement today, Mr. Brady emphasized that "the fundamentals remain in place for steady growth and low inflation."
Mr. Bush himself took a middle course today in his news conference on Capitol Hill. "The economy is still growing," he said at first, noting that employment data are what economists call a "lagging indicator," meaning they begin to improve after the overall economy has turned around.
But Mr. Bush quickly added: "I've always said unemployment for one person, that's 100 percent, and that's too much. And so, we've got to keep moving till we get it back the way I'd like to see it in terms of economic growth."
 
The Heat of the Summer
 If the economic recovery is flattening out again, as it did last summer, it could hardly have happened at a worse time for the President. History shows that the condition of the economy is one of the most important factors in whether a President wins re-election and that the summer of election years is when voters frame their views about the economy.
Prof. Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a political scientist at the University of Iowa whose specialty is election forecasting, has calculated that all five times since World War II when the unemployment rate was falling in the second quarter of the election year, the incumbent's party won the Presidency: 1948, 1964, 1972, 1984 and 1988.
On the other hand, the unemployment rate was rising, as it was this year, or flat during the April-through-June quarter in six election years, and the incumbent party lost five of those elections, in 1952, 1960, 1968, 1976 and 1980. The only exception was in 1956, when Dwight D. Eisenhower was re-elected.
President Bush has said publicly and, according to his staff, privately that he did not expect voters to begin focusing intently on the election until the fall. But some of his chief advisers are not sure he is right.
"We could be at a turning point right now," a member of the campaign staff said. "I hope I'm wrong, but I think people are really beginning to pay attention."
Stuart E. Eizenstat, who was President Jimmy Carter's chief domestic policy adviser, said he learned first-hand in 1980 the consequences of a sour economy four or five months before the election.
"Voters lock into the economy, not on Election Day but the summer before," Mr. Eizenstat said. "And unless something really dramatic happens, unless there's a really big change in circumstances, their perceptions don't change."
Don Sipple, a Republican political consultant, called today's employment data "very bad news for Bush and the Republicans."
"Right now, the American people are focused on economic issues," Mr. Sipple said. "Mr. Bush suggests that the economy is making a comeback, but events in the real world defy that."
 
Wrong Time to Fish?
 Mr. Sipple said he was worried that Mr. Bush's plans for the next month could send a signal that he is unconcerned about the economy. The President leaves next week for the economic summit meeting in Munich. Then he plans to take a vacation at his summer home in Maine and to go fishing in Wyoming with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
Polls show that Mr. Bush's popularity rating first began to plunge not when the economy actually entered the recession in the summer of 1990 but in the summer and fall of 1991, when the recovery had clearly ground to a halt, and Mr. Bush seemed rather blase about it.
The latest New York Times/CBS News poll last month showed that only 34 percent of adults approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job, and that only 16 percent liked how he was dealing with the economy.
The dispute on the White House staff about the tone the President should adopt on the economy began building about six weeks ago. In the first three months of this year, the economy grew by 2.7 percent, meager by historical standards in the aftermath of a recession but still the strongest quarter in three years. Based on their public statements, Administration officials clearly felt they were out of the woods in terms of the economy.
But toward the end of May, economic conditions began to turn, much as they did last summer, and June was clearly worse than May. Statistics released in June about the housing market, retail sales and manufacturing were unfavorable. The trade balance took a bad swing, and the growth in the money supply was sluggish.
At staff meetings, officials said, Mr. Boskin began cautioning that the recovery might be lagging and said he was getting pessimistic reports from the business executives he sees regularly, but he met resistance from Mr. Skinner and others.
As a political matter, the President's advisers are especially concerned about the situation in California and New York, the states with the most electorial votes and among those with the weakest economies. Mr. Bush's recognition of the conditions in California on his trip there last month may have been an indication that Mr. Boskin has his ear, or it may have been the result of cautions from his political advisers.
Mr. Skinner was traveling today and could not be reached. Mr. Boskin said, "Whatever differences may occasionally occur, Sam Skinner has done a good job of making sure we all have an opportunity to convey our opinions directly to the President."

HEADLINE: House Passes Aid Plan for Inner Cities

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
House Republicans and Democrats today overwhelmingly approved a $5 billion urban aid package intended to help a limited number of depressed city neighborhoods attract new businesses, health clinics, job training and enhanced law enforcement.
Few legislators claim that the program will reverse the decline of the inner cities, where the flight of manufacturing industries, drug addiction and violent crime have accelerated in recent years. 
 But several Democrats from big cities said they hoped that after a decade of Federal neglect, the legislation signified a resurgence in Government efforts to address the social problems that touched off the riots in Los Angeles two months ago.
The package emerged from the realization by leaders of both parties that Ross Perot's independent Presidential candidacy was benefiting from a widespread perception that they were so busy playing politics they could no longer run the country.
"We will demonstrate to our constituents and ourselves that we can legislate and govern," Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, said, suggesting the self-doubt and frustration felt by many House members during a legislative session marked by scandal and inaction.
 
House Represented Hurdle
 Attached to a $14.5 billion tax bill, the program passed 356 to 55, as 198 Democrats were joined by 158 Republicans. The House, which is more representative of rural interests, was considered a higher hurdle for the bill than the Senate, which is expected to approve the bill in the coming weeks.
The package is essentially a pilot program merging Republican and Democratic strategies to alleviate crime and poverty. While President Bush won a limited capital gains tax cut to fuel investment in inner cities, Democrats won his support for modest expansions in Head Start and remedial educational programs, drug treatment centers for teenagers and pregnant women, child care and modernization of public housing.
"I feel great," Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, the Administration's strongest supporter of urban aid, said after the vote. "This is the first time the Democratic Congress has realized that cutting the capital gains tax is an incentive for investment."
 
HUD to Identify Zones
 Twenty-five urban zones will receive 80 percent of the benefits. They will be designated in the coming months by the Department of Housing and Urban Development from neighborhoods with unemployment rates 1.5 times the national average with at least 20 percent of their residents living below the poverty level.
Investors willing to put their money in the zones will get a number of tax benefits, including a 50 percent reduction in the capital gains tax if they hold their interests for a minimum of five years. The idea is that new business investments will take root alongside Government anti-drug and anti-gang programs. In theory, new businesses and safer streets will anchor stronger families, improve productivity and create greater opportunities for minority teen-agers to rise into the middle class.
Since corporations are not eligible for the benefit, the tax changes are not likely to increase manufacturing or heavy industry in the zones. Businesses that are likely to benefit are small private retailers and service companies.
The tax breaks are expected to cost the Treasury $2.5 billion over six years.
 
Selling the Package
 To garner the votes of rural lawmakers, 25 more enterprise zones will be selected in impoverished farming areas, and they will receive about 20 percent, or $1 billion, of the tax and program benefits.
"Anyone who calls this 'urban aid' can't read," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, who voted for the bill. "It may not mean anything for New York, except maybe we can turn the Federal Government around to go beyond 'just say no' to give people a reason to live. This is only a beginning."
The centerpiece of the program is the urban enterprise zones, which have long been pushed by Mr. Rangel, Mr. Kemp and aggressive conservative Republican lawmakers. Following the Los Angeles riots, Mr. Bush picked up the banner, and the Democrats reluctantly followed on the condition that he support social programs.
Critics charge that the urban enterprise zones will do little more than transfer businesses from one neighborhood to another, but conservatives, joined by big-city mayors and finally the Democratic Congressional leadership, convinced enough members that the idea deserved a chance in the form of a pilot experiment.
 
Capital Gains Compromise
 The Administration wanted a total exemption on capital gains for investors in the zones as long as the investments were held for two years, but the Democrats refused to go along with more than the 50 percent exemption.
The enterprise zones will also receive $500 million in annual aid over five years in a combination of projects jointly called "Weed and Seed." As conceptualized by the Administration, SWAT teams and other specially trained law enforcement officers will "weed" gangs and drug dealers out of the zones. Then "seeds," like expanded Head Start and drug rehabilitation centers, can take hold.
The Administration originally wanted to put a lion's share of the funds for Weed and Seed into policing. But the Democrats, led by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, would only go along with the package as long as 80 percent of the funding went into social programs.
Negotiations almost broke down several times in the last two weeks. In the hours leading up to the vote, Fred T. Goldberg Jr., the Assistant Secretary of Treasury for Tax Policy, attempted to apply the capital gains tax provisions to the sale of land. Mr. Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, threatened to nix the compromise.
Nicholas E. Calio, Assistant to the President for Legislative Affairs, intervened and convinced the Treasury Department to drop its demand.

GRAPHIC: Photo: House Republicans and Democrats have approved a $5 billion urban aid package intended to help a limited number of depressed city neighborhoods. Discussing the package yesterday were, from the left, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp; Nicholas E. Calio, Assistant to the President for Legislative Affairs; Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, and John Vogt of the Treasury. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Urban Aid Proposals"
 Benefits offered to businesses willing to invest in 50 enterprise zones.
* A 50 percent reduction of capital gains taxes for profits from interests held in a zone for a minimum of five years. Investors would now pay a 14 percent maximum rate, rather than a 28 percent maximum rate, from profits on the sale of assets.
* A $20,000 deduction in their first year of operations for newly purchased equipment.
* An annual deduction of up to $25,000 for purchases of stock in businesses investing in enterprise zones, up to $250,000 for each person.
* A 15 percent credit on wages for employers of residents living in the zone, up to a maximum of $3,000 per worker annually.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
For This 4th, They're Putting Out Fewer Flags

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Patriotism in advertising has not died, but it certainly has faded away.
A year ago, marketers inundated America with ad campaigns that had patriotic themes, trying to exploit the national mood of celebration over the Persian Gulf war. 
 The star-spangled fever extended beyond advertisers, like Coca-Cola, Pepsi-Cola and Anheuser-Busch, that usually weave red, white and blue motifs into their sales messages. Even Allied Fibers, Seagram's 7 Crown whisky and the Partnership for a Drug-Free America filled the summer of 1991 with a frenzy of flags and fireworks.
Now, though, that flood of patriotic hoopla and hyperbole has dwindled to a trickle, leaving the Fourth of July celebration this weekend largely devoid of corporate jingoism.
Notable exceptions, though, include Kmart, which is sponsoring a promotion to raise funds for a Star-Spangled Banner Monument in Washington, and Kraft General Foods, which is selling a new flavor of Sealtest ice cream called American Glory.
"The fervor went away in a hurry," said Susan Spaulding, vice president of research at Market Directions , a research concern in Kansas City, Mo., that has surveyed consumers on their attitudes toward advertising that uses patriotic symbols.
A primary reason why patriotism is being played down is a radical change in public attitudes that must rank among the most severe mood swings ever. The cheering over the Persian Gulf war has dissipated, replaced by recriminations over what the conflict actually accomplished. That attitude was cunningly summarized in a Democratic campaign slogan: "Saddam Hussein still has his job. Do you?"
"It's hard to be patriotic in the middle of a recession," said Bill Oberlander, a partner and creative director at Kirshenbaum & Bond in New York. Last year, for its client Moet & Chandon champagne, the agency ran ads pegged to the parade in New York City saluting the Gulf War veterans.
"For that one instant, there was a reason to celebrate," Mr. Oberlander added, "and we woke up with a hangover."
Advertising, he asserted, "is a reflection of society," so that if consumers are in a mood to wave flags, advertisers and their agencies will clamber aboard the flag-bedecked bandwagon. If they are not, if "there's nothing to be patriotic about," he said, ads will turn to alternative themes.
Earl Cavanah, executive vice president and group creative director at Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, expressed a similar belief.
"Somebody once asked, 'How does advertising stay fresh?' " he said. "Well, what's nice is, what happens around you changes. All you have to do is keep up with it."
Last July, Mr. Cavanah was among Scali executives who created a television commercial for Allied Fibers, in which a bright-red Anso "crush resistant" carpet was walked upon by the estimated 24,000 participants in the welcome home parade, then vacuumed back to shape by a lone cleaning woman.
Now, by contrast, "the mood is introspective," he said, "not flag-waving.
"It's looking inward to see what we can do to improve our country," he said.
Last summer was "Yellow Ribbon Summer" for the Anheuser-Busch Companies, which sponsored promotions like free admittance for members of the armed forces and their families to the company's theme parks, Busch Gardens and Sea World.
"Clearly, it's a different summer from last summer, when the troops were coming back," said Tom Sharbaugh, vice president for the Budweiser brands at Anheuser-Busch.
This summer's Budweiser ads, by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, will present patriotic themes in a different context, he added, by supporting the United States Olympic team, of which Budweiser is a sponsor.
One of the few advertisers now running an out-and-out patriotic campaign, the Kmart Corporation, traced that decision to the national mood last year.
"We obviously thought there'd be a lot more patriotic 'oomph' as we planned this nine months ago," said Mike Wellman, vice president of marketing, referring to his "Show Your Colors" monument promotion. "It's surprising."
The couple of hundred thousand dollars to be collected by Kmart's fund-raiser, which began May 24 and continues through Saturday, will be "lower than what we anticipated," he added, though "we're reasonably pleased with the results." The retailer is considering further promotions next year pegged to the monument, which will honor Francis Scott Key.
Ms. Spaulding, the research executive, said: "Putting a flag in an ad is very nice, but it doesn't enhance a company if it's just a symbol without relevance or benefit to the consumer."
Three cheers for the red, white and relevant?

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Jumps to 7.8%, Raising Doubts on Recovery

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
In a stunningly grim set of figures that challenged assumptions of continued economic recovery, the Labor Department reported today that the nation's jobless rate spurted another three-tenths of a point in June, to 7.8 percent, while payroll jobs slumped by 117,000.
Apart from suggesting that seasonal adjustment factors may have unduly magnified some losses, analysts found almost no comfort in data that included a shorter workweek, lengthening spells of unemployment, more layoffs and a swelling in the ranks of the jobless by 470,000, to a total of just under 10 million. 
 Among the 11 big industrial states, California's jobless rate, which rose to 9.5 percent last month from 8.7 percent in May, was the highest. New York had the biggest increase, up 1.3 percentage points, to 9.2 percent, while New Jersey's rate also hit 9.2 percent, up two-tenths of a point. The rate fell to 7.6 percent from 7.8 percent in Pennsylvania, the only industrial state to show a drop.
 
'Bummer' and 'Terrible'
 Economists used terms like "bummer," "terrible" and "Black Thursday" to comment on the report, which contrasted sharply with expectations for a downtick in the jobless rate and an increase of nearly 100,000 in payroll jobs.
The weak employment picture prompted many economists to review -- and in some cases notch down -- their forecasts. C. J. Lawrence, the brokerage house, for example, raised its estimate of the chances for a new dip in the economy to 1-in- 2 from 1-in-4.
Democrats took the occasion to attack the Bush Administration.
"Either the President must change his economic policy, or we must change Presidents," said Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
As the Federal Reserve moved almost immediately to ease monetary policy, cutting the discount rate a half point, to 3 percent, the White House did not seek to cast today's figures in a rosy light. Michael J. Boskin, the chief White House economic adviser, said he was "very concerned" about the increase.
By region, the Northeast posted the biggest increase, five-tenths of a point and now suffers the highest unemployment rate, 8.5 percent.
In a separate report on labor markets, the Labor Department found that first-time claims for jobless benefits totaled 420,000 in the week ended June 20. This was widely seen as confirming the sizable increase of the week of June 13 and was thus seen as a negative, despite 1,000 fewer claims.
The Commerce Department said in a separate report that orders to the nation's factories declined eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first decline in five months but a not unexpected development in light of a 2.4 percent drop in orders for durable goods reported last week.
More than half the rise in June joblessness occurred among teen-agers, whose unemployment rate jumped 3.6 percentage points, to 23.6 percent, as students and new graduates flocked into the job market but met with little success.
William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, cautioned that this annual influx can lead to gyrations in the statistics since seasonal adjustments may not fully capture current reality.
In fact, total employment as gauged by the Government's survey of households rose by nearly 1.4 million before seasonal adjustment, compared with an 82,000 decline after applying the adjustment factor. The survey of business payrolls showed a similar pattern last month -- up 457,000 before adjustment but down 117,000, to a total of about 108.4 million, on a seasonally adjusted basis.
"I don't put a great deal of credence in the employment report," said Kathryn Eickhoff, a New York consultant and former chief economist in the Reagan era for the Office of Management and Budget. "I would not jump to the conclusion that the economy's weakening."
But while others expressed sympathy for this view, most economists seemed quite disturbed by the June job report.
"It raises questions about whether there is any recovery under way at all," said Norman Robertson of Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "There really was not a bright spot."
 
More Workers for Fewer Jobs
 The rising jobless rate, which hit another eight-year high, reflected continued sharp growth in the labor force, which expanded by 389,000 people last month at the same time that total jobs shrank by 82,000. Practically all of the labor-force increase was among adult women.
While teen-agers accounted for much of the rise in joblessness, the ranks of laid-off workers expanded by 169,000 and there were similar increases in the number of newly unemployed -- out of work less than five weeks -- and in the hard-core jobless who have been without work for more than six months.
The jobless rate for white teen-agers jumped nearly four points, to 20.6 percent, while the rate for black teen-agers fell modestly to 41.6 percent, with females doing much better while males did worse. The rate for black teen-age males climbed to 50.3 percent on a nonadjusted basis, up from 41.9 percent in June 1991.
Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal group, said today that more than 17 million Americans were either unemployed or underemployed last month for a "real" jobless rate of 13.4 percent over all and about 40 percent for teen-agers.
The Labor Department's quarterly tabulation of discouraged workers -- those who have stopped looking for a job because they think they would fail to find one -- was almost unchanged again last month at 1.1 million.
The payroll survey showed particular weakness in manufacturing, which lost 58,000 jobs last month, and construction, which shed 32,000 after seasonal adjustment even though actual jobs grew by 128,000. Jobs in wholesale trade dropped 16,000 and health services expanded by just 7,000, far below the gains that have prevailed for years.
The index of aggregate hours slumped back to the 120.7 level that prevailed in April, today's report showed, while only 43 percent of industries added workers in June compared with 50.4 percent in May.
"The June employment figures show that the recovery is rockier than the Rocky Mountains," said John M. Albertine, a Washington consultant. "The economy simply cannot provide enough jobs for all the Americans who want them."

HEADLINE: Glut of Office Space In New York Market Lessens Relocations

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A glut of Manhattan office space has produced an unexpected side effect: Declining rents have slowed the pace of business relocations to the suburbs, the Sun Belt and other cities.
The glut has become so severe, in fact, that for the first time New York City's midtown business district was surpassed this year by Washington as the nation's most costly place to rent office space. 
 And while Manhattan developers, lenders and landlords are tallying the huge costs of a building binge that went bust, some experts maintain that the office surplus and falling rents have shored up New York's stature as a global center of corporate activity.
Yesterday, in the latest corporate commitment to Manhattan, Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, said it had signed a 15-year lease on 15 floors at Americas Tower, a vacant new office tower at 45th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. It will transfer 1,800 employees to the building from other locations in Manhattan in July 1993.
"New York City now has to be considered the best option available," said James J. Schiro, Price Waterhouse's vice chairman. Although he declined to say how much rent the firm will pay for its new offices, he said it had considered several other alternatives, including suburban sites, but had been swayed by huge amount of space available and declining prices in Manhattan.
Other executives said they expected similar deals.
"This recession is a disaster for real estate, but it is helping Manhattan retain tenants," said Michael Solomon, director of the New York office of Julien J. Studley, a real-estate brokerage. "The deals are so sweet they can't be refused."
Data compiled by Cushman & Wakefield, a real-estate concern, showed that asking prices for rents fell by an average of 10 percent since 1988 in the two principal Manhattan business districts, midtown and lower Manhattan.
The company says that the average asking rent in midtown was $37.56 a square foot in the first three months of 1992, before discounts. And many landlords are offering rich incentives to new tenants by covering the costs of renovations -- savings that sometimes amount to millions of dollars.
To be sure, business executives continue to grumble about taxes, labor costs, crime, noise, and a host of other Manhattan complaints, and companies continue to flee.
Recent departures include W. R. Grace, which moved last year with 500 employees from midtown Manhattan to Boca Raton, Fla., and the American Home Products Corporation, which has said it will move from 685 Third Avenue to a new headquarters in Madison, N.J., next year, eliminating 1,000 New York City jobs.
 
A Change of Plans
 But analysts say the business departures from Manhattan have been less frequent over the last three years than in the previous two decades, although no one has kept reliable, long-term records on the actual number of relocations.
One company that has decided to stay in Manhattan is Sterling Winthrop Inc., a pharmaceutical and health-care subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company that employs 1,000 people on Park Avenue. It had purchased a New Jersey golf course in the mid-1980's and planned to make it the site of a new suburban campus-style headquarters.
That plan was scrapped last year. "The market forces were obviously working in our favor," said Robin Mills, a company spokesman. With midtown rents falling, he said, Sterling Winthrop negotiated a lease for more space in its current building, at 90 Park Avenue, and sold the New Jersey site.
The city's economic development officials are gloating over the decision in March by Bertelsmann A.G., the German media conglomerate that owns RCA Records and the Bantam Doubleday Dell publishing house, to purchase a new, vacant 46-story office tower at 1540 Broadway, at 45th Street, in Times Square.
Bertelsmann had been considering moving most of its New York City operations, with 500 employees spread among several midtown buildings, to Chicago. But with the developers of the Times Square building in bankruptcy proceedings, the city offered property tax reductions and Bertelsmann agreed to purchase the tower as its headquarters and set aside several floors as an "incubator" for other foreign companies seeking space in Manhattan.
 
Opportunity From Bankruptcy
 Because of the recession, the cutbacks in employment at Manhattan companies, and the building boom of the 1980's, office vacancy rates in Manhattan are more bloated than at any time since records started being kept in the 1960's, with 21.9 percent of the space available in midtown and 17.9 percent available in lower Manhattan, real-estate industry studies show. Although the vacancies have fallen slightly this year in lower Manhattan, they have continued to rise in midtown.
At the same time, of course, rents have fallen elsewhere, and corporate planners are finding landlords across the New York region who are eager to negotiate. In Fairfield County, Conn., which has been luring business away from Manhattan for more than 20 years, studies show that asking rents have plummeted 18 percent since 1986.
But executives say many companies, even those casting covetous eyes on the suburbs or other cities, face new hurdles in pulling up their Manhattan roots. One is the depressed market for homes and apartments, which has created new headaches and expenses for companies that must cover part of the losses sustained by employees who are relocated.
Another problem is faced by companies that want to move before the expiration of their leases in Manhattan, which normally run at least 20 years. Although these companies have in the past been able to sublet their vacant offices to other businesses, sometimes at a profit, tenants willing to sublet space have now become a rare breed.
As a result, "it is safe to say there are a number of companies based in Manhattan that would not still be here" if the recession had not converged with falling office rents, said Karen Gerard, vice president of Moran, Stahl & Boyer, a corporate relocation consulting firm.
Fish & Neave, a law firm at 875 Third Avenue, might have left the city if not for the lower rents. For a decade the firm had considered relocating to the suburbs, but in March it signed a 20-year lease in the former Exxon Building at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, at 49th Street. "Office space has just gotten more affordable with time," said Lars Kulleseid, managing partner.
Telerep, an advertising firm on Third Avenue at 52d Street, in January signed a lease for new and larger offices on Second Avenue near 48th Street.
The firm's new rent, $26 a square foot, will be far below the $46 it is now paying, said Patricia Prie, chief financial officer, and the new landlord has promised to pay for $3.6 million in remodeling and construction. "Even the electricians are negotiating their prices," she said.
But Manhattan remains vulnerable to the loss of large, prestigious companies. Several Wall Street brokerage firms, including Kidder Peabody at 10 Hanover Square and Smith Barney, at 1345 Avenue of the Americas, have been rumored for more than a year to be considering suburban sites for new headquarters.
Morgan Stanley, long considered a corporate trend-setter on Wall Street, has acquired an option to buy land in downtown Stamford, Conn., and commissioned architectural drawings of a new headquarters there. If it leaves Manhattan, where the lease on its headquarters at 1251 Avenue of the Americas expires in 1998, the firm said it would take 4,100 employees.
"We are keeping our options open," said Jeanne Andrews, a Morgan Stanley spokeswoman.
But at City Hall officials say the depressed real-estate market may now be proving more persuasive than the public incentives, like reduced taxes and energy subsidies, that were offered in the 1980's to persuade companies to stay.
"Renters are getting significant advantages in this market," said Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, "and that is going to benefit the city for years to come."
The industry's data suggest that the glut in part resulted from development incentives during the 1980's in the western part of the midtown area, where several new office towers still have huge amounts of vacant space on the market.
