HEADLINE: New York Area Job Data Are Especially Grim

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In an employment picture nationwide that is unremittingly bleak, the scene in the New York region appears gloomier than most.
New York State experienced one of the sharpest jumps in joblessness in the nation last month, undermining hopes for the region's recovery soon. The Government said yesterday that the unemployment rate in New York State jumped to 9.2 percent in June from 7.9 percent in May, with most of the increase coming in New York City. 
 It said the jobless rate in New Jersey also rose to 9.2 percent in June, up from 9 percent in May.
"We are still losing jobs," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Government's Bureau of Labor Statistics. He said New York and New Jersey "are in the same economic boat, and it is taking on a lot of water."
The increases in New York and New Jersey were sharper than in the nation as a whole, where the unemployment rate for June increased to 7.8 percent from 7.3 percent in May. Only California, where unemployment reached 9.5 percent in June, had a higher rate than New York and New Jersey, the Labor Department said.
Economists attributed the higher unemployment rates in New York to job losses in industries that have traditionally been large employers: advertising, accounting, management consulting, construction and retailing.
The effect has been most severe in New York City, where the Government said the unemployment rate jumped to 11.5 percent in May from 10.5 percent in April. Mr. Ehrenhalt said the city has lost 350,000 jobs since the end of 1988, including 45,000 since January. Elsewhere in New York state, he said, 5,000 jobs have been eliminated since January; New Jersey has lost 50,000 jobs this year.
Although economists said they were surprised by the increase, particularly in New York State, they say that the high and persistent rates of unemployment were simply another reminder of the severity of the recession in the New York region.
"It has been something akin to Murphy's Law: Anything that went wrong in this recession happened here," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for Chemical Bank in New York City. Consolidation and job losses in the banking industry, the streamling of corporate headquarters, and military industry spending cuts have all taken a harsher toll in the New York region than in most of the nation, he said.
Some segments of the regional economy offer prospects for improvement later this year, Mr. Kellner said, including employment on Wall Street, where the securities industry has benefitted from robust profits for more than a year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Jobs Data Push Bonds Up Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stunning weakness in labor statistics for June and the Federal Reserve Board's equally striking response to the data caused an eruption in the credit markets yesterday. Prices of fixed-income securities rose sharply and interest rates fell.
A drop of 117,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, and a sharp three-tenths of a percentage point rise in the unemployment rate, to 7.8 percent, were the highlights of a report that analysts said contained no rays of hope. 
 Aggregate hours worked fell sharply and hourly earnings fell to a five-year low, strongly suggesting that manufacturing output and incomes fell in June.
"The numbers were horrific," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "The only way to get any momentum in the economy is to do what the Fed did."
The Fed's announcement that it had cut its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 3 percent, came less than an hour after the employment data were released at 8:30 A.M. Eastern time.
The half-point cut in the overnight Federal funds rate, to 3.25 percent, was confirmed later in the morning when the Fed conducted open market operations.
 
23d Cut in Funds Rate
 It was the 23d time since the summer of 1989 that the Fed has cut the funds rate.
But many analysts said they were skeptical that this easing move would be any more effective at reviving the economy than the previous ones have been. They added that in the absence of a more stimulative fiscal policy, the Fed will probably need to lower rates again.
"Unfortunately, I don't think this will help," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America in San Francisco.
"The economy to me does not seem to be restrained by the level of interest rates or by a lack of liquidity," he said. "But my gut says the Fed is not finished easing rates. I think the economy will continue to be a slug, and that the Fed will have to help again."
The avalanche of buy and sell orders that emerged yesterday were telescoped into a few hours of trading, as the market closed at 1 P.M. to start the Fourth of July weekend. There will be no trading today.
The early close prevented market participants from reacting to an extremely weak set of money-supply figures released late yesterday by the Fed.
 
Money Supply Declines
 All three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended on June 22, the Fed said. M-2, the aggregate most closely tracked by the central bank, fell by $10.6 billion, much more than the $2 billion drop many Wall Street economists had predicted.
At the close of trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10411/32 , up just over 1 3/8 points, to yield 7.62 percent, down from 7.74 percent late Wednesday and 7.77 percent on June 26. It is the lowest yield on the Government's benchmark issue since late January.
Among outstanding Treasury notes, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 1043/32 , up 1 1/8 points, to yield 6.91 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 10027/32 , up 15/32 , to yield 4.55 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills plummeted.
 
Short-Term Rates Off
 Three-month bills were offered yesterday at a discount rate of 3.22 percent, down 31 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 28 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.33 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 30 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.55 percent.
The sharp fall in market interest rates prompted corporations to price a total of $875 million worth of debt securities, an unusually large amount for a holiday-shortened session.
Among the issuers was the Fleet Financial Group, which priced $200 million worth of three-year senior notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 5 5/8 percent notes were priced at $99.652 percent to yield 5.75 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 7/8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The sharp rise in prices of Government securities helped to bolster prices of outstanding corporate and tax-exempt bonds.
Corporate traders said prices of most issues rose by 3/4 of a point to a full point.
Prices of widely quoted municipal bonds were up by a point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Jobless Data and Rate Cuts Cause Dollar to Close Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most currencies yesterday after the Government released weak unemployment statistics and the Federal Reserve cut interest rates.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $346.50, up $2.20 an ounce from Wednesday. Republic National Bank later quoted gold at $346.25, up $2.25. 
 After tumbling in morning trading on the economic news and the Fed action, the dollar rebounded somewhat.
 
Surprise in Jobless Data
 The Labor Department said the nation's unemployment rate surged to 7.8 percent in June, the highest level in more than eight years. "The unemployment data bring into question the progress of the U.S. economy," said Kevin Logan, chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
The decline surprised economists and spurred the central bank to cut the discount rate -- the rate it charges on loans to member banks -- to 3 percent from 3.5 percent.
Several hours later, economists said the Fed appeared to lower its target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge one another on overnight loans -- from 3.75 percent to 3.25 percent.
Speculation about the Fed's monetary policy had driven the dollar lower in recent weeks. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, decreasing the need for the United States currency.
 
'Sell on Rumor, Buy on Fact'
 Traders described the dollar's bounce back from its lows Thursday as a classic case of "sell on the rumor, buy on the fact."
Mike Faust, senior currency strategist at MMS International, said the problems that have been plaguing the dollar in recent weeks -- low interest rates and the faltering economy -- are far from resolved. The currency could head lower, he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 124.45 Japanese yen, from 125.43 Wednesday. Later, in London, it rose to 124.60 yen. In New York, a dollar bought 124.40 yen, down from 125.40 yen Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9175, from $1.9111 late Wednesday. In New York, a pound cost $1.9235, up from $1.9055 Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.5075 German marks, down from 1.5230; 1.3515 Swiss francs, down from 1.37; 5.072 French francs, down from 5.1245; 1,142.75 Italian lire, down from 1,152.5, and 1.20095 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20245.
In London, gold rose to $346.25 an ounce, from $343.30 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: A SALUTE TO THE FOURTH;
Celebrating Columbus And the Age Of Sail

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
AS the tall ship Gazela glided past Penn's Landing in Philadelphia last week, her sails unfurled like a bird in full plumage display, the crowd onshore delivered the ultimate accolade: a thousand-kazoo salute.
The tribute, heartfelt and spontaneous, seemed about right for the Gazela, a hardy old Portuguese barkentine that once hauled codfish between the Grand Banks and Lisbon. Acquired in 1972 by the Philadelphia Ship Preservation Guild and later restored, she offers sail training to interested civilians, young and old, from her home port. It's a democratic mission, and the Philadelphia ship got a democratic salute as she led a flotilla of tall ships up the Delaware River. 
 The Gazela of Philadelphia (her full name) may not be the most beautiful, but at 109 years she will be the oldest of the 31 tall ships and about 250 smaller vessels that gather in New York Harbor this weekend as part of Operation Sail '92, organized in observance of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's first voyage to the New World. They will form what John E. Richard, the executive director of Operation Sail, never tires of calling "the largest grouping of tall ships since the age of sail began."
The tall-ship review will be the centerpiece of five days of ship parades, concerts, a street festival and concert at South Street Seaport, and a July 4 fireworks display in New York Harbor. Officials at Op Sail, as the organization is known for short, say they are expecting upward of 15 million spectators, and the Coast Guard says it predicts that 40,000 small craft will crowd into New York Harbor for a closer look at the ships.
The celebrations begin today when 60 smaller vessels, many of them replicas of historic ships, sail down the East River from Long Island Sound to Gravesend Bay from noon to 5 P.M. In the grand Parade of Sail on the Fourth of July, some 250 smaller ships will join the tall ships at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and, in a line stretching for 11 miles, sail up the Hudson River to the George Washington Bridge (tall ships) or 79th Street (Class B and C
vessels) before returning to berths along the East River and Hudson River, where designated ships will be open for public viewing. Replicas of the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria, which cannot make the necessary speed for the parade, will lie at anchor off Governor's Island during the parade. As a finale, on Tuesday, 1,700 uniformed tall-ship cadets parade up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall.
The ships of Op Sail's parade will come in all shapes and sizes, from Latvia's 399-foot Sedov down to the 30-foot Viking III, a Sea Explorers ship from Norwalk, Conn. Officially, vessels are divided into Class A, the tall ships (more than 160 feet long), Class B (100 to 160 feet) and Class C (less than 100 feet), although several smaller protocol ships, like Britain's Lord Trenchard, a mere minnow at 54 feet 6 inches, will sail with the Class A fleet.
With a bow to Columbus, the nucleus of the grand fleet started out from Genoa, Italy, and Lisbon in early April and headed to Cadiz, Spain, to pick up more ships. After racing to the Canary Islands, Columbus's last landfall before setting out westward across the Atlantic, the fleet started the second racing leg of the journey, to San Juan, Puerto Rico. The first ship to arrive in New York was Norway's Christian Radich, a comely 240-foot training vessel for Norway's merchant marine, with a crew that includes 36 female and 42 male cadets. The last and, because of prevailing winds, the most difficult part of the race will take place when the ships leave Boston for Liverpool, England, on July 11.
 
Training Ships
 Nearly all the ships, like the Radich (pronounced RAH-dik), serve as training vessels for merchant marines and navies around the world. The Eagle, originally built for the German Navy in 1936, now sails out of New London, Conn., where she serves as the training vessel of the Coast Guard Academy. The military purpose translated into an impressive fashion statement. The cadets look sharp in mainsail white. They also put on a good show when approached by other tall ships, lining up along the railing and giving a crisp salute and a blast of the ship's cannon. Some crews shout out ritual cheers or songs.
The Gazela is a little different. Staffed by volunteers, the Philadelphia ship offers summer training courses to whomever signs up, or in some cases, wanders by. The uniform, such as it is, is modified camp counselor: khaki shorts, a blue or yellow knit shirt with the ship's name, and Topsiders or tennis shoes. On their belts, crew members carry knives in leather sheaths and steel spikes, the all-purpose tools for tightening and loosening knots. But the seafaring philosophy and shipboard discipline is pretty much the same as on the more grandiose vessels.
"They're here for the romance, but it's hard work," said Steve Morgandale, the Gazela's boatswain, scanning the deck as the crew prepared to leave the dock. "Also, it's like an industrial scenario. You can hurt yourself really easily." Mr. Morgandale, an aircraft mechanic who has been a Gazela volunteer for six years, casually noted the prime hazards, such as getting your fingers caught in a line, or falling from the yards and masts.
A quick look upward bore him out. As the Gazela prepared to set sail, or rather, start up her engines -- the wind was calm and the Delaware River is in any case too narrow to allow her to tack -- crew members scrambled up the rigging and sidled out to the end of the yards, supported by a single, very delicate-looking strand known as a foot rope. The distance from the top of the main mast to the deck is 94 feet.
"In winter it can be tricky, because the foredeck shrouds freeze your hands, and you can't wear gloves," said Cynthia Rugart, a crew member, referring to the iron lines that stabilize the mast. "Also, when the sail billows, it can blow you right off the foot ropes."
Ms. Rugart, a student nurse, also mentioned the difficulty of climbing past the foretop, a wooden platform about halfway up the mast. To negotiate the obstacle, crew members must climb with their backs at a 45-degree angle to the deck below.
In addition to the physical work, crew members must master the hundred and one routines required to operate and maintain the ship, as well as a substantial, arcane vocabulary. "Every line and sail has a name and a function," Mr. Morgandale said. "If I say tend the course sheet and you don't know what it is, you're in trouble and you're unusable."
With a normal complement of 35, crew members work through a rotation of five jobs on a standard four-hour watch. All of them eventually get a turn at the wheel, which is more a matter of symbolism than actual power. The striking, painfully obvious fact that strikes every landlubber who boards a tall ship is this: the helmsman cannot see to steer the ship. Yes, there is a compass, right in front of the wheel. But a compass cannot indicate that an iceberg lies dead ahead. Instead, ships rely on three pairs of eyes. Two crew members stand lookout at the bow of the ship, scanning the water for ships, markers, enemy submarines, whatever. A runner delivers breaking news to the deck officer standing aft near the helmsman. In most cases, the officer already knows what the runner is telling him, since he paces incessantly back and forth, leaning over the side and scanning the horizon.
 
Aura of Mark Twain
 On the Gazela, the stand-in for the deck officer was Charles Futcher, a Delaware River pilot who normally guides tankers and container ships up the river. Anyone who has read "Life on the Mississippi" has a pretty good idea of the job description, and of a pilot's encyclopedic knowledge of tides, currents, shoals and bottom topography. Rivers have not changed since Twain wrote the book, and the pilot still carries with him a certain aura.
Looking sharp in brokerlike attire (button-down shirt, tie and suspenders), Mr. Futcher signaled rudder commands to the helmsman with one hand. A set of headphones and wrap-around microphone kept him in communication with other ships and tugboats, an advance on the whistle signals of Twain's day.
"Today is pretty crazy," Mr. Futcher said. "You don't get small-boat traffic like this normally." Indeed, the river was dotted with pleasure craft that a Coast Guard boat, siren wailing, constantly shooed away from the ships, like a bodyguard protecting a celebrity. "Small boats seem to have a hard time gauging relative motion," Mr. Futcher said. "They place too much faith in their engines."
Mr. Futcher, whose habit of crunching ice cubes as he paced back and forth betrayed a certain level of stress, said of the job, "It's not tense, but it's intense." Mistakes tend to be very, very costly. It's more than a two-aspirin bad day when you run an oil tanker aground. "There's no room in this job for a weak stomach or a tentative personality," he said.
The same might be said of running Operation Sail '92, which seems to have been concocted with three ingredients: a shoestring, a wing and a prayer.
The event originated two years ago as a joint venture between Gran Regata Colon, an international association formed to celebrate the Columbus voyage, and Op Sail, a 30-year-old group that staged tall ship parades for the New York World's Fair in 1964, the Bicentennial in 1976, and the Statue of Liberty centennial in 1986.
For the last year and a half, Op Sail has functioned with a full-time staff of one. Not until this spring was a secretary hired for the event.
If, by some miracle, all 280 ships should find their proper places and sail in orderly fashion up the Hudson and back, gale-force sighs of relief will emanate from Op Sail headquarters in the World Trade Center, where a tiny staff of 5 managers has now been fleshed out with between 10 and 20 volunteers. For the last two months the city has also helped out by lending personnel from the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Jubilee Commission.
 
New Tack Needed
 "The project has brought out the best and the worst in people," said Mr. Richard, a Connecticut banker who was approached by Op Sail's board three months ago and presented, as he delicately put it, "with a challenge that was fast approaching."
Mr. Richard's company, A.J.T. Inc. of Westport, Conn., specializes in turnaround situations. This was one of them. Op Sail had raised virtually no money, and planning was in disarray. With ships already under sail from Europe, Op Sail had not yet created the 120-page handbooks that provide each of the 280 ship's captains critical information on tides, radio frequencies and parade order -- "basically it's to keep them from running into each other," Mr. Richard said.
A lean, silver-haired man with a flair for understatement, Mr. Richard said that "there was a certain fluidity about who was doing what in the office." There was a positive and a negative aspect to this, apparently. "Everyone had a job," Mr. Richard said, "but nobody else knew what it was."
 
Like Apple Pie
 Operation Sail found that in tight economic times, corporate underwriting was hard to come by. The lead sponsors include Pepsi-Cola and I.B.M., for an event that Mr. Richard projects will cost between $8 million and $10 million. The cost is an estimate because many campanies have provided goods and services rather than money.
Mr. Richard said he was dismayed at the number of companies that could see the event only as a marketing tool, a mind-set reflected in a number of ships that had to be turned away because they had company logos slapped all over their sails and hulls. "As Op Sail sees it, tall ships are like motherhood and apple pie," he said. "You don't mess with them."
If Op Sail seemed, until the last couple of weeks, to be a closely guarded secret, that is because, Mr. Richard said, "we're trying to run a P.R. effort with no bucks. It's not apparent, it's transparent -- it's invisible." On the plus side, a number of individuals and companies have stepped forward to offer assistance with no strings attached.
Most disappointing, Mr. Richard said, has been the eagerness of certain political figures to take credit for the event. "But the political animals will come and go," he said philosophically. "These ships will be around for 100 years."
 
Road to Oblivion
 By rights, they should no longer exist. When Op Sail was founded in 1962 to organize the first gathering of tall ships, "it was a last gathering of the elephants before they became extinct, these square-rigged ships that had carried the world's cargo for 3,000 years," said Peter Stanford, the president of the National Maritime Historical Society.
But a funny thing happened on the road to oblivion. There are now dozens of large sail-training ships around the world, kept alive largely because European countries stubbornly insisted that their merchant sailors and naval personnel needed traditional training in winds and tides aboard a sailing ship.
"That argument wore thin," Mr. Stanford said, "because you don't really need that kind of training to drive a powered vessel." But there was always a hidden agenda behind the ships. They were ideal for building teamwork and discipline.
"The ships are archaic, but maybe that's important, too," he said. "They go the roots of our civilization, and maybe we need to get a little closer to those roots now and then."
The point was made for him as the Gazela headed down the Delaware River to meet a flotilla of tall ships and lead them back to Penn's Landing. As she passed the Polish barkentine Iskra, a line of cadets in white uniforms saluted, shouted the name of their ship four times in unison, and cheered. With an ear-splitting boom, a tiny cannon fired a salute. Nearby, Bulgaria's sleek black Kaliakra and the American brig Niagara prepared to fall in line and head into port.
Throughout the morning, the light flapping of the Gazela's sails was drowned out periodically by passing airliners, the faster descendants of the clipper ships, brigs, barks and cutters that plied the oceans a century and more ago. As the Gazela made her last turn toward the dock, a final passenger jet flew overhead, once more silencing the wind, the waves and the sails -- and the chorus of kazoos. It was the victory of brute strength and commerce over romance and beauty.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Christian Radich from Norway, an early arrival for Operation Sail '92. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times) (pg. C1); Aboard the Norwegian sailing ship Christian Radich. The Radich operates with a crew of men and women. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times); At the wheel of the Gazela. (Tom McGovern for The New York Times) (pg. C21)
 
Diagram: "The Sailing Ships: How to Tell Them Apart"
 
Full-rigged ship
Three or more masts, all with square-rigged sails. Designed for sailing conditions in which the wind comes from behind.
 
Bark
Three or more masts. The mast farthest aft-the mizzenmast - carries sails for set fore and aft. The other sails are square. Staysails are usually set between the masts.
 
Barkentine
Three or more masts. It carries square sails only on the foremast. The other sails are set for and aft. It has numerous staysails.
 
Brig
Two masts. Each carries several square sails. It can carry a spanker, a fore-and-aft sail used in addition to or in place of one of the mainmast's square sails.
 
Brigantine
Two masts. The foremast is rigged with square sails, while the mainmast is rigged with fore-and-aft sails.
 
Schooner
Two or more masts. Mainmast, which carries the mainsail, is either taller than the mast if front of it (the foremast) or the same size.
 
Ketch
Two masts. The mainmast is taller that the mast behind it (the mizzenmast). The mizzenmasst is in front of the rudderpost.
 
Sloop
Single mast. Generally carries two sails: a mainsail attached to the mast and a boom, and a headsail, which flies forward of the mainsail.
 
(pg. C21)

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Toronto Museum on Hiatus
In these hard economic times, many museums threaten to close; the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto is really doing it -- at least for six months, part of which had been intended for expansion. Tomorrow it will shut until Jan. 24. The museum is also laying off almost half its staff.
"I guess we're just one more on the casualty list," said Glenn Lowry, the museum's director. The Art Gallery of Ontario, considered one of Canada's most important cultural institutions, owns the world's largest collection of Henry Moore sculptures, as well as sizable holdings in European and North American paintings, drawings and sculptures. 
 Like the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which closed for two and a half years for renovation and expansion, the Art Gallery of Ontario was planning to close for three months to finish a three-part expansion begun in the early 1970's. As its financial problems increased, however, so did the amount of time it would be closed. "We really had no choice," Mr. Lowry said. "The layoffs and the closure were necessary in order to cope with the funding announced by the Ministry of Culture and Communications earlier this month."
The cultural minister for Ontario, Karen Haslam, said the blame should go not to the Government, but to the museum for not handling its finances better. "This was a business decision the gallery made on its own," Ms. Haslam said. "In fact, the gallery's operating budget wasn't cut; it was increased by $1 million."
The numbers the museum quotes for its annual budget and those released by Ms. Haslam's office differ, or at least the interpretations of the numbers differ. The museum, which calls itself the A.G.O., said in a statement: "The total of $10.5 million for 1992-1993 is considerably less than the $12.5 million in operating support provided to the A.G.O. by the Ontario Ministry of Culture and Communications in 1990-1991."
Ms. Haslam said the operating budget was $9.5 million this year and $8.5 million last year. She also said the figures released by the museum included a $1 million, one-time grant this year and a $4 million, one-time grant the year before.
Mr. Lowry said: "Since 1981, the ministry has always provided us with additional grant money. They say they are giving us a $1 million increase for our base operating budget, but nobody's buying that story. The reality is that it's a 25 percent cut."
The museum's problems go beyond its daily operating costs. The third part of the expansion cost $58 million, which "is quite separate from the operating budget," Mr. Lowry said. "We have to reinstall 113,000 square feet of gallery space, and we don't have the money to stay open and do that."
The Ministry of Culture is aware of the museum's growing pains, but officials say they are helping as much as they can, given the economic climate. Ms. Haslam's press secretary, Kirsten Kozolanka, said: "Every year, at the end of the year, the gallery has come to us asking for money, and they've gotten it. This year the minister, who has only been here 10 months, finally said no. There won't be any more bailouts."
A source close to the minister's office, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said Ms. Haslam had little sympathy for what she considered "elitist cultural institutions."
Ms. Haslam responded: "That's totally untrue. We have increased funding to the arts community by $7.5 million at a very tough time."
Meanwhile, the museum sees a bleak future. "How can you run a bigger museum with half the staff?" Mr. Lowry said. "It's impossible. I really don't know what we're going to do."
 
Selling Odds and Ends
 This is the season when the New York auction houses will sell almost anything and call it a collectible. Last Friday, for example, Sotheby's sold a piece of a guitar smashed by Jimi Hendrix at a music festival in Monterey, Calif., circa 1967, for $8,800. This may seem like a hefty sum, but not to Sotheby's, which estimated that the fragment would bring $10,000 to $15,000. The buyer was an unidentified private collector.
Included in the sale were artifacts like the harmonica Bob Dylan used during the summer of 1961, which fetched $3,575, more than the auction house estimate of $2,000 to $3,000, and Buddy Holly's signed junior high school homework, from 1952, which sold for $880, just above Sotheby's high estimate of $800. The entire sale, which included toys, rock-and-roll memorabilia and animation art, totaled $1 million.
The sum is far lower than Sotheby's estimate of $2.8 million to $3.7 million. The reason the sale didn't do better, a spokeswoman at Sotheby's press office said, was that the estimate included a ship that was being auctioned, too: the H.M.S. Bounty from the 1962 movie "Mutiny on the Bounty." The ship, part of Operation Sail '92 in New York Harbor this weekend, was expected to bring between $2 million to $2.5 million, but she sank in the salesroom. Bidding stopped at $1.4 million, and she went unsold.
Joshua Arfer, who heads the collectibles department at Christie's East, said interest in its entertainment memorabilia this summer was "out of control." "When something is iconic, from a big name like Marilyn or Elvis, people go wild," he said.
But while entertainment sells, toys, dolls, and mechanical and cast-iron banks are having a poor season, as the Christie's auction on Monday showed. The entire sale totaled $179,245, far below Christie's presale estimate of $343,245 to $477,270. Both auction houses report that buyers were predominantly private collectors.
At Christie's East, collectors bid on objects including a pair of Killer Bee antennae from the television show "Saturday Night Live," which sold for $605, midway between the auction house's high and low estimates of $700 and $500. There was also a red-and-black nylon "engineering" tunic from the 1960's "Star Trek," which fetched a whopping $1,650, above the auction house's high estimate of $1,500.
But by far the star item of its sale was a black beaded and sequined cocktail dress that Marilyn Monroe wore in the 1959 movie "Some Like It Hot." It was sold to David Gainsborough Roberts, a collector who lives on the British Channel Islands. Mr. Roberts, a collector of film memorabilia for more than 40 years, said he was lending part of his costume collection to the Imperial War Museum in London for an exhibition in February.
"I particularly enjoy buying personal things," Mr. Roberts said. "I've just heard about a car belonging to Dutch Schultz, the 1930's gangster, that's going up for sale in Pebble Beach, Calif., next month. Years ago I tried unsuccessfully to buy Bonnie and Clyde's car. But Schultz's car would be great to put in my garage, too."
 
Sid Deutsch Is Closing
 The Sid Deutsch Gallery at 29 West 57th Street in Manhattan is closing this week after 20 years. The reason is, in part, Mr. Deutsch's health. "Doctor's orders," he said. "But the recession didn't help." The gallery specialized in 20th-century American art. Mr. Deutsch will be dealing privately.

HEADLINE: For Children

BYLINE: By Dulcie Leimbach

 BODY:

United Nations Tours
United Nations
Visitors' Entrance
First Avenue at 45th Street
Manhattan
(212) 963-7713
Recommended ages: 5 and up
Once you step inside the United Nations headquarters, you enter a stream of foreign voices, languages and faces that makes you feel as if you have landed at Heathrow Airport near London; the feeling, of course, is a thrill for adults and children, who immediately seem to sense the kinetic atmosphere of the place.
The daily tours, for groups of 15 or more, can be tailored for children on request. The tours are packed with 45 minutes of head-swarming details, which few could absorb entirely, but sitting in the cavernous General Assembly chamber can make even the very young feel like worldly sages. 
 The tours leave every 15 minutes or so and are conducted in up to 20 languages, from Hebrew to Portuguese. Our group consisted of 22 people (including two boys wearing ties) who were first told the structure of the United Nations' six main entities (the Security Council, the Secretariat, etc.) and their purposes. We then moved quickly to a first-floor exhibition on disarmament, where maps, charts and display cases reveal the horrors of atomic bombs. In one display, was a melted and broken teacup that had nearly survived the wreckage of the bombs dropped on Hiroshima, Japan.
We moved on to another, far less visually interesting exhibition: how the United Nations has improved the standard of living of people worldwide through its agencies. On the third floor, we were swept through (and got to sit down in) all the chambers: the Security Council, the Trusteeship Council, the Economic and Social Council and the General Assembly. None of the rooms were in use, making visitors long to hear tempers flare in the General Assembly or to catch a glimpse of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali in the Security Council. But the assembly meets in the fall, and the council usually meets only when there's a crisis. (There wasn't one when we passed through.)
With or without dramatics, children might appreciate seeing the powder-blue berets of the peace-keeping forces, or the unfinished ceiling in the Economic and Social Council chamber, meant to indicate that the work of the United Nations is never done. Children might also find that some gifts to the United Nations from member countries would be toys worth behaving for: a carved-ivory replica of an old Chinese railway and a miniature royal gilded Thai barge.
At the end, after the two boys on the tour decided that the most impressive aspect was the institution's sheer size, and when questions were quickly dispatched with, our guide left us off in the lower-level lobby, to spend time in the many gift shops, a postal center (selling United Nations stamps) and a coffee shop (open daily from 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.). Before you leave, take a stroll along the waterfront (and pass the rose garden), where a tiny body of land, informally called U Thant Island, sits indolently in the churning river.
The tours are $6.50 for adults and $3.50 for children 5 to 14; no one under 5 is permitted. The tours are held from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. daily. Picture-taking is allowed.
 
Strawberry Picking
Various Farms
Recommended for all ages
Though strawberry-picking time arrived at the beginning of June, many farms have berries left and other farms are just beginning their harvest. This year's coldness and damp spring forced some plants to bear fruit later than usual. But one farmer said this has made the strawberries just perfect: fat and fruity, shockingly red. To anyone who wants to pick, most farms will lend a wooden carrier that holds three one-quart containers, which you may usually keep. Then you go out into the field. How long it takes to fill up the containers depends on how fast you want to eat the berries. The best approach, one farmer said, is to "get down on your knees and go."
It would be wise to ask whether the farms use pesticides, and if so when the plants were last sprayed.
Children often end up getting the berries on their clothes, so it's probably best to avoid wearing anything light-colored.
These farms, provided from a list by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets, (718) 260-2830, and from the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, (609) 984-2504, offer strawberries to pick (but call ahead): Berry Farm, Route 203, Chatham, N.Y., (518) 392-4609; Story Farm, Route 32, Catskill, N.Y., (518) 678-9716; Alstede Farm, Pleasant Hill Road, Chester, N.J., (908) 879-7189, and Matarazzo Farms, Route 519, Belvedere, N.J., (908) 475-3872. Prices vary, from about $1 a basket to about $3.
 
The Isamu Noguchi
Garden Museum
32-37 Vernon Boulevard
Long Island City, Queens
(718) 721-1932
Recommended for all ages
This small indoor and outdoor museum is a spot so Zenlike in its silence and repose that you can hear the breeze blow. Children respond to the stone sculptures by Isamu Noguchi as if they were rocks to reckon with. Children also like the nontraditional museum environment. "It's as if, too," said Lawre Stone, the museum's administrative director, "children are very comfortable with abstract artwork. They see a whole universe in them."
Visitors are asked to avoid touching the sculptures, but one marble bench in the garden and another seat in the first gallery are indeed meant to be used.
The first floor opens to the ivy-walled garden, giving the indoor area lots of natural light and making both spaces seem contiguous. The galleries on the first floor are mostly filled with amorphous stone sculptures made of granite, basalt and marble; children enjoy responding to the stones' textures, noting how they really seem smooth rather than rough.
The garden is a comfortable place for children. As a breeze ripples the Boston ivy covering the walls, birds fly from corner to corner. One chiseled sculpture, "The Illusion of the Fifth Stone," attracts children because it looks like four laundry bags bunched together; try finding the fifth one. The garden, a former junkyard, now keeps a bamboo, a weeping cherry and a Japanese black pine, among other trees, thriving. A traditional Japanese fountain by Noguchi disperses rather than collects water.
On the second floor are more sculptures and display cases showing bronze playground models Noguchi designed but never built. Children might want to decide whether these curving, pyramidlike playgrounds would be fun to play in. And they shouldn't pass by the "Ding-Dong Bat" sculpture. A continuing video, narrated by Noguchi, who died in 1988 at the age of 84, shows the sculptor at work. He talks about the virtues of mistakes, which he says force you beyond your imagination to something new, a message young visitors could probably appreciate.
The garden is open on Wednesdays and Saturdays, from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., from April through November. The admission is $4 and $2 for children; strollers are permitted. There are no refreshment stands. The N train, stopping at Broadway, is about a 15-minute walk away; just head west on Broadway to Vernon Boulevard, turn left on Vernon (Socrates Sculpture Park is directly across the boulevard), and left again on 33d Road. A shuttle bus also operates on Saturdays, picking visitors up at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, in Manhattan, and dropping them off at the Noguchi museum once an hour from 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. The round-trip fare is $5 a person.
 
Socrates Sculpture Park
Broadway at Vernon Boulevard
Long Island City, Queens
(718) 956-1819
Recommended for all ages
While the Noguchi museum down the street is steeped in the East, Socrates is like the Wild West. Its scrappy, weedy ambiance, with behemoth sculptures parked all over, give it the trappings of a frontier. But it's a welcoming place, right on the edge of the East River, where a windmill-chiming sculpture rings lightly.
The few benches are scattered; if you want to sit, take a blanket or beach chairs. And should your children feel the need to run, scream or touch sculptures after visiting the Noguchi museum, this is the place to go. One sculpture, by Emilio Cruz, is a blue hulk of a car hanging in midair; in a far corner is a brightly colored Keith Haring.
A "sound observatory" lets visitors play music by patting steel drums. You can also sing into a parabolic dish, but nothing much happens. Merle Temkin's glittery fence sculpture looks like rain. This park, named in honor of many Greeks in Astoria, has a distinctly American, individualistic sensibility, which makes it appropriate for the Fourth of July weekend.
The park is isolated, and it is a good idea to exercise caution when visiting it. It is open daily from 10 A.M. to dark. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MENTOR GRAPHICS' STOCK OFF 24% ON EXPECTED LOSS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Mentor Graphics Corporation's stock dropped $2.375 yesterday, or 24 percent, to a 52-week low of $7.50 in over-the-counter trading, after the company said it would report a second-quarter loss. Mentor blamed the weak Japanese economy and delays in introducing products for the earnings shortfall. "It appears that poor Japanese order performance has combined with product transition issues for disappointing quarterly results," said Thomas Bruggere, Mentor Graphics' chairman and chief executive. The earnings problems probably will continue into the third quarter, Mr. Bruggere said. 
 Mentor Graphics, based in Wilsonville, Ore., estimated that it would lose between 10 cents and 15 cents a share in the second quarter, which ended June 30. Revenues will total about $88 million to $90 million. The company, which makes electronics-design software, will release financial results on July 21.

HEADLINE: The Muddled Model Cities Model

 BODY:
In January 1966, President Lyndon Johnson went to Congress with a truly dramatic idea for urban aid. Model Cities it came to be called, and the idea was to show how urban America could be transformed.
As envisioned, the program would have concentrated billions in huge demonstration grants to a handful of cities. Such grants would have tested whether comprehensive aid could create a realistic chance of eradicating blight. 
 It didn't, because such aid never materialized. Every legislator had to have a slice of the pork. A few cities became 75, then 150. Eventually the money was shoveled around only a half-inch deep anywhere. The program was destined to fail.
Welcome to July 1992.
The urban aid bill that passed the House yesterday already suffers from a terminal case of Model Cities sickness. It offers a dubious solution to urban distress -- enterprise zones -- and then spreads a little money around so thinly that such zones are denied the chance to make a difference.
The enterprise zone theory, pushed by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, is that Government tax breaks and regulatory relief will lure businesses into distressed areas and create jobs for the urban poor. State-run enterprise zones haven't worked that way.
They don't give businesses enough incentive to risk moving to crime-ridden ghettoes. Businesses that operate in existing state E.Z.'s, as they are called, often have come from slightly less poor neighborhoods nearby. To have the desired effect, government would have to make huge investments in transportation, infrastructure and crime prevention. True, Federal tax breaks and regulation waivers are much more valuable. But the urban aid bill spreads too little money too thinly, in an obvious attempt to buy support.
It would spend $5 billion over six years -- but dissipated to 50 zones. And of those, only half would be urban. The rest of the zones in the package would be "rural development investment zones."
Enterprise zones, while not the magic bullet for America's cities, deserve a chance. They won't get it in this legislation. A wiser, if more politically difficult, approach would be to cut the number of zones drastically, perhaps to 10 or 20 of the most troubled inner cities. That would take courage, and leadership, on the part of both Congress and the White House.
Neither Congress nor the White House, however, seems much interested in testing enterprise zones. Like Model Cities, this measure has gone from legislation to help cities to something that permits members of Congress to help themselves.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
De Klerk And Gorbachev

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
When President F. W. de Klerk made his dramatic move to release Nelson Mandela and lift political bans, on Feb. 2, 1990, he seemed to have come to a crucial understanding: that the 15 percent of South Africans who are white can no longer govern this country.
He would try to cushion the transfer of power, it was thought, by negotiating constitutional guarantees. Those would include protections of individual liberty in a bill of rights, and safeguards of property to assure whites a continuing strong economic position. 
 But Mr. de Klerk has not pursued such limited aims. In the negotiations, now suspended, it became increasingly clear that he believed his National Party had a chance to stay in power with the help of political satellites, or at a minimum to have an effective veto over any real changes in national policy.
The turning point in Mr. de Klerk's position came at a surprising moment. It was the referendum among white voters in March on whether to go on with the process of political reform. A resounding 69 percent said yes. The logic of that great victory for Mr. de Klerk seemed to be that it freed him from concern about white ultras and allowed him to move quickly for an agreement with the African National Congress.
To the contrary, the referendum victory emboldened him to take a tougher, less flexible position in the negotiations. Everyone I have met here, regardless of his or her politics, says that happened. Some speak of a new "arrogance" in Mr. de Klerk.
Why? Euphoria from the referendum is one explanation offered. Another is that Mr. de Klerk had had great success abroad, persuading the U.S., the European Community and others to relax sanctions on the ground that apartheid was buried -- though in fact the core of the apartheid system, the denial of the vote to the overwhelming black majority, remains unchanged.
Moreover, the A.N.C. had been weakened by the terrible violence visited on black communities -- violence that made the A.N.C.'s constituency more distrustful of its leadership and of the whole negotiation. Elements in the Government may have orchestrated the violence, but that must be the subject of another column.
All this apparently led Mr. de Klerk to think there was a possibility of the National Party surviving a democratic election. That is, it could win enough support among the Asian and so-called Colored minorities, and from Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Zulu supporters in Inkatha, to keep a weakened A.N.C. in a subsidiary role.
In the negotiations the Government insisted on an interim regime hemmed in by blocking devices. There would be a rotating, collective presidency, and a powerful senate in which a party that won 10 percent of the vote in a region would have as many seats as one with 60 percent.
The interim government would stay until an elected constituent assembly wrote a new constitution. But Mr. de Klerk insisted that key constitutional provisions be approved by 75 percent of the assembly. If there was no agreement on that basis, the interim regime -- the status quo -- could go on forever.
The A.N.C. went very far toward compromise on those demands. But it balked when its leaders felt they were being co-opted into a system still essentially under white control. At one point, I am told, President de Klerk said to Mr. Mandela outside the negotiating chamber: "When you join my Government . . ."
On Feb. 2, 1990, most of us thought that F. W. de Klerk was preparing the way for Nelson Mandela to become president -- as the best guarantor of a stable and prosperous South Africa. Was that a misconception, or what has happened? The possibility is that Mr. de Klerk is like Mikhail Gorbachev: aware that a repressive system no longer works but in the end unwilling to abandon it. That impression was strengthened last night, when Mr. de Klerk gave a harsh reply to an A.N.C. letter suggesting conditions for the resumption of negotiations -- though he did leave an opening to resume them.
There is no Boris Yeltsin here, no visible substitute for Mr. de Klerk among white politicians. The only hope, then, is that he will find it in him to help bring about the genuine transition for which the country is aching. Safety for the minority? Yes. An attempt to maintain control? Disaster for all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Cutting the Deficit Must Cause Some Pain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"House Democrats Promise a Deficit-Cutting Plan" (news article, June 13) is enormously encouraging.
Our only hope of overcoming what seems nearly universal dissatisfaction with the apparent ineffectuality of our political institutions -- manifested, among other ways, in the broad support for Ross Perot's candidacy for the Presidency and the surrender of Congressional seats by worthy incumbents -- is for leaders such as the House Democrats to assume the responsibility that their opposition to the balanced-budget amendment entailed and that its passage would have merely postponed. 
 Any plan worthy of public support must incorporate such measures as Representative Leon Panetta, chairman of the House Budget Committee, suggests: a national sales tax, increased gasoline taxes, limitation on the tax benefit of itemized deductions -- to which I would add a limit on the tax exemption of fringe benefits. Also, a cap on annual deductions for mortgage interest, reductions in Medicare, Social Security, defense, veterans and farm programs.
The country needs a great deal more than deficit reduction. We must also fulfill our promises of aid to the former Soviet Union, the countries of Eastern Europe and -- to cite an additional, small example of our inexcusable neglect dramatized by recent events -- Panama; make good the disgraceful arrearages in paying our share of the costs of the United Nations, and expand domestic investment for job and training programs in the cities. All of these will necessitate even larger tax increases and cuts in other spending.
A vote for such a program will look like political suicide.
But undeserved electoral defeat for having tried to serve the country well is better than deserved defeat for timidity and ineptitude.
If Congress puts together such a responsible package and it is rejected, whether by the President or under pressure from organizations like the American Association of Retired Persons, the Home Builders Association, organized labor, the farm lobbies, the American Petroleum Institute and American Automobile Association (to mention only a few that will oppose one or another part of the budgetary plan) -- along with our almost universal lobby to cut the deficit but raise no taxes and touch no program benefiting me -- then at the very least it will demonstrate where the ultimate responsibility lies. Go to it, Leon Panetta.
 
ALFRED E. KAHN
Ithaca, N.Y., June 18, 1992
 
The writer retired as Robert Julius Thorne Professor of Political Economy at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: Cutting the Deficit Must Cause Some Pain;
Solemn Obligations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Commentators on the budget deficit attack so-called Government entitlement programs as benefits that go to people regardless of need. This focuses on an irrelevant aspect of such Government payments. By the same logic, you could lump Treasury bondholders or vendors in the same category. They get their invoice paid or their interest and principal payments, regardless of need.
The recipients of payments from Social Security, veterans benefits, Government pension programs and others are in a similar relationship to the Government as Treasury bondholders. They have paid into the system, in effect investing in it, through payroll taxes, combat or other service in the military or loyal and effective Government service (often making retirement fund contributions out of their paychecks). At a specified time, they receive the payments the Government, in effect, contracted with them to pay. 
 In a test vote on a proposal to put caps on Government entitlement programs recently, 4 Democratic and 24 Republican senators voted against exemption of veterans benefits from proposed entitlement cuts. The passage of the exemption over their votes set aside the cap proposal. But what a disappointment that 28 senators place such a low value on service to our country in time of war. It is surely an insult to the many men and women who served during the Persian Gulf war so short a time ago.
The entitlement programs for veterans, Social Security, military service and Government staff retirement, and for others are a sacred obligation of the Government and the people of this country to people who have devoted their lives and careers to United States interests.
Of course we have serious problems in our finances; however, the basic benefits and inflation protection of the entitlement programs are solemn obligations.
Some believe we are in an emergency now, but their solutions to the fiscal problems seem more like proposals to cut payments for purposes they do not agree with. In a real emergency the solutions would be painful to powerful interests. We could look for delays and rescheduling of interest and principal payments on Treasury bonds. In that kind of emergency, everyone would feel pain and there would not be calls to inflict damage on particular groups that commentators and analysts believe unworthy for some unspoken reason.
We should primarily look for savings in the reduction of waste, fraud and abuse. It is arrogant and shows indifference to the outrage that ordinary citizens feel about wasteful perquisites and privileges that some senators vote for cuts in veterans benefits while accepting a huge pay increase for their own benefit.
And, finally, nothing can be written on the deficit without mentioning its primary causes -- the tax cut and military buildup under President Reagan.
 
LAWRENCE D. GREENE
Kent, Wash., June 10, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1469 words

HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT UP SHARPLY, PROMPTING FEDERAL RESERVE TO CUT ITS KEY LENDING RATE

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate, the most politically sensitive economic indicator in an election year, rose sharply in June. Minutes after the report was released today, the Federal Reserve responded by cutting its key interest rate in an attempt to stimulate the sagging economy.
The White House, counting on an economic pickup to buoy President Bush's re-election chances, had been putting intense pressure on the Fed to lower rates. Analysts said the unemployment statistics were so grim that the central bank had little choice but to act, despite its concerns that it would appear to be bowing to political considerations. 
 The rise in joblessness, to 7.8 percent in June from 7.5 percent in May, was a sharp blow to the Bush Administration, which has boasted in recent weeks that the recovery was gathering steam.
 
Bush Advisers Split
 "It's not good news," President Bush told reporters. "It just shows the economy -- the recovery we're in is not as robust as I'd like to see it." Mr. Bush's advisers have been sharply split over how positive the President should sound about the economy's prospects. Seeking to deflect accusations that he has not done enough to spur the recovery, Mr. Bush blamed Congress for failing to approve his economic package, which called for capital gains tax cuts and other tax incentives.
But Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, sought to throw Mr. Bush on the defensive. "The President just doesn't understand that people want economic leadership, not more political blame," he said. He added that the country "can't afford a President who is willing to do anything to keep his job, but nothing to help average hardworking Americans keep theirs."
Concerned about high unemployment, the Congress today passed legislation to make it easier for the long-term unemployed to collect extended benefits, and President Bush said he would sign it. The House also approved a $5 billion package that aims to help cities through job training and tax incentives for business. [Page A13.]
 
Discount Rate 3%
 The Federal Reserve's cut in its discount rate to 3 percent from 3 1/2 percent brought the rate at which it lends money to banks to its lowest level since 1963. The Fed also reduced the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- to 3.25 percent from 3.75. Several major banks followed by cutting their prime rate, the interest rate banks use as a basis for their loans to small- and medium-sized businesses and to consumers.
Interest rate cuts fuel economic growth by making it cheaper for businesses to borrow more for investment and cheaper for consumers to borrow for spending. Still, lower rates hurt some Americans, especially retirees who live on interest income from savings accounts or certificates of deposit. After inflation is taken into account, the effective rate on many savings accounts is close to zero.
The rise in the jobless rate surprised many analysts, who are starting to voice fears of a "triple dip" recession. "It's an ugly report," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist for Morgan Stanley. "It raises a clear warning sign that this recovery is in trouble."
What upset economists in particular about today's employment report was that the survey of employers' payrolls showed a drop of 117,000 jobs, with most of the drop coming in manufacturing and construction. The report also showed that the jobless rate rose for adult males and females and had climbed sharply for teen-agers, rising to 23.6 percent from 20 percent. The report also showed a drop in the length of the workweek.
"It's excellent news for Ross Perot and Bill Clinton," said Roger E. Brinner, chief economist for DRI/McGraw Hill, an economics forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass.
 
'A Horrible Month
 "There is no favorable spin that can be put on this employment report," he added. "I don't think this is any kind of statistical fluke. This says June was a horrible month."
The President hailed the central bank's rate cuts as well as the decision by major banks to cut their prime rate. Citibank, Morgan Guaranty Trust, Bank of America, Chemical and Chase Manhattan were among the banks cutting this rate to 6 percent from 6.5 percent.
"That is a good way to stimulate growth," Mr. Bush said. "And I think that will be very well received by the markets and by the businesses, large and small, across the country."
Concerned abut the weak economy, stocks slid today on the New York Stock Exchange, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 3,330.29 points, down 23.81 for the day. Bonds rose, however, as long-term interest rates dipped in reaction to the Federal Reserve's rate cuts.
The Fed said in a statement: "Action was taken in light of sustained weakness in credit and money growth, continued movement toward price stability, and the uneven progress of the economic recovery."
Seven hours after it lowered rates, the Fed announced in a report that M-2 -- the most closely watched definition of the money supply -- fell sharply in the last week. The Fed said that M-2 declined by $10.6 billion last week and that monetary growth over the last six months had fallen below the Fed's target range. Slow growth in the money supply can mean that not enough money is available for loans to fuel economic growth.
 
Brady Urged Easing
 Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has argued in recent days that the Fed should ease further, saying weak money supply growth could cause the recovery to slow, just as sluggish monetary growth caused a recovering economy to fall into a second dip last year.
Federal Reserve officials said Mr. Greenspan learned of the unemployment figure late on Wednesday, after the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee -- the central bank's main policy-making group. The board voted at a meeting this morning, 7 to 0, to cut the discount rate immediately.
The action was a sharp departure from the policy adopted at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in May. According to the minutes of that meeting, released today, the central bankers decided at that time to take a neutral approach, because most of them believed there was enough monetary easing already in the pipeline to fuel the recovery.
Speaking about today's jobs report, Stuart Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based bank holding company, said: "The Fed had to be absolutely startled by the unemployment rate, the drop in payrolls, and the drop in the workweek. There were no silver linings in that report."
He said today's rate cuts "are very close to being too late to help" the President before November. Many economists say the lag time before lower rates percolate through the economy to spur investment, spending and growth is about six months.
Secretary Brady welcomed the action, but said it was too late. "The momentum of the recovery and the sluggish growth of the money supply indicated the need for such action some time ago," he said.
 
 
First-Quarter Growth
 In the first quarter, the economy grew by a solid 2.7 percent, with economists saying the mild winter caused an unexpected jump in home building and consumer spending.
But the economy appears to have weakened substantially in the second quarter as consumer spending seems to have run out of breath, partly because job gains and wage gains failed to pick up strongly. It is often said that thanks to the good weather, the first quarter borrowed a lot of activity from the second quarter, helping cause the second quarter to be weaker.
Mr. Brinner of DRI/McGraw-Hill said there was a 50-50 chance that the economy would stumble into a "triple dip," meaning that growth would drop below 1 percent. He said there was a 50 percent chance that growth would average 3 percent in the second half of the year, and a 50 percent chance that under the stagnation or triple-dip forecast, growth would be a weak 1.5 percent.
"Before we said there was a 30 percent chance of this stagnation alternative, now we tell our clients it's 50 percent," he said.
Economists say the current recovery has been held back -- and past rate cuts have failed to spur growth much -- principally because of the huge debt burden weighing down consumer and business spending. Growth has been hurt by cuts in the military budget and high long-term interest rates, caused in part by the huge Federal budget deficit. Other negative factors include the unusual number of white-collar layoffs and past overbuilding in commercial real estate.
In reducing the discount rate from 7 percent in 1989 to the present 3 percent, the Greenspan Federal Reserve has usually acted in increments of one-quarter point. Today's move was just the third time it reduced the discount rate by more than a quarter point.

A front-page chart yesterday showing unemployment rates over the years misstated the change from May to June in some copies. It was three-tenths of 1 percentage point.

HEADLINE: JAPAN'S TRADE GAP IS GROWING AGAIN

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3

 BODY:
After several years of reduction, Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world is soaring again to record levels, a development that could increase unemployment in other nations and contribute to a new round of trade tensions.
It is also likely to be a main topic at the summit meeting of the seven leading industrial countries next week in Munich, where Japan will be in the awkward position of being the only participant with a surplus. 
 "We've never seen a trade surplus like this in any country before," said Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist and strategist for Deutsche Bank Capital Markets in Tokyo. He said Japan's exports could exceed imports this year by $135 billion, well above the levels that followed the 1985 Plaza accord, under which the industrial partners agreed to raise the yen's value sharply to reduce Japan's trade imbalance.
 
Plan for Public Spending
 In Munich, the Japanese Government is expected to tell its counterparts about a new plan to stimulate its economy by increasing public spending by $47 billion or more later this year, which could increase imports. But economists say -- and Japanese officials concede -- that such measures will make only a small dent in the trade imbalance. They say more fundamental changes are needed: Japanese consumers must spend more and the Government must open its markets wider to foreigners.
Japanese officials say the recent rise in the trade surplus is a result of worldwide economic forces, not specific trade practices. In the late 1980's, while Japan's economy boomed, imports of everything from German cars to French wine and American lumber rose sharply.
But with the collapse of Japan's speculative bubble economy, imports have started to fall. That decline results in part from the fact that the prices of raw materials that Japan imports, particularly oil, have gone down. Meanwhile, prices of products that Japan exports have gone up, in part because Japan has shifted to making more expensive cars.
"This is essentially a price-generated change," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist for Salomon Brothers in Asia. He said that the balance of the volume of Japan's imports and exports had not changed much for three years.
In addition, a new fear is arising that Japan is no longer recycling its surplus to help other nations.
In the 1980's, Japan used the money it generated from trade to make long-term investments overseas in stocks, bonds, real estate and new factories. Such investment, while sometimes controversial, helped other countries to grow. But in the last year, Japanese companies, having been stung by unwise investments abroad and facing a recession at home, have sharply cut back on these investments. Now, more foreign capital is flowing into Japan than Japanese capital is going out, as foreigners rebuild their positions in Japanese assets.
Some economists say that unless Japan begins recycling the huge surplus, the world could face a shortage of capital. That could drive up interest rates, perhaps lengthening the current worldwide recession.
"For Japan, it is very important to recycle the capital that can serve the rest of the world," said Makoto Utsumi, a former vice minister for international affairs who is now an adviser to Japan's Ministry of Finance. Japanese investors, he said, have become afraid to take risks. "The Government should do something to mobilize this money," he said.
 
Defending Its Position
 The situation is potentially embarrassing to Japan because the nation has often defended its trade surplus as being a means of accumulating savings for the rest of the world to use. Such an argument is now harder to make.
But some economists say Japan's importing of long-term capital has not been a problem and will not become one. Instead of long-term investments, Japan is making short-term investments like sending money to foreign banks. Those banks could then make long-term investments, indirectly recycling the trade surplus.
Japan's surplus jumped more than 60 percent in 1991, to a record $103 billion, and it is heading even higher this year. Its surplus with the United States, $38.2 billion last year, is still significantly lower than it was a few years earlier, but it has started to move up again after years of decline.
Indeed, in May, Japan's overall trade surplus nearly doubled from the level of a year earlier, while the surplus with the United States jumped more than 50 percent. This is threatening to make Japan's trade practices, and the American response, a leading issue in the Presidential election campaign.
The Bush Administration, hoping to prevent worsening relations with Japan, recently tried to play down Japan's trade problems, particularly in meetings this week in Washington between President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan. The United States has pushed Japan, however, to stimulate its economy to spur spending and imports.
"The point is not to regard this as a bilateral problem," Michael Armacost, the United States Ambassador to Japan, said last week. "The sluggishness of the world economy affects everybody."
But in a sense, Japan's trade surplus is actually a multilateral rather than bilateral problem. After sharp increases in recent years, Japan's surpluses with the rest of Asia and with Europe are now roughly the same size as its predictably large surplus with the United States.
Just this week, South Korea and Japan signed an agreement aimed at alleviating the Korean deficit with Japan, which has more than doubled since 1989. The deficit with Japan accounts for 90 percent of the deficit of South Korea, a nation that can normally compete quite well in overseas markets.
 
Fewer Goods From Europe
 Japan's trade imbalance with the European Community jumped nearly 50 percent in 1991, to $27.4 billion. Japan's imports from Europe tend to be luxury items like BMW automobiles, French perfume and Scotch whisky, and such imports dropped sharply as stock and real estate prices here suffered a steep decline.
The surplus with fast-growing countries in southern and eastern Asia grew about 33 percent, to $37.4 billion. A main reason for this is that these nations, which are trying to build up their technology bases, are importing components and sophisticated factory machinery from Japan.
At the same time, many Japanese companies have shifted some manufacturing to Southeast Asia. Those shifts are an important reason Japan's deficit with the United States is lower than it was five years ago -- more Japanese products are coming into the United States from other parts of Asia.
Economists say that the Japanese Government's plan to increase public spending, which has not been made final, will not do much to reduce the trade surplus.
Naoyuki Haraoka, director of the international trade research office in the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said his personal estimate, not that of his agency, was that the envisioned spending package might raise imports by $10 billion to $12 billion. "That is not substantial, compared to $100 billion," he said.
Some economists think the surplus will bring about more pressure for a rise in the value of the yen, which would tend to make Japan's exports more expensive in other countries and make foreign products cheaper for the Japanese. The yen has already strengthened recently to about 124 to the dollar. But there are doubts that any movement of the yen will make much difference, since Japan was able to adjust for the roughly doubling of the yen's value that resulted from the 1985 Plaza agreement.
Dr. Courtis of Deutsche Bank says the surplus will defy shrinkage. He says that the investments made during Japan's economic boom in new factories and in research and development, and the competitive lift it has provided, will carry the Japanese through the next few years. "There's no fundamental reversal going to occur," he said.
Some scholars also contend that the nature of trade has changed as companies have spread operations around the globe. A significant portion of trade is now intra-company, as when Toyota in Japan ships parts to the Toyota factory in Kentucky. Under this reasoning, the balance of trade will not change much until American and European companies make similar levels of direct investment in Japan.
In the long run, Japan's surplus might diminish if the nation consumes more, but such societal shifts are slow in coming.
Falling real estate prices might reduce how much people have to save to buy a house. But one way to reduce land prices would be to take farms out of production, which might not sit well with Japan's politically powerful farmers. Shorter working hours, another Government goal, would give the Japanese more time to spend their money. But that might require allowing more foreign workers into the country, a policy that many Japanese oppose.
Japanese officials are fond of pointing out that the trade involves two or more countries and that the United States and other nations need to become more competitive to cut their deficits. "Japan alone cannot resolve the problem," Mr. Utsumi said.
