HEADLINE: Albany Lawmakers End Session Without Acting on 2 Major Issues

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 3

 BODY:
The state legislative session ended today in an angry morass of exhaustion and partisan bickering, and lawmakers left town near dawn without acting on two major economic initiatives: an $800 million bond act to create jobs and a fiscal bailout that would allow Nassau and Suffolk counties to borrow money.
As had been the case all week, the two measures remained, in essence, hostage to each other. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vigorously sought the bond act as a showpiece of his agenda to lift New York out of the recession, and the Republican-led State Senate desperately wanted the Long Island bailouts to head off the likely alternative, steep increases in local property taxes. 
 But while most lawmakers here had predicted that the two measures would be approved in the traditional flurry of last-minute dealmaking, it did not happen, in part because Mr. Cuomo strongly hinted on Thursday night that he would veto the bailouts as irresponsible. "Don't leave them on my desk," he said. "I'll throw them in the pail."
The measures would have allowed the counties to borrow a total of about $190 million, between 5 and 7 percent of their budgets, and county executives in Nassau and Suffolk said today that without them they would be forced to raise taxes, lay off county employees and cut services. They implored state leaders to reconsider the measures in special session.
Legislators could point to accomplishments this session, notably the completion of a budget virtually on time for the first time in eight years. But that did not obscure the failures. No one here was predicting that the Legislature would return anytime soon to take up the financial measure for Nassau and Suffolk. [News analysis and article, page 24.]
And there was no mistaking the air of bitterness as the session fizzled to a close.
"This is pure political blackmail," said the majority leader of the Senate, Ralph J. Marino, a Long Island Republican who berated the Democrats for blocking the bailout bills. "They clearly say to the people of Long Island and those they have elected: 'Drop dead.' "
Governor Cuomo, for his part, seemed to taunt Senator Marino for failing to win a borrowing measure that the Republican Party leaders on Long Island -- Mr. Marino's compatriots for all his political life -- had beseeched him to bring home.
"You know, it's a macho game," Mr. Cuomo said. "You go to your gatherings there where they hang elephants from the ceiling and everybody says, 'Ahh, you did the right thing, Ralphy-baby!' "
Perhaps inevitably, Mr. Cuomo was asked whether his quashing of the bailout was a payback for Mr. Marino, whom the Governor repeatedly depicted last December as the great obstructionist in budget talks who singlehandedly prevented Mr. Cuomo from being able to run for President. The Governor emphatically denied this was the case.
There were, to be sure, some 11th-hour deals here that produced important legislation, most notably a new bill to restrict the profits of criminals who sell their stories as books or films. The new measure replaces the Son of Sam law struck down by the Supreme Court in December. And lawmakers reached a landmark agreement earlier in the week to overhaul health insurance by banning discrimination in rate-setting.
But by almost any other measure, the session is likely to be judged by what was not accomplished at the end.
Aside from economic development and the Long Island fiscal measures, negotiations collapsed on bills to establish a trust fund for environmental protection, strengthen protections for the Adirondack wilderness and impose new measures to deter teen-agers from smoking.
Amid the dogfight between Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Marino, the leader who emerged from the fray as comparatively calm and statesmanlike was the rookie in this year's negotiations, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin. The Queens Democrat took over the post last December after the conviction of his predecessor on fraud charges.
Mr. Weprin managed to get several of his major initiatives passed this year, including new property-tax limits in New York City and reinstatement of a bill he spearheaded several years ago to allow news cameras in the state's courtrooms.
Beyond that, Mr. Weprin also scored a major victory in the next-to-last day of the session when courts not only upheld the bulk of an Assembly redistricting plan but also effectively forced the Senate into approving a small modification that Mr. Weprin had been unable to wrest from Mr. Marino.
The Republicans had attempted to play political hardball by insisting on some changes to help G.O.P. Assemblyman. But Mr. Weprin said no, and managed to get what he needed from the courts instead.
 
'This Is My Territory'
 "I considered it a form of intimidation, and I wasn't going to stand for it," Mr. Weprin crowed to reporters who asked him about the Republican tactic.
Negotiations on the Nassau and Suffolk bailouts sputtered around 4 A.M. this morning and ultimately broke off after what both sides concurred was a shouting match over the telephone between Mr. Weprin and Mr. Marino.
"He said some things on the phone he'll probably regret," Mr. Weprin said today of his counterpart.
"He said that Nassau and Suffolk were his domain and this is what he wanted to do," Mr. Weprin added. "He said, 'This is my territory and where do you come off telling me what to do?' I said, 'Ralph. I'm not telling you what to do, I'm just suggesting that we do it a better way.' "
The Assembly, mirroring what it called years of Republican demands for greater oversight of New York City's financial affairs, had pushed for some version of a financial review board in the two Long Island counties, but Mr. Marino balked at this.
"This is not a New York City default situation," Mr. Marino said in a telephone interview today. "It's entirely different. They have a short-term financial crisis, and they're just asking for permission to get out of it."
The Governor appeared embittered today over what he depicted as Mr. Marino's reneging on an agreement late Thursday to approve the bond act, which, even if approved here, would still have to be put before the voters in November. But Mr. Marino said there was no such deal, and that he had always made it clear to the Governor that it would not happen if his fellow Republican Senators did not go along with the bill's language.
The bill, which the Assembly passed in the final hours of the session but the Senate did not take up, reflected complicated haggling over how to allocate the money among various regions of the state.
Harold Holzer, an aide to the Governor who is spokesman for the state Office of Economic Development, said that in refusing to act, the Republicans had turned their backs on $85 million in development money for Long Island.
"One cannot escape the bitter irony of the fact the jobs bond act went down to indifference the day after the worst unemployment news in 10 years was released in Washington," Mr. Holzer said. "There's an old saying, in and out of economic development, that you don't cut off your nose to spite your face. Ralph Marino has just given Long Island an $85 million nose job."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Saul Weprin; Ralph J. Marino; Gov. Mario Cuomo (pg. 24)
 
Chart: "Legislative Sparring: The Bitter End"
In one furious telephone call early yesterday between Saul Weprin, speaker of the Democratic Assembly, and Ralph J. Marino, majority leader of the Republican Senate, the chance for agreement on the remaining issues of the legislative session fell apart. The call, about whether to help Nassau and Suffolk Counties close their budget deficits, took place about four A.M. Here's what the two leaders and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had to say about the whole thing today:
 
Speaker Weprin: "[Marino] said that Nassau and Suffolk were his domain and this is what he wanted to do. And he told me, 'i've always leaned over backward for New York City, anything they've ever wanted I've always given them, but this is my territory, and where do you come off telling me what to do?"
 
"He seemed to think I had some personal vendetta against him for not doing the Nassau-Suffolk bills, and he expressed it accordingly."
 
Majority Learder Marino: "I became angry at the fact that it became clear that the Assembly and [Weprin] were not working in good faith, that I had been jerked around, and that my county and Suffolk County were being held hostage."
 
"I took it personally because it is personal - it's my county. I became irate and we had a few harsh words."
 
Governor Cuomo: "The best thing that coul happen would be for Senator Marino to wake up, put some cold water in his face, and say 'Look, I've thought better of this.' I think what I ought to do is call Saul first of all and say. 'Saul, it was four in the morning and tempers were a little hot." (pg. 24)

HEADLINE: The Students Left Behind

 BODY:
George Bush, the self-styled education President, insists on undermining public schools in order to save them. In the name of making public schools more "competitive," he would provide vouchers allowing parents to send their children to private and parochial schools. It's an odd remedy, but November looms ahead and he is searching for a domestic agenda.
Recently Mr. Bush announced the State and Local G.I. Bills for Children. This latest voucher proposal would provide up to $1,000 that low- and middle-income families could spend at private schools or even another public school. 
 The White House argues that the plan would benefit families with incomes below $40,000, giving them "more of the same choices of schools wealthy families already have." Mr. Bush wants $500 million in new financing for the program.
That's only marginally more palatable than an earlier proposal to convert the federally funded Chapter 1 program, which offers remedial help to students who are economically and educationally disadvantaged, into vouchers of $600 per pupil. Motivated students could have transferred to another public school or a private or parochial school, taking the public funds with them.
That would have robbed the old school of its better students and, inevitably, demoralized teachers and administrators. The proposal went nowhere in Congress. The latest voucher plan is likely to be dead on arrival too, since it suffers from many of the same deficiencies.
So what's the point? Is Mr. Bush merely playing election year politics, trying to attract Catholics and some inner-city minority parents struggling to send their children to parochial schools? How much private schooling is $1,000 a year likely to buy a low-income family?
Mr. Bush's instinct to shake up public schools is laudable. But his mechanism for doing so is cynically inequitable. The Administration says many kids will choose public schools instead of private or parochial schools. But since the $1,000 travels with the student, and since the President offers nothing to the schools left behind, the plan would inevitably create new imbalances in the system.
Why not instead a major effort to equip all public schools with adequate and decent textbooks and science laboratories? In theory, expanding choice makes good sense. But only if accompanied by a vigorous effort to meet the needs of those who don't really have a choice.

HEADLINE: Washington Could Do Something

 BODY:
The sharp jump in unemployment in June, following a similar spike in May, shakes confidence that the economy is improving. Monthly unemployment data can be unreliable barometers, but the new numbers follow a worrisome trend. Home sales, durable goods orders and consumer confidence are all off. Two months ago, people worried that the economy wasn't picking up enough steam. Now they fear it is slipping back into recession.
None of these figures portend disaster. But they do warrant corrective action by Washington. The Federal Reserve did what it could Thursday by lowering interest rates another notch. But few economists believe monetary policy can do enough soon. The economy needs another punch, from Congress -- a quick-hitting combination of temporary tax cuts and spending increases. 
 Is corrective action likely? No -- which offers a sad commentary on government. The economy needs a quick shot of adrenaline. But the idea that Congress and the White House would join to deliver it is nearly unimaginable.
The economy seemed to be recovering nicely in the first quarter, growing by nearly 3 percent. But then output slackened, hastened by a fall in exports to sluggish economies in Europe and Asia. Unemployment rose 0.3 percent in May and then again in June by an equal amount. Now the rate stands at 7.8 percent, representing more than 10 million Americans who can't find jobs. The news is even grimmer in New York City, where unemployment shot up a full point to 11.5 percent in May.
The Fed responded to the jobless figures immediately by lowering short-term interest rates to their lowest levels in decades. There may still be room for the Fed to do more, but its options are limited. If it becomes too aggressive, bond markets will shiver. Fearing inflation, traders will drive rates higher -- the opposite of what the Fed would be trying to accomplish. The Fed has cut short-term rates almost 30 times since the recession began, yet long-term rates -- the ones that affect business investment -- have hardly budged.
That puts the onus on Congress. Last December Robert Solow, the Nobel laureate economist at M.I.T., and Francis Bator of Harvard called on Congress to cut taxes and raise Federal grants to state and local governments for one year. The idea was to boost the economy temporarily and thereby ward off recession.
The key word was temporary. That way the plan would not raise long-term deficits and, therefore, do no long-term harm. Had Congress listened, millions more Americans wouldn't now be collecting unemployment checks.
The Solow-Bator plan made sense last winter. It still does. But though the skies look darker, Washington still isn't listening.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush on the Environment: A Record of Contradictions

SERIES: The Bush Record -- Seventh article of a series.

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENOVA, W. Va.

 BODY:
The people who live here in the hazy valleys cut by the Ohio and Big Sandy Rivers, where the air has been among the most polluted in the country, are benefiting from cleaner air these days, thanks to changes in weather patterns as well as to a law passed two years ago.
President Bush saluted that law, the Clean Air Act, and said it would "make the 1990's the era for clean air." 
 But now, with a Presidential campaign in progress and the economy stubbornly sluggish, the law, the most comprehensive and expensive environmental statute ever enacted, is under attack within the Administration, where business interests often seem to outweigh environmental concerns. And that is leaving many people here worried that the Clean Air Act's initial gains will not be followed by the more sweeping improvements the law was supposed to provide.
 
Views of Record Differ
 During the 1988 campaign Mr. Bush often said he wanted to be known as "the environmental President." But critics say that while he took strong stands on environmental matters for the first two years of his administration, his approach changed in the midst of the recession.
Mr. Bush now seems to place a much higher priority on reducing the costs of complying with environmental regulation than on cleaning the nation's air.
In every public accounting the President has offered of his domestic accomplishments, he ranks the Clean Air Act at or near the top of the list. "I invite comparison of the record that we as a country and an Administration have built," Mr. Bush said in a speech last month. "It is aggressive. It is comprehensive. And it is ambitious, but carefully balanced."
But leaders of environmental groups have a different view.
"In his commitments during the 1988 campaign, he was good on some issues, mediocre on others, and very weak on a few," said Carl Pope, associate executive director of the Sierra Club in San Francisco. "But what we did get in the first two years was environmental moderation. He did not treat the environment as an issue he would throw away to the right wing of the Republican party and the least responsible sectors of American business.
"But what we have seen in the last six months," he added, "is an almost compete reversion to the policies pursued by the Reagan Administration."
The available evidence lends support to that view.
 
Reversed Direction
 In his first two years as President, Mr. Bush approved sharp increases in the Environmental Protection Agency's budget, blocked a new dam in Colorado that would have flooded a scenic canyon, and added more than $100 million to the Federal budget for buying land for parks and refuges.
But in the last year, Mr. Bush approved a proposal that would make it much harder to halt a dam like the one in Colorado. And he backed two proposals approved by the Departments of Agriculture and Interior that would limit or eliminate the public's ability to block timber cutting in national forests and mining or oil exploration on public lands.
Two years ago, Mr. Bush put the coast of New England, southern Florida and most of California off limits to oil exploration and drilling for a decade. But a year ago, Mr. Bush tried to open the untouched Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska for oil exploration. Congress killed that plan.
In 1988 and 1989 Mr. Bush repeatedly promised to fashion a land-use policy that would produce "no net loss" of the nation's swamps, marshes and other wetlands. But last summer, he approved a plan that would allow development on 50 million acres of wetlands, half the nation's total, including parts of the Florida Everglades.
In his first two years, Mr. Bush signed international agreements to ban ivory trading, to eliminate large-scale drift-net fishing and to protect Antarctica. But Mr. Bush was the last leader of an industrialized nation to announce he would attend the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro last month. Once there, he drew international criticism for weakening a treaty to combat global warming and for refusing to sign another to protect endangered species.
 
Job Losses Cited
 The President and his aides say they are trying to protect jobs. But environmentalists maintain that jobs would be created by tighter regulations that would spur development of new equipment and techniques to make American factories more efficient.
Since the passage of the Clean Air Act in 1990, the Administration has failed to complete more than 30 regulations needed to put much of the law into effect, including most of the important ones. The few rules the White House has issued seem intended primarily to reduce the costs of regulation to business. Before the Administration began weakening the provisions last year, the oil industry had estimated that full compliance at the 200 refineries across the country would cost $40 billion over the next 10 years.
In the view of environmentalists, the most effective rules so far were those written by Congress when the law was drafted. Those provisions dealt with acid rain and cleaner fuels and amounted to about 30 percent of the law. The remaining rules are supposed to be written by the Administration.
Mr. Bush's aides, including Robert E. Grady, the acting Deputy Director of the Office of Management and Budget, said Mr. Bush's commitment to environmental goals has not changed.
"The President has been the greatest defender of land and water since Teddy Roosevelt," Mr. Grady said.
 
The Stated Goals
Push for Clean Air Ends Up as Retreat
 With ambitious goals and high costs, the Clean Air Act was seen from the beginning as a test of the President's strategy of balancing environmental concerns with economic needs.
And in few other environmental efforts has the President's about-face seemed clearer. With prodding from the President's Council on Competitiveness, a cabinet group headed by Vice President Dan Quayle whose goal is to reduce the cost of regulations, Mr. Bush has responded to complaints from manufacturers and utilities by curtailing the law's reach.
In June the Administration issued a new rule that allows each of about 35,000 chemical, pharmaceutical and other plants to increase emissions of hazardous air pollutants by up to 245 tons a year, just by asking states' permission to do so. No public hearings or notification are required.
In March, four days before the Michigan primary, Mr. Bush told a group of Detroit businessmen that he was waiving a Clean Air rule requiring auto makers to install canisters in new cars to capture fumes during refueling.
"The manipulation of regulations is a direct result of industry lobbying at the White House," said Norm Steenstra, environmental coordinator for West Virginia Citizen Action Group, an environmental group in Charleston. "We're learning very quickly that one can pass legislation and then get murdered in the regulatory phase."
 
Awaiting Regulations
 In this region, where Kentucky, Ohio and West Virginia come together in a lumpy landscape of narrow valleys and low hills, it's easy to measure any changes in the White House view of the Clean Air Act. An accident of man and nature often makes the air here dirtier than anyplace in the East, according to the E.P.A.
On windless winter and hot summer days, the valleys trap air carrying tons of dust and chemicals churned out by steel, coke and chemical plants along the Ohio and Big Sandy Rivers. During the dry summer of 1988, residents said, the air was so bad that doctors warned families to keep children indoors.
By every measure, according to air pollution authorities in the three states, the air in the Ohio River Valley is cleaner this year, especially around this town of 4,000 people. One reason is that temperatures have been much cooler. Another is that sulfur dioxide has been reduced by the Clean Air Act.
Across the Big Sandy River in Catlettsburg, Ky., the nation's 13th largest oil refinery, owned by Ashland Oil Inc., turns crude oil into gasoline, diesel fuel and Valvoline motor oil. The refinery is one of the region's principal sources of sulfur dioxide pollutants, which can cause respiratory illnesses and which combine with moisture in the atmosphere to form acid rain.
Over the last several years, Kentucky air-pollution authorities have repeatedly levied fines against Ashland totaling several hundred thousand dollars. A report by the West Virginia Air Pollution Control Commission showed that in 1987, one of the refinery's units released caustic ash into the air that fell as thick as snow, peeling paint from cars and causing other damage.
 
Multimillion-Dollar Investment
 A provision in the Clean Air Act requires refiners to reduce the amount of sulfur in diesel fuel from 0.22 percent to 0.02 percent. Ashland responded by spending $68 million in the last year on new equipment to strip sulfur from the fuel and keep it from escaping into the air. That brought the sharply lower sulfur dioxide levels.
"We are complying with the law, and we supported the Clean Air law from the beginning," John R. Hall, Ashland's chairman, said in an interview at the company's hilltop headquarters. "We believe the new requirements for diesel fuel are right."
But Sue Holland, a mother of five and a leader of Tri State Environmental Impact, a local environmental group, complains that the cleanup of other pollutants in the Ohio Valley's air can't even begin until the Administration issues the necessary regulations.
 
Words and Actions
Regulatory Delays Slow Enforcement
 Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who was a principal author of the Clean Air Act, filed a lawsuit on June 5 asserting that the Administration was deliberately trying to thwart the intent of the law by delaying regulations to help businesses. Mr. Waxman said the Administration had missed 30 deadlines for writing regulations and had failed to follow 29 other requirements of the law.
"The record is clear," Mr. Waxman said in a statement accompanying the lawsuit. "After publicly pledging support for this law, President Bush worked closely with big polluters to undermine it, in many cases holding up vitally important regulations at the White House. This is very different than flip-flopping on a campaign promise. The new Clean Air program was enacted into law. Having signed the law, the President is legally bound to carry it out."
In interviews, the President's aides said the Administration's work on the Clean Air Act had been fair; their goal, they said, was to achieve cleaner air without bankrupting companies. The many delays in writing the law's more important rules resulted from the sheer volume of the work, they said.
"Deadlines are frequently missed," acknowledged C. Boyden Gray, the President's counsel. "The E.P.A. is being called on to issue more rules under this statute than any other act, in a concentrated period of time. It's all unfolding pretty much as Congress intended. There is a delay here and a delay there, but that is par for the course. It's very rare that anybody comes in on time under any statute."
Mr. Waxman and other critics assert that election-year politics have allowed the nation's largest corporations to influence the President's decisions on the Clean Air Act and virtually every other facet of environmental policy.
 
In-Fighting
E.P.A. on One Side, Quayle on the Other
 One reason for the delays is an angry battle within the Administration between William K. Reilly, the E.P.A. Administrator, and Vice President Quayle and cabinet members over how rigorous the Clean Air rules should be.
The Clean Air program for reducing emissions of 189 toxic substances was to take 10 years. Under the law, the Administration was supposed to begin the process last November by listing every source of toxic contamination that would need to be reduced or eliminated. But oil, chemical and other industrial lobbyists have asked Mr. Quayle's Council on Competitiveness to reduce the costs of the new rules. Mr. Reilly opposes that, and because of this disagreement the Administration has not issued the rules needed to start the program.
"This law makes the states more responsible than ever to control air pollution, but we are not in control of writing the rules," said G. Dale Farley, director of the West Virginia Air Pollution Control Commission. "Until they are finished, we can't begin to plan our work. The effect of all this is unfortunate. It means the air doesn't get cleaner."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
The event probably took no more than two minutes. In June 1989, at the Nathan Bishop Middle School graduation in Providence, R.I., Rabbi Leslie Gutterman thanked the "God of the free, hope of the brave" for "the legacy of America where diversity is celebrated and the rights of minorities are protected."
Two weeks ago, the Supreme Court ruled that Rabbi Gutterman's prayers violated the First Amendment. They were, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for a 5-to-4 majority, a state-sponsored religious exercise in which students were pressured into joining. 
 The case probably drew more attention and stirred more passions that all the praying done at thousands of graduations. Defenders as well as opponents of the prayers invoked the relationships between religion, government and public life. Both sides spoke so often of the dangers of a "slippery slope" that they might have been talking about skiing rather than a constitutional clash.
To defenders of such graduation prayers, barring them is part of a steady drive to expunge from public life all references to religion, the disentangling of all the threads historically linking religion and government in America, from inaugural prayers right down to "In God We Trust" on the currency.
Opponents of the graduation prayers saw a different slippery slope. To them, the Bush Administration's brief on behalf of the prayers was part of a drive to please conservative religious voters by getting a reshaped Court to relax its previous church-state rulings, opening the way to prayer in the classroom and financial aid to parochial schools.
For the moment, it is the defenders of graduation prayers who feel the nation is still headed downhill. Although they include some maverick liberals, they are mostly conservatives and in a curious way they make their case much the way that liberals do in economic questions.
In economics, liberals are the ones who often think that too many reigning doctrines have not been adjusted to deal with the world as it really operates -- the world of vast inequities in riches and political power and of instantaneous information and environmental limits.
That is the way many conservatives feel about interpretations of the First Amendment. Robert P. Dugan Jr., director of the Office of Public Affairs of the National Association of Evangelicals, bitterly remarked the juxtaposition of the Supreme Court's ruling that "hate speech" was constitutionally protected with the decision, two days later, that a nonsectarian prayer in the graduation ceremonies for high school students was constitutionally impermissible.
Other critics of the Court's stance argue that this is no longer a culture where religious leaders hold absolute sway over mores.
Quite the contrary, they say. At a time when urban school boards are declaring it necessary to instruct grade school pupils about condoms and anal sex, these critics find absurd the Court's delicate sense that two minutes of standing attentively during a one-time graduation benediction constitutes government-instigated peer pressure on consciences.
Justice Antonin Scalia's dissent in the graduation prayer case is a masterly expression of this view. Read after the finely balanced opinion of Justice Kennedy and even after the still more intricate weaving of historical scholarship and constitutional precedent in Justice David H. Souter's concurring opinion, Justice Scalia's dissent comes across like a blunt "Who are you kidding?"
For him, the idea that silent standing during a prayer equals unconstitutional coercion is a ludicrous "psycho-journey" that simply flies in the face of "a longstanding American tradition of nonsectarian prayer to God at public celebrations."
Of course, there are rebuttals to Justice Scalia's sallies. Douglas Laycock, a constitutional scholar at the University of Texas, said that, for all its aura of realism, Mr. Scalia's dissent appeared "wholly oblivious to the social reality that goes on in these ceremonies."
Nor is it at all clear where, or why, Justice Scalia would limit religious exercises at government ceremonies. Nonsectarian public prayer is certainly a longstanding American tradition -- but so is sectarian prayer, like the one to Jesus at an earlier graduation of the Nathan Bishop Middle School. The Justice did not say how schools or other government agencies can patrol the difference without getting entangled in theology
Does any of this matter? The Rev. Richard J. Neuhaus, a Christian theologian, argues that "the premise that anything government touches should be thoroughly sanitized of any religious reference" is "societally suicidal."
American life "is riddled through and through with religious symbols," he said, and to expunge them from government would make the state "an alien force" and "pit government against society in a way that invites a reaction."
Others disagree. "I suppose there will always be people who will take the view that this is creating a naked public square," devoid of religion, said the Rev. Dean M. Kelley, counselor on religious liberty for the National Council of Churches. "But we don't have to embody religion by putting it on the courthouse steps when there are churches all around the public square that can be religious all the time."

HEADLINE: Oiapoque Journal;
Perilous Jungle Passage Leads Poor to 'France'

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OIAPOQUE, Brazil

 BODY:
After a few shots of sugar cane rum, fishermen who gather nightly on a riverside wharf here often say that, peering through the tropical haze of the Eastern Amazon, they can see the bright lights of France.
Indeed, 15 minutes downriver by motorized canoe lies a thinly populated corner of Europe: Saint Georges de l'Oyapock, the southernmost town of French Guiana. 
 Historically, Brazil has been a nation that received immigrants, not one that dispatched emigrants. Traditionally, this remote edge of the country was a beacon for French convicts escaping Devils Island and fleeing Guiana's thick jungles. In a legacy of this era, one Brazilian border village carries the name Normandia -- a nostalgic tribute by a French fugitive to his faraway birthplace.
But now it is the lights of France that burn brightest in this region straddling the Equator. Fleeing a decade of economic stagnation, Brazilians are migrating to French Guiana in search of European salaries. French Guiana, slightly larger than Maine, has only 100,000 people. Brazil's five states closest to it have 20 million people, largely poor.
 
'Hit the Beach Running'
 Without life jackets and packed into precarious wooden canoes, hundreds embark every week from here for the perilous, seven-hour journey to Cayenne, the capital of the French department.
"You have to hit the beach running," Iran Bernardino, a Brazilian veteran of the trip, counseled a friend late one afternoon as they waited for the sun to set before climbing into a river canoe.
With French work visas virtually impossible to obtain, most Brazilians enter the department illegally by way of Cayenne. Some continue to Kourou, site of the world's busiest commercial satellite launching center.
"Until I was caught, I was earning 9,000 francs a month in a furniture factory in Cayenne," Mr. Bernardino said, an amount worth $1,730 today. By contrast, the 36-year-old former construction worker noted, Brazil's legal minimum salary is $67 a month.
Oiapoque, an isolated Amazon village without a sewage system, without a high school and without a working telephone at the town hall, has become the latest contact point between two tectonic plates -- the economically developed north and the economically deprived south.
 
One Million Have Left Since '80
 The deep recession has sent Brazilians knocking on all doors. As many as one million Brazilians have immigrated to the United States, Japan and Europe since 1980. Most recently, they have turned to French Guiana.
"We used to be one big family here," Mayor Romain Garros of Saint Georges said. "Now we have more and more canoes going downriver with illegals."
Outside the town hall, Saint Georges looks like a French village transported to the Amazon. French taxpayers foot the bill.
 
A Soupcon of France
 In the oppressive humidity, France's blue, white and red flag hangs limply near a whitewashed obelisk honoring local men killed in World War I. On a far side of the central square, a supermarket sells pate and Camembert cheese imported from the "metropole."
On a road to the airport, a new hospital and high school attest to Government largess flowing from Paris. The only major convenience missing is a road to the Atlantic coast. Road construction has progressed slowly, largely because of French fears that the road will become a highway for Brazilian immigration.
In town, sun-faded posters from France's recent regional elections serve as reminders that French Guianese are full-fledged French citizens. Attracted by social benefits befitting a European Community nation, local nomadic Amazon Indians routinely cross the Oiapoque River from Brazil to register as French citizens.
At the local gendarmerie, a police officer complained about the difficulty of blocking Brazilian immigration.
 
A Growth Industry
 "For every 2 boats you catch, 10 get through," said the sergeant, outfitted in khaki shorts and shirt. "The Brazilians don't stop, and you can't shoot them."
Border tensions increased one night in April when a Brazilian team slipped into Saint Georges. Boarding the gendarmes' only river patrol boat, the Brazilians cut steering cables and stole the two outboard motors.
Oiapoque's locals admit that smuggling illegal workers into French territory has become a growth industry for Brazil's northernmost town near the Atlantic coast.
"It started two years ago with the Collor Government," Newton Torres da Silva, a former boat pilot, said. He was alluding to the recession, for which many blame Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello.
 
Plastic Baggage
 Today, boat pilots shouting fares to "Franca" greet a bus that arrives daily from Macapa, a state capital 370 miles to the south.
Facing the river wharf is a line of tent restaurants selling cheap plates of beans and rice, and Oiapoque's largest rooming house, appropriately named Hotel de Transito. On a recent afternoon, one quayside merchant openly hawked "plastic bags for Cayenne."
"You have to keep your clothes and documents wrapped in plastic," counseled Mr. Bernardino, who recalled wading ashore at dawn on previous arrivals at Cayenne. Canoe pilots rarely beach their craft, fearing that the French police will seize their motors and cut up their boats with chainsaws.
Boat pilots, who charge about $30 a passenger, find they can pack as many as 50 people into one canoe, if they dispense with life jackets. The 125-mile journey to Cayenne entails negotiating open seas for five hours with a 40-horsepower engine. When boats capsize in the dark, passengers often drown.
"It's a risk," admitted Mr. Bernardino, who said he supported his wife and two children on earnings he sent home from Cayenne. "But it's a bigger risk to stay home and to try to survive on Brazil's starvation salaries."

HEADLINE: Man Kills Wife, 2 Others and Himself, Police Say

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
A man obsessed with the idea that his wife was having an affair killed himself last night, a day after he killed his wife and two other women in the Bronx, the police said.
The man, Jose Dolores Martinez, 41 years old, shot his wife and her niece to death in their Bronx apartment on Thursday night and then went to the home of his former girlfriend minutes later and stabbed her to death, the police said yesterday. 
 Last night, the police said Mr. Martinez, an unemployed gypsy-cab driver from the Dominican Republic, barricaded himself in an apartment in Manhattan, holding a woman and two children hostage. After an hourlong standoff with police officers, he released the hostages and then fatally shot himself, the police said.
The incident ended a search that began on Thursday night with the shooting deaths of Mr. Martinez's wife, Maria Altagracia, 40, and her niece, Moraima Rosario, 33, in their apartment at 38 Marcy Place, in Morrisania.
Lieut. James Malvey, the commanding officer of the 44th Precinct Detective Squad, said that Mr. Martinez then killed of his former girlfriend, Ana Rodriguez, 39, at 1060 Sherman Avenue, seven blocks away.
"What set him off, we don't know," Lieutenant Malvey said. "So far, there's no information from anyone we interviewed that his wife was having an affair."
Lieutenant Malvey said Mr. Martinez entered the apartment about 8 P.M., walked into the living room with a .357 Magnum revolver and pulled his wife into the bedroom, demanding to know the identity of her lover. When she denied having an affair, he went back to the living room, pointed his gun at Ms. Rosario and yanked her into the bedroom.
Mr. Martinez closed the bedroom door and shot both women in the head, Lieutenant Malvey said. When some of the children ran screaming into the hallway for help, Mr. Martinez jumped from the bedroom window and went to Ms. Rodriguez's home, the police said.
The police said Mr. Martinez demanded that Ms. Rodriguez tell him, in front of her two children, the identity of his wife's lover. He stabbed her repeatedly and left the apartment, the police said.
A police spokesman, Sgt. Norris L. Hollomon, said that Mr. Martinez appeared at an apartment at 514 West 176th Street about 9 P.M. last night and took a woman and two children, who were not identified, hostage.
Mr. Martinez released the hostages about 10:25 P.M., and when officers entered the apartment, they found him dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the sergeant said. It was not immediately clear whether Mr. Martinez knew the woman or children, he said.

METRO DIGEST
 
 LEGISLATIVE SESSION ENDS IN DEADLOCK
The New York legislative session ended in partisan bickering, as lawmakers left town near dawn without acting on two major economic initiatives: an $800 million bond act to create jobs and fiscal bailouts for Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The Governor squared off against the Senate's Republicans, and the two measures remained hostage to one another. Page 1.
 
 THE LEGACY OF '92
The enduring legacy of the 1992 session of the New York State Legislature may be that lawmakers, for the first time in eight years, passed a budget almost on time. But though there was hope that the timely passage of the $56 billion budget would free the Legislature to address the state's most serious problems for three months, that hope dissolved in the final days of the session when more deals fell apart than came together. News analysis, Page 24.
 
 YOUR TIRED, YOUR POOR, YOUR VOTES
With the foreign-born now making up more than a quarter of the city's population, Democrats and Republicans alike are reaching out into uncharted territory, after immigrants who could one day be as much a force as those at the turn of the century. Page 1.
 
 NEW YORK CITY
 
 NEW LOOK,
 OLD PROBLEM
Graduation Day for the Police Academy came with the usual pomp, but no one, from the rookies to the dignitaries, seemed able to ignore the event's subtext: that this class was entering the force as suspicions of corruption hovered over the Police Department. In a speech to the officers, Mayor Dinkins suggested that the problem was largely a creation of news organizations. Page 23.
 
 BUT WHO'S COUNTING?
Like a very merry unbirthday, the Third of July was celebrated yesterday almost as though it was Independence Day -- with flags fluttering, bands blaring and ships parading. Page 23.
 
 JEALOUS MAN KILLS THREE, THEN HIMSELF

 WORLD GOES TO MICKLETON, N.J.

HEADLINE: U.S. Puts Victorious Spin on Summit

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
With President Bush due to leave this weekend for the economic summit meeting in Munich, the White House has begun a campaign to turn it into a pep rally for economic growth to demonstrate Mr. Bush's determination to do something about the sagging American economy.
Especially after the sharp jump in the nation's jobless rate announced Thursday, which was a blow to Mr. Bush's re-election hopes, the White House is eager to declare Munich a victory. 
 In effect, the White House is telling the people back home that the meetings were a diplomatic triumph, even before the leaders of the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan gather on Monday.
At the same time, with President Bush slumping badly in public opinion polls, some American officials say the leaders at the summit meeting are deliberately pursuing a modest agenda that seeks to prevent any potentially embarrassing blow-ups among the leaders.
In briefings and statements this week before the summit, Administration officials have asserted that they have been trying for 18 months to persuade Japan and Germany to put more emphasis on economic growth. The officials said Tokyo and Bonn had finally agreed to measures that will promote growth.
 
'Modest Expectations'
 As evidence that the strategy has been successful, the Administration is citing a commitment by Japan's Government to spend an extra $45 billion next year on public works and other projects to spur its flagging growth. It is also citing measures by the German Government to hold down its budget deficit in the hope that this will enable the Central Bank to lower interest rates.
The Japanese and Germans insist that they are not taking these actions at Washington's bidding, but to restore health to their sagging economies.
While not taking credit for Tokyo's and Bonn's new policies, the Administration is publicizing them as if they were part of President Bush's economic growth package.
"These actions demonstrate forcefully the high priority which the summit places on strong global economic growth," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in a news briefing this week.
Many officials say they doubt the United States will push hard to resolve the long dispute over farm subsidies that has blocked completion of talks to liberalize world trade. Many foreign policy experts say a breakthrough in the trade talks, which would be a boon for developing nations, is needed far more than a lofty-sounding communique to send a growth message to the world.
"The Administration is downplaying the summit and is trying to keep expectations quite modest," said Robert D. Hormats, a former assistant secretary of state for economic affairs who is vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "There is good reason because the prospect of anything big coming out of Munich is not great."
 
No More Mr. No
 Some analysts say that after President Bush's last two embarrassing trips abroad -- the trade-promotion trip to Tokyo and his trip to the Earth Summit in Rio, where he was called Mr. No -- the last thing he needs on this trip, which will also take him to Poland, is a bruising fiasco over trade or any other subject.
It has been suggested that the leader attending the Munich summit who enjoys the most popularity at home is not a Group of Seven member but President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. The Western leaders will meet with Mr. Yeltsin to discuss Moscow's progress on reforms and its need for aid, but some officials say that they doubt Mr. Yeltsin will go home with anything beyond the $24 billion package that the Group of Seven leaders promised him last April.
To show their concern for Russia, Bush Administration officials hope the International Monetary Fund will approve a $1 billion aid package for Russia before the summit. Not wanting to be embarrassed by any snags, however, American officials say that it will not be a tragedy if an agreement is not signed until after the summit if that is necessary to get Russia to commit to a good reform package.
Secretary Brady has signaled the leaders' desire to give Mr. Yeltsin a special gift, saying they want the industrial nations to take the rare move of restructuring Russia's debt burden even before Moscow signs a comprehensive reform agreement with the monetary fund.
President Bush told foreign journalists on Thursday that the Munich meeting was important because, by encouraging world growth, it could help increase American exports. He noted that 70 percent of American economic growth over the past five years has come from exports.

INTERNATIONAL
Japan's global trade surplus is soaring again to record levels, a development that could increase unemployment in other nations and contribute to a new round of trade tensions. It is also likely to be a main topic at the summit meeting of the seven leading industrial countries next week in Munich. [Page 1.]
Bush hopes to turn next week's economic summit meeting into a pep rally for economic growth, despite the sharp jump in the nation's jobless rate. [5.] 
 Japan's new high-definition television system is being re-evaluated because of a technological shift that may doom it to early obsolescence. [30.]
Spain's national airline, Iberia Lineas Aereas, is casting its lot overseas, namely to Latin America, hoping to avoid the nasty price wars expected to develop closer to home. [33.]
 
THE ECONOMY
Consumers in Reading, Pa., are still pinching pennies, a habit ingrained by the long recession. If conditions in Reading are representative, this consumer attitude implies a reshaping of retailing and raises questions about a recovery. [30.]
Bankers said they expected no spurt in borrowing and spending by businesses or consumers in the wake of the Federal Reserve's move on Thursday to cut interest rates, or in response to banks' own cut in the prime lending rate to 6 percent from 6.5 percent. [33]

HEADLINE: Munich Cleans Up the Castle To Welcome World Leaders

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 2

 BODY:
The regal palace that was the seat of Bavaria's monarchy for nearly five centuries is covered with scaffolding this week. The elaborately carved clock on the front of City Hall is being oiled. And some residents are cleaning their lederhosen and feathered hats so they can look their best for world leaders who arrive Monday.
By the time the so-called Group of Seven summit meeting opens, Munich will be glistening even more brightly than usual, and Bavarians are preparing to show off their fairyland state to an unusually distinguished group of visitors. 
 Both previous meetings of the seven leading industrialized democracies held in Germany were in Bonn. But this time Chancellor Helmut Kohl decided that Munich, with its castles and world-class beer drinkers, would be a more exciting place for him to welcome the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan and the United States. In addition, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia will join the Group of Seven leaders in Munich.
Daily sessions of the conference will be held at the palace of Wittelsbach, the ancestral home of the dynasty that ruled Bavaria from the late 12th century until the end of World War I. Construction of the palace complex began in the 14th century, and it boasts seven courtyards and a dazzling collection of artworks including jeweled crucifixes and a gold panel from 1590 depicting St. George slaying the dragon.
Among the formal events scheduled during the summit meeting is a dinner at Nymphenburg, a rococo chateau set amid elaborate gardens in an outlying section of Munich that was a summer residence for Bavarian rulers.
 
U.S. Delegation Is Largest
 According to official estimates, there will be 1,800 official participants in the meeting, along with nearly 6,000 accredited journalists and an estimated 4,000 protesters attending what is billed as an "Anti-Summit."
The largest delegation by far, reportedly totaling more than 700 and more than twice the size of any other nation, is being brought by President Bush, who is also the only leader bringing his own limousine.
The hotel suite where Mr. Bush will stay has been renovated at a cost of $300,000. Among the additions were a marble bathtub and a library.
The costs of staging the meeting is estimated at $21 million, of which three-quarters is being paid by the German Government and the rest by Bavaria.
 
9,000 Police on Duty
 But because of the tight security to be imposed on the city for the event, some people fear that the investment will yield little, if anything, for the local economy. The Bavarian share, according to one disgruntled legislator, would be enough to build 50 housing units or a kindergarten for 200 children.
Nine thousand police officers, 3,500 from local police forces and the rest from other parts of Germany, will be on duty here. Police planners say they are hoping to keep security as unobtrusive as possible, but concede that armed officers will be standing on every corner, prowling in every park, scanning the city from dozens of rooftops, and monitoring the proceedings from helicopters. Special units will be posted along highways and rail lines leading into the city.
But few people here can fault the authorities for taking security seriously. In the minds of many, Munich is still linked with the Palestinian terrorist attack at the Olympic Games here 20 years ago in which Israeli athletes were taken hostage. The attack horrified the world and ultimately cost 17 lives.
"For the situation of 20 years ago to repeat itself is completely unimaginable," said Walter Renner, a policeman who was at the 1972 Olympics. "At that time, we had no preparation or training in antiterrorist tactics. The whole idea was foreign to us. We were practically helpless. Things are very different today."
To assure that the visitors can move easily through the city, most downtown streets will be closed, and parking throughout the "security zone" will be banned. These plans have irritated residents, and struck fear into the hearts of merchants.
"No one is going to come downtown for three days," worried Franz Hermann, manager of a shop that sells porcelain beer mugs and other Bavarian curios. "There will be nowhere to park, and probably nowhere to walk without bumping into police. It will definitely be bad for business."

HEADLINE: A Series of Visits to Reading, Pa.

DATELINE: READING, Pa., June 27

 BODY:
Since late 1990, in the early stages of America's ninth postwar recession, The New York Times has been visiting Reading and surrounding Berks County periodically to gauge economic conditions. The area's mix of retailing, manufacturing and services is typical of the Northeast.
The articles, appearing at intervals of roughly three months and consisting of interviews with shoppers, business people and workers, seek to portray the current activity and mood, thereby providing a glimpse of the future. 
 The first, 18 months ago, found Reading gripped in malaise and braced for a recession that was not officially designated as such until the following April -- and that is still not officially ended. The second article found this city of row houses and blue collars mired in recession's reality.
In April 1991, The Times focused on the Glen-Gery Corporation, a major brick producer that appeared on the verge of signaling a recovery that proved elusive for it and the economy at large. In June of last year, people here were anticipating recovery by Labor Day; but as school started people here said they still did not see much improvement.
This past February found optimism rising -- and the return of some shoppers -- but a continued wariness that kept spending subdued.

HEADLINE: Tales of the Tightfisted Consumer

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., June 27

 BODY:
Though some might call it false economy, considering the value of time and gasoline, Linda Startzel was intent all the same on driving 20 miles round trip to buy a picnic cooler at Reading's spanking new 114,000-square-foot Wal-Mart out on Perkiomen Avenue.
Indeed, it was with a certain satisfaction that she emerged from the discount colossus, having spent just $14.88 for an item that had been marked $17.97 at a Kmart -- no slouch at price-cutting itself -- near her home in Pottstown. 
 Mrs. Startzel, who with her husband usually spends a week each year vacationing in Cancun, Mexico, is not by nature a skinflint. It's just that the Startzels are trying to save some money, since they feel none too secure about their jobs. Both work at Bell Atlantic and face the possibility of a strike this summer.
To the dismay of merchants, there seem to be all too many Startzels around these days. "People are value conscious, looking for basic value rather than frills," said Edwin Lakin, president of Boscov's, a medium-sized regional department-store chain that has its headquarters and three stores here.
 
Questions About Recovery
 This "don't spend more than you must" attitude threatens not only merchants in Reading and surrounding Berks County, where The New York Times has taken seven soundings of business conditions over the last 18 months. It implies a reshaping of American retailing and raises questions about the nation's economic recovery. While consumers do not usually initiate recoveries, consumer spending -- representing two-thirds of the nation's economy -- has traditionally fueled recoveries. But this recession, if Reading is any indication, has trained consumers to pinch their pennies.
This reluctance to spend also tends to be a strong antidote to inflation. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Chemical Bank in New York, finds consumers these days nothing less than "defiant" about price increases, which during the recession they have learned can often be resisted successfully.
"With job security increasingly problematic and income growth slowing, cost-conscious consumers are embracing retailing discounters with unabashed enthusiasm," Mr. Kellner said, noting that discounters now account for more than 40 percent of general merchandise business and one-third of apparel sales.
Discounters probably do not pose a severe threat to retailers like Boscov's. The chain is said to enjoy a loyal following of well-served, middle-income customers, and after a flat period earlier in the year it reported a May-June sales pickup to levels about 5 percent above those of a year earlier. But traditional stores like Boscov's are finding that the range of goods in which they can be competitive is narrowing.
Increasingly, according to Joseph B. Siegel, a merchandising specialist and vice president of the National Retail Federation, department stores are being limited to apparel and related "soft" goods while ceding the mass-produced "hard goods" like snow blowers and tennis balls to the discounters.
"They've got to hurt some businesses there," Mr. Siegel said when asked about the effect on Reading of two recently opened Wal-Marts and a Sam's Club, a Wal-Mart affiliate. While "moderate" and "better" consumers, to use the industry's classifications, will not start buying clothes at a discounter, they very well may join "budget" and "bargain" customers buying picnic coolers and antifreeze there.
Talk to almost any business person hereabouts and tales of thrifty or cautious customers come pouring out. Take, for example, Mike Zdunowski, who owns both a sizable tire dealership and a local beer distributor and who sees "no inkling" of economic recovery.
"This is the most discouraging June we've had in 10 years," he said in his gritty garage on South Ninth Street, with sales 20 percent below those of June 1991, a comparison far worse than May's. Mr. Zdunowski, who is fixing more flats and selling more used tires these days, manages a wry smile when reminded that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady spoke in February about tires being a good economic indicator and seeing "robins on the lawn" that he said portended recovery.
 
Getting the Last Mile
 "People are trying to get the last mile" out of their tires, which over the years have become a big-ticket item, Mr. Zdunowski added. "That's how people cope."
As for the beer business, consumers are drinking just as much as ever but are presumably enjoying it less since they have switched to cheaper brands, shunning imports. "People are shopping price with beer,' Mr. Zdunowski says, shaking his head as if he could never have imagined such a situation, which he says is partly because of the Federal tax increase at the beginning of 1991 that forced his prices up $1.75 a case. Profits, he says, have shrunk by half.
Or talk to Daniel L. Schmehl Jr., proprietor of the Iron Horse Hobby House, a downtown fixture since 1938, which traditionally has flourished in recessions but which has suffered a steady decline in its hobby business since February.
"They're just not spending the money on anything," Mr. Schmehl said of his absent customers, adding that the neighboring hairdresser was also hurting and that the art-supply house across the street was conducting the first sale -- up to 70 percent off -- he could remember.
At Gilbert's furniture store on Penn Street, Ronald K. Buckley, the vice president, repeats the theme that "people are buying value," noting that sales these days are by the piece or possibly by the room but rarely for a whole house.
 
Incentive Went Well
 He is somewhat encouraged, however, that customers responded well to a special incentive running from Memorial Day to July 4 under which purchases on credit accrue no interest charges for six months. Those paying cash for their furniture, meanwhile, have received a 5 percent discount.
"People want to be given a reason why they should buy now," Mr. Buckley said.
And Gilbert's itself is a cautious consumer, as shown by its recent decision to reject a financing package from an out-of-town bank that would have allowed the store to move to a new site in the suburbs before it sold its current building. A suburban location would probably attract more shoppers, but Gilbert's is not optimistic that it can sell its present site quickly in the current market. "Just too risky," Mr. Buckley concluded.
The current tightfistedness among consumers is also evident among major manufacturers. A prime example is Carpenter Technology, a specialty steel company with $600 million in annual sales that announced the elimination of 130 white-collar jobs this spring in a restructuring intended to reap the benefits of heavy investment in computerization.
Carpenter, according to Paul R. Roedel, who is retiring as president, is suffering a squeeze on profit margins at a time when its overall business is flat because of soft sales of components for oilfield equipment and for jet engines.
Factories in the area report generally "spotty" business, said Donald Mattern, executive director of the 311-member Manufacturers Association of Berks County. "Most of them are just tightening their belt," he said, except for the East Penn Manufacturing Company, which has added workers to help fulfill a big new battery contract for the Army.
At the Meridian Bank, which as the area's dominant financial institution has probably the best view of local conditions, soberness is tinged with optimism.
"Loan demand is just absolutely flat," said Ezekiel S. Ketchum, the president, but the charge-off of bad loans has peaked and automobile sales have perked up a bit, he added.

HEADLINE: Life in a Trailer Park: On the Edge, but Hoping

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo.

 BODY:
Inside a narrow house trailer, where the heat works sometimes and the telephone never does, a fierce Wyoming wind slams against the aluminum walls, rattling the family pictures and everything else that hangs by a hook.
Rising from a threadbare sofa, Molly Prosinski cradles 2-year-old April in one arm, wipes a smudge from the face of 5-year-old Aaron and debates the merits of homework with Crystal, 12, all the while checking the macaroni on the stove. 
 But the most difficult part comes a moment later. Crystal raises her large brown eyes toward her mother and asks, as she has so many times before: "Mom, why do we have to live in a trailer?"
Mobile homes were the fastest-growing type of dwelling in the 1980's, according to the Census Bureau, as the cost of traditional houses soared beyond the reach of many. Although sales slowed in recent years, nearly 16 million Americans, about 1 in 16, now live in mobile homes.
Nearly half the new mobile homes being sold are the more expensive "double-wide" models, with two sections bolted together to achieve the size and look of a house. The most expensive of these models can cost $100,000.
But far more live in used trailers that cost $10,000 or less. In rural America, where the trailer park is most common, it is still often regarded, if not as a symbol of poverty, then just one rung above it.
Crystal and the other children from the trailer park where she lives make up most of the student body at the new brick elementary school next door. When they graduate to high school, where most of the students live in houses, they sometimes fear hurtful comments about "trailer trash."
Mrs. Prosinski, 28, whose husband, Scott, 27, earns about $12,000 a year from his job as a dishwasher, urged her daughter to be grateful for what they have: a 14-by-70-foot home that rents for $350 a month, part of it paid to the trailer's owner, part "lot rent" paid to the trailer park.
"Remember that last trailer?" Mrs. Prosinski said. "The one with all the mice crawling up the heat vents?"
After her daughter left the room, Mrs. Prosinski gazed out the window toward the harsh, scrub grass plains beyond the trailer court.
"There are times," she said, "when I just want to sit down and cry."
 
Their Little Sliver Of America's Dream
 Since mobile homes flourished in the 1960's, the American trailer park has become a metaphor for struggle at the edges -- the edge of town, the edge of the middle class, the edge of adversity. Half the people who live in mobile homes have incomes of less than $20,000 a year, and more than three-fourths earn less than $30,000 annually.
These are people who grasp at the American dream but who can clutch only a fragment: a tiny yard, but no basement, a parking pad, but no garage.
But for those who own their mobile homes, they have something, however modest -- and certain to depreciate -- on the asset side of the ledger.
For some, the trailer park is a way station, where newlyweds and recent college graduates save for the house they cannot afford at the moment. For others, who barely hang on, the mobile home is simply the cheapest shelter they can find. The average age of a mobile home resident is 50, and nearly 35 percent are 60 or older.
This trailer park of 200 mobile homes, Big Country Estates, lies at the south end of town, where gas stations and fast-food restaurants give way to empty countryside.
The trailers are spaced so closely that people here joke that they can look out the window and see what the neighbors are having for dinner. And arguments must be conducted in low tones, or everyone in the neighborhood will hear it.
The bigger, fancier mobile homes, which are valued about $20,000, sit near the highway, a way of advertisement for the trailer park. The smaller, often weather-beaten trailers, worth $5,000 or less, sit farther back, obscured from the road. Some of the narrow strips of ground between the trailers are bright with grass and flowers; other have gone to dust and weeds.
 
Pride by a Highway: 'We Own That'

Standing in front of an old, yellow trailer, Dale Curl, 31, crouched to pull a fistful of weeds from his yard. "This is going to be beautiful before you know it," he said with a smile.
A loud car, badly in need of a muffler, roared by and muffled his words. But nothing could dampen his joy.
For the first time in their lives, Mr. Curl and his wife, Kim, 25, own a home. Last month they bought trailer No. 5.
"It feels so good to be able to say, 'We own that,' " he said.
Mr. Curl works for a catalogue wholesaler. Mrs. Curl is a bakery shop clerk. They earned $22,000 last year. They and their two children had been renting the trailer next door, No. 4.
The payments for their own trailer, which they took over from the previous owner, will be $265 a month, along with $150 for the lot rent. In five years the 12-by-64-foot trailer will be paid off.
"I feel like having a housewarming party," said Mrs. Curl.
Mobile homes are built on assembly lines in factories around the country and shipped on trucks with "Wide Load" signs. The industry prefers to call them Manufactured Housing rather than mobile homes, since they are rarely moved afterwards.
Most people who live in them call them trailers. Trailers are most commonly found in rural areas of the South and West. Wyoming, the most sparsely populated state, ranks only after South Carolina in the percentage of people who live in mobile homes; in both states about 1 in 6 housing units is a mobile home or trailer.
Zoning codes in some areas discourage the presence of mobile homes. But 22 states have outlawed such codes, saying they are discriminatory.
"There is still a stigma," said Bruce Savage, a spokesman for the Manufactured Housing Institute, a trade group. "Some people still think of them as places for poor, undesirable characters."
In a 1991 report on ways to encourage affordable housing, Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, called on states to remove barriers to mobile homes.
While some mobile homes sit on private land, the vast majority are in trailer parks. About 170,000 new mobile homes were sold last year, down from 295,000 in 1983, when the energy boom brought jobs and a surge in demand for housing to the Sun Belt. The bad times that followed there and the national economic slump in the late 1980's dampened demand for mobile homes as well as for other new housing. About 700,000 single family homes were built last year, the lowest number since 1946.
 
 
Widow Adds Color To Neighbors' Lives
 With one hand flashing on the piano keyboard and the other hand on the organ, 69-year-old Winona Barnes delights the children in the trailer park who come around to hear her music.
One recent day she played "I'm Flying High, but I've Got a Feeling I'm Falling."
She and her husband, Lowell, bought their 14-by-72-foot trailer in 1980. They paid $14,000 and hoped to move it to the countryside someday.
"But money was tight," she said, "and it never quite happened."
Mrs. Barnes, now a widow living on Social Security, said she could no longer afford to move. Like most mobile homes, her place has lost value over the years. She thinks it is now worth about $4,500.
Almost every day she drives her 1980 Thunderbird to the nearby Veterans of the Foreign War post, where she rolls the dice. It costs a dollar for a chance to win $300.
Besides gambling and music, she said with a wink, her greatest passion is flowers. Last year, Mrs. Barnes won the award for the most colorful yard in the park. She won $35 and promptly invested her gain in more petunias and geraniums for her tiny plot.
When her husband was alive, he would rest in the easy chair as she played music long into the night. "I'd see him fast asleep," she said. "But when I would quit, he would wake right up and say, 'Why did you quit?' "
After he died, Mrs. Barnes, whose kitchen wall has a plate that says, "Happiness is meant to be shared," did not play her music for a very long time. But the children finally coaxed her back to the keyboard.
 
Costs Can Be High In Fees and Safety
 Though mobile homes offer the semblance of a house, they provide less protection from inflation or the elements. Banks treat them like a car and value them less as they grow older. And because mobile homes without land are financed as personal property, buyers pay interest rates of 13 or 14 percent, rather than about 9 percent for conventional home mortgages.
People sometimes become angry that they cannot get the lower loan rate, said Rob Mossey, a loan officer at the Norwest Bank in Cheyenne.
"We have to tell them, flat out, 'Look, your mobile home is not going to be worth much down the road,' " he said.
Insurance rates, too, are usually 10 to 20 percent higher than for traditional homes, Mr. Mossey said, because mobile homes are more vulnerable to high winds, hailstorm and fire.
Thanks to Federal safety requirements imposed in 1974, mobile homes are less likely to experience a fire than standard homes, said Alan D. Miller, a spokesman for State Farm Insurance. "But when they have a fire, they're much more likely to result in total loss," he said. While the rate of fire fatalities is 7 per thousand in houses, it is 17 per thousand in mobile homes. The extra deadliness is probably because the dense packing on mobile homes give fire quicker and more violent combustion, fire experts say.
 
Plans to Escape Fire And the Trailer Life
 Fire drills are standard practice in the Darlow home, a double-wide trailer that the family of six rents for $425 a month.
"The kids are all assigned windows for escape," said Lany Darlow, whose parents' mobile home in Texas caught fire and burned in about three minutes.
If a tornado threatens, the family plans to rush to the nearby elementary school, because the trailer park has no underground shelter. Strong winds pose a particular danger. No national statistics are kept on trailers and tornadoes, but last year in Kansas a tornado killed 14 people at a mobile home community.
Someday soon, the Darlows hope to move from the trailer. Daniel Darlow, 38, a former Coast Guard gunner, graduated from law school in Laramie last fall. He has been a substitute teacher at an elementary school, where he earns $25 for a half-day, $50 for a full day. He is also studying for his bar exams. On his first try he failed the exam by five points.
Mr. Darlow served in the Coast Guard for 10 years. If he had stayed he would be nearing retirement. As the pressure builds for his next test, he said, he sometimes regrets his decision to leave the military.
If he passes and gets a job, the family will start packing to move "that very day," Mrs. Darlow said.
But with a worried look, Mr. Darlow added: "If I fail, well, we might be here awhile."
