HEADLINE: Technology Shift Blurs Future of Japan's New TV System

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3

 BODY:
A shift in technology is causing a quiet re-evaluation of Japan's new system for providing the next generation of television. Some experts here wonder whether its high-definition system, once the envy of the world, is now doomed to early obsolescence.
The Japanese do not admit that their system, just starting to reach the market, appears to have been eclipsed by technology developed in the last two years in the United States. 
 Still, the Government and industry are following the United States into computer-like digital transmission, which can offer sharper pictures and has other advantages over the older analog transmission used for Japanese high-definition television. They are also considering a project to develop a super-high-definition system that would leapfrog everything available today.
"It's a very delicate time in Japan," said Shigeo Tsujii, a professor at the Tokyo Institute of Technology who serves on a Government advisory committee on digital imaging.
 
'Consensus' Is Digital
 That the future belongs to digital television is "the substantial consensus of the world, including Japan," said Hiroshi Fujiwara, senior vice president of GC Technology Corporation, a small maker of computer chips used to transmit video images by telephone. "But officially, nobody can tell you the future is going to digital because we Japanese spent much money to develop analog HDTV."
Indeed, the Japan Broadcasting Corporation, which led the development of the country's HDTV system, is sticking with its technology. And Japan's television manufacturers are not breaking ranks with NHK, as the public broadcasting company is known. To overcome the high prices and lack of programming that have dampened interest in HDTV, manufacturers are introducing lower-priced sets and hoping the Barcelona Olympics, which begin July 25, will spur demand.
Even so, they foresee a day when digital technology replaces their analog system, which is known as Muse.
"Japan will give up on Muse, but I don't know when," said Tomofumi Yasunari, a key official on telecommunications policy in the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. "I think the lifetime will be 10 years, but sometimes we think it will continue only five years."
Others say it will take far longer for a digital system to supplant Muse.
"For several decades, Muse is the sole candidate for HDTV for broadcasting," said Shinichi Makino, technology executive for high-definition systems at the Toshiba Corporation.
A crucial decision is likely to come in about a year when a committee recommends how to allocate channels on a new broadcast satellite scheduled to begin service in 1997. Several channels on that satellite were to be allocated to HDTV to let programming expand, but the whole question of what to use the satellite for is being re-examined.
 
Earlier Setbak
 Early obsolescence would be the second big blow to Japan's efforts in high-definition television, which provides pictures twice as sharp as conventional TV. A few years ago, Japan was far ahead in developing the technology and hoped to make Muse a world standard. But the European Community, followed by the United States, balked at accepting the system, worried that it would let Japanese electronics companies become too strong. As a result, it appears that the three major economic regions will have separate, incompatible systems, with Muse confined to Japan.
Now Japan is being hit by a change in technology. Digital technology, which transmits images using the zeros and ones of computer code, could allow for clearer, cleaner images, just as digital compact disks offer music free of the hisses and distortions of analog records. Digital technology also makes it easier for video images to be manipulated by computers -- letting a viewer zoom in on part of a picture or store a television image on a computer disk.
To some extent, NHK's choice of analog technology for high-definition television was inescapable because its development efforts began 20 years ago, when digital technology was not available. As recently as three years ago most engineers were saying that digital transmission would not be feasible for at least another decade.
But in the last two years, American companies like General Instrument and Zenith Electronics have demonstrated prototype digital systems, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to choose one as the United States standard in 1993. Some industry officials say competition in the United States spurred faster development than did the more centralized approach in Japan.
But officials of NHK and some manufacturers contend that the digital systems developed in the United States are still not fully proved and will probably take longer to perfect than the American companies hope.
Mr. Makino of Toshiba said that while digital systems can provide a crisp picture in the face of moderate electromagnetic interference, if the interference becomes too great -- as it might in a big city -- then the digital system fails completely. American companies have not fully demonstrated that they can overcome that problem, he said.
Moreover, in terms of picture resolution, the American systems, those officials say, offer no improvement over the Muse system and there is no reason to change to digital now merely because Americans have done so.
"It will take at least until the end of this century" for digital transmission to be feasible, said Shuichi Morikawa, a managing director at NHK Laboratories. "We cannot stop the service at this moment and say, 'We're going to digital in the 21st century.' If we stop the furnace it will take time to heat it up again."
The unspoken dilemma is that if Japanese industry and programmers think the Muse system will be eclipsed by a digital system in a decade, they might be reluctant to put much effort into developing equipment and programming for Muse now. And consumers might be reluctant to invest in Muse-system television sets and VCR's.
Until recently, high-definition television sets cost about $30,000; the only way ordinary consumers could watch "Hi-Vision" was in a department store or other public viewing place.
Lack of programming is another reason HDTV is struggling to get off the ground. There is only one HDTV channel, with about eight hours of programming a day. Making such programs is about three times as expensive as making a conventional program, an NHK spokesman said.
But NHK and manufacturers hope that the summer Olympics will spur interest in high-definition television, just as the 1964 Tokyo Olympics gave the first big spurt to sales of color televisions here. During the Olympics, all eight hours of high-definition broadcasting will be devoted to Barcelona, and the number of public HDTV viewing places will be increased to 300, from 100.
 
'Affordable' Sets Available
 In addition, several manufacturers, taking advantage of new microchip technology, have come out with high-definition sets that sell for about $10,000 and are thus "affordable," at least in the sense that a car is affordable.
Sony Corporation, for instance, sold only 400 of its more expensive first-generation HDTV sets. But it is installing capacity to make 3,000 of its new $10,000 sets -- introduced at a news conference recently by Sony's president, Norio Ohga -- each month. To combat the dearth of programming, Sony also announced that it planned to produce high-definition programming on video disk.
At the same time, Japanese companies are brushing up on digital television, if only to be able to make television sets and other equipment for the American market.
Sony, Matsushita, Hitachi and Toshiba have all started research laboratories in the United States working on advanced television. Toshiba recently said it would make a digital videocassette recorder compatible with the digital HDTV system developed by General Instrument. Industry executives say that the fact that the United States has developed its own high-definition broadcasting system is no guarantee that American companies will make the television sets and broadcasting equipment.
NHK is also working on several types of digital transmission technology. And the Japanese Government is laying plans for an ambitious digital imaging project.
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications has set up a digital video technology committee that is expected to make recommendations on what Japan should do in digital television. The committee is expected to recommend that efforts be made to develop a super-high-definition digital system for the next century. Such a system, which some are calling ultra-definition television, would be able to transmit images with 2,000 or even 3,000 lines of resolution, compared with 1,125 for Muse and 525 for conventional television.
Kazuhiko Nishi, a personal computer entrepreneur who heads the ASCII Corporation, a software company, has proposed setting up an organization called Digital Movies Laboratory to develop such technology. Key roles in the proposed seven-year effort would be played by ASCII, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's main phone company, and by a subsidiary of NHK, Mr. Nishi said.

HEADLINE: Malawi Merits Not One Penny From U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Malawi Needs Assistance and Sympathy" (letter, June 6) by N. W. Mwaungulu, Malawi's United Nations representative, is a feeble effort at obfuscation criticizing a May 22 editorial. Malawi has not been denied aid from many quarters because it embraced "a free market path to development." Rather, its outcast status resulted from its being the sole country in Africa to recognize and support the apartheid regime of South Africa. 
 There certainly has not been a "considerable improvement in the quality of life of the people," and Malawi remains the world's seventh poorest country. The assertion about "the nonexistence of enmity between the Roman Catholic Church and the state" is astonishing. On March 8 the church's seven bishops issued a pastoral letter criticizing the "growing gap between rich and poor" in Malawi and noting that "academic freedom is seriously restricted; exposing injustices can be considered a betrayal; monopoly of mass media and censorship prevent the expression of dissenting views."
Possession of the pastoral letter was immediately declared a crime, for which many were arrested. On March 10 all the bishops were arrested by the police and held for eight hours. The country's cabinet reportedly urged that they be executed. The bishop of Mzuzu was subsequently deported. In a speech on the overall situation, President H. Kamazu Banda warned that any dissenters would be "food for crocodiles."
Should American taxpayers subsidize a government that survives by political repression and generalized thuggery to such an extent that it is widely known as the "Albania of Africa"? Many African countries -- such as Malawi's neighbor Zambia -- are genuinely committed to multiparty democracy and a free market system, and merit whatever support the United States can give. Malawi merits no such support, and the aid cutoff that has begun should continue.
Thirty years of President Banda's regime have not solved the country's terrible economic problems, and it is clear that the nonagenarian dictator has no idea how to proceed.
While Malawians have been among Africa's best educated people, for the last 30 years to be educated is a curse. Teachers have been jailed for teaching, poets for writing poetry, journalists for producing journalism. Any thought not approved by President Banda and his clique has been forbidden, and a censorship board does its work assiduously. Foreign journalists are also explicitly forbidden to enter the country.
Not a penny of American aid should be sent to Malawi until freedom of thought, freedom of discussion and freedom of the press are established there.
 
LEROY VAIL
Professor of African History
Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass., June 15, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Tokyo Shares Close Mixed

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3

 BODY:
Tokyo stocks ended mixed today after giving up strong gains made earlier in the day as investors became cautious when the Nikkei index neared the 17,000 level.
Brokers said expectations of lower Japanese interest rates after Thursday's discount rate cut in the United States gave the market firm support. 
 The Nikkei average of 225 stocks ended the day down 39.85 points, or 0.24 percent, at 16,717.78. Even so, the Nikkei ended the week's trading up 905.05 points, or 5.72 percent.
Volume slipped to about 330 million shares from 350 million Thursday. Advancing issues outpaced decliners about 7 to 4.

HEADLINE: Rate Cuts Won't Start Big Spree, Banks Say

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bankers said yesterday that they expected no spurt in borrowing and spending by businesses or consumers in the wake of the Federal Reserve's move on Thursday to cut interest rates, or their own cut in the prime lending rate to 6 percent from 6.5 percent.
"It has got to help a little, but I don't think businesses were holding back their borrowing just because they would have had to pay 6.5 percent or 7 percent instead of 6 percent," said Richard M. Kovacevich, president of the Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis-based banking company. "What they really want to see is a full order book." 
 Bankers and economists say the key to increased hiring and investment in expansion is business confidence that consumer demand, the bedrock of the economy, is on a stable growth path.
For consumers, the interest rate cut is a mixed bag. Lower rates on bank deposits and other investments hurt savers, but are a boon to those buying a home, or have a mortgage with an adjustable rate.
 
Disappointing to Savers
 "Lower interest rates are disappointing to a large number of people, the savers, but beneficial to a smaller number of borrowers," noted George W. Hamlin, chairman of the Canandaigua National Bank and Trust Company in New York.
But the difference between the rates paid on deposits and the rates earned on loans and investments is the lifeblood of the banking system, and so long as rates are falling on loans and investments, analysts expect banks to be reducing rates paid on deposits. "If you understand that a banker's first duty is to remain in business, then you understand why deposit rates have been falling," Mr. Hamlin said.
Robert Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla., estimated that average rates on bank certificates of deposit would fall about two-tenths of a percentage point in a few months. One-year deposits, for example, might fall to a national average of 3.80 percent, from 4.03 percent before the Fed's move, he said, while bank money market accounts may drop to 3.15 percent from 3.34 percent.
 
What Consumers Won't Get
 For some kinds of loans, however, consumers should not expect any change. Interest rates on most credit cards, for example, remain above 18 percent, despite a flurry of announcements by banks in recent months about lower interest rates for their best customers.
Still, about a third of all credit cards carry floating interest rates pegged to the prime rate and will fall in coming months. Similarly, interest rates will be falling on most of the more than $70 billion of home-equity loans at banks because they are linked to the prime.
While consumers and businesses may be slow to return to the spending and borrowing habits of the 1980's, bankers said the Fed's move was in the right direction.
Activity in the housing market, the part of the economy most sensitive to changes in interest rates, will benefit from lower rates. Rates on home mortgages fell Thursday, matching the falling yields on Treasury bonds, which are a benchmark for mortgage rates. Specialists in the mortgage market said they expected rates on long-term, fixed-rate mortgages will soon match the lows set in January of about 8.3 percent. The average rate last week was just under 8.5 percent.
Mr. Kovacevich, who said the Fed's moves had been too little, too late, acknowledged that the cumulative effect of past rate reductions had begun to bear fruit in the last few months. "We are starting to see some increase in lending, not the 5 or 7 percent we would like but still a lot better than the declines of the past few years."
 
No Upturn Perceived Yet
 In other parts of the country where the local economy is not so healthy as in Minnesota, bankers said the decline in business borrowing in the last two years appeared to be ending, but that there was not any strong upturn yet.
Even in New England, where complaints about tough bank examiners causing bankers to cut back on lending were widespread last year, some analysts see improvement. Richard Syron, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, noted last week that the region's economy was picking up, and with it, the health of local banks and their willingness to make new loans.
"It takes people a while to be convinced that the improvement is real, but each time there is another easing in interest rates it is one more affirmation that the environment is improving," said Newton Merrill, executive vice president in charge of business lending at the Bank of Boston.
While large corporate customers are still repaying bank loans with money raised in the stock or bond markets, he said loan demand from other companies has improved enough that loans at the bank are no longer declining as they were in 1990 and 1991. "We certainly have the capacity to lend more, but the customers have to become more confident about the future," Mr. Merrill said.
Because interest rates have fallen so low, some bankers wondered whether they would be able to pass on lower rates to their depositors. "With savings accounts in St. Louis at 3 percent to 3.5 percent, we are already at a level where it is psychologically difficult to go lower," said Phillip E. Peters, executive vice president at Boatmen's Bancshares, a St. Louis-based banking company.
To preserve ties with consumers who are dismayed at the low rates available on deposits, Mr. Peters and many other banks have been training staff and hiring outside companies to sell securities, particularly mutual funds.
One thing bankers say they are not doing is cutting lending standards in order to gain business. The memory of heavy loan losses in the last two years is still recent enough that they are preferring to stick with low-profit investments in Treasury securities rather than take a chance on a risky borrower who would pay a higher interest rate.
 
Somewhat Tougher Standards
 "Standards are a little tougher, but I don't think that has discouraged borrowers as much as the generally weak economic outlook," said Carlos E. Evans, an executive vice president in charge of lending for small and medium-sized companies at Nationsbank in Charlotte, N.C. Nationsbank has more invested in government securities than any other bank in the country, and is eager to replace those securities with loans to consumers or medium-sized businesses.
Noting some recent improvement in the economy, Mr. Evans said, "We have a noticeable increase in the number of customers talking with us about loans, though those talks have not yet led to increased lending."

HEADLINE: ...and Worry India in Strike Over Hefty Trucking Tariffs

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 3

 BODY:
Still struggling to invigorate and recast its old socialist economy, India has been hit with a trucking strike that threatens to bring virtually all commerce in this land of 843 million people to a halt.
India's 1.5 million trucks have been parked in truck stops, gas stations, fields and garages as their owners demand an end to arbitrary road taxes, transport fees and police extortion. 
 Already, on the third day of the strike, prices for vegetables, fruit and milk have soared, and the first signs of shortages are beginning to appear in markets in major cities, including here in the nation's capital. Industrial supplies for factories have been disrupted and fuel deliveries to gas stations have stopped. Sporadic panic buying was reported at some food markets in Delhi and in other cities.
 
Two-Thirds by Truck
 Nearly two-thirds of India's goods are transported by the brightly colored Tata brand trucks that hurtle along the country's narrow blacktop roads. A prolonged strike would seriously affect food supplies for India's cities and deal a sharp blow to the country's already fragile manufacturing base. Exports, which have been increasing slightly this year and are desperately needed to enhance the country's foreign exchange reserves, would also be hurt by a lengthy walkout.
After ignoring the work stoppage for the first two days, Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao today ordered all state transport ministers to the capital to try to resolve the work stoppage.
Chittranjan Dass, the secretary general of the All India Motor Transport Congress, an association that represents the truck owners, said he was prepared for a long strike.
"In the history of road transport, there has never been an all-India strike," he said as he sat in his chaotic office in Old Delhi. "The response I get from every part of the country is that unless they meet our demands, they will keep their trucks off the road. We have to be prepared for a long, drawn-out strike."
Chief among the truckers' grievances are the levying of tolls, tariffs and transport charges by states and localities. India, unlike the United States, has no ban on the imposition of local fees on interstate trade. Even at the borders of New Delhi, a territory under the authority of the central Government, fees are collected from truckers wishing to enter the city, a fee known as the octroi.
"We are losing on every trip," Mr. Dass said between shouts into his constantly ringing phone.
 At times, the line of trucks at the octroi checkpoints into New Delhi stretch for a half a mile as drivers wait to pay the fees necessary to deliver their goods to the capital. Today, the city's perimeter was sprinkled with thousands of idle trucks, their drivers sitting in small groups playing cards, sleeping, sipping tea.
Sugdev Singh, a burly, bearded man with an unruly plaid turban, lay under his truck reading a thick novel titled "The Goonda in Uniform," a Hindi potboiler about police officers who behave like criminals.
"The police always trouble us," he said. "They are always charging us more than the road tax. Sometimes they charge 50 rupees," about $1.80, "or 100 rupees. Sometimes more."
Another driver, Balwinder Singh, interrupted. "What do you mean?" he asked. "The police take 150 or 200 rupees."
The first Mr. Singh shrugged. "Just to cross into Delhi costs 500 rupees," he went on. "That is for toll tax and checking. The police shouldn't charge us money."
Late this evening, the Prime Minister's office announced that the octroi to enter Delhi was being abolished, an act intended "to give a lead to the states to take similar steps," according to the Press Trust of India.
India is in the middle of a wrenching transition from a centrally controlled socialist economy to one governed by market forces. Aided by substantial lending from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank over the last year, the country has made some progress in reorienting its economy, but it has yet to show significant signs of recovery.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Obtaining Money From 401(k) Plans

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
"HOW can I get at the money in my 401(k) plan?" A surprising number of people well below retirement age have asked that question in recent weeks, according to Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, a New York-based certified public accounting firm.
The first response is a question, he said. "Why do you need the money?" So is the second, "Do you have any other source of funds?" 
 That is because under I.R.S. regulations, withdrawals are limited to specified hardships. A 401(k) plan is an employer-sponsored, tax-deferred retirement savings plan, and once money is taken out, income taxes will be due, and generally a 10 percent penalty for people under age 59 1/2. For residents of New York and other high-tax states, that can mean half the money goes to pay Federal and state taxes, and penalties.
It also means that the money will not be there at retirement, when it is likely to be needed. Retirees with more than $20,000 of annual income relied on savings and investments for 39 percent of their income in 1990, according to Treasury figures, compared with 20 percent from Social Security and 15 percent from pensions. Yet, today's average 50-year-old has only $2,300 in financial assets or savings, not including equity in a house, Merrill Lynch reported last month in its fourth annual retirement planning survey.
Still, there are instances where current need justifies dipping into a 401(k) plan, Mr. Neumark said, and regulations issued by the Internal Revenue Service in August spelled out permissible hardship withdrawals. He cited two examples.
One client in his 30's wants to buy a house. Not only will it be a home for his family, but in today's market with both housing prices and mortgage interest rates well below the levels of recent years, it may be a smart move financially. So he is taking money from his 401(k) plan for the down payment. A home purchase can be a form of retirement savings, if it means the buyer will own a house outright by retirement, thereby eliminating an important expense then.
Another client has an emergency need for thousands of dollars worth of dental care, and is able to borrow the money from her 401(k) plan.
"You want to get the most money for the least tax," Mr. Neumark explained, "so the first alternative is a plan loan, if allowed." That also means she can repay the money so her retirement savings will be intact.
Under I.R.S. regulations, people may borrow up to $50,000 or 50 percent of their vested account balances in their 401(k) plans, whichever is less, but not all plans allow borrowing. Similarly, not all plans allow hardship withdrawals, even though they are permitted by the I.R.S. Therefore, he said, it is important for people to know what is permitted under their employer's plan before putting money in.
"On the one hand, I always encourage my clients to put as much money as they can into a 401(k) plan for retirement savings," Mr. Neumark said. Up to $8,728 may be put in this year, under I.R.S. rules. "On the other hand, if the client says, 'I intend to buy a house in two years,' " it is probably better to save outside the plan, he said.
The hardship withdrawals permitted under the I.R.S. regulations are: medical expenses for an employee or dependent; costs related to the purchase of a principal residence, excluding mortgage payments; payment of tuition and related educational fees for post-secondary education for the employee, spouse, children or other dependents, and payments necessary to prevent the employee's eviction from his or her principal residence or foreclosure on that residence.
A 401(k) plan may also allow for hardship distributions to employees with other immediate and heavy financial needs, provided the plan has nondiscriminatory and objective standards for determining the existence of a hardship, Mr. Neumark said. But that means the judgment of the plan administrator comes into play, so people should not count on using a 401(k) plan as a source of emergency cash.
Ideally, people should put money into conventional savings or investment accounts that they can tap for emergencies, as well as participate in 401(k) plans, especially in cases where the employer matches employee contributions in whole or in part. An employer match makes a 401(k) plan "one of the all-time great no-brainers ever," said John L. Steffens, executive vice president, Merrill Lynch private client.
"If someone at age 40 earning $60,000 a year invested $3,000 after-tax annually, that investment would grow to $200,000 at age 65," Mr. Steffens said. "If he were fortunate enough to have a 401(k) plan, where his company matched 50 percent of the employee's contribution, his pre-tax annual savings would grow to about $550,000 by age 65."
Those numbers show why a decision to take money out of a 401(k) plan is not to be made lightly. Still, in today's recessionary environment, particularly with tuition payments due and work-related relocations, it can be a safety net for some people who had the foresight in better times to put the money into the plan, Mr. Neumark said.

HEADLINE: Lebanon Journal;
When Times Get Tough, Town's Officials Get Boot

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEBANON, Me.

 BODY:
If times are tough in America and taxes are high, the angry residents of this small rural town have their own answer -- shut down the government.
Last year they voted to turn off the 100 street lights to save money. Then they elected to stop financing the town's five-member police department, after which there was a murder and a rash of burglaries. 
 They went a step further in June, voting 563 to 555 not to pay the salaries and expenses for much of Lebanon's town government for the fiscal year that began July 1.
Those dismissed included the town's governing body, the three selectmen; two code-enforcement officers who handle building permits; the registrar of voters; the ballot clerks, and the animal control officer. All are part-time jobs in this town of 4,281 residents, most of them blue-collar workers, spread over 57 square miles in southeast Maine.
The voters also refused to approve money for any road repair work or for a proposed Little League baseball field. The town will continue to pay for its part-time clerk, its volunteer fire department and its schools.
"We're not totally crazy or radical," said Roxanne Bumford, a mail deliverer who is chairman of the town planning board, an unpaid position.
The problem, as Mrs. Bumford sees it, is that with many residents being laid off from their factory jobs or forced to work a four-day week, people are frustrated. That brings out an old strain of Yankee frugality.
"People don't have money to spend, so they are mad about rising taxes," she said.
In fact, from 1985 to 1990, with New England's economy booming and real estate values soaring, property taxes in Maine rose an average of 76 percent, according to state figures. "But now industry is leaving, and it is leaving voids," Mrs. Bumford said.
What made residents more resentful, she said, was that much of the increase in taxes was forced by the state when it imposed a series of mandates on schools. One, for example, required particular ratios of teachers to students; another set minimum salaries for teachers.
Two other small towns in Maine also voted to eliminate their police forces last year as an economy measure, and some tiny communities, with less than 50 people, have voted to disband, or unincorporate. But Lebanon is the first town to vote not to finance its government, said Stephen Gove, a spokesman for the Maine Municipal Association, a private service organization for the state's municipalities.
Another problem in Lebanon was that the selectmen lumped many of the budget items into a general fund, not offering a breakdown. The question on the ballot referred simply to "$70,000 for governmental expenses, officers' salaries, etc."
"I looked at this and I said, '$70,000 is not a tremendous amount of money, but what's etc.?' " said Harvey Wallingford, a resident.
Because he wanted a better accounting of how his tax dollars were spent, he voted 'no,' but assuming the majority would vote 'yes,' he said.
Mr. Wallingford runs one of the few businesses here, a mobile-home park and sales agency. There are also three general stores and three used-automobile dealers. Lebanon has no industry or large commercial establishments, so residents bear virtually all the tax burden.
In 1990, as the economy turned sour, Mr. Wallingford opened a repossession lot, selling off property like campers, cars, trucks, boats and snowmobiles that had been reclaimed by local banks. Since then, several of the banks themselves have failed.
Gilbert Zinck, the chairman of the three selectmen, who are continuing their work as volunteers, acknowledged that they "kind of messed up" by not offering a fuller breakdown of spending. So they have tentatively scheduled another budget vote for August to give residents a second chance. This time the ballot will be broken down into several major items. "I really believe people will vote for it when they know what it is for," Mr. Zinck said.
When the new fiscal year began on July 1, much of the town's government stayed on voluntarily. One who did not was the animal control officer, who resigned, but now there is a volunteer in the job, David White.
The selectmen, though, reluctantly decided to lay off their secretary, who had been doing the job for 35 years. They are also having the telephone disconnected in their office at the elementary school. (There is no separate town hall; all other officers work out of their homes.)
If the next vote fails, Mr. Zinck said, he has only one solution: "Send donations."

"We're not totally crazy or radical," said Roxanne Bumford, a mail deliverer who is chairman of the town planning board, an unpaid position. But she said people's frustration had brought out an old strain of Yankee frugality. (Gary Guisinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: When the Carousel Comes Grinding to a Halt

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRISTOL, Conn.

 BODY:
Tranquillity has returned to the Lake Compounce Festival Park. The once nerve-jangling wooden roller coaster is still, the pop guns and barkers are silent in the Victorian arcade and even the paddleboat is gone from the lake, which reflects the forested hillside of nearby Southington Mountain.
The park gates are locked, with only a handful of guards patrolling this 146-year-old institution that had called itself America's longest continuously operating amusement park. And, despite intense efforts to revive it, Lake Compounce will remain closed this holiday weekend and for the foreseeable future. 
 The park, which to many here is a symbol of the quintessential pleasures of American summertime, could be called a fatality of bungee jumping, a victim of the trend that made amusement parks into action parks: high-hype, high-cost amalgams of ever-more-punishing upside-down roller coasters, endless lines, loud rock music and ersatz evocations of Main Street, U.S.A.
Lake Compounce's demise could also be seen as a result of trying to keep up with that trend, of failing to be true to its small-town traditions. In recent years, it added admission fees and heavy metal concerts to attractions like the carousel, with its bucolic New England scenes of autumn leaves and winter snowfalls, and the Showboat, which plied the lake on cool summer evenings.
Gerard Miclette, a Coventry, Conn., electric violinist, lamented last week that this would be the first summer since 1954 that his Cowboy Caravan Band would not perform at Lake Compounce. "It was a beautiful place to work," said Mr. Miclette. "We feel quite bad about it."
The victim of a tangle of management and financial problems, Lake Compounce has meant far more to area residents than just a day's diversion or a lift for the local economy.
"It's very sad that something like this has to go," said John Gorry of Newington, Conn. "I made a lot of friends there over the years and had a lot of enjoyable Sundays. It was a family-type park, not commercial like other amusement parks."
"From the very beginning, when the Norton family started it in the 1840's, Lake Compounce was a place that families would come for picnics and band concerts," said John J. Leone, Bristol's former mayor, who now heads the chamber of commerce of this central Connecticut community. "In the 20th century, they added carousels and rides, and in recent summers, they drew more than half a million people, making it the state's No. 2 draw after Mystic Seaport."
 
Big, Big, Big
 But in 1985, under financial pressure, the descendants of Lake Compounce's founder, Gad Norton, sold it to a gaggle of investors and promoters with visions of a big expansion, big concerts and big profits.
"The park was my heart and soul and body, but it was a decision we were forced to make," said J. Harwood Norton Jr., the great-grandson of the park's founder. The selling price was "over $1 million," Mr. Norton said.
"Small family parks' days are limited," said Mr. Norton, "and I didn't want it to go down the tubes."
The buyers, a consortium of local businessmen called Compounce Associates Limited Partnership, "turned around and brought the Hershey Corporation in to manage it, but Hershey liked what they saw so much that they bought a 70 percent stake," Mr. Harwood said.
The park's policy of charging no admission, allowing families to bring picnics and offering free country-music concerts was replaced with a $12.95 entrance fee and a ban on picnics, intended to pump up business for food concessions. The Ferris wheel and Showboat were replaced by a water flume and a pirate ship.
In 1988, Hershey sold its share to the Joseph Entertainment Group, a Wisconsin company owned by Joseph Balestrieri of Milwaukee.
The new owner built a 20,000-person-capacity outdoor amphitheater as a venue for performers ranging from Liza Minnelli to hard-rock groups like Megadeth, Slayer and Alice in Chains. Suddenly, the once-placid amusement park became the source of noise, traffic and a chorus of complaints from residents of Bristol and Southington, across the lake.
"The new owners ran the park in such a way that our patrons couldn't afford to come," Mr. Miclette said.
The park's fortunes and finances began to unravel last summer when Guns 'n' Roses canceled its performance after the check to pay the group bounced, said Gloria W. Schaffer, Connecticut's Commissioner of Consumer Protection. Mr. Balestrieri has yet to pay some $300,000 in refunds to ticket-holders, she added.
 
Trying to Salvage No. 147
 Mr. Balestrieri, whose company filed in court for protection from creditors last winter, owes more than $900,000 in 1991 state and local taxes, with "a new year's worth of taxes" that were due this week, said William T. Stortz, Bristol's Mayor. Because of the back taxes, the state has suspended Compounce Associates, which technically owns the park, from operating it, said A. J. Janschewitz, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Revenue Services.
Mr. Norton said that Mr. Balestrieri canceled 15 concerts last summer and owes ticket-buyers $1.5 million. An audit by Arthur Anderson & Company, the accounting firm, showed that Mr. Balestrieri's businesses lost $1.9 million, principally at Lake Compounce.
A last-ditch effort to open the park this summer -- engineered by a Vermont financial-consulting team -- failed last month, when a deal with the Nederlander Organization, the entertainment producers, fell through, and the last 12 full-time employees were dismissed, said Gary Klemyk, a guard. But state and town officials, as well as Mr. Norton, are trying to reopen the park for at least a weekend by Labor Day to be able to claim a 147th year of continuous operation.
"We're working hard to try to bring the parties together, and we are very slightly optimistic that we'll get the park open to maintain its record," said Joseph M. Cohen, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Economic Development.

HEADLINE: Deadlock In Albany;
Sour Finish Taints Productive Session

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 3

 BODY:
The enduring legacy of the 1992 session of the New York State Legislature may be that lawmakers, for the first time in eight years, did what they are legally required to do.
They passed a budget on time, or at least almost on time. It was approved on April 2, one day late, which by Albany standards is considered "close enough for government work," in the words of the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea . 
 There was hope that the timely passage of the $56 billion budget would free a newly cooperative Legislature to address the state's most serious problems for three months. But that hope dissolved in the final days of the session when more deals fell apart than came together.
For the last 17 years, when the Republicans have ruled the Senate and the Democrats have controlled the Assembly, the Legislature has often been paralyzed by institutional inertia. But the burden of bipartisan power-sharing was reinforced this year by a confluence of destructive and distracting forces.
It is not, after all, just any election year. Voters are surly enough to terrify even a Legislature with a 98 percent re-election rate. And redistricting, in addition to preoccupying lawmakers from the start of the session to its finish, left legislators nervous about how every vote would be received by new constituents.
"All of those things brought a new sense of caution," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "Particularly on fiscal issues, there was a heightened sensitivity."
 
Intraparty Challenges
 That explains to some degree the failure of the Senate to embrace Mr. Cuomo's proposals to put an $800 million bond act before the voters, to give the Thruway Authority new power to oversee construction projects,to bail out the deficit-laden governments of Nassau and Suffolk counties and to have the state assume local Medicaid costs. The Democratic Assembly backed Mr. Cuomo on each of those initiatives, as it usually does.
It is also significant that 8 of the 35 Republican senators already have opponents in their Sept. 15 primaries, an unusually high number. Some of the challengers are Republican assemblymen who were hurt by redistricting. Others are conservatives recruited by Change-N.Y., a new interest group that hopes to move the state Republican Party toward the right.
The intraparty challenges made many incumbent Republicans reluctant to give new power to a quasi-public authority, saddle the state with open-ended Medicaid costs, or vote for the bond act, which would have increased the state's indebtedness.
"The dominant issues of the 1992 session," observed Julian S. Palmer, the executive director of New York State Common Cause, "were redistricting and incumbent self-preservation."
Even the achievements of the session seemed a result more of political calculation than of noble purpose.
The budget was passed on time because legislators finally perceived that voters would no longer tolerate needless delays that encouraged Wall Street to downgrade the state's bond rating and that forced local governments to borrow money.
Even the most significant bill of the session -- a set of sweeping changes in the state's health insurance laws -- was passed only grudgingly by the Senate and largely because of an effective threat from Mr. Cuomo.
The Governor warned that the state Insurance Department would have to impose a large Blue Cross/ Blue Shield rate increase shortly before Election Day if the insurance changes were not approved.
Ultimately, the prospect of 2.5 million angry Blue Cross subscribers proved more intimidating to the Senate Republicans than the heavy lobbying against the bill by commercial insurance companies.
Mr. Cuomo's threat to raise insurance premiums was a rare instance in which the Governor could wield a club that actually scared the Senate Republicans.
He had suggested that he would veto the Legislature's redistricting plan if he did not get the election law changes he wanted, but did not follow through on the threat. His warning that he would campaign against the Republicans for rejecting his Medicaid proposal was met with ambivalence.
 
Governor No Threat
 Indeed, it has been years since Republican legislators have worried about the political influence of the Governor, whose approval ratings have fallen with the economy. Many boast in their campaign literature of the votes they have taken to oppose him.
Mr. Cuomo, meanwhile, has shown increasing frustration with Mr. Marino's passive leadership style. The Long Island Senator has deliberately delegated power to his subordinates, creating a decentralized Senate that often undermined Albany's strong leadership system and left negotiations deadlocked.
"If Marino was tougher, we would have had the agenda," Mr. Cuomo said today. "He's not able to go into his conference, take heads, knock them together and make a deal."
Mr. Marino, in turn, faulted the Governor and Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin for holding the Long Island bailout bill as a legislative hostage. As soon as the Legislature recessed, he reverted to the kind of regional appeal that has served the Republicans well over the years.
"It had been my hope that the Democrats would abandon their assault on Long Island," he said. "This is pure political blackmail."
As so often in Albany, it seemed that Legislative inertia was completely compatible with political expediency.

HEADLINE: Bailout Hopes Dashed In Nassau and Suffolk

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 3

 BODY:
Leaders of Nassau and Suffolk counties huddled in separate emergency meetings today, each faced with bankruptcy, huge layoffs and property tax increases after this morning's adjournment of the State Legislature without approval of deficit borrowing plans critical to the finances of both.
The Republican-controlled Senate voted to approve the multimillion-dollar bailout plans, but the Democratic-controlled Assembly, with backing from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, rejected the borrowing measures. The Democrats demanded that both counties agree to have financial control boards oversee their finances, which have been crippled by lower sales tax revenues and rising social welfare costs with the recession. 
 Leaders in the Senate and Assembly said today that a compromise could still be worked out, possibly by the end of next week, even though the Legislature officially adjourned for the summer. County officials said the legislators could be called back to Albany for a special session to reconsider the deficit borrowing measures along with Governor Cuomo's $800 million job-creation bond act, which the Republicans opposed.
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, said this afternoon that he had talked with Governor Cuomo for more than a half hour today, and also talked with leaders of the Senate and Assembly. Mr. Gulotta said he was "confident that when cooler heads prevail, our differences can be worked out."
 
A Call for Sanity
 "It's very clear that at the end of the legislative session, tempers flared on both sides and a number of major issues were not addressed," Mr. Gulotta said. "When calmer minds and reason prevail, we'll be able to resolve these matters."
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert Gaffney, a Republican, met for several hours today with top aides at his offices in Hauppauge, and said he, too, was "confident that state leaders would resolve this issue."
He said that action by the state was critical for the resolution of Suffolk's "significant cumulative deficit." Unlike Mr. Gulotta, Mr. Gaffney has said that he would accept some state oversight of county finances. Mr. Gulotta indicated today that he was also softening his position, saying that "it was an area that could be negotiated."
Both counties say that by October if not sooner, they will not have enough money to meet payroll and other expenses. Without relief, property owners in both counties face tax increases between 25 percent and 30 percent and a sharp reduction in police, road maintenance and other services.
 
'Drop Dead, Long Island'
 Nassau is seeking Albany's approval to borrow $100 million, which would be paid back with a one-percentage point increase in the county's mortgage recording tax. The borrowed money would help close an estimated $159 million deficit in the county's $1.8 billion budget.
Suffolk wants to borrow up to $91 million, to be paid back, in part, with a half-cent increase in the county sales tax, to 8.5 percent. It needs the money to help fill a $100 million gap in its current $1.3 billion budget.
"I'm really very much disturbed by the outcome," said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., who jousted loudly this morning during the final hours of the session with the Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat.
Senator Marino described Mr. Weprin's and the Governors' positions as "Drop dead, Long Island."
"I don't understand it," Mr. Marino said, calling the demand for oversight "totally unnecessary."
Governor Cuomo blamed Mr. Marino for the outcome and said he did not know whether a special session would be called.
"Mr. Marino left Albany and said he wasn't coming back," the Governor said.
Mr. Weprin, the Assembly Speaker, said the door was still open if an agreement could be reached.
The Nassau County Comptroller, Peter King, a Republican, said Albany Democrats were playing partisan politics to embarrass Mr. Gulotta and other Nassau Republicans. Mr. Gulotta is up for re-election next year.
Mr. King said that "if necessary, the county would go for some kind of a financial control board."
Benjamin Zwirn, a Democrat and Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, said he hoped the bailout proposal "was good and dead."
"The real issue is cutting government spending." he said. "The threat of a tax increase is just a scare tactic. The Republicans use it all the time to get their way."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Small Gains Are Posted For Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar gained about half a pfennig in a holiday-shortened domestic trading session yesterday as the market, cautious ahead of next week's Group of Seven summit meeting, mostly followed the cue from Europe, dealers said.
The stock and government bond markets in the United States were closed on the eve of the Fourth of July holiday. 
 Foreign exchange dealings in New York essentially ended at the close of the European market, dealers said.
Speculation that the Bank of England might cut interest rates, rumors that the Bank of Italy had suspended its foreign exchange trading and interventions by Italian and Spanish central banks had scant effect on the dollar's modest recovery, they said.
The dollar stood at 1.5180 German marks and 124.75 Japanese yen, up from Thursday's 1.5075 and 124.40 New York close.
With United States securities markets closed, European trading slowed to a crawl ahead of Monday's opening of the summit meeting.
But London shares made solid gains, driven higher by talk of a British interest rate cut.
Gold closed in London at $346 an ounce, 25 cents lower, while the price of crude oil rose 5 cents a barrel, to $20.80 for August delivery of North Sea Brent Blend, an international benchmark grade of oil.
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading London shares gained 21 points, to close at 2,497.1, despite statements by British officials quashing rumors of an imminent rate cut.
The Frankfurt market was dominated by news and speculation on the corporate front and saw wild price swings in individual stocks, which steered the market erratically to its highest close in two and a half weeks. The 30-share DAX index ended 8.37 points higher, at 1,776.98.
The Paris bourse was depressed by the French truck drivers' dispute and low activity as the holiday season gets under way. The CAC-40 index closed at 1,883.64, a gain of 10.12, but it still languishes around the lowest levels for several months.

HEADLINE: Artists Amid Urban Change: A Grimly Drawn Appraisal

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 3

 BODY:
An international gathering of some 200 public officials, artists and arts professionals last week received a bleak and at times apocalyptic view of life in American cities and the challenges facing artists in an often hostile environment.
"The Artist in the Changing City," a two-day conference organized by the London-based British American Arts Organization, was the latest effort in the association's six-year campaign to research, document and stimulate the use of the arts in urban regeneration. 
 Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate Gallery, opened the conference by calling on delegates and speakers to consider the part artists could play in reshaping cities and societies "in a form that feels comfortable, a form that exists beyond recessions." Artists, he said, contribute not just to the economic regeneration of a city, but "are involved in lifting hearts and minds beyond the day to day."
"They're involved in giving us, and indeed in embodying for us, spiritual and emotional values," he said.
 
Evoking the Los Angeles Riots
 In response, Peter Sellars, the opera and theater director, and Richard Sennett, professor of history and sociology at New York University, delivered impassioned speeches about their respective home towns, Los Angeles and New York.
Mr. Sellars, the iconoclastic director of the Los Angeles Arts Festival, responded to Mr. Serota's call in characteristically dramatic fashion.
"How is the city changing?" he began. "In Los Angeles, we burn it."
Addressing his largely white audience, which included delegates from all over Europe as well as from Australia and North America, Mr. Sellars spoke about the weeks leading up to the Los Angeles riots and the growing disenchantment, as he saw it, of Los Angeles blacks with the justice system.
The crisis, he maintained, is one of a lack of context: "Nobody has a way to talk to anybody." Democracy is a discussion, he said, and that is where artists come in because only they can "put a human face on the statistics."
Artists, Mr. Sellars said, should be at the center of society, keeping "alive a utopian vision," because society will not improve "if the people envisioning a better society are politicians." Important and good art is not about style, but content, he said, adding: "There is a lot of nice art out there that has almost nothing to say" and "a lot of people out there who have a lot to say, and about whom much must be said."
Mr. Sennett, who delivered the conference's keynote address, said that the discussion of the artist in the changing city seemed a particularly "painful subject for any New Yorker" because "in the last 15 to 20 years we have in our city seen a kind of crisis emerge in the place of artists." Mr. Sennett, a noted urban theorist, said that "money for the arts has gone more and more into the distribution of art and marketing of art, while money for artists has decreased." The "trade-off," he said, "has become such that many artists are forced for economic reasons to flee the city."
 
Creativity at Peril
 New Yorkers, he said, "are witnessing an evacuation of the center." And such an evacuation, he asserted, puts at peril the very creativity of artists.
Recalling his days as a student of behavioral psychology under B. F. Skinner, Mr. Sennett said that when studying the behavior of "hundreds of hamsters massed together," he had noticed that the hamsters became "involved in what's called scanning behavior, surveying a crowd to see what's happening."
Artists, he suggested, react in much the same fashion. In a complex environment like a city, they pay attention in a special way. For the artist, and especially for the modern artist, he said, crowding "prompts a sense that somehow disturbance exists in the environment which can only only be rectified by making objects." The "less disturbing, the more unified, the more readable" that environment is, he said, "the less stimulation there is" to make art.
To Joan Jeffri, director of the Research Center for Arts and Culture at Columbia University and another conference speaker, Mr. Sennett's argument was interesting, but not borne out by her 1989 study in which nearly 10,000 artists in two rural regions and eight cities, including New York, responded to questions about their living and working conditions.
According to the results, she said, artists are in fact a more stable population than most people think: 47 percent of those who responded to her survey, she said, had lived in their county of residence for more than 10 years. Two-thirds of the artists in Los Angeles, New York and Chicago had received art-related training in the areas or regions in which they were residing. And in Los Angeles and New York, about a quarter of the respondents were living in artist districts.
 
The Pull of the City
 Still, Ms. Jeffri said, much more could be done to improve the lot of the urban-based artist. Cultural activity and support systems that "in turn foster a network of peers" are, she said, "very compelling reasons for artists to live and work in cities." The availability of arts training, too, she said, "is a very strong magnet."
Buster Simpson, a Seattle artist attending the conference, echoed what seemed to be the prevailing view that artists had more than art to create in their cities.
"There's a lot of healing, socially and environmentally, that needs to go on out there," he said in an interview. "That is our mission. We don't make geegaws to be put into somebody's palace anymore. We don't make icons to be put into churches. We're communicating."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bad Economic News Forces Bush To Refocus Re-election Strategy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Shaken by an ominous jump in the unemployment rate, White House strategists said today that they were reassessing the assumption that an improving economy would revive President Bush's political standing before the November election. Instead, they said, they must focus their campaign more on social problems and character issues.
The change in emphasis had been under serious discussion since late last month, but it was propelled Thursday, when it was reported that the June unemployment rate had surged to 7.8 percent. The shift in strategy portends a tougher and possibly more negative re-election effort by Mr. Bush than he or his advisers had predicted.
 
Short on Confidence and Time
 Mr. Bush's re-election chairman, Robert M. Teeter, said today that the campaign was making only subtle changes in the campaign's overall strategy, which always included messages about social problems, "family values" and Mr. Bush's standing as a world leader. But the decision not to rely on good economic news for an autumn "kick" nevertheless removes an underpinning from the assumptions that Mr. Bush himself has carried into the race. 
 In interviews today, some campaign advisers insisted that they had not abandoned hope that an economic upturn would yet lift Mr. Bush from a record low point in popularity polls and counter a national uneasiness, at historic levels in some polls, that the country is seriously off course.
But the advisers' hope ebbed in recent weeks as declines in some important economic bellwethers, like new factory orders and purchases of new homes and durable goods, offset other signals of recovery.
Moreover, political strategists now realize that if the economy is indeed faltering again, any fiscal measures the Administration could take would not produce results in time to affect Mr. Bush's popularity.
 
Emphasis on Trust
 "Not many economists think anything we do at this stage would do anything by the election," a senior official who spoke on condition of anonymity said today. "All it would do is inoculate both us and Congress against the charge that we stood around and did nothing."
The Bush campaign still plans to keep economic concerns at the center of its strategy, Mr. Teeter said today. But with the economy no longer assured of helping the President, the campaign will now devote more money and energy to issues like crime, health care, education and drug abuse than it had previously planned. It will also spend more time portraying Mr. Bush as the most experienced and trustworthy of the three major Presidential candidates, perhaps the one area where he enjoys a sizable lead over Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Ross Perot.
In his 1988 victory, Mr. Bush erased a deficit in summertime polls partly by mounting attacks that caricatured his opponent, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, as a coddler of criminals who was dangerously inexperienced in military and foreign affairs.
The Bush campaign at least temporarily checked Mr. Perot's rising popularity among voters last month by raising questions about his personal stability and his respect for the law. Mr. Clinton has struggled since last winter to overcome voters' doubts about his personal integrity.
 
No More Ace in the Hole
 Polls taken by the Bush campaign, an official said today, indicate that voters believe Mr. Bush has the ability to address economic problems as he has foreign crises but that he is somehow disinterested and unwilling to do so.
Facing that perception, the campaign is likely to step up its efforts to blame Congress for the economic malaise and to stress the President's concern about other domestic problems.
Mr. Teeter has frequently said that economic growth alone would not insure the President's re-election in a year when voters are increasingly worried about the fraying of the nation's social fabric and the rise of economic superpowers like Japan and Germany. But both he and Mr. Bush have clearly regarded the economy as their ace in the hole in what the President now calls a "weird" campaign.
In an interview in March, Mr. Teeter described a re-election race without a visible recovery as a "worst-case scenario."
Mr. Bush has been even more explicit. "I think most people would concede that my problems stem from this sluggish, anemic economy," he said at a news conference on June 4. "Come fall, when we're out there taking our case to the people, with an improved economy behind us, I still feel confident about the outcome of the political election."
But qualms about that strategy have grown almost visibly among Mr. Bush's advisers as bad economic news began to smother the good. They burst open during a senior White House staff meeting on June 22, when the President's conservative economic adviser, Michael Boskin, argued that the recovery was much more frail than top White House officials believed.
Mr. Boskin's chief critic at that meeting was the White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner. But Mr. Skinner has now accepted Mr. Boskin's view that the economy will move too slowly to guarantee success in November, Bush advisers said today.
That fear was heightened Wednesday night when, as Mr. Skinner chatted in his West Wing office with Mr. Teeter and other top Bush officials, a bright red folder containing unemployment statistics to be released the next day arrived.
Mr. Skinner fell silent, opened the folder, read it and heaved a deep, audible sigh.
"You could tell it wasn't good news," one official said.

Bush Signs Jobless-Aid Bill

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- As promised, President Bush today signed a bill giving the unemployed up to a half-year of emergency benefits beyond their basic 26 weeks of coverage and making it easier for them to collect such extended benefits in future recessions.
The legislation, overwhelmingly passed by both houses of Congress on Thursday, was sent to Mr. Bush at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., where he was spending the holiday.
The provision for current emergency benefits is expected to help at least two million unemployed workers before it expires March 6, although people who have benefited from the two previous extensions enacted during the current recession are not eligible. And by allowing the states a liberalized formula for measuring joblessness, the new law will also make it more likely for the long-term unemployed to qualify for extended benefits in the future.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 5, 1992, Sunday

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the effect of unemployment on Bush campaign strategy described the advance delivery of the latest unemployment figures to the White House incorrectly in some copies. The confidential report was delivered by the Labor Department, not campaign officials.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Battle Over Securities-Fraud Cases

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
Slurping and grunting noises are rising from both piggish parties engaged in a heated debate over securities-fraud class actions.
In one pen, meet the hogs who pull such shenanigans as filing class actions against corporate managements within hours of a stock drop, sometimes on scant evidence that any fraud was committed. This group of lawyers and investors has resorted to paying bounties to stockbrokers who can supply names of investors harmed in such cases. The investors frequently settle for pennies on the dollar, raising the question of whether they were simply holding up management on a meritless case. A good case, some lawyers believe, would be taken farther and demand a higher settlement. 
 In the other pen, meet the have-your-cake-and-eat-it-too swine -- an assembly of corporate executives. Pass laws that would help stop the flood of securities-fraud litigation that hurts us, they argue, but don't mess with civil laws that can work on our behalf. Frivolous lawsuits -- when companies file them against each other, for instance -- are a "cost of doing business." But the cost becomes distasteful when investors are the plaintiffs.
A bill that would change the rules governing securities-fraud suits was introduced by Representative Billy Tauzin, Democrat of Louisiana, in January; in recent weeks, a Senate panel heard arguments on the sweeping changes suggested in the bill.
Pushing hard to make the bill popular is the Coalition to Eliminate Abusive Securities Suits, an unlikely combination of 430 members comprising the most upstanding citizens of Corporate America and some of its most notorious rogues. Indeed, the roster of Ceass (as in cease, get it?) arguably is a reflection of the merits of these fraud cases generally: It includes some fine outfits, ultimately exonerated in court, and at least as many who perhaps weren't sued enough.
To hear Ceass advocates tell it in the recent Senate hearings, the whims of ruthless investors and their lawyers are causing business to grind to a halt, as managements devote nearly all their time to addressing lawsuits. Making matters worse is what the lawsuit craze is doing to the capital-raising process, they say. The bill itself asserts that the suits are causing investment bankers to shy away from working with small companies trying to gain access to the public markets -- a curious claim at a time when initial public offerings are at a high.
In addition, the bill says, "such securities lawsuits impose additional costs on publicly traded companies, often force them into bankruptcy and create job losses within the economy." Asked to give an example of a publicly held company forced into bankruptcy in this way, one of Mr. Tauzin's staffers gave an answer that told much of what's wrong with the "abusive suit" debate -- citing Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting firm that went out of business.
That's curious on a couple of counts, not the least of which is that Laventhol wasn't a public company, but a private partnership. What's more, accounting firms are the constituency that's trying to frame the issues in the fraud suit debate. Key among items in HR417 -- the Tauzin bill -- is a radical proposal that would eliminate the legal notion of "joint and several" liability in class action cases that allege securities fraud. Currently, when a company loses a securities fraud case, "joint and several" liability mandates that the damages be absorbed by whatever defendants have not yet acquired a phony passport and absconded to a South Pacific island.
The reality of that is that large professional institutions like accounting firms that expect to be sticking around frequently pay a greater percentage of the damage freight than they may have been responsible for. Hard-liners respond that that's the way the law was deliberately framed, giving priority to the needs of plaintiffs who were wronged. A cost of doing business, as it were.
Accounting firms say the law should be changed so they only pay for the portion of the damages attributed to them. The current system "is not forcing accountability by people who screw up," said Mark Gittenstein, a lawyer who represents Ceass.
But the current debate isn't focusing on the problem, either. Joel Seligman, a law and securities professor at the University of Michigan Law School, called the current proposal a "foolish overkill resolution" that doesn't properly address the real problem: that a "totally innocent corporation can spend a fair amount of time producing documents" in the discovery process.
While the coalition of companies would say that all the bill's proposals in some way cut down on discovery by discouraging "abusive" suits, the "joint and several" issue is getting the most play from accounting industry advocates, who raised $12 million in March for lobbying efforts on the issue.
Mr. Seligman suggested that the problem of frivolous lawsuits can be addressed more aggressively by using existing laws. Indeed, judges already are sanctioning class-action lawyers under two civil rules that address abusive cases. As for the onerous cost of the discovery process, "I don't think it's solely a securities-fraud case issue," Mr. Seligman said. Better to pursue the crippling time and money spent on discovery in all civil cases than to focus on the fraud cases brought by investors, he said.
That proposal doesn't sit well with Mr. Tauzin, who said in an interview last week that this subset of lawsuits is having "a very negative kind of impact" on corporate entities while lawyers and investors exploit the bounty fees and other perks of class actions.
Mr. Tauzin, for one, should know a little about bounties and perks, according to an analysis published June 21 in Accounting Today. Having received $50,000 in political contributions from accounting firms last year, he was the single biggest recipient in Congress of the industry's largesse.
