HEADLINE: Finding a Lifeboat in a Flood of Asbestos Litigation

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: GRANVILLE, Ohio

 BODY:
WHEN a company faces tens of thousands of lawsuits, nurturing innovative ways to control legal costs can be as crucial to survival as creating new products. Recognizing that, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, a defendant in about 85,000 asbestos cases, has become a pacesetter among the many businesses moving to limit legal expenses.
From their base at the company's research and development campus here, some 30 miles east of Columbus, Ohio, Owens-Corning's asbestos litigation managers have pared the number of outside defense firms they use to just 7, from 60 in 1988. That gives the company increased leverage in price negotiations because each firm now has a bigger share of the business and more incentive to do what Owens wants to keep it. 
 The company has also demanded that law firms shift work from expensive partners and associates to paralegals who operate under the firms' names but are trained and managed by Owens-Corning. Most strikingly, it has instituted a work order system that takes out of the hands of its litigators many decisions about when and how to prepare for trials. Instead, the decisions fall to those issuing the work orders, who in routine matters are the paralegals.
The problem with the old way of doing business, according to Owens executives, is that lawyers do too much work on cases that are likely to be settled and often do it so early in the process that files must be reviewed and updated later, adding unnecessary costs.
The new system is "responsive to the needs and desires of the client rather than the instincts of lawyers," said Louis F. (Ted) Rodewig, the former Booz-Allen management consultant Owens-Corning retained in 1990 to study the asbestos issue. Last year, only months after Glen H. Hiner took over as Owens-Corning's chief executive, Mr. Hiner recruited Mr. Rodewig to move here and run the system that Mr. Rodewig helped design.
The new rules of the game often call to mind the rise of managed care plans in medicine that have been chipping away at the professional freedom and income of many doctors. Just as physicians are bristling at the restrictions of managed care, some lawyers say that limits on their freedom can backfire.
Still, given the nationwide drive by business to control legal costs of all sorts, the Owens-Corning program could be adapted by many corporate law departments. While the asbestos quagmire is an extreme case, legal experts say there are plenty of other corners of the law where companies deal repeatedly with complaints that have a great deal in common. For instance, they say, car manufacturers, oil companies and others with large chains of dealers often wind up in court in contractual disputes that follow predictable patterns.
Owens-Corning executives are betting that their litigation management strategy should keep the company from ending up among the scores of asbestos manufacturers that have followed the former Johns-Manville Corporation, the industry leader, into bankruptcy. Owens's litigation costs are currently covered by the company's insurance, which stood at $675 million at the end of last year. Behind that is a $950 million reserve fund the company has set aside from earnings.
A manufacturer of glass-fiber insulation and construction materials, Owens-Corning had net income last year of $73 million on sales of $2.88 billion. Its asbestos problems stem from insulation products it sold from 1953 to 1974.
Owens believes the new system has helped reduce the amount it pays on plaintiffs' claims, which were resolved at an average of under $10,000 last year, down from more than $12,000 in the mid-1980's. But Owens points out that future plaintiffs could benefit from the company's effort to avoid bankruptcy, which will preserve the company's ability to deal with their claims.
Owens added tens of millions of dollars annually to its legal expenses over the past five years to set up the new system. Total spending related to asbestos peaked at $175 million in 1991. This year, with its heavy computer and research investments behind it, Owens has budgeted just $55 million for expenses and expects actual costs to be even lower, said William W. Colville, the company's corporate counsel.
THESE costs do not include payments to plaintiffs whose claims of injury from exposure to the company's asbestos products have been resolved. Owens had resolved more than 101,000 cases by the end of last year and had 85,000 pending. Although cases continue to be filed at an accelerating rate, Owens has been able to dispose of them even faster, reducing the overall caseload.
There is no longer any dispute that asbestos can cause cancer and lung disease. Instead, the suits turn on the questions of whether a particular plaintiff's illness or death was actually caused by asbestos and which company's products the plaintiff was exposed to.
Owens-Corning's take-charge posture stems from its conclusion that a decade of experience with asbestos litigation has left it in a pretty good position to judge which cases are likely to end up in the small group that actually go to trial and how much it is willing to invest in preparing the rest for settlement. When a case is headed for trial, the company strives to make sure that detailed evidence on subjects like the claimant's medical condition is assembled close enough to the trial date that the job is done only once.
MR. COLVILLE said that the innovations are mostly the common sense results of stripping away the shroud of mystery that lawyers tend to wrap around their work and simply analyzing the tasks involved, much the same way that an airline would break down the elements of baggage handling. He likens the result to just-in-time manufacturing.
In the Owens-Corning system, paralegals at seven regional centers are trained to prepare responses to most pretrial motions, which they send to local attorneys for filing. The company's team of trial lawyers may learn only a few days in advance which cases they will be trying the following week and sometimes see the particular files only the day before. Owens-Corning lawyers liken the litigators' role to that of a top heart surgeon who has others do most of the preparations and may not even meet the patient until shortly before the surgery is to begin.
There are risks. Relying on paralegals to screen new filings, for example, may occasionally lead to missing out on a chance to bring a co-defendant into the case or to present an unusual defense, said Jack B. Manning, whose Houston-based firm of Bean & Manning is Owens-Corning's regional coordinator for eight Southwestern states. He recalled one instance in 1991 in which a change in schedule was not noted in the centralized electronic files that all lawyers involved in the cases use. That led to a failure to issue a work order for sending a list of witnesses to a plaintiff by the required date. Barred by the lapse from presenting most of its case, Owens paid a premium to settle.
On balance, though, Mr. Colville has been so pleased with the changes that some of them, like work orders, are being applied to other legal problems Owens faces. "We want to be able to specify what's to be done and who's to do it," he said.
Plenty of other asbestos defendants have also made huge strides in case management. The Center for Claims Resolution, which coordinates the defense efforts in 60,000 cases involving 20 companies, says it has reduced the number of law firms it deals with to 22, from 60, and cut spending 50 percent since 1988. Companies assisted by the center, which is based in Princeton, N.J., range from small contractors to major defendants like the GAF Corporation and Armstrong World Industries.
The Keene Corporation, an asbestos defendant that used to be a member of the center but now operates on its own, says it cut costs by 40 percent from mid-1990 through the end of last year. This year, it says, it is on track to lop off another 30 percent.
"When we looked at it in 1990, 30 to 40 percent of the work took too long or was being done by someone too qualified," said Stuart Rickerson, general counsel for Keene, which is based in New York. "Now, we are under 2 percent in both categories."
These other defendants do not use work orders, nor do they rely as heavily on trained paralegals as Owens-Corning. But the directives they have laid down and the strict, frequently re-evaluated budgets they develop with outside firms have a similar impact.
SIMILAR trends are occurring outside the asbestos field. The General Electric Company, for example, has imposed a strict budgeting process on any outside legal job likely to cost $25,000 or more, requiring agreement on the tasks to be done and how they will be staffed.
"I can't recall a single case in the two years we have been doing it where the company has been hurt by vetoing something a law firm wanted to do," said Sally King, manager of litigation services at G.E. "We almost always end up in complete agreement on what to do after negotiating. There has to be an open line of communication."
In practice, even Owens-Corning's relationships with its lawyers are less regimented than they sound. Attorneys in the field and litigators do make recommendations about what pretrial work should be done, how long it should take and how much it should cost. Once Owens sets policy in weekly review meetings coordinated here or in special conferences, it relies heavily on its regional law firms to execute it. Not surprisingly, firms that have adapted to the system speak highly of it.
"THIS is the wave of the future," said Robert E. Wagner, a partner at the Detroit firm of Kitch, Saubier, Drutchas, Wagner & Kenney. "You can expand your law practice by showing other clients you can do this."
Still, the declining deference to the judgment of outside lawyers is more likely to be grudgingly accepted than enthusiastically embraced by most lawyers. The end of the go-go 1980's left corporate law firms around the nation scrambling for new work.
"Law firms are going along because they have no choice," said Douglas Young, a partner at the Economic Analysis Group Ltd., a Washington-based firm that conducts an annual survey of cost-containment measures employed by corporate legal departments.
Even some leading corporate lawyers are skeptical about the trend. "The very best lawyers are not going to put up with attempts to control their professional service," said Harry Pearce, general counsel for the General Motors Corporation. "We are not going to manage law firms, because we want them to be creative."
G.M. has sought to reduce its costs by paring the number of outside law firms it uses from nearly 800 in the late 1980's to just over 300. It also installed a computer system to monitor how each firm spends its time and money, and it lets each of them know how it stacks up against the competition, without revealing names.
"We tell them that those who get the best results the most efficiently will get the most work," said Mr. Pearce, a former litigator. "I've never found a more powerful motivator and we don't end up spending so much administrative time managing budgets."
Yet even Mr. Pearce concedes that there can be good reasons for companies like Owens-Corning to go to unusual lengths to tailor outside legal work to their business needs.
"There is a tendency for lawyers to be myopic," he said. "God knows there need to be some limits."
 
 
200,000 CASES AND COUNTING
 ASBESTOS is among the most versatile of all minerals, combining insulation value, flame resistance, flexibility and durability. Manufacturers built thousands of products as diverse as brake linings, movie theater curtains, toasters and pipe insulation from it. But tens of thousands of workers who inhaled tiny asbestos fibers, and in some cases those who handled their clothes or were otherwise exposed, have developed cancers and lung diseases.
The health risks were suspected for decades but it was not until the mid-1960's that public scientific studies began to accumulate, in part because asbestos diseases often take decades to develop.
Lawsuits against asbestos manufacturers and installers mushroomed during the 1980's. The cases involved not just personal injuries but also the declining value of buildings containing asbestos and the costs of removal. Few people have been as heavily exposed as World War II shipyard workers, who were the majority of the early claimants. About half of the more than 200,000 claims to date have been resolved. Experts say hundreds of thousands of new claims are likely to be filed in the years to come.
The most dramatic legal development in the asbestos saga was the 1982 bankruptcy filing of the Johns-Manville Company, the industry pioneer and giant. The filing put a stop to new suits involving the company while it was in Chapter 11. (Now that it has emerged, plaintiffs still can't sue the company, now known as the Manville Corporation, but can bring claims against two funds set up during the bankruptcy reorganization.)
The 1982 filing set off a mad rush among plaintiffs' attorneys to find other "deep pocket" defendants.
"It's amazing how many people suddenly remembered that they had worked with Kaylo," said William W. Colville, Owens-Corning's general counsel, referring to his company's branded asbestos product, which it stopped selling in 1974.

HEADLINE: Czechs Gear Up to Resume Weapons Exports

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
REVERSING a policy of Vaclav Havel to end arms exports, the Czech Government has announced that it will reactivate its industry and sell weapons abroad.
Mr. Havel's pledge, made when he became President after the collapse of Communism in 1989, was described by officials here as naive and costly at a time of economic difficulties. "Other countries are trying to fill our former markets and we have factory capacity that is not being fully used," said Pavel Slejskal, director of engineering in the Ministry of Trade and Industry. "Western countries as well as other Central European countries are taking our place in the market." 
 The move comes as several countries in Eastern Europe discover that converting big weapons factories into other kinds of production is prohibitively expensive. This is especially so because financial assistance for conversion that was expected to come from the West has not materialized.
When Mr. Havel made his promise, he was President of Czechoslovakia. In January, the country split into the Czech Republic and Slovakia. Much of the heavy weaponry, like the tanks and missiles that are of most concern to Washington, was made in Slovak factories. Those factories have have suffered a far steeper decline than the Czech plants, which also produce some heavy-duty weaponry but are launching a counteroffensive.
The State Department, knowing the Czechs were contemplating reviving their arms industry, sent a delegation here in March to tell the Czechs what countries are on Washington's arms-export-embargo list. When members of the American delegation talked with the Czechs they were satisfied that the Prague Government, unlike others in Eastern Europe, was in reasonable control of decisions on where arms would be exported, American officials said.
They said the Czechs would probably even pass the eligibility requirements for receiving some American military-technology assistance in upgrading their weaponry. In order to receive this help, the Czechs will have to pledge not to export the technology or weapons made from it to countries unfriendly to Washington. So far, the Czechs have not formally applied for the technological assistance, an American official said.
WASHINGTON did not absolutely discourage the Czech plans from reactivating the arms industry, American officials said. This was partly because the Czech Republic wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and the Czech argument that it must make the army's weaponry compatible with NATO's was considered valid, the officials said.
But at the same time, there were concerns, they said, that the Czechs might find it hard to keep their promise not to sell to countries under embargo. The Czechs have already had preliminary contacts with Iran, one American official said. And the arms companies, eager for business, could sell arms to Serbs
Mr. Havel, whose political profile has been overshadowed by that of his Prime Minister, Vaclav Klaus, has made no public statements on the change in policy.
American officials said the decision to reverse the policy was made by the cabinet. They pointed out that since the split of Czechoslovakia, Mr. Havel has become a figurehead statesman, with no power to make policy.
More than a dozen Czech weapons producers announced on June 11 that they would form a consortium, the RDP Group, to design, produce and market Czech military-industry products. The head of the group, which is expected to grow to 30 companies, is Lubomir Soudek, general director of Skoda Pilsen, one of the republic's biggest arms manufacturers.
"President Havel is a man of high moral principles," he said. "But the world is not moral. If it were moral, there would be neither arming nor re-arming."
THE Minister of Trade and Industry, Vladimir Dlouhy, was quoted here last month as saying that Mr. Havel's arms policies were "naive" and that they had been pushed upon the country by hypocritical Western powers. "They preached to us to drink water while they themselves were drinking wine," Mr. Dlouhy said. "Armaments are a commodity and Czech weapons have a good reputation worldwide."
The first focus of the new consortium will be improvements for the Soviet-designed T-72 tank, which in its current pre-1989 version is obsolete, Czech officials said. The new consortium will fit the tanks now in stock with a modernized engine, transmission and night-vision capability, making the machine more competitive on the international market.
The industry minister said he was drafting a new law regulating Czech arms exports to be presented to Parliament before the end of the year. It stipulates that the Industry Ministry will be in charge of licensing arms for export and the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Interior and Defense would have a right of veto, he said.
Mr. Dlouhy said he wanted a senior Government official to sit on the board of the new arms consortium. The new regulations, he added, would make it easier for the companies to sell weapons legitimately.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 27 - July 2

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
One Swallow Can Be Ignored; a Flock of Them Can't 

Yes, month-to-month figures mean little -- any number of odd events can jostle them. Yes, it's the long term that counts. But when the arrows head relentlessly downward, they just can't be ignored. And last week it was down, down and down again. Here's just a sampling: even with bargain-basement mortgage rates, new-home sales took their biggest plunge in 13 years, erasing a big April gain. And if the ever-fickle consumer can be believed, there's worse to come, as consumer confidence, which soared in the post-election months, dropped perilously close to its feeble October level. What's to blame? Uncertainty has to be a factor. Tax increases and health care reform are on everyone's lips, but no one knows how the script will play out after the folks in Washington finish their horse-trading. When people feel uneasy, they snap their wallets shut. And the economy stalls.

No Comfort in the Job Numbers
 
Last week's job data provided no exception to the gloomy economic news, as June unemployment climbed right back to 7 percent after a brief visit at 6.9. And the underlying figures were discouraging -- a loss of 53,000 manufacturing jobs and a scant 13,000 rise in payroll jobs. Bob Dole, as usual, couldn't wait to make political hay from this scorched field, saying that with tax increases looming, "employers are scared to death, so they're simply not hiring." But the White House, in the person of Laura D'Andrea Tyson, economic adviser, countered that the job-stimulus bill the Republicans hacked to death would have been felt by now. And in any case, she said, nearly a million new jobs have been created this year.
 
Tim-ber! Watch for Falling Jobs!
 
What's most important -- jobs, trees or owls? The answer isn't easy. Typically, Bill Clinton is trying to serve all three masters, and he has everyone angry. Environmentalists want to protect ancient forests in the Northwest, and the northern spotted owls that live there, while loggers warn that if trees aren't being lopped off, their livelihoods will be. So last week Mr. Clinton proposed a compromise, with limits on logging balanced by $1.2 billion for economic development and helping displaced loggers. But the timber industry said the cuts were too deep -- they do represent a drastic change in the way public forests are managed -- while environmentalists said loopholes would allow too much cutting. At press time, the owls had yet to comment.
 
'Violent Content'? Bring It On
 
"Due to some violent content, parental discretion advised." What do those eight little words say to a 10-year-old grazing across the channels? Simple. They say, Drop your Nintendo, forget your homework, get your buddies, and watch this! A watchful parent should switch off the set? Right. Mom's stuck at the office, Dad's doing the laundry, the coast is clear. But that warning is what the four commercial broadcast networks came up with last week to try to head off criticism of the increasing violence on television. Some critics want more -- curbs on the violence, ratings, perhaps a way to block out some shows. Not likely; lobbyists are out in force. "We cannot allow broadcast television to become barren of dramatic excitement," the networks said. Farewell, subtlety. There used to be drama in a raised eyebrow, a piercing look. Now, it seems, it can be found only in a raised knife, a piercing bullet.
 
He Caressed the Modem . . .
 
Humans have eight years left: In 2001, computers complete their takeover, rendering us obsolete. Don't believe it? Listen to this. Last week, a steamy novel came out that was written partly by a computer named Hal -- surely a cousin of the "2001" star. It seems that Scott French, Hal's "co-author," delved into Jacqueline Susann's masterworks, broke the digital code that dictates exactly when hearts leap and pants drop, and programmed Hal to churn out a hot romance. It took eight years, but he and Hal did it, calling the book "Just This Once." And the Dead Jackie Susann Quarterly (yes, there is such a publication) decreed that it had just the right mix: "money, sleaze, disease, death, oral sex, tragedy and the good girl gone bad." Surely, by 2001, Hal can perfect his (her? its?) craft, and discard the mortal co-author, stripping humans of one of the last things they can do better than machines. Time to pack it in.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Germany Meets Critics Halfway
 
Germany tried to keep interest rates high to ward off demon inflation, but outsiders were impatient. Typical were remarks by President Clinton, who called for lower rates "so that all of us together can expand this economy." But Germany has been giving in -- gradually, giving out crumbs of rate cuts every month or so. Last week, perhaps to head off criticism at this week's meeting of leading nations, it dropped rates again, to 6.75 percent for its discount rate and 8.25 percent for the Lombard rate -- a move one German economist called "more of a middle policy."
 
Setback for the Trade Pact
 
When the United States, Canada and Mexico came up with their North American Free Trade Agreement, environmentalists said: Wait a second! What about air and water pollution in border areas if industry flocks to Mexico? What about pesticides in imported food? Unsatisfied with the answers, three environmental groups took this lament to court, and last week a Federal judge said they had a point. The judge ordered the Government to prepare an environmental impact statement -- which could take six months -- probably delaying and maybe even killing the pact. This setback for the Administration may have a silver lining, though, because Congressional support for the pact was shaky anyway, and President Clinton may thus avoid another nasty battle.
 
Learning the Rules in Japan
 
In the board room, east isn't meeting west quite yet. American pension funds, feeling their oats after pushing some directors around back home, tried their stuff in Japan. But the Japanese do things their way: they have their annual meetings all at once, making it impossible for a troublemaker to attend more than one, and they brook little dissent. It's a clubby affair, with a lot of reciprocal back-scratching. Enter Calpers, the mighty California retirement system, which has about $5 billion worth of Japanese stock. Wanting to have a say, Calpers cast a number of "nay" votes last week, but when the votes were counted, management resolutions somehow passed unanimously.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Where's the Bottom at Empire?
 
At some point things have to hit bottom at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, where, amazingly, each wave of news is worse than the last. Last week would be hard to top, though: at a Senate hearing, the insurer's chief auditor testified that she couldn't get straight answers from the chief financial officer about discrepancies in the books -- even as the ousted chairman, Albert Cardone, testified that there never were two sets of books. But there was a ray of hope, when Empire picked a new chairman and chief, Philip Briggs, formerly of Metropolitan Life. Mr. Briggs brought understatement to new heights by describing Empire as "a little disorganized," but, for a change, he has experience at a for-profit insurer. That can't hurt.
 
A Kinder Refrigerator
 
Here's one way to get companies to make things that are kinder to the planet: drop the stick, try something more edible. In a contest referred to as "the golden carrot," a group of utilities offered $30 million for the best refrigerator design that saves both energy and the ozone layer. This is no small matter, for refrigerators account for fully 20 percent of household electric bills, and their CFC's eat away at the ozone. The carrot worked, for Whirlpool came up with a model that uses 25 percent less energy and has no CFC's, and last week it took the prize. And because the prize money will offset some startup costs, the new refrigerators, due early next year, will cost about the same as current models.
 
Benefits for Gays at HBO
 
Gay workers edged closer to the mainstream last week when HBO, joining a growing list of companies, offered health benefits to same-sex partners. But it's not true equality; the I.R.S. doesn't recognize such couples, so part of what HBO gives, the taxperson takes away.
 
Outsider to Run Westinghouse
 
Again, the corporate ladder is not as orderly as it used to be, as newly bold directors cast their net far and wide to pick a boss. After Paul Lego resigned at Westinghouse, Gary Clark filled in as acting chief executive, but directors kept searching outside. Only last week, nearly half a year later, did they find their man: Michael H. Jordan, with a long stint at Pepsico on his resume.
 
Now It's Murdoch vs. the Unions
 
The choice was coming down to this: a New York Post owned by Rupert Murdoch, or no New York Post. No one else seemed willing to pour millions into this especially leaky bucket -- at least no one who didn't appall the Post staff (or have you forgotten Abe Hirschfeld?) -- and Mr. Murdoch was about to pull the plug. So last week the F.C.C. granted Mr. Murdoch a waiver to let him own a newspaper and television station in a single market. The F.C.C. insisted it was setting no precedent. It's a one-time-only bow to "the overwhelming body of responsible public opinion," said James H. Quello, the acting chairman. But before he can make the purchase, Mr. Murdoch must still get union opinion on his side -- and that'll be tough. His latest threat: if there's no contract by July 9, no more Post.

HEADLINE: Germany's Push to Expand The Scope of Recycling

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN

DATELINE: LANDSHUT, Germany

 BODY:
IN a warehouse on the outskirts of this tidy Bavarian town, several new BMW sedans are being stripped. Motors, wheels and doors have been removed, windows smashed, seats slashed, dashboards torn out. But what looks like some Teutonic chop-shop actually belongs to BMW itself, a laboratory for finding ways to recycle the raw materials in cars that have traveled their last mile.
If the German Government has its way such "disassembly plants" will become commonplace. In an extremely controversial move, the German parliament is expected to pass by year's end a bill requiring most manufacturers to take back and recycle their products once their service life ends. That revolutionary step -- no other country has even remotely similar legislation -- would cement Germany's status as the world's leading proponent of mandatory recycling. 
 For Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition Government, approval of the bill would be a giant stride toward fulfilling its goal of transforming the nation's economy into almost a closed loop, where waste creation is minimized in favor of maximal re-use of resources. Because Germany is the dominant force in the 12-nation European Community's tightly knit economy, the legislation could become the de facto model for harmonizing its recycling regulations.
Germany began moving toward a "circulatory economy" last year, when it became the first nation to require business and industry to collect and recycle all packaging -- the bottles, cans, cardboard, paper and plastic that contained everything from toothpaste to refrigerators. Those regulations call for an average of 80 percent of packaging materials to be recycled by mid-1995.
The packaging regulations have been imitated by other countries. France and Austria have already adopted slightly modified versions of the German law and the United States and Japan, among others, have shown interest.
But financial, logistical and technical problems have hindered the implementation of the German packaging law -- and cast serious doubts on the timing and economic viability of going a step further to recycle products themselves. Duales System Deutschland, the private company set up to collect, sort and pass packaging on to recyclers, is operating deeply in the red. And because of severely limited recycling capacity the company has been forced to store 70,000 tons of plastic containers. Because of the capacity shortage, Germany has also become Europe's leading trash exporter, shipping plastic and other wastes abroad to be recycled or burned.
Despite the problems, the Kohl administration is forging ahead. The initial draft of the product-recycling legislation was approved by the cabinet last spring. It was deliberately written in general terms to give German industry a chance to respond. The proposed regulations call for companies to collect products and recycle as many components as possible, beginning in 1995. They also require manufacturers to prove a component cannot be re-used before it can be discarded. Manufacturers from the United States and other nations that sell in Germany would be forced to comply as well.
Environment Minister Klaus Topfer sees product recycling as an ecological breakthrough and his ministry is negotiating the specifics of the bill with representatives of German industry in an effort to make it as palatable as possible. Sticking points remain, like the Government's insistence that auto makers take back their cars free. But both sides think the parliament will vote on the law this fall, and approval is widely expected.
Whether Germany's recycling initiative represents the most effective and economical way to manage the world's increasing glut of household and industrial waste is a subject of heated debate at home and abroad.
THE Bonn Government claims the packaging- and product-recycling laws force industry to rethink the way it manufactures products, prompting companies to avoid nonvital components and materials that cannot be recycled. German officials say a product-recycling law is needed now because the nation is facing a trash crisis. With a population of 81 million, Germany is Europe's largest waste producer, and its large landfills will be filled within 10 years, said Clemens Stroetmann, the State Secretary in the Environment Ministry.
"We know a circulatory economy is not 100 percent possible; we have not discovered a perpetual motion machine," Mr. Stroetmann said. "But it is indisputable that this is a sensible idea. Germany has no more room for landfills and almost no natural resources left, so we need the increasingly precious resources we have."
Critics, including the powerful German Industry Federation, the umbrella group for the nation's companies, have described the law's intent as "recycling at all costs." They challenge its logic and argue that with Germany's economy in its most severe recession since the end of World War II, the move is ill timed. The notion of a circulatory economy is dismissed as a utopian dream that will expand Germany's already formidable bureaucracy and prove phenomenally costly, pushing small companies with slim profit margins out of business.
MOST companies will probably try to pass their recycling costs on to the consumer, which could erode Germany's competitiveness by raising its already high product prices. The German Government is also being attacked for taking too narrow a view of waste management in emphasizing recycling rather than a broader mix of solutions, including incineration.
"We would like to see them allow more incineration," said Horst-Henning Wolf, the head of the vehicle recycling project at Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., the maker of BMW cars and motorcycles. He is also one of two chief negotiatiors for the German auto industry. "Things like composite materials and some plastics cannot be recycled because of technical problems or prohibitive costs. But we could burn them safely, generating energy and heat."
Germany does appear to be shifting away from its rules forbidding incineration of many kinds of wastes both domestic and industrial. The Environment Ministry says it will soon introduce legislation that would soften the impact of the product-recycling law by allowing incineration of such wastes if recycling proves too expensive.
Mr. Wolf concedes that the stakes are high for the car makers and suppliers that account for one in seven German jobs. The car makers' costs are already among the highest in the world. If German manufacturers are forced to take back old vehicles free of charge, as the Government insists, "we will factor that into the price of the car," Mr. Wolf said. "There is no such thing as free of charge. Someone always pays."
Like companies across Germany, BMW has begun learning how best to take apart and recycle its products and how to build them to make their dismantling easier.
The disassembly plant here can dismantle 25 cars a day. Currently about four-fifths of the parts in the cars of BMW's low-end "3 series" can be reutilized in some form. Two-person teams dismantle each car, beginning by draining all fluids and oils. Glass from the windows is removed and sold to glass companies, which use it to make bottles. Engines, rear-axle differentials, transmission housings and alternators are reconditioned and sold as high-quality spare parts under warranty from BMW. The plastic bumpers are melted and turned into interior wall panels on new BMW's. Catalytic converters are reconditioned and re-used. Recovered seat covers and polyurethane foam are used as a sound-deadening material for the floor in the 3 series.
Munich-based BMW moved quickly to begin setting up recycling centers here and in other cities across Germany, and expects to complete the network by 1995. It also oversees three such plants in the United States -- in the Bronx (Hunts Point Auto Parts at 1480 Sheridan Expressway), Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla. BMW owners can exchange their cars for a $500 voucher toward purchase of a new or dealer-certified used BMW.
"There is no point in trying to fight the product recycling law," Mr. Wolf said. "There is strong public support for recycling and we knew this law was coming."
But, he added, "the key is that it be economically feasible, that it be attuned to the free market. If it is not, then it is going to limit our competitiveness, and that will not help anyone."
 
A COSTLY MODEL FOR AMERICANS?
 AMERICAN critics of Germany's bold push into recycling could scarcely contain their glee when Duales System Deutschland, the private company set up to collect and recycle packaging, announced recently that it was operating at an annual loss of up to $300 million.
Opponents of the German recycling program quickly branded it a failure and suggested that Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, may want to revise his plan to introduce packaging-recycling legislation based on Germany's law.
That may be premature. The Duales System, which serves 96 percent of German households, finances itself by charging producers a fee on each type of packaging material; paying the fee allows them to put a symbol known as the Green Dot on the package indicating their participation in the program. The fees have not been sufficient to cover costs. But beginning in October, the company will charge more for collecting and separating packaging materials -- from 4.5 cents per pound of glass to 74 cents for plastics.
Ines Siegler, a spokeswoman for Duales System, said it hoped to take in about $2.5 billion in 1994 and is instituting severe cost-cutting in a bid to become profitable. "Part of the problem is that the volume of materials collected has far exceeded our expectations, so the cost of transporting and handling that much material was far higher than we had originally estimated," she said. "We expected 105,000 tons of plastic packaging in 1992 and took in 409,000 tons. Storing that added to our costs. But the situation should stabilize."
Despite the changes, many critics contend that Germany's system remains too costly and too dependent on recycling (as opposed to landfills and incineration) to be a model for the United States.

HEADLINE: Technology;
A New Music Retailing Technology Says, 'Listen Here'

BYLINE: By MATT ROTHMAN; Matt Rothman covers technology and finance for Variety in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
IT is one of life's little frustrations. You walk into a record store and cannot find the music you want. You may know the tune, but not the artist. Worse, you like one song but have no idea whether the entire album is appealing. At $16 for a compact disk, a snap decision could disappoint.
To make music shopping easier, the record industry is using computer technology to update the old-fashioned listening booth, where customers could take their 78's or 45's for a spin before putting down their money. One of the most sophisticated approaches, just hitting the markets in New York and other cities, is an interactive kiosk that lets record store customers listen to samples from 30,000 albums with the help of a touch-screen computer menu. 
 The kiosk, called the I-station, was test-marketed last winter in New York, St. Louis and San Diego. Several went into full use last week at the largest music store in the United States, the HMV shop on Lexington Avenue at East 86th Street in Manhattan. The roll-out will continue through the summer and will include a handful of Wherehouse record stores in the West.
Josh Kaplan, founder of the Intouch Group, the San Francisco company that makes the machine, said the goal was to ease the anxiety a music buyer faced with the enormous selection in most stores.
"Someone walks into a store that has 40,000 choices and you have selection stress," Mr. Kaplan said. "You should never walk out without a purchase."
Futuristic technologies have been proposed, like the plan announced in the spring by I.B.M. and the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation for a system that would make customers' own compact disks in the stores. But the I-station is here now, and is meant to enhance the marketing of the products already in the stores.
If successful, the I-station and other systems like it could provide a much-needed stimulus to the music industry, which was hit hard by the recession. It is still struggling with slim profit margins and the fragmentation that comes with a welter of competing genres as diverse as world beat, hip-hop and Christian rock. After sliding 7.5 percent in 1991, sales of recorded music in the United States rebounded 11.8 percent to $9 billion last year, according to the Record Industry Association of America.
The industry is also seeing its core audience grow older, in part because of the general aging of the population and the ascendancy of the more expensive CD format. Compared with 1987, when virtually half the money spent on records was spent by customers age 24 and younger, less than 43 cents of each dollar comes from these younger listeners today, the industry association said. Record merchants must contend with an older, more discriminating audience that is less willing to ride each new wave in music. That means buyers are more cautious.
"Any information you can get in the hands of consumers reduces the risk of the purchase," said Deborah English, a vice president at Wherehouse Records, which is based in Torrance, Calif. "You can't open a book like in a bookstore and read a few lines. Any information we can give them helps reduce that risk. That's the key. Make it easier for them to buy."
Intouch, founded two years ago, is one of several efforts bent on educating consumers. Also competing for attention is an information kiosk introduced three years ago by Muze Inc., a Brooklyn company controlled by Metromedia, the East Rutherford, N.J., company whose chairman is John W. Kluge.
Though it does not provide any audio, Muze offers a touch-screen kiosk that lets users find an album title by searching an electronic directory for the artist or song. Consumers can even enter a piece of a lyric into the directory of the computer, which will find the record. The Muze kiosks are in 300 stores nationwide, including Tower Records.
Tower, which is based in Sacramento, Calif., has also tested the Intouch system but opted to go with its own listening system. This summer, Tower, one of the largest chains in the country, is installing listening posts that each contain 12 albums on CD. A customer can sample tunes -- or listen to the whole recording. Chris Hopson, the senior vice president of marketing for Tower, said the aim is to help customers learn about new artists, not to let listeners sample every title in the store.
INTOUCH has a much more ambitious strategy, Mr. Kaplan contended. It intends to offer a user-friendly teacher and provide retailers and record studios with a wealth of consumer data.
After answering a demographic questionnaire, I-station customers are issued a free I-card by a store clerk. The card, which is stamped with its own bar code, can be scanned by a laser reader at the I-station, which logs the customer onto the computer system.
If a CD has already been selected from the store shelves, the bar code on the label can be scanned by the laser, which will call up a menu of the album's songs on a touch-screen monitor. With a touch, a 30-second sample of the song will be played and a movie camera icon will appear if there is a music video to watch while listening.
An on-screen keyboard lets customers locate albums by typing in song titles, or find a best-seller by summoning a list of the top 50 records on the Billboard magazine chart. If the songs are appealing, another touch of the screen will produce a list of other albums by the performer or similar music by related musicians. After listening, the customers are asked to rate the albums from poor to excellent by touching one of five on-screen windows.
Every session on a kiosk produces valuable information for the record companies. Through computer networks, Intouch intends to collect the data from each machine every night and compile the information into weekly and monthly reports that will be sold to the record companies for $10 apiece for each metropolitan market. Such consumer polling could enable record companies to release an album in certain markets, testing reaction on a weekly basis.
"I love all this information," said Larry Stessel, the senior vice president and general manager of Mercury Records, a unit of Polygram N.V., which has arranged with Intouch to place its recordings on the I-stations. "If we're dealing with Bon Jovi, we can get an idea of how that audience has grown," he said. "Is it just the demographics that purchased their albums 10 years ago, or are they building a new audience? It's very useful. They really thought this through."
The machine can also be a marketing tool. Coupons, special sales and promotions can be programmed into each I-station. The I-card holders, though, may be the real draw of the Intouch system for retailers who can put together lists of customers rich in information about their tastes in music.
In the six weeks that Tower operated five test machines in New York last winter, the experiment generated customer profiles of 25,000 I-card holders. Intouch, which expects to have 1,000 kiosks in operation throughout the United States by the end of 1994, said it hoped to have two million I-card holders by then.
COLLECTING all the data is an Apple IIci inside the I-station. It also controls access to what the listeners can hear: 150,000 songs sampled from 30,000 albums. That amount can easily be doubled, said Steve Katz, a vice president of Intouch.
About 60 graduates of the San Francisco Music Conservatory are working for Intouch to enter the album titles and performers into a database designed by Mr. Katz. Representative 30-second samples of music from five selections are picked by the graduates and the passages and titles are put into a Macintosh program. Later, the song samples are plucked from a rack of 150 CD's, compressed, and transferred to digital audio tape and then to the I-station CD in the stores.
Mr. Kaplan, a former investment banker with Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco, said he had been nurturing the I-station idea since 1987, when the notion struck him during a visit to a record store in Geneva that had an old-fashioned listening booth. He recalled asking himself: Why not digitize the operation?
Bitten by the entrepreneurial bug, he quit Robertson, Stephens in 1990 and invested $143,000 in his own prototype. He raised $600,000 from his former colleagues and the executives of a company he helped take public, the Rasterops Corporation, which also provides computer video chips for the kiosks. He has since put together $12 million in capital from investors who include the Getty oil family, David Hewlett, the co-founder of Hewlett-Packard, and Ray Noorda, the chairman of the computer network software company Novell Inc.
Mr. Kaplan's business plan calls for Intouch, which has spent $7 million on start-up costs, to be in the black by 1995, with pretax earnings of $11 million on revenues of $26.8 million.
But plenty of work lies ahead. So far among the biggest recording labels, only Polygram has signed on. Negotiations are under way with the others, Mr. Kaplan said. He said he has had to cut the fee that a studio pays for an album's inclusion in the I-station; the current asking price is $4 apiece for popular categories and down to $2.50 for classical titles. On top of that, the record company is expected to pay 30 cents for each sample chosen by a customer.
Meanwhile, the biggest retailers are just coming around to the idea of paying monthly rental fees of $300 on average for each kiosk.
AND though Intouch appears to have a technical lead, Tower, for one, rejected the approach. "People want to listen to more than 30 seconds, or a snippet of the song, and want a flavor of the album," said Mr. Hopson of Tower, explaining the decision by the retailer to pursue its own 12-CD listening posts.
But Wherehouse, a chain with 315 stores, likes what it has seen so far with its I-station tests. "Of the machines available to retailers, theirs is the best," Ms. English, of Wherehouse, said. "If the customers listen to the CD, they'll be more apt to buy it, rather than just interact with the screen and search for it later."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
First-Half Buoyancy From Japan

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The hottest sector in mutual funds so far this year may be gold -- up 63.1 percent after a decade in which the group lost money -- but funds that invest in Japanese stocks have shown new life, rising to second place in performance in the first six months of 1993.
As the first half came to a close last week, the six Japanese funds were up 39.1 percent, despite a recent drop of 3 percentage points in the week after the nation's Prime Minister received a no-confidence vote in Parliament. In third place was a group of funds that invest in the Pacific Rim that rose 25.6 percent. That group, including the Japan funds and others with interests in the Japanese market, obviously got a boost from the Tokyo gains. 
 Overall in the latest quarter, United States stock funds rose 3.4 percent, on average, as the stock market kept chugging along. For the first six months, the gain was 4.8 percent.
Indeed, almost all of the Nasdaq-listed stock fund categories traced by Morningstar Inc. produced positive returns in the first half. According to the mutual fund researchers in Chicago, the only exception was a group funds that invest in health-and-biotechnology issues, which dropped 8.1 percent.
The funds that invest in Japanese equities have long been due for a comeback. They lost 4.1 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended June 1993, compared with an 11.9 percent annual gain for domestic stock funds. Going back five years, the Japan group rose just 2.6 percent a year, compared with 12.9 percent for domestic funds.
What happened? The Japanese Government, which keeps a firm hand on its economy, stopped the huge liquidity-driven bull market of the mid-1980's by raising interest rates at the end of 1989, after the benchmark Nikkei index reached nearly 40,000. That burst the huge bubble in asset prices.
The Nikkei began a decline that touched bottom last August at 14,300. Then, in April, Tokyo's 13.2 trillion-yen fiscal stimulus package gave a lift to the Tokyo stock market, said Rika Yoshida, managing editor of the Morningstar Japan newsletter.
This year's Japan fund gains were augmented by the rise of the yen, a climb that managers do not expect to continue. Even so, most say that Japanese issues are cheaper on a valuation basis than comparable United States stocks, "so it makes sense to invest some money in Japan, probably with not as high expectations in the second half of the year as in the first half," said John R. Hickling, who manages the $200 million Fidelity Japan Fund, which was started in September 1992. Its cyclical plays include Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, which is heavily involved in capital spending, and Toyota Motor.
Chris D. Alderson, who co-manages the $95 million T. Rowe Price Japan Fund, says he is cautiously optimistic. "We're now at the point where economic levels must catch up with valuations, which will happen slowly over the next 12 months," he said. He likes companies that may benefit from an economic recovery, especially Nippon Kompo, a transportation and trucking company, and Toshiba Tungaloy, an industrial tool maker.
The combination of a strong yen and political uncertainty caused the market to fall back once the Nikkei index reached a technical ceiling of nearly 22,000 in the spring, said Elizabeth J. Allan, manager of the $535 million Japan Fund. The market will have to digest these factors, but that process should be complete in six months to a year, she said. In addition, "the economy is at a cyclical bottom and the recovery is all in front of us," she said.
Among the fund's biggest holdings are the Nichiei Company, which makes loans to small businesses; the Secom Company, Japan's largest producer of electronic security systems, and the Kyocera Corporation, an electronics manufacturer.
Christian Wignall, chief investment officer of G.T. Capital Management in San Francisco and the original manager of the $111 million G.T. Japan Growth Fund, is the group's biggest bear. "We're quite cautious about the Japanese stock market, even though it's rallied. We don't think the rise is justified by the fundamentals," he said.
The fund is positioned defensively, with nearly one-quarter stashed in bonds. Among stocks, it likes Takeda Chemical Industries, a large chemical and pharmaceutical company, and Daiichi Seiyaku, a medium-sized pharmaceutical company. Another favorite: the Seven-Eleven Japan Company, which owns a chain of 7-Eleven stores.
The other two Japan funds are more limited. The DFA Japanese Small Company Fund, in Santa Monica, Calif., is available only to institutional investors and clients of investment advisers. Capstone Nikko Japan is a $2.2 million fund based in Houston and available only in 25 states. (It is also the only one of the six Japan funds that is not listed by Nasdaq, which means it does not appear in newspaper listings.)
Another route to Japan is through the funds that invest in the Pacific Rim countries. Among the biggest plays are Merrill Lynch Pacific, which is three-quarters invested in Japan, and Nomura Pacific Basin, nearly two-thirds invested there. An even larger Japanese investment, 85 percent, is found in the Vanguard International Equity Index Fund: Pacific Portfolio. It was a high scorer among Pacific Basin funds so far this year, up 37.3 percent.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Me-First Scramble To Find Screen Gems

BYLINE: By Anne Thompson; Anne Thompson is a Los Angeles-based writer.

 BODY:
A cadre of young, globe-trotting movie executives charged with knowing every nonstudio film being made around the world is transforming the way these movies are bought for distribution.
No longer are these executives waiting for Cannes or Berlin or Toronto or other major film festivals to screen the best of international cinema at the same time as all the other independent distributors, then making their offers in their own time. In today's cutthroat global film economy, where financing dollars are scarce and releasing costs astronomical -- and where only a handful of independent releases succeed in North America each year -- getting to the right movie first has become the key to survival. 
 "By the time I got to Cannes, I'd already seen 25 movies," said Mark Ordesky, vice president of acquisition and co-production at New Line Cinema ("Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles"). And by the time he got to Cannes in May, his company had already acquired the Taviani brothers' "Fiorile" in Rome. Fine Line Features, a New Line division, announced the acquisition at Cannes even as more cautious competitors were still waiting to see how it would fare with critics.
New Line's toughest competitor right now is Miramax Films, which not only released "The Crying Game," with an American box-office gross of more than $62 million to date, but also the recent art-house hits "Enchanted April" and "Like Water for Chocolate." The co-chairmen of Miramax, the brothers Harvey and Bob Weinstein, are paying higher prices for more screen gems than any of their rivals.
Before Cannes this year, Miramax, which was purchased by Disney in the spring, had already landed both eventual winners of the coveted Palme D'Or: "The Piano," a New Zealand period drama starring Holly Hunter, Sam Neill and Harvey Keitel, and the lush Chinese epic "Farewell to My Concubine."
To get "The Piano," Harvey Weinstein used his connections to arrange a screening in Paris in the winter. Miramax promptly bought the film for more than $3 million.
"Everyone went ballistic" at being shut out of the process, said Bingham Ray, a partner at October Films ("Un Coeur en Hiver"). "That's what you deal with. Everyone tries to jockey for position. Good relationships can pay off with an early screening ahead of the competition."
Marcie Bloom, co-president at Sony Classics ("Howards End," "Orlando"), agreed: "The business is all about relationships. You have to stay alert and attentive to anything that might be helpful in any way. You have to be open to possibilities when films are emerging from literally anywhere on the globe."
And, said Bobby Rock, senior vice president of acquisitions for Triton Pictures ("American Heart"), "You have to have a good back and a good pair of arms to carry your bags, and be able to watch a movie on six hours of sleep."
Like most of his colleagues, Mr. Rock screens 7 to 10 movies or videotapes a week and attends seven or eight film festivals a year, during which he sees three to five movies a day. But it's getting riskier for the smaller companies like Triton that lack lavish travel budgets to wait to see a movie at a huge festival like Cannes: The film may not be available by the time they get there.
"More films are bought earlier, so there is less completed product available," said Betsy Stanbock, director of acquisitions for the Samuel Goldwyn Company. "We have to hustle that much harder."
Still, "Cannes is the triple triathlon for acquisitions executives," said Zanne Devine, vice president of Universal Pictures, who seeks films for the studio as well as for the new independent distributor Gramercy Pictures, which is owned by Universal and Polygram. "I'm looking for lightning in a bottle: a movie that will light my hair on fire."
Staying alive in this pack isn't easy. After seeing "Tous les Matins du Monde," starring Gerard Depardieu, at the Berlin Film Festival last year, Jeff Lipsky of October Films wanted to buy it. So his partner, Mr. Ray, had to screen it right away. He flew to Montreal, where the film was playing without English subtitles, and persuaded a local friend to translate. The next day, the partners made their offer, and "Tous les Matins" has grossed more than $3 million in the United States, a sizable sum for a foreign-language film.
While getting there first is the acquisitions executive's priority, even more important is judging market value. Although Howard Cohen, vice president of acquisitions for Goldwyn, flew to Hong Kong to see "Farewell to My Concubine" before anyone else, Goldwyn ultimately passed in favor of another Asian film, "The Wedding Banquet," which it bought after the Berlin Film Festival.
It remains to be seen whether he or Miramax made the right call.
Many potential hits are not obvious. While sex has usually been an easy sell, many distributors have overlooked the strong appeal of food in films. "Tampopo," "Babette's Feast," "My Dinner with Andre" and "Eating" have been joined by "Like Water for Chocolate," which created very little heat at Cannes last year but is now a hit.
Everyone saw "Like Water for Chocolate" in the same screening room, says Trea Hoving, senior vice president of acquisitions of Miramax. But Miramax saw in it some of the same elements as in its Oscar-winning Italian hit "Cinema Paradiso," the highest-grossing foreign-language film in the last decade. And Miramax was willing to work with the director, Alfonso Arau, to recut the film for the American market, shortening it by 10 minutes. The movie has grossed more than $10 million in the United States.
"You're always trying to stay a jump ahead of the taste of the public," Ms. Stanbock of Goldwyn said. "You just have to listen to your heart."

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
Try Foreign Insurance, Not Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By HOWARD HILLS; Howard Hills, of counsel to the law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, served as general counsel of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation from 1989 to 1993.

 BODY:
WASHINGTON is still scratching its head over how to respond to the decline of Communism. Emerging capitalist states need aid, and they represent vast new markets for America -- and for its competitors. How, Washington wonders, can the United States help these new nations and help itself?
The answer is not easy. None of the usual tools seem appropriate. Foreign aid can help, but in these days of deficit reduction it is politically impossible to get enough of it to make a real difference. And, anyway, the government-to-government approach of the Agency for International Development, which administers all foreign aid, is a relic of the cold war. It seems obsolete in this era of the ascendant private sector. 
 One tool is tailor-made for the new economic order, however. It is the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC), a tiny Federal agency that sells insurance to companies that invest abroad and to lenders who finance such investments. For reasonable premiums, the agency protects policyholders for 20 years against the "triple threat" to investment abroad: political violence, expropriation and inconvertibility of currency.
The agency's economic importance is hard to overstate. While some private insurers do sell such "political risk" insurance, they cannot match the agency's low premiums and long-term coverage. By law, the agency is required to help private insurers develop such products but, in the meantime, the agency is invaluable if American businesses are to invest confidently overseas.
HERE'S one of many examples. In 1989, General Electric wanted to invest $150 million in the privatization of Tungsram, a Hungarian lighting products company. But G.E. was unwilling to proceed without insurance, and unable to buy it privately. So G.E. got the Federal insurance instead -- and the project became a reality.
Created by statute in 1971, the agency operates in more than 130 countries. Hundreds of American companies -- including American Express, Caterpillar, Citibank and McDonald's, as well as G.E. -- use the agency's services. All told, the agency participates in $7.2 billion in private foreign investment each year, primarily through insurance but also through foreign-investment loans to small businesses and loan guaranties. And it does so efficiently. Its staff of under 150 operates out of a single office in Washington, and its administrative budget is less than $20 million.
Congress must expand this tiny but productive insurer. The demand is certainly there. Last year, American companies asked the agency for $12 billion in insurance and loans for projects in the former Soviet Union alone. That sum substantially exceeded the agency's total yearly insurance and lending authority.
A larger agency makes sense in other ways too. For one, it's economical. Agency income from premiums, loan interest and its own investments more than cover its cost to taxpayers; indeed, since its inception the agency has returned to the Treasury Department a net profit of $1.5 billion -- even counting the hundreds of millions of dollars paid in claims to insured businesses.
Moreover, as a market-driven program, the agency is in tune with the times. Businesses pay their own premiums and it is their own capital that is at risk overseas -- not the taxpayers'. If the ventures fail, the private parties will feel pain along with the agency. This approach avoids the inefficiencies of loan guarantees, with which taxpayers subsidize failure, and of foreign aid, which just gives taxpayer money away..
As Washington puzzles over the big question of economic change around the globe, it should know that part of the answer can be found right in town, in a very small agency on New York Avenue, just a few blocks from the White House.

HEADLINE: HAITIAN MILITARY AND ARISTIDE SIGN PACT TO END CRISIS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
Ending a week of uncertainty and bitter recriminations, Haiti's exiled President and the army commander who ousted him signed an accord yesterday providing for the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to power and for democracy to be restored to the country by Oct. 30.
After Father Aristide signed the accord last night on Governors Island in New York Harbor, he made a brief statement, saying: "To all of the international community, peace and love. Peace and love to the Haitian people." 
 The United Nations mediator, Dante Caputo, speaking later, thanked President Aristide for his flexibility. Mr. Caputo also said there were "no side letters and no hidden agenda."
The separate signings by Father Aristide and Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras came on a day of high tension in which it sometimes appeared that the deposed President would reject the agreement. Father Aristide was angered that the settlement did not provide for the quick retirement of the army high command, aides said.
Diplomats said he yielded after repeated assurances that the international community would see to it that the accords would be respected. Even then, an adviser to Father Aristide said, the Haitian President was "not at all comfortable," but diplomats said little pressure was required.
 
21 Months After Army Coup
 Father Aristide finally signed the accord shortly before 11 P.M. yesterday, roughly 21 months after the military coup that plunged Haiti into crippling economic isolation and led to a frantic boat exodus of tens of thousands.
At 10:40 P.M., Father Aristide and several aides entered the room where General Cedras had earlier signed the agreement. The exiled President then exchanged signatures and broad grins with United Nations mediators amid applause.
Father Aristide's representative in Washington, Jean Casimir, in a brief statement after the signing, said that the "coup leaders' departure, and the President's immediate return, have been the most sensitive concerns of the negotiations," but that the results were "a great day in the history of the entire hemisphere and of Haiti."
The accord, which General Cedras had signed about 11:30 in the morning, opens the way for a political conference this week in which President Aristide's aides and Haitian political parties will begin work on forming a Government and preparing for his return.
 
A Week of Uncertainty
 A leftist Roman Catholic priest, Father Aristide was elected with an overwhelming mandate in Haiti's first democratic presidential elections in December 1990. He has been in exile since he was overthrown in a military coup on Sept. 30, 1991.
The delay in Father Aristide's signing was in keeping with the uncertainty, frustration and sudden reversals that characterized the six days of negotiations on Governors Island. Late yesterday morning, shortly before General Cedras entered the brick Officers' Club to sign the pact, diplomats said grimly that they expected Father Aristide to reject the settlement.
On Friday, his objections to the settlement centered mainly on the timetable for his return to power. After 21 months of exile, he chafed at the prospect of waiting almost four more months to be restored to office.
 
Issue of Officers' Fate
 But the major sticking point to the agreement yesterday was disappointment on the President's team that members of the Haitian high command would not necessarily be removed from the armed forces for their role in the coup, but could be simply reassigned by a new commander who is to be chosen by Father Aristide shortly before his return in October.
"That was a shock to us," said one member of Father Aristide's delegation, who expressed anger that General Cedras could not be asked to delay his departure for more negotiations on this point. The commander left New York on a flight for Haiti after signing the agreement yesterday morning.
Father Aristide was worried that the commander and other senior officers who took part in the September 1991 coup could resort to violence or intimidation to frustrate his return, diplomats and aides said. Human rights experts estimate that anywhere from 500 to 3,000 people have been killed by the military since the 1991 coup.
 
Mediator's Exasperation
 This morning General Cedras was ushered out of the signing room at one point while Mr. Caputo, the United Nations mediator and a former Argentine Foreign Minister, held a series of last-minute telephone conversations with one of Father Aristide's top advisers, Michael D. Barnes.
 
Caputo 'Fed Up'
 Minutes earlier, alluding to Father Aristide's objections, Mr. Caputo whispered to a reporter: "He will have to answer to history. I am fed up."
Throughout months of negotiations, diplomats have said, Father Aristide has often changed tack, shifting from a mood of patient deliberation to adamant rejection of concessions.
By holding out until the last minute, Father Aristide grated on the nerves of many diplomats. But the delay helped the exiled President to obtain assurances that his most bitter enemies among army leaders would "either resign or leave the country," as one person involved in the negotiations said.
"The way we have left it is that they have conveyed to Caputo and Caputo conveyed to us that they will leave the high command or they will leave the country," a senior adviser to Father Aristide said of the military leadership.
The transition outlined in the settlement also called for Father Aristide to propose a new Prime Minister who would require the approval of Haiti's parliament before forming a new Government. Once the choice of prime minister is ratified by parliament, diplomats said, international aid will resume and countries will suspend sanctions against Haiti, including an oil embargo imposed last month by the United Nations.
 
Sanctions Hinge on Transition
 If Father Aristide is not restored by Oct. 30, diplomats said, the sanctions will automatically be reimposed. If the transition is successful, the penalties will be revoked by the Secretary General of the United Nations.
After Father Aristide has chosen a new prime minister, a selection that could come as early as this week, and his choice is ratified, a "$1 billion plus" aid program to Haiti will begin almost immediately, diplomats said.
Diplomats said the aid program for the desperately impoverished country would be vast, encompassing virtually all areas of society, from the separation of the police from the army and reforms in both institutions to technical help in building a new and professional civil service. Almost immediately, officials planning the aid said, officials will focus on creating thousands of new jobs to help revive an economy near collapse.
Lawrence E. Pezzullo, President Clinton's special adviser for Haitian affairs, said the package, to be provided by the United States and several other international donors, represented "a big commitment of money into a society to make it viable."
 
'A Long Journey'
 "It's been a long journey," Mr. Pezzullo said as he left the Officers' Club. "I feel good."
First, however, the Haitian political parties meeting with representatives of Father Aristide are to decide on a plan to purge the current Parliament of lawmakers who were elected last January in a vote that the United Nations and many others have denounced as illegitimate.
To do so, the parties represented in Parliament would be required to agree on what to do with the empty seats. Immediately afterward, diplomats said, attention will turn to ratifying the President's choice of a new prime minister, who is expected to be a independent political figure.
Asked what would happen if the Haitians could not agree among themselves, as has often been the case in the recent past, one diplomat said, "If they dicker away their time, that is their responsibility." Meanwhile, sanctions will remain in effect.
"This is, as far as I know, certainly the first time in the Western Hemisphere, that a sitting President who has been expelled has then been restored to power through international pressure," said Robert White, a senior member of Father Aristide's negotiating team.
"It is a tremendous success for all of the parties, Haiti, Caputo, the United States, certainly. Aristide showed that he has flexibility and that he is able to take decisions even when people in his movement are concerned."
A Haitian member of Father Aristide's delegation, Jean Dominique, expressing satisfaction with the accord, said: "No one can despair for the future of democracy in Haiti because for 21 months of dictatorship we have had a people that has never hung its head. That's the bottom line."

Chronology: "HAITI: CRISES AND ACCORD"
 
By The Associated Press
 
Dec. 16, 1990: The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide wins Haiti's first free presidential elections by a wide margin.
Jan. 7, 1991: Roger Lafontant, an ardent backer of the former Duvalier dictatorship, tries to overthrow a provisional president, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, but loyalist troops stifle the attempt. Incensed Aristide supporters go on a rampage, killing at least 70 people.
Feb. 7: Father Aristide is sworn in peacefully as President and retires most of the army command.
Sept. 30: Troops mutiny and overthrow President Aristide, who is sent into exile. Hundreds of civilians are killed.
Oct. 7: Soldiers turn away a delegation from the Organization of American States that flew to Haiti for first of many attempts to reinstate President Aristide.
Oct. 8: Justice Joseph Nerette of the Supreme Court is sworn in as a provisional president, but real power remains with the army. The O.A.S. calls for a hemisphere-wide trade embargo against Haiti.
PUB-DATE: May 24, 1992:
June 2: Marc Bazin becomes Prime Minister with the army's backing, replacing Mr. Nerette as head of the military-backed Government.
PUB-DATE: June 8, 1993:
June 23: A U.N. oil embargo and the freezing of Haitian assets takes effect.
July 3: -- After nearly a week of negotiations in New York, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, chief of the army, and Father Aristide sign an agreement on restoring him to power as President and on a series of steps toward democracy.(pg. 12)
