LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
It's a Small Show, but It Sends a Signal

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
A 10-MINUTE DELAY AT THE Midtown Tunnel. Bumper-to-bumper past the airport. Construction tie-ups on the Long Island Expressway. That's not just the morning traffic report on the radio. It's also architectural criticism, a daily dispatch from the urban infrastructure. And the radio station does more than report on the infrastructure. It's an integral part of it. The station's broadcast beams are invisible links in an architecture of communications, a sprawling mega structure of steel transmission towers and airwaves that stretches across Long Island, creating new patterns of urban space.
Those patterns are the subject of "Transmission Towers on the Long Island Expressway," a show on view at the Urban Center in Manhattan through July 10. It's a modest exhibition, made up of drawings and small, jewel-like scale models, lodged on a stairway landing on the Urban Center's second floor. But there's nothing modest about the show's sweeping megalopolitan vision. And the contrast between its large vision and its small physical scale is a clue to its purpose. Michele Bertomen, the New York architect responsible for the show, has issued a call for architects to think bigger. 
 Probably millions of Long Island commuters have appreciated the taut, airy beauty of transmission towers, which relay signals for television, radio and telephone. Ms. Bertomen is a connoisseur of them. A commuter to her job in Central Islip, where she teaches architecture at the New York Institute of Technology, she can discuss dish, disk and horn antennas with the enthusiasm classicists reserve for Doric, Ionic and Tuscan columns. She delights in cellular phone calls as others thrill to Gothic spires.
In 1985, Ms. Bertomen gathered together a group of her architecture students to pursue her enthusiasm in a more scholarly way. Each student was asked to "adopt" a tower, document it with drawings, and study how the towers function within the larger network of communications. The team's work became the basis of a book with the same title as the show (Princeton Architectural Press), which is a best seller at the Urban Center's bookstore. Response to the book prompted Nicolas Rojas, of the bookstore's staff, to invite Ms. Bertomen to organize the show now on view. Evidently, a good many young architects are on Ms. Bertomen's wavelength.
While the show addresses contemporary urban issues, it pulls together strands of thinking that other architects have pursued in the past. Ms. Bertomen acknowledges the pioneering research of Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi on the architecture of the American highway, but her interests take a different route. She is not drawn to the pop repertoire of golden arches and kitschy billboards. Whereas Mr. Venturi defined architecture as a "decorated shed" whose skin matters more than its bones, Ms. Bertomen has reverted to the modern idea that there's something virtuous about peeling away the skin to expose the structure underneath.
She is fascinated by the high-tech, engineering esthetic of transmission towers: their delicate steel tracery, the prefabricated parts that can be combined to create different forms. But she is also concerned with the spatial structure of the suburban developments that the broadcast media have helped to shape. This focus harks back to Broadacre City, Frank Lloyd Wright's 1935 Utopian scheme for a decentralized urban America. Wright recognized back then that the car and the radio would bring about a new kind of city. Ms. Bertomen wants us to recognize that this new city has generated new kinds of public space: realms of movement and communication that have gone far toward supplanting the eroded public sphere of our beleaguered older cities.
But is there a place in this environment for architecture? Unlike Wright, Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown, Ms. Bertomen doesn't tackle this question. Instead, she and her students have staked an esthetic claim on objects already built. They've gone clambering over transmission towers along the Long Island Expressway, taking measurements, tracing forms, even giving them names like Lioness, Triplets and Upstart. The drawings and models in the show are beautiful, and perhaps it's unfair to ask for more. They are intended as aids to vision. There are Eiffel Towers in your backyard, Ms. Bertomen is saying: Just open your eyes.
When it comes to interpreting what we see, however, Ms. Bertomen is not a wholly reliable guide. That is partly because her infatuation with current academic theory is stronger than her grasp of history. For instance, she sets great store on the value of transmission towers as vernacular objects, which she regards as a departure from the star system of Masterpiece buildings by Master form-makers. In fact, vernacularism is an old and somewhat stale ideal in architecture. It's the flip side of Romanticism's cult of the inspired genius, and no less sappy in its worship of the collective.
Ms. Bertomen also holds the naive hope that electronic communications can overturn the lopsided power hierarchy traditionally associated with towers. Like Frank Lloyd Wright, she imagines that urban decentralization should logically disperse power from the few to the many. Actually, suburban development has been accompanied by an intense concentration of power in the hands of corporate giants. That's one reason to be skeptical about the claim that highways and radio waves add up to acceptable substitutes for parks, streets, squares and other traditional forms of public space. As was made evident in the Los Angeles riots, our suburban highway utopias leave a large segment of the public by the side of the road.
True, transmission towers are physically dispersed throughout the landscape, but every TV advertiser knows how well they still transmit the old tower message: senders above, receivers below. Indeed, that message is probably what drew Ms. Bertomen to this project. With radar precision, she has honed in on these towers as symbols of power in the information society. Her drawings, models and maps resemble fetishes, magical objects designed to tap into the power structure of global communications.
More power to her. Ms. Bertomen speaks for a generation of young architects who want to enlarge the role of their profession. They are looking for something more out of architecture than decorating the skins of 60-story skyscrapers. They want to respond to the larger forces shaping the urban environment: communications, transportation, systems of energy and water. They don't want to design A.T.&T. buildings. They want to get their hands on A.T.&T.
How this ambition can be translated into practical terms remains to be seen. It's admirable that Ms. Bertomen wants to cut through the barriers that separate art from industry, architecture from engineering, the ivory tower from the corporate penthouse. But for now those barriers remain firmly in place. Architects are not entrusted with the design of entire infrastructures. They're given small pieces of land and asked to create livable places on them. That's not an ignoble calling, and the city stands to lose if architects turn a deaf ear to it. Stay tuned.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: The transmission towers that line the Long Island Expressway rise like Eiffel towers of the back yard -- Magical objects and at the same time symbols of power. (Urban Center)

LENGTH: 2212 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A Revitalizer of Russian Opera

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
New York has been a battlefield in the Russian operatic wars over the last year, with competing companies struggling to establish themselves as American favorites. Unfortunately for the Kirov Opera, which makes its American debut tomorrow evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, the feebler cannons were fired first. After the visits of the Bolshoi Opera of Moscow last summer at the Met and of the St. Petersburg National Opera earlier this year at the New York State Theater, New Yorkers may not realize that the Kirov Opera operates on an altogether higher level.
The Kirov, which shares its 175-member orchestra and the Maryinsky Theater with the Kirov Ballet, is currently the best Russia has to offer in terms of big, bold productions deftly blending old and new dramatic values, with stirring singing and thrilling choral and orchestral work. Or so it seemed on a recent visit to St. Petersburg, during which the company's artistic director, Valery Gergiev, conducted performances of Mussorg sky's "Khovanshchina" and Tchaikov sky's "Queen of Spades." And so it seems on the recordings Mr. Gergiev and company have released on Philips. "Queen of Spades" will be given in New York over the next two weeks, along with Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" and Prokofiev's "Fiery Angel." 
 The Bolshoi's disappointing season last summer was widely seen as a product of a company caught in awkward transition between a stodgy past and an as yet uncomprehended international future. The St. Petersburg National Opera, known until recently as the Maly Opera Theater, struck most observers as penny-pinching and provincial.
While these companies struggle to find their footing in the perilous economic and social conditions of the new Russia, the Kirov is already leading the way to a new kind of economic base and artistic policy. It is doing so because the 38-year-old Mr. Gergiev (pronounced gur-GHEE-ev), who took over artistic direction of the company in 1988, has asserted himself in almost every area of its operations. Old-fashioned conductors were tyrants, not democrats, and the soft-spoken Mr. Gergiev seems to be proving that the best results in a fledgling democracy like Russia's can be obtained with the fervor of a benign dictator.
"I have to be strong to protect the artistic line in this theater," the conductor said in his excellent English at a coffee shop in the Astoria Hotel, a few blocks from the Maryinsky. "I have to be autocratic, which is not a favorite word in the arts.
"The Kirov is part of Russia, but it doesn't have to be as chaotic and disorganized as the rest of the country. Somebody -- in this case, it's me -- has to be strong. The company has to be constantly pushed and watched and double-checked. I make things easier and shorter for myself if I step in and help solve a problem or simply do it myself. Otherwise, two or three months later, we have a double problem, because now it's already late."
What Mr. Gergiev has accomplished in his four years as head of the Kirov Opera has all of musical Russia talking -- and critics in Western Europe as well. Anatoly Malkov, the chief administrator of the Maryinsky Theater, happily brandishes a 1991 Russian critics' poll in which the Kirov topped every category -- best new production, best revival, best musical performance and others -- and usually also took the second and third spots.
In the declining years of the Soviet system, the Kirov and the Bolshoi normally each presented one big new production a season -- "maybe a second one," Mr. Gergiev said, "but usually something lighter, like a ballet or 'Don Pasquale.' " When he took over, he announced that he would do five new productions a season, including many operas never before performed at the theater or ignored in decades of repression. Traditionalists dismissed the notion as impossible chutzpah.
He started with a Mussorgsky Festival in 1989, presenting all five of the composer's operas, along with symphonic and chamber programs. A Prokofiev Festival followed in 1991-92, featuring four new productions ("The Fiery Angel," "War and Peace," "The Love for Three Oranges" and "The Gambler") within eight days. The Mussorgsky series was done in modified form at the Edinburgh Festival; the Prokofiev is planned for the Bastille Opera in Paris in 1994, and there is to be a Rimsky-Korsakov Festival in St. Petersburg in the same year.
For Mr. Gergiev, the restoration of so many Prokofiev operas, long in official disfavor, was an important step. "For the Kirov," he said, "Prokofiev was a new language, a new force, new ideas. We are learning new feelings, a new tempo in our work. The music started to give energy to the people."
Mr. Gergiev is no fanatic avant-garde firebrand, determined to uproot time-honored traditions. Opera in St. Petersburg dates to 1736, only 33 years after the founding of the city, by Peter the Great. The first theater was built in 1783, and the current building came in 1860. Between then and World War I, the Maryinsky company counted as one of the most important in the world. It was renamed in 1934 for Sergei Kirov, an assassinated friend of Lenin's, and today neither the opera nor the ballet wants to give up the brand name.
Mr. Gergiev has been willing to invite flashy Western directors into his temple of Russian tradition, as David Freeman's production of "The Fiery Angel," with its writhing naked and near-naked bodies, proves. But he is also eager to retain classic set designs, some dating back before the Russian revolution.
The "Khovanshchina" seen recently, and preserved on video for future release, dates from 1953, when so much of Russian cultural life was suddenly liberalized after Stalin's death. Some Western visitors have found it archaic theatrically, but Mr. Gergiev, who has introduced new staging ideas and substituted Shostakovich's performing edition for Rimsky-Korsakov's, loves it for just that reason.
"It's not just old-fashioned," he said. "I wanted to document it because it's good to fix on video things we have in our repertory that are beautiful and that one day may be lost or die."
Mr. Gergiev was born in Moscow in 1953 of parents from Ossetia, a non-Russian ethnic region in the Caucasus Mountains in southern Russia. He was trained in Ossetia and moved on to the Rimsky-Korsakov Conservatory in Leningrad, as St. Petersburg was then called. As a student, he won the Soviet Union's most prestigious conducting contest, the All-Union Competition in Moscow, and the Herbert von Karajan Conductors' Competition in West Berlin.
Instead of plunging directly into the international concert scene, Mr. Gergiev signed on in 1978 as an assistant conductor at the Kirov Opera under Yuri Temirkanov. Though he graduated the next year to permanent conductor, a hard apprenticeship lay ahead. "It was not a star track," he said. "But it was the only way to learn this very, very complex business of opera."
In the early 80's, his career blossomed. He became chief conductor of the Armenian State Orchestra in 1981 and regularly led new productions at the Kirov. A Wagner "Lohengrin" in 1982, he said, won him recognition both inside and outside the company.
By 1987, his international career was gaining momentum, with a particularly strong base in Holland (thus his relationship with the Dutch Philips label). But in 1988, Yevgeny Mravinsky died. Russia's most famous conductor, Mravinsky had headed the Leningrad Philharmonic for 50 years. Mr. Temirkanov took over the Philharmonic, and Mr. Gergiev was elected artistic director of the Kirov Opera by the members of the company.
"For this country," he said, "it was a shocking combination of an old, famous tradition and a young man." But he moved ahead decisively on all fronts. He rebuilt the orchestra and chorus and fought to retain the loyalty of his singers at a time when tempting offers were pouring in from the West.
His success with the chorus and orchestra is there for all to hear: wonderfully rousing singing, ideal for the big, sweeping choruses that enliven Russian operas, and an instrumental sonority that raises national and local traditions (pungent winds, lush and exact strings) to an international level of excellence. Mr. Gergiev is especially proud of the improvement in the brass playing.
"Technically, there are many brilliant orchestras in the world," he said. "There are very few that provide a style, a sound. I have no need to conduct the St. Petersburg Philharmonic now, because I don't hear a difference."
Eastern European singers are flocking to the West, with its hard currency and its opportunities for diverse repertory and international fame. But a healthy number of the Kirov's stars have remained loyal to the company, partly because they are attracted by Mr. Gergiev's vitality and the opportunities his association with Philips provides for audio and video immortality.
The company includes many singers from countries that used to be part of the Soviet Union but have severed their ties to Russia. "There's no problem in keeping non-Russians," Mr. Gergiev said. "I'm not Russian myself. And in 1988, I was one of the first who could have left."
Mr. Malkov explained that singers sign contracts that allow them to spend time in the West but return for new productions or special events. By devoting part of their hard-currency earnings to the benefit of the Maryinsky Theater, he said, they keep their pension and medical benefits.
Even some Western stars have chosen to appear in St. Petersburg, notably Placido Domingo, who sang Otello there in February. Mr. Gergiev is fostering Western, especially Italian, repertory along with the Russian classics.
All this costs money. And state support has been cut, and further riddled by inflation. Mr. Malkov said precise figures are nearly impossible to give in the current fluid economic situation.
Yet the Kirov, partly through its tradition and partly through the new attention being paid Mr. Gergiev, has been able to obtain support from the West and even from newly privatized companies in Russia. Mr. Gergiev has had great success in attracting co-producers, particularly the Royal Opera at Covent Garden in London, and media giants like Philips, the BBC, NHK in Japan, ZDF in Germany and RAI in Italy. Covent Garden staged a gala in April to benefit the Maryinsky Theater as well as itself.
In addition to the Kirov Opera's frequent tours, its orchestra travels independently; it will undertake a two-week North American tour in the fall, ending with two concerts at Avery Fisher Hall in November. Mr. Gergiev often takes Kirov singers with him for guest engagements with other companies; he had 10 of his own singers in a recent "War and Peace" at the San Francisco Opera. He still manages, he said, to spend 40 percent of his time in St. Petersburg, and performances continue at home when the bulk of the orchestra is on the road.
The touring enhances the company's international reputation and increases its marketability, thus insuring its future. "With me or without me," Mr. Gergiev said, "the Kirov will survive. It's too beautiful, too important. Too many eyes are watching."
In addition to sustaining the standard of living of company members and the loyalty of flighty stars, Mr. Gergiev would like to generate enough income to permit long-needed renovations in the Maryinsky. The theater is gorgeous to look at and has superb acoustics, but it is hemmed in by a canal and a public square. And while its elegant interior has been maintained, its exterior and backstage equipment are antiquated.
Still, Mr. Gergiev said, "the reason I am trying so hard to convince the best singers and players not to leave is that this is the best place in the world to do Russian opera."
 
 
 
GERGIEV ON CD, WITH THE KIROV IN TOW
 Before Valery Gergiev and the Kirov Opera signed their exclusive agreement with Philips, Mr. Gergiev made several recordings in the West:
* Rachmaninoff, Piano Concerto No. 2, with Yevgeny Kissin and the London Symphony. RCA 7982-2RC (also on cassette).
* Mussorgsky-Ravel, "Pictures at an Exhibition," and Tchaikovsky, "Francesca da Rimini," with the London Philharmonic. Philips 426 437-2.

* Borodin, Symphonies Nos. 1 and 2, with the Rotterdam Philharmonic. Philips 422 996-2.
Mr. Gergiev and the Kirov have released one ballet and one opera on Philips:
* Prokofiev, "Romeo and Juliet." 432 166-2; two CD's. Against stiff competition from Western orchestras, this recording impresses with inherently Russian sound colors.
* Mussorgsky, "Khovanshchina." 432 147-2; three CD's. The opera's best recording, this version offers idiomatic elan and singers equal to or better than Claudio Abbado's on Deutsche Grammophon.
For the future, Philips is planning audio and video recordings of opera, ballet and orchestral works with Mr. Gergiev and the Kirov, including:
* Prokofiev, "War and Peace," "The Fiery Angel," "The Love for Three Oranges."
* Tchaikovsky, "Queen of Spades," "The Sleeping Beauty."
* Glinka, "Ruslan and Ludmila."
* Rimsky-Korsakov, "The Czar's Bride."
* Borodin, "Prince Igor."

PUB-DATE: July 5, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1864 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Pacino's Star Turn Reflects the Glories of Rep

BYLINE: By David Richards

 BODY:
I CERTAINLY RELISHED AL Pacino's performance in "Salome," just as I relished his performance in "Chinese Coffee." But what I found most satisfying was watching him in "Salome" and "Chinese Coffee."
Mr. Pacino is currently appearing in both plays at Circle in the Square on Broadway. One night, he wraps himself in gold jewelry and luxurious fabrics, as King Herod, a potentate of some renown. A few nights later, he's Harry Levine, a Greenwich Village novelist of no reputation whatsoever, and he's wearing a threadbare black raincoat and a shapeless Mexican sweater. 
 The double bill has been conceived as a fund-raiser for Circle in the Square, which, like most not-for-profit theater companies, has some bailing out to do at the end of the season. Although tickets are a flat $50, Mr. Pacino is proving a big draw. By the time the run is over on July 23, Circle in the Square estimates that an accumulated debt of $1.2 million will have been reduced by about $200,000.
So you can say the primary mission has been accomplished.
It strikes me, however, that the enterprise is helpful in another way -- less immediately pragmatic, perhaps, but equally important in the long haul. It serves as a vivid reminder that there is no better measure of an actor's gifts than repertory theater. If you want to know just what a performer can do, let him play Hamlet on Tuesday and Biff Loman on Thursday. Or, in Mr. Pacino's case, a king, then a pauper. Back-to-back characterizations will expose any tricks and mannerisms in a flash. But they also reveal the stretch and breadth of an actor's talent in no equivocal terms. Theatergoers are given the increasingly uncommon opportunity to measure a performer against himself, not against fuzzy memories from prior seasons.
I won't pretend that either "Salome" or "Chinese Coffee" amounts to more than a pretext for Mr. Pacino to dazzle and mesmerize, although the former work is not without historical interest. Written originally in French, it is Oscar Wilde's ornate and overheated elaboration of the fairly straightforward biblical story. Rebuffed by the prophet Jokanaan (John the Baptist), Salome promises to dance her famous dance for Herod if afterward he will grant her whatever she wishes. He agrees. She sheds her veils, then demands -- and receives -- Jokanaan's head on a silver shield. Sarah Bernhardt was said to be impressed enough to think of putting on the play in London, which prompted Wilde to envision huge braziers of perfume on stage feeding heady scents into the auditorium in lieu of orchestral accompaniment. That should give you an idea. What Aubrey Beardsley is to the art of illustration, "Salome" is to the art of drama.
Ira Lewis's "Chinese Coffee," on the other hand, is a lean, contemporary two-character comedy, set in a dumpy photography studio belonging to one Jacob Manheim (Charles Cioffi). Manheim used to take pictures of soused nightclub patrons for a living and now shoots theatrical portraits. He's had exactly four customers in six months and business is slowing down. Looking like something the cat wouldn't drag in, Mr. Pacino shows up in the wee hours as the would-be writer Harry Levine. Ostensibly, he's come to claim the $473 Manheim owes him, but he really wants to hear what the photographer thinks of his new novel, a thinly veiled account of their friendship. Not a great deal, it turns out. By the night's end, the relationship has been irreparably damaged. Mr. Lewis's point would seem to be that failure, not success, goes to a person's head.
If you tried hard, I suppose you could make a case that the two roles are somehow related, that Mr. Pacino is showing us power and powerlessness in action. Or that a deep-
seated neuroticism governs the conduct of both Herod and Harry Levine. But it wouldn't be a very persuasive case. The actor himself is the only common denominator here. As directed, respectively, by Robert Allan Ackerman and Arvin Brown, his performances constitute a virtual about-face.
Early in the evening, Salome refers pointedly to Herod's "mole's eyes under his shaking eyelids," but it is Mr. Pacino's lips that are likely to draw your attention, when he drifts out of the banquet hall and onto the moonlit terrace where Wilde's play takes place. They're smeared with red, as if stained by gluttony or a drunken makeup man. Smacking his swollen chops and chewing constantly on his saliva, as old people sometimes do, Mr. Pacino suggests that years of self-indulgence have left a bad taste in his mouth and it won't go away.
He has untempered scorn for his servants and subjects -- not unlike that of the interior decorator for cheap home furnishings. They offend his sensibility, even as they confirm his own sense of superiority. When told that someone calling himself the Son of Man has been raising the dead, he seems to object on grounds of taste alone. Changing water to wine is one thing. "But no man shall raise the dead," he insists, laying a spidery hand to his breast and turning up his nose in squeamishness. "It would be terrible if the dead came back."
The voice, although pitched sharp and high, is weary, as if it had barked entirely too many commands for one lifetime. The body, by contrast, is soft and effeminate. During the frenzied dance of Salome (Sheryl Lee), Mr. Pacino lets himself slump so far down on the throne that it could be a bed. The posture says he couldn't be more bored, but you'll notice his eyes don't leave her for a second. If petulance makes this king highly comic, it never makes him ineffectual. Under the running mascara and poses of dissipated grandeur lurks a despot who's biding his time before giving the order that brings the play to a chilling conclusion.
In "Chinese Coffee," Mr. Pacino is pretty much on edge all night long. If he's not running a nervous hand through his hair or grinding his teeth to chalk or trying to quiet the muscle spasm in his right leg, he's feeling the equivalent of red-hot nails in his intestines and persuading himself it's a heart attack. Let him sit at the beat-up kitchen table and bury his head disconsolately in his hands -- his foot continues to dance a jittery little jig on its own.
Here is a man who can't fall asleep at night (Herod can't stay awake), whose thoughts are a muddle (Herod knows just what he thinks, even if he's not telling), who has accepted the indifference of others as his lot (Herod invites toadying). In short, a pasty-faced nobody, past his prime at 44, abandoned by his lover, with only the manuscript of a mediocre novel to pin his hopes on. And his best friend is telling him snidely, "Your idea of success seems to be to make it all the way up to the national poverty level."
By rights, Harry Levine should crumble there and then. But way down inside, where Herod's meanness slumbers, the writer has a nugget of self-respect. His novel may be lousy, but still he wrote it, got it off his chest, and that's more than the bitter photographer can boast. Just before he's thrown out of the studio for keeps, a crooked smile breaks over Mr. Pacino's face: he has suddenly realized that he's not shaking anymore. As dramatic revelations go, this is not a big one. "Chinese Coffee" doesn't ask a whole lot of its characters, other than that they get on each other's nerves.
Well, Mr. Pacino's tics are undeniably amusing, but the fascination of the performance lies elsewhere. While you're certain he's got a snapping point, you're never sure when or how he's going to erupt. The verbal uppercut causes no visible reaction, and he suffers the insulting right to the jaw without flinching. It's only later, in the middle of a seemingly innocuous reply, that the anger breaks through to the surface, dragging a lot of surprised words along with it. The actor can go from 0 to 60 mph -- from the paralysis of depression to table-pounding fury -- in under six seconds.
Did I say Mr. Pacino's two performances have nothing in common? I take it back. In both roles, the actor demonstrates an uncanny ability to communicate the gathering tension in characters who, to behold them, appear merely discombobulated or spent. (Even as Herod is sinking into a kind of heavy-lidded indolence, his patience is growing dangerously short.) The outburst of emotion -- whatever it may be -- comes as a delayed reaction, and catches you completely off guard. That's why it's so hard to take your eyes off the actor. He's a master of the sneak attack, and you don't want to be looking elsewhere when he strikes.
Maybe this would be just as obvious if he were performing in a single play, not two. But I doubt it. Plays and players really are better off in clusters. Put them side by side, they'll talk to one another. Interactions occur, connections get made. And everybody's vision is sharpened by the process.
As a rule, our theater doesn't make comparisons easy. If actors don't belong to an established company -- and most don't -- we see them all too infrequently in the flesh to indulge in fruitful discussions of their craft. When they become successful, they head to where the more lucrative work is -- television or the movies. If they come back to the boards, it is usually for a limited engagement. They may not have lost their feel for the stage in the interim, but we tend to lose our feel for them on a stage. No sooner have we all begun to renew acquaintance than they're packing their bags.
I don't know when Gene Hackman, Richard Dreyfuss or Glenn Close will be back on Broadway again. While their performances in "Death and the Maiden" are still fresh in my mind, though, I'd be eager to see them assume other guises, undertake other confrontations. Jessica Lange was not critically well received in "A Streetcar Named Desire," but I hope that doesn't mean an end to her theatrical career. I, for one, still have questions. How much of her portrayal of Blanche DuBois was instinctive behavior? How much the result of deliberate and conscious choices? There will be no hard answers until we are permitted another look at her in different theatrical surroundings.
To my mind, one of the most exciting performances last season was Jane Alexander's as Claire Zachanassian, the world's richest woman, in "The Visit." The actress was virtually unrecognizable in the part. I can say that confidently because Ms. Alexander has been better than most about showing her face regularly on the stage over the years.
The time, however, when Broadway had its stable of faithful stars, who returned each season in a new play, belongs to history. Continuity of any kind is rare these days. That's why Mr. Pacino's double-header at Circle in the Square is such a welcome reminder. One of the reasons we go to the theater, after all, is to watch actors act. The play doesn't always have to be the thing. If it did, the Lunts wouldn't have had a whole lot to show for themselves and the decades of barnstorming.
Unfortunately, there is a serious hitch to repertory theater. It is enormously costly to keep whole casts and sets at the ready so they can be changed every few nights. While that is the practice at all the great theaters of the world -- from the Comedie Francaise to the Royal National Theater of Britain -- it is one we have never been able to implement for long in this country before the money runs out. Without healthy subsidies, it's no go, and we're all aware of the state of governmental largesse these days.
The ultimate irony is that in order to relieve the economic pinch, Circle in the Square has resorted, however briefly, to repertory theater. You have to applaud the company for the gesture. Just because we can't afford a theatrical ideal, doesn't mean we should forget it altogether.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 5, 1992, Sunday

A review by David Richards in Arts and Leisure today about two plays in which Al Pacino is appearing on Broadway misstates their closing date. The run of the plays, "Chinese Coffee" and "Salome" at Circle in the Square, has been extended to Aug. 1.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Tax Refund for Co-op
 
Question: I live in a co-op apartment. The board recently won from the local town a real estate tax reimbursement of about $400,000. This money was put into a reserve fund. I filed a claim for my share -- $1,800 -- and was denied it.
Can the board do this? . . . Donald Forester, Scarborough Manor, N.Y.
 
Answer: Probably. According to Marc Luxemberg, a lawyer who is also a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, in most co-ops the board has no legal obligation to return an excess in taxes or in maintenance payments made by shareholders.
"In the bylaws of most co-ops," said Mr. Luxemberg, "there can be no collecting maintenance retroactively. By the same token, shareholders are not entitled to rebates when there is a surplus."
The exception would be, he said, if your co-op grants shareholders some kind of a year-end rebate. Although you will not get this in cash, you will benefit from the tax ruling because the effect will be to lower the amount that you and other owners will pay in the future.
 
Switching Apartments
 
Question: My aunt and uncle live in a rent-controlled apartment in a building that has been converted to a co-op. They have been offered a larger, vacant, rent-stabilized unit in the same building.
Would there be any risks in their moving out of their rent-controlled apartment and into the larger apartment? . . . Ellen Stern, Manhattan
 
Answer: There could be.
Under normal circumstances, when a rent-regulated apartment is vacated in a building that has been converted to a co-op, it is no longer governed by the rules of rent regulation. The sponsor or other owner has the right to sell or rent the apartment at market rates.
However, according to Joseph D'Agosta, an acting deputy commissioner for rent regulation for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, a sponsor or other owner could relinquish those rights. The owner's motivation might be that there was a buyer for the apartment that the rent-regulated tenants occupied.
In any case, your relatives must be sure that the apartment they accept will be recognized as a rent-stabilized unit by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
For further information on how to proceed, contact the state division rent administration office at 718-639-6400.
 
Deducting Workspace
 
Question: My husband and I live in a one-bedroom co-op. We both work in the apartment about 50 to 75 percent of the year. Our accountant advised us a while ago against writing off part of the apartment on our income taxes because there could be a complication when we decide to sell.
However, we have converted our bedroom entirely into workspace. It is easily one-quarter to one-third of the apartment's space.
Can we write off a portion of the mortgage against taxes? . . . Kim Hanneman, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. According to Neil O'Keeffe, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, if you use part of your home regularly and exclusively for business purposes, you may be able to deduct a part of the operating expenses on your home like mortgage, utilities, and insurance payments.
But expenses are deductible only if the space is in your principal place of business. And if you take a business deduction for anything that is also used for personal or family household purposes, such as a computer, then you must limit the deduction to that portion of the expense that is attributable only to its business use.
The complication to which your accountant referred probably had to do with depreciation rules. If you depreciate the part of your residence used for the business, it would affect your ability to postpone paying the tax on any profit when you sell.
For additional information, consult I.R.S. publication 587, Business Use of Your Home, which can be ordered by telephoning 800-829-3676.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: On the Move in Manhattan;
In a Weak Market, Alluring Lease Deals Abound

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AS millions watched the parade of tall ships up the Hudson yesterday, employees and partners at LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae were busily consolidating the operations of their diversified law firm at 125 West 55th Street.
The firm, which moved from two locations in Manhattan, is occupying 203,000 square feet on eight contiguous floors, plus a portion of the main floor and basement level. The space is about 40 percent larger than the firm's total leasing commitments in the past. 
 "Even so, our costs will actually be less," said Alan Berman, a member of the firm's administrative committee, as he extolled the virtues of making a move in a weakened marketplace.
Thus, he said, although the lease at LeBoeuf's former primary location at 520 Madison Avenue still had two years to run the opportunity was too tempting to let go. The new landlord, he said, was even willing to buy out the old lease.
Similar reasons have been cited by other commercial tenants that signed leases in Manhattan over the last 18 months, with law firms among the most active.
Leasing Trends, an annual report by Cushman & Wakefield that measures industry trends for leases in excess of 10,000 square feet, shows that in midtown almost 90 percent of the 1991 transactions involved law firms. And they have continued to dominate midtown activity in the first half of 1992, with twice as many deals as any other sector.
The survey also showed a 30 percent decline in the amount of Manhattan space leased -- 16.8 million square feet in 1991 against 21 million square feet in 1990.
Yet by mid-1992, leasing volume had picked up and was 40 percent above 1991 levels, according to a mid-year report from Edward S. Gordon Company, a commercial brokerage. So had asking rents in midtown and downtown, although rents continued their decline in Midtown South. The averages were $33.70 in midtown, $16 in Midtown South and $28.85 downtown, about 30 percent below the market peak in the late 80's.
Frederick Kane Marek, a senior vice president at Julian J. Studley, who specializes in law firms, attributes the high activity in the law sector to an opportunity to grab space in prestigious buildings at a time of increased vacancies and lowered rents. He further maintains that the frantic merry-go-round among law firms is also the result of the recent rash of mergers.
"I've seen more law firms merge in the last year or so than I've seen in the past 24," he said. When this happens, he explained, space needs change radically. And landlords have been tempting many of the new entities to stay on by offering to terminate an old lease without penalty if they are willing to take space with the same owner, even if it's in another building.
But some of the law firms, like LeBoeuf, that developed an expertise in growth areas such as bankruptcy and international commerce, have chosen to move because they have also been expanding.
Indeed, the companies that predominate in the Cushman & Wakefield report include many that have prospered during the recession.
"WHAT you are seeing is larger companies taking advantage of situations that may not come again for another 10 or 15 years," said Percy Pyne, principal in the Pyne Companies Ltd., commercial consultants and brokers. "For the really big users with offices all over town its also been a chance to set their houses in order."
The Cushman & Wakefield survey also showed high leasing activity among insurance, advertising and financial services firms. The insurance industry, for example, rose to first place in 1991 with 12.4 percent of the total leases. The year before it had been in sixth place.
Part of this had to do with the rapid expansion of health maintenance organizations. One of the major leases signed in the insurance industry, for instance, involved the move of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (HIP) into 211,000 square feet of space at 7 West 34th Street. It moved from three sites with a total of only 130,000 square feet, according to Steven Cohen, its chief operating officer.
Once again, growth was the motivating factor, together with an opportunity for consolidation at a time that the company considered "perfect" for a major space reorganization, said Mr. Cohen. "We took advantage of an ideal market to position ourselves for the future as well as for our present needs," he said.
A similar tale of expansion coupled with an opportunity for consolidation is told by Leslie C. Quick 3d, president of the Quick & Reilly Group. The company is a fast-growing firm of discount retail brokers and financial services that has benefited by shifts of money lately by an increasing number of people out of low-yielding certificates of deposit and into the financial markets.
QUICK & REILLY moved in May into 62,000 square feet at 26 Broadway and has already taken a further 5,000 square feet in the same building, said Mr. Quick. The total is about 25 percent higher than the company had previously occupied around the city, he noted, and all "for about the same cost as before."
"We particularly wanted a presence in this building and it was a wonderful chance to get in," he said, mentioning also how pleasant it was to be able to see the Statue of Liberty from his 11th floor window.
Eric Ossorio, a broker at Cushman & Wakefield who frequently works with companies that need less than 10,000 square feet of space -- companies not included in the Leasing Trends survey -- said the profile of the smaller users mirrored the larger ones. Smaller users normally account for about half of total space leased in Manhattan.
The advertising sector, he said, included newly-created spin-off partnerships of senior personnel at the larger agencies who had lost their jobs as advertising languished in the doldrums and had decided to start their own concerns. Many smaller companies in law and advertising were also on a "flight to quality" now that the costs in quality buildings were down.
Some of these smaller spaces offered particularly appealing quarters because "landlords had been stuck when a company had suddenly gone out of business," he said. He mentioned, by way of example, 6,500 square feet of what he called "drop dead" space at 135 East 57th Street with paneling, marble floors and a top-of-the-line kitchen. Once the New York headquarters of Alan Bond, the failed Australian financier, it was now on the market.
A concurrent chance to get out high-priced space was also a strong motivation to make a deal, he said, "because when you're only a small partnership your rent becomes a particularly crucial part of your overhead."

HEADLINE: A $234.6 Million Mixed-Use Tower For the West Side

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
AS backhoes clawed the earth last week near Lincoln Center, a development partnership led by Christopher M. Jeffries announced that it had raised the $234.6 million financing needed to build one of the most mixed mixed-use structures that New York City is ever likely to see.
The project, called Lincoln Square, is to have 38 floors of rental and condominium apartments. Its commercial base, which is already leased or sold, would hold 10 movie theaters, including a 900-seat house and a giant-screen Imax auditorium; a sports center; a post office and book, music, clothing and athletic apparel stores. 
 Neighbors are looking warily, even angrily, at the prospect of an 800,000-square-foot building that would rise 545 feet and fill the block from Broadway to Columbus Avenue, 67th to 68th Streets. Lincoln Square would add hundreds of residents and thousands of moviegoers, shoppers and athletes to an area that now seems close to bursting at times -- especially near curtain time.
But the developers maintain that the project can be built as a matter of right under zoning rules. The city's Buildings Department has agreed with them, approving the overall plan and granting a construction permit for the east half of the site, where work has begun.
What may be most striking about Lincoln Square is that a project of such magnitude is under way at all.
"We felt that the only way of succeeding was to surround ourselves with people who were much bigger, whose stamp of approval meant something to the other participants," said Mr. Jeffries, a partner in the development group, Millennium Partners, and general partner in Lincoln Metrocenter Partners, which owns the project.
Lincoln Metrocenter also has an option to purchase the block immediately south of the project site from Capital Cities/ABC, which owned the Lincoln Square block.
MICHAEL BAILEY, a vice president at J. P. Morgan, which is serving as financial adviser, said: "We worked to structure a transaction that was pre-bought and preleased, so investors and lenders could look at something that was quantifiable and creditworthy and removed some of the cynicism and doubt we all have in this real-estate market."
Rather than build first and market later, the developers sold or leased the entire commercial base and many of the apartments. Tenants and owners include Barnes & Noble; the Gap; Goldman, Sachs; Loews Theater Management Corporation, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment; Morgan; Reebok International; Sumitomo Real Estate Sales; Trans World Music; the United States Postal Service and the Zeckendorf Company.
A $142.5 million construction loan has come from the Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank of Munich and the Sudwestdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale of Stuttgart. And the developers secured a completion guarantee from the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company of London. This diversified international company is the parent of Lehrer McGovern Bovis, the construction manager at Lincoln Square.
The mix needed to make Lincoln Square economically possible will insure its long-range success, the developers believe. "That's the most exciting feature -- the integration of so many high-quality individuals in a single structure," said Philip E. Aarons, a partner in Millennium, who was also allied with Mr. Jeffries in the General Atlantic Realty concern. The third partner in Millennium is Philip Lovett.
Charles Lowrey, a vice president in Morgan's real estate group, said, "We tried to find a series of institutions that would be compatible partners or neighbors and that, for fundamental strategic corporate reasons, needed to be on this site."
To lure these companies, the developers offered a 55,500-square-foot, full-block site where tenants could create spaces to suit their needs, rather than squeeze into narrow confines. "It's as though Loews and Sony went to the suburbs, bought a piece of land and said, 'Here's how I'd design my business,' " Mr. Jeffries noted.
But with one critical difference -- the location. "We see this as a Lincoln Center site," Mr. Aarons said. "In our minds, it is very much an extension of Lincoln Center."
Crowded and cosmopolitan, the area mixes cultural institutions, high-rise apartment towers, restaurants and cinemas. Many who live there believe that enough has been built already and that too much is in store, when Lincoln Square is added to the Riverside South and Manhattan West projects nearby.
Lincoln Square would clearly have a profound impact. Atop an 8-story commercial base, a 38-story apartment tower would rise in mid-block. There would be 47 floors in all, including one for mechanical equipment, but at 545 feet, it would be equivalent to a 54-story apartment tower. The architects are Kohn Pedersen Fox and Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron, both of Manhattan.
On Broadway would be the entrance to the 110,000-square-foot Loews Lincoln Plaza Metroplex, including the third largest movie house in Manhattan, a 900-seat theater where Hollywood-style premieres would be staged.
"One of the reasons for the paucity of old-fashioned premieres in New York is the absence of an appropriate venue," said A. Alan Friedberg, chairman of Loews. "A venue across from Lincoln Center is more conducive for the kinds of audiences that turn out for a motion-picture premiere."
Another auditorium would have an 85-by-125-foot Imax screen. While Imax science and nature films are familiar to museum-goers, Mr. Friedberg said this 600-seat house would be the first to show commercial movies in this format. There would be four theaters with 370 seats each and four with 215 seats each, some showing art and specialty films.
Next door would be a 22,000-square-foot Barnes & Noble "superstore," which would stock up to 100,000 book titles and 1,400 periodicals, about four times more than the average Barnes & Noble store. South of that would be Gap and Gap Kids clothing stores and a 22,000-square-foot Coconuts music store, a division of Trans World Music.
The Ansonia Post Office, now on Broadway, would be moved to Columbus Avenue, where it would own and occupy 40,000 square feet. Next door would be a 12,000-square-foot Reebok store, selling athletic apparel.
TOGETHER with the manager of Sports Club/LA in Los Angeles, Reebok would run a 135,000-square-foot sports center that has been proposed. It would have a 25-meter swimming pool; basketball, volleyball and squash courts; an outdoor running track on the eighth-floor setback; weight-lifting and exercise areas and dining rooms.
"We view it as an entire laboratory," said John Frascotti, Reebok's director of licensing, "where we can talk to our customers and experiment" with new equipment.
The residential tower, entered through lobbies on 67th Street, would have four strata.
The first 6 floors, with 79 apartments, would be owned by Morgan and used to house corporate trainees and traveling executives.
The next 13 floors, with 91 apartments, would be rented by Lincoln Metrocenter.
Above that would be 56 units on 8 floors, owned by a group that the developers will identify only as Middle Eastern. These are to be used by business travelers who stay in the New York for months at a time.
At the top of the building would be 88 condomium apartments over 11 floors that are to be sold by a group whose partners are the Zeckendorf Company, Sumitomo Real Estate Sales New York and Goldman, Sachs.
That adds up to a critical mass that comforts investors but infuriates neighbors.
"The community is outraged," said Hope L. Mason, chairwoman of Community Board 7, adding that it was also frustrating because "when something is as-of-right, we don't have any say." She said the board had complained about the traffic jams, vehicular and pedestrian, that the theaters would create.
The president of the Landmark West preservation group, Arlene Simon, said that Lincoln Square would not only congest sidewalks and nearby subway stations but add to what is already "some of the worst pollution" in the city. "We are crazed by the fact that it is so insensitive," she said.
She charged that the application was "wrought with fraud," as the developers secured approval with plans that did not show the post office loading berths on 68th Street. Had they been shown, Ms. Simon said, the project would have had to go through a special-permit procedure involving community review and environmental analysis.
Mr. Aarons said that the plans did not show loading berths because "this is an issue for the city and the post office to deal with." In any event, he said, there would be "fewer loading docks than they currently have in exactly the location they're currently in."
As for traffic, Mr. Aarons said: "There are 10,000 theater seats at Lincoln Center. This is an entertainment environment. The building has been designed with extensive interior waiting areas and ticket areas, so there will not be large numbers of people on the streets. This will fit into the environment."
Zoning at the site permits a building 10 times the lot size, or 555,000 square feet. The developers also get a 20 percent "inclusionary housing" bonus, or 111,000 square feet, for having built low-income apartments at 123 West 104th Street and 171 West 107th Street. Another 111,000 square feet is below grade and not counted for zoning purposes. The remainder is mechanical space.
The 107th Street building, developed by General Atlantic, has 15 stories and 25 apartments. It generated 169,000 square feet of bonus space, 21,000 of which are applied to Lincoln Square. The 104th Street building, which Mr. Jeffries and Daniel Brodsky developed, has 11 stories and 56 apartments. It generated a 90,000-square-foot bonus.
THE developers of Lincoln Square also hope to take advantage of two types of tax benefits, both the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program and the Section 421-a program for residential construction.
They need authorization from the State Legislature to do so, because mixed-use projects were not eligible for tax deferrals under the commercial program as of December, when the developers applied. And no benefits are to be given for new commercial construction in Manhattan after December, under legislation proposed by city officials.

HEADLINE: Talking: Contractors;
Avoiding Pitfalls On Loans

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
WHEN Patricia Grimes, a home health aide, decided two years ago to put a porch on her Victorian home in Newark she was overjoyed to learn about a remodeling company that would also provide financing. "I don't earn very much," she said, "so I knew I would have had difficulty getting a loan on my own."
But Miss Grimes has found herself locked into monthly installments of $520 for the next 18 years (a total of $112,320), a much heavier and longer-term debt than she had originally been told was needed to repay the $35,000 she was borrowing. Moreover, she now fears it could cost her the house if she falls behind. 
 Miss Grimes is one of about 100,000 homeowners in 20 states that the Massachusetts Attorney General's office estimates are trapped in this latest contractor fraud -- unscrupulous financing. Massachusetts has had a severe outbreak.
Anyone considering allowing a contractor to finance as well as carry out a job should should check the company's reputation with regulatory authorities before making a commitment, officials say. And a more sophisticated outsider, preferably a lawyer, should look at any papers before they are signed. Even a seemingly innocent-looking application should be examined carefully because many defrauded homeowners have reported that they were led to believe they were signing only a loan application or work order.
"They rush you into signing before you know what's happening," Miss Grimes said.
Some homeowners say they were never even told the loan would put a lien on their homes or the terms would be different from what they had been led to expect. This was done, officials later discovered, by leaving some blank spaces and filling these in after the forms had been signed.
"If you know you can't get the kind of money you need on your own, it should be a warning to you to take a closer look at what you are being offered," said Bob Lippmann, president of the Long Island chapter of the National Association of the Remodeling Industry and the owner of HIS Inc., a remodeling company in Melville, L.I.
Normally, homeowners do best by getting their own financing, which lets them control disbursement of funds and make sure the work is satisfactory before releasing any. The most popular way is an equity loan, because the interest payments are deductible from taxable income, but some bankers have been tightening their requirements for such loans as recession makes incomes fall and property values sag.
"With money tight, many people can't afford to fix up their homes," said Emma Byrne, New Jersey's Director of Consumer Affairs. "These companies know this and deliberately set out to lure them into contracts that promise home repairs for easy credit."
Others say the growth of these schemes is equally symptomatic of an increase in non-English-speaking homeowners who may not be knowledgeable or alert to such practices.
In one pending Connecticut case, Luis and Dalila Montes, a couple from Puerto Rico, were offered a loan to help pay for vinyl siding on their home in New Haven. Folded into the offer was cash to pay off other loans.
In Miss Grimes's case, she conceded that an extra $14,000 the company was willing to lend her -- seemingly irrespective of her ability to make the payments -- became an added inducement. "I didn't even get any other estimates," she said.
Officials also believe the rise of these frauds may reflect growing competition among remodelers, a result of the decline of new residential construction that has left many builders and carpenters in need of alternative work.
THE contractor in Miss Grimes's case, Maywood Builders of Bogota, N.J., was charged in January with inducing homeowners to sign blank contracts, failing to disclose the total amount involved, understating the monthly installments and falsifying the true cost of the job along with the value of the home to get the necessary extended credit. Maywood has denied all this.
If the state wins, the contracts signed by Miss Grimes and others will be rescinded and they may be allowed to halt payments.
Contractors have been charged with similar schemes in Alabama, Arizona, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Kentucky, Missouri, Michigan, Maryland, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Virginia and Washington, according to the Boston tally.
"It's become a national problem," said Elizabeth Bradford, assistant attorney general in charge of the Nassau regional office in Mineola, L.I.
Ms. Bradford has been working on an alleged scam involving The Dartmouth Plan of Garden City, L.I., which, she maintained, acted as a sort of clearing house, setting up financing schemes for many contractors in the area. Dartmouth, which has also denied all charges, also operated throughout Connecticut.
Anyone who has signed for contractor-related financing in the last few years and is still making payments should find out if the company, or any lender to which payments are currently being made, has since been indicted or named in a suit. This can be done by calling the local office of the state's department of Consumer Affairs or Attorney General's office (found in the Blue Pages of the telephone book).
Citibank, for example, which eventually became the purchaser and servicing company for some of the loans initiated through Dartmouth (but was never directly involved in the scam) has agreed to assist its defrauded homeowners by lifting the liens on their homes and providing a cash payment towards the outstanding debt, said Ms. Bradford.
The 235 or so eligible homeowners holding Citibank loans will be notified this summer. In Massachusetts, Fleet/Norstar, Baybank and Shawmut are offering similar concessions.
Ms. Bradford recommended that anyone paying off contractor financing check with the local land records' office to see if a lien has been placed on the property -- even if a lien was not supposed to be part of the deal. She also recommended consulting a lawyer. The liens could have been fraudulently obtained or there could be other technical errors in the loan agreement, she said, which might make the agreements eligible for cancellation.
If so, she said, the homeowner would owe only the outstanding principal balance and be entitled to a refund of any interest paid to date. A homeowner has three years from the date the loan agreement was signed to apply to the courts for a recision, she said.

HEADLINE: Housing Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on April 5 headed "New York Slashing an Array of Programs" paints a distressing scenario for one of the most impressive government-led efforts since the New Deal. 
 New York City's 10-Year Housing Plan represents perhaps the most sensible, well-conceived government program now under way in our country, a plan -- unusually enough -- that has been delivering far beyond its original promises.
Responding to a critical housing shortage, the city since 1986 has pumped hundreds of millions of dollars into the production and preservation of thousands of units of decent, affordable housing for renters and homeowners alike. Encouraged by the city's commitment, other important players have entered the fray: national nonprofits like the Enterprise Foundation, Local Initiatives Support Corporation and the Low Income Housing Fund; financial institutions such as Bankers Trust, Chemical Banking Corporation and the Community Preservation Corporation; even corporations traditionally not involved in financing housing, like Pfizer, American Express and the Continental Corporation.
These segments of the business and philanthropic community have joined in direct partnership with the myriad not-for-profit community development corporations that have proliferated in our city's neighborhoods.
New homes are springing up, fed by millions of dollars from public, private and philanthropic sources. Construction workers grateful for the opportunity to work in these hard times pour their best into their labors. Area suppliers revel in the purchased materials going into the newly constructed and rehabilitated homes. Homeless families move into new permanent homes while longtime renters feel the joy as first-time home buyers.
Commercial strips are revitalized in pursuit of new residents needing local goods and services. And neighborhoods taste the gifts of stabilization and renewed private investment. These are the ingredients of a vibrant economy, the foundation for a growing tax base, the antitoxin for a depressed economy.
If our nation offers a better example of a workable recession fighter than the city's 10-Year Housing Plan, I have yet to see it. Hard budgetary realities are upon us, to be sure. But in terms of its multiplier effect, economic and social, and its sheer success in fulfilling its objectives, this is one effort that should be zealously guarded.
 
JAN C. CHILDRESS
 
The writer is administrator of the area development fund of Brooklyn Union Gas.

HEADLINE: Rent-Loan Fund Expanding to Manhattan

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
A NEW, privately financed program that pays the back rents of Westchester County tenants facing imminent eviction is planning to expand to New York City this fall.
The 18-month-old program, the Bridge Fund, hopes to raise $150,000 for a nine-month trial period in a Manhattan neighborhood, which has not yet been selected. Fund-raising efforts are to begin this summer. 
 "What we are trying to do is set up a private financial safety net for the working poor," said Oscar S. Pollack, an investment adviser with Ingalls & Snyder in Manhattan and co-founder of the Bridge Fund.
The fund works by giving renters grants or no-interest loans with flexible repayment arrangements if they are in danger of becoming homeless. The money from the loans or grants is sent directly to third parties, such as landlords or public utilities.
To get a grant or loan for back or current rent -- or for a security deposit -- a family must be referred by a social service organization or religious institution; no walk-ins or telephone inquiries by tenants are accepted. The fund also helps a limited number of families and individuals move out of public shelters into permanent housing. There is no dollar limit on loans or grants, though most are under $2,000.
"What we are facing is, in many cases, a small difference between success and failure," Mr. Pollack said. "These are the working poor, and they just can't scrape up $800 or $1,000, and they have no access to credit."
He said that a director for the New York City program, Anna Fisch, was appointed last month. She is a co-founder of the Children's Hope Foundation, a pediatric AIDS volunteer organization.
He added that although the program has been successful in Westchester County, the demand for loans and grants in New York could easily overwhelm the tiny fund. That is why -- in the beginning, at least -- it will be limited to one neighborhood, as yet undetermined.
"We may also only take referrals from one or two community organizations at first," Mr. Pollack said.
The Bridge Fund was designed in May 1990 by the Rev. Peter R. Larom, rector of Grace Church in White Plains, in response to growing concerns about suburban homelessness and the strain the problem was placing on local taxpayers.
The fund raised money through churches, synagogues, corporations, foundations and private contributions. It began operation in January 1991, and in its first year raised $192,909 and disbursed $96,463 in loans and grants to 108 families and individuals in Westchester County. The balance was carried over into 1992; fund expenses for 1991 totaled about $45,000.
Of the 108 disbursements in 1991, 92 were made to prevent evictions or foreclosures, four were made to relocate people into less expensive housing and 12 were made to move families out of public shelters into permanent housing.
So far this year, the fund has made $49,700 in loans and grants to 66 families in the county. "Our projection is that we will go to $120,000 this year," said Stanley Schear, the director of the fund.
There is no means test for recipients except that they have nowhere else to turn for financial assistance and are in danger of becoming homeless. Many of the recipients are renters with low incomes and small children. Several others, however, have been small-business people who own their homes and were in danger of being foreclosed on.
"This is the first recession that has really hit the white-collar worker," Mr. Pollack said. "And as soon as they are hit with a crisis, they are in a position where they might fall over the cliff immediately."
The fund often requires clients to undergo financial counseling that includes bringing in their pay checks and making out their checks for rent and utilities in the presence of a counselor.
THERE are numerous other organizations in the New York region that offer assistance to renters who are about to be evicted. They include the Homeless Prevention Program in Passaic County, N.J., the Salvation Army and the Red Cross. They all differ from the Bridge Fund, however, in that they either receive Federal, state or local funds, make grants rather than loans, or they do not operate solely to prevent evictions.
"They don't do what we do, but they sometimes do something that is similar," Mr. Schear said. "For a lot of them, though, it is just a sideline, something that comes out of petty cash. They don't do things like offering financial counseling."
"Eighty percent of the people who come in here mismanage their money," he added.
Mara Perez is a typical recipient of a Bridge Fund loan. She lives in Yonkers and is a mother of a 10-year-old son and a 6-year-old daughter. She arrived at the Bridge Fund offices on Aug. 15 with an eviction notice in hand, having been made aware of the program by a local social services counselor.
Fund officials analyzed her finances and determined that she was not managing her limited income properly; she receives Federal disability checks for herself and one of her children that total about $1,000 a month. They noted that her cable television bill and monthly rental fees for a VCR, stereo and a television exceeded her rent.
She received intensive counseling and agreed to allow fund officials to restructure her budget, getting rid of the rented equipment and buying minimal amounts of lower- priced items. She was also encouraged to supplement her disability and child-support income by starting a day-care business, taking care of working women's infants in her home.
When she agreed, the fund bought her a new crib and a playpen so she could qualify for network referrals, and last fall she opened for business, taking care of one child five days a week. The job also enables her to stay at home with her children and maintain a more stable household.
"It's a great program," Miss Perez said. "They didn't say anything about paying it back."
Clients are encouraged to pay back loans, if and when they can. In 1991, loans totaling $18,835 were paid back to the fund.
"It is an indication to us that people are trying to be responsible," Mr. Pollack said. "This is not a welfare program."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Employment: Not Great, but Not Horrible

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
More people were working in America in June than in any month since the end of 1990.
If that's not what you thought you read in the papers last week, don't worry. It isn't. The report that employment plunged in June, with nonfarm payrolls declining by 117,000, helped to persuade the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates yet again and spurred more talk about a "triple-dip" recession. 
 In reality, however, there were 457,000 more people employed in June than in May.
The difference between those two figures -- aside from the obvious political implications -- is seasonal adjustment. The Government figures that employment levels should increase sharply in June, with school out for the summer and a new crop of graduates available to work. And it figures the numbers should drop in the fall and again in the winter, because school resumes and some seasonal jobs end with the cold weather. So it adjusts the numbers to take into effect those seasonal factors, and the adjusted numbers are the ones that get the publicity.
It is hardly surprising that businesses are hiring fewer summer workers this year or that graduates are having a tougher time finding employment than their older siblings did a few years back. But the seasonal adjustments assume that this year is no different from any other.
In sum, the economy is neither doing as well as some statistics earlier this year seemed to indicate nor as badly as June's have scared people into believing. This is a stuttering recovery, far weaker than normal, with a decided deflationary tinge, and the Fed is following rates down, not leading them in that direction. "I don't think the Fed did anything more than confirm what the money markets were saying," said Chuck Clough, Merrill Lynch's chief equity strategist.
History and most economists argue that lower rates will eventually get the economy moving. But there are differences in this economy from previous ones. Weaponry used to be a reliable and stable industry; now there are huge layoffs of well-paid workers at Hughes Aircraft. State and local governments are slashing payrolls and forcing current workers to accept smaller paychecks. Politicians fear that tax increases will destroy their re-election chances, and many companies are finding that price increases are no easier to impose.
Last December, lower interest rates sparked a stock-buying panic among individual investors, and it could happen again, especially considering the large cash positions that have built up in mutual funds. But bonds look like a far safer investment. Mr. Clough has a point when he says it is hard to envision the kind of credit demand that will drive rates up.
The real message of the economic statistics last week is that this recovery is not going to be a great one, at least not anytime soon. But the numbers do not mean that the sky is falling or that a new recession is about to begin.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Rain in Spain, and Elsewhere

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
It was an unhappy time in world stock markets as the first half of the year ended.
Markets in Spain, Italy and Norway were at 1992 lows. In Japan, the Nikkei index was hovering around its lowest level in six years. The British rally that came after the election of Prime Minister John Major had lost its footing; the Financial Times index was 7.9 percent off its 1992 peak and at its lowest level since the election. Germany and France had retreated from recent highs. And the Mexican stock market miracle had, at least temporarily, unraveled. 
 There is new worry abroad about the economic outlook. It does not look as if the German Bundesbank will ease interest rates soon. The economic recovery in Britain, like the one in the United States, is showing disturbing signs of weakness. In the United States the surprising drop in nonfarm jobs in June helped to persuade the Federal Reserve to cut the discount rate and the Federal funds rate by half a percentage point on Thursday.
The only recent good news for investors is that the Hong Kong stock market, the top performer of the year, continues to chug along to all-time highs. It is up 46.5 percent for the first half of the year.
In addition, the fall of the dollar, which is down sharply against most major currencies since mid-April, has meant that Americans who sold foreign stocks received a nice boost when their proceeds were converted back into dollars. The Financial Times index of world markets registered a decline of 2.8 percent in the second quarter, but this was equal to an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in terms of the United States dollar.
In this summer slump, Henry B. W. de Vismes, the head of international investments at Citibank Global Asset Management North America, is resting a little easier than some other money managers.
He is a stock picker, focusing on companies that he expects to show strong growth in the next two to three years. The ups and downs of markets and the economic outlooks for the countries they are in concern him less than the prospects of individual companies. He believes he can find good bets in any cycle. And the retreat of markets now provides Mr. de Vismes with the opportunity to pick up some of his favorites like Mexico's telephone company, Telmex, for a little less. "You can always find value, even in an uncertain macroeconomic climate," he said.
Mr. de Vismes starts by looking for companies whose growth in earnings per share is projected to outperform the average for their home stock markets for the next two or three years. But he won't buy a stock -- even when its growth potential is rosy -- if its ratio of earnings per share to the stock price is more than 10 percent above the market average.
This gives him a portfolio of about 70 stocks that on average have a projected 1992 earnings growth rate of 19.5 percent, compared with a local market average of 1.5 percent. The portfolio's price-earnings ratio is 14.6, compared with an average of 26.6 for the markets over all.
The Landmark International Equity Fund, a small mutual fund he manages that reflects the investment decisions he makes for many of Citibank's private clients, is up 4.5 percent through June 30. Because he picks individual stocks instead of national markets, he has 18 percent of his money in Japan. This is actually a rather high percentage compared with many other managers who have given up on Japan for the time being. He has 52 percent in Europe, 11 percent in Latin America and the rest in Asia.
Mr. de Vismes's strategy requires discipline on several counts. He has to be willing to hold a stock for some time to get the expected gains. At the same time, Mr. de Vismes does not want to risk being too greedy. So he sets a threshold for reviewing his holdings. When a stock's price-earnings ratio gets to 10 percent above the market average, it is reviewed. Unless there is a special factor accounting for this rise -- like a takeover bid or new and higher earnings -- it is sold.
Living with this long-term strategy is still not easy, partly because projected earnings growth may not show up in the stock price very quickly. Still, while some stocks in the Citibank portfolio are not living up to expectations, they have done better than the average performance for the markets in which they are traded.
For example, Aoyama Trading, a discount retail outlet in Japan that Mr. de Vismes began buying in March, closed at 7,500 yen on Friday. That is down 5.7 percent for the year, but it is far better than the performance of the blue-chip Nikkei index, which is off 27.3 percent, or the broader Topix index, which is off 24.6 percent. But, at the same time, the stock is down 17 percent from its 1992 high of 9,050 yen in February.
Albert Fisher, a British food retailer, has yet to show its promise. Mr. de Vismes began buying the stock in the middle of last year and kept buying through March. The stock was at around 115 pence a share last July but has fallen since then, hitting a 1992 low of 58 pence in February. It struggled back to 83 pence in May, but closed on Friday at 68 pence.
"I am not a market timer," he said, explaining why he does not worry about missing what might be temporary highs.
One of the very successful bets has been the News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, which trades in Australia and has an American Depository Receipt on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite the recent retreat in the Australian and American markets, the News Corporation is up 38 percent, closing in New York on Thursday at $31.875, far outperforming both markets.
