LENGTH: 2090 words

HEADLINE: America, Land of the Long-Term Financing for Foreigners

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Showing that a pullback in 1990 was only a pause, foreign corporations have resumed their rush to the United States to sell tens of billions of dollars worth of stock and bonds to American investors.
The issuers include British biotechnology companies; Spanish and Portuguese banks; Argentine, Mexican and British phone companies; Venezuelan paper, petrochemical and metal concerns; French oil companies; Indian textile, metals and petrochemical companies, and Japanese and South Korean electronics giants. 
 The renewed interest in the United States is part of a larger trend: companies, governments and supranational organizations like the World Bank are increasingly peddling big blocks of securities around the world. They are aiming in the equity markets for the highest possible prices, and in the bond markets for the lowest-possible interest rate on the longest-possible maturity.
"You want to turn over as many rocks as you can to make sure you achieve the maximum possible demand," said Robert K. Steel, a managing director at Goldman Sachs International Ltd., the American investment bank's London-based arm.
This is happening as competition for capital intensifies while banks remain stubbornly hesitant to lend. Demand for capital is growing among everyone from Eastern Europeans, who need to rebuild their economies, to Western European, Latin American and Asian governments selling state-owned companies.
In scrambling to expand their sources of supply, all naturally look to the United States, the world's largest and most sophisticated market.
Analysts blame the 1990 decline in foreign securities sales in the United States on the uncertainty generated by the Persian Gulf War and a pause in sales of state-owned companies. But in 1991, the sale of foreign shares in public and private deals doubled, to a record $9.78 billion, according to the London-based IFR Securities Data Company. Bond deals rose 48 percent, to $55.33 billion.
Based on results so far this year, investment bankers think the 1992 totals will at least match and probably exceed last year's.
What makes the United States markets so attractive? Largely, an easing of disclosure rules, low interest rates and increasingly adventuresome American investors.
"U.S. institutional and retail investors have over the past 18 months become very avid buyers of foreign equities and bonds," said Julian Summer, a managing director at London-based Merrill Lynch International Ltd. "This is a major sea change."
Merrill Lynch expects the value of foreign securities held by Americans to increase to $875 billion in the year 2000; that would be up from $275 billion in 1991 and just $120 billion in 1985. One reason is the increase in mutual funds in the United States that invest in foreign securities. As of May, the assets of stock funds that invest largely outside the United States stood at $41.8 billion, more than twice the level at the end of 1988, and assets of global bond funds have soared to $28.5 billion from just $3 billion in 1988.
The regulatory atmosphere in the United States has become more friendly with the easing of disclosure rules under Rule 144A, which the Securities and Exchange Commission introduced in 1990. Foreigners can now sell securities to big institutional investors, disclosing only the data required in their home markets.
For American investors, who have long been more receptive to a wider range of stocks and bonds than their foreign counterparts, the rush of foreign offerings has meant new opportunities to increase their returns -- something many have been seeking as falling interest rates have reduced their bond returns.
Investment bankers point to some interesting plays among recent foreign issues, particularly European and Latin American telephone companies, French oil companies like Total and Elf-Aquitaine and a German software company named SAP.
There has been an especially noticeable rise in the number of European companies and banks issuing debt and preferred shares, including Sweden's SKF and Electrolux, France's Banque Paribas and Britain's British Petroleum, Grand Metropolitan and British Aerospace. Many now have big United States operations and prefer to borrow for them in dollars.
Even foreign companies without American operations are being drawn to the United States. These borrowers, especially those without top credit ratings, have found that the cost of selling dollar-denominated debt in the United States -- that is, the interest-rate level -- is lower than in the Euromarket, which remains unreceptive to corporate issues rated below single-A.
Borrowers can also obtain maturities of up to 30 years in the United States compared with an effective maximum of 10 years in the Euromarket. This has become increasingly important to companies like Grand Metropolitan that are worried about the long-term availability of capital.
Grand Met, the British food, drinks and restaurant giant that owns Pillsbury and Burger King, raised $900 million in the United States last year by selling equal amounts of 5-, 10- and 20-year bonds. It used the proceeds to replace short-term borrowings.
"We wouldn't have been able to achieve that in the Eurobond market," said Simon D. A. Martin, Grand Met's assistant group treasurer. "We may go back to the U.S."
By giving foreign companies more flexibility, the burgeoning world of interest-rate and currency swaps has also encouraged foreign companies to exploit the advantages that borrowing in dollars in the United States might have over another market at a given time. A company can issue fixed-rate dollar-denominated bonds, then through swaps, choose alternative payment patterns -- ending up, for example, paying floating interest rates in Japanese yen, and the principal in British pounds.
Companies have also discovered it can pay to look abroad for capital because different types of securities may be more highly valued in one country than another. This helps explain why two British biotech companies, British Bio-technology Group and Cantab Pharmaceuticals, are interested in the United States.
In the United States, plenty of investors are willing to buy shares of biotechnology companies that not only have never made any money but have yet to bring a product to market. Although the London Stock Exchange is considering making an exception for biotechnology companies, companies generally cannot obtain an exchange listing until they have a five-year profit record.
Barring a sudden collapse, the overall value of deals in the international equities market seems set to pass the $19.4 billion worth of shares sold in public offerings in 1991. So far this year, companies have sold $14 billion worth outside their home markets, according to Securities Data. That is already more than the $12 billion sold in all of 1990.
Getting into the global market themselves, American companies have sold $5.7 billion worth of common and preferred shares in public offerings outside the United States this year, meaning the 1992 total is certain to exceed the $6 billion in 1991.
However, although investment bankers are confident of strong long-term growth, there are some signs that the international market may be losing a bit of steam. They include the recent withdrawal of an $800 million to $1.06 billion initial public offering by GPA Group P.L.C., an Ireland-based aircraft lessor, after institutional investors in Europe, the United States and Japan expressed little interest. American companies that have postponed deals include Payless Cashways, Gulfstream Aerospace, Franklin Mint and Trident NGL.
GPA's withdrawal may have been an anomaly. Some apparent reasons were concerns about its high debt level, the fragile health of its airline customers throughout the world and the lack of a big home market to serve as a base for the offering.
Investment bankers blame the general pullback on the recent weakening of American and European stock markets and the continuing slide in the Tokyo market, reflecting investor nervousness about those economies. A slide in the Mexican stock market has also deflated what had been one of the hottest international sectors: Mexican stocks.
The bankers, pointing to some post-GPA successes as proof, are confident that planned sales of relatively high-quality shares will go ahead. Delta Air Lines raised $1.15 billion through an international sale of 23 million convertible preferred shares, 10 percent of which was sold abroad. And the French Government's offer of 22.9 million shares in Total, for about $1 billion, was oversubscribed.
Wellcome Trust, a charitable trust that owns 73.5 percent of Wellcome P.L.C., the British drug company, seems confident about international demand for shares it plans to sell in late July. It says its investment bankers believe they can smarket 330 million to 380 million shares, worth $5.42 billion to $6.24 billion at current market prices. Some 80 million shares are earmarked for the United States.
Even if some sellers have to accept lower prices, many investment bankers are confident the international equity market will pick up steam within a few months. "It's a comma and not a full stop," Charles G. T. Stonehill, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, said of the current slowdown.
Indeed, bankers say plenty of the forces that have been behind the rise in international securities deals in general and foreign sales in the United States in particular are still there.
Sellers often have no choice now but to try more than one market. The size of many issues dwarfs their home market's capacity.
A large number of foreign offerings also have involved governments selling all or part of their shares in state-owned companies. The pioneer in such privatizations in the 1980's, Britain, was also the pioneer in international stock offerings. Many proved to be very lucrative for buyers.
But the market really began to soar in the last few years when Latin Americans, led by Mexico, began to do the same. The deal widely seen as having kicked off a flood of international sales was the $2.17 billion sale of shares in the Mexican phone company, Telefonos de Mexico, last year. Goldman Sachs oversaw it.
Investment bankers point out that the privatization boom shows no signs of abating in Europe, Asia or Latin America.
It is also expected that American companies will continue to spin off foreign units in international offers to exploit the higher value investors sometimes place on their individual parts than on their whole. One example was the April sale of Waste Management Inc.'s European unit, orchestrated by Merrill Lynch.
In addition, many American and some British companies that loaded up with debt in the 1980's or early 1990's are now trying to reduce it, or replace it with cheaper debt. These include companies that went private via leveraged buyouts and have recently gone public with international equity offerings, like America's Duracell, Burlington and RJR Nabisco. A planned public offering by Revlon is expected to be international, too.
There is also no sign that banks around the world will open up the lending spigots anytime soon. Indeed, many banks are trying to raise capital themselves to shore up their own balance sheets.
And Japanese companies must soon begin to refinance billions of dollars worth of bonds that were sold with equity warrants attached. Because of the plunging Japanese market, many warrants have been worthless when they expired. That has left these companies in need of equity to strengthen their balance sheets. It also has deflated the market for such bonds, generating speculation that Japanese companies could turn to international equity and bond issues.
"As the Japanese market moves down to a level of valuation comparable to other markets, Japanese stocks will become increasingly attractive to international investors," Mr. Stonehill said.
The importance of the United States to foreigners seeking capital helps to explain why American investment banks dominate the international stock and bond business. These firms -- including Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Salomon Brothers and Lehman Brothers -- have vastly expanded their foreign presence in the last five years or so.
Paying homage to this dominance, British firms like Warburg, Robert Fleming and Barclays de Zoete Wedd, have been recruiting talent from them. "Our aim is to join the club," said Ian Hannam, a Fleming director who had been at Salomon.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1746 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 28 - July 3

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Fed's Short-Term Medicine for the Economy's Long-Term Ills 

 It was a tough couple of weeks to be Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. The Bush Administration's heaviest hitters -- including the President -- took turns trying to persuade Mr. Greenspan to bring down interest rates. The Fed finally caved in last week, trimming the discount rate to 3 percent from 3.5 percent, after a sharp rise in unemployment and a bevy of lackluster economic statistics revealed that the economy was going nowhere, at best. But not every economist agrees the Fed's prescription will rid the economy of its problems. "What is inhibiting the economy is not the level of interest rates," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. "The economy is being held back by structural impediments," including lots of corporate and consumer debt. Finessing interest rates is more suited, he said, to smoothing the ups and downs of the business cyclethan fixing long-term ills.
 
Unemployment's K.O. Punch
 
When the Labor Department said unemployment shot up to 7.8 percent in June from 7.5 percent in May, it set the economy trembling. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 23.81 points, to 3,330.29, on the news, and bond prices shot up. Economists were stunned to find that, on a seasonally adjusted basis, 117,000 people had been trimmed from the nation's June payrolls. Their consensus forecast was that unemployment would fall. "It was a real one-two punch," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. "I was just working on my mid-year review with a prognosis of positive, slow growth. These numbers are so shocking, now I don't know if I'll stay with that."
 
Half a Jobless Program?
 
With 10 million Americans out of work -- and the jobless-benefits bill about to expire -- House and Senate negotiators met last week to hammer out a compromise to extend jobless benefits. The measure, which passed overwhelmingly in the House and Senate, extends worker benefits for up to 26 weeks. President Bush said he will sign the $5.5 billion measure as soon as it reaches his desk. But he chastised Congress for not passing his economic stimulus package. "The president's program is dead in the water," said Norman Ornstein, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. "At some point, Congress will move to a substantial infrastructure and jobs program, but it can't happen until after the election."

Confidence Refuses to Budge
 
After showing steady improvement for three straight months, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index remained virtually unchanged at 71.7 in June. It was 71.9 in May. In 1985, the index, which measures how upbeat consumers feel about the economy and their job prospects for the future, was 100. The index is considered a reliable forecasting tool of future economic behavior. "We've had this before in recessions -- good gains for a couple of months then it flattens out," said Fabian Linden, director of the survey. "I'm not terribly pessimistic. But if we get another report like this one in July, I'd be concerned the recovery is petering out."
 
The Prime Falls in Line
 
The Fed led the way last week when it whacked half a point from the discount rate. That move was quickly followed by the nation's largest commercial banks, which trimmed the prime rate to 6 percent from 6.5 percent. Since the spread between the rate at which the banks borrow and lend will remain the same, the drop in the prime is not expected to affect the banks' bottom lines.

Forecast: More of the Same
 
If the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators is any guage at all, the economy will remain a 98-pound weakling for some time to come. The index, which forecasts economic activity six to nine months in the future, expanded by six-tenths of a percent last month, the fifth increase in a row but a wimpish one at that. Such lackluster growth has economists worried. "The recovery still looks rather fragile," said Norman Robertson at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Jump-Starting Japan's Economy
 
When Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa arrived in Washington for talks with President Bush, he was all smiles. To put some snap in Japan's sagging economy, Mr. Miyazawa said he would use "every possible means." Then he outlined to Mr. Bush details of a $48 billion to $55 billion supplemental budget intended to move Japan from near-zero growth to 3.5 percent by the end of the year. Faster growth will shrink Japan's huge trade surpluses, he said, by increasing domestic demand. Tokyo's surpluses are certain to be a topic at this week's economic summit in Munich. But while Mr. Bush said he was "encouraged," economists here and in Japan were skeptical about the plan. The spending "package is so vague that we can't see how it could stimulate domestic demand," said Masaru Takagi, chief economist at Fuji Research Institute in Tokyo.

McDonnell's Two China Policy
 
While the McDonnell Douglas Corporation was busy trying to sell a stake in itself to an investor group from Taiwan that includes the Government, the company's commercial airplane manufacturing group was equally busy stitching together a deal to assemble planes in China -- Taiwan's historic rival. Last week, McDonnell said its China program had paid off. It will supply China with 40 mid-range jetliners in a deal worth more than $1 billion, with the possibility of selling the country 130 additional planes by mid-decade. The planes -- twin-engine MD-80's and MD-90's -- will be assembled in China with components from the United States and Canada. The Boeing Company also competed for the the deal.

Norway Abandons Whaling Ban
 
Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway used to be known as the environmental prime minister; she was chairwoman of a United Nations commission on that topic. But last week she jumped to the other side when she said Norway, along with 15 other nations, would no longer abide by the moratorium on hunting minke whales. Though environmentalists dispute it, Norway contends minke whales are no longer endangered.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Saving the Endangered Osprey
 
Though they call the V-22 the "Osprey," for months it appeared that this awkward-looking, tilt-wing whirlybird would never get off the ground. The Osprey, which is made by Bell Helicopter Textron in Fort Worth and Boeing Helicopters in Delaware County, Pa., has been the subject of a tug-of-war between Congress and the Pentagon. Congress wanted to build 500 Ospreys, which take off like helicopters but fly like airplanes, for $30 billion. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the aircraft was too costly and too heavy; he wanted to kill it. But high-tech weapons built in states with large electoral votes are difficult to cut outin an election year. Last week, Mr. Cheney agreed to a compromise: $1.5 billion would be set aside to develop the Osprey.

Chrysler's New Gamble
 
Much of the redesign work at the Chrysler Corporation has been internal -- layoffs and a massive realignment of its development, engineering, manufacturing and purchasing operations. But while management was doing its thing, the designers were doing theirs. Last week the first bright-red fruits of the engineers' labors rolled off the line: the Eagle Vision, one of Chrysler's new LH models. Analysts were impressed with the car. "If they're a dud, every one of us who's ever seen this car, driven it, wrote about it or touched it is going to be wrong," said Joseph Phillippi, an analyst at Lehman Brothers Inc.

Mr. Perot Takes on a Bank
 
When still-undeclared presidential candidate Ross Perot went on TV last week to answer questions, he noted that the biggest American bank was only the 21st largest in the world. He didn't name the bank but the nation's biggest is Citibank. Then he said: "If you ever take the third world loans that'll never be paid out, it's insolvent." That was refuted by the Comptroller of the Currency, a bank regulator. Not unusually, Mr. Perot had put his money where his mouth was. His most recent financial disclosure statement showed he had sold short about $1 million of Citibank stock, meaning he stands to gain from a fall in its price.

A New Face at The New Yorker
 
Last week, when S. I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of Advance Publications, named Tina Brown as The New Yorker's new editor, it unsettled the literary community. Ms. Brown, a powerhouse in publishing, is editor of Vanity Fair. But while The New Yorker is witty, literary and wise -- some also say stodgy -- Vanity Fair is racy and hot. The New Yorker, once a mailbox-stuffer with 4,300 ad pages in 1981, had only 2,001 ad pages last year. Ms. Brown made Vanity Fair a hit, but what will she do to The New Yorker? "She'll treat the magazine's heritage tenderly," said Martin S. Walker, president of Periodical Studies Service, a magazine consulting firm. "But you'll see more younger writers, and she'll make it appeal to a younger audience, which is where its subscription growth has to come from."
 
The White House Stops a Sale
 
When a Federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan approved the sale last spring of the missile division of the bankrupt LTV Corporation to Thomson-CSF for $300 million, the losing bidders, the Lockheed Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation mounted a campaign to stop the deal. Thomson-CSF, which is French, is partly owned by the Government. The losing bidders warned that American missile technology could pass into foreign hands. Last week a Bush Administration panel recommended blocking the sale, saying there was no way to protect the technology.
 
Hughes' Woes Give G.M. a Loss
 
When the General Motors Corporation bought the Hughes Aircraft Company for $5.2 billion in 1986, it did so to diversify into a business that was a little less cyclical than automobiles. Trouble is, Hughes' main customer, the Pentagon, has been cutting its budget ever since the Soviet Union collapsed. Hughes said it will lay off 9,000 employees and take after-tax charges of $789.4 million in the second quarter. The charges mean G.M. is "looking toward a net loss of $250 million," said Harvey Heinback, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
 
Last week Braniff International Airlines shut down, the first victim of the airfare wars.

HEADLINE: Stop Ticketing Nudists In East Hampton

 BODY:
The use of "undercover" police officers to arrest nude sunbathers on the village beaches in East Hampton ["All Nudes Off the Beach," "Long Island Journal," May 31] is a misguided effort to enforce an archaic law. Nude recreation is becoming increasingly popular nationwide. The vast majority of those who enjoy nude beaches have shown consistent respect for the rights of non-nudist beachgoers. On Long Island, this is most apparent at Fire Island National Seashore, where nudists actively cooperate with National Park Service officials to preserve clothing-optional use of the Lighthouse Beach area.
The Naturist Society, a national nudist organization, has begun efforts to amend the New York State "exposure of a person" law, a poorly drafted statute that prohibits all public nudity. The proposed change would allow nude recreational activity where appropriate while continuing to ban lewd and disorderly conduct. 
 Police Chief Glen Stonemetz should take his cue from these developments. Instead of harassing nude sunbathers, help establish a rapport among nudist and non-nudist beachgoers and local residents. Instead of inciting beachfront confrontation, use communication and cooperation to address the complaints and concerns of all parties. Focus enforcement upon those who abuse the right to nude recreation, not upon those who seek only to enjoy it.
Such a policy would yield significant fringe benefit. Rather than take their business elsewhere, nude beach visitors would continue their contribution to the village economy. And rather than endure their ludicrous assignment on the sands, Chief Stonemetz's bathing-suit-clad officers would don their uniforms and resume their proper role of protecting and serving the people of East Hampton Village, clothed and unclothed alike.
 
THOMAS GREENWOOD
Bay Shore

HEADLINE: The Dangers In Privatization

 BODY:
The article "A Rush to Privatize Government Services" (May 31) issue is rather frightening.
It seems to me that whenever there is privatization of services in a governmental agency, the lower echelons like the bus drivers, custodians and kitchen workers in public schools lose jobs and benefits. Needless to say, there rarely is any attempt to cut down on higher echelons, even where called for in light of economic conditions. 
 Schools that have done this also are trying to extend this to teachers by hiring them for less than a full teaching load. Perhaps the ultimate folly will be the school staffed by daily teaching substitutes who certainly will never achieve tenure nor receive benefits. Watch the further decline of public education!
Private business has been steadily eroding the concept of the permanent worker through the use of "temps" for some years now.
Our society faces a very frightening future if this trend continues, for no one but a few will have any future.
 
TIM DYAS
Ridgewood

HEADLINE: The Death Penalty: Questions to Weigh

 BODY:
Re: "Death-Penalty Law Tightened," May 17:
Lest we be led down New Jersey's path to mindless acceptance of execution of the first in line on death row, I urge New Jerseyans to find the time and courage now to think about capital punishment. 
 During the last 10 years since the death penalty statute was enacted in New Jersey, we've enjoyed a stay of conscience and consciousness concerning this decidedly disagreeable subject. Our time may be running out, especially in the wake of the recent rash of executions throughout the United States.
Of the many questions surrounding the concept of capital punishment, the following, I believe, demand careful consideration:
Are there life-or-death arguments to be voiced more loudly than the oft-heard ones that the death penalty may be a deterrent to violent crime, that execution may be more economical than life imprisonment, and that death may be the sole sure punishment? Is, perhaps, the more muted fourth rationale, that execution offers the victim's family and friends -- and all of us? -- the opportunity for revenge, the most undeniable rationale?
Yet, before we accept this "eye for an eye" justification, are we certain that we aren't actually trying to vicariously put to death a potential for wrongdoing that may lie within us all?
By "treating" symptoms rather than trying to cure root causes, is death by lethal injection anything more than a "quick fix" for violent crime? Can you be sure that you would develop "normally" if, as do so many criminals, you grew up in an inner-city ghetto or on a United States Indian reservation where seeds of criminality are nurtured by extreme poverty, lack of parental (or other wholesome) guidance, rampant drug and alcohol abuse, despair and hopelessness? Or, might you develop enough hate, rage and lack of control to commit heinous crimes?
Are you sure that the potential to murder (let alone for recidivism in general) is not also bred in a prison system that offers inmates little or no rehabilitation, yet whose conditions and attitudes provide breeding grounds for dehumanizing activity, rancor and wrath?
Do you really think that death, rather than a lifetime behind bars with no possibility of parole, is sure punishment for someone who has come to believe that life -- including his or her own -- is cheap and meaningless?
If we don't attempt to fully and humanely examine the issue of capital punishment, perhaps one paramount question remains: Who truly are the "uncivilized animals" in our society -- those who execute violent crimes or those who favor their premeditated execution?
 
GLORIA CROSBY
Flemington

HEADLINE: At Work;
Bidding the Wage Wars Goodbye

SERIES: One in an occasional series on coping with career dissatisfaction.

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
When Ron Moore went to New York last spring to appear on a television show, he was immune to the enticements of that holy city of conspicuous consumption. Not for Mr. Moore, an avowed skinflint, designer celery at triple-digit prices in the latest Manhattan chic-ery. Mr. Moore and his wife, Melodie, run Skinflint News, a monthly journal of frugality and practical advice, out of their Palm Harbor, Fla., home. Mr. Moore is no mere sunshine skinflint.
Because he knew the television appearance would give him a $50 food allowance , he packed a brown bag at home. "I had a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and a fried bologna sandwich with mustard, a huge bag of popcorn and an orange from a neighbor's tree," Mr. Moore recounted in the May issue of Skinflint News. He ate doughnuts at the noon-time taping, during which he suggested such money-saving strategies as collecting the final slivers of bar soap and grinding them in a food processor into laundry powder. He saved his real appetite for the airline lunch on the flight back to Tampa-St. Petersberg and arrived home with the $50 intact. "It went into the general fund," he said. 
 Strictly speaking, Mr. and Mrs. Moore no longer need to be as frugal as they are. In the last five years, they have turned what used to be a drain on the income they made at two unsatisfying jobs -- Mr. Moore worked as an electrician, Mrs. Moore as a certified public accountant in Florida's depressed wage economy -- into a full-time venture that yields what they describe as a comfortable living. And though they might seem merely to be shrewd exploiters of the counterprodigal Zeitgeist of the 1990's, the Moores believe they used a philosophy that came to them quite naturally to take control of their lives.
"People think it's trendy," Mrs. Moore said. "But our newsletter is not a 90's thing. It's a way of life any time, recession or not."
Mr. Moore, who is 36 years old and grew up in southern Indiana, espouses a genetic theory of skinflintery. "I am a fourth-generation skinflint. My great-grandmother raised seven children, including two sets of twins, by herself on a seamstress's salary," he said. He remembers large family gatherings where relatives would produce lists of things they wanted to get rid of: "They would barter and trade. Once my dad swapped the roofing on our house. I don't know what he swapped it for."
Mrs. Moore, 31, grew up near Atlanta, in a similarly thrifty household, with three older brothers: "My mother did anything and everything she could to stretch the food dollar."
The Moores used to share with friends some of the money-saving tips handed down from their families. What came to them by birthright intrigued their friends. "We'd say, 'You're kidding -- you never made your own soap powder? Well, here's how,' " Mr. Moore said. They decided to start a newsletter to spread the gospel locally.
It was more than two years before what they thought of as a hobby began to pay off. Mr. Moore's original vision was to make an extra $100 or so every month. "That's what we needed to make it," he said.
Now Skinflint News has 30,000 subscribers who pay $12 a year for its blend of full-length features, on, say, buying a car or building up a savings account, and low-cost recipes and other frugality esoterica like how to dye pickled eggs with beet juice. Each issue contains suggestions from subscribers, most of which the Moores try to test before they print them. "Someone wrote in that you could make liquid soap by putting bar soap in the microwave," Mr. Moore said. "We never could make that work."
The Moores say they hear from many people who are skinflints out of necessity. "A lot of elderly people," said Mrs. Moore, "a lot of single mothers and newly married young people." Some economize to dig themselves out of the debt they took on during the 80's. "They realize they're just as happy as they were, so they keep up the skinflint lifestyle," Mrs. Moore said. But many readers, like the Moores, just think the discipline is good for the soul. "People with tons of money are still skinflints," Mrs. Moore said. "We will always be skinflints, no matter what."
The Moores are writing a book of tips and say they have turned down several acquisition offers from investors. They worry not at all about a Maine-based competitor, the Tightwad Gazette, because they feel it does not represent an authentic skinflint sensibility. Mr. Moore acknowledges that he seeks out the skinflint's high, when his endorphins get roused over a good deal at, say, an estate sale. He goes the day before a sale opens and often manages, with a little Florida blarney and a judicious flash of cash, to get a beat on other foragers: "By Saturday," he said, "all the fools are there paying retail."
 
 
 
 
THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO SKINFLINT
 A sampling of advice from recent issues of Skinflint News (1460 Noell Blvd., Palm Harbor, Fla. 34683-5639; 813-785-7759).
* Never go grocery shopping hungry. You'll buy more than you need.
* Put the package of garbage bags in the bottom of your waste basket. Then when you throw out the full bag, you have an empty bag ready to go.
* When recycling aluminum cans, take them to your local scrap yard instead of the can crusher in the grocery store parking lot. The scrap yard will pay quite a bit more per pound than the can crusher.
* To get more juice when squeezing a lemon, drop it into hot water for a few minutes or put in the microwave at high for 20 seconds.
* Pour the juice from tuna fish over your cat's food. He will love the added flavor.
* Make empty plastic milk jugs into kitty-litter scoops by cutting off the bottom at an angle and punching holes in it.

HEADLINE: The Mild West;
Tourists Ride Into Town, Cowboys Ride Into the Sunset

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

 BODY:
BIG Sky. Open Space. A man's got to do what a man's got to do. These sentiments are selling better than ever, in Ralph Lauren-styled clothing and furniture, vacations built around cowboy themes, and range country sliced into 20-acre "ranchettes" tailored for the urban refugee.
At high noon it's easier to get espresso in Bozeman, Montana, than it is to find an available spittoon. But many of those people sipping their iced caffe lattes have come to Bozeman, not far from where Ted Turner is raising buffalo on his vast ranch, precisely because tobacco-spitting is part of the mythic landscape. 
 The West as a home for dust-chewing cowboys, lonely ranchers and strong-willed miners and loggers has all but disappeared. But the West as a theme park built around its legends is stronger than ever.
Nearly a hundred years after the American frontier was pronounced dead by historians like Frederick Jackson Turner, a new generation of faux ranchers, urban cowboys and high-country artists are getting rich helping to develop a new economy out of the enduring icons of the old West.
In the high plateaus and remote valleys of the West, where once only the most leathery-faced homesteader or stubborn sheepherder would try to hold on, new communities of urban exiles who live by fax machines or as tour operators have sprung up. They make their living not from tearing apart the scenery or wrestling with the elements, but from selling an image that Americans refuse to let go of.
"We're losing our heritage in this country, the old image of the pioneer, but people are desperate to hold onto it, so they come to me," said Arnold (Smoke) Elfer, who runs a horse- and mule-packing outfit in Missoula, Mont. For $160 a day a visitor can sleep on a bedroll in the Bob Marshall
Wilderness and smell real horse manure as a guest of Smoke and his boys.
"I think the average, fast-paced American really wants to settle down and live at 3 miles an hour, which is exactly the average speed of a horse," said Mr. Elfer. Business for horse-pack outfitters and ranchers who arrange for city slickers to go on cattle drives has never been better.
And it is not just in Montana. In 1902, Owen Wister, a well-bred Easterner, drew on the Methow Valley, a meander of aspens and larch trees on the east slope of the Cascade Mountains in Washington State, to write "The Virginian," the first Western novel.
Ninety years later, the real-life cowboys, ranchers and desperadoes of the Methow Valley are long gone, as are most of its loggers and miners. But the area has been able to stay out of the register of ghost towns by putting on late 19th-century Western costume to become economically revitalized. The town of Winthrop, where Wister stayed, has gone Western, complete with swinging saloon doors, wood-planked sidewalks and easy-living dude ranches. Booking a room in Winthrop in mid-summer is harder than squeezing gold dust from a boulder.
In southern Arizona, near Tucson, the high peaks of the Santa Catalina mountains hide natural and historic secrets as authentic as sunsets in the Monument Valley. But far more visitors prefer the man-made charms of Old Tucson, a fake Western town that was constructed in 1940 as a set for the film "Arizona." A sort of Western Disneyland, Old Tucson features staged gunfights and frontier train rides. Old Tucson may represent the apex of myth-making, American West style: from its humble beginnings as a movie set constructed to look like Hollywood's stereotype of the West, it now passes for a bona fide imitation of the real thing.
For those who still consider themselves real cowboys or ranchers, the transition's ultimate threat is that there will be no place for them. They fear they will become props.
Montana, the rangeland destination for all those 19th-century Texas longhorn drives, has about 14,000 cattle ranchers, down from 17,000 10 years ago. Between soul-numbing winters and finicky consumers, raising red meat on the open range is harder than ever.
"Ranching is not an easy life -- never has been," said Allen Nelson, a fourth-generation rancher who lives just south of Livingston, Mont., in the Paradise Valley. "Now you got all these people coming into the state who don't understand what it's all about."
Mr. Nelson has opted to sell part of his ranch as a conservation easement -- he is paid to let elk roam free -- rather than sell to realtors who would carve out ranchettes.
Ironically, few people who buy ranchettes end up living on them. People may say they move to the West for elbow room, but when they get here they prefer to live in cities. Nearly 80 percent of all people in the Rocky Mountain West now live in urban areas -- a higher percentage than on the East Coast, except for the mid-Atlantic states.
 
The Lure of 'City Slickers'
 Virtually all the job growth in the West over the last decade has come from areas outside of ranching, mining and logging. In the three-state area around Yellowstone National Park, 96 percent of the nearly 70,000 new jobs were tied to tourism, recreation, light manufacturing and services. Tourism and recreation have boomed, growing by up to 10 percent a year in many areas.
When "City Slickers," the movie about three men who go on a cattle drive as an antidote to their frayed lives in the city, came out last year, it became a huge draw for the theme economy. Now, as "City Slickers" goes on sale in video stores in Europe, the Montana state tourism bureau is running an advertisment with the video on how Europeans can visit the Big Sky state and play cowboy. The initial response has been overwhelming, state officials said, notably from the English.
The West's original inhabitants, the Indians, have largely missed out on the theme economy bonanza. Some tribes in the Southwest do report a surge in jewelry sales, and Blackfoot and Salish Indians in Montana have added more "trading posts." In a nod to political correctness, staged Indian gunfights with white settlers are seldom a staple of Old West Days. Instead, the white gunslingers shoot each other, a la Clint Eastwood and the unshaven bad guys.
About 6 million people visited Montana last year, a record. Many of them came for the chance to do what Westerners have long done -- drink thick coffee under the stars, swat carnivorous deerflies, and experience the many moods of a horse in the summer heat.
The West has always had a strong hold on people because of its landscape. But now, at some of the West's best-known scenic areas, plans are afoot to promote the scenery to visitors who may never actually have to see it.
At the entrance to Zion National Park in southern Utah, a California company is ready to start construction of a vast indoor theater, hotel complex and parking lot. Without ever entering the national park, visitors will be able to simulate the park experience by watching film of the salmon-colored canyon country on a huge IMAX movie screen. The company, World Odyssey, is studying a plan for a similiar operation near Yellowstone, America's first national park.
Perhaps the ultimate extension of the Western myth is the proposal by two Rutgers University professors, Frank and Deborah Popper, who advocate creating a Buffalo Commons, a vast open space in the high prairie east of the Continental Divide where bison herds would roam. The area is losing population, and its economy has continued to slide, the Poppers argue. Why not return the bison to the land, as Ted Turner, the broadcasting executive, has done to his 130,000-acre ranch south of Bozeman?
To many ranchers, the Buffalo Commons idea is absurd, a sort of gigantic zoo. They feel they would be reduced to observers on the land they have known intimately all their lives. As William Kittredge, one of the most eloquent of Western writers wrote in a recent essay, "This is nightmare talk to longtime inhabitants of the shortgrass plains."

HEADLINE: TRIPLE THREAT;
In 3-Way Races The Old Rules Can Trip You

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER a month of high panic and strange omens as the two major parties struggled to adjust to Ross Perot and a three-way race for the Presidency, a few rough lessons are clear.
First and foremost, Mr. Perot's rivals learned that the Dallas billionaire would bleed just like any other pol. In May and early June, his surge in the polls had crossed most of the lines of ideology, demographics, party and region, a strange new phenomenon from talk-show land that seemed immune to the normal rules of politics. After a month in the arena, however, getting frisked by the news media and worked over by Republican surrogates for President Bush, Mr. Perot looked much more vulnerable to both parties. 
 Second, all sides got a lesson in how attack politics can have unintended consequences in a three-way race. The Bush forces went after Mr. Perot last month, making a strategic decision to try to cap his movement early on. And two polls released last week showed that Mr. Perot was indeed acquiring an increasingly negative image in the minds of many voters. But the candidate who was gaining was not Mr. Bush, but Gov. Bill Clinton, who carefully stayed outside the fight and concentrated on rebuilding his own image.
Veterans of three-way statewide primaries already knew this lesson: Supporters peeled away from one candidate do not automatically go to his attacker. Democrats say this dynamic is particularly problematic for Mr. Bush. "He was able to beat Michael Dukakis by constantly battering him into the ground, and since voters had no place else to go, he survived and won without a mandate," said Stan Greenberg, a pollster for Mr. Clinton. Mr. Clinton's allies say that strategy is harder in a three-way race, where voters always have someplace else to go.
In a race this long and this intense, Mr. Bush could also pay a cumulative price for being chronically on the attack; voters, after all, have repeatedly shown their distaste for politics and politicians this year. At the moment, that appears to be a risk the Republicans are willing to take, although they are trying to insulate the President himself from the attacking being done on his behalf.
This leads to a third major development in June: The President's continued malaise. After a month when the Bush forces tried negative politics and positive appeals, took their own forays into the new talk-show campaign, and pulled off a successful summit with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia -- tried, in other words, just about everything -- Mr. Bush remained stuck, frustrated, unable to connect. Polls showed the President with about a third of the voters in a closely packed race, an embarrassing place for an incumbent President to be.
"What we're still grappling with is the means with which to portray positively President Bush's substantial accomplishments so they are greater appreciated by the American people," said Rich Bond, chairman of the Republican National Committee. "We've figured out how to move the other guys. We just haven't figured out how to move ourselves."
The President's dilemma was only deepened by the week's economic news. The unemployment rate reached 7.8 percent, an eight-year high, just as the Republicans were trying to make their case against Mr. Clinton's new economic package.
Some Republican strategists say they fully expect Mr. Clinton to emerge from this month's Democratic National Convention, which begins July 13, as the clear front-runner in the polls. "He's going to consolidate his base and surge and be in first place for a while around his convention," said Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign. "But then he's going to have a hell of a challenge to keep it."
In fact, one of the cautionary notes of the last month is how quickly the poll numbers can change in this strange and quirky race. Some experts argue that the Perot support
was always exaggerated in the polls, a reflection of a brutish primary season that left many voters discontented, and thus easily swayed by the first wave of news coverage of Mr. Perot, which was largely positive. "He was being propped up mainly by media enthusiasm, in my opinion," said Nelson Polsby, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley. "I think there will come a point where this will become a two-party race again, the way one would normally expect."
Not everyone shares that view. But people engaged in this campaign do expect some wild swings over the coming months, with one of the candidates ending up "cratering," as Mr. Bond puts it. Mr. Greenberg, the Clinton pollster, argues that voters are doing a lot of "parking" at this stage of the race: aligning, for the moment, with candidates to whom they feel only faint allegiance.
For the three candidates, this makes for a white-knuckle election that puts a premium on discipline and the ability, on occasion, to simply ignore the polls. Mr. Clinton, for example, spent most of the last month as a distant third in the polls, and was under substantial pressure from numerous savants to mix it up with Mr. Perot. He did not, deciding that the way to re-introduce himself to the American public after a savage primary season was not as the attacker of Ross Perot.
Instead, Mr. Clinton made the pilgrimage from one television program to another, trying to present himself as a bright young man with a plan and a set of deeply held beliefs about the course of the country. (As opposed to the deeply political, ambitious image he acquired in the primaries, when he was fending off allegations of infidelity and avoiding the draft while slashing his way through the opposition.)
This points to another trend peculiar to 1992: the remarkable role of untraditional television venues, from "Larry King Live" to the "Today" show. Ross Perot demonstrated its power early on, Mr. Clinton took to the circuit with gusto, and even Mr. Bush finally brought the cameras into the Rose Garden last week. How long will it last? "If these appearances keep delivering money to the networks and voters to us, they're going to have us there and we're going to be there," said James Carville, a strategist for Mr. Clinton.
Perhaps the traditional politics will reassert itself. The two-party structure may be so embedded that Mr. Perot is destined to fade, come fall. The candidates may pull back from the television lights and the happily inquisitive voters, each playing Phil for a day, and revert to a tarmac-to-tarmac, event-to-event campaign, with the questioners safely back beyond a rope line. For now, though, this race looks very different and very new: three men feeling their way through a wild year.
Mr. Clinton, glib and trying not to be, crammed with policy positions and proud of it, but keenly aware in his head that his campaign needs to come from his heart. Mr. Perot, discovering that even a billionaire from Dallas riding a grassroots uprising in an angry year can get roughed up by the Beltway crowd. And Mr. Bush, who looks almost haunted these days, with the anger of any incumbent who sees two-thirds of his constituents turning away.

HEADLINE: 50 Different Economies;
Workers Who Follow the Jobs Are the Keys to Economic Health

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
IT'S morning in the Midwest and middle South, where the numbers crunchers at the Federal Reserve recently identified satisfying upticks in industrial production. But the rays have yet to penetrate the recessionary gloom in New England and New York City. And the night is still a pup in southern California, where cutbacks in defense are just beginning to hit home.
Who changed the rules? What has happened to transform one economy indivisible into a regional free-for-all? 
 Nothing at all, argue scholars who have rediscovered the field of regional economics; it has always been thus. "Think of America as 50 small, open economies with a single currency," suggested Prof. Lawrence Katz of Harvard -- economies that rise and fall with the fortunes of regional industries.
What apparently has changed is the perception that Americans are all passengers on the same economic boat. And that change has given analysts an excuse to take a fresh look at the way economic regions interact -- and, in particular, at the remarkable degree to which this country has come to depend on the movement of workers, rather than on jobs or wages, to right regional imbalances.
The reexamination seems particularly timely. For if the Maastricht Treaty is ratified, the European Community will be transformed from a loose confederation into an American-style economic system, one that will hem in the ways regions can adjust to lean times.
In the postwar decades the lion's share of new American business and jobs has gone to the Sunbelt. But layered on top of this trend are sharp fluctuations in the fortunes of regions tied to major industries. Happily, adjustment has generally been rapid.
In an analysis to be published by the Brookings Institution, Mr. Katz and Olivier Blanchard of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology conclude that unemployment in individual states has rarely exceeded the national average for long. And no region seems to have been favored: the average jobless rate in the high-growth Sunbelt was neither better nor worse than in low-growth states. Contrast that with England, say, where the Thatcher-era boom seems to have permanently widened the unemployment gap between the prosperous south and the chronically depressed north.
 
Educated Guessing
 But the means of adjustment may matter almost as much as the speed. And in the end, there are only two possible routes. Excess economic capacity can drive down business costs, attracting new companies and making the products of established ones more competitive. Or, unemployment can fall as workers migrate.
In practice, costs rarely decline much and few businesses expand to fill the job vacuum. The burden is thus borne by workers, who must move to where the jobs are.
Economists offer some educated guesses on why the adjustment is so skewed toward the movement of people. Daniel Hamermesh of Michigan State University notes that unemployed American workers do not have the luxury of waiting for something to turn up: jobless benefits are pitiful by northern European standards.
And although there is plenty to push the unemployed to move, there isn't much to pull employers from healthy regions to those in trauma. Wages don't respond quickly to a fall in demand, perhaps because the majority who remain employed resist pressure to make do with less. Or perhaps, as research by Robert Barro of Harvard and Xavier Sala-i-Martin of Yale suggests, because wages by occupation are increasingly tied to national pay scales rather than local market conditions.
Mr. Katz notes, moreover, that regional economic distress can actually raise the cost of doing business. Certainly recession-battered cities and states go out of their way to keep employers happy, providing tax breaks and custom-tailored infrastructure improvements. But they must compete in a national market at precisely the time when they can least afford to erode their tax bases. And one way or another, places like Detroit must pare publicly provided amenities or collect sufficient revenue to cover the escalating social overhead.
How one views this dependence on the movement of workers depends on how one see the alternatives. Labor mobility has been celebrated as a uniquely American strength in a world of rapid change. Indeed, the periods in American history with the fastest growth have been periods of pell-mell interregional migration.
 
Social Costs
 There are, however, social costs to the survival-of-the-fittest tilt toward regional adjustment. Other things equal, it is safe to say that Americans would like the assurance of stable incomes, tax rates and Government services. But Mr. Sala-i-Martin and Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard estimate that the Federal Government absorbs only 40 cents of every dollar in income lost to regional economic fluctuation, leaving 60 percent of the adjustment burden to be carried locally. Also, the loss to families separated from friends and community may far exceed the dollar loss in income.
In Mr. Katz's view, these "externalities" justify greater Government intervention, perhaps through increased Federal support of local governments. Rebecca Blank of Northwestern University would go a step further, shifting some of financial burden to companies that close plants.
In any event, economists argue, it might well be possible to maintain high levels of labor mobility while still reducing the imperative to move. "Americans think it is up to the individual to find a job," pointed out Janet Norwood, former commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics who is a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a Washington research group. As a result there is no Government-supported national labor exchange, no allowance to cover the cost of moving and precious little help in retraining.
These ideas are not likely to strike an election-year chord. Among the candidates, only Bill Clinton seems inclined to favor policies that reduce the adjustment burden on individual workers. But he is also eager to distance himself from anything that smacks of traditional liberalism. And as Mr. Hamermesh notes, virtually all the pressure for adjustment assistance comes from groups defending entrenched interests -- specific industries or specific union jobs.
But the new regional economics may resonate in Europe where, months after their governments declared their support for a common currency, voters are beginning to contemplate the consequences.
 
Obvious Payoffs
 Today, a European country hit by an economic shock has the option of creating jobs by printing more money or devaluing its currency. But under the deal tentatively struck at Maastricht in December, Italy will have no more power over its money than Florida. Moreover, Floridians are free to move to Arizona in search of jobs; custom and language will severely limit mobility within the European Community.
That, points out Mr. Katz, will put great pressure on the European Community to buffer regional economic shocks with cash. It will also focus attention on the notorious reluctance of businesses to lower prices and for unions to make wage concessions during recessions. And while Europe will no doubt adapt, the restrictions imposed by a common currency will probably lengthen the time it takes regions to recover from downturns.
Economic integration obviously has its payoffs: few economists, after all, think America would be better off as five or 50 independent economies able to print their own greenbacks. But the example of America shows that integration has costs, too -- costs that hardly anyone wishes to recognize.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The New Era Still Demands Bold Strokes Of Leadership

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
SO the end of the cold war was not the end of history, after all. The multinational organizations that were supposed to take over from the superpowers to run a more peaceful, stable world have been faltering under the economic, political and ethnic problems that arose after the collapse of Communism.
President Bush and the other world leaders at the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial countries in Munich and the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe summit in Helsinki this week have a full agenda. But what they really need to do is to demonstrate clear leadership, which is still something best provided by leaders of powerful nation-states. 
 The lesson of the Persian Gulf war a year ago, and of the current war in what used to be Yugoslavia, is that it takes a bold course of action by a powerful, confident national leader to forge an effective international coalition against a renegade state like Iraq or Serbia.
In the Persian Gulf it was President Bush, acting under the aegis of the United Nations, who took the initiative, and other countries that followed. In Yugoslavia, it was once again the threat of American action to show up European ineffectiveness that prompted President Francois Mitterrand of France to take a bold step himself, in a courageous solo mission to Sarajevo that showed his fellow Europeans, and the rest of the world, that talk and inaction do not constitute the only possible response to the crisis in the Balkans.
By flying into the Sarajevo airport and visiting the city while it was under fire, Mr. Mitterrand broke the logjam and spearheaded the delivery of humanitarian aid to the city's besieged population. By his courage, he cowed, at least for the moment, the Serbian militia leaders who had bullied Sarajevo's citizens for weeks and he emboldened the United Nations Security Council into sending in peacekeepers to keep the airport open.
Mr. Mitterrand, like Mr. Bush, is a politician fighting for his political life, and part of his motivation was resentment at months of carping by the United States at the inability of European leaders to stop the disastrous civil war on their eastern doorstep. If Mr. Mitterrand wanted to get France out ahead of the United States at the United Nations Security Council, he succeeded. At the time, it was Mr. Bush who was sounding equivocal about whether the lives of American airmen or sailors could be used to protect the United Nations peacekeepers.
Rival nations have always found ways to resolve their rivalries -- either violently, through war, or peacefully, through cooperation or deterrence. Deterrence prevented nuclear war between the United States and the Soviet Union for nearly 40 years. But it vanished with the old order. The challenge before the leaders of the industrialized democracies is how to help build a new structure of security that can help prevent disasters like the one in the Balkans.
A year ago, there was hope that this could emerge from American-Soviet cooperation, but the Soviet Union is gone, too. President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia will be welcomed by the participants in the Munich summit, but not, yet, as one of them, ready to play a role in a new Concert of Europe. His main purpose will be to plead for more money to prop up his staggering economy and help him continue with change that will stave off even worse ethnic conflicts there in the future.
Mr. Mitterrand reminded the world that international organizations can be galvanized into effective action against renegade states only by strong leadership from individual member nation-states. The fire of nationalism, to some extent, has to be fought with fire, not with the watered-down collective will that emerges from international consensus. The great powers of Europe knew this when Sarajevo last flashed into the news, nearly 80 years ago, but they were at odds with each other then and used the Balkans as surrogates of their rivalry, leading to the disaster of World War I. Today, two years after the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, local ethnic and national rivalries are once again flourishing in a leadership vacuum.
The small United Nations peacekeeping force in Sarajevo has only the mission of opening the airport to an airlift of humanitarian aid, food and medicines to relieve the city's beleaguered, mainly Muslim Bosnian population of its torment at the hands of the Serbs. The war itself goes on, and neither Europe nor the United States has yet found an effective way of stopping it.
 
Mitterrand's Choice
 The 12-nation European Community wrangled long and hard in Lisbon at the end of last month before finally timidly agreeing that it would "not exclude" support for the use of military means by the United Nations to achieve humanitarian objectives in Sarajevo.
Mr. Mitterrand, backing Italy, had argued for "bold action" by the community's member states, but they were divided. Germany wanted to do something but pleaded that its own troops could not take part, given what the Nazis had done to the Balkans in World War II. Britain wanted to help, but it did not want to get stuck in another endless local conflict like Cyprus, or Northern Ireland. This is the trouble with "Europe" as a foreign policy maker: The member nations do not see all international problems the same way.
Until the treaty on European union that was signed in Maastricht, the Netherlands, last December is ratified and put into effect, Mr. Mitterrand concluded, the Europeans could not act in concert. But nothing would be done about the fighting in Yugoslavia unless some country took bold action unilaterally, and Mr. Mitterrand did not want that country to be the United States.
 
A Role for NATO?
 What will happen to European union, and to the Maastricht treaty, is unclear since Danish voters rejected it in a referendum last month. But even if all 12 states do eventually ratify it, "Europe," unless it becomes something more than a loose confederation of sovereign states, will never have the political and military clout that some of its members have individually -- France and Britain, for example, as permanent members of the Security Council.
The NATO alliance, searching for a new role after the collapse of its Warsaw Pact adversaries, has also been struggling to find a fitting way of bringing its power to bear in the Balkans, and agreed in Oslo early in June to the principle that it could carry out peacekeeping missions assigned by the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Conflicts there are aplenty, not only in the Balkans but in Moldova, in Georgia and between Armenia and Azerbaijan. But getting a consensus in a group of 52 people, let alone nations, is often elusive. Mr. Bush and most of his colleagues from Munich will travel to Helsinki later this week to try to lead this organization to its next phase, but whether it is really an effective means of keeping stability and order in the new Europe remains to be seen.
Bold leadership has to come from confident leaders, and neither Mr. Bush, Mr. Mitterrand, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan nor any of the other leaders of the major democracies, which are in the grip of recession and domestic political discontent, can be said to be supremely confident these days -- not even Prime Minister John Major of Britain, who won a national election in April, but with only a 21-seat majority. If Munich produces broad visions and brave actions, it will be a welcome surprise.

HEADLINE: On Welfare in Sumer;
No Society Rejoices At Helping Its Poor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IF some members of the Bush Administration had been around 4,000 years ago, they might have denounced Sumer in Mesopotamia as the epitome of the welfare city-state. Work was a duty, but social security was an entitlement. It was personified by the Goddess Nanshe, the first real welfare queen immortalized in hymn as a benefactor who "brings the refugee to her lap, finds shelter for the weak."
Later, the New Testament presciently declared: "The poor always ye have with you." But during periodic introspections, society has been ambivalent about the causes of poverty and the possible cures and about who is responsible for both. That historic vacillation between its role as protector or punisher reverberates with remarkable consistency in 1992 politics. 
 Individual states, resources sapped by the recession and resolve weakened by well-intentioned but largely unsuccessful prescriptions, are cutting basic welfare grants. New Jersey is denying additional benefits to mothers on welfare if they have more children. The Supreme Court recently upheld a ban on begging at New York-area airports. Wisconsin's highest court just upheld a 60-day residency requirement for welfare applicants. And the Bush Administration singled out New York as emblematic of the failed welfare state and then adjudged the Los Angeles riots the "grim harvest" of Great Society programs and the ethos that welfare was an entitlement without responsibility.
 
Giving Charity Selectively
 Richard P. Nathan, a social historian at the State University of New York at Albany, says the United States has not altogether relegated its poor to Dickensian damnation. "The idea of poverty in America is a far cry from what it would have been a hundred years ago or what it is in other countries," said Mr. Nathan. "We ratchet up our ideas about what poverty standards should be and, in an ironic way, that reflects progress."
But the debate over whether public support for the poor is too much or too little has not advanced much. Relatively enlightened societies provided for the poor selectively. Charity, as a biblical precept, was left to individuals or to the abundant resources of organized religion. Four hundred years ago, Elizabethan poor laws transformed social welfare into secular obligation. The laws entitled the poor to assistance from taxation and distinguished the helpless from those who chose to help themselves to other people's money.
But the laws also imposed demands on the poor so that welfare would not be dispensed indiscriminately. Vagrancy, like begging, was circumscribed to contain the growth of criminal gangs. (To discourage panhandling, the city of Lyon created an authority in 1534 to serve as a funnel for all public philanthropy.) In the 17th century, English localities evicted people who had migrated to take advantage of more generous benefits.
The American view of poverty was founded on a profoundly different premise than the European view: as a detour in the nation's manifest destiny rather than as an inevitable consequence of a divine hand that doomed some people to deprivation.
Still, even Benjamin Franklin maintained that the way of doing good to the poor "is not making them easy in poverty, but leading or driving them out of it."
American welfare reform began about a century ago. The settlement-house model, which is just being rediscovered, was widely copied to cope with immigration. Jacob Riis and his contemporaries, who crusaded against the slums, envisioned Government's role as that of a regulator -- leaving the execution to philanthropy and the profit motive. By appealing to conscience and self-interest, they surmounted Social Darwinism and Malthusian fears of welfare -- that era's version of benign neglect. Helping the poor also meant protecting public health, curbing criminality and insuring social stability. Any hopes that poverty had been eradicated were dashed by the Depression, which spawned a Government-sponsored welfare state: New Deal job programs and aid for widows and the elderly.
In the 1970's, Michael Harrington awakened society to "The Other America." Welfare-rights groups, eschewing the intrusiveness of social workers, insisted that relief was an inalienable right. Even the lexicon was revised: the poor became the underprivileged; welfare, public assistance.
But in the 1980's, as the homeless population grew and poverty became more visible, welfare became seen by some as a palliative at best. Some advocates for the poor responded by pursuing a single-minded agenda: housing, without the vital social services that many of the homeless required. The White House response to the Los Angeles riots this year has been similarly one-dimensional, focusing, in part, on jobs for people, many of whom are unprepared to keep them.
"We have a welfare system that nobody likes," said Michael B. Katz, a University of Pennsylvania history professor who has written extensively about the system. "And we have the conjunction of stale rhetoric with an unprecedented situation in American cities."
Poverty among blacks has been typically taken for granted. But the growth of a dependent class of teen-age mothers defies precedent and solution. During the recession, it has also defied the public's indulgence. The concern is less about money -- which the public is more accustomed to spending on the dole than on day care and job training -- than about the burden of an "undeserving" underclass and the plight of the deserving, if seemingly permanent, poor.
"We are loath to punish severely for fear of doing injustice," an ambivalent official of New York's private welfare organizations said 85 years ago, "but we hesitate to offer much aid, for fear of being duped."
Today, progress isn't likely unless the public agenda melds morality and self-interest. In renegotiating the social contract, Government's obligation is to find the middle ground that has eluded society since Nanshe, the Mesopotamian goddess, was hailed by some bards of Sumer for her compassion and, undoubtedly, denounced by others as a dupe.
