HEADLINE: A Quiet Majesty Sails the Hudson With Tall Ships

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Majestic in a gray morning mist, the world's largest gathering of tall ships in this century sailed out of the past and up the great amphitheater of New York Harbor yesterday in a stately salute to Independence Day and the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's voyage of discovery to the New World.
Canvas set, pennants fluttering, a breeze singing in the rigging, the 11-mile procession of 34 windjammers and other craft -- 270 ships from 37 nations -- moved across the whitecap-flecked harbor and up the Hudson in an awesome and graceful five-hour parade, reviewed by a flotilla of smaller boats, one million people on shore and a national television audience. 
 It was a sight to behold: barks and barkentines, brigs, full-rigged ships and schooners from yesteryear, sailors lining rails and yardarms like rows of magpies, steepled shrouds straining at mastheads, gaff-rigged spankers and jibs set, rakish bowsprits and dolphin-strikers churning froths of wind and wave, a ballet whose beauty seemed all the greater in the leaden fog.
 
'Big and Beautiful and Quiet'
 "Watching these ships takesG d Vanderbilt Jr., a great-great-great grandson of Commodox@ilt and one of the organizers of Operation Sail, 1992. "They're big and beautiful and quiet. They come from another age, and it's like magic to see them again."
It began as a drizzly, fog-banked Fourth of July in the metropolitan area, with temperatures in the 60's and low clouds that wrapped the ships in mystery and caught the day's soft celebratory mood. On the rim of the harbor, sea mists drifted up like a flower's fragrance and spectators in summer whites, stippled like figures in a Seurat, strained to make out the regatta.
But later in the day, the fog lifted, temperatures rose into the 70's and the sun peeked through oyster clouds upon a wondrous tableau -- tall ships in the distance; fireboats shooting plumes of red, white and blue water; tugboats hooting, and crowds watching from reviewing stands on Governor's Island and from rooftops, piers, windows, decks and shoreline parks.
 
In Streets and Parks
A Day to Play, A Day to Protest
 Away from the nautical maneuvers, people across the New York region and the nation marked the holiday with concerts, street festivals, picnics and quiet family gatherings, with outings to beaches, ballgames and more serene retreats. There was an old-fashioned parade of marching bands and veterans groups in River Edge, N.J., and thousands jammed the Connecticut River front in Hartford for a music festival.
Hundreds of New Yorkers, many of them immigrants, flocked to Bear Mountain State Park for a picnic that reflected the nation's diversity and a bit of its good life for hardworking people. But in some of the poorer neighborhoods of Brooklyn, the mood was downcast, the holiday all but forgotten and the American dream seemed elusive.
In Battery Park City in lower Manhattan, the police arrested 17 demonstrators on charges of disorderly conduct. They were protesting the celebration of Columbus and calling for Puerto Rican independence from the United States.
For many Americans, it was just a day to stroll in a park or down a road, far from the maddening crowds, or to relax with a good book, perhaps to reread the Gettysburg Address or reflect on the day's meanings.
The nation this Independence Day was besieged with problems: a sagging economy, grinding unemployment and poverty, racial strife, conflicts over abortion and profound concerns over crime, educational failures, soaring health costs and dismal choices in a Presidential election year.
But it was also a nation at peace, with the apocalyptic threat of nuclear war receding and promising new ties to old foes in the works, and there remained a strong underpinning of faith in a diverse, democratic people who had somehow weathered wars, depression and other crises and would do so again, if need be.
The venerable tall ships seemed to capture that spirit. They evoked a sense of America's immigrant experience, of commerce and the dangers of life at sea, of skills and ideas in a new land. And in their rugged seaworthiness, they offered something quietly authentic in a world crowded with noisy artifice.
In the gloomy overcast, the turnout for OpSail '92 was a disappointment for organizers, who had gathered three-quarters of the world's tall ships for the day and had hoped for up to eight million spectators for their five-day extravaganza of events, four million for the sail parade. The drizzly weather also kept crowds low at beaches on the Jersey Shore and on Long Island.
But late in the day, the clouds gave way to patches of blue. And as the last light retreated, the night sky over the Hudson exploded in a 30-minute blaze of fireworks. Rising on rockets from barges off Lower Manhattan, 11,000 pyrotechnic shells created a barrage of color -- swizzles, whorls, bursts of cascading red, white, blue, gold and silver -- that echoed and flashed off skyscraper facades, overpowered the lights of New York and dazzled crowds of spectators.
After the fireworks, waves of people poured out of Battery Park and other riverside vantage points, clogging streets and subways. Their exit, though orderly, was punctuated by loud and steady explosions from firecrackers and more powerful explosives.
But the parade of sail was at the heart of the lavish day. Nearly 18 months in the planning, its $10 million cost borne by the city, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and corporate sponsors, OpSail '92 was staged by the group that brought tall ships to New York for the World's Fair in 1964, the nation's Bicentennial in 1976 and the Statue of Liberty centennial in 1986.
Weighing anchor off Sandy Hook, N.J., the tall ships, led by America's 295-foot, three-masted bark, Eagle -- built in Hamburg in 1936 and acquired by the United States as a war reparation -- glided under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge shortly after 9 A.M. The winds were insufficient to drive the ships, which purred ahead on engine power, but sails were set for show and occasionally they puffed out in 10-to-15-mile-an-hour gusts.
"Oh, that's beautiful," exclaimed Marie Brzezinsky, gazing at a Spanish ship through binoculars from the esplanade at Battery Park City. "It's right there now. Wow! It looks gorgeous!"
 
At Governor's Island
 Symbols of Hope And Persecution
 At Governor's Island, replicas of Columbus's caravels -- Santa Maria, Nina and Pinta -- rode at anchor, and 3,000 invited guests watched from reviewing stands as Mayor David N. Dinkins spoke of those who had come to America in ships, some to escape persecution, some in the holds of slavers, some seeking new opportunity.
Flanked by smaller escort ships and followed by a host of ketches, yawls, sloops and other vessels, the tall ships crossed a harbor sprinkled with small spectator craft. The Coast Guard had estimated that up to 40,000 craft would be on hand, but only a few thousand boats bobbed in the 2- to 4-foot swells, and it was clear that many fair-weather sailors had stayed home.
They were missing something, for there was a subtle beauty in the rough day: its frail light lay on the harbor like polished metal, the astonishingly human cry of seagulls carried great distances, and the panorama of ships, the golden torch of the Statue of Liberty against the fog, was like poetry.
As dawn broke over Sandy Hook yesterday -- that is, as the sky turned a paler shade of gray -- Marcel Gubala, 22, looked into the light drizzle and saw that it would be useless to swab the immense, gently rolling decks of the Polish square-rigger Dar Mlodziezy (pronounced dahr M'LUHD-shee).
"It's very nice work, as you see," he said, leaning on a long-handled scrub brush and surveying the fleet of tall ships anchored in the slate-gray sea, bows into the breeze. "Sometimes you can brush," he added, slapping at the pine deck.
Below, in the aft cabin, Richard D. Seeth, a 43-year-old harbor pilot from Yardville, N.J., was grouching about weather forecasters. "They said, 'Oh, there'll be a break in the weather,' " he grumped, peering through a porthole at the great gray continuum. "There's not going to be any break."
In a manual provided by OpSail organizers, he found a new target for his ire. "See, this was done by someone sitting at a desk," he said. "The first thing I can tell you is, forget the time schedule. These are sailing vessels." But he was wrong.
Promptly at 7:30 A.M., the Eagle weighed anchor and, riding an incoming tide and a following breeze, assumed her spot as the lead ship. One by one, the tall ships fell into line behind her. By 8:50, when the Dar Mlodziezy raised anchor, the Eagle had long since faded into the thickening fog.
The Dar Mlodziezy's crew of 180 cadets from the Polish Merchant Marine Academy in Gdynia had been at sea for three months and faced the prospect of liberty in New York with a mixture of fear and excitement. "It is true the city is very dangerous for us -- everybody told us," said Wojtake Hajdamowicz, 21. But, he added, "It is necessary to meet any women."
Like most of the tall ships, the Dar Mlodziezy has the profile of a salty antique, but her equipment is modern (including a fax machine) and it serves its purpose: teaching cadets about wind, tides and seamanship. Teamwork was on display yesterday as cadets scrambled into the rigging to set sail, then raced over the deck to seat halyards. But moments later, in keeping with the bizarre Rime-of-the-Ancient-Mariner quality of their voyage, they dropped sails again.
"We are in an extremely dangerous situation," said the captain, Tadeusz Olechnowicz. Waving at a wall of gray where Brooklyn was supposed to be, he said sails were "for fun, for decoration -- but there are no viewers."
Abruptly, there was another reversal: The ship passed under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and emerged from the fog. There lay the distant, vibrant city. Up went the sails, cadets gathered at the rails to gaze at Manhattan's towers and the ship moved into the harbor like a ghost out of the mist.
 
At Bear Mountain
After the Rain, A Go at the Trout
 Undeterred by light rain, a shroud of fog and soggy playing fields and picnic grounds, thousands of holiday celebrants descended on Bear Mountain State Park. The crowds were thin because of the weather, but by afternoon the barbecues were sizzling, radios were blaring and grocery bags full of chicken, hot dogs, chips and beer were being unloaded for a day of feasting.
Eddie Ramos, who immigrated with his family from El Salvador seven years ago, was among 300 people bused from Jamaica, Queens, and Hempstead, L.I., by the New York-based El Salvador Human Rights Commission. "We'd planned this for months, so I'm here to have a good time," he said. "But I really want to celebrate the 500 years since Columbus came, and I want to see the ships in New York tomorrow."
More affluent New Yorkers relaxed in the Hamptons or Berkshires, but Bear Mountain has been a popular day-trip destination for those of more modest means since the park was established in 1908 by a gift to the state of 10,000 acres from the Harriman family. In recent years, it has become an upstate version of a city park, a mecca for Hispanic and black families, many of them immigrants, seeking a patch of lawn to enjoy seemingly bottomless food coolers.
Picnicking was the No. 1 priority for most, but some also hiked on the Appalachian Trail, fished for trout on Hessian Lake or the Hudson River, rented paddleboats or swam in the park's oversized pool. At the stone-and-wood Bear Mountain Inn, all 60 rooms were booked and the souvenir shop did a brisk business in patriotic paraphernalia.
 
On Franklin Avenue
'There's No Work And No Money'

From Empire Street to Park Place along Franklin Avenue in Brooklyn, only one symbol of Independence Day was evident yesterday: an American flag, edges stained with coffee, hung in the window of Franklin Laundry Center. There was none of the jubilation that usually surrounds the Fourth of July along the commercial thoroughfare that runs through the ethnically diverse neighborhoods of Crown Heights and Flatbush.
"It's not like before when things were going smoothly," said Jint John, a 34-year-old laundry worker. "Everyone used to have a good time on the Fourth. A lot of the problem is financial. There's less of everything."
Robert Paris, 31, working at Los Amigos Grocery in Crown Heights, agreed that the area's economic depression had a dampening effect. "We really don't have the enthusiasm like we used to," he said. "Normally, there's more parties, barbecues and music. It just doesn't have that feeling any more."
Morale was even lower for Haitians in the community, with their lovely, terrifying homeland in turmoil. One symbol of patriotism in the office of Wilson Desir, a prominent local Haitian emigre, was not colored in red, white and blue, but in black and white -- a poster of the deposed Haitian president, Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
"No one feels the Fourth means anything," said Urbain Richard, a 24-year-old student at Brooklyn College. "It's just a holiday to stay in bed and relax. The Independence Day for Haitians is yet to come."

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: July 5, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 2423 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Perot Told U.S. To Soften Policy On Vietnamese

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
As a way to win the repatriation of any American servicemen still held in Southeast Asia, Ross Perot unsuccessfully sought to persuade the Reagan White House to begin limited economic relations with Vietnam and to expand diplomatic contacts.
At the time, Washington was taking a harder diplomatic line with Hanoi to achieve the same end. 
 In a report to Ronald Reagan written April 8, 1987, after Mr. Perot returned from Hanoi, the Texas businessman promoted several ideas, including the establishment of a Vietnamese "economic representative" in the Swiss or Swedish embassy, and a reciprocal American business office in Hanoi, a former Reagan aide said. Mr. Perot also offered to pay for a Vietnamese delegation to the United States to study American industries.
 
'A Small Price to Pay'
 In a list of recommended future actions that accompanied his report, Mr. Perot said he would finance an American tour for Vietnam's primary war hero, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, as part of an overall plan of "good faith" gestures to Hanoi. Mr. Perot said in his letter that the moves would be a "small price to pay" if they led to the release of long-missing American prisoners of war. [Excerpts, Page 14.]
The recommendations were rejected by Mr. Reagan after Administration officials argued that United States policy toward Hanoi should stay on course, requiring Vietnam to meet its pledges to withdraw from Cambodia and clear up issues relating to missing American servicemen from the Vietnam War era before the United States considered diplomatic recognition and lifting the longstanding trade embargo.
 
Fear of Manipulation
 To a number of Reagan Administration officials, Mr. Perot's proposals raised questions about his approach to foreign policy. Members of a committee supervising policy toward Vietnam under the National Security Council criticized the proposals because they granted "concessions without performance," several of them said in recent interviews.
These officials were concerned that Mr. Perot's eagerness to make progress on the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue was being manipulated by Hanoi's leaders, who were seeking to use it as leverage to bring an end to their diplomatic and economic isolation.
Commenting today on Mr. Perot's actions then, a senior spokesman in his undeclared campaign for President said in Dallas, "The Administration had no effective game plan" on Americans who were missing or were still held prisoner in Southeast Asia.
He added that "Ross Perot was asked to develop one and he did so and delivered it to the Administration," which he said was too preoccupied with the Iran-contra scandal "to follow through and implement the plan."
The letter from Mr. Perot to Mr. Reagan is the most illuminating document that has emerged so far from Mr. Perot's short-tenured service to the Reagan White House as an unofficial reviewer of the Administration's P.O.W.-M.I.A. policies.
The document shows that Mr. Perot was seeking to place himself in the role of broker of a new economic relationship between the United States and Hanoi as part of his strategy to win the release of Americans he believed were still being held.
"They are interested in direct assistance from the private sector, feeling that the private sector knows more about business than the government," he wrote to Mr. Reagan, adding parenthetically, "I believe this is their primary interest in me." A few paragraphs later, he noted, "The Vietnamese have studied me in detail."
At the same time, Mr. Perot said that he had explained to Vietnam's Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, "that it would not be possible for our two countries to work together until the P.O.W./M.I.A. problem was resolved."
"He accepts this," Mr. Perot added, "but needs shows of good faith on our part."
Reagan Administration officials observed that Mr. Thach, the most pro-Western member of Hanoi's politburo, appeared to be using his relationship with Mr. Perot and the promise of economic development through such a relationship in an internal power struggle with hardliners. Mr. Thach was forced to retire a year ago.
Richard Childress, a former National Security Council official who was supervising P.O.W.-M.I.A. policy at the time, said in a recent interview that Mr. Perot's actions were "directly undermining" negotiations. His approach "represents naive acceptance of a strategy of responding to the laundry list of well-known Vietnamese objectives as if it would automatically bring cooperation."
Mr. Childress said United States negotiators who went to Hanoi three months later faced hostility from the disappointed Vietnamese.
 
Action Based On Deep Belief
 Mr. Perot's letter to President Reagan reflect's Mr. Perot's blend of sharp criticism of Government competence and his enthusiasm for action and Government activism, if necessary, in support of a good cause.
In sparse and staccato sentences, Mr. Perot punched out his recommendations and observations, leaving plenty of white space to accentuate his declarative statements.
Mr. Perot, unlike Government officials, founded his recommendations on a deep conviction that Americans had been left in Southeast Asia.
"We knew we were leaving men behind," he asserted. In Laos, he said "there are 343 M.I.A.s."
Reagan Administration officials said Mr. Perot's assertions did not take into account the fact that at the end of the war some of those prisoners were transferred to Hanoi for repatriation as part of a 1973 prisoner exchange, and most others were under Vietnamese control.
Mr. Perot takes credit in his letter for having insinuated himself into the confidence of Vietnam's leadership with a suggestion that Hanoi would not be held responsible for long-missing P.O.W.s.
"I carefully postured the conversations so that the M.I.A.'s would be found in Laos and returned by the Laotian government," he wrote to Mr. Reagan.
One member of the negotiating team was critical of this strategy. "There he is inventing a strategy," he said, "without consultation with us, which is destructive, because it narrows you to only one option. Asking the Vietnamese to sell out Laos, a neighbor and a friend, is impossible. They are not going to sell a neighboring country down the toilet."
 
In Sharp Contrast To Official Stance

Mr. Perot's proposals, had Mr. Reagan followed them, would have marked an abrupt change in strategy. Washington's view was that Vietnam needed to make the show of "good faith" by cooperating with American efforts to complete a final accounting of Vietnam war dead.
"History has shown that concessions prior to performance is death," said Mr. Childress.
"They'll take and take and take," he added. "We've learned that over 25 years."
Richard Armitage, who was in charge of the Pentagon's P.O.W.-M.I.A. efforts and now serves with ambassador rank as director for aid programs to the former Soviet Union, said, "Had we changed strategy and policy in the face of non-performance of Vietnam, they would have felt that they had, yet again, cracked the resolve of both the Administration and the American public. In effect, they would have been rewarded for non-performance."
Mr. Perot had criticized Mr. Armitage's role at the time and had undertaken an investigation of his private life.
Mr. Childress and Mr. Armitage agreed to comment on the letter only if it was made clear that they did not provide the document and that they believe their criticisms of Mr. Perot's approach were representative of the views of a broad array of policy professionals in the Government.
A copy of Mr. Perot's letter and a memorandum of his discussion with a senior Vietnamese official were provided to The New York Times by an official who is not involved in any of this year's Presidential campaigns, but who believes Mr. Perot should more fully disclose his dealings with Hanoi. In earlier interviews, Mr. Perot has referred to the letter numerous times, but declined to make it public.
"If I release the letter, hell, there's no telling what will be the next step," he said in a June 3 interview.
The course of United States policy, that Mr. Perot sought, particularly the proposal to set up what would have been economic interest sections, was strongly opposed by a special group under National Security Council supervision. The group was pushing to elevate the P.O.W.-M.I.A. question to a higher priority than it had had in the Nixon, Ford and Carter years.
This push followed the defection of a Vietnamese mortician who testified that Hanoi had stored hundreds of sets of remains from American servicemen to use as possible negotiating leverage.
Referring to Mr. Perot's offer to finance a visit to the United States by General Giap, Mr. Childress said, "The fact that you would take an official at that level -- he was still a member of the politburo -- and take him on a tour around the country, is implicit recognition and sends all kinds of signals to Vietnam and the world that we are recognizing them while they are occupying Cambodia and not cooperating on the humanitarian front."
 
Talks Continued In Private Channels
 The New York Times reported last month that Mr. Perot continued his dialogue with Hanoi through private channels after his 1987 visit to Vietnam and after he broke with the White House. In June 1990, Hanoi issued a letter designating Mr. Perot and his company as official business agents to attract Western capital and investment upon the lifting of the international trade embargo.
Mr. Perot said in an interview last month that he never wanted to do business with Vietnam, and only discussed economic matters in a "philosophical" manner in pursuit of his overall goal of winning the release of American servicemen.
"I could do business anywhere in the world," he said on an ABC News program with Peter Jennings last week. "The last place in the world I would want to do business is Vietnam."
When asked on the ABC News program what his associate, Harry McKillop, was doing during a number of private missions to Hanoi between 1987 and 1991, Mr. Perot replied, "He would respond to their request to come back in, listen, and come home, and, I'm sad to report, nothing ever happened."
A senior Vietnamese official who participated in lengthy discussions with Mr. Perot and Mr. McKillop over several years characterized Mr. Perot's goal as one of becoming an intermediary between Hanoi and United States corporations seeking to do business in Vietnam after the lifting of the embargo.
 
Perot's Clashes In Washington
 Mr. Perot secretly visited Vietnam's mission at the United Nations in the winter of 1986-87 without notifying the White House, Reagan aides said, securing an invitation to go to Hanoi, which he then told Reagan officials had appeared "out of the blue."
Arriving in Washington in 1986 as a strong ally of the Reagan White House, Mr. Perot promised a lavish $2.5 million gift to Mr. Reagan's Presidential library fund and promoted himself to head a Presidential commission on P.O.W.-M.I.A. affairs. The commission, as he envisioned it, should be armed with subpoena power and an open-ended charter to "get all the way to the bottom" of the emotional national debate.
Within the space of a year, he was bypassed for the job. In the course of his White House-sponsored investigations, he clashed with a wide range of officials in the Pentagon, White House, Central Intelligence Agency and Congress over the management of P.O.W.-M.I.A. affairs.
A senior foreign diplomat in Washington said that in a recent conversation with President Bush, Mr. Bush suggested that Mr. Perot's anger over not winning appointment as the P.O.W.-M.I.A. policy chief could be a factor in his drive for the White House this year.
Mr. Perot's estrangement from Ronald Reagan, including his withdrawal of the $2.5 million pledge to the Reagan library, and his bitterness toward Mr. Bush, then Vice President, has radiated into the current Presidential campaign.
 
Raised Expectations Back in Hanoi
 At the time of Mr. Perot's proposals for "good faith" gestures to Vietnam, Hanoi's aging rulers wanted to end the trade embargo and restore ties to Washington.
United States negotiators were holding on to their leverage until Hanoi made progress on a step-by-step "roadmap" to improved relations, through cooperation on P.O.W.-M.I.A. investigations.
Referring to his discussions with Mr. Thach, Mr. Perot said, "Thach stressed that we are always asking the Vietnamese to do things for the U.S., and that we are unwilling to do anything for them."
At several points in his report to Mr. Reagan, Mr. Perot emphasized Vietnamese frustrations. "Several times they commented, 'We won the war and yet you do not treat us with respect.' They feel that we are rude and arrogant in our dealings with them."
The official United States negotiating team that traveled to Hanoi three months after Mr. Perot's March 1987 trip encounterd a hostile and deeply disappointed Vietnamese delegation after Mr. Perot had raised expectations, several members said.
The United States group, which included Mr. Childress, representatives from the Pentagon and State Department and Ann Mills Griffiths, the director of the largest organization of P.O.W.-M.I.A. family members, was sent by the White House to prepare the way for the first visit of John W. Vessey Jr., a retired general whom Mr. Reagan chose in January 1987 to be his Presidential emissary to Hanoi for P.O.W.-M.I.A. affairs.
The White House had not been willing to announce General Vessey's appointment publicly until Hanoi agreed to an agenda dealing strictly with P.O.W.-M.I.A. issues. But Mr. Perot had prematurely disclosed General Vessey's appointment to the Vietnamese, Reagan aides said.
Mr. Perot said he had been given permission by Howard H. Baker, the White House chief of staff, but Mr. Baker said he did not recall giving it.
By the time the United States negotiating team got to Hanoi, one member said the atmosphere had been seriously muddled.
"When you lined up the things we were offering against the visit by Perot, who was talking about setting up economic-interest sections in both capitals, all that stuff we came up with must have looked penny ante to the Vietnamese," one of the team members said. "That was our worst meeting in four years."
Ms. Griffiths said that given Mr. Perot's actions, "I am not surprised that Vietnam continued to manipulate P.O.W.-M.I.A. responsiveness and hold out for a better deal."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: New Politics of Welfare Focuses on Its Flaws

SERIES: Rethinking Welfare/First of six articles.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
The platform that George S. McGovern carried away from the Democratic convention in 1972 enshrined "The Rights of Poor People" right after "The Rights of Youth" and before "The Rights of American Indians."
It assailed "the coercion of forced work requirements" for welfare recipients. It happily predicted that "the handout system of present welfare" would no longer be necessary once the Democrats embarked on an immense new program to create millions of "decent jobs."
 
Wiser or Meaner?
 The platform that Gov. Bill Clinton will carry to the Democratic National Convention in New York next week reflects a sadder but wiser era -- or, in the view of some of its critics, a poorer and meaner one. It declares that welfare should be "a second chance, not a way of life." It talks of the responsibilities of the poor. It is a snapshot of the new politics of welfare. 
 This is the era of "mutual obligations" and "the new paternalism," of increasing alarm over the persistence of welfare dependency, of new attempts to change the behavior of the poor with carrots and with sticks. "Forced work requirements" have support across the political spectrum these days. Even traditional champions of social welfare programs are now quick to acknowledge their flaws.
Many of the statistics aired in this debate simply stun, and indicate a legacy of poverty that has fallen disproportionately upon blacks. Three decades after President Lyndon B. Johnson declared his "war on poverty," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan cites a study by the University of Michigan that estimated 22 percent of all children born in the late 1960's spent at least a year in a family on welfare by the time they were 18. It estimated that 72 percent of the black children had.
Around the country, there is a growing sense in academic and political circles that the nation needs to rethink a welfare strategy that can reward dependency more than personal initiative. At the same time, working people buffeted by recession are ever more sensitive to the notion of "handouts" to chronic welfare recipients, many analysts say. Adding to this volatile brew is the extraordinary strain on state budgets these days.
 
Bigger Role in Campaign
 As a result, welfare, an issue that is with you always, has taken on a renewed prominence in this election year. Mr. Clinton, seeking to project a new, tough-minded Democratic approach to poverty programs, suggests an automatic two-year limit for many welfare recipients. "I want to erase the stigma of welfare for good by restoring a simple, dignified principle: No one who can work can stay on welfare forever," he declares.
President Bush, whose party has prospered by casting itself as the guardian of the middle-class taxpayer, rails against "deadbeat dads" and vows to "break this cycle of dependency that destroys dignity and passes down poverty from one generation to the next." Out in the states, where the welfare system is largely run, Governors from Tommy G. Thompson in Wisconsin to Jim Florio in New Jersey are pushing proposals that use financial incentives and penalities intended, they say, to encourage work and education among the poor.
California, as befits its image, is considering one of the more sweeping measures: This November, its residents will vote on a ballot initiative (felicitously named the Taxpayer Protection Act) that would, among other things, cut welfare benefits by 10 percent, along with an additional 15 percent for families with "an able-bodied adult" that have been on the rolls for six months. "We consider this an attempt to cut back on dependency," said George Gorton, who is managing the campaign for the initiative, put forward by Governor Pete Wilson.
 
Penalizing the Powerless
 Not everyone sees such tender motives at work. Advocates for the poor argue that much of the talk about encouraging work and personal responsibility is simply political cover for budget cuts, a rough new recessionary politics that penalizes the least powerful: one in seven American children is on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the basic welfare program. Robert Greenstein, head of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, asserts, "Incomes are stagnant, budgets are tight, and there's a very high degree of frustration right now. When that happens, people on the bottom who are not working are targets for resentments."
Welfare recipients have hardly been living the good life. Over the last 20 years, a time when more popular benefits like Social Security were regularly adjusted for inflation, the purchasing power of welfare and food stamp benefits for single mothers declined by an average of 27 percent, according to data from the House Ways and Means Committee.
Levels of generosity vary markedly: as of January, a needy single mother with two children in Texas received combined benefits of only $476 a month, just below Louisiana's but above Alabama's and Mississippi's, the House panel found. Among the better paying states are New York, at $806, and California at $850. In 1991, 31 states froze A.F.D.C. benefits and nine states actually cut them, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. Other welfare benefits suffered too: in Michigan, already meager assistance for childless adults was eliminated altogether.
Some advocates for the poor assert that the welfare issue, in some instances, is being used as racial code. Marian Wright Edelman, head of the Children's Defense Fund, declared in a recent speech: "While it is no longer acceptable in most polite circles to race-bait explicitly, bashing welfare has become the next best resort for politicians." She described it as "a fourth generation code phrase, perhaps more powerful than busing, quotas or Willie Horton."
 
Fundamental Unease
 All of these currents are, in fact, swirling through the current debate -- money, resentment, race, the many myths of welfare. "It's the domestic equivalent of Middle East politics, just wrapped in prejudice and attitudes," said Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat who has spent much of his legislative career on the issue.
But the debate also reflects a fundamental unease with the present system, a recognition in both parties that something is wrong with the nation's approach to poverty and that a simple cash assistance program will not put it right. Some politicians and analysts ask whether Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the basic welfare program begun under the Social Security Act of 1935, has come, in fact, to discourage marriage, support a rising illegitimate birth rate and perpetuate dependence.
Representative Mike Espy, a Democrat whose district encompasses the Mississippi Delta, and who is pushing measures aimed at encouraging savings and small businesses, argues: "Democrats have to get ahead of the curve. Let's admit that the present system does foster dependence, and let's move to a new system that fosters independence." Jim Pinkerton, a leading strategist in the Bush campaign, mentions the recent film about race and poverty in Los Angeles and says, "People have the 'Grand Canyon' feeling that there are tears in the social fabric that are getting worse, not better."
And Senator Moynihan, who has found much of his earlier writings vindicated by the new focus on dependency and the breakdown of families that is most acute among black Americans, says, "Suddenly we're back to our old friend, the urban crisis."
 
Voters Criticize
Yes to the Poor, No to the Idle

The public's discontent with the welfare system is captured by one remarkable statistic. The New York Times/CBS News Poll asked a question in May about the level of spending for "assistance to the poor," and two-thirds of the public said it was "too little."
That question was immediately re-asked, with one small change: the word "welfare" was substituted for "assistance to the poor." Only 23 percent said the nation was spending "too little" on welfare.
 
Perception Versus Reality
 A Times poll, conducted later that month, found that 74 percent agreed with the proposition that most welfare recipients are so dependent on the system that they will never leave it. Majorities also said that the welfare system encourages people to have larger families than they would have otherwise, and that it discourages pregnant women from marrying. In each of these cases, a public perception that may be true for some welfare recipients is inaccurate for the majority, who get off welfare within a few years, most often through marriage, and who on average have small families.
All of this co-exists with strong support for helping those who might have been called, in earlier times, the "deserving poor." Lawrence M. Mead, a conservative and author of "The New Politics of Poverty: the Nonworking Poor in America" (Basic Books, 1992), argues that many Americans consider the willingness to work to be the dividing line between the two.
"What the public wants to do is not spend more or spend less, but to cause the behavior of the recipients to change," he says. "What's at issue in the current social politics is: Shall we enforce values upon which everyone is agreed?"
Stan Greenberg, the poll-taker for Mr. Clinton, argues that the welfare system "symbolizes a lot of things that are wrong" to the middle class. "People don't understand why, particularly in tough economic times, with many full-time workers living near poverty, we have programs that appear to be based on the wrong values," Mr. Greenberg said. Honoring the "work ethic" and shaping welfare policies that reflect the importance of work, he argues, are critical to rebuilding support for poverty programs.
 
Trying to Reward Work
 Such views emerge in polling and in interviews around the nation.
Bryan Bauer, 35 years old, who owns a small construction company Houston, says flatly: "The system only works if everyone works within the system. You work, you get laid off and you have a family to support, you need it." But he added, "It's for temporary help until you're back on your feet."
Such an attitude has driven the policy debate over welfare in recent years; much of the energy has focused on easing, encouraging and rewarding the transition to work. The heart of the Family Support Act of 1988, a significant revision in the welfare law that was written by Mr. Moynihan, was the "welfare to work" provisions that required states to expand their job training and placement programs.
But there is a Catch-22 to "welfare reform" aimed at reducing dependency: It costs money, at least in the early stages. And the Moynihan law arrived just as many states were encountering their worst fiscal situations in years. As a result, states were using only about 60 percent of the Federal money available to those who could match it Mr. Moynihan estimated.
"We had a real consensus in 1988," said Mr. Moynihan, "and there's no reason to believe it disappeared. The money's disappeared."
 
The Role of Marriage
 Aside from work, the other value at the heart of this debate is marriage -- or at least, parental responsibility. The image of unwed mothers producing baby after baby, while the fathers disappear and the welfare check takes their place, is a powerful one. (Actually, almost three-fourths of the families on A.F.D.C. have one or two children, the American Public Welfare Association says.)
This image pops up in politics in various ways, sometimes with racial overtones, as when David Duke railed against a "rising welfare underclass." It was at the heart of the recent debate over Murphy Brown, prompted by Mr. Quayle's attack on the television character as an unsuitable role model. And it is part of the cultural subtext for measures like one in New Jersey that would deny additional payments to women who have more children while on A.F.D.C.
Many politicians worry that the children themselves get overlooked in all of this. "Paternalism, in general, doesn't bother me as a principle if it means you're going to provide guidance and help and goads to these people," said Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat. "The basic dilemma I have is this: What do you do when you have parents, usually mothers, who resist and resist and resist? At bottom, I am opposed to visiting the sins of the parent on the child."
There is, however, a strong bipartisan support for increased child support enforcement, which is evident on Capitol Hill and on the campaign trail.
 
Candidates Respond
 Promising Change In the System

Republicans have long used the Great Society and its supposed "giveaway" programs as symbols of a Democratic Party out of touch with "mainstream America." Vice President Dan Quayle, with his attacks on "cultural elites" and his appeals for "family values" is continuing in this tradition. The Clinton campaign, for its part, tries to use welfare to show its commitment to a new Democratic approach to government and poverty, which encourages the values of personal responsibility, work and family.
All of these issues were already swirling through the 1992 campaign, but the riots in Los Angeles guaranteed that the nation's attitudes toward the poor would be at the heart of the fall debate.
Before the riots, Mr. Bush was accused of practicing sound bite politics on poverty because of his commercial in the primaries promising to get the "able-bodied" off welfare and his declaration in his State of the Union Address, "Welfare was never meant to be a lifestyle." In that address he said that welfare recipients had responsibilities to work, "get their lives in order, hold their families together and refrain from having children out of wedlock."
Critics asserted that he had proposed little in the way of policy to foster independence, and was simply using the issue to galvanize an economically anxious middle class.
 
A Changed Tone
 Since the riots in Los Angeles, Mr. Bush has changed his tone, speaking more sympathetically about the plight of families on welfare. But his proposals on Capitol Hill remain modest, like a measure that would seek to encourage savings by the poor by raising the assets limit for families on A.F.D.C, many analyst says.
Mr. Clinton campaigns extensively on the need to revise welfare to encourage work. After two years, he says, he would have every welfare recipient capable of working either in a private sector job or working off their grant in a community service job.
His deputy campaign manager for policy, Bruce Reed, says, "I think that there's a growing consensus among Democrats that we have an obligation to end welfare dependency and reform the welfare system, to move beyond the rhetoric of the right and the mistakes of the left."
Analysts are still waiting for Ross Perot to present detailed positions on the welfare system and numerous other issues, although in recent appearances, he has talked about his concern about poverty and drug use. He is expected to emphasize job creation in poor areas, as well as early intervention for children through better health care and schools.
In the end, the Presidential campaign, and the debates roaring through states like California, could help forge a new consensus on poverty issues, connecting the ideas that have emerged in policy circles over the past decade with the attitudes that have been building in the middle class.
Still, almost no other issue carries so great a temptation to scapegoat and frighten. This is one part of the new welfare politics that has not changed.

HEADLINE: Companies Working Out of the Recession With No Added Jobs

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
After two years of being battered by recession, the Timken Company, a producer of bearings and high-quality steel in Canton, Ohio, is beginning to stir.
In its cavernous plant in a quiet city an hour south of Cleveland, forklifts whiz back and forth, and men and women in bright yellow hard hats scurry to fill the growing level of new orders. 
 But as the plant begins to churn out more and more steel products, its work force will not grow. "We've seen modest increases in demand so far this year," said Joseph F. Toot Jr., the company's chairman. "We expect demand to increase even more next year. But, if we're successful at making gains in productivity, we wouldn't add people next year either."
As manufacturers work their way out of a recession that trimmed their profits and work forces, Timken is the rule, not the exception. Executives in industries from chemicals and machine tools to steel and paper say they have no plans to recall workers, even if demand for their products becomes more robust in a year or so.
Their corporate policies are reflected in the spurt in the nation's unemployment rate by three-tenths of a percentage point in June to 7.8 percent that the Labor Department reported on Friday, leading the Federal Reserve almost immediately to cut the interest rate it charges on loans to banks a half point to 3 percent in yet-another effort to stimulate the economy.
The White House has been counting on an economic recovery to help President Bush's re-election campaign, and across the country laid-off workers have been counting on a recovery to restore their jobs. In some ways the signs of recovery are abundant, although the pace appears to be gradual. From the Government's Index of Leading Indicators to the economic index of the nation's manufacturing purchasing managers, there are persistent messages proclaiming an economic upturn. Still, gains have not appeared in hiring practices of the nation's heavy manufacturers.
Unemployment is a stubborn, perhaps even intractable problem. The latest data included a shorter work week, lengthening spells of unemployment and more layoffs as the ranks of the unemployed rose 470,000 to a total just under 10 million people.
 
Job Reductions Continuing
 "We're seeing an attempt to improve productivity in manufacturing without making additions to the work force," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former governor of the Federal Reserve and president of Brimmer & Company, a Washington-based economic consulting firm. "And so while the economy is expanding now, many companies are still reducing their work forces. It's not unique to manufacturing. You can see it in commerce and services as well as factory production."
Mr. Brimmer noted that employers were avoiding hiring to escape paying for benefits like health insurance and vacations. "Even as output has picked up in some industries, the chief response has been to increase hours, even paying overtime if necessary," he said.
One reason companies are able to produce more with fewer people, executives and economists say, is that the nation's heavy industries have so modernized their plants in the last decade, using computers and automated production lines, that many jobs have been made redundant.
At the Reynolds Metals Company, for example, nearly 5,000 jobs have been cut in a decade, many during the recent recession. "We will be able to manufacture more product with fewer people," said John R. McGill, the company's vice president of human resources. "Even if we see a sizable jump in demand, I don't see that it would affect the size of our work force."
 
Workers Won't Be Recalled
 Indeed, a monthly survey of the nation's manufacturers by Cahners Economics indicated that 59 percent of manufacturing companies surveyed said many jobs eliminated during the recession would not return because operations had become more productive.
Moreover, there is a worldwide overcapacity for many products as diverse as truck tires, polyethylene, aluminum and office paper that has led to intense price competition, lower profits and a reluctance to hire.
That means thousands of workers laid off during the recession will not return to highly coveted jobs. In Canton, as in many communities across America, manufacturing jobs were long thought to offer security and relative prosperity for people with little more than high school educations.
"It has been many people's lives because manufacturing jobs tend to be high-paying jobs in communities like ours," said Charles T. Edwins, a manager in the Canton office of the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services. "Many people hold out hope that improvement in the economy will make their jobs available to them again, but I don't know how realistic that is coming out of this recession. In economic times like we're in now, there are more people in the labor market than there are jobs."
 
Recovery in Fits and Starts
 Part of the reluctance to add workers, economists and executives say, reflects the expectation that the economic recovery will be slow and characterized by fits and starts. But part simply reflects new corporate efficiencies.
At the Ferrow Corporation, a maker of coatings, specialty chemicals and plastics, demand for the company's products has risen. Production at the Cleveland-based company's plants is now 12 percent higher than a year ago. But Hector R. Ortino, senior vice president and chief financial officer, said there were no plans to add to the work force. "With our present structure, we can easily handle a far greater increase in demand with our current work force," he said.
Similarly, PPG Industries, a Pittsburgh-based maker of glass and paints, reported growth in orders and production, but no plans to add workers in the coming year.
 
'We're Holding the Line'
 "We're holding the line on hiring and working hard at being as productive as possible with the work force we have," said John S. Ruch, a spokesman for the company. Even if the prediction of continued economic growth comes true, he said, "it's unlikely that our work force will grow."
Of course, many companies do expect some hiring in the next year, saying that their operations have been staffed too leanly during the recession to handle increases in demand.
"We have already seen an increase in demand, and we've brought back or hired 969 people to the tire side of the business," said Hoyt M. Wells, president and chief operating officer of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Mr. Wells said the company had added equipment to a plant in Alabama, increasing the work schedule to six days from five. "That has necessitated that we increase the number of crews of people from three to four," he added.
 
But Some Are Hiring
 Some smaller companies are also increasing their work forces. There are also plans by companies to increase inventories, marketing outlays and spending on new plants and equipment. But mass production no longer means mass employment.
In the chemical industry, for example, employment peaked at 1.1 million workers in 1981. But that had fallen to 1.09 million in 1991 and has stayed around that figure. "Companies in our industry don't want to hire more people because people cost money," said Allen J. Lenz, chief economist with the Chemical Manufacturers Association.
Mr. Lenz estimated that employment in the chemical industry was unlikely to change for years. "It's hard to determine if this is going to be good for the industry in the long run," he said. "But when you're dealing with day-to-day problems, you have to go for the short-terms results."
In the machine tool industry, employment fell to 56,000 in the early part of this year from 59,500 in 1991, according the Association for Manufacturing Technology.
 
Demand for Machine Tools
 William G. Copeland, president of the Copeland Economics Group, an economics consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn., predicted that demand for new machine tools would increase by about 30 percent in a year. "Detroit canceled a lot of machine-tool orders in the last year, and we think those orders will be replaced in the early part of next year," he said.
Nonetheless, he said he expected employment to rise to only 59,000 workers, below last year's level and far fewer than the 64,300 the machine tool industry employed in 1990.
Even the steel industry, which has endured tough economic weather in the last few years, is seeing improvements in shipments this year, running about 9 percent higher than in the first six months of last year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Demand is picking up because of increased demand from automobile and appliance makers. Still, Milton Deaner, president of the association, said he expected employment to remain around the current level of 143,000 workers. "Analysts have predicted that shipments for this year will increase to 83 million tons, from 72 million tons last year," he said. "But we think employment will remain where it is."
If there is a slender hope for laid-off workers, it is that some economists question whether companies will be able to step up their production, if the economy's rebound is strong, without adding workers.
Referring to the goal of increased productivity, Kermit Baker, the chief economist at Cahners Economics, said, "That's always the goal of a manufacturing operation but whether they can achieve that remains to be seen."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC POWERS FACING THEIR LIMITS AT MUNICH SUMMIT

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 4

 BODY:
At the summit meeting of leaders of the world's seven most powerful industrial democracies beginning Monday in Munich, the dominant problems will be global economic stagnation and the danger of violent ethnic conflict in the former Communist countries.
Since the same problems preoccupied the last summit meeting here a year ago, there will be an air of pessimism at the gathering, which many of the leaders had hoped would be a post-cold-war celebration of the triumph over Communism. 
 Pre-summit briefings and news conferences by President Bush, by other leaders and by their aides left little impression that this, the 18th in a series of meetings originally designed as informal "fireside chats" of world leaders, would lead to a breakthrough.
 
Gorbachev Just a Memory
 The aura of hope that surrounded last year's talks in London, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was welcomed by most of these same leaders almost as one of them, is gone this year. So is his country, the Soviet Union, which collapsed in the wake of a hard-line coup attempt about a month after the London meeting.
Still with them are many of the problems that the heads of the United States, Canada, Japan, Germany, Britain, France and Italy, plus the president of the European Commission, discussed but failed to resolve at their last two meetings. These include a continuing impasse in negotiations for a new agreement to govern more than $1 trillion in world trade, weak economies in all seven countries, and problems of ethnic strife.
Over the next three days, the summit leaders are expected to promise to keep trying to achieve a new global trade agreement by the end of the year, and to grant President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia a $1 billion down payment on an International Monetary Fund plan to pay for badly needed imports and modernize the economy.
 
Yeltsin, Guest and Lobbyist
 They may agree to a limited moratorium on Russian debt repayment if Mr. Yeltsin provides assurances when he appears before them on Wednesday afternoon that he intends to keep moving toward a market economy. In Moscow today, Mr. Yeltsin said Russia would ask the summit leaders for a two-year moratorium on repayments of principal and interest on the former Soviet debt. [Page 6.]
Beyond the $24 billion already pledged by I.M.F. member nations to aid the transition of the former Soviet economies to the private market, the Munich meeting appears unlikely to offer much. "We can't finance the transition in its entirety," said Horst Kohler, state secretary in the German Finance Ministry. "That's not feasible."
President Bush, who visits Poland on Sunday before going to Munich on Sunday night, and the other leaders are also expected to agree on a package worth $600 million to $700 million to finance safety improvements to Soviet-built nuclear reactors in Eastern Europe.
This measure is planned out of fear that if nothing is done, Europeans could face more nuclear accidents like the near-meltdown at Chernobyl in 1986. It is not clear whether all seven of the nations at Munich will take part.
 
Avoiding Yugoslav Quagmire
 The summit leaders are expected to deplore the Yugoslav violence, as they did last year, and indicate greater support for the United Nations peacekeeping force that is trying to control it. Mr. Bush made it clear last week that American ground combat forces would not become involved, and most European countries are eager, as well, to stay out of the fighting.
Most of the summit participants will move to Helsinki on Thursday for a two-day meeting of 52 European and North American leaders to continue the search for a new security structure and agree on country-by-country ceilings on armed forces in Europe. Beyond this, expectations are limited.
"There's a sense of institutional hollowness, a staleness, as people go to Munich," a senior American official said. "After the euphoria of the end of the cold war, a kind of Monday morning feeling has set in."
Most of the leaders coming to Munich face mounting political problems at home, problems that limit their room to maneuver. Mr. Bush is in the political fight of his life for re-election. The Socialist Party of President Francois Mitterrand has hit near-record lows in French opinion polls, one reason for his extraordinary visit to Sarajevo last weekend.
 
Diplomacy in a Beer Hall
 The Japanese Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa also faces a difficult election campaign, and the Germany of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, after the political euphoria of unification, is suffering from an economic hangover. Possibly this is why the first event he scheduled is an informal lunch on Monday in a typical, if slightly up-market Munich beer hall, the Spatenhaus.
"The global economy will intentionally be the main point," Mr. Kohler said. "Currently growth is weak and recovery is under way, but it is of uncertain strength and dimension."
There, too, the leaders are not considered likely to take bold steps. The United States, with chronic budget deficits and unemployment at an eight-year high, is hardly in a position to lead the way to world recovery, even though the Federal Reserve Board lowered its key interest rate on Thursday to 3 percent, from 3 1/2 percent.
Germany's equivalent rate is 8 percent, and Bonn is keeping its interest rates high because of inflation brought about by its unprecedented deficit spending to reunify the country economically as well as politically. German officials say they do not expect their central bank to soon follow the American action.
Officials in Japan have also been saying in effect, "We've already done all we can." Mr. Miyazawa told Mr. Bush on Wednesday that he planned to spend $47 billion to $55 billion on a package to stimulate his country's economy and possibly spur demand for American and other Western imports. Japan has a ballooning trade surplus, one that again worries American and other Western leaders.
 
Discord Over Farm Subsidies
 Crucially, the leaders will be confronted in Munich with their failure to make good on pledges to conclude a new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, an accord that could go a long way toward bringing about economic recovery.
The talks have been deadlocked by disagreement between the United States and the 12-nation European Community on agricultural subsidies. American officials say that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was willing to come to Europe this weekend to try to achieve a breakthrough before the meeting, but that the Europeans were unwilling to make the concessions on reducing export subsidies Washington considered necessary for an accord.
The leaders are not expected to resolve this issue in Munich, German and British officials say, but they will probably issue another commitment, their third, to see to it that there is a new GATT accord by the end of the year.
"I think the United States must also find maneuvering room," Mr. Kohler said in briefing reporters in Bonn on preparations for the meeting.
American officials believe that Mr. Mitterrand, President of the biggest agricultural power in Europe, is the central figure among the Europeans, and hope that Mr. Kohl will push him to make greater concessions. But with French farmers angry about the cuts in price supports recently decided upon by European Community agriculture ministers, he may not be willing to.
"The best thing we can do for all these countries, from the third world or from the Soviet Union, is to open our markets, and that's very much bound up with GATT," said Richard Portes, director of the Center for Economic Policy Research in London.

French Farm Protest Goes On
 PARIS, July 4 (Reuters) -- Protesting French farmers blocked rail lines in the southeast today, aggravating transportation problems caused by a six-day protest by truck drivers.
The farmers blocked parts of a line in the area of Avignon, cutting the route from Lyons to Nice. Elsewhere, trains near Bordeaux were halted.

HEADLINE: Indian-White Rape Case Splits Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28

 BODY:
With his yellow parrot headdress, Paulinho Paiakan has emerged in recent years as a worldwide symbol of Brazilian Indians' defense of their Amazon homelands.
"A new Gandhi," proclaimed Anita Roddick, who purchases Brazil nut oil from the Kaiapo Indian chief for her international cosmetics chain, the Body Shop. 
 "A man who would save the world," the American magazine Parade trumpeted last April in a cover profile of the powerfully built Kaiapo with shoulder-length hair and piercing black eyes.
International awards, television appearances in the United States and a heroic role in a children's cartoon series were all to culminate this fall with the filming of a $40 million Hollywood version of Mr. Paiakan's life, directed by Ridley Scott.
 
Accused on June 2
 Then, a bruised and battered 18-year-old woman appeared June 2 at a police station in Redencao, 1,000 miles northwest of here. She accused the 37-year-old chief of raping her in the back seat of his Chevette, a charge the chief denies.
"Explosion of savage instinct," said the headline in Brazil's largest selling news weekly, Veja, which broke the story on its June 10 cover. "The chief symbol of ecological purity tortures and rapes a white high school girl."
The ensuing uproar has bared Brazilian attitudes toward rape, race and Indian rights. Today, feminists are fighting anthropologists, who in turn are fighting Brazilian press barons for supposedly inciting an anti-Indian backlash.
The young woman, a Portuguese language tutor for the chief's three children, charged that after a long day of drinking at a barbecue he attacked her and forced her to have sex with him, causing her to lose her virginity.
 
Granted Numerous Interviews
 The woman, Silvia Leticia Ferreira, has been widely identified by Brazilian news organizations and has granted numerous television and press interviews about the case; she has also allowed photographs of the bruises she said were inflicted in the attack.
In initial press interviews, Mr. Paiakan admitted, then denied, having sex with the woman. Formally charged with rape, the Indian leader in a police deposition June 19 again denied that he ever had sex with the woman. Instead, he said that his wife, Irekran, grew jealous of the younger woman and raped her with her fingers.
[On Tuesday, a presiding judge received a police report that affirmed that Ms. Ferreira's underwear was stained with her blood and with Mr. Paiakan's sperm.]
The chief awaits trial while under house arrest in his native village, A-Ukre. A cause celebre in Brazil, the chief's defense has been taken up by a legal team led by Luis Eduardo Greenhalgh, a human rights lawyer who is Deputy Mayor of Sao Paulo.
 
Legally a Ward of the State
 Feminists assert that the Kaiapo chief is hiding behind his wife, knowing that she cannot be indicted. Because she does not speak Portuguese and is only vaguely familiar with Western ways, she is legally considered a ward of the state and cannot be tried in Brazilian courts.
The chief, on the other hand, attended missionary school, speaks Portuguese reasonably well, has a bank account, owns an airplane and a city house, drives his own pickup truck, and has traveled overseas, mostly recently to London last April.
Many anthropologists fear that the rape charge against the Kaiapo chief is being used to discredit Brazil's Indian rights movement and their foreign backers.
 
Group Founded by Rock Star
 "We are all worried that the Paiakan affair is being used by people who have designs on the wealth of the Indian territories," said Olympio Serra, an anthropologist who is president of the Brazilian Rain Forest Foundation, a Kayapo support group founded by Sting, the British rock star.
Anthropologists say rape is rare among the Kaiapo. Traditionally, rape was restricted to warfare against outside groups.
"If a rape occurred, it was a reflection of his living among white people," said Darcy Ribeiro, a Rio anthropologist.
Mr. Paiakan and other Kaiapo chiefs are caught between both worlds. Often touted as "Brazil's wealthiest Indians," the 5,000 Kaiapo earn millions of dollars a year in royalties from gold and mahogany extracted from an archipelago of reserves stretching over 42,500 miles in central Brazil. Responsible for nearly half the economic activity in Redencao, the chiefs have second households and often indulge in sexual liaisons with local women.
 
A Rarely Punished Crime
 Traditionally in Brazil, rape is an underreported and rarely punished crime. For example, in nearby Ceara state, 930 rapes against girls under 18 were reported in 1990. Of these cases, only six led to arrests.
Mr. Paiakan also said he is being persecuted. "Why aren't gold miners who rape and murder Yanomami women punished?" he demanded of reporters, referring to northern Amazon tribe whose lands are frequently invaded by gold seekers. "Is this law only for me?"
Marcos Terena, an Indian spokesman, said, "When a white man rapes an Indian woman, there is never any scandal."
In a growing backlash against the Indians, more and more Brazilians say the Government is bottling up vast amounts of timber and minerals by recognizing huge reserves to shelter Brazil's 225,000 indigenous people -- about 1.5 percent of this impoverished nation's population. Under Brazilian law, logging and mining in Indian reserves can occur only with tribal permission and by paying royalties.
Although daunting legislative hurdles remain before the reserve could be abolished, the vote reflects regional dissatisfaction over setting aside a mineral-rich area larger than Portugal for 10,000 Indians.
In another action last week, 2,000 settler families invaded a 650-square-mile ranch in a frontier town near Redencao. During the Earth Summit, an Italian oil company, under pressure from Italian and Brazilian human rights groups, gave up its 25-year-old title to the land and announced the return of the ranch to its traditional inhabitants, the Xavante tribe.
Racial tensions are also high in Redencao, where Paulinho Paiakan maintains a townhouse and a small farm. "An Indian's place is in his village, a rapist's place is in jail," read a banner carried by protesters through streets of Redencao, in early June.
In reprisal, Kaiapo Indians sacked a store, blocked the airstrip to A-Ukre, and temporarily trapped 3,000 loggers and gold miners on Indian lands. Recalling that Kaiapo Indians killed 22 white squatters in 1981 and rioted at Redencao's hospital in 1990, residents of the Amazon town panicked at rumors that Indians would invade and burn the courthouse.
To defuse tensions, Redencao's Mayor banned liquor sales to Indians, banned sound trucks by protesters, and arranged the Kaiapo's trial to be shifted to more neutral territory, Maraba, a town 210 miles to the north.

He was accompanied by family members as he surrendered to Brazilian police officers. (Olava Rufino/AJB)

HEADLINE: As Interest Rates Are Cut, Retirees Are Stung

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Listen to June Johnston, 84 years old, of Salt Lake City, or to Lois Hair, 79, of Gainesville, Fla., or Homer Weaver, 85, of Houston, and you hear the anxiety and anger of those who see themselves as the economy's other losers.
They are not the unemployed, who need work, or the young families who cannot afford to buy homes. Their goal is security of another kind: a safe place for their savings and a predictable income. They invested in savings accounts and certificates of deposit, only to watch their income be drastically reduced as the Federal Reserve sliced its discount rate from 6.5 percent in January of 1991 to 3 percent last week. 
 The rates on C.D.'s, which banks typically offer for terms from three months to five years, are set by banks but tend to hover near the discount rate, the lowest rates at which banks can borrow from the government.
"I depend on it," Mrs. Hair, a retired secretary, said of her monthly interest income, now down to $300 from about $600 just 18 months ago. "But I can't afford to gamble on anything else. I want to stay safe, but I'm only getting half of what I used to get." Her only other income is about $600 a month in Social Security payments.
 
Leery of Stock Market
 In a time of low inflation and low interest rates, many investment advisers recommend stocks, bonds and other investments that return much higher rates than savings accounts and certificates of deposit. But experts say that older people with limited assets tend to be leery of the stock market and its risks.
"They have been schooled to stay away from equities," said Lester I. Kaplan, executive director of the Jewish Community Center of Greater Washington in Rockville, Md., which provides services for more than 5,000 elderly people. "They have relatively little choice about what they put their money into. They cannot risk putting it into stocks for fear the principal will decrease. Adults tend to stay with C.D.'s because they are not only economically but psychologically attached to principal.
"The great fear of senior adults is what will happen if they become frail. The fear is that they will become dependent. A senior adult views independence as some people view life itself. One of the great securities is having money in the bank."
Erna and Melton Wallace of Houston, both 78, took early retirement 16 years ago. The last two years have slowly eroded the interest income they had come to count on.
"Every time they drop it, it drops our money farther down," Mrs. Wallace said, "and now it's practically to bottom,. We've just quit eating out altogether. We seldom ever eat out, maybe once every six weeks to two months, we'll have a little binge. We don't go to movies any more. I quit bowling because I couldn't afford the fees."
 
Dipping Into Savings
 In Salt Lake City, Mrs. Johnston, a former assistant librarian, said she was dipping into savings because she could not get by on interest and Social Security alone. "Every time the interest rates drop, it makes me sad," she said. "It's just one more drop in the living scale."
Or as Mr. Weaver, a retired contractor, said: "It just means we have less money to live on. I don't have a pension. The only retirement fund we have is the one we created ourselves."
But one economist, Tim Smeeding, a professor of economics at Syracuse University, argues that the decline in interest rates is part of cyclical economic fluctuation, and can be weathered by those who have a mixture of different kinds of investments. Putting money into certificates of deposit, he said, "was betting on high interest and high inflation."
He added: "The only kind of people who could be in trouble are those who have Social Security, no private pension and a small amount of savings they count on for private income." An outside estimate of their numbers, he guessed, would be one-fifth of the total elderly population, or a maximum of about 6 million people of the 31 million people 65 years old or older. But, he said, these totals may be exaggerated.
"I just can't see this as being all that terrible a problem," he said. "The idea is, if you've got enough money for the rate drop to make a difference, you should be diversified. Some who have problems ought to consider their portfolios and get some advice as to how to invest it. They might have to take a little risk."
Etta Keevil, an 88-year-old retired librarian from Seattle, is not willing to do that. Her C.D.'s now earn about 4 percent, down from 9 percent a year ago, so her income from them is reduced from $18,000 a year to about half of that. But, like others her age, Mrs. Keevil remembers the lessons of the Depression, a time of frugality. Housebound and physically restricted, she said she is too old to take risks. Rather than change her investments, "I could go into savings," she said.
 
'No-Win Investment'
 Ursula Constantini, of Ocala, Fla., did pull out of C.D.'s after her interest rates went from 6 percent to 2.5 percent. "It's a no-win investment," she said.
Others will not abandon the safety of federally insured C.D.'s. "You think about getting into stocks," said William Langley, 75, a resident of a retirement community in Silver Spring, Md. "But I don't want to take the risk."
Many of the retired interviewed in Silver Spring and Rockville, Md., who live in one of the nation's richest counties, indicated the interest rate drop had little effect on their spending habits. "I'm lucky enough that I don't have to cut out too much," said Lilli Isner, 76, a volunteer at the Jewish community Center in Rockville. "But yesterday I went to the bank; I had some certificates coming due. They were paying 3.2 percent, down from 6.8 percent a year or so ago. And I remember when I got 13 or 14 percent."
