HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
Luck and Voter Scrutiny Forge a Rare Harmony

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
Congress left town for the most patriotic of holidays after its most bipartisan votes of the year on Thursday, with Republicans and Democrats both supporting urban aid in the House and Russian aid in the Senate, and, in both chambers, changing unemployment law for both the long and the short term.
Rare combinations of political necessity and lucky timing helped forge agreement on those measures, after months in which the most frequent item of agreement was on the impossibility of breaking the legislative gridlock. In coming weeks, conflicting party interests and philosophies seem sure to bring renewed conflicts on issues from abortion to hunger and taxes. 
 Still, Thursday's unity is worth examining for its ingredients. They illustrate what was there that day and what is usually absent from the working of the 102d Congress.
Nothing caught Thursday's unusual mood better than the sight of Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania, the Republicans' chief deputy whip in the House, urgently persuading colleagues to support procedures to bar amendments to the urban-aid bill so it could sail through safely. Most afternoons, Mr. Walker sees prohibitions on amendments as tyranny.
But the urban-aid bill contains an enterprise-zone proposal whose terms satisfy Republican orthodoxy. Even more important, this is a measure that Republicans have helped build from the ground floor in the relatively swift two months of lawmaking since the Los Angeles riots. For the enterprise zones, Republicans in Congress and the Administration accepted Democratic demands for greater social-service programs in exchange for tax breaks for investors.
 
Unusual Harmony
 "Everybody gave a lot and got," trying the best of each other's ideas, said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. One thing each side got was temporary relief from the public perception that Congress is engaged only in debate "contrived because of politics," he said.
That sense of shared purpose united Republicans and Democrats against amendments to the urban-aid bill so they could squelch an expensive increase in Social Security payments to the "notch babies." Those people, born between 1917 and 1926, complain that a technicality in the law has cheated them because people born earlier or later than that get higher benefits.
In the Senate, the eventual unity behind aid for the former Soviet Union was, as they used to say in Moscow about far more dubious propositions, a matter of historical inevitability. After piling senatorial distraction on distraction during the debate, with diversions to everything from the balanced-budget amendment to a dialogue on President Truman, the aid bill passed.
All along, the only question had been when that would happen. The argument against helping Russians or Uzbeks or Ukrainians while Americans were in need was heard from time to time, but not often, and the Senate's sense of history left it no alternative but passage. In the more parochial House, in contrast, strategists were talking this weekend about what they would try to get from the Bush Administration as a bribe for passing the aid bill.
 
Economic News Prods G.O.P.
 The near unanimity on the unemployment bill was locked in by the morning's news that the national unemployment rate had jumped to 7.8 percent in June. President Bush had talked in the morning about vetoing the bill. But lawmakers in both parties rolled their eyes at that idea, although House Republican leaders were prepared to support him, if necessary.
It would have been simple if the bill had provided just another emergency extension of benefits for workers who had exhausted their state payments. But the Democrats had grown more and more insistent that the need to keep voting for stopgap aid showed that the fundamental benefits law was too tightfisted and needed to be amended to protect more workers.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk, kept pressing more senior Democrats to stand and fight on this issue. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, decided this spring that permanent changes were needed to make extra benefits easier to get in a recession. His conservative approach left him in a position to deal with the Administration and to bring along another canny Senator, the minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas.
Mr. Bentsen's ability to deal with the Administration made the House Ways and Means Committee accept a bill that avoided the most obvious way to pay for the changes: by raising the base on which taxes to pay for emergency benefits are calculated.
The limit is now $56 per worker per year, whether the worker earns $7,000 or $200,000, though unemployment benefits themselves are higher for workers whose paychecks are bigger. With Republicans dead set against increasing the wage base because that would be a new tax, other ways to pay for the change were found, including revised rules for taxing lump-sum pension payments that everyone agreed not to call a new tax.
 
Agreement on College Loans
 There was one other mark of bipartisanship in the week's events, an agreement between the Administration and Congress on a new higher education bill. Congressional Republicans talked the Administration out of a veto of a plan to provide student loans without using banks as intermediaries because voting against college grants and loans is perhaps even less popular in an election year than voting against the unemployed.
Similarly, Democrats may succeed this week in prying House Republicans away from their loyalties to Mr. Bush and into bipartisan harmony born of electoral necessity on a trade bill. The measure would direct the Administration to identify the nation's most difficult trading partners and take action to remove their barriers. It is counter to Republican theory, but lawmakers are likely to judge the issue far more in terms of their constituents than in terms of political philosophy.
But once Congress returns July 21 from the Democratic National Convention, the prospect is for bitter party fights. Three issues stand out.
First, Democrats plan to pursue abortion-rights legislation so as to cause maximum conflict among Republicans and embarrassment for Mr. Bush. They expect a veto but intend to argue that the rejection will be just one more reason not to re-elect him.
Second, attention will turn to another Downey bill, a five-year plan to provide $3.5 billion to help keep children within troubled families by providing social workers on call and to provide $3.5 billion to increase food-stamp allotments for families with children. It would be paid for by a 10 percent surtax on incomes of more than $1 million per year.
The bill got only one Republican vote in committee, that of Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut, and its tax feature would invite a veto. But Democratic leaders are increasingly thinking of it as both good policy and good politics, serving two sympathetic constituencies by taxing the rich.
And there will be more arguments over health care. Democrats are seeking common ground on ways to cut costs and increase access to health care, while Republicans are stressing a different agenda that relies on cutting paperwork costs, curbing malpractice suits and creating a new tax plan called a Medisave account, which they think would motivate patients to keep medical costs down.
That is gridlock.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Clinton Camp Finds the Time Is Ripe

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 4

 BODY:
Taking advantage of the fruits of discipline, circumstance and political serendipity, Gov. Bill Clinton is poised to enter the Democratic Party's nominating convention in the best strategic position he has enjoyed since his checkered Presidential campaign began.
Mr. Clinton is using an extended holiday weekend to mull over his Vice Presidential selection and to formulate a general election campaign that presents him as the most substantive and change-oriented candidate in a three-way race. 
 Recently, the campaign has had a modicum of success. Mr. Clinton and his aides are convinced that they succeeded in luring the White House onto their turf last week when poor employment statistics forced President Bush to defend his handling of the economy. The day before, the President had taken the unusual step of submitting to random questions on a live morning talk show, an approach used to advantage by both Mr. Clinton and Ross Perot.
"The mood of the electorate is very different today than in 1988," said Paul Begala, a Clinton strategist. "That's the whole thing George Bush doesn't get."
 
Leaning on Specifics
 Their goal is to keep the debate centered on the economy and on an agenda of debatable specifics on topics like education and health care that will put the Bush-Quayle campaign on the defensive and contrast Mr. Clinton's details with Mr. Perot's generalities.
If this approach succeeds, it will allow Mr. Clinton to campaign for President on the terms he has long sought. Instead of answering questions about his character and his personal behavior, he will be debating the issues he is convinced voters want to hear more about.
"The one thing that's been clear throughout the 1992 campaign has been that people want real answers, not political ones," said Bruce Reed, the deputy campaign manager for policy. "And what most frustrates them about politics these days is that politicians say or do whatever it takes to get ahead instead of telling them honestly what they plan to do when they're President."
Mr. Clinton and his campaign staff are now reaping the benefits of the strategy they settled on at the close of the primary season. They decided not to attack Mr. Perot, who was then surging in popularity polls, predicting that such a battle would make them look worse instead of better.
"We swore almost a blood oath that we would spend June talking about Bill Clinton and that we would not join in any political fight with either George Bush or Ross Perot," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker. "We now have an audience."
The campaign's spokeswoman, DeeDee Myers, added: "It's like in baseball: Good teams make their breaks."
This newly attentive audience, the campaign strategists hope, has now tuned in as Mr. Clinton uses his return to the spotlight to choose a running mate, deliver a carefully composed acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention and begin a hectic cross-country campaign immediately after leaving New York.
In the past, the two months between the convention and Labor Day were largely devoted to the political equivalent of killing time, waiting for the fall campaign to officially begin. But this year, his advisers acknowledge, they will be a crucial period for Mr. Clinton.
"These breaks don't last too long," observed James Carville, a senior strategist.
President Bush has already telegraphed some of the punches he plans to take when he gets into what he describes as "campaign mode," saying that Americans will be voting on experience and temperament. Presumably, the President is referring to Mr. Clinton's lack of experience on the national and international stage and to Mr. Perot's reputation for having a short fuse.
The Clinton forces say they are prepared for the White House to take aim at Mr. Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas and his lack of foreign policy experience.
"I'll put his plan up against our record any day of the week," said George Stephanopoulos, the campaign's communications director.
But a greater vulnerability for Mr. Clinton may lie in the Republicans' ability to transform a debate about family values into a discussion about Mr. Clinton's moral fitness.
Vice President Dan Quayle, while doggedly refusing to say that his remarks are aimed at Mr. Clinton, has continued to expound on the need for a return to family values. But this message was muted last week when a Little Rock trip that the White House had billed as an effort to embarrass Mr. Clinton in his home state occurred on the same say that the Labor Department announced the startling new rise in unemployment.
His claim that Mr. Clinton's economic plan was a "pipe dream" went virtually nowhere. Meanwhile, the Democrats seized on the bad economic news as evidence that Mr. Bush was not doing enough to help the economy.
The statistics undercut Mr. Bush's assertion that the recession was ending more quickly than he had been given credit for, and they reinforced Mr. Clinton's conviction that he had hit upon the formula that would strike a stronger chord among voters -- their distrust for politics and their unhappiness with the economy.
 
Fewer Talk Shows
 Mr. Clinton, whose campaign in the last month has largely been limited to walking in and out of television studios, is expected to rely less on talk show appearances in coming weeks. One adviser said that approach, which was considered novel only weeks ago, is now an "old formula."
Instead, aides said, he will be appearing before crowds more, often in town meeting formats where audience members are allowed to ask questions. Part of this plan is meant to appease the candidate, who has been unhappy that technology has cut him off from the sort of campaigning he enjoys most -- old-fashioned handshaking.
The Democrats arrive in New York for their orgy of self-congratulation next week knowing it is the last time Mr. Clinton will have the stage to himself this year and keeping in mind at least one the lessons they learned in 1988. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's 17-point post-convention lead in the polls disappeared in large part because the convention itself became, as one adviser put it, "a little too much a celebration of the past" and no one had planned for the months that followed.
Much of the Democrats' post-convention strategy is closely held. But the one clear strategy reflects the lessons they have learned.
"You come out of the convention campaigning hard and never let up," said Mr. Stephanopoulos.

HEADLINE: Demonstrators Are Targeting The Democrats

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
In a year in which the trappings and structure of politics have paled in the glare of voter resentment, the Democratic Party had hoped to seal its Presidential nomination in a celebration marked by unity and calm. Instead, the Democratic National Convention, which begins in New York a week from tomorrow, is expected to play out before a backdrop of protest the likes of which the nation has not seen since the Vietnam War.
With the drama of the streets competing for attention with that on the convention floor, comparisons to the 1960's are inevitable. Yet the scope of the protests and the variety of their demands could be wider, as more groups with more agendas than ever before try to steal their spotlight from the Democrats. 
 "In the 1960's the fight was just for civil rights and against the Vietnam War," said Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. "Now, there are a lot of wheels moving. Now, it's black, it's brown, it's lavender and yellow and white. My sense is that it's going to be bigger, it will be louder and it will be angrier than anything we've seen for years."
More than 20 groups representing hundreds of local and national organizations have announced plans to hold demonstrations for issues like homelessness, abortion rights, gay rights, civil rights, unemployment benefits, housing, health care and police brutality. A conservative note will be added by Operation Rescue, the national anti-abortion group that has vowed to shut down New York-area abortion clinics while blaming the Democrats for ignoring the rights of the unborn.
As of last Thursday, police officials had issued eight demonstration permits. But at least as many more groups have vowed to join the fray. The job of keeping the peace has fallen to Police Inspector Michael Julian. In a telephone interview last week, he outlined police preparations and said police officials did not fear widespread disorder. "These are all intelligent people with very serious causes," he said. "What they want, and what they will get, is an opportunity to be heard."
The only trouble he really expects is the battling-megaphone syndrome in which two groups may want to shout their pain at once. In that event, the group with the permit will be allowed to keep yelling, but those without will have to relinquish their sound systems.
Logistics could also be a challenge. Mr. Julian said the police can move "hundreds of thousands" of people peacefully through the city. Yet there could be trouble if the groups move beyond police lines. "Ever since L.A.," said Mr. Julian, "people seem to think that violence is a natural part of these things. Look at the Gotti verdict. When did you ever see cars turned over in the street because someone didn't like a verdict?"
 
Impact on Platform Unlikely
 The protesters' impact on the Democratic platform is likely to be slight. Most of the major issues have been decided. But the street-side jeering could steal the convention's thunder and perhaps even some of its television exposure. More troubling to party officials is the prospect that the protests' scope and diversity could make a powerful statement about the level of voter rage in an election year that increasingly holds that very anger as its central theme.
The irony for the Democrats is that the language of outrage was supposed to be part of their message, one for them to send, not receive.
Protests are also expected in Houston, though on a much smaller scale. Operation Rescue has announced it will be holding "rescues" during the Republican Convention, and liberal groups may gather as well. However, the location of the Houston Astrodome and police preparations for the event should keep demonstrations small and far from the delegates.
In New York, the Democrats will have to fight the grass-roots coalitions outside their doors to get their message across. And rather than the spontaneous demonstrations in the 1960's, party officials will have to deal with demonstrators well versed in media manipulation and armed with organizational sophistication that often includes the presence of marshals whose sole job is to keep the protests peaceful, orderly and legal.
"There will be 75 television trucks parked outside the convention hall," said Mr. Siegel. "Activists know that New York is the theater capital of the world and they are going to do their theater."
Most of the groups will arrive with speakers, posters and the standard paraphernalia of politics. But like any great political campaign, there will be surprises, too, and on the streets, a wacky side that transcends the standard whistle and beanie indulgences of the convention floor.
 
Variety of Tactics
 Lifting tactics from Act Up, the AIDS advocacy and protest group, and even some refined by the Chinese during the Tiananmen Square upheaval of 1989, protesters will press their cause with an array of approaches from the simplest sound bite and slogan, to "fax zaps" and "phone zaps," intended to tie up convention phone lines with an avalanche of incoming ire. Citywide "wheatpastings" should leave almost every light pole, newspaper box, subway entrance and public space with a message -- and an attitude. And candles will flicker quieter judgments at prayer meetings of the homeless and those opposed to abortion rights.
The more radical of the groups intend to invade the convention hall itself. One group leader who insisted on anonymity said her organization had obtained 25 floor passes from a friend within the Democratic Party, giving them open access to the Garden. "We'll be doing something inside," she said. "But I can't say what, because then the guards would know what to look for."
Act Up is almost certain to take a lead in aggressive tactics. "We are going to be zapping the candidates," said Amy Bauer, an Act Up member. "There will probably be confrontations in public, and also in private functions. We want them to know that Act Up is watching, that we are paying attention."
 
'This Is Deadly Serious'
 How will Act Up members gain access to the convention hall? Ms. Bauer said the group's members would have no trouble getting in, and would dispense with some of the wilder garb that has marked some of their protests in the past. "This is deadly serious," she said. "The more attacks we can get in against George Bush and the total lack of action on AIDS the better off we'll be."
The Women's Action Coalition, a new and rapidly expanding feminist group, has scheduled a "W.A.C. Convention" on July 14, the night the city's museums are opened to the Democratic delegates. Protesters will carry a banner putting the Democrats on notice that there are "10 million more women who vote than men," and march down Fifth Avenue distributing leaflets with information on women's issues and a list of demands covering economic equity, health care, child care, violence against women and discrimination.
"We are going to have professional politicians getting these materials and we wanted to really show them that we are out here, and we're angry and we're informed, and we're going to pressure them," said Lindsay Walt, a member of W.A.C.'s convention committee.
 
Surprising Success
 B. C. Craig, a member of Act Up's 12-person Campaign '92 team that has organized an AIDS march for earlier that day, said a coalition of more than 270 groups will be represented there. They include such obvious supporters as health-care providers and gay and lesbian organizations to less predictable allies like the March of Dimes. Mr. Clinton and Jerry Brown have endorsed the group's five-point platform, she said.
Some groups say they are astonished by their success at organizing. "This whole thing just started as an idea," said Jasmine Griffin, an insurance company worker who has helped organize the "Take Back Our Lives" march, scheduled for July 13, to protest violence against women. "We put together a wish list of who we'd like to have come speak. The incredible thing is that most of them said yes!"
It is nearly impossible to predict the size of that and other rallies. Some may only bring out a handful of people to chant and sing and shake their fists. Others could draw anywhere from a handful of faithful to thousands of protesters enraged at a system they no longer trust.
 
Police Brutality an Issue
 On July 12, the Rev. Al Sharpton and other black leaders will stage a rally and march to press the Democrats to endorse more black issues. He declined to predict its size, saying: "I won't play the numbers game." But he added that preliminary rallies are already being held in Harlem and elsewhere by black leaders trying to call attention to the need for protest. "We just can't allow the convention to come through here and have laryngitis about police brutality," Mr. Sharpton said Thursday.
While the demonstrations play out in the streets around the convention hall, another, more familiar, drama is expected to stretch from Brooklyn to the Bronx. Last summer, leaders of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue said they would use the convention week to stage their largest "rescue" ever, in an attempt to shame the Democrats for their stand on the abortion issue.
Operation Rescue leaders have since indicated that activities around the convention will be of a regional rather than national scope, and presumably smaller than at first anticipated. But the group's telephone hot line on May 31 encouraged participants to "torture the Democrats" over the issue. Last week some of the top leaders started to convene in Manhattan.
Daniel Brusstar, a coordinator of the Bi-State Operation Rescue Network, which represents Operation Rescue in New York and New Jersey, said anti-abortion protesters would hold a series of prayer meetings throughout the week and would attempt to shut down abortion clinics.
"We want to try to bring attention to the reality of abortion, which is the killing of an innocent life," he said.
Abortion-rights supporters have been preparing to meet that challenge for months, and have received a surge of support themselves in the wake of the Supreme Court decision to uphold most of the limits a Pennsylvania law places on abortion. More than 2,000 volunteers have already been trained in a series of meetings held throughout the region.
Efforts to block Operation Rescue teams are expected to be a $100,000 undertaking involving the establishment of a "clinic defense hot line," a telephone bank operation designed to coordinate volunteers, and the printing and distribution of a mountain of leaflets, posters and signs. It could be the largest coordinated abortion rights effort in the history of the debate. It could also be a sideshow in a city fascinated by its discontent.

HEADLINE: Documents Warned in '85 of Iraqi Nuclear Aims

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
Newly declassified Pentagon documents describe warnings as early as 1985 that there was a danger that American technology could be illegally diverted from Iraq's nuclear energy program into an effort to make nuclear weapons.
The documents indicate that Administration officials had warnings about Iraq's dangerous nuclear ambitions much earlier than previously known. They were released this week as Congressional Democrats pressed their case that the policies of the Reagan and Bush Administrations toward President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were flawed up to his invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, and may have also been criminal. 
 One May 1985 Defense Department document cited a Central Intelligence Agency report "indicating that Iraq continues to actively pursue an interest in nuclear weapons, that the large number of Warsaw Pact nationals in Iraq makes diversion in place a real possibility and that in the past, Iraq has been somewhat less than honest in regard to the intended end-use of high technology equipment."
 
Restrictions Were Urged
 The paper, written by Richard N. Perle, then Assistant Defense Secretary, to Caspar W. Weinberger, then Secretary of Defense, recommended that "to protect our national security interests" the United States impose certain restrictions on sensitive equipment and technology sold to Iraq.
Another document, a March 1985 Pentagon memo, said Iraq had refused to provide assurances that it would not use two American computers in its nuclear program. The Pentagon memo argued in favor of requiring such assurances, noting that the State Department was arguing against it.
"Iraq is a problem country, at least in the mid-to-long term," the memo argued, noting that it had "many if not all" of the elements necessary to reprocess uranium in place and possessed about 100 to 112 pounds of highly enriched uranium. "While we have seen no evidence of a weapons-design program, it makes sense to apply controls to help deter the use of U.S. computers in any such program."
It could not be determined whether the two computers were eventually shipped to Iraq, but American computers were used by the Iraqi military. According to a previously released November 1986 memorandum, for example, Pentagon officials warned that a license for a hybrid computer for the Saad 16 missile complex near Mosul should be denied "because of the high likelihood of military end use and the association of the involved companies in sensitive military applications." The memo stated that the computer could be used to monitor wind-tunnel tests for ballistic missiles.
 
Overrode by Commerce Dept.
 But the Commerce Department overrode the objections and the sale went through without any conditions. The Saad 16 complex was a key target of allied bombing raids in 1991 in the American-led assault to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
Representative Sam Gejdenson, the Connecticut Democrat who released the newly declassified documents on Wednesday, said he was doing so to counter President Bush's statement on a network news program that day that the United States had not enhanced Iraq's "nuclear, chemical or biological capability." Mr. Bush said that he had issued an executive order on the subject, adding, "You have repeated something that isn't true."
"I'm watching the CBS Morning News and the President says we didn't help his chemical or nuclear or missile capability at all, and that is not factually correct based on the Administration's own documents," Mr. Gejdenson said in an interview.
Some of Mr. Bush's own aides are uncomfortable with his blanket denial, which he first articulated last month at a news conference in Rio de Janeiro. The aides have noted that American technology did enhance, albeit inadvertently, that capability.
 
October 1989 Directive
 Even the executive order to which Mr. Bush referred, a national security directive signed in October 1989 that became the cornerstone for his Iraq policy of economic and political incentives, implied that the United States should sell Iraq equipment related to its nuclear energy projects as long as it was not weapons-related.
Other memos released earlier by Mr. Gejdenson showed that Bush Administration officials were convinced that Mr. Hussein would continue to develop his military capability despite the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988. An undated State Department memo written early in the Bush Administration, for example, stated that Iraq's military attache in Washington was actively trying to buy equipment that could have military applications.

HEADLINE: Gov. Weld's Stature Rises in G.O.P.

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 3

 BODY:
Gov. William F. Weld did something Michael S. Dukakis could not do: balance the Massachusetts budget without raising taxes. Now he is doing something George Bush will not do: advocate a change in the Republican platform favoring abortion rights.
Through a combination of fiscal conservatism and support for traditionally liberal causes like abortion rights, Massachusetts' 46-year-old freshman Governor has rapidly become a national figure and a potential leader for many Republicans. 
 "Bill Weld is already one of the more popular governors around because he has not raised taxes," said William Schneider, a visiting professor of American politics at Boston College and a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. "He could really emerge as the hero of the pro-choice Republicans. There are a lot of angry moderate Republicans out there, and they are a constituency waiting to be led."
 
Mixed Reviews in State
 While Governor Weld's reputation has spread nationally, he is getting mixed reviews at home. There is general agreement that his biggest accomplishment was in balancing last year's budget after three years in which Governor Dukakis presided over growing deficits as the state had to borrow from Wall Street.
"Achieving fiscal stability is the single most important thing a governor can do to help the economy of his state, especially given the perception that we were out of control," said Michael Widmer, the executive vice president of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, a business watchdog organization. "And Bill Weld did it without raising taxes in a year in which 30 other states had to raise taxes."
The budget for the new fiscal year, which began July 1, is expected to be passed by the Legislature within a week and to be in balance after Mr. Weld makes some minor vetoes.
But there is less agreement about whether the spending cuts Mr. Weld has made to balance the budget have been fair and about whether he has really succeeded in his much publicized efforts to transform state government by making it more entrepreneurial. A wealthy lawyer whose father ran the family investment bank, the Governor has been particularly criticized for the impact his cuts have had on programs for the poor and on public higher education.
 
'It Comes Ttoo Easy to Him'
 "I think he makes some of these cuts in a very calculated way, targeting certain groups that aren't popular so it won't affect his popularity," said Deborah Weinstein, executive director of the Massachusetts Human Services Coalition. "It comes too easily too him. I don't think he understands what it's like to live on a few hundred dollars a month."
One of Mr. Weld's biggest cuts, made with approval from the Democratic-controlled Legislature, was to replace the state's general welfare assistance with a smaller program with more stringent eligibility requirements called Emergency Aid to Elderly, Disabled and Children. Of the former 38,000 recipients, 15,000 have lost their monthly checks of up to $308 while 6,000 more are continuing to receive benefits while appealing their disqualification for the benefits.
Joyce Whitford, a 36-year-old jewelry saleswoman who has not been able to work since she suffered a nervous breakdown two years ago, is one of those appealing her benefit cuts. "He's taking things away from people who really need it," she said. "If I lose my benefits, how does he expect me to live?"
Mr. Weld also trimmed the Medicaid benefits of 9,000 people 18 to 21 years old, all young people who were not pregnant or disabled, on the theory that younger people could better withstand the loss of medical benefits than could the elderly.
In a potentially much more sweeping change, Mr. Weld's staff is preparing a plan to overhaul the state's welfare system that would essentially end Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Currently, about 200,000 children and 100,000 adults receive welfare benefits in Massachusetts.
To replace welfare, the state would increase its education and training program for women in poverty, requiring them to find jobs themselves or accept work assigned them by the State Welfare Department. In addition, Governor Weld's plan envisions greatly stepping up efforts to collect child support from fathers, using this money to partly replace welfare payments. Under the new plan, after an 18-month transitional period, mother's who had received welfare benefits would be on their own.
The plan would have to be approved by the Legislature before going into effect as well as receive some Federal waivers. In the state, it is already drawing fire.
"This would put people in an untenable position with artificial deadlines," said Ms. Weinstein, of the Human Services Coalition. "It assumes there are jobs out there, good-paying jobs, and that something magical will happen within 18 months so that these women will earn enough to pay for child care and health insurance."
Governor Weld has insisted that his cuts will preserve a social safety net. He says Massachusetts overspent on human service programs in the 1980's compared with other states and must now trim its tastes back from "a Cadillac to a Chevrolet."
That tough fiscal stance has won him praise from national conservative organizations and has led to speculation that he might be a strong candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996. In a Wall Street Journal article in February, Stephen Moore of the Cato Institute, the libertarian research group, gave Mr. Weld the highest mark among the 50 governors on a fiscal report card.
 
Abortion Confrontation
 And the debate over abortion within the Republican Party could thrust Mr. Weld into the limelight at the party's convention in Houston next month, if he decides to confront President Bush and the strong anti-abortion wing of the party.
In an interview, Mr. Weld insisted it was too early for him to decide because there are still unknown factors: the public reaction to this week's Supreme Court on abortion, and whether the Republican platform committee will adopt an anti-abortion plank.
In May, Mr. Weld appealed to the platform committee to at least make the plank neutral on the subject, in keeping with the idea of making the Republican Party a "big tent" inclusive of divergent views.
"If they make it a closed tent, we'd certainly side with the pro-choicers," he said, speaking for himself. Aides to Mr. Weld say it takes six state delegations to force a floor fight on the platform, and as one of six Republican Governors who favor abortion rights, he would be willing to deliver Massachusetts.
 
Challenges Ahead in State
 Beyond this year's election, Mr. Weld faces some tough challenges in the remaining two years of his term as his state's battered economy tries to recover from its worst economic slump since the Great Depression. The recession has cost Massachusetts 10 percent of its jobs over the past three years.
Some economists think biotechnology may do for Massachusetts in the 1990's what computer companies did for it in the 1980's, and the Weld Administration has been trying to attract drug manufacturing plants. It helped find land in Boston for the Cambridge-based Genzyme Corporation, one of the most successful biotechnology companies, which wanted to move to the manufacturing stage from research and development.
But Katharine Bradbury, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, expressed skepticism about how much any governor can do to revive his state's economy. "Governors can't do much to stimulate economic growth," she said.
Mr. Weld's efforts to reform state government, making it, in his words, "slim down, get faster and more customer oriented," have also met an uneven response.
He cites the closing of nine large old state mental and public hospitals, which had been designed for 35,000 people but which were housing only 6,000. They are gradually being replaced by what Mr. Weld says will be smaller, less expensive community-based facilities.
Mr. Weld's most ambitious plan, to date, is a new bill to overhaul the state's public schools. Much like the changes introduced in Arkansas by Gov. Bill Clinton, it would strip teachers of tenure and seniority, giving school principals more authority to reward or punish their teachers' performance.
 
Promise of Education Aid
 The bill would also set a minimum statewide average for spending for each pupil of $5,058, with the state helping the poorest communities that are currently trapped by a law that inhibits them from raising property taxes as fast as the rate of inflation. Mr. Weld has promised $800 million in new state aid to education over the next five years if the are passed by the Legislature.
But Mr. Weld's proposal has been sharply criticized by some business leaders and Democrats in the Legislature. They say the Governor's new money would barely replace state financing that has been cut over the past two years. Instead, they want to ease the law that limits communities from raising property taxes for schools, something Mr. Weld adamantly opposes.
State Representative Mark Roosevelt, a Democrat who is chairman of the House Education Committee, has this assessment of Mr. Weld: "He has no idea where he is going. This man is so much more bark than bite. I don't see any entrepreneurial government. There isn't enough intellectual energy or commitment."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Perot's Letter to Reagan in 1987

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a letter sent by Ross Perot to President Ronald Reagan on April 8, 1987, on Mr. Perot's study of American prisoners of war in Southeast Asia. 
 Dear Mr. President:
My findings on the POW/MIA study are as follows:
We left POWs behind at the end of the war in Vietnam.
We knew we were leaving men behind.
The men left behind were held in Laos.
The evidence that men were held in Laos is substantial --
*There are 343 MIAs in Laos.
*During the war, Pathet Lao officials repeatedly made public statements about holding POWs, including statements made directly to me.
*The CIA listened to the Pathet Lao radio system during the war, and had detailed information about live POWs in Laos. (During my trips to Laos during the war, I was personally briefed on this point by the CIA.)
*At the end of the war, the Pathet Lao publicly stated that they would not release the men until they received the money promised in the Nixon reparations letter.
*The Paris negotiations with Vietnam did not include POWs from Laos. The Vietnamese emphasize this point.
*The Pathet Lao never released any POWs directly or explained what happened to the men they held. (A small number of men who were captured in Laos and turned over to Vietnam for detention were released by Vietnam, along with the other POWs.)
In the Spring of 1973, Congress decided not to pay the $3.25 billion President Nixon had committed in his letter.
Watergate was underway, and our government was not functioning well.
In April, 1973, the Defense Department publicly declared that there were no more living Americans being held in Southeast Asia.
*This is the most significant mistake made by our government on the POW/MIA issue.
*This was done at a time when we knew we had left men in Laos (and probably in Cambodia and Vietnam).
 
. . .
 Several months ago, I recommended appointing a Presidential negotiator. I urge you to appoint a personal representative to negotiate with the Vietnamese. General Vessey is an excellent choice. He will have my full support.
POW/MIA family members and veterans groups will react positively to this action.
General Vessey must report directly to you -- not to the Secretary of State or the NSC -- if he is to have the status needed to successfully deal with Vietnam.
General Vessey's role cannot be limited to recovering the POW/MIAs and remains. This would make him ineffective with the Vietnamese. His role must be a broad one -- to resolve the outstanding problems with Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.
 
. . .
 During my meetings with the Vietnamese, I carefully postured the conversations so that the MIAs would be found in Laos and returned by the Loatian government. This approach allows Vietnam to avoid criticism for having held the men.
Information regarding economic conditions in Vietnam and Southeast Asia and other concerns expressed by Vietnam's leaders were conveyed to me during the meetings. This may be helpful to General Vessey. Howard Baker has this information, but I am not including it in this letter in an effort to keep it brief.
 
. . .

 
 Best wishes,
 Sincerely,
 Ross Perot
Comments on Meetings With Foreign Minister Thach
 
. . .
 Several times they commented, "We won the war and yet you do not treat us with respect." They feel that we are rude and arrogant in our dealings with them.
They resent the fact that they continue to allow us to come into Vietnam to talk with them about the POW/MIAs, and freely travel throughout their country -- and yet, we do not reciprocate in the U.S. They are subject to a twenty-five mile limit when they visit the UN. (Foreign Minister Thach was particularly sensitive about this subject.)
 
. . .
 "Your government declared your own men dead shortly after the war. How can you expect us to take you seriously about looking for men who may be alive after all these years. Why did your government declare these men dead right after the war?"
The Vietnamese do not trust our government. They pointed out several times that our government has not kept its promises. (It would be possible to get a list of the promises they feel we have not kept.)
The current team negotiating for MIA remains is ineffective. The Vietnamese believe they are minor figures in our government who have no authority, and can only "make demands."
 
. . .
 The economy is in bad shape. People are hungry. The soldiers are hungry and are not always paid. Corruption is a serious problem.
The Vietnamese openly admit this. It appears to be their number one concern.
*They are reading economics books.
*They know they must change their economy, but they don't know what to do.
*They would welcome our help.
*They are most interested in direct assistance from the private sector, feeling that the private sector knows more about business than the government. (I believe this is their primary interest in me.)
They would like to have an economic representative from Vietnam in the U.S., studying how we do business. (This person could be located in either the Swedish or Swiss Embassy, according to them, and would keep a low profile.)
They would like to be able to have teams come from Vietnam to the U.S. to study specific industries. The Vietnamese economic representative would coordinate these activities.
They would like for the U.S. to have economic representatives living in Vietnam. This group could be operated privately, if the government does not wish to become directly involved. The Vietnamese would prefer to have a private group from the business world, because they would have more practical experience than people from government.
The Vietnamese have studied me in detail.
They say conditions in the South are better than in the North.
These people have a great deal of pride, toughness, and willingness to endure. We must be careful when dealing with them not to underestimate them.
 
. . .
 I explained to Thach that it would not be possible for our two countries to work together until the POW/MIA problem was resolved.
*He accepts this, but needs shows of good faith on our part.
 
. ..
 Thach, who is very shrewd, picked up on Laos right away, saying he was willing to help us in every possible way in Laos. He emphasized that the Paris Treaty did not cover U.S. POWs in Laos. He knew exactly what I was doing in focusing on Laos (giving him a graceful out by having the men come out of Laos.)
He indicated a willingness to have U.S. teams in Hanoi, to conduct a full scale search of their country.
He indicated a willingness to help us establish teams in Laos to conduct searches of Laos.
After returning from this trip, I received word through an intermediary that a senior Pathet Lao government minister wants to meet with me to "sell some POWs." I doubt that it resulted from my Hanoi visit. It is a remote possibility, but I will check it out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Dinkins Is Mastering The Art of the Mayor

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Imagine a Mayor who trims $2 billion from New York City's vast bureaucracy in a single year, cobbles together a $500 million surplus despite a recession, moves aggressively against possible police corruption, stands up to the city's labor unions and demonstrates toughness and guile in outwitting state legislators.
David N. Dinkins? Precisely. 
 As recently as a year ago, that would have been unimaginable, as the Mayor and his administration lurched through a series of crises that sometimes seemed to overwhelm them. But over the last six months, and in particular over the last 11 weeks, Mr. Dinkins has engineered a remarkable turnaround, demonstrating on an array of issues that he is seizing control of his government.
"I think we're beginning to find ourselves," a senior aide said last week. "When John Lindsay came in, people said, 'These people can't even find the lights.' I think we're beginning to find the light switches, and things are working a lot better."
 
More Tests to Come
 To be sure, Mr. Dinkins still falters on occasion, and he will be tested many times before facing re-election next year. In just the next few weeks, he faces opposition to his plan for a new incinerator in Brooklyn and battles over new contracts with municipal unions. The city still confronts awesome and perhaps insoluble problems like unemployment, crime and homelessness, and voters may take their frustrations out on the Mayor.
His political opponents, including his likely challenger in the Democratic mayoral primary, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, say they have not been particularly impressed by Mr. Dinkins's recent performance. Mr. Stein contended that the Dinkins administration was in "severe disarray" during its first two years and that the Mayor had now "settled into routine incompetence."
"It's not as bad as it was," Mr. Stein said, "but it's still horrendous."
But there are abundant signs of change, both in the way Mr. Dinkins runs the city and in his results.
 
Triumph Upon Triumph
 The first sign came in January, when the Mayor issued a preliminary budget that won praise from previously skeptical business leaders and fiscal experts for beginning to confront head-on the city's long-term financial problems. In late April, Mr. Dinkins announced the budget surplus. Four weeks later, he wrapped up negotiations with the City Council over the budget for the new fiscal year a month before the deadline, the earliest such agreement in memory.
Around the same time, Mr. Dinkins received credit for the calm that prevailed in New York while Los Angeles and other cities exploded after the verdict in the Rodney G. King beating trial.
And two weeks ago, he surprised many people when he moved quickly and decisively after news reports of possibly widespread corruption in the Police Department.
Mr. Dinkins, a cautious, deliberative man who has been faulted often for responding too slowly and too dispassionately to events, wasted little time in announcing that he would set up an independent panel to investigate the charges. He also made public a plan to create an all-civilian board to review complaints of police brutality. In both cases, he overruled Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown.
 
Tactical Maneuvers
 Perhaps the most symbolic manifestation of the Mayor's newly assertive style came last week, when the Mayor used a bizarre fiscal gambit to outmaneuver several state lawmakers who were trying to place stricter legislative controls on a major expansion of the city's police force.
Mr. Dinkins had sought to save $20 million over the next year by postponing the start of training for 2,100 new police officers until the new fiscal year. He needed permission from the Legislature to postpone the starting date, and assumed that approval would be granted as a courtesy. Instead, he found himself under pressure from lawmakers who tried to withhold permission until the Mayor agreed to their demands.
Among the earlier criticisms of Mr. Dinkins was that he had not learned how to lobby the Legislature effectively. This time, he discarded his customary technique -- quietly offering reasoned arguments in the hope that his position would prevail on its merits -- for the stealth of a political in-fighter.
He ordered the police recruits to report for duty at 11:59:59 P.M. on Tuesday, the final second of the fiscal year. That enabled him to meet the letter of the law, which required the new officers to report during the fiscal year that ended Tuesday, and still avoid having to make $20 million in pension contributions for the recruits over the next year.
 
Not Taking It Anymore
 The gimmick, which worked because the recruits received no salary in the 1992 fiscal year, antagonized some state lawmakers. But it also sent them a powerful message: that the Mayor was tired of being pushed around and was willing to resort to extraordinary means to protect the city's sovereignty.
"You have to have a little bit of flair, to show that you can give as good as you can get, and he had never demonstrated that before," a senior city elected official said.
The string of successes contrasts vividly with the week in October 1990 that has long been emblematic of the administration at its nadir. Over just a few days, the Mayor reached a labor settlement with the city's teachers that was widely criticized as too expensive, announced a $1.8 billion program to add thousands of new police officers and then began talking about laying off as many as 15,000 other city workers.
Mr. Dinkins has struggled for nearly two years to overcome the sense of disarray conveyed that week. Now he and his aides believe they have finally rounded a critical corner.
"The wind's at our back," First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel boasted last week.
 
Practice and a Little Luck
 The Mayor's aides offered several reasons for the turnaround: practice (it takes time, they said, to master the complexities of the $30 billion-a-year city government), good fortune and an evolution in the Mayor himself.
Several advisers said that Mr. Dinkins had been more intense and focused since last fall. Some speculated that the Mayor finally felt really comfortable in his job, and decided with conviction that he wanted to win re-election.
Many advisers also said that Mr. Dinkins had become more open to different strategies to obtain his goals. A year ago, they said, he probably would not have approved the police-class gambit.
Mr. Steisel and Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, Mr. Dinkins's chief political adviser, whose relationship has sometimes been said to be problematic now say they and other senior aides are working together more smoothly.
Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that "we're certainly more adept now than we were on Jan. 1, 1990," when he took office.
 
Ratings on the Rise
 It remains uncertain what political dividends the Mayor will yield from his managerial turnaround. Two recent polls, one conducted for a municipal union and another for New York Newsday, showed a sizable jump in Mr. Dinkins's favorable ratings, which had dropped sharply. But the polls also showed that the Mayor continued to suffer high unfavorable ratings, and Mr. Stein argued that it was hard for a politician to counteract such negative impressions.
But many politicians said the Mayor could only be helped in the long run if New Yorkers see him grappling successfully with the budget, the police and other significant matters.
"All of his actions in the last few weeks suggest a heightened capacity to respond swiftly and surely to whatever events the day brings," said Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, a longtime Dinkins ally. "In the first two years of his administration, there were fewer swift moves and fewer tough decisions."


GRAPHIC: Some major moments for David N. Dinkins in the last 11 weeks.
"CHRONOLOGY: "Good News For the Mayor"
April 21: A budget surplus of more than $200 million is announced, enabling New York City to avoid borrowing for operating expenses in the next fiscal year.
April 22: The surplus estimate is raised to $455 million.
April 29: In the wake of the verdict in the Rodney G. King beating trial and riots in Los Angeles, Mayor Dinkins and aides work to dispel rumors and calm neighborhoods, and New York is spared serious violence.
May 26: The surplus estimate grows to $515 million, allowing the Dinkins administration to withdraw a proposal for $115 million in new taxes.
May 30: The Mayor and City Council leaders agree on a $29.5 billion budget, the earliest city budget pact in memory.
June 18: Mayor Dinkins announces a plan to appoint a special investigator to look into charges of police corruption.
June 25: Mayor Dinkins appoints a five-member panel of judges and prosecutors to investigate police corruption. He urges the Council to approve an all-civilian agency to monitor charges of police misconduct and brutality.
June 29: The Mayor circumvents state lawmakers by saying that 2,100 police recruits will begin training at 11:59:59 P.M. the next day, the final second of the fiscal year. The plan saves the city $20 million in pension contributions and thwarts legislators seeking to influence police hiring.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Golden, Gifted and Confused About Her Future

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSERO KRUGLOYE, Russia

 BODY:
Svetlana Boginskaya, one of the world's best gymnasts for a very long time now, is having a case of the 19-year-old jitters.
It's not just the approaching Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, which she has said will be her last. And it's not so much the usual confusion, in the debris of the former Soviet Union, about where her loyalties lie. Nor the declining standards of food provided for the Commonwealth of Independent States' best gymnasts, who live at this permanent but deteriorating training center at Osero Krugloye, or Round Lake, in the pretty forests an hour's drive north of Moscow's grime.
Her confusion is really about growing up, and what to do with her life when her already extraordinary career as another of the great pixie gymnasts is over, as it must be, and quite soon.
 
Brilliant but Unsure
 Like Steffi Graf and other tennis stars before her, whose machinelike nervelessness began to collapse with the onslaught of young adulthood, Boginskaya sometimes wonders whether she's any good at anything at all. It is quite an unsettling thought for a gymnast whose brilliance has been indisputable since she first became all-around winner at the 1989 world championships,
"I try not to think about Barcelona," she said, playing with two thin silver necklaces and touching a line of earrings pierced into one ear. "I try not to think it's the Olympics, but that it's just another competition." She paused, pulling back her hair. "The more you think about it," she said finally, "you just get more nervous."
 
No Zmeskal Rivalry
 Although much has been made of her rivalry with the younger American star, Kim Zmeskal, 16, who defeated her in April at the world championships in Paris, Boginskaya says she feels "absolutely neutral" toward her competitors. At the 1991 world championships in Indianapolis, Boginskaya barely lost because of what many believed to have been the overenthusiasm of American judges. Asked about Indianapolis, Boginskaya began to cry, but only for a moment. Brushing a tear away and trying to hide it, she said: "Well, it's all in the past."
She stopped again, then said: "Of course, I want to be the best. I've always been that way."
Fidgeting in her pink trousers, rolled up above her molded calves, she said softly: "It may seem strange, but mostly I want to take the upper hand over myself. I feel some uncertainty, and I tell myself sometimes I can't do anything the way I want to do it, and feel I'm incapable of anything."
 
'Repetition and Repetition'
 She knows it's an absurd feeling, she said, because she's been a world champion for so long. "But the last year and a half have not been so successful for me," she said. "I'm growing older, and it becomes harder for me to train the same way as before. When I was younger I did many of the elements easier than now, and sometimes I make errors. And of course, when I was younger, we studied new aspects all the time. Now it's more routine work for me; it's repetition and repetition, which is of course less interesting."
It's a little strange to hear such thoughts from someone so girlish and lithe, seeming almost to disappear inside her fashionably loose trousers and tank top, but Boginskaya knows she must plan for her future after sports, and she knows a good show in the Olympics may be crucial to her marketability.
"In the future," she said, "maybe I'll leave for professional sport, or maybe work as a choreographer, or in advertisements for sports clothes. At least that's my plan so far." She said she's already had some proposals from manufacturers.
 
Competing for Themselves
 The Olympics itself, for the last "unified team" the former Soviet Union is ever likely to field, now provides a different sort of motivation than in the past. If previous Soviet teams were told to win for "progressive socialism" as much as for their motherland, now the athletes know that they are also competing for their careers in a tough, private marketplace.
"Before the Seoul Olympics," Boguinskaya said of the 1988 Games, in which she won the gold medal in the vault and the bronze in the all-around, "we were told we have to protect the honor of the motherland, that you perform not only for yourself, but you display the image of the Soviet Union and socialism. Now they don't say things like this, but we know ourselves what we want."
And that is? "We want to win the Olympics," she said. "There can be no minimum performance there."
 
Shows and Endorsements
 The chief coach of the women's gymnastic team, Aleksandr S. Aleksandrov, is blunter. "These girls are only teen-agers, but they understand their future depends on their performance at the Olympics," he said. "Many will leave the sport afterward, and now that it's easier to leave the country, or come and go, they can take part in various professional shows or sponsorships."
Boginskaya says she's friendly enough with her fellow gymnasts, but they're younger, "and I can't be frank with them." That's why, she said, "I mostly talk with the boys' team. They're mostly the same age, and more interesting for me." Does she have a boyfriend? Blushing, she pushed aside her hair. "Well, I have many friends who are boys, but I can't say one is my boyfriend."
She says she feels closer to the young women who were her teammates, but who now have left gymnastics to make their lives in this complicated, dead empire undergoing economic difficulty and reform.
"The girls are practically all married now and many have children," she said. "They write me in their letters, 'Sveta, enough of this gymnastics! Live a normal life!' But I think it's difficult now to live a normal life, because our country is not in a normal situation."
Aleksandrov thinks Boginskaya has "good prospects" in Barcelona in the vault, the beam (her favorite) and maybe in the all-around. As a team, he said, "our plan is three gold medals, a silver and a bronze," but he says there is more competition this year than in 1988.
As for Zmeskal, Aleksandrov says he doesn't want to offend her, "but usually each world champion brings something new, some new beauty or complexity, and I didn't see anything new in her." Frankly, he said, "I like Shannon Miller more. She has a good program that meets today's demands, at least as we see them."
Aleksandrov said he thought that some of the American gymnasts emphasize their leaping and dancing ability at the expense of mastering the sport's technical points.
Boginskaya is wistful for life, having hardly lived an ordinary one. Her father, a builder, and her mother, a housewife, are from Minsk, in Belarus. Boginskaya started in gymnastics at the age of 7, pushed by her parents. "It was boring for me at home," she said. "So in the first years of school, when a lady coach came and asked who wanted to go into gymnastics, I agreed. I wasn't much of a gymnastics fan then, but my parents said they'd better send me to some sports group, because I wasn't obedient at home and didn't listen to them."
Now, of course, her parents are proud, but she sees little of them. For more than half her life, since the age of 10, Boginskaya has been coming here to the Olympics training camp at Osero Krugloye, at first for 10 days a year, and then for longer and longer periods. "You could say I've spent most of my life here," she said.
Not that the life is bad amid the forests. There is a dormitory for the athletes, excellent facilities, no lines for food and few worries. But now, of course, with the end of large state subsidies, maintenance is lacking, the grass is growing long and the paint is peeling. And both Boginskaya and her coach agree the food is worse, with less dairy products, fresh fruits and vegetables.
Will she go back to Minsk when her career is finished? "Maybe," she said. "I just don't know what will happen. So far I only know gymnastics."
Here she gave a big, grown-up sigh and shrugged. "Of course I want to do well," she said. "But life is very complicated, and in the end, you must give in to it."

HEADLINE: Interest Rate Bubble Is Going to Burst

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Bush Calls on Fed for Another Drop in Interest Rates" (front page, June 24) makes me sad. This overuse of monetarism is unsound. The excessive use of monetary theory interferes with the more rational play of supply and demand in the bond market. Keith Trauner rang the bell in an article in Barron's last April 13, stating: "Never in my experience has the price of a commodity doubled in a time where its supply has quintupled." The flaw in the Nicholas Brady-Alan Greenspan bond scheme will be that the law of supply and demand will eventually catch them.
One of the dangerous consequences of this bond scheme is the redistribution of wealth taking place on Wall Street. To keep the Bush-Brady bond scheme greased, Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has continually had to lower interest rates.
This continual lowering of interest rates has pushed the public out of certificates of deposit to seek higher returns. This has caused excessive evaluation in the stock market. The public is being fleeced.
This will only serve to multiply the social dislocations when the bubble bursts. President Bush, like Ronald Reagan before him, is playing stooge for the Stock Exchange.
The Federal Reserve has lowered the interest rate more than 20 times since 1989. Unfortunately, gross debt keeps increasing.
The things the Bush Treasury has done to sustain this hoax go beyond the absurd. The Treasury postpones borrowing. It postpone taking over savings and loan institutions. It postpones the marking to market of bank assets. Withholding schedules have been changed, veteran benefits accelerated. The breakdown of Treasury refunding has been changed (lowering the 30-year offering).
Now, President Bush calls for lower interest rates to keep this bank-fed Treasury bond scheme going. He's over his head. The longer it takes the public to realize it, the further in the hole we get. We've already reached the point of social dislocations. What next? Anarchy?
 
RUDE KERVEN
Fayetteville, N.Y., June 24, 1992

HEADLINE: More Thoughts on the S.E.C. and Mutual Funds . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Congratulations to Barry Guthary for his insightful analysis of the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposed rules to govern mutual funds ("The S.E.C. Misses on Mutual Funds," June 14). Having both sold and bought mutual funds (before my retirement), I agree with every point he makes -- particularly his emphasis on small investors. The bulk of people likely to own stock are likely to do so through some kind of mutual fund, including variable annuities. A clearer and more comprehensive prospectus would aid greatly in choosing among the hundreds of funds now available. 
 I would add only one issue to those raised by Mr. Guthary: the details, including past payout records, of variable annuities sold by insurance companies. It's well-nigh impossible for the small investor to find out the various fees assessed by the various companies; only a few are able to inform would-be purchasers of their payout records and thus enable the individual to make a reasonably informed judgment as to likely future payout. As life expectancy increases and inflation continues to be a permanent part of contemporary life, the variable annuity is growing in popularity for retirement income. The S.E.C. has extended its jurisdiction over this part of the insurance industry and demands standard prospectuses for each variable annuity, to which all of Mr. Guthary's criticisms should also apply.
 
LEONARD S. STEIN
Evanston, Ill., June 15

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
The Ultimate Hauling Machine?

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
FIRST, a brief quiz on today's topic, which is BMW. The answers will be woven skillfully into the text. Unless I forget.
1. What do BMW's initials stand for? 
 2. What major announcement did the company make last week?
3. What is the significance of the company's round emblem?
4. Why is the emblem blue and white?
5. What do you do if you are a BMW fan, can afford only one car but need room for kids, dogs, tents and skis?
Taking the last question first, you just dig down into your jeans for $38,600 and trot over to the dealer for the latest offering in BMW's midlevel 5-Series, which is really what this is all about.
The vehicle is called the "Touring," a neatly-done multi-purpose version of the 525i sport sedan and the first station wagon ever to be imported by BMW of North America.
The Touring is not the first to be made by Bayerische Motoren Werke, however. (And see how easy this is?) That honor went to a three-door hatchback version of the "02" series, and the vehicle was sold in Europe from 1971 through 1974. It was offered again in '87 and continues in Europe today as a five-door wagon in the 3-series.
As a 525i, the company says, the wagon may be more appropriate in size for the American market, and it is built on the same platform as the sedan. Like the sedan, too, the Touring is powered by a 2.5-liter in-line six that was new for '91.
It will, of course, be built in Germany, unlike a new model planned for 1995. That car, speculated to be a convertible or roadster version of the 3-Series, will roll off the line in Greer, S.C., site of the $300-million American assembly plant that was announced by BMW last week.
For now, though, the four-door wagon is the newest of the new, and its size means that it accommodates five adults and that it can carry as much as 51 cubic feet of cargo with the rear seat folded down. With the seat up, a removable window-shade arrangement covers the area, which offers about 16 cubic feet of space.
The seat itself is split 60-40 so that part of it can be folded and one or two people can still get back there next to a lengthened cargo bed. And, this being a BMW, the cargo floor is fancy, carpeted in velour and replete with recessed tie-downs.
The test car was painted a light metallic blue, and its lines were at least as pleasing as those of the sedan, although the wagon configuration impinges on aerodynamic figures.
All the same, the vehicle shares much with the sedan, including most of its dimensions, and from the windshield forward, the sedan and wagon are identical. The wagon, however, has a slightly higher roof, with built-in rails for the multifunction rack system that is available as an option.
At the rear, there is a one-piece tailgate -- but a tailgate with a difference. One of two separate latches opens the gate to its 90-degree upward position. The other opens only the rear window, allowing easy loading of smaller objects. In the gate's fully open position, two more latches let down a beautifully finished toolkit that includes wrenches, screwdrivers and such.
Like the hatch, the wagon's immense sunroof is unique and works in more than the usual tilt-or-slide ways. It consists of two panels, front and rear, and various pushes of its pair of operating buttons provide tip-up ventilation or open-air driving. The panels can be opened fully over either front or rear seat or can be slid together for a partial opening over both.
As for other body parts, the hood opens from the rear to expose a very civilized compartment under whose accoustically padded roof resides the 189-horsepower engine, mounted in north-south fashion and driving the rear wheels through a standard four-speed automatic transmission.
Performance is good if not spectacular, and zero-to-60 figures are in the 10.5-second range, with an electronically limited top speed of 128 miles an hour. The engine's 10:1 compression ratio means that the 21-gallon tank needs premium unleaded fuel, but the economy rating is reasonable at 17, city, and 25, highway.
Behind the four-spoked leather wheel, you face an instrument panel that is dominated by a 7,000-r.p.m. tach and a pleasantly fraudulent 160-m.p.h. speedometer. The wheel, of course, has an air bag in its hub, and antilock brakes are standard, just to round out the safety measures.
Heavy-duty leatherette is standard in the car, although the tester's real leather can be had at a price. The seats, like the rest of the Touring, are stiffly supportive in the Germanic mode, and other comforts are plentiful. Power equipment, for instance, extends to a telescoping wheel, and the driver information center will tell you everything but your anniversary.
The back windows go all the way down, a surprise in a vehicle of moderate size, and audiophiles will be more than happy with the 10-speaker sound system, which features tweeters in the front window posts and giant woofers in the rear ceiling.
Storage abounds, just to reinforce the notion that this is a utility vehicle that has been seriously considered by its designers. Among other things, the glovebox is a cavern, there are bins in the console, and a toll-change holder is mounted atop the map pocket in the driver's door.
Then let's see . . . yes, I did forget a couple of things.
You knew, of course, that the blue and white of the BMW emblem were Bavaria's official colors. But the emblem itself has its roots in BMW's history as a manufacturer of airplanes. It is an artist's conception of a spinning propeller viewed from the front.
And I'll give you a bonus that you are unlikely to find anywhere else. The next time somebody asks, you will know that the roof of the newest Bimmer has a load limit of 220 pounds.
