HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Monroe

BYLINE: By ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

 BODY:
"WE'RE a rural town trying to be suburban," said Kenneth S. Heitzke, First Selectman of the Town of Monroe, in the northern hills of Connecticut's Fairfield County.
"It's not an Easton or a Weston," said Gary L. Sippin, president of the Chamber of Commerce, whose grandfather came from Czarist Russia and bought a farm in Monroe in 1910. "It's middle-class." 
 Lois and Robert Mitchell, who "didn't want a rarefied atmosphere," bought a new colonial on two acres on Fan Hill Road in 1988, paying in the low $300,000's. "Being a fairly young family," said Mrs. Mitchell, who grew up in Darien, "we had to watch our pennies."
Her husband is with a law firm in Bridgeport, 20 minutes away.
What is now Monroe was a northern wilderness area of Stratford in the 1600's that became the separate parish of New Stratford in 1762; it became part of the town of Huntington in 1789. Settlers grew grains, corn and flax and raised cattle and sheep.
The town was incorporated in 1823 and named for the President at the time, James Monroe, basically because "it was the 'era of good feeling,' " according to Edward Nichols Coffey, the town historian. The villages of Stevenson, Stepney and East Village and the center district became part of the town in 1823 and still remain distinct sections. As street names attest, there were hat shops on Hattertown Road, a tannery on Old Tannery Road, a copper smelter near Copper Mill Brook and a scythe and axe blade factory on Hammertown Road. There were also some pick-and-shovel mines for bismuth, limestone and copper until the mid-1800's.
After the Civil War the town's economy lagged behind industrial centers like Bridgeport, local industry faded and people moved elsewhere for their livelihoods.
New Yorkers summered there in the late 1800's. By the early 1900's, Eastern European immigrants, among them several Jewish families, began buying abandoned farms, but it was not until the 40's that the population reached 1,728. By 1950, the town's first housing boom was under way and population continued to rise, getting another boost during the corporate shift to the suburbs in the 70's.
Today Monroe has mainly one- to three-acre zoning and no sewers. Available on a quarter acre along Cottage Street is a three-bedroom remodeled ranch for $124,000. In May, an 11-year-old, three-bedroom colonial on half an acre on Settlers Farm Road sold for $252,500. And a four-year-old, four-bedroom colonial on Georges Lane, with a heated pool and 28- by 12-foot kitchen, sold last week for $319,000.
At the high end is Hattertown Woods, a subdivision with custom-built contemporary colonials on 34 lots. . A nine-room house, with four bedrooms and three fireplaces, being built on two acres there now, is priced at $475,900.
The only two condominiums in town are the 319-unit Northbrook and the 160-unit Hills of Monroe. The latter also has 16 one-family homes.
"Monroe has a very good school system with a high level of services at a reasonable cost to the taxpayer," said Schools Superintendent Dr. Norman Michaud.
An average of 82 percent of seniors at Masuk High School went on to higher education in the last three years. The school offers eight college courses through the University of Connecticut and 48 extracurricular clubs. Enrollment, now 932, is expected to reach 1,100 within five years.
ABUTTING a nature trail is the 6-8 Chalk Hill Middle School, with 696 students. Seventh graders can take exploratory French and Spanish, and troubled seventh graders are offered mentoring. The school rewards 100 percent attendence and high honors with a year-end trip. This year, 100 qualified for a ride up the Connecticut River in the Tom Sawyer riverboat.
The oldest of the three elementary schools, built as a W.P.A. project in 1935, is Monroe Elementary School, with 392 children. The others are Fawn Hollow, with 678 pupils, and Stepney, with 516. The Monroe school was damaged by fire in 1982 and rebuilt. Today it has a wing for multi-handicapped youngsters. It also has 27 computers and a Gifted and Talented Dimensions program in Grades 4 and 5.
Fawn Hollow sets aside a classroom for Kindertime, a morning and afternoon supplementary kindergarten program for up to 21 children who spend the other half of their day in any of the local schools. It is run by the local Lakewood-Trumbull Y.M.C.A., which charges $180 a month.
Stepney has a schoolwide reading program in which students clocked-in more than 2 million minutes of reading in the just-ended school year.
There are several nursery schools in town run by local churches. The pre-k-8 Roman Catholic St. Jude School has 240 pupils and charges $1,570 a year for regional parishoners, $1,855 for others.
The 43,000-volume Monroe Public Library, in the municipal complex, is open six days a week and has four story hours a week for 3- and 4-year-olds.
Although Routes 111 and 25 are dotted with 10 commercial strips, residents do department-store shopping at the Trumbull or Danbury Fair malls and rely on neighboring towns for movies.
There is no shortage of restaurants. Among the dozen are Bailey's with a continental menu; the Smithy, whose specialty is seafood and sirloin; Roberto's and Sal's Home Pizza Restaurant, and Land Ding, offering Chinese food.Bill's Drive-in offers a bit of 50's nostalgia on Friday Classic Nights, 6 to 10 P.M., from mid-May to mid-October, when dozens of vintage cars, mainly 50's models, and families gather in its parking lot.
Popular yearly events are the Memorial Day Parade; Spirit Week, early inJune,, which features an art show and strawberry festival and the Firemen's Carnival next Wednesday through Saturday, with rides and food sponsored by the Monroe Volunteer Fire Department, one of the three units with 200 volunteers and six stations. A 75th-anniversary celebration will be held next month for the Stepney Volunteer Fire Company No. 1.
The town has a wealth of outdoor recreational facilities, but no beach. But on Memorial Day, the town opened Great Hollow Lake. It is a $900,000, 16-acre manmade lake with a sandy patch at the shore in the 309-acre William E. Wolfe Park. The park also offers, for a yearly or daily fee, eight tennis courts (four lighted) and an outdoor pool. There also are two basketball courts, four baseball diamonds, hiking trails and picnic areas.
Six Sunday evening concerts are being held at the park this summer, and the new gazebo on the Monroe Town Green will be the site of other events. On an acre of land in the park, starting Oct. 7, parents and children will build a playground, for which they are raising $83,000.
FROM high points of the 135-acre Webb Mountain Park, vistors may enjoy views of the Housatonic River and the hills of Oxford. The park has seven miles of hiking trails and two large stands of blue and white spruces. There also are trails, reblazed in 1976, in the 75-acre Lane's Mines Park. Adjacent to the park is the Chalk Hill Nature Trail, developed by the Junior Women's Club of Monroe in 1980. It has numbered posts corresponding to a guidebook available in the town library. Any resident can fish, canoe or go motorboating in Lake Zoar, a manmade lake created in the 1960's.
Residents can also use Penfield Beach in Fairfield for $75 a season or Seaside Beach in Bridgeport for $30 a season.
Whitney Farm Golf Course, once the site of stables used for wintering horses, now offers 18 holes, a clubhouse and restaurant in a stone barn. The 17-acre Cricker Brook Farms Riding Academy has 30 stalls and offers private and group riding lessons. There are also an indoor shooting range at Firearms Training, run by Tim McCarthy, and a variety of activities at the local Y.
Summing up the town's attractions, Stephan H. Price said "it has a lot of lakes, a lot of lawns, a lot of brooks, and is right between New York and Hartford." Mr Price, who runs Steve Price Tree Experts, moved to Monroe 17 years ago from Stratford and found the outdoor life it afforded just what he wanted.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 5 about Monroe, Conn., misstated the date of completion of the manmade Lake Zoar. It was completed in 1919.

Many of the children come wearing clothes of the era, and during recess they have sack races. For information, call (203) 261-8554.

HEADLINE: Peru Leader's Problems Ease Abroad, but Mount at Home

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, July 4

 BODY:
Two months after President Alberto K. Fujimori seized dictatorial powers in South America's most unstable nation, a promise to elect and install a new Congress within six months is rapidly easing Peru's international isolation.
 But Maoist guerrilla violence and rampant cocaine trafficking, two of the problems Mr. Fujimori cited to justify his suspension of Congress and the courts, have barely been touched by the April 5 crackdown. 
In June, Mr. Fujimori announced a date for elections and in return saw a thaw in the aid that was frozen when he seized power.
 In the same month, Shining Path guerrillas detonated more than a dozen car bombs, and the Government imposed a curfew on late-night and early-morning car traffic here.
 
50 Dead in Prison Fighting
 The bombing wave was the Maoists' response to the closing of their underground newspaper by the Government and its attack on guerrilla-controlled jail blocks here. In the prison fighting, 50 guerrillas and policemen died.
 Beyond the curfew, the President decreed that convicted terrorists would face life sentences and that minors aged 15 and over accused of terrorist acts would be prosecuted as adults. In addition, he called for a national debate on restoring the death penalty in Peru.
Hard-line measures gained popularity here as the Shining Path shifted the focus of its terror in the last two years from distant Andean villages to this coastal capital, home to a third of all Peruvians.
 Over the last 18 months, support among Lima residents for the execution of terrorists has risen from 47 percent to 67 percent, according to polls conducted by Apoyo, Peru's most respected polling organization.
 
Drug Flights Resume
 In the drug war, air shipments of coca, Peru's largest export, were disrupted for six months when the United States stationed two radar units, operated by 45 American technicians, in northern Peru. But both units were withdrawn when Peruvian jets on April 24 fired on an American reconnaissance plane and a crewman was killed.
 Another American died on June 20 when an American helicopter crashed near Santa Lucia, a drug-fighting base in a coca-growing jungle valley.
 In May, small planes loaded with semirefined cocaine resumed direct daytime flights from Peru's coca-growing areas to cocaine laboratories in Colombia. In June, the Peruvian Air Force took control of two municipal airstrips in Peru's "coca basket." But drug pilots took to landing on secret strips or on straight stretches of paved road.
 Despite the lack of progress in fighting drugs and terrorism, Mr. Fujimori is regaining some of the international support he lost in April.
 
November Elections Set
 Few Peruvians and virtually no foreign governments objected when the President closed Peruvian courts for a thorough overhaul. According to public opinion surveys, Peruvians overwhelmingly believed that judges sold verdicts and, caving in to death threats, released guerrillas from jail.
 The shuttering of the Congress, however, caused most Western countries to suspend economic aid to Peru and provoked Panama and Venezuela to suspend diplomatic relations with Peru.
 "We would welcome a fairly elected, constitutional Congress," a senior American official here said this week when asked what was the major obstacle to a return to normal relations between the United States and Peru.
 In June, President Fujimori took a major step in that direction by setting elections for a Congress for Nov. 22. The 80-member Congress will have powers to legislate, to investigate the executive branch, and to amend the Constitution.
 
Loans Are Unfrozen
 The United States, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank acknowledged the move by partly unfreezing loan and aid programs. As an incentive for more democratization, the United States has kept $150 million in aid frozen.
 Now debate revolves around the election process.
 Opposition politicians charge that Mr. Fujimori wants to bend election rules and gerrymander the nation into 80 election districts to guarantee a rubber-stamp assembly.
 In response, Mr. Fujimori says he refuses to return to business as usual: a Congress paralyzed by interparty squabbles and dominated by many of the same faces who have dominated politics here since the 1960's.
 "As a statesman, he is a failure," Fernando Belaunde Terry, a former President of Peru, said of Mr. Fujimori. "Cambio 90 is nothing," he added dismissively of the President's political party.
 
Fujimori's Nightmare
 One fear haunts Mr. Fujimori as he juggles competing desires for an internationally acceptable election and for a Congress that he can control until his mandate expires in July 1995.
 An opposition-controlled Congress could exact vengeance on the President by removing him from office on charges of violating Peru's 1979 Constitution.
 "It's unlikely, but it's Fujimori's nightmare," said Alfredo Torres Guzman, president of Apoyo.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
In New Haven, a Struggle for Recovery

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THOUGH blessed with some of the state's best legitimate theaters and restaurants, a felicitous green flanked by vintage New England churches and the prestige of Yale University, New Haven is still plagued by persistent crime, blighted neighborhoods and crushing taxes.
 Some stalled real estate projects are recovering from the recession and others are being born, but progress is spotty and tentative, and the city, like many others in Connecticut, is rattled by the results of a 1991 property revaluation. 
We hadn't had one since 1978," said Gerald Sachs, the assessor. "Now that there are state penalties for delays, we've had to do one, and the average assessment is more than two and half times higher. In some cases, it quadrupled."
 The office vacancy rate, says John Nussbaum of CB Commercial real estate brokers, is 30 percent. "New Haven has been unable to attract companies from outside," he said, "so local businesses hopscotch from old buildings to newer ones, doing nothing to increase the absorption of space and creating a wasteland of empty old buildings."
 "We have terrible problems that we are trying to address," said Sal Brancati, the city's Director of Economic Development. "We take each situation individually, and we consider tax abatements according to certain criteria. Manufacturing companies and companies with at least 100 employes come first."
 Macy's is a noteworthy example. Its downtown New Haven store was one of 10 nationwide scheduled to close, until city officials offered a package of incentives.
 The incentives include $12 million grants from the city and state for improving the deteriorated 1,285-space parking garage; a city tax freeze at the 1991 level that will save $100,000 a year and a reduced energy bill from the United Illuminating Company.
 The store will be a key element in a proposed 1.3-million-square-foot shopping mall that would extend from the Macy's site on Church Street to a platform over Route 34.
 Five anchor stores and 4,000 parking spaces are planned by the Taubman Company of Bloomfield, Mich., which has entered into an agreement with the city to build the mall at an estimated cost of up to $635 million. A 1998 opening is anticipated.
 The complex would be financed under recent legislation that lets the state issue bonds based on a project's ability to raise a like amount in sales tax revenues over a 25-year period. "We hope to have state financing approval by the end of July," said Mr. Brancati, noting that there are other obstacles.
 Standing between Macy's and Route 34 is the vacant, deteriorating Malley's department store, bought by Mordecai Litkis, a New York developer who has been unable to recycle it. It is one of several private properties in the mall's path that must be acquired by negotiation or condemnation. In addition, the city must get air rights over Route 34 from the state, and hold public hearings on the project.
 "A groundswell of negative public opinion could kill it," said Mr. Brancati, adding that some opposition has surfaced but that "once people understand what the mall means to the city I believe they will get on board."
 ANOTHER kind of criticism was leveled at a new factory begun by U.S. Repeating Arms Company, formerly Winchester Arms Company, in a city where random gunplay recently led to the shooting of a child on a school bus. The company responded by saying it produces only sport rifles and shotguns, not handguns.
 In New Haven since the 1850's, Winchester planned to move but scrapped the idea when city, state and Federal grants and tax abatements and subsidies from the OIin Corporation, United Illuminating and Yale University were offered. Ground was broken in June on the 350,000-square-foot factory at the edge of the Yale campus. An opening of the first phase is scheduled for next summer.
 Last month, a $30 million mixed-use project called Audubon Court was rescued from receivership by the Knights of Columbus for $6.3 million cash. Mr. Nussbaum arranged the sale, including a 100,000-square-foot office building, almost 20,000 square feet of retail space and a 290-car garage.
 "The Knights' financial stability will be an important factor for prospective tenants," said Robert Motley, CB Commercial's leasing agent. Office rents are around $19 a foot, down from $24. Retail rents have not been determined.
 The project's 28 unsold residential condominium units out of a total of 61 were not part of the deal and are being sold for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by the Beazley Real Estate Company. Prices range from $139,500 for one bedroom with one bath, to $159,900 for 2 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths and fireplace. All units are air-conditioned, have separate dining rooms, all appliances, and are ranged around a handsomely landscaped private court.
 Surrounded by an enclave of art schools, galleries and performing arts organizations, Audubon Court was completed in 1988 by the Lawrence Development Company of Bronxville, N.Y., on land owned by the New Haven Arts Council. It fills a once-vacant lot cleared during urban renewal.
 Condominiums and commercial space were being absorbed slowly through 1989, until the major tenant and mortgage holder, Connecticut Bank and Trust, was taken over by Fleet Bank and moved out. The project was then foreclosed.
 A few blocks from Audubon Court is Century Tower on Church Street, designed by Cesar Pelli and opened two years ago. Its 282,000 square feet are more than half leased, but at rentals far lower than anticipated.
 GOVERNMENT CENTER overlooking the green is another competitor, begun more than 10 years ago and built around the preserved facade of the 19th-century City Hall designed by Henry Austin. The developer is David Chase of Hartford, who started the project in 1981. It was later reduced by about 100,000 square feet to 425,000 square feet because of financial problems and it was completed in 1990. Last month, United Illuminating leased half the space.
 As for other projects, the state is paying $23 million to rebuild the faulty 2,400 space garage over the Coliseum sports arena, and Yale has contributed $10 million toward the redevelopment of Ninth Square, a downtown commercial block. But real estate professionals worry that high taxes and heavy expenditures for social problems will keep prospective tenants at bay and drive existing ones elsewhere. "A few have gone already, but it's not an exodus yet," said Mr. Motley.

HEADLINE: On the Street: Drug Gangs Thrive as Arsenals Expand

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
ON a blustery blue-sky day in New Haven recently, a 21-year-old drug boss stood on a street corner and chewed on a meatball sub while praying that it wouldn't rain.
"I guess it really doesn't matter," said the man, as he licked tomato sauce from his fingers. "I've been in this business long enough to know that if people want dope they'll find a way to buy it even if the snow is six feet high." 
 Soon after, a woman with glassy eyes walked up from a nearby house and asked the man's partner for some p-dope, or heroin, that came in a small yellow packet with the words "mad dog" stamped on the front; it sold for $20 and the transaction took about five seconds.
The drug boss said that he employed 17 lieutenants who sold drugs in key spots of the city and that they made up to $15,000 a day. "We only net around $500 apiece of that though," said the man, adding that he had been arrested several times for selling drugs and was currently out on bond on a murder charge.
Because the corner where he stood was considered one of the profitable drug outlets in the city, he said, his gang armed themselves with handguns and kept an arsenal that included two M-16's and an AK-47, just in case things got too hot. He said he got the assault weapons from a man who exchanged them for drugs and $450.
 
Better Organized, Better Armed
 "We pioneered this corner," said the man who was interviewed days before a 6-year-old boy was critically wounded by a gun shot after the schoolbus in which he rode was caught in a gang-related shootout on nearby Frank Street.
"And nobody's going to take it away from us."
As the drug trade maintains a stranglehold in city neighborhoods, street gangs that profit from the sale of narcotics have become better organized and better armed. Federal and local law enforcement officials said that over the last 10 years, many gangs have survived and prospered and some have crossed the threshold into organized criminal groups that have expanded their operations statewide.
The surge in gang activities has spurred an epidemic of gun violence in urban neighborhoods over the last couple of years. Recent shootings include incidents in New Haven where two children were wounded by stray bullets and a gang shootout in a Meriden housing project where children and their parents were gathered.
In response to the increase of drug gang violence in Connecticut, Federal agents are working closely with state and local police to curtail gang activity by surveilling and arresting more gang leaders and their weapon suppliers.
While the Connecticut General Assembly last week was debating gun-control measures intended to stem the flow of guns into the hands of minors, the agents said they were taking advantage of Federal gun control laws passed during the mid-1980's that have expanded their jurisdiction and given them more leverage to arrest violent criminals.
Convictions under the Federal statutes are also likely to result in harsher prison terms for offenders, which may greatly reduce the incidents of gang violence and discourage teen-agers from joining gangs, the officials said.
Though the bulk of the drug business is made up of small-time dealers who act on their own, law enforcement officials said, since the mid-1980's more and more ethnic gangs in Connecticut have emerged, like Los Solidos, based in Hartford; the Rats and the Cats, two Jamaican gangs based in Bridgeport, and the Latin Kings, whose members have surfaced throughout the state.
Other new gangs include those styled after or tied to California organizations, the Crips and the Bloods, which are both under Federal investigation for the looting of 3,000 firearms during the riots in Los Angeles in April.
While the ethnic gangs may require an oath of loyalty, police officials characterize the nonsectarian gangs as loosely organized business organizations that are not allied to any particular leadership beyond the local level. Their common thread, officials said, are drugs and violence.
 
Market 'Made Them Richer'
 "The drug market hasn't made these guys rich and powerful yet, but it's made them richer and given them ready cash to purchase better weapons and gain more influence," said Jack Killorin, the director of public information for the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Washington, D.C., who headed the Hartford office during the late 1980's. "And their way of doing business is quite terrible. Remember, these are the people that gave us the drive-by shooting."
Though there are no precise statistics on the number of gang members or gang-related crimes in the state, police officials said that they were tracing an increasing number of assaults and homicides to gang members. While most of the offenses are drug related, they said, a growing number of incidents involve conflicts between members of the same gang. The police attributed the rise in drug-gang membership to the decline in the economy and an increasing array of social and psychological problems faced by young people growing up in urban areas.
"The system has collapsed," said Allan MacDonald, the resident agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in New Haven. "Nowadays it just makes good economic sense to deal drugs."
Mr. MacDonald said many drug gangs obtained weapons through drug users who stole the guns from homeowners, drug shops or firearms factories, or through "straw purchasers," people with clean criminal records who buy guns for themselves, then resell them to dealers.
As a result of investigations by the local police and by Federal firearms agents, Charles Hubbard, a New Haven resident, was sentenced in January to 17 months in Federal prison for reselling 130 legally bought guns that were later sold to gangsters.
And earlier this year, agents arrested Robert and Robin Carroll, the owners of a Fairfield gun shop. The couple has since been indicted on charges of knowingly selling 450 guns to a straw purchaser, Felix DeValle, and are awaiting trial. Mr. DeValle has been in prison since his arrest and is awaiting sentencing.
 
Career Criminals
 Gun-control laws passed in the 1980's have also given Federal agents more jurisdiction to arrest gang leaders, Mr. MacDonald said. Last year, agents tracked down and arrested Willie Carter Jr., a reputed leader of the Jungle Boys drug gang in New Haven. In January prosecutors used a Federal law aimed at career criminals to convict Mr. Williams, whose fingerprint was found on a gun confiscated by the agents during the arrest. Mr. Williams is currently serving a 19 1/2-year prison term.
Two weeks ago, a team of 150 law enforcement officials, which included agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration along with state and local police, raided a housing project in New Haven and arrested 14 members of the Jungle Boys and charged them with conspiring to sell cocaine and violating Federal firearms regulations.
 
Undercover Purchases
 During the raid, agents confiscated six firearms, including a sawed-off shotgun and a 12-gauge pump shotgun. The investigation leading to the arrest began in February and included undercover purchases of narcotics and electronics surveillance. If convicted of the conspiracy charges, each defendant faces a minimum of 5 to 40 years in prison.
Among their most urgent concerns, said police officials, are the Latin Kings, which began as a Hispanic fraternal organization in Chicago in the 1940's and resurfaced in Connecticut's prison system about two years ago. Since then, the police statewide have attributed dozens of assaults and several killings in prison and on Connecticut streets to the gang, which they said was tightly organized and out to recruit teen-agers and children.
 
Monthly Meetings of Task Force
 Since January, a task force of more than 50 local, state and Federal law enforcement agents has met monthly to compare information they have gathered on the gang whose membership is estimated to be 2,000 to 8,000.
In New Haven, three teen-agers were arrested and charged with assault on June 12 after their gunfire hit a school bus the day before wounding a six-year-old passenger, Cesar Sandoval, who remained in fair condition last week at Yale-New Haven Hospital. The police said the suspects were tied to the Latin Kings.
The incident followed a shootout in late April when a faction of the Latin Kings sprayed automatic weapons fire at another faction at a Meriden housing project.
 
'Serious Public Safety Concern'
 "It's become impossible to predict where this violence will erupt," said the Chief State's Attorney and a task force spokesman, Richard Palmer. "Which is why their activities have become such a serious public safety concern."
Last month, Ruperto Vincente, 39 years old, who police said led the shootout, was arrested in New York City after evading the police for three weeks. A former auto mechanic, Mr. Vincente has been charged with three counts of conspiracy to commit assault and three counts of first-degree assault.
Mr. Vincente's arrest warrant, which was made public following his arraignment, stated that the shooting appeared to be ordered by a high-ranking member of the organization, Pedro Millan. A former Connecticut resident, Mr. Millan told Latin King members in a telephone call from a Federal prison in New York State that he had been seeking to retaliate against the leader of the Latin Kings, Jose Garcia, who wanted to break from the organization. Mr. Millan has been charged with conspiracy in connection with the shooting.
 
Newsletters From Gang Members
 At the Narcotics and Vice Division of the Bridgeport Police Department on a recent day, Detective Ralph Villegas flipped through separate newsletters published by members of the Latin Kings and a black prison gang called The Nation, which were obtained by officials of the state's correctional system. Both letters read like promotional material for benevolent fraternal organizations.
But Mr. Villegas, whose office is filled with beaded necklaces from gang members and photographs of guns confiscated in narcotics raids, said the materials were merely propaganda distributed by violent criminals.
"They are an embarrassment to the hard-working Hispanic person," he said about the Latin Kings. He added that a member of the gang recently assaulted a Bridgeport police officer by throwing a rock in his face and that at least four homicides in Bridgeport were linked to the gang.
In comments about the dangers police officers face when confronted by gang members, he said: "Remember the old rule about how you never shoot a cop? Well, with these guys that rule doesn't apply."
 
Reputation and Appearance of Arms
 Mr. Villegas, who also teaches at the Police Academy in Bridgeport and briefs suburban police on the characteristics of gangs, said that most gang members carried conventional firearms that were based on reputation and appearance rather than quality. One exception is the Rats and the Tats, who have strong ties to the Shower Posse, an international criminal organization.
"They would never want to be caught with a .22 handgun," he said. "They love high-powered automatics and they're good at using them."
Of the hundreds of illegal guns flooding Bridgeport neighborhoods, Mr. Villegas said, the police may only be able to confiscate about 20 percent. Most guns are found by beat police or through drug raids, he said. Unlike the 1970's when a drug bust required fewer officers and less firepower, today's raids require high-speed dynamics with the assumption that the suspect is armed and dangerous.
"It's like working in a pressure cooker," said Sgt. Joseph Convertito, who supervises narcotics raids for the division.
 
Six to Seven Raids a Week
 Narcotics police now average around six to seven raids a week and must respond to all drug cases, from the occasional dealer trying to get money to buy sneakers to the violent career criminal. The followup paperwork involved in each raid can take hours, the sergeant said, noting that while the Police Department tried to adjust to severe layoffs and cutbacks, the drug and gun cases continued to swell.
In some instances, he said, the police come up empty-handed after a raid because dealers often hide drugs or guns outside or in a car. "It's cat-and-mouse all the way," he said. The police must also consider public safety by scheduling raids when few people are outside. At a recent early morning raid in a Bridgeport housing project, the police confiscated crack paraphernalia and residue and arrested two women and four men. Among those arrested was a man Sergeant Convertito said he had picked up two years ago on a gun charge.
"You're too early," the man said to the sergeant, adding that the drug shipment would not be there for three more hours.
 
One of Many Problems
 Standing outside the apartment while detectives handcuffed and led suspects to a white police van, Sergeant Convertito said the raid had been one of three planned that day. Neighbors who watched the raid said that while the occupants had been a nuisance, they were simply one of many problems relating to drugs that residents in the projects faced.
The city's drug and gun problem continues to worsen, said the sergeant, and he saw no relief in sight. He added that he found it hard to believe Federal Government studies reporting a decline in drug use in the United States.
"I'd love to know where they got their statistics," he said. "Maybe Iowa."
Other law enforcement officials agreed that the drug trade had become a well-entrenched element of American society with its own set of values and priorities.
 
'A Bunch of Amateurs
 In a separate interview following the accidental shooting of Cesar Sandoval, the 21-year-old drug boss in New Haven said the incident disgusted and angered him.
"Those guys that did that were nothing but a bunch of amateurs who didn't know how to shoot straight," he said. "If you want to get somebody, then you should find your target, then shoot to kill."
Bridgeport Police Chief Thomas Sweeney said fresh ideas were needed to combat the drug war and that he was tired of the arguments, both pro and con, concerning the issue of gun control. He said one of the biggest obstacles in solving the drug violence was the complacency of suburban residents who believed they were immune from the travails of the cities.
"We've got a great big problem on our hands in Connecticut, and everywhere else in this country," he said. "And it's about time we all woke up and stopped dreaming."

HEADLINE: Another Season of Music and Picnicking

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE Summer Music program at Harkness Park in Waterford started with a series of four chamber music concerts in 1984, and it has expanded every year since, becoming the largest classical musicl festival in Connecticut.
This year, Summer Music's ninth, the program will open July 18 with the pianist Leon Fleisher and the Connecticut Orchestra, and will close Aug. 22 with music from Broadway and fireworks by the Grucci family. 
 In between will be Ray Charles and the Raylettes Aug. 13, banjo player Buddy Wachter July 30, and the Pointer Sisters July 21, in addition to several classical performances.
And for the first time, Summer Music Inc., which has offices in New London, will offer two weeks of Arts Camp for children 4 to 14 years old, featuring instruction in theater, dance, puppetry and, of course, music.
"We've been modest in what we've added each year, so we don't become more than the public can handle," said Cynde Iverson, one of Summer Music's founders.
The strategy seems to have worked because, even during the recession of the last couple of years, Summer Music has grown, Ms. Iverson said.
 
Indoor and Outdoor Seating
 Summer Music was started in the fall of 1983 by Ms. Iverson, the principal bassoonist with the Rhode Island Philharmonic and the executive director of Summer Music, and her husband, Peter Sacco, the music director of Summer Music and the assistant conductor of the New Haven Symphony.
Concertgoers can choose from seats under the tent, or less costly seats on the lawn. Picnic meals are sold on concert nights.
Among the artists who have appeared at Harkness are Midori, Wynton Marsalis, Dizzy Gillespie and Jean-Pierre Rampal.
"Almost from the start, Summer Music took off in a direction we really didn't anticipate," Mr. Sacco said. "After the first season it was apparent we had something too large for a string quartet, because it loses the intimacy that the string quartet demands."
This year, in fact, Summer Music will phase out the chamber music performances, Mr. Sacco said, and the money that was used for that purpose will be directed to the Arts Camp. And the Harkness Festival Orchestra that started it all is now known as the Connecticut Orchestra.
"We're attempting, by renaming it, to give it a sense of permanence, and to show that it attempts to draw the best musicians not just from southeastern Connecticut, but from all over the state," Mr. Sacco said.
 
A Permanent Center Proposed
 Much of the success of the music series, Ms. Iverson and Mr. Sacco agree, is due to the beauty of the surroundings. The Harkness Mansion recalls the elegance of an era that passed early in this century, and the gently rolling grounds that slope down to Long Island Sound, where a tent is pitched for the music each summer, provide a perfect setting.
In fact, Summer Music is discussing with the state Department of Environmental Protection, which oversees the park, to build a permanent center for Summer Music.
"We're looking into the feasibility," said Richard K. Clifford, chief of the department's Bureau of Parks and Recreation. But, he cautioned, because of the state's budget problems any permanent complex is years away.
Still, Mr. Clifford said, the department appreciates the attention Summer Music brings to one of its more beautiful parks.
"The concert series has brought a lot of people to Harkness who have never been there before," Mr. Clifford said. "There's no question it's brought us a lot of recognition."
John Ostrout, executive director of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, said Summer Music had been an "exemplary" arts organization that, in competing for grants every year, had always won financing.
"Our money is considered development money, to get an idea started," Mr. Ostrout said. "They've been able to come up with new ideas every year, to continually expand their program, so they've been successful with their grant applications."
 
Arts Camp Nearly Full
 The new idea this year is the Arts Camp, and the camp's managing director, Andrea Leiser, said of 125 spots, nearly all were full.
"Summer Music being the parent organization gives Arts Camp a lot of credibility," Ms. Leiser said. "And, we've got a terrific faculty."
Among the instructors are Carol Glynn, director of the O'Neill Theater Center's Project Earth; L'Ana Burton, founder of the Connecticut College Children's Dance Center, and Wall Matthews, composer in residence at Connecticut College.
About 20 percent of the students are from low-income families, who will attend on scholarship money from the Palmer Foundation in New London. Arts Camp is also seeking corporate donations to sponsor other children.
"Because of the cutbacks at so many schools, people feel there's a hole in their children's education, and they're looking for a way to fill it," Ms. Leiser said. "The arts are seen as sort of peripheral in the schools, unlike math and science -- and sports."
The Summer Music concert series continues to be the core of the program, however, with an additional concert in the schedule this year, bringing to 10 the number of performances scheduled.
Among them will be the Empire Brass Aug. 6; a July 25 program of Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries" and Holst's "Planets"; an all-Richard Strauss program Aug. 1 with the world premiere of a newly discovered arrangement of Strauss's last orchestral song; an all-Haydn evening Aug. 15, and the violin virtuoso Cho-Liang Lin on Aug. 8.
Ms. Iverson said when Summer Music started, she was warned that people would not give up their summer weekend plans in order to travel to Waterford and listen to classical music. Some warned her she would be lucky to have 200 people attend the events. The first appearance by the Tokyo String Quartet, though, drew 2,000.
"That was our first inkling that we'd hit upon something no one had expected," Ms. Iverson said. "Today, we get people calling from as far away as Ohio and Kansas who know they're going to be traveling in the area and want one of our brochures. And locally, people who formerly went to Tanglewood are staying home with us."
Ms. Iverson said that last year about 30,000 people attended Summer Music performances.
 
Budget Burgeons
 Mr. Sacco said that about half of Summer Music's annual budget, which has grown from $60,000 the first year to $750,000 today, came from ticket sales, with prices ranging from $10 to $30 depending on the seat and the show. The rest of the budget comes from foundations, government grants and the sponsorship of more than a dozen corporations.
Mr. Sacco said the outdoor setting of the concerts had its advantages, and its drawbacks.
"It enhances the experience in the best of circumstances, and distracts under the worst," he said.
"But in the middle of January in Carnegie Hall, you can hear candy wrappers rustling, and people sniffling or talking," Mr. Sacco said. "Being outside, listening to music under the stars, can be the most encompassing, most thoroughly satisfying experience of any we can offer in the symphonic world."

HEADLINE: A Rush of Candidates Courts Restive Voters

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
IN Connecticut's Second Congressional District the Republicans usually come up with one candidate to take on Representative Sam Gejdenson, the six-term incumbent Democrat. This year, though, there are three from the G.O.P. seeking the nomination, including a lawyer from Norwich whom Mr. Gejdenson defeated four years ago, Glenn T. Carberry. .
Across the state, in the Fifth Congressional District, five Democrats have filed candidacy papers to challenge the one-term Republican incumbent, Gary Franks. 
 While there may be more incumbents declining to seek re-election this year, there are more candidates than anyone can remember who are challenging state and Federal officeholders or who are trying to fill their shoes. Candidates say it has made it more difficult to get attention, attract contributions or line up delegate support for the party nominating conventions this month.
The campaign finance clerk for the Secretary of the State's office, Florence R. Cutting, said she had about 175 candidates for state and local offices, almost a third more than at this point in the election process two years ago.
"We're getting a lot of outsiders, people who have never run before," said Mrs. Cutting, referring to it as the "Ross Perot syndrome."
"And it's still early; I don't know what we'll do in September if this keeps up," she said.
For the first time in memory, this will be the first election with a third major party, which explains part of the barrage of candidates. A Connecticut Party, which was formed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., and which has the top line on the ballot this year, has already nominated almost a dozen candidates to various state offices, and promises to be a force in almost all legislative districts.
Anita L. Mielert, a former Democrat from Simsbury who was the first nominee of A Connecticut Party for a seat in the State House of Representatives in the 16th District, said she had met a lot of people working on Mr. Weicker's campaign in 1990.
"We kept in touch, talked about the issues, and when it came near the time to announce they offered me their support," Mrs. Mielert said. "The two parties we have need shaking up. There's so much garbage going on in the name of politics as usual."
Morton J. Tenzer, a professor of political science at the University of Connecticut and a longtime observer of Connecticut politics, said dissatisfaction was the reason for the glut of candidates.
"The public is unhappy with the state of society, with the economy, and with politics in general," Dr. Tenzer said. "But there is nothing cohesive to form around, so people are fractionalizing all over the place."
Lisl Standen, a Democrat from New Milford who was born in Austria, worked for the United Nations for 25 years and has held a string of city and state appointive posts, is running for office for the first time in her 76 years, seeking the seat vacated by State Representative Oskar Rogg, a Republican.
"We have to take a stand, we have to be honest -- democracy is not a spectator sport," Ms. Standen said. "I always thought I would never get into politics because of my horrible accent. But I'm getting impatient."
Not everyone believes the situation has changed all that dramatically, despite the numbers at the Secretary of State's office. Lynn H. Taborsak of Danbury, a Democrat who abandoned her secure seat in the State House of Representatives to run for Congress against Mr. Franks, said that while there were five Democrats seeking the nomination, only two were serious enough to get the 20 percent needed to force a primary. And two years ago, there were seven Republicans seeking the seat when United States Representative John G. Rowland gave it up to run, unsuccessfully, for governor.
"Sure it's harder to raise money this year, but that's not because of H. Ross Perot or anything else," Ms. Taborsak said. "It's because of the economy, and the fact that people don't have the money to give."
Still, state party leaders acknowledge that they are watching the races coalesce. Democratic State Chairman Edward L. Marcus said the number of candidates might be good for the system, provided there were no fringe candidates like David Duke emerging. He said he expected that most of the neophytes would peak early and do poorly come election time, but he pointed out that in some districts, a third-party candidate grabbing 2 or 3 percent of the vote could affect the outcome.
"Everyone figures, 'why not be a State Senator?' But I don't think it's going to be that easy," Mr. Marcus said. "Still, we have to respond to each race as it develops. It makes for a very active political season between now and November. I'm not sure there will be the traditional hiatus this summer."
Republican State Chairman Richard Foley Jr. said that people contemplating independent campaigns in this Presidential election year faced a tougher task than they thought because they "don't realize where they'll be on the ballot."
With A Connecticut Party on the first line, Republicans on the second, Democrats on the third, and Libertarians, New Alliance and Ross Perot somewhere beneath them, Mr. Foley said, "Independents could end up on line 8 or line 9, and at that point you're about at the voter's right shoelace."
For the most part, though, the scramble is on within the state's three major parties. Three Republicans announced their candidacies for the United States Senate seat held by the two-term incumbent Democrat, Christopher J. Dodd, and although one, Robert Jaekle of Stratford, has dropped out, two others -- Christopher Burnham of Stamford and Brook Johnson of Greenwich -- remain in the race.
And there was talk of several others being interested in the job, most prominently United States Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Democrat in the Sixth Congressional District, who decided against running because of the time and money required for a Senate campaign.
Incumbents often interpret the rush of candidates differently.
"It just shows us the Republican party is in disarray, and can't decide who their candidate will be," said Mr. Dodd's spokeswoman, Julie Rosson Small. "It wouldn't surprise us to have another couple of candidates show up before things are over. Senator Dodd is just going to continue being a senator, and stick to his original game plan." Mrs. Small declined to say what the game plan might entail.
Some of the incumbents say the ebb and flow of political fortunes can quickly change, so they are scrutinizing their opposition. Mr. Gejdenson said he was worried about his seat when the President cut money for the Seawolf, the billion-dollar submarines built at Electric Boat in Groton, which is part of his district. A few weeks ago Congress approved financing for one of the submarines, however.
"Until the Seawolf fight was won, it looked like a much tougher year," Mr. Gejdenson said. "Things will change a dozen times between now and the election, but they're looking pretty good right now."
One of his three announced opponents, Mr. Carberry, challenged Mr. Gejdenson's assessment. He said he had put off making a decision on another campaign until only a few months ago, but so many people had approached him and told him about the growing dissatisfaction with incumbents, that he decided to try.
"It's a good sign that there are so many candidates for state and Federal office," Mr. Carberry said. "It's a sign people do want to get involved, and do believe in the future of government. The other option, in times like this, is voter apathy, and then nobody wins."
Others see the number of candidates as an opportunity, particularly if they are in an opposing party.
"The more Democrats who are in the race, the more difficult it will be to get the nomination, and win a primary, and the more money they're going to have to spend just to get the nomination," said Howard W. Waltzman, a spokesman for Representative Franks. "It undermines anyone's ability to focus on the Republican until after Sept. 5th, if there's a primary, and in this case we're sure there will be."
Even some candidates who consider themselves well entrenched find that they are facing challenges for the first time in years.
"There is a lack of leadership, a lack of sense of direction, and a genuine feeling that we're entering into a really new era, with all that's happening in the world," Dr. Tenzer said. "So we're floating around, trying to get our bearings. And, in the meantime, the whole political system is under attack."
Mr. Foley, the state G.O.P. chief, said that having more than two candidates in a race makes democracy difficult to work. Mr. Weicker, for instance, "came in when 60 percent of the people were for somebody else."
Some people point to coalition governments in Europe as evidence that third-party candidates are not the death of a political system, Mr. Foley said, but in Italy the 51st government in 47 years is now being formed.
"In some of these three-way races it would be possible to take office with 35 percent of the vote," Mr. Foley said. "Where I come from, 35 percent ain't a winner. And the loser is the general public, because you have too many narrow, parochial interests."

HEADLINE: A Candidate's Core Curriculum

BYLINE: By Paul Burka; Paul Burka is executive editor of Texas Monthly magazine.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
In a film version of H. G. Wells's novel "The Time Machine," the 19th century time traveler takes three books with him on his final return to a distant future where primitive people live without books or knowledge. The reader is left to guess what those books might be.
Ross Perot is in much the same situation. A few weeks ago, he announced that he would devote more time to studying issues. What, one wonders, is his reading list? What new knowledge will he take into his future? 
 It would be simple enough to assemble a list of influential public policy books for Mr. Perot to read: Kevin Phillips's "The Politics of Rich and Poor," Robert Reich's "The Work of Nations," William Greider's "Who Will Tell the People" and so on. But are the lessons of policy books really what Mr. Perot most needs to know? He may not be fluent in the specifics of issues, but he has shown an intuitive understanding of the nation's fundamental problems.
He has shown less understanding, however, of the eternal truths of politics: the uses and limits of power, the interaction of policy and personality, the relationship between credibility and trust, the difference between right and wrong. The more we learn about Ross Perot, the more it is apparent that these are the kinds of issues that will ultimately determine whether he can be elected President.
Here is a reading list that would enhance his appreciation of politics.
1. "All the King's Men," a novel by Robert Penn Warren (1946). Moral: The ends do not justify the means.
Gov. Willie Stark practices what Machiavelli preached. He wants to do good, but when doing good turns out not to be so easy after all, he resorts to corrupting his friends and blackmailing his enemies. "It takes dirt to grow grass," Willie says. To persuade an idealist to work for him, Willie argues that goodness can be made only from badness. But two can play this game. When the idealist's illusions are shattered, he puts Willie's philosophy to work by assassinating him.
2. "Antigone," a play by Sophocles (circa 442 B.C.). Beware of hubris, the sin of overweening pride.
Ross Perot is not afflicted with self-doubt. Neither was Creon, ruler of Thebes. "The man the state has put in place must have obedient hearing to his least command, when it is right and even when it's not," he proclaims. Sure enough, Creon has issued a wrong command: the corpse of a traitor must be left unburied. But Antigone, sister of the traitor and fiance of Creon's son, defies him, and Creon is determined to ignore all pleas for clemency. The inevitable consequences of his arrogance are the suicides of Antigone, his son and his wife. "The gods must have their due," the chorus intones. "Great words by men of pride bring greater blows upon them."
3. "The Best and the Brightest," by David Halberstam (1972). Experts don't know everything.
The men John F. Kennedy brought to Washington were the best and brightest -- "brilliant men," Mr. Halberstam writes, "men of force, not cruel, not harsh, but men who acted rather than waited." Does this sound like anybody we know? Ross Perot presents himself as a can-do man of action, and he relies heavily on bringing in elite experts to brief him.
But this combination of expertise and love of action is exactly what led America into the quagmire of Vietnam. The experts failed to factor public opinion into their neat theories. Even Lyndon B. Johnson, who ought to have known better, was so awed by the best and the brightest that he ignored the warning of his friend Sam Rayburn, the House Speaker: "I'd feel a whole lot better about them if just one of them had run for sheriff once."
4. "The Butter Battle Book," by Dr. Seuss (1984). Don't try to destroy people who disagree with you.
Yooks eat bread with the butter side up, but, "In every Zook house and in every Zook town, every Zook eats his bread with the butter side down!" This difference is enough to make each side want to annihilate the other, and to build ever more sophisticated weapons to do so.
As a cold war parable, this children's book is flawed, because the differences between the Yooks and Zooks were not so trivial. As a general indictment of feuding, however, the book has a message for a potential President with a penchant for vengefulness: Be sure what you're fighting over really matters.
5. "Character: America's Search for Leadership," by Gail Sheehy (1988). Character is a legitimate political issue.
Character is destiny, Ms. Sheehy believes, and these profiles of six Presidential candidates and Ronald Reagan try to prove it. The book would drive someone like Ross Perot nuts with its street-corner psychology but at least it explains the media's current fascination with a candidate's past: "We need the cold slap of insight to wake us up from the smoothly contrived images projected by highly paid media experts," Ms. Sheehy writes.
The best argument for character-cop journalism is the prescience of the fourth profile: "If George Bush cannot bear to offend people, if he hasn't got the outer strength to pursue a lonely course, if he feels wholly comfortable only when being liked, might he not, as a president, become paralyzed?"
6. "The Company," a novel by John Ehrlichman (1976). Political spying is a two-edged sword.
Ross Perot has a long history of hiring investigators to spy on people, including President Bush. As President, could he resist using the F.B.I., the C.I.A., the I.R.S. and other Federal agencies against his political enemies? This novel by a convicted Watergate figure might make him think twice about it.
The President and the Director of Central Intelligence are locked in a power struggle filled with snooping, surveillance and intrigue -- and the loser is the President. "The people are wholly fictional," Mr. Ehrlichman writes in an author's note. "But the forces -- the stresses, pressures, fears and passions -- that motivate the characters are real."
7. "In Defence of Politics," by Bernard Crick (1962). Politics is compromise.
College students will recognize this one. It's mandatory reading for Poly Sci 101 almost everywhere. The author, a British political scientist, describes politics as a process of discussion -- in other words, compromise. It produces progress out of dialogue and preserves both freedom and social order by bringing everybody to the bargaining table.
"There are two great enemies of politics," Mr. Crick writes: "indifference to human suffering and the passionate quest for certainty in matters which are essentially political."
8. "Lady Chatterly's Lover," a novel by D. H. Lawrence (1928). Lighten up, Ross.
There are two sides to everything -- even adultery.
9. "Lying: Moral Choice in Public and Private Life," by Sissela Bok (1978). Tell the truth.
Why does Mr. Perot waffle, backpedal and even deny when confronted with controversial positions and statements he has made in the past? He ought to realize by now that he is far more likely to lose the Presidency by lying than by telling the truth.
Mrs. Bok, who has taught ethics at Harvard and Stanford, argues for truthfulness. "A society whose members were unable to distinguish truthful messages from deceptive ones would collapse," she writes.
10. "The Politics of Upheaval," volume three of "The Age of Roosevelt," by Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr. (1960). How to be a successful President in a time of crisis.
Start by being committed to people, not ideology. F.D.R.'s "basic principle was not to sacrifice human beings to logic," Mr. Schlesinger writes. "He had no philosophy save experiment, which was a technique; constitutionalism, which was a procedure; and humanity, which was a faith." Then, conduct yourself in a way that sets an example for the country. If Ross Perot is elected President, he could ask for no better judgment from future historians than the valedictory Mr. Roosevelt receives at the book's conclusion: He made it possible for people to believe again in Government's capacity to solve problems of economic stability and social justice.

HEADLINE: Starting Climb to the Top at the Bottom Rung

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your front-page article about the carpentry program at the Youth Build school in Boston (June 8), one of many around the country that try to rehabilitate and prepare young inner-city males for a job market, is in a way edifying. Manual arts training is a good idea since it's about drills for coordinating mind and hands, which is good therapy; and it has commercial value. 
 Unfortunately, carpentry presents a big problem professionally for these youngsters, who're unequipped to persevere in a market that's unsteady and in which there are hurdles for white males and walls for blacks.
I've worked on large home-building construction sites as subcontractor for laborer help, and of the 100 or so carpenters, only one or two were black, mostly middle-aged men. The young white boys who hammered away had been taught the craft as pre-teen-agers and teen-agers by family members. Blacks started much later and had to wait years to be admitted into this closed shop rife with nepotism.
The urban males wouldn't have the strength to endure the trial. Thus teaching them carpentry for earning a living is as unrealistic as teaching calculus in inner-city schools to students shattered by domestic instability and who get no intellectual stimulation at home. This therefore makes these males dream when they think they could begin their own businesses as carpenters.
However, teaching them "menial" crafts makes much more sense, and is practical. I took advantage of America's disdain for menial labor and broke into major construction, providing a needed service, in which I had no competition. I built a nice business doing dirty work in cleaning, mopping and buffing.
These labors are close to these males, many having had these experiences working in fast-food restaurants. Teaching them these crafts formally would be clever. This is what I've begun to do.
Jobs in these skills are far more secure than those in carpentry; the opportunities far greater. An ambitious inner-city male could conceivably become an entrepreneur. Around the country, the market for building crafts and maintenance crafts, which includes such specialties as mopping, sanding, finishing and general cleaning, is in the billions of dollars.
The urban entrepreneur who knows his "lowly" craft well may even get to wear a suit because consumers and manufacturers need consultants. One major home improvement retailer greatly increased its sales when it hired professional craftsmen to answer customer queries and to put questions to manufacturers about the claims they make in their products. I'm writing a series of booklets on floor care and repair.
When the well-intentioned social missionaries to the ghetto, and the academics and foundations who advise them, shed their prejudices and contempt for the servant and service classes, they will see that those males they have committed themselves to serve will do better being simple than being middle class, with all its pretensions.
 
NORMAN DARDEN
New York, June 19, 1992

HEADLINE: Putting Young Farmers Back on the Land for Everyone's Good

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Quiet Exodus by the Young Leaves the Future of Family Farms in Doubt" (news article, June 9) focuses needed attention on the urgent problem of the shrinking family farm base. However, your tone of inevitability, reflecting a sadly routine analysis of agriculture, is shortsighted. 
 Our Government is struggling to create new living-wage jobs and seems clueless about how to correct the ravages of unemployment, overcrowding and disenfranchisement in our cities. Yet, at the same time, its longstanding farm policy is the primary cause of economic and social devastation in our rural areas -- fewer farmers, fewer people on the land, fewer independent food processors and other agribusinesses, and fewer Main Street jobs and businesses. The continuing depopulation of rural America and loss of farming and agribusiness jobs can only add to the strain on our beleaguered cities.
However, this decadeslong trend is not inevitable. Government policies helped created these circumstances, and dramatic changes in Government policies can remedy them. To reverse the trend, Federal farm tax, commodity program and credit policies that subsidize land consolidation and encourage intensive use of energy and agricultural chemicals must be changed. The large taxpayer investment in agriculture research and development should also be reoriented to increase rural economic opportunity and improve the quality of rural life.
A growing number of farmers are becoming involved in what is known as sustainable agriculture. These are smaller-scale, family farmers who are developing farming methods that are not only economically profitable but also more ecologically sound, often with little or no yield reductions.
Interest among young people in getting into farming is high, as demonstrated by standing-room-only attendance at a recent beginning farmer workshop in Faribault, Minn. At that meeting, LaVonne Nicholai, director of the Minnesota Rural Finance Authority, which administers the state's beginning farmer loan program, stated:
"Countries around the world are looking at the family farm as a model for agriculture and are trying to learn how to use private and public money to rebuild rural economies to insure food for future generations."
In addition to programs in several states, key beginning farmer legislation is expected to pass Congress in the next months. The agricultural credit improvement bill would return the Government's Farmers Home Administration to its original mission of providing modest amounts of supervised credit to small and beginning farmers unable to obtain credit elsewhere.
The bill would allow the agency to make down payment loans to young farmers and would establish a Federal-state beginning farmer partnership program. With more than half of all farmland in the hands of farmers who will likely retire by the year 2000, passage of this critical legislation could not be more timely.
We must have a new policy of repopulating the land and increasing rural economic opportunity. Small and moderate-scale farms, with more environmentally sound farmers, will play a key role in agriculture's future. Such a trend reversal would go a long way toward solving not only our rural woes but some of our urban ones as well.
 
MARTA CLEAVELAND
Media Coordinator
Land Stewardship Project
Marine on St. Croix, Minn., June 21, 1992

HEADLINE: I.M.F. and Russia Reach Accord On Loan Aid and Spending Limits

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 5

 BODY:
The Russian Government and the International Monetary Fund announced today that they had reached a lending agreement that gives President Boris N. Yeltsin the endorsement he had sought from the West for his economic policies, but also commits him to cut back on Government spending just when the deficit is rising sharply.
The I.M.F. had been under pressure for weeks from the Bush Administration to soften its usual requirements so that an agreement with the Yeltsin Government could be announced before a meeting of leaders of the seven industrial powers that begins in Munich on Monday. Mr. Yeltsin is to join President Bush and the other leaders in Munich on Wednesday. 
 I.M.F. officials said in Washington 10 days ago that they planned to scale back their original plans for a multibillion-dollar package that would require more sweeping reforms from Moscow, and that they would instead seek a simplified agreement.
The formal announcement of the loan agreement today came in a one-paragraph statement signed by Acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar and the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus. The statement spoke vaguely of "new measures" that will "strengthen the economic reforms and the stabilization program of the Russian Federation Government."
The agreement appears to commit the Government to anti-spending policies just when Parliament is pressing for greater outlays to subsidize state-owned enterprises that have been hurt by a steep recession and by the transition to a market economy. As a result of these pressures, the budget deficit has risen sharply in recent weeks.
A Government official said that to reach the agreement, the Russian Government and the I.M.F. had delayed talks on the issues of foreign debt and the I.M.F.'s desire for Russia to keep raising energy prices. The energy issue is one of the toughest issues in the talks because higher fuel prices would raise the cost of living.
Specifically, the agreement commits the Government and Russia's Central Bank to maintain a ceiling on loans and adhere to spending guidelines, said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist and a senior adviser to the Government. Mr. Sachs took part in the I.M.F. talks last week and returned to the United States on Saturday.
"Mr. Gaidar is aware that if all the parliamentary pressures were met, that would put Russia into hyper-inflation and the Government is committed to resist this," Mr. Sachs said in a telephone interview.
I.M.F. officials did not comment on the plan, beyond acknowledging that Russia will qualify for a $1 billion I.M.F. loan, once the agreement is ratified by the I.M.F. board in August.
Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Camdessus had worked out the general terms for the $1 billion loan when they met in Washington two weeks ago. Although an I.M.F. team had been trying to negotiate the details for the past week, success came only after Mr. Camdessus flew here from Washington and met with Mr. Yeltsin on Saturday.
A broader agreement, to be negotiated in two stages over the next six months, would release a total of $24 billion in foreign assistance, including $4.5 billion from the I.M.F. and the World Bank and $11 billion in direct credits from Western governments.
Just before his meeting with Mr. Camdessus, Mr. Yeltsin told a group of journalists that the I.M.F. would have to ease up on its standard requirements because "Russia is unique and its reform is unique."
The I.M.F., however, eased up only slightly, accepting, for example, a monthly inflation rate of 7 percent to 9 percent instead of the 3 percent limit it had once sought. The current inflation rate in Russia is about 14 percent monthly, according to the Government.
The I.M.F.'s proposals mainly seek to strengthen the ruble so that it is more readily convertible into hard currencies. A stable ruble, in turn, helps to attract foreign investment and encourages foreign trade, which are two other goals being sought by the fund.
The I.M.F. has also pressed for what it describes as a stable ruble zone. Under this requirement, all the members of the Commonwealth of Independent States using the ruble as their currency must agree to a single monetary policy, preferably one controlled by the Russian Central Bank.
Today's agreement sidestepped this issue by stating that Russia and the other states will take steps to define the ruble zone and work out procedures to be followed by those republics that want to switch from the ruble to their own currencies.
