HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ACCORDS BRING NEW FEARS ON ARMS DISPOSAL

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Federal and private experts say the recent East-West breakthroughs in nuclear arms reduction are replacing one danger with a wide range of new risks as the world's two nuclear superpowers prepare to retire nearly 40,000 warheads.
Mutual annihilation is no longer a threat. The new risks are emerging because arms reductions call for weapons systems to be disabled -- by demolishing missile silos, for instance -- and do not, as is often supposed, require nuclear warheads to be destroyed. 
 In practice, warheads and their firing mechanisms will be dismantled, and their nuclear cores either stored, pending future disposition, or recycled into new weapons.
 
New Uses for SS-18
 Even Russia's fearsome SS-18 missiles, whose retirement crowned the recent accords between President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin, are exempt from actual ruin. The 12-story behemoths are simply to be taken out of military service and stored, cannibalized or used for firing payloads into space.
Few decisions have been made about the final disposition of nuclear weapons and their parts, including hundreds of tons of bomb materials like plutonium 239 and uranium 235. The full retirement operation will take more than a decade and cost tens of billions of dollars.
On Thursday, President Bush announced that the United States had completed its withdrawal of all shorter-range land and naval nuclear arms based outside the country, returning them to American soil.
 
Terror and Proliferation
 Future challenges are expected to include keeping nuclear gear secure from terrorists and thieves -- storing it, possibly for millennia without environmental damage, imparting discipline to generations of nuclear custodians, and commercially recycling some arms materials without contributing to the spread of bombs.
Two perceived dangers, especially in the former Soviet Union, are clandestine sales to black marketeers and atomic theft by terrorists.
The Russian military's system for transporting nuclear material "is not up to anything we would call Western standards, or even remotely adequate," Robert Gallucci, the State Department official dealing with Russian nuclear matters, recently warned. "If this situation doesn't get fixed, in the long term it will be an area in which we will have real worries about materials disappearing."
The biggest fear is bomb recycling. Nothing in the arms reduction accords prevents reuse. The United States pioneered this practice by taking warheads from the Pershing 2 missile, retired from Europe, and manufacturing them into weapons for bombers. Those arms, not covered by Mr. Bush's recent weapons withdrawals, are now back in Europe.
Some American experts worry that the Russians might do likewise on an expanded scale. Others dismiss the idea as extremely improbable.
Frank J. Gaffney Jr., an official in the Reagan Pentagon who how directs the Washington-based Center for Security Policy, belittled the recent accords as "cosmetic" and charged that they could allow Russia to build a covert arsenal.
That, he said in an interview, "could pose greater dangers" than the cold war did, suggesting that the Russian military might one day launch a pre-emptive strike on the West or engage in political blackmail with "large numbers of nuclear weapons they weren't suppose to have."
 
The Cuts
Some Will Be Real, Others Recycled
 The nuclear arms race peaked in the mid-1980's with the Soviet Union having roughly 33,000 weapons and the United States 24,000, according to Robert S. Norris, a senior analyst with the Natural Resources Defense Council and co-author of the Nuclear Weapons Databook.
Of these 57,000 warheads, arms control treaties and unilateral actions have marked about 37,000 for retirement. Other weapons have been dropped for military reasons. The total number to be retained is estimated at 12,000, including 5,000 shorter-range ones. These reduced arsenals are to be more or less evenly divided between East and West.
Reductions began in 1987 with the signing of the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty, which cut 2,150 Soviet warheads and 550 American ones, including those atop the West German-based Pershing 2. Its thermonuclear warhead, code-named W-85, had an explosive force five times that of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima.
Beginning in May 1990, an unknown number of W-85's were quietly repackaged into gravity bombs, Dr. Norris said. The recycled arms are now carried primarily by Air Force F-16's based in Europe.
The pace of disarmament picked up last July with the signing in Moscow of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start. It calls on each side to shed 4,500 long-range warheads. Here too, some American warheads are already being recycled. The W-76 from the Trident 1 missile, carried aboard older submarines, is being refitted for use atop Trident 2 missiles on the newest submarines.
After the unsuccessful Soviet coup attempt last August, Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised to cut, respectively, 5,500 and 11,000 shorter-range nuclear arms. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney soon afterward said that the bombs could easily be recycled. In the past, he noted, "we've remanufactured that material into new systems and into new warheads."
The Washington accord signed last month by Mr. Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin earmarks for retirement 5,000 American and 3,500 Russian long-range arms. Like earlier treaties, it has no provisions for warhead destruction, upsetting some members of Congress who worry about stability in the former Soviet lands.
 
The Philosophy
Cold War or Not, Distrust Lingers
 Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, criticized the Bush Administration during a June 25 hearing of the Foreign Relations Committee, calling nuclear cuts without verified destruction "a bad trade" and suggesting that Moscow's warheads could fall into unfriendly hands.
"There's going to be an overwhelming urge," he said, "to sell those warheads, to disseminate those warheads, to folks who are ready to pay a whole lot of money."
Administration witnesses strongly defended the treaties. "To verify the destruction of warheads is conceivable," said Linton Brooks, the chief American negotiator in the latter part of the Start talks. But Mr. Brooks said this would be too intrusive because East-West reciprocity would force Washington to curtail its activities, including warhead recycling.
Such remanufacturing of bombs, he went on, avoided new production costs. And even if existing arms were verifiably destroyed, he said, Washington could never be sure that Moscow was not secretly producing new ones.
"So we would spend enormous costs and not necessarily close off any doors," Mr. Brooks concluded.
Private groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Federation of American Scientists, disagree, arguing that in theory it is relatively easy to verify both warhead destruction and the cutoff of nuclear production.
Senator Biden noted such inspection ideas and accused the Administration of "old thinking."
On Thursday, the Foreign Relations Committee voted to recommend negotiations with Russia over verification methods that would cover nuclear warheads, in addition to delivery systems.
 
The Withdrawals
Guarded Convoys To Twilight Zone
 American weapons destined for retirement are stockpiled at military depots around the country awaiting disassembly. When openings arise, the weapons are put on unmarked, heavily armored tractor-trailers that ply the nation's highways in convoys of one to five trucks, flanked by armed guards in escort vehicles with darkened side and rear windows.
The bomb-carrying fleet now has 51 trucks and will soon add 7 trailers and 15 tractors for "the expanded workload," said Ben McCarty, an Energy Department spokesman.
The warheads are hauled back to a sprawling Energy Department plant in the Texas Panhandle known as Pantex, where they were first assembled. In case of an accident, Pantex's work areas, awash in reinforced concrete, can withstand usual explosions.
A main disassembly job is to gently remove the high explosives that surround the grapefruit-sized ball of plutonium at the heart of a bomb. The violent implosion of a plutonium "pit," as it is known, is the spark behind most atomic and thermonuclear blasts.
Pantex in the 1980's took apart 1,000 or so bombs a year for retirement and inspection. The plant's rate in 1991 jumped to 1,600 and is expected to reach 1,800 this year, said Tom Walton, a Pantex spokesman. By 1993, it should be 2,000. The aim is to maintain that pace for the rest of the century.
The Federal Government is pondering what to do with the plutonium pits, considered the weapons' deadliest part. Plutonium has a radioactive half-life of 25,000 years and has been called the most toxic substance on earth, since minuscule grains can cause cancer. The interim plan is to store the pits at Pantex.
The plant has 60 concrete-and-steel bunkers. During the cold war they held new bombs awaiting shipment. Now 18 are earmarked for pit storage. These bunkers already hold 2,900 pits and can accommodate about 1,400 more, Mr. Walton said. The pits are held in steel drums arranged in a single layer.
With space fast running out, the Energy Department is considering setting aside more bunkers for storage, or packing more pits into designated areas by stacking drums atop one another. That would raise the radiation dose to workers, so the agency is studying whether to replace humans with robot forklifts controlled by radio transmissions from a nearby truck.
Texas state officials are upset by such plans, charging that Pantex is fast becoming an unlicensed plutonium dump. In response, the agency says it has a good safety record and is taking every precaution at Pantex for interim storage, including assessing the environmental impact.
The Energy Department also says it is spending $110 million to beef up plant security, including roads and surveillance gear, stronger buildings and storage bunkers, alarms and radiation detectors, and new concrete guard towers with bulletproof windows.
A thousand miles eastward, in the rolling hills of Tennessee, a similar challenge is unfolding for the nation's prime handlers of uranium 235, a bomb material also to be retired, in quantities five times greater than plutonium. Both plutonium and uranium are used in H-bombs. Uranium from retired weapons is to be hauled to the Energy Department's Y-12 plant at Oak Ridge. Once the king of uranium enrichment, the 600-acre plant is now increasingly being turned to storage, as at Pantex.
"At some level of storage," a terse Y-12 statement said, "the plant might have to construct or modify additional, secure facilities."
 
The Russians
A Huge Bunker In Siberia
 Similar withdrawal and dismantling work is now under way in Russia, though few details of the operation are known publicly. Western experts tend to see Russian transportation as weak. Britain in February offered Russia 20 armored trucks for bomb removal and the United States offered 25 armored rail cars. The Russians accepted the British offer but eventually turned down the American one, saying the rail cars would be too difficult to adapt.
As for storage, Russian military officials say that they have lost depots to other former Soviet republics and that their remaining areas are quickly filling. They have asked that a promised $400 million in American aid for nuclear dismantling go to help build a huge bunker for retired weapons fuels.
The proposed center, bigger than 10 football fields, would be located near a gargantuan plant in Siberia that has five nuclear reactors and a center for plutonium-pit fabrication.
The Bush Administration is studying the bunker idea. It is also preparing to send 450 sets of armored blankets to help protect Russian nuclear weapons containers during shipment and 1,000 pieces of special clothing and equipment for any nuclear accidents.
It has ordered the manufacture, in this country, of 10,000 special canisters for the transport and storage of Russian arms material.
 
The Debate
Future Menace Or Megawatts?
 In East and West, the ultimate fate of hundreds of tons of plutonium 239 and uranium 235 is largely undecided. At the heart of an intensifying debate is whether such materials should be treated as dangerous waste or great treasures.
Private analysts say factions in both military establishments would like to retain either whole weapons or plutonium pits and other key parts, so that large arsenals can be rapidly reconstructed.
But Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee late last month that there was little to fear from a covert Russian force. "I do not see a particular danger," General Powell said, noting that some of Moscow's systems like missile silos would be destroyed and that in any case the United States had a nuclear retaliatory force "that cannot be taken out."
A different group of analysts sees bomb materials as an economic bonanza because of their value as nuclear fuel. One pound of fissioned plutonium is equal to 10 billion watts of thermal energy, an amount able to generate electrical power for millions of people. The problem is that burning plutonium 239 in a nuclear reactor is not easy, requiring special fuel processing. Even then, it remains attractive for bomb construction, creating new temptations for nuclear theft.
In contrast, uranium 235 is easily diluted into a reactor fuel that cannot readily be used in a bomb, though some analysts question whether such conversion would be economic. And the present manufacturers of nuclear fuel would undoubtedly fight such competition. Nonetheless, the option is being carefully studied.
Energy Secretary James D. Watkins in January told reporters that the idea had generated "a lot of excitement."
A less sanguine view, espoused by some nuclear arms scientists in East and West, is that the weapons materials are inherently dangerous and should be destroyed. Russian scientists at Arzamas 16, the country's main nuclear design center, have proposed burning up plutonium in underground nuclear blasts.
A different destruction plan would poison bomb fuel with radioactive waste and store it in high-level nuclear dumps, which have yet to be built and have engendered widespread public opposition.
A final proposal by Theodore B. Taylor, a former weapons designer at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, would have big rockets loft plutonium and other bomb fuels into the sun. Sun incineration has been discussed for years as a way of disposing of hazardous waste. One problem is that it is hardly cheap -- the bill could run into billions of dollars.
"It's dangerous stuff," Dr. Taylor said of the nuclear material. "If you can get rid of it at some reasonable cost, that seems like the best thing to do."

HEADLINE: WARSAW WELCOMES BUSH AS HE STOPS ON WAY TO SUMMIT

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 5

 BODY:
Flying thousands of miles to get a balm for his domestic political pains, President Bush arrived in Munich today for a seven-nation economic conference after receiving a thunderous ovation in a Warsaw square where he promised that "America wants Poland to succeed and to prosper."
"Hello Warsaw! Hello Poland!" Mr. Bush shouted cheerfully from a stage erected in Castle Square. He appeared with President Lech Walesa after a mass said for the re-internment of the remains of Ignace Jan Paderewski, the Polish musician and statesman whose dying wish in New York 51 years ago was to be buried in a free Poland. 
 "Today, Poland stands transformed," said Mr. Bush, who visited Warsaw in part to alleviate worries in Eastern Europe that the United States is too heavily focused on helping Russia to pay attention to its concerns.
"Your bold economic reforms have earned the world's admiration and support -- and what's more, they're working," Mr. Bush said, glossing over Poland's economic and political problems, which have worsened considerably since he last visited, in 1989.
 
'God Bless America'
 President Walesa drew loud cheers when he said in English, a language he has rarely spoken in public, "God bless America and God bless President Bush."
Mr. Bush came to Munich for a three-day meeting of the leaders of the seven biggest industrial democracies: the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada. Tonight he dined with President Francois Mitterrand, hoping to smooth over rough spots in French-American relationships that have formed over the United States role in European security and other issues.
White House advisers had hoped that Mr. Bush, whose approval ratings on foreign policy have plummeted with his overall popularity, would get a hero's welcome in Poland, where he was making his third visit. Indeed, the crowd, which seemed to number in the tens of thousands, cheered lustily and some waved American flags when Mr. Bush appeared.
 
'Ross for Boss'
 But there were reminders of Mr. Bush's political problems. Toward the front of the crowd, a half-dozen Americans unfurled banners that read "Ross for Boss," a reference to Ross Perot, and "Bush: The Environmental President. NOT!"
The President brought with him a plan to bolster Poland's economy by converting the $1 billion fund used to stabilize the zloty on world currency markets into loans and direct grants to stimulate investment in Poland's flagging private sector.
But even Mr. Bush's aides conceded that the plan, which would require Poland to resolve its problems with the International Monetary Fund as well as the agreement of the 16 other nations that contributed, was only a modest gesture. The sluggish performance of the United States economy prevents Mr. Bush from providing more ambitious economic assistance.
Mr. Bush's trip to Poland, to Munich, and on to Helsinki later this week for a meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, was one of a series of events that the White House hoped would focus voters' attention on foreign affairs, Mr. Bush's strong suit.
But so far, that has not worked noticeably. Mr. Bush's political strategists, and Mr. Bush himself, were alarmed by the lack of any marked increase in his political standing after the signing of a sweeping arms-reduction agreement with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. Mr. Bush's embarrassing visit to Panama and his difficulties at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro ended up hurting the President more than they helped.
Although Mr. Bush is trying to keep the focus on foreign affairs and away from the 1992 Presidential campaign, he seemed eager to send word back home that he was working on domestic problems even while he was overseas.
On Monday, Mr. Bush plans to meet with Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, who helped deliver that state to Mr. Bush in the 1988 election and the 1992 Republican primary, and executives of the BMW automobile company, which plans to build a plant in South Carolina near the Greenville-Spartanburg Airport.
In Warsaw, Mr. Bush did not let slip a chance to remind his audience -- and those listening back home -- of the millions of Polish-American voters. "In a strange new world called America," he said, "in the stockyards of Chicago, in the steelworks of Cleveland, in a thousand towns thousands of miles from this land they love, Poles worked and worshiped and built a better life."
 
A Changed Aura in Poland
 Mr. Bush sought to evoke the revolutionary euphoria of 1989, when Poland's voters handed the Communist Party a stunning electoral defeat. But the Poland he visited today was markedly different, with Mr. Walesa's Solidarity movement long since divided and redivided.
Prime Minister Waldemar Pawlak, who met with Mr. Bush today, handed in his resignation last week after a month of failed attempts to form a Government. The only reason Mr. Pawlek was there was that President Walesa has refused to accept his resignation. Hanna Suchocka, a lawyer, is front-runner to be Poland's fifth Prime Minister in three years, but her ascendancy is by no means assured.
Mr. Walesa told Mr. Bush, "The people of Warsaw love you," and "Only the Pope has attracted so many."
But there were signs that the enthusiasm of the crowd had dimmed from Mr. Bush's last triumphal visit, at the height of revolutionary fervor in Poland. "This was once an active opposition," said Jadwiga Kutnik, a 46-year-old lab technician. "Now people have other things to do. This is vacation time."
Others, however, were enthusiastic.
Lydia Pendrak, 37, an architect, said: "I made a special trip to see him. There are moments that one simply feels one should be in a certain place at a certain time. President Bush represents the friendship of America and Poland, and I think that's a very important thing."

HEADLINE: Welfare in the New York Area

 BODY:
States in the New York region have historically paid higher benefits than other parts of the country, but the value of Aid to Families with Dependent Children benefits plus food stamps has declined faster in New York and New Jersey over the past 20 years than in the rest of the nation because these states did less to counter inflation.
Benefits in New York City -- $9,672 a year for a mother with two children as of January -- buy one-third less than in 1972, as against one-fourth less for the nation as a whole. 
 As a result, New York's status as a generous supporter of poor people has eroded. Several states pay higher benefits, including California, Vermont and Connecticut, which pays $10,344 a year. And New Jersey's benefits, at $8,292 a year for a family of three, are little more than the national average.
With the recession, the number of people in the region on welfare has climbed sharply over the last three years. In New York City, where 1 in 10 people is on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the number of families receiving benefits has risen to 258,000 this year, from the 228,000 in 1989 that was a 20-year low. An additional 138,000 families receive it in the rest of New York State, while 54,000 families in Connecticut and 130,000 in New Jersey receive it.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has promised not to balance the state budget by slashing welfare benefits and has emphasized the need to help women get off welfare through education and training.
New Jersey is more aggressively trying to change the behavior of welfare recipients by cutting benefits for women who have more children and allowing women who marry to keep more of their welfare grant. Connecticut considered similar proposals, but the Legislature did not adopt them.

HEADLINE: Santiago Journal;
Scrubbing The Skies Over Chile

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
On a clear day during the Southern Hemisphere winter, the towering Andes mountains glisten with a blanket of snow. But from here they are for the most part invisible, hidden behind a thick brown layer of smog that fills this city of more than four million people, making Santiago among the most polluted cities in the world.
This is the time of year when most Chileans would like to avoid the capital. Eyes sting. Bronchial illness surges. And, according to doctors, the march of cancer in the population increases. 
 If smog were the only pollution problem in Chile, it might seem less daunting. But it is only the most visible of numerous woes from the country's southern forests to its northern desert.
Chile has some of the world's dirtiest factories, belching sulfur dioxide, arsenic and heavy metals into the atmosphere. Many of its rivers are heavily contaminated with industrial and human waste and its natural resources, experts say, are over-exploited.
As the two-year-old democratic Government of President Patricio Aylwin enters the first stages of addressing the pollution problems, many critics are pointing fingers at the former military Government as the main cause of the problem.
 
The Free-Market Fever

They say that during the 17-year military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, economic growth, based on the free-market model of the University of Chicago economist Milton Friedman, was pushed at all costs, creating a political atmosphere in which concern for the environment did not exist.
It is open to debate whether the pollution is the result of Friedman economics or Friedman economics misapplied. What is undeniable is that Chile, which under General Pinochet,emerged as the most robust and stable economy in Latin America, now faces the dilemma of choosing between the daunting cost of cleaning up -- imperiling economic growth in the process -- and the daunting cost of not cleaning up.
"For years, we could not even talk about the problems of pollution or environment," said Francisco Gonzalez, who is in charge of environment at La Ventana copper smelter just north of Chile's famous beach resort, Vina del Mar. "We could lose our jobs. And if a report was made warning of pollution, it was marked secret and put in a drawer. Produce, produce, produce -- that was the politics of the day."
The Ventana smelter, which supports the livelihood of small copper-mining operations around the country, is a classic example of the Government's problems. With its antiquated technology, the plant has spewed noxious sulphur dioxide into the surrounding area for years. Not only have its workers been exposed to dangerously high levels of toxic gases and shown a growing rate of illness, but farmers and peasants living miles from the smelter have complained of health problems, lost productivity in the fields and livestock illnesses believed to be linked to the pollution.
Though the Government installed equipment to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions by 30 percent, it will cost $240 million to modernize the smelter and bring it up to current health standards, an investment the plant is not likely to make quickly.
"We will never clean up this area," said Carlos R. Risopatron, director of a project to monitor the Ventana pollution. "You cannot talk about decontamination. The best we can hope for is not to let the situation get worse."
Almost 400 hundred miles north along the Huasco River, farmers growing olives found that production fell precipitously, and investigators blame carbon dioxide emissions and particulate from a plant that makes iron pellets upriver.
Yet another 200 miles north near Chanaral, runoff from a large copper mine has created a vast encrustation of white sediment, including heavy metals, that flows into the ocean, a deposit that few think will ever be cleaned up.
And at Chile's largest copper smelter, Chuquicamata, researchers have found it belching unusually large amounts of arsenic, causing health problems among hundreds of workers.
Nowhere is the pollution problem worse than in Santiago. Environmental specialists consider Santiago the most polluted city in Latin America after Mexico City.
Though for years the city has had intense smog problems, experts here say the the military dictatorship and world preoccupation with the lack of democracy here muffled public debate and concern about pollution.
Experts give the Aylwin Government passing grades for its actions to date, but add that it is only now casting about for a comprehensive plan.
Santiago's pollution results mainly from the city's fleet of 11,000 diesel buses, most of which are old and burn fuel inefficiently, and from the fact that the city has more than 400 miles of unpaved roads, where vast amounts of dust are stirred up.
During the Pinochet years, the bus system was totally deregulated, and the Government permitted the import of thousands of used vehicles. By contrast, Sao Paolo, with close to 20 million inhabitants, four times the size of Santiago, has 7,000 buses.
The intensity of the pollution here is also a geological and atmospherical problem. Like Mexico City, Santiago lies among mountains and is subject to thermal inversions that do not permit polluted air to escape during the winter months.
This winter has been one of the worst. In mid-June, pollution alerts were issued for eight straight days.
 
Water Is Foul, Too
 A far greater concern, according to experts, is the pollution of the city's water supplies -- a problem brought home when cholera broke out here a year ago. The city of Santiago has no water treatment plants, and thus almost all home and industrial waste water is dumped into rivers, which in turn run through much of the country's farm land.
Two years ago officials discovered that almost all of the country's vegetables were being grown through irrigation with contaminated water.
To this day there is no regulation of toxic waste. The Government is only now trying to conduct a survey of such waste, which it hopes to complete by the end of next year.
"We have no idea of where and how much industrial toxic waste is being dumped," said Eduardo Arriagada, president of the Special Commission for Decontaminating the Metropolitan Region. "It could be anywhere. We assume a lot goes into rivers but we just don't know."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Environmental specialists consider Santiago one of the most polluted cities in Latin America. The pollution results mainly from the city's fleet of 11,000 diesel buses, most of which are old and burn fuel inefficiently. (Santiago Llanquin for The New York Times)
